description:
Great restaurant for a nice night out with friends. Make reservations,  though there may be seating at the bar. Plenty of options for plates to share with friends, as well as mains for yourself. Their list of carefully crafted cocktails, varietals of wine,  solid selection of beers, and non-alcoholic options ensure all members of your dining party are happily watered as they await the delicious food to come.

Appetizers/shared items:
Shishito peppers: perfectly blistered with that tasty finishing maldon salt evenly salting the peppers (even the ones on the bottom). A must-have for sharing with the table. 

Sourdough batard with whipped duck fat: Can't go wrong with fresh, hot bread with a savory duck fat spread on top

Poutine: Well balanced gravy (not too salty! Yay!),  cheese, fries ratio. Glad that we chose to share this between the 5 of us, giving each of us just enough to enjoy the dish without stuffing ourselves.

Black Pepper Cavatelli: Again, great for sharing so that none of us felt guilty for filling up on pasta prior to our mains

Mains:
Duck breast: I ordered mine medium rare and it came out wonderful. Very tender and flavorful, paired very well with the vegetables (loved the turnips)  and fruit (plum).

Dessert:
Black Pepper Pound Cake: Don't wrinkle your nose at this if you're unsure about the foie gras chantilly. The depth brought out by the extra fat  and subtle flavor of the foie gras goes well with the pound cake (I appreciate that it wasn't overly sweet), contrasting with the light plum sorbet. 

Matcha Cheesecake: This matcha cheesecake was DELICIOUS, but the angostura bitters sorbet was what hit this dessert out of the park.
author: Gloria S.

description:
Crammed and Unpleasant environment with hit appetizers and miss entrees..  Poutine with cheese curd was amazing and the Shisito pepper was really good. However the entrees sucked. shrimp salad was underwhelming and missing a lot of flavors. My rock fish was over salted and was overcooked. 

The worst was the open kitchen. Some chefs should really not being working in open kitchen. One guy shouts the order out so loud that it startled me every time and it's quite frequently.
author: Helen L.

description:
I heard someone rave about Salt House, so once I saw it I thought it was worth checking out.  It was an okay restaurant, but I couldn't see why it got such high exaltations.

The service was great and the atmosphere is nice.  Industrial and rustic, exactly my vibe. The food is some type of Canadian...fusion?  So I can see why it started off as a promising experience.

DINNER
Cheese plate- humbolt fog cheese with cinnamon walnuts and champagne? Jello
Duck fat potatoes- tasty but salty
Sea bass

The food was good, however after dinner the both of us had serious stomach issues.  Extremely bloated and unsettled, but nothing along the lines of food poisoning.  Dinner itself was nice, yet not too memorable, but the after effects were unpleasant.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Really nice restaurant in downtown San Francisco. They serve modern American fare with some other options (like tacos and ramen). Pretty generic when it comes to the food and nothing really all that extraordinary.

The bread they give as a starter is pretty basic, nothing special. I had the pork ramen and was just average. The broth wasn`t too flavorful (don`t expect anything that`s been stewed 24 - 48 hours in a real ramen place). The pork was just a fried piece of pork and the noodles weren`t cooked all the way through. People mainly come here for the location and ambiance.
author: Taylor Z.

description: Had a very good dinner with great service. Went here for a business dinner upon the recommendation of one of my local colleagues. The food was very good, however, if you are a meat and potatoes type person and not into the eclectic, then this is not the place for you. That said, they do have a good wine selection, and some very yummy cocktails. I had the smoked salmon ravioli, and it was delicious. We also enjoyed several appetizers before hand and all were good.
author: Ann J.

description:
Came with two other coworkers with reservations for lunch. They only take RSVP so make sure you reserve if you want to eat here. Beat the lunch rush around 11:30am and got seated right away. I liked my drink a lot - patty's cooler; tasty and refreshing. I ordered appetizers to share and we even got complimentary bread, which was delicious. 

- Shishito peppers: must get, super tasty and 1/8 is spicy ;)
- poutine fried: loved the unique flavoring with the kick of hot sauce. This was heavy but so delicious with the cheese curds.
- ramen: OK, definitely not a place to order ramen but it was tasty. The meat was flavored well and the noodles were not bad, but the broth was ok. A bit oily for me but again, decent. 

Colleagues liked their burger and tacos a lot though. 

Definitely got appetizers down. I'll have to return to try other entrees next time.
author: Amanda C.

description: Short rib was to die for!! Mmm and the rice was so interesting and delicious. I highly recommend this place. Be prepared to spend some $$$ here, it is pretty pricey. Service was excellent!
author: Maddie S.

description:
Had a business lunch yesterday at Salt House. My first visit- my client had been numerous times since his office is only a few blocks away. 

This is true American classic restaurant with unique twists -- arugula salad with light dressing mixed with duck confit. Yum. Client had the amazing peppers on the side and the salmon burger. He said it was excellent but didn't eat much of the bun. Didn't ask "why." Service was efficient if not a little cold- abrupt would be too harsh-- it's just that even now I couldn't identify him if he was standing in front of me. Hostess at front of house very pleasant even though a lot of people trying to get in. We had reservations and were seated promptly. One thing- there is a very nice and exceptionally clean parking garage about 50 ft from the restaurant - short term rates were fine and service excellent.

Check out the menu before you go- creative salads, tacos,  salmon, pasta, burgers, ramen etc. nice cheese plate as well. Noise alert- very crowded as tables are close together. All hard surfaces including an upstairs seating area. Very noisy. We managed ok. Last, the shared bathroom located at the back of the restaurant proper and in a hallway - kind of touch and go. Not my favorite. Not dirty but didn't sparkle.
author: Greg C.

description:
Nice atmosphere, good service, disappointing food for the price.

I got the chicken al pastor sandwich, at the recommendation of the waiter. I was expecting flavorful shaved or shredded chicken, but it ended up being a pretty bland chicken breast with a pineapple slice on top. The avocado mousse was standard avocado. The bun was slightly burned. Overall, it felt like something You could have gotten at a chain restaurant - but for $16.

We had the poutine, which was good (but who could screw up poutine?) Small portion for $12.

My friends enjoyed their salmon, burger, and tacos well enough, but the general feeling was that with so many excellent restaurants a stone's throw away, it's just not measuring up. It's too bad, because I remember dining here a few years ago and thinking it was pretty special.
author: sarah b.

description: I have been coming to the Salt house for years for lunch. I just want to personally give a huge shout out to Ms Gabbi the fabulous bartender. Since she has been the main bartender this past year, the lunch cocktail quality has gone up a couple of notches. When I partake for lunch she nails the perfect Manhattan and Old Fashioned every single time. She has suggested great ryes and bourbons as well. The bar area is in tip top shape under her watch. Thanks thanks Gabbi. You rock!!
author: Cyn K.

description:
Dinner with a best bud.  I have been here a few times since it is an easy place to get to from the FiDi, and is next door to the Deloitte office where I know people who work there.

The ambiance is cozy, meaning the tables are very very close to each other, so do not expect much of a private conversation if the place is croweded like it was last Thursday night.  

Service was friendly and prompt, with the hostess chipping in to bring us items besides our server.  The only slight ding is that I ordered a martini with our bottle of wince, and it took a bit too long to get it back from the bar. Very slight ding, as at the end of the meal and with an empty bottle of wine, we wanted to have another glass, and the server suggested a half a bottle that made sense price wise vs two glasses of the red stuff.

We shared apps, had oysters on the half shell, and they were great. But, they were smeared with a light amount of some kind of sweet paste. I like it better when I am in control of what goes on my oyster, and how much.

We also shared the salmon belly app, and it was ok. Shared the ravioli with squash, and they were yummy.

My entree was the baby ribs, and they were really good, would definitely recommend.
author: Massimo M.

description:
I came here for lunch with a few of my coworkers. We started off with oysters and steak tartare. Both were really good and tasted fresh!

I ordered the pappardelle for my entree. That wasn't very good. There was supposed to be a truffle cream sauce but I didn't taste any truffle at all. The whole dish tasted really salty. Tasted nothing but overwhelming salt. A couple of my coworkers got the salmon and said that was fantastic. I definitely made the wrong choice here.

For dessert, we shared the panna cotta, the chocolate mousse, and the black sesame cheesecake. The chocolate was really really heavy. One bite and that was enough. The panna cotta was pretty forgettable. The black sesame was really good though. Black sesame is always one of my favorite flavors in general. I never had it in cheesecake form though but I was impressed. The cheesecake was light and I could taste the accents of black sesame. 

The service was really slow. It took forever for us to order, forever for us to get our drinks, forever to get our appetizers, etc. Not sure why it was so slow since it wasn't busy either.

All in all, there are some good things here, just have to make the right choices.
author: Becky H.

description:
I've had lunch here once a few years back and was not impressed so I never returned. A friend of mine really wanted to try this place so I ended back here last night for dinner. It was better than the lunch I remember but nothing blew me away either. 

The pasta dishes were better than the rest. The meat dishes were fine but the meat portion was small. See my pics.

We started with the chips. That was creative. Desserts were fine until we found a hair. They did the right thing, remade the dish and took the dish off our bill. It wasn't a big deal. Shit happens.

They do charge a 5% SF mandate fee. It's one of the highest I've seen.
author: Andy W.

description:
Amazing food, great service , & creative and unique venue! We started with the Poutine and some cocktails. My friend ordered a whiskey sour which was well balanced. For dinner I ordered the pork loin which was delicious and perfectly cooked. The price is very good considering the local & organic ingredients used as well as in house chef owner!
The staff was very accommodating. The children didn't like the food they ordered and our waiter noticed and took the food back and asked if the kids wanted something more like chicken with rice and gravy (something not on the menu ). The server brought that out and that kids loved it and they didn't even charge us for the first orders. Finally they brought out complimentary mango sherbet deserAlso we came in about an hour before closing! Would definitely return and would recommend!
author: Adam R.

description:
The food at the Salt House is well prepared, if not extraordinarily original. The ambience is great, and the location is as well.

The problem - service. When we visited the service was quite slow, and the food arrived at our table only warm-ish. The house was full, and the staff seemed unprepared to handle it.
author: Derek K.

description: Very bad ramen, but great cocktails. The broth of the ramen had no depth at all and honestly tasted a lot like soy sauce and water.
author: Austin W.

description:
I can't get over the complexity of flavors that each dish presented.  It's obvious that people care very much about creating different kinds of tastes at the Salt House.
I've never had so many different and boldly seasoned plates that came one after the other at a restaurant in SF.

My drink, The Dr. No, was the first clue that something different was going on here. The ingredients consisted of: osco sea gin, yuzu citrus, amontillado sherry,  cucumber , furikake rim.  The furikake rim is what caught my eye and after asking our excellent server what it was--I decided to go for it.  Winner!  Furikake is dried seaweed ground down to the size of salt.  It was a wild addition but it totally worked.

We shared 2 plates of Shookum oysters, the flavored popcorn and the artichokes to start.  The oysters had a hint of pineapple granita and Ponzu sauce!  The popcorn was seasoned with furikake!  The artichokes sat in a stinging nettle sauce and were accompanied by pickled strawberries. 
I forgot to  mention that we also ordered the pickled quail eggs.  They were filled with pickled horseradish sauce, nori and salmon roe.  They just completely burst with flavor!

The grilled whole fish, English pea ravioli ( in a chocolate sauce!), California Halibut and a pasta dish with scroll shaped pasta and pork represented our main dishes.
They too were seasoned creatively and were very much appreciated by these diners.

We all shared a slice of their Key Lime Pie for dessert.  It was served with cinnamon sticks and blueberry, lemongrass compote. A Swiss meringue sat atop.

If you are into experiencing full flavored and bold tastes--then this is the place for you.
Clap! Clap! Clap!
author: Thomas D.

description: Excellent oysters, savory poutine with potatoes fried in duck fat. Amuse from kitchen featured charred salmon belly - an intensely flavorful bite. Competent servers and cocktail preparations added to overall experience
author: Kurt L.

description: Easy, last minute reservation for 2 on a Wednesday night. Great variety of cocktails and shared plates - little busy right after work, but simmered down for a cozy dinner.
author: Auburn S.

description: Service good, but vegetarians steer clear. The only thing I could eat was a salad and the goat cheese they served had gone off. Yuck. No thanks!
author: Ara S.

description:
Went here for a dinner celebration. Great food and good atmosphere but the place was pretty empty for a Saturday night and couldn't figure out why. 

However, we started hearing really loud noises (which I thought were cars driving by). Turns out the restaurant shares a bathroom with a night club which was playing extremely loud music. Also a bit weird to go in from dinner and see a bunch of people wearing club attire - there is also a bouncer sitting outside of the bathroom which is strange. 

A good place to go during the week but wouldn't recommend going during the evening on the weekend, unless you want to go to the club after haha.
author: Clara M.

description:
First time at Salt House. Business meal. The ambience was fine. But the restaurant felt a bit too crowded. It was loud and hot (I think their AC wasn't working properly). 

Not a place to have a formal business meal, but a great place for a semi-formal lunch with friends or coworkers. For a formal business meal I suggest Roy's.

Food was fine but not spectacular. Tho the shishito peppers were very delicious! For my main dish, I had the parpadelle  with summer squash. Very buttery! I liked it but put me right to sleep after lunch. 

Overall, I'd come back for lunch or happy hour! But this is not my first pick for a semi formal lunch spot in the area. I'd consider Roy's or RN74.
author: Dana Z.

description: Food was okay, $35-40 for the entree but the taste was not meeting the price standard in my opinion. We left half of the entree in the plate but the server did not ask why or how was the taste. No bread... which I would expect this kind of restaurant serve bread but it actually cost 4$ for a tiny loaf of bread. Wine was amazing but I would not come here again because I could get way better food with the same price I paid here.
author: Cindy Y.

description: Finally was able to try this place and we all loved the food. The shishito peppers were so good and the chicory salad was amazing. I could've eaten a big version as an entree and been perfectly happy.  That said, I'm really glad I had the striped sea bass! It was cooked perfectly. Cocktails were all really good too.  And service was super friendly. Definitely worth repeat visits.
author: Debbie L.

description: The food and drinks here were really good, thought a little bit pricier than what I would usually spend for a dinner. We got the shishito peppers and fries appetizers - both were good! I ordered the mushroom and burrata ravioli off of the appetizers menu and they offered it to me in a dinner size. The flavors were pretty good, though the pasta itself was more firm that I'd prefer. Overall a good experience.
author: Lillian B.

description: Ordered shrimp salad. Terrible. Vegetables were not fresh, rotten lettuce, tones of dressing..  none of the courses we ordered was good. Huge disappointment.
author: Merav N.

description:
Went here for the first time for a Business Lunch.  

Location and Space and Decor was great.  Overall Service was great and attentive.  Host was immediately helpful.  Waiters were super attentive.

Shishito Peppers were "good."  The Salmon Lunch entree was "good".  Ambiance was vibrant, which is mostly good...but can be somewhat challenging if you're trying to hold a more serious discussion amongst more than 2 people (we were a party of 3)

I thought the overall experience was "good" and would visit again, and would not steer someone away if they asked me about it.

However, my Client, who had been to the restaurant a number of times before, indicated that he wasn't thrilled with his meal and maybe things have slipped a little; hence the lower star rating.
author: Brandon S.

description:
Salt House is a modern restaurant with a trendy atmosphere/décor but the food left more to be desired. Presentation was beautiful, but what's the point of making the food look great when it doesn't taste great? The food is overpriced for the quality. 

Swordfish- fish lacked flavor and was slightly overcooked. Overall I was really disappointed by this dish.

Octopus with gnocchi- the portion was really small. Looked more like an appetizer than an entrée. This dish was decent, but not that great either. 

The restaurant is next to a club called Harlot and they share the same bathroom. Really not a good idea for a nice restaurant to share a bathroom with a club. I won't give deets but if you're a club goer you'll know what I mean.
author: Mai Y.

description: For lunch the salads are a terrible option. The shrimp salad was drenched in dressing and the lettuce was wilted. The poutine was decent but given the amount of options in FIDI I would not ever return for lunch. Service was good.
author: Leily P.

description:
Hostess was awesome with a good attitude. Food was finger licking good! And server was sharp! I'll be coming back and checking out there sister restaurants.

Server Nick was great! Knowledgeable and personable.

Sylvia on the other hand... well, just kidding she was awesome as well.

Thank you !
author: Antonio B.

description:
I've been to Salt House twice now, and I honestly can say that I like the appetizers better than the entrees. The entree selection appears to periodically change, which is a nice feature, but I have been unimpressed by the creativity and quality of the dishes compared to the price. The first time I was at Salt House, I ordered chicken tacos. I don't even remember what I thought of them to be honest. The second time, I ordered the fried chicken sandwich. While the chicken was juicy and hot, it had very little flavor. Which is weird...for fried chicken...

I LOVE the taro chips that they make. The shishito peppers are lovely too, but very salty, which makes for a perfect pairing with a beer! They have hibiscus tea as well, which was nice. Overall, a nice safe choice for a business meal, but I wouldn't expect to be blown out of the water.
author: Alice L.

description: This is a pretty standard place to have dinner. Nothing too special about it- I've had great food here then I've also had not so great experiences. My experience at lunch has been better, better service, less crowded. The service seems to suffer at dinner, we had two separate people waiting on us and neither of them had any idea what was going on with our table. We ordered the appetizer bread which is made fresh, they told us it would take 7-10 minutes and we were not in a hurry so we said we would wait. Then my husband got the pork chop and I got the salmon. They both arrived too quickly so we had to cancel the appetizer. I'm fine with appetizers taking longer but then the server needs to wait to put in entrees. Overall food is fine, service is eh and atmosphere is nice. Plenty of other nicer places close by!
author: Carol Ann V.

description:
Fantastic meal.  Started with the Chicory salad with a very nice dressing.  We then had the Striped Bass and Rock Fish entree's.  Both dishes were very well seasoned and cooked perfectly.  The sides were also very, very good.  We ended the meal with the black poppy seed cheese cake, OMG, it was fantastic.

Highly recommend Salt House and will be back.
author: Dave P.

description:
Good location from FiDi with a nicely decorated interior. Hostess was nice and overall service was attentive and great. Food, however, was nicely presented but was definitely not out of the world (for the price point of San Francisco food, anyway). 

We ordered the Sushi Rice, Octopus, and pork chops. Would recommend trying the Sushi Rice if you want to try something new and unique! Octopus was meh but pork chops were pretty tasty. Definitely am interested in checking out their sister restaurants.

Good place to try out if you're in the area!
author: Claudia W.

description:
Go for a drink but skip dining here.  Not sure what happened over the years bc it used to be great.  

Unfortunately, all our food (the octopus w/pork belly and roasted squash) were both cool/not warm when they arrived to our table.  Took almost 20 mins to get our wine so ate cool temperature food with no wine.  The wine arrived after they cleared our plates.  Bummer.  No acknowledgment of what seemed lime slow bar service.  No "thanks for your patience" or just a thanks for coming in.

Won't go back even though my office is next door...wouldn't recommend.
author: Kelly O.

description:
We came here at 11:45 hoping to snag a table before the lunchtime rush. Definitely made a good choice because there was a line forming after 12. For those who want to be on the even safer side, you can get a reservation on Open Table. 

There was complimentary bread that was sadly not warm but soft nonetheless.  It went great with my entree of Penn Cove Mussels.  The mussels are served in a bowl with toasted slices of bread.  The bread they gave was definitely not enough for the portion of mussels and more unfortunately, all 3 slices I recieved were burnt.  I'm not a stickler when it comes to slightly charred foods (which I actually love) but the bread was left on the fire for too long and chunks of it were not edible.  The sauce/soup that collected at the bottom of my bowl was too salty for my taste.  Even when I sopped up the tiniest bit on the bread roll, I found it too much.  If I were to go back, I'm definitely getting a sandwich.  Those seem to be the popular items that people were getting.  

Poutine fries were good, nothing amazing.  But hey, it's hard to find poutine so any poutine is better than no poutine.
author: Michelle B.

description:
i came here for a friends birthday. The ambiance was cool, it wasn't super busy and service was ok. 

My friends and I ordered the oysters, salad, and chips to share. The portions weren't super huge so we ordered a few doubles. The raw oysters weren't the best I've had. They had this sauce on it that tasted a bit weird to me. I would rathe just have lemon and tabasco with it again its only my preference. The chips were good, I didn't think it was worth ordering since it wasn't anything special. '

For my main dish I ordered the steak medium rare. I was a bit disappointed as the steak was dry, and the portions were really small. I assumed there would be vegetables that came with it but it was just puree of carrots and something else that looked like mashed potatoes. 
My friends ordered the fish and she wasn't too impressed as the fish looked really dry.

All in all the food wasn't too great to my liking, but the service was well.
author: Tiffany K.

description: A good place to grab drinks & bites with friends. Inventive cocktails at the bar and the food is very tasty.
author: Aida T.

description:
Went with a group (4) of coworkers. We decided to order 8 dishes and share, as opposed to individual meals--this allowed us to try much of Salt House's entree menu: Creative King Salmon (Wonderful), Pork Chop (Wonderful), Octopus (Wonderful), Pappardelle (Hard Pass), California Halibut (Pass), Ribeye (Wonderful) and appetizers: Shishito Peppers (Hard Pass), Skookum Oysters (Hard Pass), Poutine (Hard Pass)

I'm very glad we did this as everything is in extremely small portions, especially considering it's pretty pricy.
author: Josh M.

description: Over priced, food is average, slow service. However, the atmosphere is pretty nice (some might say it's too dark to read a menu during dinner service.) Location is great! I might come back for happy hour after work.
author: Lana B.

description: The look of a great restaurant but the food lacks depth and frankly flavor. The servers look like they have fear of the job. My fish came out raw after waiting an extended period of time that was too long for any meal. appetizers were good and the bread was the highlight, but beyond that this place is probably one you want to skip unless you just need food or walking by it like we were on a last-minute lunch. Unfortunate
author: Brad M.

description: Came here after an interview. I sat at the bar and was warmly greeted by the bartender. Instantly, I felt like I was at ease and welcome there, which is rare in SF (in my experience anyway). I ordered a glass of burgundy wine and was convinced by the group next to me to order the poutine. It was excellent, though I have never eaten poutine before.  Be warned though - it's deceivingly filling. The short ribs, gravy, cheese curds and fries all came together in a wonderful symphony of subtle flavors. Will definitely be back with my friends or family!
author: Naveen A.

description: We liked our entrees  - black cod and striped sea bass, but thought the food was too salty (not trying to be funny here). The roasted vegetable salad was good, but not much food and expensive for the portion. The oysters were excellent and service was very good
author: Jill W.

description: The Pappardelle with Tartufo really surprised me, I didn't have a good pasta like this in the US for a long time!
author: Damian S.

description: Man, I ordered a big beautiful, thick pork chop and it was nasty. Hard, dry, almost inedible. The space is awesome but the food was terrible.
author: Chris S.

description:
*This review is solely for Salt House's happy hour* 

How early is too early for Happy Hour? Well, I know that nothing is too early for Salt House  because their happy hour starts at 3pm. *ahem* not like I've been there that early for happy hour *ahem*. Their happy hour menu is great! Cocktails are $7 (and they're delicious!). The flavors rotate every once in awhile so it has always been something different every time I'm there. It's good in that I always get to try something new but bad in that I never remember the name of the drinks from the previous list .... sigh. 

The staff is also amazing. My friend and I got seated at the bar and barely missed happy hour by 10minutes. The server felt bad that we barely missed it and brought out a cheese platter on the house for us. Now that's a way to our heart, through wine and free food! :)
author: Tram N.

description: Peace all.. we went here for a lunch meeting and arrived 1:30 to avoid the lunch hour. Service was excellent and the three of us had the seasonal salad which was quince w/arugula. I topped mine with shrimp. They were out of salmon which seems strange since it's open for dinner but maybe they get it fresh. So instead my coworker got the grilled chicken. We had appetizers of french fries, green peppers and spinach w/mushrooms. Everything was great, fresh and I enjoyed the experience. Hopefully I can try the chocolate chip cookie next time. I definitely recommend it.
author: Wallace A.

description: I barely made a dent in my San Francisco bookmarks! But I can say I am so glad I ended up here. I can't say enough great things about Salt House. I came here on a rainy night for a drink and a couple apps. I ordered a whiskey sour and it was delicious, frothy perfection! We started with the octopus and pork belly appetizer- it was seriously the best octopus I have ever had! It was crispy and so flavorful. The pork belly was to die for! We were literally counting pieces and dividing them up equally so it was fair. Next we got the Ahi tuna with poached seafood. Some of the assorted seafood included muscles, uni panna cotta (yum!) and shrimp. Everything tasted very fresh and it was a great light app to balance the octopus/pork belly. Service was spot on- and since we did not stay for a full meal I will happily be back next time I find myself in San Francisco.
author: Taylor J.

description:
This was my second time at the Salt House. The first time was with a group of 7 other people. We came without a reservation on a Friday night. The host was very accommodating and we were served drinks and seated at a long table within 30 minutes. I went again yesterday for lunch with two others and was seated immediately. 

Service was excellent both times. The food was also very very good for everyone at the table. My coworker enjoyed the chicken sandwich (for the second time) and it was great. The grilled cheese and soup was solid. 

Get the poutine and octopus. So very yummy! 

I had the beet salad and added salmon. It was fantastic. The salmon was worth running back for today! Given how well prepared all of the meals were, twice in a row, I am considering making this my local spot. 

Ambiance is great with a very cool upstairs that looks down on the main floor. 

Worth noting: they ask if you would like water from the get go. This is a rarity in San Francisco due to water shortages but it is important to offer it.
author: Nichole W.

description: Food was good! But service was awful... waited for the food for about an hour almost. Other tables were complaining as well. Manager was clearly super stressed out. Not sure if they were short on staff yesterday or what. Plus our server was kind of rude. Boo!
author: Joan M.

description:
Had dinner there last night and really enjoyed everything, from the (white) wines, appetizers to the main course and desserts. We had:

Appetizers:

Tuna crudo - fresh tuna and beautifully presented with garnishes and seasoned with ponzu sauce
Persimmon Cannellone - again beautifully presented and made into a roll with dungeness crab and seaweed salad, with creamed avocado "dots" on the side of the roll and flying fish roe sprinkled on top of the "roll". It was light, tasty and refreshing. I don't know how they made this into a sushi roll looking dish; it sure was visually pleasant to look at.
Octopus - don't expect to see any fried calamari looking pieces of "fish" on this plate. (I wish I had remembered to take pictures of all the dishes we ate...). There were a few well seasoned lamb sausage and octopus as well as grilled vegetables on the plate. Tasty and visually pleasant to look at.

Main course:

San Francisco Ling Cod - juicy and light white fish that was very well seasoned. If you prefer less fishy fish and a light flavored seafood dish, try this one. Love the creamy white beam puree as well as the olive tapenade crisp, which I don't know how they made olives into a piece of corn chip looking cracker. 

Skuna Bay salmon - Loved this dish! I would go back just for this one! The salmon was juicy and flaky. The chanterelle mushroom added a strong "meaty" flavor and texture to the dish and they sure were generous with the mushrooms!

Gnocchi primavera - this is the BEST gnocchi dish I have ever tasted! Contrary to the commonly seen heavy white cream sauce, they made this dish without any cream sauce and yet still managed to make the gnocchi delicious. It had the perfect texture without being too mushy/soft or too firm and was so fresh and lightly crispy on the outside. Loved the king trumpet mushrooms, which added a layer of flavor, and winter root vegetables, which were grilled just right.

Dessert - being a "caker" myself I could not possibly pass up the opportunity to try their beautifully presented, decadent looking desserts! Thanks to the hostess Nicole, who seemingly read my mind and picked these two desserts for us:

Pumpkin spice layer cake - perfect amount of spice, moist not overly sweet cake, frosted with creamy cream cheese frosting. The buttermilk-huckleberry sherbet was refreshing, light and a nice palate cleanser. I especially LOVED the nice touch of sprinkles of sea salt on top of the cream cheese frosting. It added an additional dimension of flavor when you take a bit into the cake: it was salty at first, then the creaminess of the frosting hit you, then the sweetness of the moist, spiced pumpkin cake took over, and you suddenly realized, yeah, I am still eating a dessert. I made a mental note to remember to add sea salt on my cakes next time.

Gingerbread sable - probably the best gingerbread "cookie" I've ever eaten. Very crunchy texture with sprinkles of  sanding sugar on top. Again there are layers of different textures stacked on top of one another, from the maple panna ccotta on top, to the crunchy cookie in the middle, to the creamy hazelnut cream at the bottom. Just think of all the efforts they made to compose this dessert dish! Oh, and let's not forget about the spiced pear sorbe on the side that was the perfectly refreshing palate cleanser to end the meal.

The recommended French white wine pairing was great too, which went perfectly with the seafood dishes we had. 

Overall, it was a fantastic dinner, with great service. The hostess knows our guests by name and was very personable and helpful. Fresh and very flavorful dishes with beautiful plating techniques. I would definitely come back again to try more dishes!
author: Claire W.

description:
Salt House Restaurant Review 
Outside looking in the restaurant looks like a higher end restaurant. Coming in they had interesting business cards and menus that makes the restaurant classier. The host seated us right away because we had reservations. 
*A tip would be to make reservations especially during lunch/dinner rushes. 
The seating of the restaurant is a little tight that creates a loud environment. I would not suggest to bring someone here if you wanted a private conversation.
The hard walls and ceilings create the restaurant noise to not leave the room which makes you have to speak up to talk to the person next to you. The service was also good. We did not have a problem with them. They were kind and professional but you do need to ask for bread, they won't just put it on your table.
I will also like to add that the kitchen is open and can be seen while eating which makes for some entertainment. There is also a bar and upstairs seating which adds more value to the restaurant 

On to the food, I ordered the "Carnitas Tacos" and they were pretty good. It's not amazing but when you put your salsa on them that's where they get good. They also come with a side of chips which make for a delightful side. These tacos aren't your usual run of the mill tacos from a taco stand they have a little more glam to them. 

With the Carnitas Tacos I also ordered the "Salt House Burger" and that was great. Places that are more modern and are trying to be fancy sometimes can't make a burger well. I asked for it medium well and it came out exactly how I desired it to be cooked.
*Tip I have heard they cook the burgers more rare if you don't ask for how you want it to be cooked. Be sure to ask for it to be cooked how you would like.
The burger came with fries that were pretty salty, no pun intended. But they did taste better than I expected and made my burger that much better. 

I also had the Chocolate Mousse for dessert, it tasted average but the the design of it was laid out like a snake which made it look more interesting and fancy. You would expect mousse to be not displayed like that which makes it significant but it did have these chocolate and white chocolate balls that tasted good that added a crunch to it.

Overall the restaurant would be a great place if you are in the area for lunch or going to take coworkers out. The only cons I would say is that that restaurant is pricey and would probably go to the extent say over pricey because 3 tacos should never cost you 16 dollars or a burger and fries should not cost you 17 dollars. It is also on the louder side. So be expected to speak up at the table.

I WOULD recommend this restaurant to a friend.
author: Tobias L.

description:
I assume for SF standards their food is not that off, but i found it a bit too designer. Micro herbs and all.
Atmosphere is nice, dishes nicely presented.
author: Barbara S.

description:
Had my birthday lunch here with my coworkers and it was actually pretty good.  Not sure why it has low ratings but it was pretty packed on a Tuesday lunch.  It was loud with a line out the door.  The inside has high ceilings and an open kitchen which we had a front seat view of all the things going on in there.

I tried the pork belly sandwich and also we got the poutine too.  Regarding the poutine, it was a good version of poutine but definitely not traditional recipe for sure.  The pork belly sandwich was pretty good as I literally inhaled my sandwich in a few bites.  The chips that came with were also good but didn't eat them until after I ate my entire sandwich.

The unexpected entertainment that we had that day was some kitchen theatrics.  Apparently a worker in there was being yelled at and he ended up leaving the kitchen.  I wasn't sure if he came back but that didn't look like ordinary kitchen communication.  I guess Hell's Kitchen is may more reality than I initially thought.

I had a good meal despite a super loud environment although I most likely will come back during happy hour.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Had an amazing work lunch of 6 here a couple of weeks ago, so yes this was on the work credit card.

We had BLISTERED SHISHITO PEPPERS and HUMBOLDT FOG CHEESE to start. I love shisito peppers and they were perfectly salted. I am lactose intolerant, so I did not have the cheese, but it look tasty and my co-workers like it a lot.

Our table ordered the following:
CRISPY CHICKEN SANDWICH (x3) Yep three people ordered it...enough said.
PENN COVE MUSSELS: Perfectly cooked and could not stop dipping the garlic/wine sauce.
SALMON: Look very beautiful and salmon was cooked perfectly. Co-worker LOVED it.

If we were not full enough, yes we got dessert:
TAHITIAN VANILLA CRÈME BRÛLÉE: Delicious rich crack, need more....
DARK CHOCOLATE CAKE:Rich, chocolate coma, need more....
author: Mei L.

description:
My favorite aspect of Salt House is the amazingly beautiful use of space. At the entryway, there's a stairwell up to this loft seating, great for a large group looking for privacy. Views from above allow you an eagle eye into the open kitchen and bar space beneath. The original hardwood floors and exposed brick are rustic accents on the modern furniture, kitchen design, and loft area. 

I've only come here for lunch (will definitely return for drinks and dinner), but the menu was fairly simplistic--salads, sammies, and fries. Definitely a great choice for a quick in-and-out business lunch or more upscale experience than just running across the street for a quick bite. The small touches on each dish made the food and drinks stand out from the average FiDi restaurant. Garnishes, food presentation, and espresso were all plated and served with the utmost care. My favorite had to be the single brown sugar cube on a teaspoon beside the macchiato. Very standard in Europe, but not often seen in this neck of the woods. 

They also serve Acme pull-apart bread, which is an enticing incentive to head over there on its own.

Service is amazing from the host to the waitstaff. If anything, it's a great place to just get away from the office as a group or alone, and sit in a really beautiful venue.
author: Alison A.

description: Good drink and wine list and decent food. Great hot nuts and Shishito peppers to start. Got the brined pork chop, which in and of itself was amazing, but yam and green bean with it weren't good. Green beans covered in a thick molasses type of black paste that wasn't appetizing. Menu is also limited if you don't like sea food. Would only come back for drinks.
author: Jo M.

description:
***************** 1588 *************

I haven't been here for sometimes so I was excited to return. We dropped in on the weekend without a reservation but we got lucky with seats at the bar.
Salt House was packed. Candle lights, music, and a lot of laughter, we knew we were in for a good time here. 

Felina, the floor manager was greeted us nicely and recommended us a few highlighted dishes that she thought we would enjoy. Every dish was on point. She even recommended a nice red wine to pair with our steak and a nice margarita drink for my friend. Thank you Felina for the warm hospitality. 

-  BLISTERED PEPPERS - citrus infused maldon salt
pepper 

-  GRILLED LITTLE GEMS - marble potato / queso fresco 
pickled green strawberries / fava avocado purée - a must order

- OCTOPUS - cherry yuzu jus / baby corn 
snap peas / baby sweet potato, a perfectly dish in taste and presentation.

- BEEF CHEEK & RIB-EYE DUO - maitake mushrooms / bonito beef jus garlic potato purée / kohlrabi, delicious, big portion, it was perfect to share.


- CLAM BRAISED LAMB - fava agnolotti / gypsy peppers / fresno chiles xo sauce / purslane - so good.

We also got to meet 1 of the owners Doug. It's nice to see the owner serving you food at the bar. He was attentive and warm to our party. It's refreshing to see that. 

So if you love sitting at the bar, Salt House is a great spot in SoMa.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
The only reason this isn't a 1 star review is because my meal was comped - I do appreciate that.

I wandered in around 2:20 on a Tuesday afternoon hungry for lunch. Hungry is an understatement. I was informed it was happy hour and the lunch menu was not available. That was fine by me and at 2:30 I ordered a grilled cheese sandwich that comes with tomato soup and a side salad.

Water was delivered almost immediately, but other than that it was crickets. I started getting dagger eyes for people bringing food my way, but it never came. At 2:50, a waiter told me my food was almost ready, and at 2:55 it finally came. Mind you, there were 3 other parties in the restaurant, and I think the kitchen staff still outnumbered us. 30 minutes to make a grilled cheese sandwich in an empty restaurant is unacceptable.

As I take my first bite, the whole bottom side of my sandwich is burnt to a crisp. I can't even begin to describe my disappointment. See pic for the visual.

I don't think I would ever return here.
author: Kailey O.

description: Last restaurant before heading back to Europe, I've eaten in 5 states and numerous cities this trip, and this was the best! I've read some reviews here and my head hurts. People know very little about goo food. Our server Dill knew very well what he was offering and how to match everything. Management came bye to check in, which is always appreciated (timing is everything). Prices are very fair considering the combinations of flavors on a single plate. Americans are too accustomed to crazy big plates that they don't even finish (For disclosure, I'm born and raised in Chicago), then they complain when it's "too small" even though they actually go home not feeling bloated from over-eating. This place deserved a visit from Michelin. Thank you to everyone at this amazing place for your hard work and talent. These people love what they do. Very grateful. Until next time (hopefully not very long!).
author: Richard K.

description:
Salt House's crispy chicken sandwiches have become my offices' go to happy place for lunch.

I definitely recommend making a reservation if you want a table between noon and 1:30pm.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Please order MONTEREY BLACK COD
corn purée / romano beans / favas
squash / chorizo / squash blossoms, if you enjoy fish.  Superb!
author: Bleep S.

description:
I've wanted to come to Salt House since I moved to San Francisco, and I finally had the opportunity. I came here with a group of seven people (we made a reservation) and were seated in the middle of the restaurant. What a fun vibe! Our waitress was super friendly and hospitable throughout the evening. This is a great place for a date, business dinner, or general get-together with friends. They also have a happy hour and lunch menu.

We started off with a few appetizers to share, including the blistered peppers and Brussel sprouts, both of which had unique flavors. For my main entree, I ordered the Niman Ranch Pork, which is bacon wrapped tenderloin with peaches, gnocchi, chanterelles. SO GOOD. Would definitely recommend this dish. Salt House is a bit pricey, especially if you are also ordering a few drinks, but the service and atmosphere are great. Plus it's conveniently located near the Montgomery BART station.

I would want to come here more often if I could afford it, but alas... Salt House shall be saved for those very few special occasions when I'm looking to celebrate, eat some good food, and enjoy a lively atmosphere.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Excellent customer service from the Bar. Because it took a while for them to make my drink, they offered me a glass of prosecco.The bartender was friendly and gave warm hospitality.
author: Shanice C.

description: Mediocre. I had the crispy chicken sandwich which was okay, but bland. Also the poutine was just okay. It is a nice touch that they bring complimentary bread and butter to the table but the bread was cold and hard. The burger looked the best.
author: Maja M.

description: The food here is really good! It does take a long time to reach your table but it's always worth the wait! The last time we were there we got a salad and asked to add chicken - $7 extra :/ . The poutine fries are so good!
author: Anne-Marie R.

description: Such a great experience dinning here. From the moment my boyfriend and I walked in we were greeted with friendly customer service and that trickled down to the dinner we had. Defiantly visiting the sister restaurants and will be back again to Salt House! Thank you Nick for the excellent customer service.
author: Amber S.

description:
I like the ambiance and the potential of this place. I just went here once for the first time tonight and I enjoyed my Tortillini dish, but I think they have it within them to expand on the menu a bit and also think of some more eye appealing dishes. I'm giving them a 3 for now, but see great potential in this prime location of the SoMa district. I intend on going back and ordering something different. I also had a nice Pinot Noir from Burgundy France which I would have again. 

Til next time...

Oh!, I must add- the shishito peppers for an appetizer were awesome! Probably my favorite food I tried of the evening. Those peppers were delicious in fact.
author: Nina L.

description:
I went to a friend's birthday and we were a large group and we all didn't get there all at once, but they had our table ready for us.  The place is pretty packed so expect it to be a bit loud, although it looks pretty nice inside.

Food:
+ Beef Rib-eye with black trumpet mushrooms, braised leeks, crispy potato and parsley root ($39) - I thought this was just OK.  It's a bit weird that they cut the meat for you and give it to you in pieces, which isn't much meat.  I ordered medium rare, so it wasn't tough or anything.  

+ Roasted Apple & Almond Tart with rosemary and honey ice cream, honey tuile, pinecone bud syrup ($10) - This basically just tasted like an overly sweet apple pie slice. The "tart" pretty much overwhelmed the ice cream, which was very forgettable. Wouldn't really order this again.

+ Gingerbread Sable with maple panna cotta, spiced pear sorbet, hazelnut cream and pomegranate gastrique ($10) - This was just an oversized gingerbread cookie, which was once again - just OK. Also wouldn't really order this again.

+ Valrhona Guanaja Chocolate Mousse with tangerine sherbet, caacao nib tuile, and chocolate mait pearls ($10) - This is good for chocolate lovers.  The sherbet doesn't taste any different from regular orange sherbet that you can get at a supermarket...

Service: 
It took a REALLY loooooong time for us to get our food, probably some time between an hour to an hour and a half to get our entrees.  We were all pretty hungry and snacking on the bread to keep our hunger down.  The bread wasn't that soft either, but when you're hungry, you'll pretty much eat anything.  

General breakdown:
Service: 2 stars for slowness
Food: 3 stars
Total: 2.5 stars rounded to be 3 stars

Would I go back again? Probably not... I would rather go to Roy's, which is just down the block instead...
author: Gilda W.

description: The chef and staff are terrific. Hence, more than a single star. The restrooms are an atrocity against the human race! It was a frightening nightmare to go into this awful coed bathroom and simply intolerable for a restaurant of this caliber and price. The restroom was filthy beyond your worst imagination and ruined an otherwise lovely evening. It was filled with 10-12 wasted guys by 830pm. One tried to hug me. There was a security guard seated outside the restroom on a stool who did nothing to help. I've traveled all over the world and it was more disgusting than any lavatory I've ever seen.  We told the hostess and she said they had a bathroom attendant coming in at 9pm. You've got to be kidding! They needed to call a cleaning hazmat team and the police two hours ago.  Not joking, not even a little bit. Will never go back.
author: REN S.

description:
This will be a quick review:

Service-great 
Ambiance: really lovely interior design, but really loud inside. Wouldn't recommend if you actually need to have a meeting with someone 

Last but not least, my order for lunch: 
I got the fried chicken sandwich. I was looking really forward to it. I'm such a fried chicken sandwich connoisseur and make it a point to try it everywhere. Salt House did disappoint. The sandwich was so bland. No taste to it at all. The bread was ok, could have been better. The slaw that was in it, also no taste. For the price, I expected more.
author: Sheena C.

description:
Poutine: having lived in Canada for over 10 years, I'll give myself the right to say that this poutine was an embarrassment -- fries too chunky, curds dry, and gravy barely there at all. 

Salt House burger: I ate 1/2 of it and gave up. Dry dry dry. Barely any house sauce. The beef had weird hard chunks that I had to spit out. Yuck.

Service: lunch was sloooow. Plan to spend 1.5h there at least!

Ambience: this (and location) are the best parts. The decor is lovely.

Pricing: given that the overall quality of the experience didn't match the price, don't think I'll be going back here for lunch again.
author: Dejana B.

description:
If I can give a zero I would. 

I went here because of proximity to my work. I literally can't believe how people still come here. Food horrible, service even worse. Biggest pet peeve is when a server doesn't want to be work. Cleaning a customers plate when we've only had 5 minutes to eat it is not pleasant either. I would have had a better meal at McDonald's. The Poutine... It's not even Poutine. The flour in the gravy was not cooked out so it had clumps of uncooked flour and tasteless. Definite gross.... Then my chicken came and it was undercooked. Who eats raw chicken. Straight disaster!!!! I could go on and on but why.
author: Mare F.

description: Went to Salt House for lunch with my wife and had the burger. I really loved it, loved the charred meat, strongly recommend it!
author: Thomas L.

description:
Comfort food... sigh.
Maybe it's me, but still don't get it.
After reading several reliable Yelp Elite sources, this cozy SOMA eatery wasn't exactly on my radar screen.  My cousin invited our family to a recent Sunday get together for our party of seven.  Seated near the bar, the dining room is spacious with high ceilings.  The brick structure gives it a rustic feel as it is likely a historic building.  Here is what I tried:

Shared apps
1) Poutine - Their staple dish, this was only okay as the fries were on the dry side and the gravy one note.

2) Ravioli with rabbit - It wasn't bad, but no comparison to Cotogna's tortelli.  Modest portions made it difficult to share.

3) Raw oysters - A good selection of oysters and tried only two.  Like the dipping choices of cocktail sauce, horseradish, or mignonette sauce.

4) Risotto - The veggie risotto was above average with a interesting variety of locally grown vegetables.  This dish disappeared quickly.

Entree
5) Vegetable soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=lkFuo6HpqmN4KnBCr9C1dw) - Ingredients were good and like the clear broth.  The flavors were a bit one note and still haven't found the menu listed 'dumplings'.

6) Rockfish ceviche (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=S3StOChB-SnAhqTmaJouNw) - Like the tanginess and the fish and sauce had refreshing flavors.  Again, wished the portions were a bit more generous.

We also shared three desserts between the seven of us.  Nothing really stood out as I can't remember any of them outside of the cheesecake.
There was nothing particularly good or bad (outside of the present company), just that nothing really stood out; did notice that the prices are a bit on the high side compared to other comfort food places.  Our waitress was informative and helpful, but sometimes there were big gaps between seeing her; she explained that the restaurant name is inspired by an eatery in England after I asked.  Thanks uncle for hosting this dinner.
Given the menu choices and prices, you're more likely to find me a few doors west having a warm chocolate cake.
author: Mike C.

description: I would like to give this place a good review, that menu is great, the roasted salted peppers were delicious, the truffle oil on the French fries was a nice touch. Everything was cooked perfectly. But I was very disappointed when I chomped down on lots of inedible gristle in my otherwise nicely prepared burger. (At least, that's what I hope it was!) Why go to all the trouble of doing a good job on a burger when the quality of the meat is terrible? No matter how pretty, chunks of gristle in a burger is a total turn off.
author: Janet F.

description: The service was very capable of dealing with my smartass remarks which were a cup runeth over tonight. The octopus starter is sooo tasty and the steak is shut your fat mouth delicious. Killer drinks too. Just do it.
author: Steven D.

description: I rarely yelp while I'm eating but.. English pea ravioli is out of this world amazing. Cocktails are also delicious although I mostly enjoyed martinis. Great selection of cheese including some awesome Humboldt fog goat cheese.  Will be back!
author: Diana C.

description: The Salt House had been one of my go to restaurants in SF but not anymore.  I want to point out how friendly the staff are, especially the bartenders.  On this visit, I sat at the bar for a quick drink and a bite.  The old fashion was great, but the poutine I always get here was terrible compared to past visits.  Did they change the recipe ?  It had sriracha sauce dollops and some chopped green stuff that was gross on top that I don't remember.  Also, as some other reviewers mentioned, the food wasn't hot -- warm to cold.  The gravy was watery and not as flavorful as in the past.  On top of this, the bill (excluding tip) was $27 for one cocktail and the poutine!!
author: John O.

description:
I've walked by this place a million times and we finally tried it this weekend - the pork chop is amazing and I highly recommend the pasta (mine had pancetta and sea urchin and a poached egg in it). The service was phenom, can't recommend it enough.

And I'm not sure if it's on the regular menu, but they gave us a chocolate chip cookie (a nice gesture after a veryyy minor mishap) and it was to die forrrrr.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Short rib poutine is what enticed me to put Salt House on my list to try and that is what we came here to test as I am always on the lookout for a better poutine option in the city.

On entering, it is noticeably loud and crowded in both the bar and dining area. With high ceilings and sleek metal finishes, the atmosphere felt very trendy with random eccentric artwork spread around the interior.

Stuffed chicken wings - 2/5 - This sounded far more intriguing than it was. There was a tiny amount of stuffing in one section of the wings. I think we were hoping that instead they had pulled the bone out or found some clever way to actually make this feel like a stuffed piece of chicken rather than just being an overly spiced set of fried wings.

Short rib poutine - 1/5 - Sigh, another miss. The fries were not crispy enough and the cheese curds were average, but I did like that they torched it a bit to melt some of them into a stringy goo. Most disappointing, however, was that the gravy had the most minuscule pieces of short rib in it and nothing else. Where is the actual short rib??? Not a single chunk of meat to be found here. Utterly underwhelming.

Pork duo - 3/5 - The ribs were average and not something I would order again. The pork tenderloin was quite good, and had a nice bacon wrap and crumbled topping with a tasty sauce. It was also nicely pink throughout and looked to have been cooked by sous vide. While not the most exciting item, it was decently done. The plantains were good as well.

Overall, I'm basing this rating on the poutine since that was our focus and reason for coming. For the cost and supposed quality of this restaurant it is embarrassing that there isn't any visible meat to be found in the poutine. "I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description: Great service all around. The corn ravioli rocks. Order the bread and the warm nuts. Loud environment.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Makanan disini kurang rasa. Kami order poutine, hamburger, chicken sandwich semua kurang rasa nya. 
Jangan makan disini.
author: Geordie E.

description:
Bad service but good food.  Vegetable soup, Salmon and chocolate desert were fabulous. My husband had Fried chicken which was really salty. Bad service though...

Didn't even ask to take drink order until I went to find her I asked if we should move since she was clearly toooo busy.  Bad attitude at first then got super nice after it was clear I was not happy.
author: kem t.

description:
The Salt House definitely captures the SOMA vibe and is a trendy restaurant in SF. During lunch, I mistakenly forgotten to make a reservation and I was meeting friends for lunch. The staff was more than helpful, and we had a table within 15 minutes.

The vibe was popping and the restaurant was filled with hipsters, biz people dining and a few fun tourists. The food was a little pricey but delicious. We had drinks, appetizers, and lunch. I loved the Brussel Sprouts.

I definitely recommend the restaurant for meeting friends or a business lunch or dinner. Good times.
author: Shawnee N.

description: It was okay. Salt house is your basic uber trendy restaurant in San Francisco. High ceilings make for maddening acoustics, making it difficult to carry on a conversation. Great cocktails and wine list. I had their $13 gin based Dr No. The food, I have to say, was mediocre. Everything was beautifully plated, as you would expect at a restaurant where main entrees are $30+, but for some reason, everything seemed overly salty to me. I didn't hate my experience, but I probably won't go back anytime soon.
author: Pebbles E.

description:
My experience at Salt House was very mixed. Most of the dishes ordered were excellent.  The spring vegetable soup was perfection and the halibut was very good.  Unfortunately, we ordered a chicken liver pate that had a tart and bitter glaze (passion fruit, I think) that made it completely inedible.  Our server noticed that we didn't touch it and whisked it away with no questions asked.  

The service was certainly very friendly, but also very slow.  

I am hoping this was just a bad night, as I have had much better meals and service here before.
author: Aldo G.

description: BEWARE!  Purse was stolen at lunch and conveniently their camera, pointed right at my table, doesn't work all of a sudden!  Owner was a complete ASS about the whole situation.  I would not give this establishment your money!
author: Amanda G.

description:
We ordered the tomahawk steak. It costs 110$ 
And it was mediocre at best.

The service is very nice but the food is not worth coming back especially with such high prices
author: Oz Y.

description: BRAVO - AMAZING - FABULOUS - went in for dinner Saturday night and walked out having one of the best meals in SF - everything from the starters to entrees and dessert - were delicious - chef really takes the time to make sure everything tastes amazing - decor, beautiful.  Service, superb.  Will go back?  ABSOLUTELY.
author: Phillip S.

description:
I'm a law student at the law school across the street. I've been to this restaurant twice in the last year. It's super cute and classy, and I would frequent it more often if I didn't have a student budget. 

I arrived before 2 p.m. Their happy hour. Glass of wine is between 13-15 dollars. 

Tip: arrive between 2-4 and have their cava or pomegranate martini for 7 bucks! Half the price. I haven't tried their food but I hear it's fantastic. I just can't afford 17 bucks for a burger :) this place is adorable and classy, check it out!
author: Cece F.

description:
Meh.

Came here for a nice-ish dinner and the food was mediocre with small portions. Always come into these places with suspicion because it can be hard to hit this price range and pull it off well without overshooting the actual food quality.

It's located in a sparse restaurant area so can see how it attracts business lunches/dinners. If you're coming for a personal event, travel a bit farther into Hayes Valley and you'll be much better off at a similar price point and experience.

Best advice I have for anyone if you find yourself here: order the bâtard (basically a freshly baked baguette, listed under appetizers) and proceed from there :)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
We happily spent 3.5 hours here... seated with a sidewalk view of street. Passers by, our dinner show. Lost somewhere in a daze of cocktails, appetizers, and cheese.. lots of cheese, I ordered the check... ouch! But worth the pain.. The sister(s) in law woes, birthdays, kids, and holidays all had to be discussed and we needed a solid base of booze and food to get through it all..

ambiance:
I had reserved a table for two (opentable) but found out we would be a party of three.. the hostess tried in vain to find me a table for three.. she kindly sat me under the stairs. Which, at first glance you might think only a hobbit would be able to comfortably sit, but upon sitting down there is a nice street view and actually enough room to chat and spread out without impeding the traffic of the rest of restaurant. It was the perfect corner for girl talk.

the food: 
Blistered peppers, spicy, small and salty. Cheese, sheep's milk with crostini and perfectly paired with the peppers.. I believe we ordered the whole wheel by the end of the night. Tuna crudo, the only dish that did not impress: small but tasty bits of tuna but the rice was almost nonexistent, yuzu sauce was good.. oh well, moving quite along to the pickled quail eggs, which were as promised, delicious! Grilled octopus, with seared lamb sausage, peppers, and huckleberry sauce.. we ordered two of those. The persimmon cannelone, was amazingly good and unique.. slices of persimmon wrapped around crab in a CALI roll fashion.. very, very good. To finish, we had the chocolate mousse, lovely presentation and very chocolatey with sorbet to round it out. 

booze:
The tipsy mermaid (3), lightly fruity not too sweet, cucumber-citrus and vodka, champagne on the house for three, in honor of the birthday girls ;)

Really good coffee to end!
author: Sara F.

description:
Hit or miss.

I was here for a company event and so can't speak to the pricing or regular entrees. As a note, if you have a party of more than 15 people, I recommend you book more than just the '2nd floor' area. It got rather cramped as the attendees trickled in. Service was good. The staff was friendly and professional. 

I don't think it's the same menu as the the standard service but hopefully this review is useful. The cheese was a miss on appetizers as it was a bit warm upstairs resulting in not the best texture. 'Entree' bites were tasty. I particularly enjoyed the quiche square and the braised meat (although the cold temperature was a little odd). Dessert was a hit or miss. 'Lemon Meringue' pie in a shot glass was a bit too tart but I liked the texture. The fudge chocolate covered cake ball was delicious and indulgent. The shortbread cookies topped with a sour cream, not worth the calories. Finally a berry jam surrounded with a thin layer of chocolate was beautiful to look at and pleasant to eat.
author: Tammy T.

description: Delicious oysters and shaved fennel salad for me, steak frites for him. Great atmosphere. Cozy fireplace 200+ year old building with thick stone walls and wooden beamed ceiling. Sofas on the 2nd floor for more eating and drinking. I will come again!
author: Rachel F.

description: Highway robbery. Selling a bottle of wine for $72. That's 750 ml or 25 fl oz. Bought 4 glasses of wine containing barely 5 fl oz each for $18 a glass. That's 5 glasses per bottle! Refused to give any sort of credit or offer the rest of the wine to true us up to 750 ml. Horrible service!
author: I M.

description:
We celebrated a b'day dinner here and enjoyed the following dishes, pretty presentation and awesome service.

1) Two appetizers: (1) Poutine - Kennebec fries with mozzarella curds, mornay & short rib gravy (2) Octopus with yukon gold potato, dehydrated blood orange, pickled fennel & hazelnuts. 
2) Half Moon Bay Petrale Sole with kabocha, marble potatoes, brown butter almond sauce & grapes
3) San Francisco Ling Cod with bean brandade, clam garlic broth, olive crisp & meyer lemon confit
4) Gnocchi with mushroom ragout, parmesan fondue & crispy shallots
5) Dessert: Gingerbread Sable - a maple panna cotta with spiced pear sorbet, hazelnut cream, pomegranate gastrique
author: Racquel E.

description:
FOOD POISONING!

I have eaten here twice and both times I was left doubling over in wretched pain. The first time around I thought maybe I was having an allergic reaction to a mushroom dish. I started feeling queasy before I even left the restaurant! That's probably since I was there for so long. The staff was quite rude and the servers were completely inattentive. My party sat at the table without water or bread for one hour! When bread was served everyone was given exactly one piece each. Ha! The second time around I didn't eat anything. I only had a glass of water. Sure enough, I was up all night in severe pain and projectile vomiting afterwards. Absolutely atrocious!
author: Meg F.

description: I went to Salt House with a group of co-workers and several of us ordered the Halibut. At over $30 for the entree, my expectation is that the fish will be cooked properly. However, all of us had fish that were severely overcooked and dry. One of my co-workers said it tasted more like chicken than fish.
author: Annie L.

description:
WIKIPEDIA YOU ARE FIRED!!!

Back for a meal - FiDi kind of dinner. not too fond of eateries near work, i never feel satisfied with a bang for my buck. For conveniences with distance/location/time I was treated to very nice dinner here for some delicious eats. Reservations were made and highly recommended as the space isn't as big as it appears from the outside. We were seated on the second level which has minimal seats but the ambiance is very nice with dimmed lights casting over your pretty food plate. 

PROSECCO - I never sipped on a prosecco before. Imagine an Italian light champagne bubbly because that is exactly how I can describe it. It's not rough like regular champagne and goes down very smoothly. No acid reflex here!

KUSSHI (bc) - they say the smaller the creamier, not necessarily true. There was some sense of creaminess but the not creamiest oyster. The taste had a very "clean" taste to it which was more refreshing then the other oysters that are usually gritty. 

BEEF BAVETTE ($29) - fondant potatoes, raclette cheese broccoli, and long pepper jus. What is "Bavette"? According to Wikipedia it's pasta - LIES!!! It's not. It was a very tender pieces of steak. Portion to price, kind of small but it can fill someone who has a medium appetite. Highly Recommend.

ALASKAN HALIBUT ($28) - sunchoke puree, spiced baby carrots, concord grape vinaigrette. the thing about ordering fish at a restaurant if that you have to expect it flavored with other ingredients. white fish is my favorite kind of fish - its light and any sauce or dressing added will pick up nicely without overpowering the star item on the plate. this was perfectly cooked, hardly noticeable very light crisp outer edges with a very fluffy and tender inside. Highly Recommend.

PUMPKIN CHEESECAKE ($9) - cinnamon marsh mellow, pumpkin seed brittle. ITS PUMPKIN SEASON!!!!!!.I have a sweet-tooth and always need dessert to end a tasty meal. The portion is good for sharing between two people. The cheesecake was moist, creamy, and with hints of pumpkin with every dabble. The red dots on the plate made the dessert "pretty" but it was too sweet and was avoided after several attempts to mix it with the cheesecake. The pumpkin seed brittle is the round thing ontop of the cheesecake taking the shape of a cookie and tasted very similar to a very thin fortune cookie. Highly Recommend.

Will I be back? Maybe for lunch hour.

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: The food was delicious. Our group of 4 loved each of their meals and the drinks were also great. Would be 5 stars if the service was a bit better. Service was slow, especially since I was out on my lunch break.
author: Roxy P.

description: Came here with co-workers and we were literally in here for 30 mins and after they took all of our orders, one of the servers came up to our party of 15 and said that the table we were sitting in was reserved! Then they placed down the bill, started clearing the table and pretty much kicked us out. No real apologies or anything. Super rude. I will NEVER eat here again. Bad service, pretentious food, etc. the list goes on and on. They didn't even say thank you on the way out. Stay far away. Sure it seems nice but it's definitely not worth your time.
author: Foodie P.

description: Was planning on ordering food after a happy hour, was informed me and my entire table had to leave as the table was reserved for a reservation.
author: Brandon R.

description:
Well let's do the positive part first. The interior of this place is fabulous, a great mixture of casual and chic. The staff is helpful and service prompt.

The food however was a disappointment. We ordered the duck salad and A beat salad both of which were saturated in dressing and incredibly over salted, (maybe it's the name, LOL).

We had two salads and two of their non-nonalcoholic specialty drinks (nothing exciting) and the bill was $55. I won't be coming back
author: Bonnie W W.

description: Service was great, atmosphere nice, drinks amazing, cheesecake bomb, but......my entrée...it just wasn't up to par with the rest of my dining experience, which is a shame because that's supposed to be the highlight. I got the Creative King Salmon with grilled sushi rice and soy broth. Salmon was soft and cooked evenly with a little bit of pink but the soy broth quickly became too much. It got so salty that I couldn't enjoy the salmon nor the grilled rice. Ever left a meal feeling unsatisfied? Yup, that was me.
author: Thao T.

description:
So, apparently in San Francisco you need to make dinner reservations 1 year in advance if you want to go to any of the 4-5 star places on Yelp. Good to know for my next visit.

We decided to go to Salt House because it was literally the only place available on Open Table that could accommodate a party of 4. When we arrived (on a Saturday night at 8:00pm), the restaurant was completely empty. The hostess was very friendly and our server was as well. 

We ordered a round of cocktails right off the bat. Our server kept coming back to our table every 5 minutes to apologize that the bartender was backed up even though there was nobody at the bar or in the restaurant. After 20 minutes, our cocktails arrived. I will say that the cocktails were good, although not sure what happened with the delay. 

For appetizers, we ordered the olives and mixed nuts. The olives were drizzled in olive oil and the nuts were coated with honey. 

For entrees, Pauline and I had the Cod, Kristina had the Gnocchi, and Dan had the Salmon.

The Cod had a borderline chemical taste to it. Pauline said her dish didn't taste bad; but had no flavor at all. The cod was served with fried zucchini blossoms and sautéed zucchini. I'm guessing it was prepared in an oven since there was no searing on either side. If I had to guess, I'd say the portion weighed 4-5 ounces. This plate cost $32.

Dan had the Salmon which actually looked very good. Seared on both sides. Kristina said her gnocchi was cooked well, but she counted only 10 tiny dumplings. Needless to say, we ate every last nut and olive from our appetizer. 

With tip, our bill came to $240 for 4 people. That's 1 drink and a small entree each. For the price, we were severely underwhelmed. 

I think to bring more people in, they should have some heartier entrees for under $30. In a city where everyone has a Michelin Star, you have to do something different to bring people in. You shouldn't rely on the overflow from the surrounding restaurants.
author: Adam F.

description:
Salt House is not bad. For the price, however, you would expect just a bit more (in terms of flavor). Had the Poutine and it was certainly unique. Poutine is native to Canada, and usually it is not something you find in American restaurants too often. That being said, if you stop by Salt House be sure to get an order for yourself. It is a medley of cheese, fries, and gravy.

I also had the order of the Spicy Chicken Sandwich. It was about what I expected. The coleslaw and chicken went well together.

My complaint is that the food tastes pretty ordinary. Considering you are paying a decent amount for the food, the taste to price ratio is not symmetrical. Also the service is not incredible. The waiter rarely stops by to refill your water or help you.
author: David N.

description:
i had a fabulous girls lunch here yesterday and enjoyed every moment.  The service is fantastic from when you enter until you depart.  The salmon was tasty and the chicken salad is heavenly!  Bread is fresh, waiter attentive and crowded and bustling in a good way.
I will be back .
author: Sarah F.

description: The meal was excellent.  There were three of us for dinner.  We had the raw hammersley oysters, mushroom pate, roasted vegetables, foie grad creme brûlée, Japanese hamachi crude and octopus.  We had the halibut and the grilled sushi rice.  Flavors were so outstanding and delicious.  We also had a beautiful bottle of wine!  We shared the valrhona dark chocolate mouse with Concord grape sorbet and chocolate pearls.  This is a special place for a meal.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here for a work lunch and nothing to complain about!

Food:
+Poutine Fries- could use a bit more gravy, but overall tasty
+Shisito Peppers- proud of myself for tolerating the spice! ok. it wasn't that spicy :)
+ Mussels- delicious spicy lobster broth complemented the mussels perfectly
+ Complimentary bread and butter at table

Service:
+Friendly, with a smile and quick

Ambiance:
Open aired, rustic feel with a middle-age professional crowd at lunch

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description: Such a good decision. I was in SF for a conference and looking for something for a low key team dinner that was still on the nicer side of things. This place was perfect! It was so good that the next 2 nights, the people I was with ended up choosing Salt House for their professional dinners. They have a great wine list. The food was delicious. I ordered different things each night, and we all tried each others entrees - my advice is to try the seafood dishes on the menu. They were my favorite. Someone in our group the first night ordered the flat iron steak - it was delicious, but I would still stick with one of the fish entrees. If you're in the area of this place, my recommendation: don't miss it.
author: Tanya P.

description:
Went there for lunch. We thought it was busy but our waitres said it was kind of slow. Or server seemed to have a difficult time either hearing or understanding what we were saying. When she served our drinks she passed out 2 of the 4 drinks than spilled her tray. I guess accidents will happen. Though I saw her serving the table next to us and tipped over and cracked a glass. 

On to the food, I had the burger. Kind of funny when they served it. The condiments were on the side and it was as tall as my burger. I ate it like a salad. All in all not a bad burger.
author: Rob F.

description:
1- The bread was great! we ordered three rounds.
2- The service was not the best
3- atmosphere was very loud, noisy and rambunctious.
4- ceviche was fine.
5- entree (Atlantic cod) tasted like chlorine.  

In a nutshell we're not coming back.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 2 stars

I really thought I was going to enjoy this restaurant. Yelp pictures looked really good. High ceilings, very modern decor, and the atmosphere was inviting but I have two very big complaints...
