1. It's hella hot AF! No ventilation at all. I'm sitting at the table trying to fan myself because there's no damn ventilation. I start to feel more buzzed as the night goes on. Maybe this is a con to get you to buy more drinks? 
2. The waitress had the audacity to passive aggressively tell us our party didn't tip enough. 

Before I finish my complaint, let me get to the food. 

The evening was going great! Appetizers came out within a matter of 10 minutes, one after another the other.

Appetizers
-Salmon Rilette (second best app)
-Brussels sprouts 
-shishito peppers 
-oysters (best app we ordered) - ketchup and vinegar dipping sauces really added to the flavor and this is coming from a person who doesn't enjoy oysters. 

Entree
Short ribs and beef cheek with garlic puree - beef cheek was off the hook! I bit into the beef cheek and I was instantly wowed. Soft and tender and my teeth made contact within half a second. Instant foodgasm in my mouth. Short rib was cool but for medium rare, was a bit chewy. 

Drinks
The waitress recommended very fantastic wine. I give her tops for this but that was the best thing she was good at. Our whole group was conflicted on what Entree to order but she described each dish really well. She had me sold on the beef cheek even though I was aiming for the salmon or cod Entree. Had she not subtlety implied for more tip, she would've been great with us. We spent a good amount of money in the three digit range and tipped what was expected (20%), yet she still asked for more tip. 

"Was there something wrong with the food or service? I think this tip is kinda low."

....

Soooo Yeah, food is good but if you want to expect pretentious waitresses to  demand more tip, take your foodie cravings elsewhere.
author: Linda N.

description:
Expensive. Their size is of tapas, but at the full course price. 
Not only the cost, but it is hard to order as well. Especially for first timers.
How many dishes will be enough?
author: andy s.

description:
Salt house is fine.


The menu is boring, and expensive.   The food is fine.

I went here for a 'team building' work dinner.   I don't want to team build outside of 10-6.
author: Michael E.

description: First night in SF &  was advised to have dinner here.  No disappointments. A+ for attentive and diligent staff.   Happy to return... and I did!  Buy shear coincidence... my colleagues to lunch here the next day.  Duck salad was awesome.   Service again rated A+.   Will return soon.
author: Mike S.

description:
Mmmm, pappardelle.  I love pappardelle, and this one doesn't disappoint!  Lately, it has been rare to find a dish that I would want to go back to a restaurant for, especially at the mid range $$$ and especially at a California or American cuisine restaurant.  But I am going to be remembering this one for a little while.  I even reluctantly let my family members try my dish, and they all said it was really good, with some saying it was the best at the table.   

A couple of side notes, slightly spicy, and a smaller dish, but I was full from the Giants game so it was plenty for me.  

Others at the table had the rib eye and pork, both not bad, but not remarkable.  My daughter had a cauliflower ravioli which was good.  Also, had to pay around $8 for bread....

Been here a couple of times and always thought it was good, but like Town Hall a little better, but I guess I missed the pappardelle.

Service was good, and they were able to make a pasta for my youngest.

Come back? Yes please, pappardelle!
author: Jeff N.

description:
Not what it used to be. I thought it would be a safe bet, but I was disappointed with the food and the ambience.

First, it's now a popular place for happy hour. And apparently some people take their drunken happiness to dinner there afterwards--table next to ours.

Second, I didn't like some of the new dishes on the menu. Mushroom pate was a bit of an overkill. And the chips they were served with couldn't handle the denseness or saltiness of the mushroom concoction. For dinner, I had cod which was served zucchini or some type of squash it did not go well with.

Waitress was nice.

But the price was not worth the experience.
author: G F.

description:
Dear Chef,

Kindly take a trip to Roli Roti at the Ferry Building to see how a REAL porchetta should look AND taste like.

For your convenience, here's the link: http://www.yelp.com/biz/roli-roti-gourmet-rotisserie-san-francisco.

Thank you in advance,
Miss Wannabe Bauer

OTHER NOTES:
*Goat Porchetta ($35) took 40 minutes to arrive and it arrived room temperature: http://bit.ly/153pUou. No apps were even ordered.
*Nice presentation but it was horribly executed. It was like gnawing on cellulite coated chewing gum. The skin was chewy (no crackling crust) and the meat was extremely tough and sinewy. It was also very bland; where's the herbs, yo? IMO, this dish should have never left the kitchen.
*Friendly albeit slow service.
*Porchetta + one cocktail + tax + 4% SF health tax + tip = Worst $60 I've ever spent in my life.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: We had great expectations for this place became e we've been here before. We ordered a split of a glass of bubbles followed by a bottle of Pinot. Our server was attentive when we first ordered then it was like pulling teeth to get service. Our split glass of bubbles arrived when we were nearly finished with our appetizers.  Our bottle of wine arrived while we were waiting for our appetizers. We were totally cool with that and asked that it breath while we finished out bubbles. Our first course arrived and it was thrust at us like we were a nuisance. Our second course arrived 30 minutes later and was undercooked. We sent it back and the manger came by to apologize. Then the server returned with the more cooked salmon and dropped it in front of us. Then he asked it the temperature was ok and walked away. Not cool. We own restaurants and would expect better service Salt House.
author: Andrea M.

description: Come on!  The $17 fall veggie salad was a joke.  Maybe a tablespoon of rainbow quinoa, a few limp pieces of squash on top of an unappealing mound of arugula.  If I hadn't gotten the chicken (added cost) I would have left as hungry as I went in.  Seriously.  Skimping on quinoa and squash, two cheap ingredients?   This salad provably cost them $1.50.  Rip off.
author: Gregg M.

description:
For a real foodie person this place is SO mediocre! I feel like I ate at some random bar in Ohio! This is San Francisco, people! Let me introduce you to quality food! 

We ordered: 

Fois Gras: Probably the worst one I've ever had! Please don't waste your money on that! 

Rock Fish Ceviche: Just okay! 

Steak dish: was served semi-cold, tasted okay. The side veggies were tasty! 

Wine per bottle: quite pricey for this place!  A $60 bottle of wine tastes like a $10 bottle! ( We know our wine!) 

Bottom line: 

Please don't waste your money if you appreciate food. We are going back to Lolinda! It's a waste here!
author: Ghazal P.
Bonnie Z.

description: I've been here a couple times; food is great and last time the service was good as well. Last night I made a reservation on open table and mentioned it's a birthday. I approached the hostess and told her as well but it didn't seem like she relayed the message to the server (who was also very moody and unpleasant). Anyways I had to tell him in front of everyone again that we were celebrating birthdays. My ribs I asked for medium came out rare. The mushroom pâté was ok; but it was presented very nice. The pappardelle was delicious and the halibut was good as well. The best part of the meal was the vanilla creme brûlée. Order it and you will not regret it!!
author: Yas G.

description: Our server Marissa was so delightful and refreshing.  She was so informative, not only did she make this already beautiful atmosphere more pleasant she made it worth every reason to come back!!  Can't wait to request her again!
author: Charlotte S.

description:
I've only been to Salt House for lunch, but it has been on my radar for years. This spot has been an established SoMa eatery for some time, and I'm glad I finally was able to sample the fare here. My initial impressions? I think I need to return for dinner. 

As far as lunch goes, the menu is a mix of accessible, lunch-y options like soup, sandwiches and salads, alongside a few higher-end, fancied up entrees. The portions are on the small side, and the prices are on the large end, so you're definitely spending cash for the ambiance and quality of fare. Is it there? Sort of. The food is definitely good, but I don't think it merits the extra $$$ over some of the fantastic, more casual spots around the area. Sentinel's sandwiches are easily as good as the one I sampled, and the entrees are delicate enough to leave a hungry guy still hungry. And if you're dining on an expense account with normal limits, you'll easily exceed those. 

However this format always lends itself better to dinner than to lunch. I'm hoping there's a little more bang for your buck after 5pm. The flavors and ingredients are quality, and the service trends toward upscale dining. I can see dropping extra dollars here for a longer dinner dining experience. 

Compared to the caliber of food I've become accustomed to in Portland and SF at this price point, Salt House is definitely good but could stand to knock it up a notch. I'll happily come back again for more, and hopefully dinner on a future visit.
author: Don B.

description:
3.5 Stars.Great ambience and modern decor, but food was better than average at best and just lacked the flavor profiles that would make me a repeat customer at this price point. 

The poutin ($15) was great but it's hard to mess up fries with gravy and mozzarella cheese curds. 

The braised beef shortribs ($26) was what really fell short here. The shortribs itself was tender enough but just a tad on the stringy side. If you're a fan of fatty melt-in-your mouth deliciousness, then this will scratch the itch but not quite hit the spot. The kale on the side was true to the name Salt House - wayyyy too salty, while the herbed breadcrumbs were bland as cardboard.
author: Catherine C.

description:
An interesting space with a very high ceiling but also a small loft like dining area with a half dozen additional tables. 

I was seated quickly. Service was very fast and friendly. Very good bread to start off with. 

A very good list of wines by the glass. They have a "rare opportunity" feature of high end wines that are rarely available by the glass. In this category the Delamotte champagne was a great experience. The Domaine Ramonet Chassagne-Montrachet was sublime. 

Oysters were fresh and shucked perfectly. One faux pas was that the server didn't ask if I wanted more. I would have ordered another half dozen. 

The roasted cauliflower soup was excellent! I'm normally not much of a cauliflower fan but this was delicious. 

The black cod with clams, white beans, orange wedges, and crispy Brussels sprouts was stellar ! A world class balance of flavors.

An excellent dinner, I highly recommend the Salt House.
author: Chris S.

description: BIG thanks and appreciation to Neil - for all your efforts in ensuring great customer service. Thank you for retrieving receipt for my boss's expense report. Thank you for your consistency, diligence, patience, politesse, and most importantly, for being accessible.
author: Bisrat T.

description: Enjoyed a lovely birthday dinner at this historic yet posh eatery. The food was better than expected and the welcome and service was pleasant. Our server was very friendly and we felt well served yet not rushed. I would highly recommend this spot for girlfriends night out, couples romantic evening out or smart casual dining.
author: Rosilyn H.

description:
Nothing special. Very loud and while the food looked very cool, in the end it was just okay.  I ordered the pickled quail eggs and asked the server if they are soft. He said yes so I assumed I would be getting warm eggs with a soft center. Instead the were hard boiled and chilled.  Meh. I also ordered the sole, which the server said would be light and refreshing. The dish was over-salted and slightly over-cooked. 

My colleagues liked their meals better, and at $200 for the three of us (with wine by the glass and no desert), it wasn't over the top expensive.
author: David K.

description:
I've become quite the Salt House slut.  Near my office, I take people here all the time.  

Pluses:
-Changing menu and usually the food is good.
-Nice atmosphere.
-Solid service.
-Culinary highlights:  shisito peppers, fried chicken sandwich, all cocktails
-Wine list always solid.

Minus
-Duck salad disappointing.  Very frustrating that this has to be the one weak menu item.
author: Rob R.

description:
Went here with my friend tonight and had an okay experience. 
I think it's really 2.5stars. 


We got:
-salmon belly
-asparagus
-tuna crude
-poutine

And wine.

Each food item is very small for the price. Presentation is beautiful but not sure some of the stuff actually go well together. 

Nice atomosphere but food was kind of disappointing.
Service was ok. The waitress just took my glass of wine in the end although I hadn't finished yet. That was rude. 


I don't think i will go back.
author: C M.

description:
Slowest. Service. Of. My. Life. Literally.

Went there for a corporate meal with a party of 6 and the wait for even water was ridiculous.
The taste of the food wasn't too bad but by the time the food got to the table, we were all more or less over it.

Got the lamb tacos, tasted good, but were literally the messiest tacos i've ever eaten. It dripped with oil and literally made a puddle of oil on my plate.

Don't think i'll be coming back anytime soon unless I had to with another company event.
author: Janet L.

description: I come here often as I work at the building next door. The food is always ok(over priced for what it is). The drinks are good and come quickly- recommend their take on the Moscow mule. But what kills me about this place is they are super picky about seating you without a reservation. Last night we came at 7pm to a pretty empty restaurant and they said nope all the tables are reserved. Surely, a Tuesday night at 7 for a mediocre restaurant in soma isn't all the sudden going to be packed....
author: Lisa B.

description:
Yeah, I kinda love this place as I'm a sucker for high ceilings, old school industrial fixtures etc.  And for gastropubs.  Highlights!

- Poutine.  OK, so maybe I shouldn't call this a highlight... I'm kinda a poutine snob ever since I experienced this magic in Montreal.  Anyway, the cheese curds here were a more runny and cottage cheese-y than squeaky and savory.  Not for me.

- BUT the foie gras mousse was excellent.  Super rich and creamy which is the way it's supposed to be.

- The Green door was a great cocktail: cucumber and vodka and other stuff... you know the drill.

- A surprise: the mixed nuts were magical - coated in truffle oil, they tasted a bit like movie popcorn.... and the walnuts in the mix were vastly superior to the peanuts in there.  Order it and skip the peanuts!

- And also the pickled quail eggs with Asian sauces were money too.  But tiny, as expected.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I have been to many many restaurants and I have to say the service is horrible at this establishment. Made reservation for two on 12/12/15 for me and my girlfriend. Initial thoughts were the decor and the style of the restaurant looked great. The Brussels and poutine were good but our main course was not. I had the Ribeye and expected it to be much better, it was too chewy and the portion was laughable. My girlfriend had the chicken and she was not satisfied at all and couldn't even finish.

It took quite awhile to get our food especially when all of it was ordered together. During the course of our dinner the waitress was walking with a tray and accidentally spilled red wine all over my shirt. This was Saturday at at around 8 still had the rest of the night to go do things. I am not a jerk and did not make a scene. The waitress who spilled the drink ended up being the manager, after about 7 minutes she walked up to our table with a napkin and seltzer water to clean my shirt. She said sorry but wasn't fazed by the situation. She said if I couldn't get it cleaned to let her know. The waiter didn't even acknowledge the situation and came around maybe 2 times during our dinner. Expected more especially after pay $130 for dinner. Won't be going there again.
author: z h.

description:
Walked by this place a thousand times but never had the chance to dine here. Decided to try it out before watching Kurios. LUV: this would probably be the layout of my house! I love everything about the decor, high ceiling, wooden tables, large windows, the stairs that lead up to the second level(where we requested to sit) with some original brick walls. Arrived at 6:15pm and the place was still empty and quiet, perfect timing for conversations. 

Our waiter and helpers were friendly. Water and bread came immediately. Wine choices by the glass was plenty. Food is simple but yummy, (huge portions too). Had the chips, salad and I went for the porkchop (scrumptious), can probably feed three people. Place got super packed around 7:15pm but they never rushed us while we chomp down a huge chocolate dessert with coffee. 

Will return for bday =)
author: Vee V.

description:
Awesome food, service and ambience.
Parking is quite difficult that I had to park 4 blocks away.
Had the cod for dinner and it was very tasty
Ordered a bottle of Chardonnay for dinner and it definitely complemented  our entree's.
author: Claudine V.

description: Everything was amazing. I wish I tasted the chicken though... couldn't get through to eat more than a piece cause I was fighting with stripping it off the deep fried armor that I think was the skin? What a workout. Good times, sat next to a really cool guy.
author: Mila C.

description: This classic lunch spot that I've been to dozens of times over the years is usually great. The food is consistently good, the servers are always friendly and attentive. But it seems they've decided the hostess doesn't need to adhere to the same standards as the rest of the staff. Rude is an understatement. As someone that actually writes for a living, I'm having trouble finding the right word here to describe her and our interaction from moments ago. Unnecessarily condescending, short and adhering to a ridiculous and inconsistent policy of only seating full parties (we are a party of two) even with a reservation and the acknowledgement that I planned to order a glass of wine while I waited. I was instructed to sit at the bar. I said I'd rather sit at my reserved table and wait for my guest, freeing up a converted spot at the bar during a crowded lunch rush. She said, under her breath that I was a "dick." Well guess what honey, this dick is sitting in your restaurant, we've made eye contact several times as I've typed this. I hope next time I'm here, you're not. Note to management: fire this uppity, bespectacled, hipster wanna be.
author: Rob B.

description:
To be fair, Salt House's happy hour isn't too work friendly unless you jet right after work but if get the chance to play a little hooky, you should definitely stop in for some cocktails plus you get to avoid the crowds that come in later. 

We sat around the bar on a weekday around 3pm and enjoyed lovely service from our bartender. He was cordially chatty and informative plus he made one darn good cocktail with that Ancho Mule. It's a deceivingly well balanced cocktail of vodka, ancho chile liqueur and lime that doesn't taste exceptionally strong but beware - it packs a punch. Salthouse also has a variety of wines and beers which I enjoyed my Calicoast IPA quite a bit. 

They have a couple of food specials at happy hour but it's a pity that those end at 5pm. Still with such delicious drinks and friendly service, we can be thankful for drink specials that last an hour longer so hurry out from work if you can.
author: Jon L.

description:
Mediocre food but amazing wine.  They've got your fish, chicken, pork, and beef dish. Nothing exciting.  But I will say, the most memorable Pinot Noir I've ever had was here. Also, don't be fooled by the name.  Everything is not overly salty.  

Their famous poutine is also very undeserving of its fame.  Those who find it good most likely had too much to drink and praise it as if they would carne asada fries at 3am.

I'll reiterate once again: come for the wine and ambiance, not the food.
author: Michele L.

description:
HORRIBLE SERVICE !!! NEVER going back...

 We went there on a Tuesday around 5pm. There were four in our party. The place was pretty much empty. The hostess walked us to a table and asked us if we would be done by 7pm. We thought that was strange, but we said yes, probably. When the waiter arrived at our table, he took our drinks order and asked if we would be done by 7:30pm. We all look at each other like what is going on here. We asked him why the staff keeps asking us if we'd be done by a certain time, and he replied that our "Clientele" starts coming in for dinner around that time. We all thought, so who are we???? After FUMING for a few minutes, we all left the table and left the restaurant. The waiter and the manager had looks on their faces like, why are they leaving, lol.  

Start treating your patrons with a little more class people...Oh and the only reason they get one star is because the place itself looked pretty cool.
author: Mike D.

description:
came here for a bday dinner

ordered:
-shisito peppers: good

-chips (taro,yam,yukon,purple) and yuzu aioli: good

-poutine w beef cheeks: salty!! do not get! 

-oysters w ponzu, pineapple granita, cilantro: wow so sweet, we all wanted more

-roasted cauliflower: ok

-octopus w gnocci, pork belly, chimichurri, chard: a-ok, but a little too much going on

-pork and shrimp tortellini: clam broth, chili sauce, chinese mustard greens.. tasted like it could 
be served at dim sum.. the flavors were good but there was way too much salt! 

-foie gras w blueberries: wow amazing

-pork chop: barley, kholrabi, walnuts, pear puree.. best entree dish 

-chai ice cream

-rosemary honey ice cream

-maple panna cotta w almonds and brittle.. i liked having the crunch of brittle and almond w every bite of smooth panna cotta

-apple tart

even though everything was ok, there was way too much salt used in some of the dishes
author: Raquel T.

description:
Pretty good food, but overall an unpleasant experience due to poor customer service. We made a reservation well in advance, but were crammed at a table that did not fit our party size.

My coworker's credit card was then charged for more than what was on the receipt (even including tax), and the staff has done nothing to fix this and has made it extremely inconvenient to fix it or even look into the matter.

A customer shouldn't have to call the restaurant every single day for a week AND show up to the restaurant just to speak with a staff member and STILL not get an answer.

Please step your customer service game up! It matters!
author: Bre S.

description:
Salt House was in the right location for a recent dinner, so I went with a friend. I'd been there before...a looong time ago...and remembered it as being decent. 

The service was really lovely. Everyone who took care of us, from the busboys on up, was great. The space is a bit cavernous, with a half-loft as you walk in, and the rest open and high, but the noise level was completely bearable. I could hear my companion talk, and could easily ignore those sitting around us, which is what you need in a place in the financial area. It's a cool spot, and the ambiance reflects that.

However, the food was uneven. We started with the winter fruit and vegetable salad, and the composition was really strange. Three *extremely* salty heirloom-style lettuce chunks (and by salty, I mean it made me pucker like crazy), and maybe five very small pieces of roasted fruits/vegetables (two kinds of squash, pear, mushroom, and something else I couldn't figure out) over pureed celeriac. Needless to say, it was not a very successful dish. The roasted nuts with sea salt and honey were outstanding, however. I could have eaten two whole dishes of that, solo.

For my main, I got the steak. The steak was fine--cooked properly, cut into six generous strips, and served with small potatoes and onions over mushroom sauce and raclette cheese. The steak wasn't the best I've ever had, but it was completely serviceable. Unfortunately, the fish my companion got was bland. It was served with some tasty brussels sprouts, but honestly, even with the crust, it could have used some salt.

This place has been around a long time--almost eight years--and so they must be doing something right. However, I don't know that I'd take a companion back unless they wanted to go.
author: Lis B.

description:
I threw caution to the wind today and ignored Yelp reviews.  Meh.  I made reservations to come for a business lunch, thinking this would be an excellent meal that was sure to impress. 

We were both excited walking in, and ordering.  The atmosphere is fantastic.  We both ordered the chicken salad, and shared some shishito peppers and nuts to start.  The peppers were fantastic and perfectly roasted.   The first peanut I tried was stale and it seemed like they had been roasted to hide this fact; the rest turned out to be just fine (not great).  The nuts were so hot when they arrived at the table that my colleague burned himself.  

Then our salads came.  Here's the thing....romaine or a heartier lettuce can withstand the grill and turn out quite delicious.  But the baby gem lettuce in this salad just becomes wilted and grossly warm.  Top that with a couple of slices of apple (maybe 4-5) and a few SMALL bites of chicken (again, maybe 4-5 MAX) that could honestly have come from a can, some sort of warm, mayonnaisey dressing, and you definitely do NOT have a $21 salad entree.  Not even close.   

I remember going to Town Hall for a very special date with my husband once several years ago when we really could not afford it, and thinking that Town Hall had a great reputation so we would definitely love it.  Our experience then and my experience today were similar.  This restaurant is overrated.  Thankfully this meal was on the company or I'd be livid.    

The one good part of our meal was dessert.  We had two wonderfully plated desserts - a caramel apple pie thing and a caramel chocolate cake.  Both were spectacular, but the only part of lunch that was at all memorable in a good way.  

We both had tap water, and the bill came to $85 before tip.  So $106 later and I'm still hungry.  Very disappointing.
author: Cori D.

description: The chef always impresses me and the food is delicious! We also had great service. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Creative and tasty food prepared with seasonal ingredients. On the pricey side.

I have been there several times already and always sat at the bar, partly because it gets very busy during lunch on weekdays. Fortunately the barmaids are friendly.

Their grilled cheese with soup on the side and salad is a good deal. Their burger is pretty good too!
Last time I went there I had the Humbolt fog cheese with delicious sweet peanuts, and the braised short ribs in Mac and cheese.

Not a daily go-to place due to the pricing, but happy to go back from time  to time.
author: Bruno P.

description:
i've been to salt house on a variety of occasions - business lunches, dinner with friends, lots of drinks.. and i LIKE it. but by no means do i love it...

was just here for lunch with a group of 6 - the new team at work. we ordered for apps - olives, shishito peppers, mussels, tuna tartar to start. then the group decided to do chicken confit and the branzino as entrees - 3 of each. not even sure how that happened. 

the apps were good - shishito peppers were definitely my fave, but theyre kind of hard to mess up. mussels also had pretty good flavor, and the soup is great for dipping the epi bread, which they're quick to replenish if you would like.  tuna tartar had this interesting color to it...so i didnt try it. oops.

entrees came out WAYYY too fast to be normal. i guess we were there for a later lunch and they wanted to clear out the restaurant, but it was still unusual.  the chicken confit was kinda bland! SAD! and i had asked for fries instead of the smashed potatoes, and this was not the case at first... but they did bring me a side of fries, which were steaming hot and crunchy and great with their housemade ketchup.

my coworkers paid $6 for their non alcoholic 'refreshers' to accompany their meals, but no one seemed thrilled about them.  we also ordered the salted caramel cake to share as dessert.. and that went SUPER fast.  so perhaps come for their happy hour and dessert, not their food? meeps!
author: Christina L.

description:
Meh.

Salt House is way over priced for what it is. I feel like you can find the same exact menu all over San Francisco, except cheaper and better executed elsewhere. The overall vibe of the restaurant is very mid-late 00's Edison bulb / darker woods, etc. It's not necessarily a bad restaurant, and is convenient to SFMOMA for sure, but you could get more for your money at similar restaurants nearby.
author: Tini T.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for a long time since it's just around the corner of my office, but i was a little let down!

we started off with the poutine fries. I think i've had better poutine at other places but it's definitely a different dish that not many other places offer. the fries were really soggy and that was before the gravy was poured over so it must have been the cheese that ruined the consistency. 

I came here for lunch so i ordered their salt house burger with blue cheese. I asked for medium but it came out way over cooked. The onion rings was a little over cooked too.

Other than the decor and the atmosphere, nothing really stood out.
author: Andy H.

description:
Salt House is a great restaurant for lunch and dinner. Thoughtful wine list (~30 Pinot Noirs among other types) and seasonal tasty fare.  Make sure you have a reservation - this place is popular for a good reason.

The staff is friendly and helpful, particularly the hostess (thank you Abby) and bartenders.

I've eaten here for lunch, late afternoon drinks, and large (8-person) business dinners.  Highly recommended and within walking distance of Moscone Center yet off the beaten path.
author: Sam R.

description:
Here are some tips...
You have to ask for things that you might expect to be included, like bread or ice.  Ask for water, it comes room temp no ice. "We don't do ice, in the water, it's a thing". It's not a thing, it says we don't give a crap about you, and your water. The ice probably tastes worse than the water and they are obviously too cheap or lazy to buy a filter.  The food was ok, so was the waiter, sure wish I knew the bread trick before I finished my meal.  Too bad the owner lets something as simple and cheap as ice, water and bread drag down this review, but think about this, if they don't care enough about the customer in these little things, how is the rest that you don't see.
author: Jason L.

description: While this is one of my favorite places in SF, I literally had the worst experience ever. The bar, which is my favorite place to sit was absolutely terrible. The bar tender went out of her way to not acknowledge us. We also ordered an appetizer and she forgot to put it in, and actually told us after our main dish had arrived that the oysters were on the way. When we told her we didn't want it anymore she rolled her eyes. Considering there were only 2-4 people sitting at the bar the level of service could've been a lot better. Really disappointed to have experienced such terrible service, would've expected more.
author: Ankur A.

description: This place is OK.  A nice environment and a vibrant crowd.  I found the menu choices at lunch a little limited, but the food was generally good.  It's a busy work related crowd at lunch, given the neighborhood, and I think I preferred the evening seating and menu on a previous visit.
author: Guy B.

description:
Much hype about this place and I thought it was just OK. (knocked off another star due to "THE UGLY" below)

- - - - - - - - - - - - THE UGLY
- Server brought us 2 water glass and a water bottle/ pitcher.  We poured ourselves some water and WALA!  THERE'S A FLY!!!  (not sure if it was in the cup or water)  ... EWWW!!!  Completely GROSSED OUT!!!

We immediately told our server and there's no apology/ compensation -- she didn't even apologize but simply said "Oops!"  Then returned a minute later with another water glass and a new water pitcher.  She then poured us a new glass of water and said, "It's all clear."  I'm like:  WTF!?!?!?!?    (I was with a client so did not make a scene or any remark.  I just smirked and she walked away happily ... OMG!!)

- - - - - - -  THE BAD
- Everything was too salty.  I know it's the "Salt House" but dishes at Farallon are not "watered down" either!  
- Party of 2, we had:  Poutine (waay too salty), Soup (ok), Scallop (salty), Duck Confit (salty but a tad more bearable) + 2 drinks (1 good, 1 ok).
- Atmosphere is quite loud.  Tables are quite close together and difficult to have conversations.

 - - - - - - - THE GOOD: 
- In busy SOMA district but they have valet parking for $8;or metered parking is not too difficult to find if you have the time to go around the block once or twice. (meter takes credit cards too)
- Restaurant decor is very nice, hip and unique.  We got a table on the 2nd floor and it's quite nice.
- Hostess service is great: warm, friendly welcome and accommodating.

- - - - - - - OVERALL:  NO THANKS!
- For nearly $70, party of 2, there are waaaay too many quality / better restaurants in the area.  NO THANKS - WILL NOT BE BACK.
author: Winnie W.

description:
Salt House is a trendy upscale restaurant right on Mission between 1st and 2nd. They are part of the Stock And Bones group (owners of Anchor & Hope and Town Hall) so I had high expectations for them. Unfortunately, I thought they were just ok.

Salt House is smaller than A&H and Town Hall, but they've crammed as many tables as possible into their modest space, creating a very crowded and noisy environment. My hearing isn't the best, having abused my ear drums with Oingo Boingo cranked to ten through headphones during my teenage years, so carrying on a conversation with others can be a challenge here.

Tip: Get a reservation. Lunch or dinner, it doesn't matter. Open table through their website. Super easy. Or be prepared to wait.

Onto the food!

There were four of us and we were pretty hungry, having to wait for a 1pm reservation, so we dove right in with appetizers: a dozen oysters and an order of poutine. They only had one kind of oyster on the menu: Kusshi from British Columbia. The kusshis were characteristically small, sweet, and clean. As someone who prefers the brinier East Coast varieties, I was a bit underwhelmed, but ate my trio nonetheless. I recognize that if oysters are what you are looking for, you skip Salt House and proceed directly to Anchor and Hope, but I thought that being with the same owner group, the quality and taste would be to par and I didn't think they matched up very well.

The poutine consisted of perfectly fried French fries, with a nice crispy outer shell, covered in a white mozzarella cheese sauce and gravy. It was fairly light on the curds. My friend described them as being very good "unless you're a poutine snob." Now I don't consider myself a poutine snob, but I am from Canada (believe it or not) and I have enjoyed my share of Montreal poutine. I didn't think the poutine here was very good. The flavors were just too far to the bland side. Still, a decent effort.

Ok, maybe I am a poutine snob....

For lunch, I had the grilled chicken sandwich. It was served on an crusty artisan bun with a very light salad. The sandwich itself was excellent and if I did come back I would have no problem ordering it again. My friends got the heirloom tomato sandwich (x 2) and the duck confit hash. The hash looked amazing, save for the fried egg that sat on top of it. I don't eat eggs, but if I did, I might have given the confit a try. He seemed to enjoy it.

All in all, it was a good lunch, my disappointment likely a result of high expectations. The service wasn't too friendly, but certainly very efficient. They had us in and out within an hour.

On the downside, they were on the pricey side. All in all, the lunch for four set us back $180, but that's sorta what you expect when you come.

Salt House was certainly good enough to come back to, but given the wealth of amazing restaurants in very close proximity, I'm not sure if I will be back...
author: Devin A.

description: The grilled pork sandwich with broccoli rabe was absolutely delicious. The piquillo pepper sauce was mild and added moistness to the sandwich. There was a nice balance between the ratio of protein to veggies, so each bite provided a bit of each. The sandwich comes with a side of house made potato chips which were less than desirable given that they were very thin and had a lackluster crisp. I'd swap the potato chips for a side salad or something in general. After polishing off the entire sandwich, which is a reasonable portion, I was a bit taken aback when the waiter commented on my ability to finish the plate.... "Girrrrrrl, you did good. You must have really liked it!". I didn't mind the comment but was a little surprised given the atmosphere feels a little more "upscale".
author: Julia K.

description:
There's a lot to like about this bustling SOMA restaurant.
As you walk in to Salt House, the energy is palpable. The place is buzzing with hungry diners and attractive FiDI business types. Although our party of 6 had a 12:30pm reservation (which is definitely recommended, BTW), we still had to wait 10 minutes before we were finally seated. So be warned: if you are coming in for lunch, allow more than an hour to dine. But I'm totally cool with taking my time, because this is a special place. The food and dining experience here is something to be savored - not rushed.

Our table wound up splitting some appetizers, including the refreshing citrus salad, the ahu tuna tartar with avocado/peanut sauce/potato chips, and their delicious (yet artery-clogging) Poutine - which is essentially French Fries topped with mozzarella cheese curds and short-rib gravy. All of the above items were winners. And our friendly server brought out fresh baked bread with creamy butter. Even if you hate carbs, this chewy bread is hard to pass up.

The only thing that was kind of a let-down was my main dish. I ordered the Grilled Chicken Banh Mi (a Vietnamese inspired sandwich topped with sambal yuzu aioli green papaya & mango slaw). The sandwich was fine - just nothing memorable. And let's face it - for a fraction of the price, you can get a much better/more authentic Banh Mi in the Tenderlon @ Saigon Sandwich.

Since it was a working lunch, we abstained from wine and ordered the Bruce Adams - a delightful Mocktail made with grapefruit, ginger, lemon, and soda water. De-lish!

Service is friendly and top-notch. Everyone from the hostess to the waitress made us feel like a V.I.P. 

Since their menu is seasonal, I'm looking forward to coming back in a month or two to try out their latest offerings.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I went to lunch here with a friend.  Both of us ordered the burgers with Parmesan fries.  The burgers were huge!  Bigger than what you will get at In N Out.   I asked for mine to be cooked medium well. It was a tad overdone because parts of it were crunchy (burnt meat).  

For dessert, I ordered the Meyer lemon cheesecake.  First of all it wasn't the standard heavy cheesecake.  This was light and airy.  The lemon was superb. Crust was a little soggy.  

Service was friendly and attentive.  They poured our water for us every single time even though the carafe was next to us. 

Bathrooms were clean but was located in the building's lobby so you have to exit the restaurant to use the bathroom.  

Overall, Salt House was great!
author: Wendy H.

description:
*Review is for happy hour only*

A group of about 20 coworkers stopped in for happy hour on a Thursday, just before 5. There were a few other tables occupied but it wasn't crowded yet. We decided to post up in the bar area which served our group size really well. Bartenders and wait staff were super attentive. Yes it was crowded, but surprisingly easy to order even as the restaurant filled up.

Great happy hour deals on wine, beer, and snacks. We didn't eat, but I'm incented to come back after a good first go!
author: Brianna M.

description:
Where to begin?? This is going to be a long one. Let's start with atmosphere, awesomely amazing! This place has a cool chic old is the new thing vibe. From brick walls to oversize light bulb lights, this place screams I'm hip and chic. 
The wait staff is amazing they are really on top of their game! My water glass is always full, even in a drought, and my server, Kelsey. What a sweetheart on top of her game. Not rushing us, and gave us great service. 
Now for meat and potatoes of the review so to speak. THE FOOD!!! We started with what everyone of yelp has posted about the pouting, they weren't kidding they were right. Amazing!! Potatoes and dressing how can you go wrong. Then the oysters well It all depends on the oysters themselves and the kushis are what they always are... superb, with garlic, lemon, horseradish, and cocktail sauce. Yummy!! Now for the main entree I ordered the cod. Wow!!! Zucchini blossoms with stuffed olives for the side dish. Rib eye was excellent as well. The side dishes of greens (lamb quarters) with cherries, and mushrooms!!! Wow!! I could order just that. 
To end the night with coconut pana cotta!! A beautiful evening! Let's not forget the wine!
author: Danielle G.

description:
The four stars is definitely for the service!  My party hadn't arrived yet, and the hostess kept an eye on me until they arrived.  There were a lot of people coming in, mostly with reservations and I was afraid I wouldn't get a table because I didn't have one.  But she was so accommodating and I didn't wait long for a table.

The food was really good.  I ordered salmon with chanterelle mushrooms and fava beans.  I was hoping for a bigger portion, especially for the price, but it was nonetheless delicious.  And we ordered to desserts to share: the raspberry cream tart and the brown butter cream cheese pound cake.  The tart was had just the right amount of sweetness and tartness.  The pound cake wasn't served sliced.  They were cut into half-dollar size circles on top of whipped cream with scattered strawberries.  It was really good, and I'm glad it wasn't a bigger piece because it can tell it would be heavy.

The atmosphere was lively for a Monday night, and I like the industrial decor.  I'd like to come back and try the poutine!
author: Vira P.

description: Been here a couple of times because its proximity to work. Service and ambience are cool. Food is average especially appetizers. Poutine, cheese and Sweet chips were nothing special. Enjoyed sishito peppers and salmon with mushroom puree. Beef burger was pretty average and had me wishing that I had gone to Super Duper instead.
author: Umer M.

description: We had a great experience at Salt House. The food was unique and delicious! Our waiter, I can't remember his name, was extremely helpful and attentive to our party. The rib eye was delicious and the corn soup scrumptious! If you have the opportunity, try Salt House!
author: Amy B.

description: They took us with a moments notice on a Monday night. We had the poutine- a must have. The chips- basic but still delicious and then the octopus- a tad beachy by means of sand- to start. Followed by ravioli with goat cheese which was noticeably absent due to a gelatin shell and a phenomenal rib eye that was perfectly bloody. Now on to the creme brûlée- yum
author: Danielle D.

description:
I came here for a late dinner my first night in San Francisco -- just 8pm PST but my body told me 11pm EST. So I wasn't too adventurous with my ordering. In fact, I ordered just one dish -- "White polenta, spring vegetables, grana padrano" ($23). Lots of veggies -- broccolini, carrots, asparagus, squash, lima beans, and a vegetable I couldn't identify. Polenta was yummy. I definitely felt "healthy" afterwards :) 

Honestly being in San Francisco, I would've preferred to order seafood but there was a strong fishy smell when I walked in. Also if I wasn't so tired, I would've liked to try the "mixed nuts w/ truffle honey" and the "braised short rib" (instead of the veggie dish) -- since they got some very positive reviews. 

Service was friendly, and ambiance was dim but lively.
author: Addy C.

description:
Food delicious high quality ingredients . Everything was delicious and fresh, delightfully simple menu. 

Service was meh, not great nor terrible. They were a little  slow in taking our order and the server struggled with my guest's accent, which as a little annoying. But over all it was alright. She took a bit of time in taking my check etc. I think if the service was a little more attentive  I would have been happier with my experience.
author: Susan Z.

description: Definitely! It's in that weird part of the city where you don't see a soul on the street during the weekends, but who cares! The food was incredible, specifically the fish. I tried three different kinds from friends plates and my own and believe it to be some of the best I have had in the city! You better believe the cocktails are just as good. Make sure you get the POMARETTO SOUR.
author: Sara N.

description:
Really nice decor and not crazy expensive.
Service was also quite fast.
I tried the chop chop salad with fish , the serving plate had an antique touch to it and the food was great and fresh, loved the texture of fish. But I would say there were not many options in the lunch menu though. 

Oh and hibiscus cooler is a must try, it's a perfect cooling summer drink.
author: Shwetz M.

description:
** (kind of) poutine only review **

For those of you who have never been to Quebec, Poutine is the quintessential Quebec food experience that Canadians enjoy (see CBC greatest Canadian invention at #10, ahead of the alkaline battery, the blackberry, the electric oven, and the snow blower!). 

Simple recipe in principle: french fries, gravy and cheddar cheese curds. For the ultimate experience, the fries must be hot, the cheese curds must be cheddar (from unpasteurized milk -- hard to find in the US), fresh (never refrigerated) and the gravy must have a thickness sufficient to have the cheese slowly melt onto the fries without making the latter mushy. 

I tried this poutine on two occasions. Their beef gravy (with added short-rib) was rich and complemented the cheese well. I was pleasantly surprised. Unfortunately, the fries were average being not crispy and, on the second occasion, actually felt like they had just been reheated. It wasn't the right cheese (what's up with chefs melting the cheese in the oven) and ended up being bland. If it hadn't been for the gravy, this would have been a pretty bad poutine.  

Major thumps up for offering Unibroue's La Maudite on tap. The Quebec amber belgian strong ale (8% ABV), with it's heavy spices on the nose, complemented the poutine perfectly and added to my experience (and made my walk back to the hotel somewhat tricky).
author: Simon B.

description:
3.5 star Canadian style restaurant in the SoMa district of downtown SF. 

It's hard to find great poutine (Canada's national snack / bar food consistenting of french fries, gravy and cheese curds) outside of Canada, but Salt House does a good job. They add a ton of gravy though, and not much in the way of cheese curds, so it's very different from the ones I had in Vancouver at least.

The tuna tartar with avocado was solid. Not the tastiest fish, but not bad.

The beef carpaccio was tasty, though the shredded hard boiled eggs took away from the natural raw beef flavors. Skippable.

I ordered the branzini (sea bass like fish), but they had run out (despite only having 3 entrees on the lunch menu), so I opted for chicken confit. The chicken was really tender, but it lacked true confit (a cooking term for when food is cooked in grease, oil or sugar water, at a lower temperature than deep frying) essence. The polenta was also lacking in flavor.

It's good to come here for bites and to try Canadian food, but it's nothing special. The food simply lacks depth.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Very yummy. Had dinner here with my hubby after a long work day. It surprising how busy it was on a Monday night. Not one open table in the place by 7pm. 

We started with the salmon special as an appetizer which was Devine. I then had the halibut and hubby had the meat duo. My halibut was amazing!!!

I had told our waiter that I'm allergic to wheat and nuts so I needed guidance with my ordering. He assured me that the halibut was gluten free but when it came the squash looked breaded. As we were waiting for him to come around to ask, I made a comment to my husband about what the chances were that it was rice flour. And we bet very slim but what do you know? It was rice flour! I don't know if that's standard or if they did that because of my allergy but it was wonderful. 

The food was very light. Very few carbs. Everything was prepared beautifully. It's a bit crowded and loud so it's more of an after work place not a date place, but great food and a fun atmosphere. I would definitely come back!
author: Alexis M.

description: I hosted a dinner for 14 at the Salt House. It was delicious. Terrific menu with lots of choices and the service was great. Definitely will come here again!
author: Carisue B.

description:
Like you, I've heard good things. We all have. Then again, I "heard" good things about Yamo. In my mind experiencing is believing so when I visited Salt House to celebrate a recent success I had a work, I was pleasantly surprised by everything from the greeting from the host, to the verbose descriptive poetry about the food from our server, to the outstanding food. Here is the breakdown: 

SERVICE (5 out of 5): 
Brilliant service across the board. Been here twice now (had to go back to confirm its awesomeness) and both times the service was incredible. The 2nd time I was celebrating my roommates last day in SF and we were delighted with some free champagne to start things off. That about sealed the deal for me. I was knee deep on Salt House after my first visit but after being brought free champagne to start my 2nd visit I was all in...

FOOD (4.5 out of 5):
Absolutely freakin' incredible. Some of the best dishes I've had in the city without a doubt. Complex flavors are distinct and wave through your taste buds with a pleasure reserved for only the best restaurants. You won't get a bunch of things just blandly mixed together with no "real" taste for anything specific. No no, not at all. 

Poached Egg - Do yourself a favor and get the Poached Egg. Best appetizer on the menu. Qual Egg was really good but Poached Egg was better. They change this all the time but it was rich and creamy then smokey before finishing with pork goodness. Various textures worked perfectly together. Brilliant dish, just brilliant. 

Pork Loin - Very, very good if you are a meat lover. Loved the glaze and it went very well with my wine. Really enjoyed this dish and highly recommend it. 

Beef Duo - Had a specially prepared Beef Duo so not exactly the one on the menu but despite the fact it paired perfectly with our Duckhorn wine it was just a tad bit below the Pork Loin in my opinion. Both excellent dishes though and highly recommended. 

Caramel Espresso Mousse - Good dessert but not great. If you like chocolate and espresso flavor you will like it. Nothing more. 

Carrot Cake - Loved it! Really moist, rich, and the frosting was incredible. Reminded me of the carrot cake from Kara's Cupcakes. Fantastic dessert. 

TIP THAT WILL 10X THE EXPERIENCE: 
They have a $20 corkage fee on a bottle of wine so go buy something expensive, enjoy, and save some money. 

OVERALL 5 out of 5): 
I'm sold and all in on this place. Hands down one of the best spots I've been to in SF when looking at all categories from service, atmosphere, food, wine, etc. You will not regret going to this place. It's fantastic! Credit to Abby for running such a fine establishment. Amazing job and THANK YOU for making both of my visits incredibly fun, special, surprisingly delightful, and most of all... memorable.
author: Jackson B.

description:
I came here for a farewell dinner for a friend who was moving to the other side of the country. I honestly can't remember what we had--something of the meat and vegetables variety--but I remember it being pretty tasty and well-cooked. 

So why the 3 stars? Well, everything was just a bit too....much. The prices were a little too high for the portions you get. The lighting was a little too dim to be functional--we had to use our phones to read the menus. Service was friendly when it was there, but a tad too inattentive considering how empty the restaurant was when we were there. In short, Salt House misses the mark by a few degrees but isn't a bad choice if you want vibe/atmosphere/trendiness in this stretch of SoMa.
author: Josephine L.

description: Food was awful.  Service was poor.  Cocktail tasted bad.
author: Christopher N.

description: Salt House is a sign of the times.  The real transients in the city eat at Salt House.  The food is a mixed bag.  I've had good duck tacos and decent oysters.  But the price doesn't equate to the quality.  Other dishes, like the poutine is an aberration of the original.  French fries covered insufficiently and the gravy is like brown jello.  The location is ground zero for hipster wannabes and no one comments on the demonic painting of a Don Quixote type of figure on the back wall.  Loud, presumptuously priced, packed; someone is laughing all the way to the bank.  I hope the revolution against gentrification begins at Salt House.  It is a place where you just can't take it anymore.
author: Timothy H.

description:
This place is all right...

came here for a quick working lunch with an old friend to catch up, and was a bit disappointed. Note that if you're planning on coming here for lunch, reservations are a must, or come early and eat at the bar. Onto the food..

Ordered a burger and a smoked duck salad, and split half and half with my friend. Salad was ok...severely overdressed so it felt like 1/2 dressing 1/2 salad...yuck. Burger was redeeming, but at the end of the day just a good burger (not quite great), with good fries and good execution (read: cooked to the correct temperature). Service was solid, and the ambiance good, but for the price paid I feel like the salad was that sad thing that you can't wait to forget about.
author: David H.

description:
Great food, and his staff..

Gets pretty noisy during lunch hours...Not recommended for business lunch. Time for other delivery is long too.. Food quality gets it four stars
author: Hitesh G.

description: I had a company meet up for our staff appreciation day and this place really pulled out all the stops for us and gave us simply amazing service for our party of 10. The food was so good! Omg the food! So good! I will definitely come back even for one of our events.
author: Erin H.

description: At Salt House, the food, service and ambience were all first rate.  We tried an array of smaller plates (although all the portions were on the generous side), and enjoyed everything.  Our dishes were all thoughtful, well prepared, and perfectly cooked and seasoned.  My favorite dishes of the evening were the beet ravioli with homemade burrata, the toasted cauliflower served with romanesco, squash, and tiny root vegetables, and the delicious warm bread served with homemade butter.  Note: the noise level is a bit high in the main dining room, but upstairs where we sat it was just lovely.1/
author: Mandy R.

description: Salt House is great for after-work cocktails! Lovely staff and great food. Ambiance is very hip and trendy.
author: Tim C.

description:
I stopped by Salt House for the first time last month. Being an expat from Quebec, I was surprised to see a Poutine on the menu so I decided to give it a try.  Short story is that the fries, the bechamel and the short rib sauce were all on good on their own, but they didn't work together and not in any way an excuse to call this dish a Poutine, which is normally made french fries, fresh cheese curbs and gravy... 

So it if you order this dish hoping to experience this classic Quebec dish, you should think twice.... especially for the $13 they charge for it! 

The sound level quite loud, but the service itself was quite good.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Service and hostess were excellent for a busy Friday night (no reservations).  We shared the poutine, beet salad and free range chicken and we all ended up with sharp stomach pains that night.  We figured it was something that we ate here since we all had different drinks at happy hour.

The food is really salty.  The poutine lacked flavor or the cheese curds washed out the flavor.  The chicken was really salty.  The beet salad was pretty good but it's hard to mess up a beet salad.

I probably wouldn't come back.
author: Chris L.

description:
I always pass this restaurant when I pass Mission Street on my way home and have always been intrigued with this place because it looks so pretty from the outside.  Ate here when I my sister was in town.  She was footing the bill so boy was I happy to get  a free meal and spend time with my sister. So glad we had a reservation since this place is always full. What's great about this place was the location it's right downtown.

The atmosphere in the Salt House was warm and hip. They have this pretty painted art on the wall, brilliant and really adds to the ambiance. I like the lighting it felt very elegant.  Great place to go for a group of friends or family, not really on a date since it can get a bit loud.  Bad acoustics. I love restaurants with open kitchens seems like the owners are very proud of their food and want it on display for everyone to see. I love that they give you Acme bread and butter while your waiting for your order.

I had the double ranch New York Steak. Delicious! Meat was tender, the mushrooms and asparagus went well with the potato puree to give this dish so much flavor.  Also tried the Alaskan Halibut, I love Halibut and this was pretty tasty it menlted in your mouth. And for dessert the Urban Smore, oh wow the kid in me was jumping for joy. Rich and delighted just the perfect way to end the meal.  The reason for me giving it four stars is the slow service.  I know it gets pretty packed but if I have to wait for my meal for more than 30 minutes that is a little too long.
author: Maria M.

description: Downtown scene man.. Busy place with lots of people ( which we like) not sure what I last had here? But I do recommend trying them if you are Downtown SF.
author: Kirk M.

description:
Been hearing about Salt House for awhile..and honestly I'm not really a gravy girl, but when I heard that they have like the best Poutine in the area, I wanted to try it because gravy & cheese on fries?  You gotta try it once before you knock it, right?  

I was having a business lunch here & admired the sleek, industrial shiek loft feel of the restaurant upon arrival.  We were presented with my favorite bread...the pain epi from Acme!  Bonus points just for that!  The three of us shared the Poutine ($12) & I got the steak frites ($24).  The Poutine was total gluttony, but everything worked so well.  The gravy, cheese and fries, I couldn't stop picking at it!  The portion was also generous.  The flat iron steak was grilled perfectly, tender & so juicy (medium rare..the only way to go)!  The herb butter I could have done without, the mixed greens side was fine, and the fries were delish!  Crispy, thick enough and seasoned well.  

So what keeps this only at a 3?  The horrible service!  I know they get really busy during the lunch rush, but it's badl!  Our waitress was okay, but I felt like she wasn't very timely & the lunch was over an hour and a half.  But our waitress was a total angel compared to the bus boy from hell!  This guy doesn't ask if you're done, or at least to us he didn't, he just takes your food.  He lifted our plates without saying anything, & I was like, "we'll take a box for our fries."  He then puts the plates back on the table tells our waitress this and then she walks off with the plates & doesn't even come back with it til after she gives my coworker his credit card back.  But even before this, when the bus boy was taking our bread plates away (mind you again, without even asking) my hand was right in front of my bread plate with my butter knife on it..he grabbed it so fast that it poked my finger.  At least it was a butter knife, but still!  This guy needs to learn manners!!

One of my coworkers loves this place, so I may be back, or just come back for dinner with my homeboy who frequents this place a lot.  I just hope that bus boy isn't around me!!  2.5 due to bad service, but feel generous due to the holidays so bumped to a 3.  =)
author: Cat C.

description:
three stars instead of four because I think it's a bit too expensive for the value and the menu items seem a little disconnected and there should be more choices. the food is great, but a four star restaurant should make you want to return immediately to try other things but I don't have that feeling here.

that being said, the food we had was awesome. I recommend most everything, including the salted peppers and poutine. I'm not really familiar with this style of fries so I'm not sure if they were better or worse than average, but I enjoyed them. the foie gras was very large, definitely for two people, but without enough bread, which was quickly remedied by our server. the rockfish ceviche was okay, not outstanding. same for the rockfish main.

we sat at the bar and ate, and the two bartenders were very attentive and friendly, even though they were super busy. they made the experience much nicer. there was a nice cocktail menu. wine prices were normal

it gets pretty crowded after 5pm and all the table were filled so I assume reservations are a good idea. but it's pretty good just sitting at the bar.
author: Bob U.

description:
Came here for a work dinner this week.  The service was very good and the food was excellent.  I started with the tomato soup and had the Halibut.  The soup was good and the fish was cooked perfectly.  

This place will make it into the work dinner rotation for sure.
author: John F.

description:
I came here with Sarah C. for Dine About Town. We arrived right around the time of opening for lunch and didn't have any reservations. I didn't expect them to be completely booked to be honest. They did have space in the communal area so we went with it anyway. The restaurant isn't really that big and there were single tables facing the window below a flight of stairs that go up to the mezzanine. I suppose those were also reserved as well for lunch. I'm not a real big fan of sharing a table with other patrons that I don't know at all. Luckily for me the seat next to me was unoccupied until we were almost finished.

I ordered the Duck Rillettes Terrine and the Moroccan Chicken Salad. The Duck Terrine was served with shredded pieces of kumquat, pickled veggies, and several pieces of croutons. This is the first time I have tried duck prepared this way. I did a little bit of reading beforehand to understand how it was made. It's certainly an interesting dish for an appetizer. The Moroccan salad contained mint, tangerines, chickpeas, almonds in a spicy dressing. It was served with flatbread on the side. I have a pretty big appetite and the salad did fill me up because it had plenty of pieces of chicken.

The service wasn't spectacular. We were asked once if we wanted more bread and then the waitress came by another time to give us the dessert menu.
author: Tim G.

description: Satisfying meal. Waiter was a little too talkative. Food was good. Ambiance lovely. Pleasant dinner. Highlight for me was the octopus beet salad. Outstanding. Weakest dish was entree: stuffed chicken breast. Little too much sausage for me. Would recommend, but not sure we'll be back.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
We attended Salt House Sat PM on the recommendation of the local hotel concierge. 

After being seated by the hostess who was charming, we experienced what I would consider a sub par dining and service experience. Long delays, never the same person showing up at the table offering services, limited wine offerings, and on top of that the restaurant was not filled to capacity.

After lengthy delays for the cocktails to be delivered, chefs recommendations were finally offered, water service slow, and wine list came and went from the table as each server who came by was not sure what was previously offered. 

We did order a bottle of pinot noir ($110+) and it arrived at the table no where near cellar temperature.  Faulty refrigeration unit to blame!  Yikes...what about other the inventory?

We did enjoy the appetizers  (tuna crudo and oysters) and dinner (sole and salmon). They were artfully presented and tastes were terrific.  The waiting for service, waiting for glasses and dishes to be removed and waiting for the next stage of the dinner to progress weighted heavily on our rating of 2 stars.

At this price point for a fine dining experience we would have expected more and better. 
Food - Very good
Service - Poor
Atmosphere - Very dark
author: Ashley S.

description:
Went here for date night before a show downtown. Just saw it on the way by and decided to try it out. No reservation but got lucky right away. It was great choice. Service was excellent, very friendly and knowledgable waiters. Im a fisherman and know sea fare, Waiter didn't try to bs me on the fish. Single page menu so not overburdened with choices.  
Had the Black Cod and Ribeye. Both were excellent. Portions were just right, and cooked perfectly. The batard with in house butter spot on. The prices were very fair. I would recommend Salt House to any of my friends looking for a great meal downtown.
author: marty M.

description: My friend Anna and I decided to try this after she heard from a co-worker that this was a good restaurant.  We were not disappointed.  Nice very modern and chic layout.  Friendly staff and servers.  The shishito pepper appetizer was delicious and our entrees were both tasty.  NY steak and sole were both flavorful and well prepared. Our dessert and cocktails did not disappoint.
author: Eddie O.

description: My girlfriend I stopped by after an evening trip to Golden Gate University right across the street. The place was hopping on a weeknight!  We had a nice plate of oysters and glasses of wine. We sat at the bar where the speedy and attentive Gabe and Adam made sure we were well supplied. Thank you, guys!
author: Sydney F.

description:
Meh...

I really had a difficult time trying to place the menu.  There were some good oysters, but then a combination of menu items that I didn't feel had a particular theme.  I chose to have the 44 dry aged rib eye and I will definitely say I've had a better steak.  It felt compressed and flat and tasted somewhat dry.  Good atmosphere however but with so many options in SF, it will be a while before I'm back.

I just realized someone else started their review off with "Meh..."  !
author: PJ M.

description: Food was fine but small portions and eeexxxpensiiive for what you get. Corkage = $25. Good option if you need to find a nice restaurant within walking distance to some nightclubs. Otherwise, many better options in the city.
author: Angela L.

description: Great menu, really hard to get a table even at lunch time you need to make a reservation or wait for a long time. Everything that we had was great and our table ended up sharing all of the apps and entrees that we ordered so that everyone could get a chance to taste everything. The lunchtime menu is just as great as the dinner menu, fyi! And I don't even like the smoked flavor but the smoked turkey sandwich with crispy brussel sprouts I crave often. The small bite/happy hour menu is also great and reasonably priced and the pomegranate gimlet is perfect.
author: Free P.

description:
Went last night on a business dinner, I will say the building itself was really awesome looking. The lighting was perfect and the noise level was manageable, no one was yelling over one another, but it wasn't so quiet that it felt uncomfortable. The two stars are for the ambiance alone. 

The food, I have to agree with many others on here, was very uninspired. I had the Cod ($29), my partner had the Sole ($32). The components of each dish were decent, the Cod came with some muscles and the sauce it sat on was tasty. The fish itself, as Ironic as it sounds could have used some Salt. Both were very bland, to the point where we stopped eating and mentioned it to each-other. Usually in these business dinners if the food is half way decent the conversation moves on quickly from food to business, not this time. We spent a lot of the meal shocked how a place that looked so great, was set up to be awesome, the menu came across really strong fell so flat on its face. 

If you are looking for a cool place to go have a drink the "Salt House" may be for you. I'd recommend eating just about anywhere else.
author: Richard G.

description:
I've been here many times and they have never impressed me with "This is good!". It's always with "this is kind of too salty" or "this is okay..."

They cook the food in waves so the food takes forever!
author: Dorris W.

description: Service and food was fine, a true 3/5. But PSA: don't order the poutine, it's not legit. The gravy is too thick and chunky, and somehow kind of dry (although the cheese curds are on point).
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Meh. It's okay. I don't feel like writing prose today so here, instead, are some pros (and cons):

Pros:
- burger is pretty dang tasty.
- they *have* poutine. it's not the best poutine, but at least they have it.
- good cocktails, if a bit pricey.
- swanky atmosphere.
- service is generally nice.

Cons:
- the wait for food is often pretty bad. sat down at around 12:15 and didn't get food until around 12:50. this happened a few times. don't go here if you're on a tight lunch schedule.
- pricey! nothing in particular (except maybe the burger, and probably not even that) is worth the price.
- the poutine is underwhelming. it needs to be saucier and dirtier. their poutine was quite plebeian and dry.
author: Michael B.

description: I have always been curious to try this place and was excited when our work chose this location to book a group outing.  We got sat on the second floor though and the whole evening the place was overly hot perhaps being so close to the ceiling lights.  The food itself was okay.  The raw tuna appetizer was pretty standard and sitting in a light soy sauce.  The poutine fries were good but I personally thought it would be better with some meat on top since it's basically a mound of fries with gravy slathered on top.  Then the pork entree was ok, and was more on the overcooked side.  Along with the vegetable sides, the dish was actually lacking flavors and on the bland side with a pop of citrus (kumquats) that was rather sour. Then I had the Panna cotta for dessert which also was not silky but super firm with a scoop of citrus sorbet throw on top which was icy and really didn't go along well.  I was also a lil disappointed given it was the same that we received earlier as a palette cleanser.  Overall, I ordered all the relatively safe items that I would say are difficult to go wrong but all still turned out rather average. I would go here as a place for drinks but not for the food.
author: Tramy V.

description:
The mister and I came here on a late Thursday night after a mixer. We were looking for small eats, and this place seemed to have some good food selections.

We got the poutine and the shishito peppers to start. The shishito peppers were done very well -- loved them. Of course, you can't really go wrong with shishito peppers, but the yuzu salt on it was delicious. The poutine was just that -- cheese curds and gravy on top of fries. Also can't really mess it up, I guess, but it was good too.

We then got the white seabass to share. It was served with a teeny bit of chorizo, tomatoes, and cucumbers on the side. I was hoping for more chorizo because there were only 2 pieces, not quite enough to cover the whole piece of fish. However, the fish was done well, not too firm and retained a lot of flavour, especially paired with the sides. It was a decent dish.

Overall I liked what they have. They also have an extensive bar with a very big selection of whiskies, and when I asked about the choices they even sent their bartender over.
author: Alice C.

description: Have been here a few times and have always enjoyed the food and experience, but felt like the quality of the food may have slightly declined. We liked the appetizers better than the entrees.  It was also super loud, we were a table of 5 and it was hard to hear each other across the table. The server was really nice, but I feel like the food is a little over priced.
author: F D.

description: Went for dinner with a couple of friends and was able to get a reservation via Yelp pretty easily.  The ambiance was nice, waiter was a little strange in terms of his personality but knowledgeable about the food and wine.  The food was just okay - I thought the presentation was nice but the flavor was really bland. I wouldn't really go back.
author: Carmelita B.

description:
I've had lunch here twice and unfortunately the first time was better than the second time.

Their menu is pretty select so, it's either chicken, beef, or veggie option, unless you go for a salad or sandwich.  I've had a couple of their salads, the one I can remember was their Heirloom Tomato salad.  Being an anti-tomato guy, I sucked it up for the sake of my dining companion.  It didn't kill me but at the same time, it didn't convert me either.  Their french onion soup was on spot.  I've had their roasted chicken which was good, not enough juice though, but it was way flavorful.

The resto is rustic cool and has a 2nd floor dining area.  But man is it tight in there!  If you're lucky to snag a table along the kitchen, that's ideal but otherwise you're rubbing elbows, especially upstairs.  Also, it can get really loud.  We couldn't help hear other people and likewise.

Service was just okay, both times.  Service wasn't stellar but it wasn't bad either.  I'll cut them slack though because when it gets busy and they have to shimmy down the aisles, yeah that could be a challenge.

Overall, I'd say it's an okay spot, but there are other places I'd rather try out next time.

#LunchInTheFiDi
author: Nick D.

description:
I had the shrimp persimmon salad, which was mediocre.  The service wasn't stellar - I ordered a diet coke which I never got.  Service was very slow in general, I was not at all impressed.
For the amount of money they charge, service should be a lot better.   Food needs improvement as well.
I will most likely not return.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I came here last week with two other couples for dinner, and was pretty disappointed at how bland and boring the food tasted.  The menu changes often, and what I ordered is no longer on the menu this week when I checked.  That being said, it was the only vegetarian option that they had, and I kid you not, it was basically oatmeal, barley with wild mushrooms and asparagus for $26. I took two bites of my food and asked the server to take it away.  My friends ordered two chicken dishes, and one beef item, they were also underwhelmed with the food.  The one dish that we had that was AMAZING was their Poutine, with the gravy on the side for me.  The fries were pipping hot with a wonderful cheese sauce on top - lovely.  

The service was good.  The server was attentive, but not very knowledgeable about the menu and wines.  We ordered a round of Patron shots to start the night off right (it was a Friday after all), and when we got the bill we were shocked that the shots were $15 each.  I don't remember ever paying that much for Patron, not even at 25 Lusk.  

Overall, I wouldn't come back here unless it was just for a drink with my friends. I take that back, I wouldn't even come here to drink with them.
author: Judy C.

description:
I really like salty foods so I've had my eyes on salt house for a while. I'd say the overall experience was pretty good. A group of us came here to celebrate my bf's birthday. Proportions were a big small for the price, but i really liked their seafood. 

-1 star the waiter brought my food to some other table and just told me to wait another 5 minutes. no compensations for their mistake. Everyone else in my party were too polite to eat without me =/ 

-1 star for not celebrating a birthday. I know this is always a plus when restaurants do it and never expected, but from a fancy place like salt house that charges a bit more for their service & food, I expected a small cake or something since we brought a big party to the restaurant. A little disappointing. 

I'd say 4 stars for the food, 2 stars for service. 3 stars overall.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town Lunch.

I had work at 1.40 therefore we arrived at 11.45am. We were technically the first patrons to arrive but we thought they weren't open yet. We followed a couple in. The couple didn't have a reservation and were still given a table. We didn't have a reservation either but they ran out of tables. We were forced to sit at the stool or either the bar. We sat at the stool. No place to put my purse. Poo!

We were given a menu and we were ready to order right when the waitress came with our waters. 

First Course
Curried Kohlrabi and Apple Soup - This was what I ordered. I enjoyed it. I wasn't able to taste any apple but it was very flavorful. Not spicy.

or

Duck Rillettes Terrine
served with kumquat marmalade and croutons - My friend ordered this. It was my first time trying duck rillettes terrine. It was very different from what I am use to. Chinese people don't prepare duck like this. It was good but the portion was a bit small. 

Second Course
Moroccan Chicken Salad
served with chickpeas, tangerines, and chickpea flatbread - My friend ordered this. It came with a lot of chicken, nuts, fruits and 4 pieces of the flatbread. Barely any green though if you are expecting the typical salad. A hint of spicy. 

or

Stuffed Calamari
served with ciopinno broth, chorizo, mussels, and white beans - Rather small dish but the ciopinno broth was so savory. I could have drink an entire of bowl of it. There are bits of sausage in the broth. It was like fishing for treasure. Delicious! You get a piece of shrimp. 5 mussels and a lot of beans.
