I am not a fan of beans but they went very well with the broth. My favorite surprise was the stuff calamari. It was so cute and filled with sausage cut into tiny pieces. 

The bread they offered were oddly shaped but good. Nothing spectacular. We were given another helping of it. 

Ambiance was young and inviting. Kind of reminded me of Anchor & Hope but with less personality.  

I thoroughly enjoyed the food. I would like to come back and sit at a table though. The service was prompt but not amazing. It would do.
author: Sarah C.

description:
3.5 years after my first visit I was forced to do a business lunch here. Again--this place confirms that SFers will over pay for just about anything. 

Had the smoked duck salad that simply tasted like vinegar dressing--totally too much! I mean when you can't even get a lunch salad right how the hell do you stay in business. Must be my confirmation noted in paragraph #1  

At least I didn't get food poisoning from this visit (at least not yet)...
author: Howard G.

description:
Easy to get a reservation.  Seated at the top floor, which is a great overview of the restaurant and open kitchen below.  The lighting and decor is great and intimate.  Just make sure you aren't a clumsy one going upstairs!  I love the tall windows, which makes the restaurant look more spacious also.  Service is great. Our table was a bit too small for all the food we ordered though.

Ordered:
1. Poutine:cheese curds and short rib gravy is heavenly.  Makes me miss my childhood favorite back in Canada.  Be sure to share this because it comes in a rather large portion of fries!  Nothing beats Canadian Poutine in actual Canada though! :P

2. Oysters: Kumamotos & Fanny Bay

3. Local swordfish: complimented the potato and leek very well.  My favorite fish dish of the night unlike the other.

4. I forgot the other fish dish but I know it was cooked with squid ink.  I realized squid ink is a bit too rich for me.

Both of us downed cokes since we were super thirsty.

Great ambiance but food is mediocre!

Time to check out the other establishments!
author: Kathy D.

description: I've had lunch here a couple times - once for work, once for fun.  Both times the food was delicious and the service was very good (even though the place was jammed).  Reservations seem to help during weekdays.
author: Brian O.

description:
Come for their fresh oysters and poutine!

While their octopus was tender, the squid ink sauce was too confusing for my palate, it was fighting with the octopus for flavor and I could have done without it. 

I also love the space, with old wood beams...I would def come back for more oysters and poutine!
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Yummmmm 

Wine: cab really good and at a great price 

Poutine: fries. Extremely amazing!!!!!!!!!! Best fries ever. Get the sauce poured on top. 

Corn soup: best corn soup of my life.  Super creamy with cilantro  

Beef: amazing!  Cooked to perfection with more corn!  

Salted Carmel Brownie- looks basic but tastes great!
author: Craig S.

description:
Was excited to try Salt House after hearing so much about the place. The peppers in sea salt were delicious. However, the pork loin was cooked well done and was rather dry. To round things up, the passionfriit cheesecake was a nice twist on the traditional cake.

It was great to finally try SaltHouse, but I was not blown away at all.



Passion fruit cheesecake very good
author: Vince E.

description:
Shatangi appreciates great service.

To their credit, the serving, host and bus staff at Salt House work very well together.  They are personable without being pushy, attentive, and very approachable.  Hats off to management!  The food however left me wanting to bounce.  My burger was way overcooked despite the server explaining that they tend to err on the undercooked side. Despite the huge blob of mystery sauce, it was absolutely tasteless as were the fries.  The carpaccio was completely buried under an excessive amount of microplane-grated cheese (that's soooooo over LOL).  Don't hide the featured flavors Salt House (sadface)!!  I'm very unimpressed with the food at this price-point and accompanied by such professional service.  Not on my list for lunch.

Shatangi Told You...
author: Njon W.

description:
Have dined here a couple of times for business.  The food is consistent and service is great.  Have had a few different things on the menu and everything was well prepared and ok.  

Last time I came here I was with a party of 7 other diners and everyone enjoyed their meal.  Seating can be a bit difficult if you don't plan ahead.  Don't chance it, make reservations.  You will end up frustrated otherwise.  Fortunately I work nearby so I didn't have to worry about parking.
author: Kristine F.

description:
Every time I've walked by here I could feel the energy of bustling, casual high end business lunches. I really don't give myself the time for a lunch like that. My time often would be better spent to do it after work, but some work days I'm thankful that it could happen. We were lead here for a group lunch of 7, and their upper mezzanine was perfect for our reservation. Really, I couldn't imagine a better location for a group lunch, especially if it's a meeting and you want to be productive over it. The mezzanine maintains the energy but gives you the ability to have a full on discussion. 

The service was really kind and steadfast. The menu gives everyone an option. You're going to spend $14-$20 a person. There's an anchovie kale caesar that skips that step of "could you just replace all the greens with kale?" 

Now, I don't often use quotation marks but when I do it means something. Thus, "Poutine." So far... any "Poutine" in SF isn't Poutine. I'm no pro but spending much of the last 18 months in Canada, it's such a simple, terrific idea: fries, squeaky cheese curds, gravy. America so far from what I've seen adds to much to it -- shocker! This one has wild boar gravy and meat. Word. It's fantastic "Poutine." 

For a meal to go from gluttony to tempered healthy tartare to kale isn't common, which speaks to how rare of an experience Salt House really is. It's American (New) and often that doesn't mean a thing, but it does here.
author: Jon A.

description:
Ok this is one of those deals where the food was really pretty good however the server killed the deal. Boarder line rude at times, very short as if we where not important enough to hold his attention. Had to ask for water three times, guessing that was because we opted for just the normal free house water and not the bottled water you could tell he so badly wanted us to buy. 

I enjoyed the food however nothing really stood out. One of the items that was nice was the roasted chicken, it was very moist and seasoned nicely. 

Managers, pay attention to your wait staff, jump in and see how your customers are feeling!
author: Brook M.

description:
Optimally located in the Financial District (technically SoMA?) next to some industry giants, Salt House has the ability to offer small portions at a high price to attract bundles of professionals (hoping to impress their dining partners with the tavern-charm Salt House exudes). They're ridiculously successful in this front, having found and occupied a prime niche located smack dab in the middle of their target market's favorite dwelling place.

The food is good and you won't hear me alluding otherwise, but as I said they provide rather small portions for the price. 

Salt House's downside is its popularity. It is a high demand spot, especially if you're thinking of going during a weekday lunch around noon. Thus, Salt House works to cram as many tables into its space as possible, including the narrow alley of a window display that exists between the staircase to the second level and the front windows. It is along this narrow strip that I was seated. Needless to say, it felt vaguely like being a zoo animal.

All in all, although I would rather try some place new, I wouldn't throw too big of a fit if I had to go back.
author: Rex X.

description:
Oh no!  Salt House - know this - I'm rooting for you.  I remember a day when short rib gravy flowed like the Mississippi over golden crispy fries to create a Poutine that you could form a religion around.   Last night it was more like cold Swanson TV dinner horror show.  Of everything that came out of the kitchen - the best course wasn't cooked - your heirloom tomatoes & burrata. 

The people, the vibe, the intentions are all delightful.  I just wish the food could return to its former glory.
author: Ethan B.

description:
When my friend with fab first-class taste suggested we dine at Salt House, I knew it would be good. But it was better than that... the unseducable was seduced. And, I popped my oyster cherry here. 

Can you believe it? Oysters on the half shell for the first time. Some little, and some large mouthfuls of salty sea deliciousness were presented to us and I bravely downed them all. Oysters-- you and I, we'll never be apart again.

But there's a world beyond oysters here, too. There's the beautifully-appointed space which makes your skin glow (see attached photo of my lovely dinner companion). There's servers, chefs and managers that will cater to your every whim. And there's hours of decadent food to sway you from going out after, as the après-meal food baby makes the sofa that much more alluring. 

Yep, Salt House is the multitasker that does it all, and well. Aces!

The short list of what to try:

Oysters, obviously
Poutine
Pork belly
Dayboat scallops
Atlantic cod
Gnocchi (from the lunch menu) (yes we're special;)
Fulton Valley chicken (ooooh orgasmic!)
And a lot of bubbles

We finished our epicurean adventure with a light and refreshing panna cotta garnished with blood oranges. 

A night here puts a smile on everyone's face. Case in point? The table next to us bestowed the remainder of their bottle of gorgeous Cabernet to us. Everyone starts as strangers, right?
author: Jelena Z.

description: We went here for dinner on a Thursday night. A group of 10... A work dinner to celebrate a milestone. We could not be seated until all 10 people had arrived and so were all stuffed at the door trying to get a drink. The waitstaff was curt and repeatedly tapped us on the shoulders to try to clear our plates. Even though it didn't appear that there was another party waiting for our table. Also, the upstairs is ridiculously hot. Next time, I would prefer to go to their sister restaurant, the townhouse, where the service is impeccable.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Came here for happy hour around 545 or so. It's a small, very cramped space. The hostess offered us two seats by the front window which we had to crouch and squeeze through to access. I did this and promptly hit my back against the stairwell. Hard. I have a black/blue bruise to prove it.

Once seated, it took 10 mins for a waitress to drop off about 10 menus including the happy hour menus (happy hour is between 2-6) then peaced out for a good 20 minutes. We tried to order off the happy hour menu not realizing the time, and she promptly told us it was 10 minutes past 6, not really acknowledging that she took forever to get to us. Whatever; an extra 3 bucks a glass, fine.

However, service the rest of the night was just poor. The waitress kept forgetting about us for long stretches of time and then would awkwardly barge in and say "OHHH just wanting to make sure I'm not neglecting you!!" 

Not coming back, wouldn't recommend it.
author: Kim T.

description:
Very chic setting.  Ambiance is nice.  Wait staff was just ok.  I guess we were there during dinner rush hour so we didn't get the best service but the waiter was still very nice. 

Love the menu set up.  Very simple and straight to the point.  Only one page (love it!).

Dinner:

Crunchy Shimp - LOVE IT!  MUST order!  It's pretty much lightly batter shimp with string beans in a bed of lettuce. I think there was bits of prosciutto which was a nice touch. 

Mix green salad- we were trying to be healthy but you can skip that. Too much mustard dressing :(

Half a dozen of Kumamoto oysters - can't go wrong with that :)

Foie gras - YUM! 

Pork Chop - Pork chop was a litlle too fatty for me but it was still very tasty.

My overall experience was still great.  The food was fantastic and I'm just in love with the Crunchy Shrimp!
author: Ying F.

description:
So sad that I actually ended up dinning there when I knew how displeased were most of the people I talked to about this place.
But so funny to see how they actually feeling the selling gourmet.. Really funny!
I will not go into the details of how the duck confit almost meet every single rule of 'not to do' when preparing such specialty dish and skip my opinion about the quality of food vs prices and skip to what will really interest most people: 
So when I got my dish, which was a super overpriced, mediocre at best ribeye, I asked politely if I may get some mustard and the server rolled her eyes and told my waitress : pfffffffff, he wants mustard!!! 
So, I'm really sorry that I didn't leave the house that night with the intention of making the server happy but I really felt like having some mustard. Sorry...
author: MICKY T.

description: Come here with my husband for dinner before seeing the Cirque De Soleil show at the ball park (it also happened to be my birthday). We were in a bit of a hurry and had about an hour and 15 to eat and get out of there. We told the waitress this and she was very attentive to getting us on the road (except they brought me a dessert for my birthday which was wonderful and nice but we really did need to get out of there and need the check. So how can you be angry at that?). We ordered quail eggs which we though we're really good and interesting, the mushroom/Apple dish - we didn't like this one, it was a weird texture and I didn't taste mushrooms at all, the cauliflower entree which we really enjoyed and the whole fish with red quinoa which was awesome. Overall we thought the food was very good and would like to go back when we have more time to dine. The staff was very friendly and accommodating as well.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Over priced,tiny portions, poorly cooked. Go elsewhere. Oyster appetizer, 4 tiny oysters, adulterated  with some orange mess for $16. The salmon entree was nearly raw at room temperature even though I requested medium. Chicken entree also undercooked and over salted.  Service slow and unattentive. Clearly my most disappointing dining experience
erience in SF.
author: Charles E.

description:
Have been to Salt House several times for business lunches in the past few months. On each occasion I've booked a reservation through Yelp's link to the OpenTable online reservation system . . . which is simple "Clockwork".   At Salt House I've been consistently very satisfied with the overall dining experience, the attentive service, and the high quality meals.  Salt House is located on Mission St. in the vibrant SOMA area . . . (that's "South of Market" St. for you non-San Franciscans).  

There's something about the ambiance at Salt House that I find particularly appealing . . . although I can't quite put my finger on exactly what it is . . . perhaps it is a combination of the old red brick industrial style building . . . the high ceiling . . . the relaxed bar adjacent to the dining area . . . the white table cloth tables . . . the stairs leading to additional seating in an overlooking balcony/loft type area . . . along with the friendly reception and table service.  Whatever it is, it makes for a very satisfying experience.

A few of the plates I have enjoyed and would recommend include the Salmon, Sole, Tagliatelle, and the Burger (particularly with Blue Cheese).  My personal favorite is the Grilled Chicken Paillard, served on top of a green salad.  The Marinated Olives or the Yellowfin Tuna are nice openers/appetizers.  All selections have been very very good, with nice presentation -- many of the photos on Yelp will give a good sense of their presentations.

Noise level can be slightly above average, but I wouldn't consider it to be a 'loud' environment, at least not at the lunch hour.  (I can't comment on the Happy Hour.)
author: Joel E.

description: I can make better food at home. The poutine was flavorless with some sort of brown gelatinous gravy and the petreole sole is very small and comes with the skin charred on, so be prepared. :)
author: Ashley M.

description: What's going on here? I've been here a couple times a month for the last year, and the last two times were not great experiences. In fact, the last time, walked out after sitting at the bar for 15 minutes, and not being greeted. And they weren't even busy.
author: Amy O.

description:
Just in case you weren't aware, weekdays from 5PM-8PM this place is LOUD!! It's apparently a very popular happy hour spot. If you want a nice intimate dinner, make your reservations for 8PM or later as even on a Friday night, the crowd didn't die down until around then.

This place has class and I felt like a million bucks after eating here. It really hits the spot. 

The poutine here is very crispy.. and apparently they do use cheese curds and not mozzarella so it's authentic. For $12, it's definitely a must!

The oysters are kinda small but delish! All they needed was a smidge of lemon and they were shucked perfectly!

The scallops were somewhat bland.

The smoked salmon salad was PERFECT. Arugula and horseradish, it was a nice combination.

The halibut was excellent although it if you want something experimental, skip it because it's just your typical classic halibut dish.

For the mains: the porkchops were extremely tough and difficult to eat. The halibut was nice and soft in the inside and crispy on the outside. The tuna was very original! It had a curry seasoning on the crust and was nice and rare on the inside. 

ALL of the desserts were divine except for the strawberry/rhubarb pie. It was too sour.

Top favorites: 
Smoked salmon salad 
Tuna entree(rare)
Carrot cake, peanut butter/hazelnut cake
Poutine (for novelty/nostalgic sake)

Top Drinks:
You have to get Le Vieux Maison (tastes like a high end pina colada)

I would skip:
Porkchops
Scallops
Rhubarb apple pie
author: Kathy S.

description:
Had my first Salt House experience last night for dinner with a couple of old friends, one of whom was visiting from out of town. Nice modern space, comfortable bar and tables, and 30s/40s downtown crowd.

We shared a somewhat odd appetizer combination of a dozen Kumamoto oysters on the half-shell, and an order of poutine (french fries covered in cheese and gravy). Odd, but delicious. The oysters came with freshly-grated horseradish, which gave the cocktail sauce (which I assume also had some) a nice fresh upgrade.

For my main course, I had the pork chop, which was the clear winner at the table. It was a thick, nicely-marbled hunk of pork loin, pre-sliced over a heap of green onion spaetzle, root veggies, and bacon. Fortunately they left the bone standing up on the side of the plate with a little extra meat on it, which was delicious. 5-star dish.

By comparison, the sea bass that my friends both ordered was small and unimpressive. They seemed okay with it, but I kept giving them bits of my pork chop to keep them happy.

Service was friendly and attentive, and the space is nice. The prices seem a little on the high side, but not completely out of bounds. I might come back if I needed to be in the neighborhood for dinner and was looking for a nice, mellow place with good food.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Nice after work crowd.  Good Happy Hour drinks however limited to certain specials.

Modern contemporary design, slightly loud for dinner, tables close together so not a private experience.

Good food, nicely arranged menu.

Only downer is that some of the servers seemed a bit off their game in an angry sort of way.  Of course there were others very nice and on top of their game.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
They aren't kidding about the salt, everything is salty! I was not really happy with this place. I mean, I understood this was suppose to be gourmet, and the food must be good for the price, but it wasn't. I had gotten a chicken dish, and I like everyone else in my party complained that the food was too salty, to a point it was not enjoyable. The appetizers were ok, and the drinks were made well. The decor is really nice as well! But the food that was so expensive was no where near the expectations. I would suggest going elsewhere. 

TLDR: SALTY(VERY VERY SALTY) FOOD.
author: Nakul B.

description:
I knew this place had poutine and that was the only reason I knew it existed.

After several months with this knowledge, I finally wandered in for lunch today and promptly ordered the poutine.

The fries were good, nice and crispy. The "curds" were far too melty and there was some kind of white cheese sauce on top. The gravy IMO was too beef laden and dark to be a good poutine gravy. Don't get me wrong, it tasted great but would be better suited with some roast beef and mashed potatoes.

My colleagues both ordered a sandwich. 1 chicken and 1 burger. They looked great.

I'll come back again to try something else but I'll steer clear of the poutine.
author: Mike Z.

description:
"Eek! Me thinks not" is so right

The reason for the one star....well bottom line overly disappointed in the service.

My first experience at this place was a huge let down. I would have expected the mistakes made to come from a Denny's (not to hate on Denny's since they've proven to me to have better customer service) or even a drive through window restaurant. My group of 4 decided on this place for a late lunch to catch the happy hour for a birthday celebration. It was supposed to be a nice surprise and the nice part was ruined. We definitely got a surprise experience though. We ordered a round of white wine for the table, they brought us one glass...excuse me but seriously?! You took the drink order for a table of 4 and brought back 1 glass? I assume the issue here began when we got seated by the host, that took the initial order, then served by 2 separate servers that had no idea what was the status of our table. We had to re-order the Wine with both servers so that we all got our own glass and ask for water just as often. Frustrating enough that was, we still haven't gotten to ordering our food... After the drink order disaster I personally decided against food. However, the birthday girl and one friend were starving and placed an order for the Cheese Sandwich each. We later got served 2 cheese plates. Had no idea what that was about till later asking why we got servers cheese plates and where the sandwich's were?! Turns out the server put in Cheese Plates and not Cheese Sandwich's. By this time it was well over 45-50 minutes and never ate. Imagine a birthday lunch with no lunch served. UGH! We had to rush the last 5 minutes to grab a quick snack on the way back to work. I will personally never revisit this "Salt House" place again.
author: Allison B.

description:
I like this place. It's got a super cool vibe & décor, and my dad and I sat "upstairs" in a little loft area. Only downside is that it's small, so the tables are pretty close together. 

The food is really good and the servers are great as well. We had an awesome time. The location is a little bit sketchy, and we had a drunk homeless man come in the restaurant and start yelling as we were trying to leave, but overall we enjoyed it and will probably come back!
author: Courtney Y.

description:
Ladies and gentleman, the star of the show. The amazing, the sensational, the best ever Shellfish Plateau!!!! (The crowd goes crazy)

The highlight of my experience was this delicious meal of shrimp, oysters, clams, and muscles. Every bite was fresh and crisp. Definitely recommending this as a must, the rest of the menu however...was not to par.

I ordered the Sea Bass, unfortunately never had the opportunity to taste the dish as it arrived raw. The second time around the dish was still undercooked and everything else on the dish dry and overcooked. Thank goodness I had more than my share of the Shellfish Plateau!

My fiancé had the pork lion which was tasty and packed with flavor, but dry and a bit pork jerky.  

Would I go back...ehhh? Maybe only for a shellfish allergy.
author: Laura P.

description:
Awesome work lunch everytime! 

I love their salmon tartare with their criss cross lightly salted chips as an appetizer. I do favor their poutine but for lunch, that's all I'd be having if I ordered that. I usually go for their sandwiches but this time I tried their seasonal watermelon salad with arugula, feta cheese topped with light jalapeno dressing. Service is also great here and it's always busy for lunch.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Looking for a late-night, post-movie dinner spot, we trekked to Salt House. Happily, we were able to get a table without a reservation at 9:30 pm Thursday night. The place was lively but not crowded like it is at happy hour. 

Every time I've gone to Salt House I've ordered the poutine. As other reviewers point out, it's not to be missed. 

Likewise, the oysters were fantastic. We ordered 2 different kinds, and they were outstanding. 

However, the cocktails, while decent, don't stand out compared with other bars / restaurants in SF. Solid, good recipes, but not surprising or unexpectedly creative. The heirloom tomato and watermelon salad was good. Not more, not less. 

Overall for the price it's so-so. Definitely fine, but not necessarily a place I'd seek out again.
author: Rae B.

description:
Met a buddy for lunch at Salt House a few weeks back.  Super clean and nice inside, service was crisp and friendly, and overall it was a really nice experience.  The bathroom is part of the "building", so you have to go thru an elevator lobby to get to it - but otherwise the environment is nice.  It's got a nice, modern, high-end look to it....although I feel like the upper loft tables would get warm when it's crowded.  (I didn't sit up there)

The food overall was solid, but not spectacular.  Nothing to complain about - if fact they did have a really good poutine with shortrib gravy that was phenomenal.  (But it's french fries with cheese and gravy - hard to go wrong)  I had a flounder sandwich which was pretty good too.  My buddy had the mussels, which was a humongous portion....

I'm a fan and will likely be back.  Food is good, if not a little boring.
author: Arthur Y.

description: I am visiting from out of state, we went to Napa, Yosemite and SF if course and my meal here was the best of my entire trip.  I had the gnocchi and it was absolutely delicious, I would definitely recommend that dish.  My husband had the beef dish, I think it was rib eye and cheek, he kept raving about how melt in your mouth the cheek was and I agreed with him that was delicious as well.  We found the place because of the poutine on the menu (I used to live in Quebec so poutine is my thing!), it was good but didn't taste anything like a poutine.  My only thing was that the sauce for the poutine was really thick and gelatinous, could have been more saucy but other than that I really enjoyed my meal.  If I'm ever in town again I'll stop by and save room for dessert.
author: Krissy D.

description:
Cool vibe and good drinks.

Food:
Seafood platter was delicious with oysters, mussels, shrimp and clams. We were not offered bread and staff rarely checked on us. The pork loin was flavorful but very dry as if it was under the warmers for a while. The sea bass was undercooked and returned. When it was reserved the rest of the dish was overcooked and unflavored. 

Service:
3/5
Needs to be more attentive
author: Ron P.

description:
The food is just okay. I think the flavors are a little off and not enough in certain dishes. My friend and I did not hesitate to order multiple dishes but it was Unsatisfying for the price.

My waitress was very attentive and the Riesling was delicious.

Oysters are very fresh but tiny which is a good thing because they're not farmed and they're fresh!

We had the crab appetizer with the exotic fruit garnish on top and grilled veggies to start.

Veggies were bland but the crab was very good. It was probably the best part of the meal.

My soy breaded fish was very bland in sauce and in seasoning. Fish is so good because it's like a clean canvas and you can literally compliment it's taste with so much flavors but they didn't.

The pork loin seasoning was sooooo good! That was what I used to pair with my fish since my dish lacked flavor. The pork loin itself was very tough and hard to chew or cut. 

The bill was high and I guess my expectations are too when plates of food with such exotic favoring fails to be that flavorful.
author: April W.

description:
#1 reason: They messed up a dark and stormy that took over 30 mins.

-Inattentive waitress, unfamiliar with the menu. 
-questionable oyster
-overcooked meat
-why the hell is my overcooked meat taking so long!??? (over 1.5 hrs)

I would never return even if all the other restaurants were booked. cup-a-noodles would be more cost efficient and more gourmet.
author: Alena L.

description:
Mmm. Eating foie gras while it's still legal in California.

Went here for dinner and ended up sharing the appetizers with a few friends. Foie gras, poutine, suckling pig, hama hama and kumumoto (sp?) oysters and we were in foodie heaven. We went straight to dessert and ordered the black and white silk thingy. The vanilla layer was pretty light, but the chocolate layer was rich in a flavor. Surprisingly, the taste and consistency went really well with the pecan cookies.

Will definitely be back, even if not for the foie gras!
author: Kris I.

description: Appetizers are ok ambience is nice but waitress kept interrupting table and trying to kick us out
author: Maen M.

description: Thoroughly decent place.  I had the 38 North Chicken - it was tasty, but not mind-blowing.  The ambiance is nice, but nothing exemplary.
author: Kirk S.

description:
Likes:
Ambience: lighting is soft, but not in need of a flash light, cozy setting
Hostess and Waitress: friendly and accommodating
Cocktail selection
Everything but the salmon on the Skuna Bay Salmon dish

Dislikes:
Pork Loin was dry, could not be finished
I like my salmon flaky, ordered it medium, had to use a knife
"bread basket" used for complimentary bread was more like "bread trashcan" placed on floor beside server station
"bus guy" took plates, salt and pepper and all silverware before we could confirm if we were done or not
Cost. Because your food should back up your price
author: Ashley W.

description: Great tomato soup!  Get ready for salty food.  Creative, inventive dishes, cool decor.
author: Mark S.

description: Have been here several times. Have had a few fab meals but usually very meh. Sad to say I've dined probably the last time here. Quite expensive & even more salty. The food is way over seasoned & portions are on the smaller side. The king crab salad appetizer is a serious joke..I needed a magnifier to see the crab. Even the quality of the Poutine (one of their signature dishes) is no longer tasty. Could not find any beef in the sauce this time & wasn't hot. I'm sad cause I really want to love this place.
author: Alex M.

description: Sort of a three star place with four star prices. Long story short everything was good, nothing was great. Definitely would keep this on the list of potential dinner spots, but pretty low on it. Caters more to the business around the area (financial district after all). Good for company lunches, not so great for celebratory dinners.
author: Patricia K.

description: I was here for lunch with a friend. I got the Chicken Banh Mi and caramelized brussell sprouts and both were excellent. It would have been a higher rating except for the fact that the service was soooo slow, both items took forever to come out and the waiters seems stressed. They need to speeden up their kitchen!
author: Sunil R.

description:
Such a great evening, delicious and elegant dishes, the staff is very pleasant, polite and fine, especially Nicole, such a charming girl. The food is simply amazing: new American food, a mix of different tastes and countries, suitable for all tastes, perfect portions and wonderful desserts. 
Try it and you will not regret.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
A fantastic SF spot. All the little Yelpers keep complaining about the cost, but it is comparable to any other restaurant you'd find at this level. And the food lives up to the price- you can definitely tell  that the chef puts great care into the quality of ingredients he uses.

Started with the beet salad. It was beautiful to look at and had perfectly bright flavors. A super tasty start to a big meal.

Now the Poutine. A decadent dish that I would only eat maybe annually, so it had better be worth it! It was prepared classically and right on mark. I don't know what the guys secret is to the gravy (the most important detail of a good Poutine) but it is phenomenal!

The steak was cooked to perfection and I loved the texture of the little wheat berries that accompanied it- who woulda thunk wheat berries with steak? A divine concoction.

We ended with the pumpkin cheese cake. DAMN SO GOOD OMG. Nuff said.

Salt House is great and still lives up to it's name after all these years. I recommend it to anyone wanting a solid, tasty meal downtown.
author: nancy s.

description:
Oh no! Almost forgot to review Salt House. Was here for DAT lunch with coworkers. Sat on the top deck which overlooked the ground floor, kitchen and bar. Pretty cool since it felt more private yet we had the view to observe all the happenings if we chose to. 

All 4 of us started off with the chilled (something) soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jk1T4xIb_FH_SsiVng43HA?select=JTmk1Qm3umJbgK8Ws5Y1bg). Potato? None of us enjoyed it nor finished it. The soup was too chill. The consistency was creamy yet liquidy. The flavor was nowhere to be found. To me, it tasted like alfredo from a jar. Made my stomach queasy.

However, the second dish won us back. Braised pork shoulder with white polenta (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jk1T4xIb_FH_SsiVng43HA?select=6pyHMZ7ZCQUjgNpdhjVjAw). The pork was served in cubes with a tangy barbeque-like sauce. The meat was tender with tons of flavor. The white polenta was creamy with bits of lumps. Never had polenta served like that before. Sooo good. It was a very hearty dish, and the highlight of our meal.

For dessert, had the milk chocolate pot de creme (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jk1T4xIb_FH_SsiVng43HA?select=6G9WlxY6gpqrAp0gnaHTRQ). Literally was what it sounded like, a pot of cream. Layers of chocolate pudding-like cream, each with a different amount of richness and chocolate flavor. Topped with a shortbread cookie and a sprinkle of coffee beans. Yummy! 

Aside from the soup, great atmosphere, great food and great company. =)
author: Marti L.

description: Hell yes. Salt House is well worth it. Let's start with the handcrafted speakeasy-style fizzy drinks. With or without alcohol, they are delicious on a warm day. Then, the food. The food is amazing. Everything on the menu looked fantastic. from the grilled cheese and tomato soup, southern chicken sandwich and the burgers to the roasted duck salad and duck tacos, everyone in the group enjoyed everything. Dessert was an awesome treat as well - the peach and matcha green tea tart with sorbet was epic. Highly recommend!
author: Michael J.

description:
I was really happy to find poutine in San Francisco or even in the west coast in general. It's really difficult to find it or even find it at all, especially when people don't even know what it is outside of Québec. 
The fries are good when it comes to the rest such as the gravy and cheese that's where it has a different punch, but that is totally okay since even in Québec there are many different variations. 
Since this poutine looks just like a classique, I did not judge it a lot. Is it good? YES. The best, ummm well not compared to Québec but I am content to keep coming back for it. 
The gravy is good and it had I believe some sort of meat, I forgot what kind and also the cheese is good and I think I could taste some sour cream. 
Definitely coming back for an after work meal and perhaps a bear on the side. 
Reminds me a bit of Montréal.
author: Nadav M.

description: Salt House is a great place for Happy Hour, the food is ok.
author: Joe J.

description:
Why do I always go to places with great food but horrible service????

It was the week of Dreamforce and we got to the restaurant right when it opened. Place was booked for a table of 2, so we sat at the window, which we were perfectly fine with. 

Everything started off fine as we rolled through the menu and talked about how everything looked delish. 15 minutes roll by and the server comes over, no introduction, no hello, just a "what are you having?" In the rudest time ever, ps the restaurant is still empty. I'm sitting there like "can you say hi, introduce yourself, tell us about any specials, or maybe asking if we are fine with water"...seriously rude. So we tell him to give us another minute...guess a minute to him means 20. 

So we finally order. My soup comes out (the butternut squash - extremely good but it was like warm) and my coworkers salad comes out. We finish our starters and then the wait happens. The server NEVER comes back around while the tables behind us are already done with their meals and other groups are being sat. FINALLY an HOUR later out main course comes. I ordered a salad for my main course and my coworker ordered the mussels. Like it really takes an additional hour for those two items? Oh and did I mention his mussels were cold and when we tried to find the server to tell him he was no where to be found. But when we wanted the check he was there instantly. 

Overall, the food is decent, our server needs to be fired or leave his personal issues out the door. It's truly a shame, as I work a block away and was hoping to make this place a regular spot but one server can ruin the overall experience. 

I would say check the place out as the good is good, but don't have too high of expectations for the rest of it.
author: Lindsey M.

description: Great dinner.   Salmon with mushroom sauce was great.  Quail egg app was amazing.  Colleagues had great meals.   And a very good wine list.
author: John R.

description:
Dine About Town!

I was so excited to try this restaurant.  But I don't have a good experience.

Dine About Town's menu:  $17.95 for two courses.  The selection was very limited; two items from Course 1 and two items from Course 2 to choose from.  Course 1:  You can choose from salad or soup.  Course 2:  Salad or other dish that I forgot.  I think the combination was very weird.  

My auntie and I both chose the soup (forgot what in there) and the Chicken Salad.  The soup came with a LARGE plate and the portion was ridiculously small. It only took one minute to finish the soup.  The taste of the soup was good; very creamy and rich but the portion was too small.  I think the water bowl for my dog was even bigger.  

The portion of chicken salad was much better.  It came with four tiny pieces of flat bread.  The salad was soso.  The dressing was weird and the flat bread was hard, cold and overcooked.  

The service was bad.  Our waiter was not friendly at all.  He had no smile on his face.  It seemed like we owe him a lot of money.  He did not even check on us after he served the second course.  

The bill was about $39 without tips.  We gave $60 (because of no change) and waited for 5 minutes for him to come.  He said,"change back?"  We were like.....Are you kidding me?  I don't think we will pay more than $10 for this kind of service @_@

Overall, Salt House is just ok.  It is kinda over-priced restaurant.  The ingredients they use are fresh and the dishes are prepared well (the presentation of both dishes were nice).  However, nothing is  special to me and especially for the bad service.
author: Liza T.

description:
I had planned lunch with a colleague.  

I used Opentable.com to make a reservation for 1 pm.

Upon arriving, the restaurant was very full and there were numerous people awaiting tables.  We had both arrived a little early.  The space is a little cramped around the bar.  There is really not a good space to stand and enjoy a drink while awaiting a table. We ended up kind of just standing in the middle of the restaurant.

We were seated relatively at the time of our reservation.

After a period of time, a very friendly and professional female server came over and took our beverage order. She may have been a manager.  The drinks were brought out pretty quickly.  There was also some nice bread and water brought to the table.

There was a little delay before our food order was taken.  We placed our order.

The food came out in a timely manner.   Our server for our meal was professional and polite but I would not say overly friendly.

I ordered their burger with cheddar cheese.  It comes with a plentiful order of onion strings.  I requested the burger be cooked to the chef's preference.  This ended up as a very nice medium rare.  The burger was a good one.  It was not a huge burger.  The meat was quality beef though.  The condiments were also of good quality.  The onion strings were very good.  While this was a good burger, I do not think it was necessarily a $15 burger.

http://tinyurl.com/3b3s89y

My colleague's salmon dish looked appetizing.

http://tinyurl.com/4fcbyls

The ambiance is clean and modern.  This is a slightly upscale spot for an average lunch.  However, for dinner, it would be relatively casual.

Overall, this was a pretty good lunch.  I do think the cheeseburger was good but slightly costly.  The service was a little inconsistent.
author: Mark D.

description:
Decent entrees and nice beverage list. I came for the poutine, and it actually does not resemble the Canadian version at all. In the Great White North it is a  diner/fast food style dish available at a cheap price. This version is a fancypants version with short rib gravy. Mornay? Sheesh, well it was fine, but the fries could be a little crispier. Entrees were fish/meat based and they were good.
Oh yeah, they also have Maudite (beer) to further the Quebec connection with Poutine. Nice selection of cocktails and some wines, by the bottle and glass. Heavily slanted towards European wines, surprising to see in Northern California so close to wine country. The owners of this place also own Town Hall and Anchor and Hope.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Great interior, vide and environment. Arrived for a birthday party and sat at the bar. Asked for a spicy drink and received an awesome jalapeño drink with a piece of honey comb wrapped with a jalapeño. This set the bar high!

APPETIZERS
Sweet Corn Soup - JESUS THIS IS A MUST HAVE. It's a complete purée of sweet corn goodness. Probably the best I've had. 

SNACKS
Poutine - DISCO FRIES! Mozzarella, fries, amazing gravy YES YES YES.

Chips - how can you lose with a small plate of various chips and aioli? You can't with this. 

ENTREE

Natural Pork Loin - so moist, so good.
author: Ruben O.

description:
We had a fabulous meal at Salt House.  Aside for the very attentive service in their lovely upstairs mezzanine, we had a delicious meal for six that was at once homey and sophisticated.  The seafood plateau selection was generous and delicious.  Interesting dishes ranged from the seasonal roasted fruits and vegetables to a persimmon cannoli stuffed with crab.  Our hanger steak was beautifully aged.

Our only wish would be to have a restaurant of equal calibre and value in Menlo Park.  Honestly, the Peninsula needs to step up it's game!
author: S K.

description: Delicious. The octopus with carnitas and peaches was amazing. The Halibut was delicious with crispy skin.
author: Julie H.

description:
WOW! The best halibut I have had...so far! The crispy shrimp salad is so flavorful and perfect for sharing. I love that the portions are not too large and everything is presented beautifully. The ambiance is great and the waiters know how to pair drinks with what you are having for dinner. 
I can not wait to go back again...this time, I will save room for desert.
author: Kellie N.

description:
The staff is attentive, friendly and efficient.   The food is very good.   This place is on the pricey side but it has a great ambience and the staff makes it worthwhile.  I've been to Salt House about five times and enjoyed myself and my meal each time.  It fills up very quickly, so reservations are a good idea.    I love dining in SF and Salt House is the quintessential SF-dining experience.

Plus, they got Acme bread, which is the most freakin awesome thing ever.   I'm not a carb freak because I can no longer afford to be, but Acme bread is  so good and I eat so much of it that I know I should google bread rehab facilities, but it is so good that I'll never quit.
author: Wayne S.

description:
I don't know why this place has 3.5 starts. I've already been there twice and would go back any day! Everything we've had has been so tasty and well presented and I usually walk out super full!
Last time we tried the garden vegetables app and it was great! The John Dory was good, but what surprised me most was the Chicken with sausage .. very well cooked and so tasty!
Service is decent .. ambiance is SF typical.
author: Shirin E.

description:
This review is just for the drinks.

I came here with one of my candidates for drinks on a Friday around 5:00pm. Not too crowed (which was nice). We were there early enough to actually grab a table (also very nice) and the waitress gave us some water which she left in a carafe (major points). 

To start I had the Bijou and she had the Pistol & Petal. I had ordered the Bijou because it had gin in it...but I didn't realize that it really was all alcohol. Nothing to cut it with so it TASTED like alcohol. Which is fine, but for 5:00pm, a little early. The Pistol & Petal was DELICIOUS! It had orange peel in it and tasted orangy (is that a word?) without being "fruity". We both ordered those the the second time around.

Good atmosphere. Not super attentive waitstaff, but it was fine becuase we were there early enough. I would absolutely come back here for drinks.
author: Melissa N.

description:
I have been hearing great review of this restaurant and I am so glad to come here for lunch.

Ordered the duck salad and it was excellent. The dining area is very comfortable and the restaurant was packed but the noise is still tolerable.

I have now found another great spot for lunch in SF.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Found parking across the street.  Took a seat at the bar.  Carrie, the bartender, was very friendly and helpful and provided excellent service.

Hubby had the Racer 5 IPA on draft ($7) and I had a glass of the Ferrari Rose ($16).  We started with half a dozen of the Calm Cove oysters - it was plump and sweet.  The freshly grated horseradish is fantastic.  We also had the veal sweetbread w/ English peas, pearl onions and bacon ($14) - delicious!  I love peas, the English peas were perfectly cooked - still firm and you can really taste the sweetness, the bacon adds a nice flavor to the dish.  The sweetbread was crispy on the outside and soft inside - the brown butter jus was very flavorful - so good that I wiped some w/ the bread.  

Should have stayed here to enjoy more oysters and tried other apps instead of heading to Roy's...oh well, will return to have the Poutine and other dishes - still at the bar, not a place to "dine" for us.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I am sad to report that I was thoroughly unimpressed with my dinner at Salt House. Having been here for drinks after work (and enjoyed myself quite a bit), I decided to come back for dinner.

The poutine was nothing extraordinary. The fries were average, the gravy average (almost watery), and everything borderlined on being too soggy. It was also extremely filling - it will certainly take away from the entree items if you don't discipline yourself. It was also so salted that I felt extremely thirsty throughout the meal after consuming it.

The salmon entree was also nothing special - not as fresh as it should have been, and did not bring out the bright butteriness that you would look for and desire in a great salmon dish. As my friend noted, it was "fishy." The corn on the plate stole the show.

The steak entree was quite good - prepared just right (perfect medium rare) with great flavor. This is the definite highlight of the night.

Service was also scattered/inconsistent/lacked warmth - we also had to ask for bread 3 times before actually receiving it, and overall lacked a personal touch/friendliness. For the steep prices that Salt House demands in the highly competitive FiDi/SOMA area, there are MUCH better options based on this experience.
author: Jocelin L.

description: Loved Salt House.  It is my 2nd time here, the first time was when it first opened so has been many years.  I got the heirloom tomato gazpacho (delicious) and the halibut with squash blossoms!  It was amazing.  The wine line was excellent.  The only thing that was a criticism is that it's pretty loud but the food was well worth it.
author: Lisa N.

description:
I was very turned off by the first few Yelp! photos, but I couldn't be happier with my experience. 

We had phenomenal wines, including the rose, and the food was pitch perfect. 

Seasonal root veggies, perfectly cooked beef and pork, and an amazingly balanced desert.
author: Bay M.

description:
Salt House gets packed. really packed. so make reservations, and if you're here for two, make it for upstairs overlooking the bottom floor.

salt house is great for business meetings with high profile clients, romantic dinner for twos, after work happy hours, catch up with friends, or foodies looking for new culinary adventures & savory bites.

the noise level matches the ever bustling atmosphere in here but is not too loud to have a decent conversation & the high ceilings & exposed brick walls somehow lessens the overcrowded feeling during peak times.

we ordered the foie gras, petrale sole & polenta. 

the foie gras is served two ways; cured and sautéed accompanied by kumquats, rhubarb and huckleberries. all that + a bag of chips.
the petrale sole was tasty. an onion fondue with baby shiitakes, chorizo and manila clams. unfortunately, i didn't try the polenta but my company for the night had made high remarks.

if you have come to eat, be prepared to spend in the $$$ price range, or just come with friends, grab a drink and mingle at the bar area. it's a very solid dining choice for sure.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is ok, because I think the best was their bread with butter :)

I ordered the Petrole Sole and I think I have had better fish :) I am sorry but I really didn't taste anything spectacular at this place especially for the price I paid.

Maybe I shall give it another try and order a different dish next time...
author: Tiffany K.

description:
We came here with a group of 8 for a work lunch. They were busy (full) as usual and food service was slow (around half an hour+ for the food to come out). The pricing is certainly high given the flavor is way on the low end of the scale and the service dismissive. Multiple servers were cold and lifeless.

I wasn't in a seafood mood which cuts out about half the menu so I had the $17 burger (actually I think it was about $20 as I added avocado). The meat came out beyond well-done even though it was ordered medium-well, a big thick dry patty with zero flavoring. Also it tasted fishy, I think it was cooked next to or just after one of the seafood burgers, gross. The bun looks fancy but is flavorless. Fries are super dry and lack salt or seasoning, so I asked for dipping sauces (ketchup and ranch) for myself and co-worker who also had fries as there is no sauce at the table. The guy brought back 1 very small side of ketchup (like 2 tablespoons) and a little Tabasco... They don't have ranch and apparently it's unusual to get ketchup with your fries. Anyway we had to ask him to get more ketchup as obviously it wasn't enough sauce for the two of us.

Others in our group seemed mildly more positive about their chicken wings, chicken sandwiches, and salads, but nobody was amazed by any means. Apparently the fresh juice drinks are refreshing, but they really are tiny as it's mostly ice. The sweet potato chips are good, but it's a tiny bar-sized snack for $6. Even as a free work lunch they are pretty pointless, almost anywhere else would be preferable. Giving them a small bump for convenient location and okay ambiance.
author: Munok S.

description:
Overpriced and under-delivered - quite an awful combination. 

The only positive was the poutine fries, which admittedly were unique, savory without being salty and had the perfectly melted cheesy texture that I love. However, one solid side dish is not enough to make up for a menu filled with mediocrity and lack of any real flavor. 

We had the pork loin, the alaskan hailbut and the pacific cod as our main entrees. To be honest, we couldn't really tell our fishes apart from each other - they tasted quite identical and were equally flavorless. The pork loin was chewy and quite hard - certainly lacked the tenderness we were hoping for. We also ordered their specialty drink - the Elysium dream (an Elderflower sparkling Riesling cocktail) at a whopping $16. It was way too sour and quite unappetizing for a refreshing cocktail. 

All in all, I highly recommend trying other reputable SOMA dining establishments including Salt House's sister restaurant, Town Hall, before popping in here.
author: Priya S.

description: Had dinner there with friends recently. The venue is nice, warm, and comfortable. The place was very busy which may account for the slow food delivery. We were not in a rush, so did not mind. The waitress was friendly.  The food itself, appetizer Tuna Crudo and mains Skuna Bay Salmon and Gnocci was "fine". For me, not high on the flavor scale. They did have a nice selection of wine. Summary: Nice place but they are a lot of great restaurants in the city.
author: Scott F.

description: Food and drinks were incredible. Ambiance was perfect. The general manager Chelsea was stunningly generous and kind.
author: Luke R.

description:
There were four of us and a reservation was essential, but it didn't prevent us from waiting a long time for our food. However, the hostess acknowledged the issue, assured us the food would be out shortly and offered us an additional round of drinks to compensate us for our wait. We appreciated that gesture. 

For our entrees, two of us ordered the pork and the other two had scallops. With these two items, the portion size fluctuated dramatically. The pork loin was both generous and delicious. Equally tasty were the day scallops, but there were only three of them (that's an appetizer portion.)

We each had a different dessert and we enjoyed them all. 

Overall, my experience was positive and I'd go back for dinner again.
author: Paul B.

description:
+ great wine selection
+ ling cod - nicely cooked and comes with english peas, which I'm a HUGE fan of

Poutine (apparently a Canadian classic) was average. Basically, poutine is fries covered in gravy with cheese. 

I enjoyed myself because of all the wine I drank, but the food wasn't memorable.
author: Margaret R.

description: Great pork! I think the poutine could use some heat but tasty fries!
author: Lauren T.

description:
Oh Poutine, how I love you!  Seriously, what can be better then French fries smothered in mozzarella and short rib gravy???  I am always tempted to order this as my entrée but I could never get over the guilt.  I feel better about myself after I pretend share it as an appetizer. ; ) 

I work within a three minute walk from Salt House, so most of my vendor lunches take place here. The menu is constantly changing and highlights seasonal fruits and vegetables.  My favorites are the salmon and liberty duck (when they have it) entrees.  The burger is massive, comes with a side of garlic fries and very reasonably priced. Also, the service is great. The wait staff are just the right amount attentive without being annoying.
author: Ronita J.

description:
an intimate dinner for 6 to celebrate a birthday. 

this place was on my list to try and I finally had the chance. i wasn't expecting much, but I was blown away on how much I enjoyed this place!

must haves appetizers:
poutine fries
beet salad (goat burrata)

I expected the entrees to be visually enticing and small but I was dead wrong about the size! it was a large portion, none of us finished it (hmm maybe because we ordered 3 appetizers)! we all had a different entree and we tasted each one and none disappoint. I can't even name or describe what entrees we had but I am sure whatever you get will be a winner! I had the pork loin and loved it. 

the desserts were also delicious but this was on the smaller side. 

it has been 24 hours since I've eaten here and I wanna go back!
author: Rosalee C.

description:
This meal was not excellently prepared, as Yelp's example review template suggests you may want to mention.  The menu items seem to be creatively orchestrated but the execution in melding flavors was lacking. Each ingredient was just a component on the plate;the role of each component shined--with the exception of the protein in my entree. It was overlooked, grainy pork loin swimming in a too salty, brothy sauce and topped with a peach compote that was random. 

I'm still hungry...or craving/wishing for something more or different than what I got.

I have eaten here before and remembered it being a better experience...that was years ago though. I won't come back.
author: Sue W.

description:
My fiancé made a great Valentine's Day dinner choice and reserved Salt House. Apparently he does listen to my food & restaurant babble and realized that this was on my checklist!

I loved Salt House- from the decor, marketing, menu, food and service everything was great. We started with oysters and poutine (a must for lil Canadian me). The oysters were really large and the accompanying sauce was delicious. The poutine was a bit disappointing- not a fan of the really salty gravy.. but the fries were really good.

I ordered the salmon, bf ordered the steak. I liked the lentils that came with my dish- filling and healthy. The manager came to check on our dinners and introduced himself. It was a nice gesture and proved how great restaurant service CAN be. 

We were too full and still had half a bottle of red to finish so we skipped dessert. The menu was really tempting, especially the featured cheeses.

Salt House is great for date nights- a cute little spot with a lot of class.
author: Seema M.

description:
Lovely meal, from start to finish. Abby the manager, is amazing as well as Nick our waiter. Food is innovative and delicious. Everything we had was spot-on perfect. Before we had time to check out the menu, Abby brought us complimentary champagne and a starter just for fun. 
A new pastry chef was starting on Monday and someone from the kitchen came up with a dessert that I can still taste. It was a white chocolate cake, that was served stacked thin at angles, (stacked like pancakes) on the side a carrot sorbet with tarragon that had a bit of a crunch and then a slice of dark chocolate and something gooey white. Take a bite of each component and it is other worldly. I'm not even a big dessert person but wow...talk about layers and layers of flavor. 
I love this place. I look forward to another dinner at Salt House. 
Oh, and I am not only particular but I send things back and complain easily if something isn't right. I am so happy to find a restaurant where everything was perfect. Trust me, my friend was even more happy that I was happy.
You can tell the staff loves working there because it has that charming family feel. Well, that and two of them actually said that.
author: Lanie D.

description:
Salt House is a really nice looking restaurant with food prices to match it. There's quite a rush of business people eating in here during lunch time. Try to make reservations ahead of time or there might only be bar seating. Lastly, the restroom is not inside the restaurant, but accessible by going out the back door.

== Food ==

Burger and fries. The meat is really fresh and made the way you like it. Be careful with medium rare as it comes out to be very dripping juicy. The toppings are onions, pickles, tomatoes, and lettuce which comes out on the side for you. Pick and choose whatever you like in your burger. The bread is really soft and fluffy.

== Service ==

Service was pretty good. They were very busy and it was hard to flag down someone.

== Overall ==

Salt House makes a really good burger but it's pricy. In my opinion, it's not worth $15 for it for a regular daily lunch.
author: Steven B.

description:
Sometimes, you're obligated to frequent some businesses. 

In my case, Salt House is one of those businesses simply because it is located in the same building I work at. Can't argue with that, right?

Fortunately, Salt House is a great all-round restaurant that has hit the spot every time I've visited.

While the appetizers and snacks are all solid choices, I find myself coming here for the variety of exotic meat/poultry/fish dishes they offer, like:
- Day Boat Scallops: braised endive / sunchokes / black trumpets / brown butter pomegranate sauce ($29)
- Stuffed Pheasant Breast: port glazed lentils / quince purée / kumquats / winter vegetables ($32)
- Trout ($28) and Swordfish ($30): both dishes equally soft and buttery and perfectly seasoned. I prefer the swordfish because their lemon cherry marmalade is killer.

-----

Distinguishing factor: Quality food, fulfilling menu, and an ambiance that is near-perfect for a date or intimate dinner.
author: Nick A.

description:
Meet The DIVA.

She is almost always late.  She has 50+ purses shoved in her closets.  She has a chihuahua named Sarah Vaughan that she dresses up in outfits.  She took a cab from her hotel (4th & Mission) to Salt House (2nd & Mission) because it was "too cold."  But under that divalicious exterior lies a heart of pure gold.  (Though really she would prefer platinum.)  

The Diva likes COCKTAILS.

It was apropos to order "Lil' Peach" cocktails since she was visiting from Georgia.  It was as a summertime cocktail should be - fruity, strong but not too sweet.  She said it was "decent" and then immediately ordered another.

The Diva likes FRIED FOOD.

The last time I was here, the Poutine stood out.  You can't go wrong with fried potatoes and cheese but the rib gravy is what makes this dish memorable.  My friend agreed and dubbed it her favorite dish.  We also liked the perfectly fried and seasoned Shrimp that garnished the salad of Spicy Green Beans, Serrano Ham, & Almonds.  (But she was displeased that there were only four shrimp.)  However she did say,  "I am impressed thus far."

The Diva likes SEAFOOD.

She grew up in N'awlins, so she's picky about her seafood.  I had the Petrale Sole and loved it mostly because was accompanied by a Sweet White Corn, Spelt & Squash combo that was fantastic! Especially as it was juxtaposed on the plate with a delicious savory Pesto.  She had the heartier Halibut with Pork Hocks, Porcini & Romano Beans.  She enjoyed it, especially the rich sauce, but we agreed that my dish was the better of the two.

The Diva likes SWEETS.

The Nectarine & Cherry Pie was calling my name but she doesn't "do cooked fruits."  Instead, we had the Cookie Plate and it quite a plate!  There was a nice variety of about a dozen cookies.  We tried the classic chocolate chip (ok) and the butter cookie loaded with homemade gooey caramel in the middle (very good) before we cried uncle.  [I took the rest home to my neighbor and he scarfed them down in about 5 minutes.]

The Diva was PLEASED.  (And so was I.)
author: Amy C.

description:
Heyyyyy nowwwww, it's my first official Yelp check-in! Yep, got the new smartphone last night & had to break in my new check-in capabilities with a nice lunch with Raina S. at Salt House. Plus Raina picked it & offered to pay...how could I refuse? 

We arrived right around noon & the place was already packed. Since we didn't have a reservation (sorry, I'm not used to having to reserve a table at my usual casual lunch spots) we were seated at the cozy seats at the front window. By cozy I mean cramped, but we're both short so it was no problem ducking under the stairs & behind a crossbeam to get to our seats. This ended up being a cool place to sit cuz we had a great view of the hustle & bustle out on Mission Street. Oh, and we saw Joe Montana walking by. Another local celeb sighting! 

Our waitress was prompt & friendly & didn't mind that we decided to split everything. She even split up our butternut squash soup into 2 bowls. Nice touch! I love the bread they serve, I think it's Acme. It was great to scoop up the last remnants of soup out of the bowl. We also tried the poutine which is something I had never even heard of before. French fries, melted cheese, & gravy? Okay! It was very decadent and oh-so-good. I would definitely recommend sharing an order with friends cuz I imagine you might regret eating a whole bowl of it by yourself. 

Our main dish was the petrale sole with linguica & clams. The fish was cooked perfectly with a slight crunch on the outside. It was light but exactly what we needed after the carb-busting poutine. 

This is a great little spot but definitely out of my price range for lunch ($24 for one entree is pretty steep). I'd go back for a special occasion, or if someone else decides they want to treat me to a fancy lunch in SOMA!
author: Erin S.

description:
for some reason I enjoy having lunch here more than having dinner. The service was okey! I gotta give it to them though, every time Ive had lunch here I have been impressed by their service.
Must try: Octopus salad, last time I had octopus that was cooked so well was in Spain and Salt house topped it for sure!
author: Kajal P.

description:
Damn good I tells ya! 

5 stars for it's category (upper-middle priced dining). The space is really quite amazing, very modern and well appointed. Interestingly shaped mirrors line the foyer as you walk in. 

Service (especially the female bartender and the host) was top tier. And now a story to back it up... We walked in and didn't have a reservation. The host scoured the restaurant for a spot, and unfortunately it looked like it was going to be too long of a wait so we headed out the door. We took a few steps outside and the bartender chased us down and told us she was able to accommodate us at the bar. We were seated temporarily at the bar and as soon as a table opened up we were able to move over. Perfect.

I had oysters to start and roasted chicken. Admittedly I made a rather basic selection, but you'd be surprised how few restaurants can come through. Salt House scored high marks, presentation was good and the chicken was delicious. My only complaint was that my two glasses of wine (yes I'm a lush, the Pinot Noir and Zin) weren't all that exciting. 

I'll be back for more, stay tuned.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Excellent atmosphere. Excellent service. I highly recommend several of the appetizers. Especially the one with ravioli and duck is outstanding.  I have the cod for dinner and it was just OK. The seasonal vegetables were very skimpy and the fish didn't have any special flavor
author: Ed G.

description:
I have not been here in ages!  This is a good spot for happy hour. They have a really good selection of wine and nice bar snacks.
I ate dinner here as well.  Food was fresh, good.  V
Definitely on the pricey side...was not bad for a work dinner! :)
author: S G.

description: The fried chicken sandwich is so comforting and totally yummy.  Also, diverse wine by the glass selection.  If you like sitting at the bar, you'll receive warm genuine service while you dine...always a bonus :)
author: Ghazal V.

description:
So I read the reviews after the fact of going there.  I guess the question is did I make a good decision?  Yes, very much so.  I read the 2's and 3's because I wanted to see what they complained about the restaurant.  I can say without worrying about being crucified that Salt House is a keeper and you would be missing out a real treat to yourself and those that you care about if you don't go.  This is the short version of it..below is the extended explanation of why I gave it 5 stars.

It started earlier last week with me making reservations.  I was indecisive because I didn't know her schedule nor the place that well but we tend to try new places and so I thought it would be nice to see if the place is worth the coolness.  Anyhow, after a couple calls (she was patience with making the reservation) I also mention to her that I would bring a signed bottle from my friend for my girlfriend and I to celebrate.  Although the information was on their website (maybe I should've checked before asking) about corkage she told me as though it wasn't which made me feel not so much of an idiot.

I got there early because she was stuck in traffic so I presented them the wine and mention to them the occasion.   John asked me whether I want it chilled or iced.  I was perplexed until he mention to me that if I put it on ice the writing would disappear.  So they chilled it and I mention to them when to take it out and the prefer temperature, 55º degrees.

Before she arrived Caryn, our waitress gave me some pointers on what to have with the wine.  I was a blank canvas tonight.  She arrived, bottle disappeared into the restaurant.  We decided on having the salmon but before we had that she excused herself to the washroom.  I took that time to talk to Caryn about how to present the bottle.  I also placed the order for the salmon.  Caryn mention to me that the salmon would take some time so she suggested something before hand. Orders were placed and Caryn was gone.

Caryn, appears to my girlfriend's left side and mentions to her that they don't have the bottle she choose but they have......she was surprised to see the bottle.  And I thanked Caryn so much for presenting it at the time I requested.  Soon after that our appetizers came.  Shrimp were tender and melted in the mouth.  We enjoyed half the bottle before our entree came.  After taking one bite of the salmon I almost forgot my name.  Everyone knew our names like we always went there and this was our first time.  Wow, simply wow.

Warmness is something we don't take for granted and it was nice to be around individuals that actually were concern about us and not just collecting a check.  If I could tipped her more than I would.

There's no excuse in not going to Salt House.  Unless you don't want good food, service, atmosphere and a memorable experience.
author: Rickye J.

description: Food was fresh and prepared well. We had octopus & salad to start. Cod & Salmon/seafood as entrees. Only downfall was entrees took about 20-30 min after apps were cleared.  I'd prob give them another chance as food was good and we weren't in a hurry, so it worked out.  Overall good but not great experience due to delay.
author: John W.

description:
Went here for a celebration dinner on a Thursday night.  Everything was good but ultimately underwhelming.  There's a lot of amazing places in the city to have a big night out.  This one feels like it's trying to be on par with the big dogs but you come out feeling like you paid a bit too much for a good but not great dinner.

That said its worth a try if you're in town on business.  The halibut was delicious but skip the chicken.  It's stuffed with other meats and nothing worth writing home about.  Great bar and cool vibes but needs to step up their game or lower their prices.
author: Rich L.

description:
I was a little trepidatious about this place after reading the reviews... overpriced food with poor/snooty service? 'even the best french-fry-cheese-curd-gravy combination in the world couldn't make up for those shortcomings,' I said to myself.

Lucky, most of those negatives didn't surface during my dinner.

The waiter we had was new, and a little overly-friendly, and he still had some work to do on the timing of all the courses, but I appreciate 'too nice' and 'trying too hard' from a waiter, even if the end result isn't immaculate service.

The food overall was good. Good rustic bread, good oysters, good poutine, good salad (although still not sure what a chicory is?), and my beef 2 ways (some kind of regular steak and then some beef cheek) was very good, especially all the other things on the plate. The steak 1 way was a little cold/dry (probably because it was pre-sliced and had been sitting for a little while?), but overall the flavors were really good..

I'd say that this was not my favorite meal of my life, but decent enough and bonus star for the nice staff and the cool ambiance.
author: Jake D.

description:
I had a terrible experience at this restaurant. We ordered the Seafood Plateau, which is essentially a selection of raw oysters, mussels, clams and shrimp. Two of the oysters on the plate were rank - I discovered this by putting one in my mouth and chewing it. I nearly lost everything right there at the table. I then smelt the rest of the oysters and another one was the same.
The prices at this restaurant indicate that this should be high quality seafood and it was not. The server was very apologetic but it didn't make me feel any better and the taste essentially ruined the evening for me. There are plenty of fantastic restaurants in San Francisco, so I won't be coming back to this one!!
author: Bree D.

description:
Maybe I came on an off night, maybe they had a new line cook, maybe Jupiter's alignment with Saturn was off...there are a lot of maybes.

All I know is that on the night of my friend's bday dinner Salt House lived up to it's name...and not in a good way.

Every entree that made it to the table was incredibly over seasoned almost to the point of being inedible. At first I thought it was just my Scallops that had been slighted, but as the meal progressed I couldn't help but notice that the rest of the table wasn't as enthusiastic about their meals as they usually were.

As my friend Brian B put it...Ya'll know I like a good salt lick every now and then, but this polenta is SALTY!

It's a shame because the restaurant was beautiful, the cocktails were on point, and the staff seemed friendly enough (okay, so our waitress overcharged us on several items but I'm willing to chalk that up to the busy night). I just couldn't get over the carelessess of how everything was seasoned. 

Salt House just misses the mark.
author: Kevin T.

description:
I came during "late lunch" but this was perfect because the restaurant was not busy at all and I just wanted to try the Poutine. If we were in the mood to drink, maybe we would have gotten drinks as well since we sat at the bar.

The bartender was nice and our fries came out quickly. The server poured the gravy on the french fries in front of us. The dish was tasty but I definitely need to try some authentic poutine from Canada someday.

The interior design was nice and the staff was nice--I'd say this is a nice date spot.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Slow start on the service, but I think it was because we were hungry and maybe a little aloof:

1. Good location/parking/valet for $10 bucks
2. Deliciously fresh oysters! (could use more creative side sauces though)
3. Tastily-strong cocktails
4. Open Late-ish for Dinner
5. Attentive wait staff when noticed.
6. Some dishes a bit overpriced--but scrumptious nonetheless.

Now that's the most bipolar review you'll ever read: don't blame me--I'm a Gemini.
author: Mennlay A.

description:
I came for lunch with two of my girlfriends. I made reservations through Open Table and they had a table open for us when we arrived. My friends ordered the dine about town dishes while I opted for the burger with onion rings.

The duck rillettes with kumquat marmalade were good, as was the apple curry soup. 

For entrees, they had the ciopinno and the Moroccan chicken salad. neither finished their entree. 

When my burger came out, it had the wrong cheese (i ordered cheddar and they brought me one with blue) so i sent it back. When i got the correct burger (not less than two minutes later) the onion strings were very cold, so i had to send that back. 

The burger ($14.50) was decent, nothing special. It came with lettuce and nothing else. they give you little containers with ketchup and mustard, though. it was also a little on the small side. 

Even though the service was very good, and the place itself was hip, the food was not good enough to bring me back.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I have been here for both dinner and lunch and found both to be very good.  It can get crowded so reservations are a must.  The atmosphere is very SF with good energy and décor.  The cocktails are great - I think we sampled nearly every one the menu.  

Dishes I recommend:
POUTINE (fries with gravy)
SALT HOUSE BERGUR
FRIED CHICKEN SANDWHICH
COLEMAN RANCH PORK LOIN
HALIBUT

Drinks I recommend:
WAISTCOAT AND TAR
THE SABOTEUR
MILANO MULE 

I have been underwhelmed by the salads but certainly always leave satisfied
author: Dylan G.

description:
This is what salt house needs to do.  Make the place more casual, and approachable, and less expensive. And improve the quality of their service and their food. 

Basically, what i'm saying is ...this place is OK. There are tons of places that are worse...but the basically, the price/performance ratio is off.
author: amit s.

description:
I came here for lunch around 12:30PM on a Thursday. We made a reservation and were seated immediately. 

I had the flounder sandwich. It was delicious! The flounder was a bit saltier than expected but it worked with all the bread and avocado. Afterward, the five of us split 3 desserts and couldn't finish any of them. The apple galette, chocolate hazelnut, and pumpkin cheesecake were all incredible. I could probably have eaten five of those apple galettes if given the opportunity. 

The interior of this restaurant is beautiful. It has that modern industrial look with metal and wood accents and tons of natural light. Love it! 

Unfortunately, it took forever for our food to come out. Our server was sweet, but she didn't make up for the fact that we waited almost 30 minutes to eat.
author: Anna N.

description: We had the crab cake balls and shishito peppers followed by the turkey sandwich and sea bass. Everything was delicious, arrived promptly, and was well sized.  Will definitely return the explore more of the menu.  Excellent wait staff were friendly and abundant.
author: Anthony S.

description:
I have been to Town Hall so it deemed fit to finally try out Salt House. 

Reservations changed from 4 to 6 to 8. They were very accommodating which was good. Getting seated took a while though. Finally got seated- service was a bit slow. Waiting waiting waiting .......for menus, the waiter, bread, mains.....

Anywho, POUTINE! That's why I wanted to try this place. Fries were super delicious. Curds were melted atop. Short Rib Gravy was rich and hearty. It was salty though!! Could of used less...
