Entree was the Foulton Chicken. It was moist!! YUM! The bacon or ham or something that was in my veggie mix was realllllly hard. I even took it out of my mouth thinking it was like un-edible. It was wayy overcooked to point of "It's like chewing on a rock." 

Overall, for the price point I wasn't too impressed. I did like the Poutine but wouldn't come back here. Town Hall is the better of the pair.

3.5 stars.
author: Angela D.

description:
I wrote a review in the past, not sure why it was removed. 

I came here for lunch and had Pacific cod for $24- it came with gulf prawns, mussels,
little neck clams, and cioppino broth. The  broth was flavorful, cod was tasty, the mussels and clams were not special. The portion was small and I did not see the value to the entree. It was just ok, at the price I've had much better. As well I wanted to order some appetizers but didn't see too many options to order from. 

Service was great and ambiance was very cute and stylish.

I will say I really like their burger here!
author: Azizi A.

description:
Minus 1 star right off the back for their lousy reservation system. More about that later..

Yesterday (3/28/13) my boss was in town visiting so I brought him and my colleagues here for lunch. I've previously visited Town Hall and Anchor & Hope and have been satisfied so I figured I would try Salt House since they all have the same owner. Overall the service we received from our waiter was good and the food selection was decent. I had the shrimp salad which was fine. 

Now back to their reservation system, I was really annoyed with the fact that I had a reservation for 12:30 but we were not seated until almost 1pm and its not like the restaurant has a waiting area either. My boss and colleagues had to stand outside on the sidewalk and wait with the crowd of people who also had a reservation. For a restaurant that charges $$$ I expected the manager to come over to my table and apologize for the wait at the end of our food service. But that didn't happen. 

I guess what im trying to say is that if you are looking for a restaurant that sticks to its reservation system and wont make you look like an idiot in front of your boss then this isn't it. I would suggest trying RN74 just a couple blocks down.

+3 stars for good food
+1 star for good waiter service
-1 star for reservation system
author: V I P.

description:
Came here with a friend recently, and I have to say it was ok but I would not say I was blown away. We actually came in because we wanted something with shortribs in it and while it showed up on Yelp, it apparently was something that was only on special. But we made do and I saw braised beef cheeks and hanger steak on the menu and was like sold! My friend got the chicken entree. We also shared a rabbit appetizer. Nothing was really anything to rave about in my opinion, it's ok. 

The service on the other hand was weird. The server would ask us questions and sort of look around the restaurant while we tried to answer and even filled it in with what she hoped we would say. 

Server: "How is everything over here,"
Us: "Oh can we get more wa..."
Server: "Great!"
tried to walk away... and we had to flag her down and the whole routine. So we ended up just drinking more alcohol in the end. Sucked. :-/

Sat by the window overlooking the street, was an overall interesting experience (Missed Lyft rendezvous, crazy people trying to make friends with us coming in the restaurant, etc).

Anyways probably won't come back, since it was pricey, not really wowed, and the service was really lacking
author: Greg G.

description: Great food but 3 stars for somewhat "so-so" service. If you come here during the lunch hour or dinner hour, service can be extremely slow. I'd come back but only if I had plenty of time.
author: Payal C.

description: Salt House was supposed to be one of those "San Francisco musts". Good ambiance - would be great for a date, but I wasn't impressed enough to want to come here again. Portion sizes are not impressive and the bill does some damage. We ordered the poached egg hash, which was tasty - the egg was cooked to perfection - I just wish there was more! I ordered the chili pepper rockfish for my entree, which had so much potential but was overcooked and extremely dry. A few drinks, appetizer, and an entree came to $100+/pp. I expect to be blown away at those prices. Can't say I was.
author: Denis M.

description: This place is pretty good, and a real cool atmosphere. I came here after work with some friends and had a great exerpeince...the quail egg is incredible. definitely get that. The service was good and the adult beverage were very well thought out. I would definitely recomend this place for anyone looking for a trendy dinner spot to take a date or clients.
author: Kyle H.

description:
Had dinner with a group of 8. I would give it 6 stars, based on what I ordered. 
Mixed nuts - tuna crudo - painted hill beef duo (a Devine dish!) - rum shortcake (just had the perfect sweetness, not too sweet that is)

Service was quick and friendly. I'll definitely come back when in SF again
author: Joris L.

description: went for work lunch. Everything was tasty from acme bread to poutine (althought I wish they added a little more of the mozzarella cheese curds) I was impressed with brussel sprouts and the rabbit dish. Citrus salad had a very tasty - not overpowering citrus vinaigrette. Our waitress was very helpful and attentive.
author: Julie R.

description:
It has been a LONG time since I have been here, but I can still remember the tenderness of their short rib - probably one of the best preparations I have had. The meat was perfectly cooked, the flavor was outstanding - like they marinated it for days!
Although, it is no longer being served, I have to point out that their foie gras was quite memorable.
I definitely need to go back and re-review. 
 (July 2011)
author: Charlene R.

description:
This place is gorgeous, and the staff has been great. I had a good meal. That's the only issue, it was just a 'good' meal. Plates hover around $30, and everything's an add on. Easy to spend $50 per person. I'll probably be back, but only because I happen to be walking by. 

Fun fact, you can transition quickly from dinner to dance through the back hallway straight into Harlot.
author: Eric W.

description:
A little too loud at first -- and a little cramped seating ... but the food and the service were very good. 

Tasty blistered peppers, nice burrata salad...

But the halibut entree was like magic in my mouth. Perfectly cooked, seared and seasoned, with delicately cut asparagus and a bed of quinoa. 

Is it strange to also remark that the coffee (which I was told was Illy Americano) was the best after-dinner coffee I an remember having at a restaurant?
author: Mark P.

description:
Here's what I enjoyed about Salt House:

1.  Someone else paid!
2.  Nice ambience, nice food, nicety-nice-nice.
3.  Did I mention that someone else paid?  

Here's the problem:

Salt House feels like a million other places I've been to.  It's quite good:  the food is tasty, the bread on the table is superb, my chorizo stuffed calamari on garbanzos was delish, service was excellent, ambience was winning.  On the flip side, there's nothing that makes this a place I'd run back to.  Matter of fact, I'd try another place just for the variety.  

I don't know what the "it" factor is that makes some places return destinations versus one-hit wonders.  Restauranteurs wish they knew.  Salt House seemingly does everything right, for a 1-time visit.  So go and enjoy, especially if someone else is paying.  

You'll see what I mean.
author: Tracey A.

description:
Love the vibe of Salt House- lots of wood grains and dimly lit exposed light bulbs.  It felt casual and warm.  Service was great and my water glass was never empty.  The poutine was tasty and I admit I'd order it again even though it wasn't blow-your-mind-amazing... but it's hard to turn down any kind of french fries topped with cheese, topped with gravy.  Just keepin it real. 

Came with a group and had a chance to sample the steak and salmon dishes.  Both good, but nothing that stuck me as special.  Neither was overcooked, which I definitely appreciated and I will say that the bed of corn that the salmon came on was pretty delicious.  I wonder if you could just order that as a side... 

I had the rock cod, and like the other entrees it was good (sorry, serious lack of adjectives here), but unmemorable.  All the different elements seemed appealing. The crisp chorizo "chips" on top were an interesting add on, but overall the flavors somehow seemed lacking and just didn't have that  "je ne sais quoi" that I was hoping to find.

I hoped dessert might save the meal from becoming just any ol' meal, but was not impressed with the german chocolate cake. The coconut ice cream saved it from being a total wash.
author: Melanie C.

description:
The burger with white white (Yes, I wrote white twice), fries and what shall we have to share?

How about more fries, but this time sprinkle them with even more cheddar and dump a gallon of gravy on top of them.

But to save on the calories, just water please.

A beautiful lunch that will eventually require a triple bypass.
author: V B.

description:
I had my first meal in San Francisco at the Salt House and was quite satisfied with it.  The food is tasty, high quality and prepared with care.  Our waitress was attentive and first rate.  The food was prepared with care and brought out warm, no complaints, only compliments.

My only misgiving was the selection.  I ordered a hamburger and had two options for cheese: cheddar and blue cheese.  Both are fine choices, but quite honestly I have a problem with dairy which magnified through these two choices of cheese.  Swiss would have been the ideal option.  Second, there was quite a bit of pork and beef on the menu.  Additional poultry and/or fish options would have been ideal.

The atmosphere is open and quite a bit of office talk at the tables.

A good selection that I will recommend.
author: Marc G.

description:
Could not have been more surprised and pleased with everything I had last evening. Excellent cocktails, well curated wines by the glass & warmest, most attentive service in a while from such crazy busy restaurants in the financial district.
Even though it was packed & busy, our table of 6 was well taken care of. My personal faves: the pickled eggs, a must with the homemade chips as starters; the beet salad was a revelation, perfectly balanced, seasoned & textured; the salmon, smoked potatoes & sautéed rapini; and ending with sticky toffee pudding. Only complaint was the salmon was under salted & dessert was too much cake to ice cream ratio. The cod & beef duo was also popular around the table, but I was lost in my meal & declined tasting.
Will absolutely have to return to try everything else & also visit Townhall which some girls at the bar recommended as equally great food.
author: Johnny V.

description:
I came here for a Friday night holiday celebration dinner with my partner and friends. I was looking forward to it because we rarely go downtown and it was a cold evening to walk around and see the holiday lights and feel the downtown energy. It was great to try a new place.

We were assaulted upon entry with a small entry area crowded by 4 people at the bar which is smack up next to a standard door opening flanked by the host station with a stair about 5 feet away. There was so much commotion in such a small area, that it was very off-putting. We were seated right away so we didn't need to spend too much time in that small crowded area.

The second assault is on the ears - loud, loud, loud. And it is no wonder - hard materials everywhere including steel beams holding up the mezzanine and we were seated right next to the bar under the mezz, not for from the entry. This is not a pleasant place to sit, hard to talk, but I suspect it is very loud anywhere in here. Oh, and it is very dark so as is typical in high end restaurants, it is also pretty dimly lit. I am embarrassed to take out my flashlight on my iPhone, but it was all I could do to read the menu!

Overall, the service was fine, attentive, friendly but a bit too perky. The food was pretty good - large portions and interesting mix of flavors. We had the pork loin which comes as a bone-in leg and a roast. The roast was so difficult to cut that I was building up a sweat. Fortunately, once I got bite-sizes, it was reasonably tender, a bit dry and average flavor.The potato"souffle" was the best item on the plate - light, rich and tasty. Also the bread is excellent, but not the reason one goes to an expensive restaurant.

So it was OK, but nothing stood out to make it memorable. I wouldn't go back again considering how many other restaurants are available.
author: Jonathan P.

description: Lunch was good - but not superb.  The vibe and energy was nice.  But food was a bit forget-able.  The poutine was bland and a bit on the soggy side.  Thai shrimp salad looked beautiful when it was served - but that was the best it got.  Shrimp were flavorless..  Seems ironic that a restaurant named "Salt" seemed reluctant to put enough on its food.  Maybe I caught them on an off kitchen day.  It was a Thursday and it was packed.  So it's obviously very popular.  I will give them another chance, just because it seems like a fun place to have lunch.  i just hope the food is better next time.
author: Lewis C.

description: Went here for a business lunch. I had the beet salad and the eggplant sandwich - both delicious. Great ambience and service, definitely gets crowded so get here early.
author: JD D.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here - if you can find a man to pick up the tab like I did - go! $90 for a bottle of wine? even more delicious when someone else is paying.
author: Kristina B.

description:
Came here for dinner with my mother-in-law.  

She is a fairly picky eater and definitely not on the adventurous side.

I ordered the Burrata to start and had the gnocchi for dinner.  My monther-in-law ordered the Coleman Ranch Pork Tenderloin.

I LOVED both my dished.  You cannot really go wrong with burrata... The gnocchi was utterly fantastic.  They were light, fluffy and tasted like heaven.

Per my mother-in-law, she LOVED the pork tenderloin.  She thought is was very tasty and was very happy with her meal. And what totally made her evening is that they carried Coke - the REAL cola.  The other night we were at Marlowe and she was pretty perturbed that they carried some unknown cola brand....

The service was fantastic.  Johnny was our server and he was extremely polite and helpful.

I absolutely would recommend this place for dinner out!
author: Emme F.

description: This is a fantastic small restaurant near the convention center.  I brought a group of clients here and we all enjoyed our meals immensely.  We sat upstairs which was a nice, out of the way location.  It's a little on the loud side, but we all enjoyed our dinners so much that we didn't mind. I will definitely be back.
author: Ruby R.

description:
Salt House has been offering quality food at prices which are built on years of FiDi fandom. Said another, they're good and they know it. 

I won't bother to highlight any particular dish except the poutine. In general, the portions aren't large, but they're rich. You won't go wrong on the menu but if you haven't eaten poutine previously, this is a good example. Oh, they carry some quality bourbons too.
author: Mike H.

description:
this restaurant is very chic' and is made for romantic dinners, business meeting with high profile clients, and foodies alike.  The ambiance was great and the noise level was typical with no one talking over each other to see who could be the loudest.  

We started out with the mixed nuts which could get a little bland if it weren't for the sweetness and consistency of the sugary goodness of the honey that accompanied.  Then I moved on to the Alaskan cod which was magnificent and my company had the Fulton Valley chicken which has to be some of the best I've ever tasted.  I would go back again in a heartbeat!
author: Kevin J.

description:
I came here for lunch right after the Giants parade. The hostess looked at my friend and me like we were kids,who shouldn't be in the restaurant, but I didn't let that get to me. Other than that, the service was good. 

I had their salmon sandwich with their homemade potato chips. My friend had their sear albacore tuna. Both dishes were delicious! If I had a second choice I would get the tuna over the sandwich. 

I plan to come here for dinner one of these days.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Delicious, crowded, a few veggie options, great cocktails, though they seem purposefully small.

The food was all very delicious, though I enjoyed the cocktails much more. The ambiance/decor was great, and so was the service.

I'll be back.
author: Jeff M.

description: We went here with a group of 7 to celebrate a b'day. The drinks were great and we really liked all of our apps. Things went a bit south with the entrees - only 2 of us really cared for what we ordered. The ambiance is nice too. I certainly don't feel compelled to make a repeat visit, but it was fine.
author: Kent C.

description:
Love the atmosphere in salt house, it always has a noisy but lively feel whenever I go there. Limited menu which gives me confidence that everything is cooked fresh.
Some of the prices seem a little steep which for me the only difference between a 5 and a 4 star review.
author: Simon D.

description:
Good food, okay service, but very long gap between apps and entrees, and where the HELL are my leftovers???

My DP talked me into an extra appetizer and I specifically said yes because I decided to take half of my entree home for another meal. Well, we finished our meal, paid the bill, sat and sat chatting for like ten or fifteen more minutes while we chatted. Finally said our goodbyes when I was on the friggin' BRIDGE when I realized we never got our leftovers. Damn it. Seriously, I can't justify that tab for ONE meal. It was tolerable for two meals. I think I'm done with Salt House. I am so bummed. That was like four and a half ounces of duck. Seriously. I am SAD! =(
author: Karen Z.

description:
I would give Salt House a 3.5 if I could! I thought the food was good just a bit overpriced, which I think is unfair because this is probably a normal price range for this area and this type of restaurant. I feel that I would rather go to a different restaurant for that price range. Service is really great and the decor, more so. Here's what we ordered:

Chips: basically just fancy chips. The aioli dip is yummy though.
Pork loin: the apple sauce on top of this is surprisingly complementary (I'm usually not a fan of fruit on my meat).
Braised beef: really tender but I thought that the pork loin was better
author: Alli Q.

description:
I'll start with the positives. Staff is incredibly nice from hostess, to bar tender, to server. My manhattan was perfect and we were seated promptly at our reservation time. 

The poutine is very good but it's fried potatoes, brown gravy, and melted curds (kudos for not trying to phone it in with grated cheese). So not too much credit to be given. 

I ordered White Sea Bass. While the broth was fantastic it was so over cooked I couldn't cut through it. Sadly I was under a time constraint and could not wait another 30 min for a replacement dish (something went very wrong in the kitchen the night I was there, you could see it on the wait staff's faces). 

GF had gnocchi. It was ok, nothing to race about and have certainly had better for less than $25. 

Long story short. Go for happy hour. I think dinner is way over rated after everything I've heard over the past couple of years.
author: John D.

description: Decor and ambience was nice. Service was slow, food was flavorless and bland. We ordered the poutine, risotto and some fish plate. Overpriced and definitely wouldn't reccomend it.
author: Vince L.

description: Service was subpar.  Waitress was slow and strained....food was above par even though the pound cake was old.
author: Terry B.

description:
I really want to like this place, so I won't let this review be the only one.... I came here after work with a friend one night, and we squeezed into a table for a quick bite to eat.  We ordered a dozen oysters, as well as champagne - obviously how else does one eat oysters?! The oysters were shucked well and they had a nice selection (kumamotos, kusshis, etc).  We also ordered a calamari dish to share along with the oysters.  This was served with beans and I don't think it was what my friend was expecting (fried calamari).  It was OK, but I definitely wouldn't be ordering it again.

I think I need to give Salt House another shot.  Maybe try the foie gras and crunchy shrimp?  At any rate, I'll be back soon.
author: Taylor L.

description:
I've been twice so far.  Ate both the cod and the steak.  All and all great food and reasonably priced.  Service was a little slow but it was lunch time.  

I would recommend booking a table since they get really packed at noon.
author: Barry S.

description:
SOOOOOOOOOOOOVERPRICED!!!!!!  

Classic high end restaurant where the food sounds good on the menu, and it shows up and you wonder where the food is.. Total corporate place..
author: Kieran D.

description: I got the chicken sandwich. It was really good- but definitely not worth $16.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Another great restaurant in Soma. Cool industrial vibe with very high ceilings and exposed brick. 

Was quite happy with my food. The pork belly appetizer was crispy and the accompanying figs were super sweet and simply delicious. My friend loved the foie gras. The steak was served over a tasty bed of corn kernels and a potato mash. The side of braised short ribs was a bit of a surprise but a tasty one. Portions are slightly larger size than you would expect at a higher-end place.

Only really negative was the crowd...I saw more than one tourist in shorts and athletic hoodies. Salt House is a nice restaurant, and although SF can be very casual. you should at least feign trying to dress up a bit.
author: Dave S.

description:
The moroccan chicken salad was excellent. Would've preferred more salad and less chicken. Protein overdose! I could barely finish my plate from the amount of food and wish that the dish was more balanced. The toasted pita bread on the side was burnt.  Nonetheless, the flavoring was wonderful. 

Salt House really shone through their desserts. Omg that lavendar blackberry jam cheesecake thing was ridiculously good. The right amount of creaminess that I want in a cheesecake. Adorable presentation in a jar and two ginger cookies on the side (though to be honest, I didn't taste the ginger).

The warm strawberry rhubarb shortcake was also delightful, but I preferred the cheesecake. The shortcake was not too sweet, and the rhubarb was melt in your mouth tasty. 

Perhaps the least impressive thing was the mint lemonade. Refreshing but I didn't like the bubbly in the lemonade. Not bad, just nothing I would order again.

While the food was seriously good, the price range is above my budget.... and I'm not sure I'd pay that price again for the food. But, excellent service and cozy restaurant. Great presentation.

I definitely have to come back out to try the poutine. I find it hilarious that poutine has become such a fancy thing... this is late night, after a night out type food in Canada!
author: Stef S.

description:
Salt House was DELISH! Be aware that you will spend a pretty penny here though...

We started off with drinks - and I was able to get one that wasn't even on the menu: I had been craving an espresso martini and the bartendress was kind of enough to make one for me! She brewed the espresso fresh and didn't use any creams and yet it was still one of the best ones I ever had. 

For dinner I had the grilled rib eye - which was a pretty big portion, I couldn't even finish it. We also had the stuffed calamari which was awesome. But don't think of it as your traditional fried calamari - it seemed more grilled and was stuffed but it was sooooo good. 

I also enjoyed the crowd which was lively and hip. They also have a communal table for you to eat at if you can't get a coveted reservation.
author: LuLu M.

description:
Salt House is a reliable casual/business lunch destination in the neighborhood.

Service is very efficient and friendly. Decor is beautiful, warm, inviting. Lunch menu options are good, though it would be great to update the menu more frequently.

The main reason I give it a 3 star is that the restaurant seems to be suffering from its proximity to the construction of a tower near by. We had lunch yesterday and the place smelled like kerosene. The smell of kerosene would come and go but it was extremely unpleasant to deal with.

The waiter acknowledged the smell but didn't offer any solution...
author: Andre H.

description: If you're in the mood to hang out with some friends and enjoy delicious oysters and have a few drinks, then this is your place! The oysters are absolutely exquisite and of the highest quality.
author: Ryan P.

description: To would rename this place Client House since whenever I have a client in town I bring them here. Closely located to my office with wonderful food and ambiance, it is an easy choice.
author: Ge O.

description:
Our dinner at Salt House was very satisfying. Overall, the dishes were very nicely prepared although they weren't mine-blowing. It's a pricey place, so it should be taken into consideration.

Starters-
poutine :: when we first saw their poutine, we knew we had made mistake by ordering too much food! often, portion of appetizers usually indicates the general portion for the rest of the meal.. and it was a lot of food. It could easily be an entree. the gravy and cheese really worked well together although I could've used a little bit more salt.

quail with black rice & mushrooms :: the quail was perfectly seasoned and cooked. I thought the rice was a bit too salty and not that interesting, yet again, it was a very big dish. I wish they had the crispy shrimp appetizer that everyone's talking about! 

Entrees-
dorade :: the fish was perfectly cooked and the terrine it came with was really delightful as well. 

38 north dry aged duck breast :: the dish came with two huge chunks of duck breast and other stuff. it was really awesome but by the time we got this dish, we were already replete with food before. wish we could've been more aware of the portion here.. but i am not complaining ;)

dessert-
urban s'more :: a super decadent and rich dessert.. again a big portion! the espresso marshmallow was very tasty, but the dish itself wasn't too interesting itself.
author: Sung C.

description:
Came here for lunch and had one of the best lunches (if not the best) lunch I've had in the area. 

We shared the crispy shrimp appetizer... this is definitely more green beans than shrimp, but it's a pretty good portion size. Came with four delicious shrimp. I liked how even though there weren't too many shrimp, it didn't seem like the green beans were just there as a filler. They did really add something. Entree was the duck confit... sooooo good. The duck was cooked perfectly, very tender and I loved the crispy skin. The lentils that it was sitting on were delicious as well. We even shared a pomegranite cheesecake in the end... I'm not a dessert person, but this was pretty good. 

Service was attentive and our waitress was really friendly. I thought that the price was right, I did not leave there hungry. It was packed at lunchtime and the place seemed a little crowded, but I love the interior and the open kitchen. The place and the service were both good, but it was really the food that made this place great for me.
author: Alison B.

description:
Short version:

Solid 4-star place with great service down to the home stretch.  Very decorative dishes plated well, and tasty, creative selections.

Long version:

After a roller coaster ride of a day, the lady decided to come here since it was one of the few upscale restaurants open late on a Monday night (they seat until 10:15pm).

We had a good recommendation from our server, Josh, and settled on a French Grenache, which was delish.

We decided to go tapas-style even though some of the entrées looked amazing.  Eventually, we settled on the olive "snack" plate, the mixed lettuce, the scallops, the white corn soup, the clams with sausage, and the foie gras - then we finished with the Red Hawk cheese.

First off, the olive selection was very good...normally I wouldn't note something like that but since it was an orderable item and we like it, done.  The mixed lettuce was very fresh and the croutons were buttered brioche pieces.

Josh was awesome and had the chef split the salad and the white corn soup, which was so good, I could've chugged a whole pot of it!  The scallops were PERFECT and just colored enough.  The weird thing about this dish, however, was the vegetable "soup" it came with.  While I liked the greens separately, in this particular dish with the scallops, it clashed and I think it would've suited something lighter like halibut better.

The octopus with fennel sausage and clams was BOMB!  Again, not enough for one person when done tapas-style, but seriously, can you really blame us for wanting so much variety?

I've said it before and I'll say it again...I'm a sucker for foie gras.  And before you get PETA all over my ass, check out Anthony Bourdain's video - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ABeWlY0KFv8.

Continuing...they brought out 3 different kinds!  It's like Christmas in July.  Now because I know more about foie gras than the lady, I suggested to taste it in this order (which, oddly enough, is the same order I'd recommend to all of you).  Taste the smoked first, then the "pâté", then the seared.

The smoked was very pleasant although, it was tiny.  Also the apricots or kumquats were VERY bitter and not quite ripe enough for the dish.  The pâté version was fabulous and so was the syrup/reduction...I think it was raspberry.  The seared was by far THE BEST thing of the night and the black currant syrup/reduction was absolutely heavenly.  I mean butter doesn't melt this quickly.  If I didn't have to worry about a balanced diet, I think I could eat seared foie gras every day at all 3 meals.


In between plates we were having a heavy discussion about how the day went and Josh came by to refill our wine and said "Just have more of this and you'll feel much better."  He was also a highlight of the evening.  They closed at 11pm and we were there until 11:30pm.  He kept asking us if we needed anything else and said it was no problem since he'd be there late anyway.  He was funny and not hovering, but attentive.  This guys was a pro.  

Even after we finished ordering he asked if we had room for dessert...after they'd closed their doors.  He said only one thing on the menu they couldn't do since the cooks were already gone, but everything else we could've ordered.  Since we'd already had such a decadent meal, we went with the cheese, which was a little softer than we had anticipated for cow's milk, but pleasant all the same...and the brioche it came with was like cake!  MMMmmm...

This was the perfect way to end a rugged day.  The ambiance was a typical loft-like SF joint.  I bet this would be an excellent place to have a private party or a business function that closes down the whole place.
author: Dylan T.

description:
Make reservation before you go, and bring your iphone!

4 stars for food, 3.5 stars for the wine list (but I love the wine I got), 3 stars for the service. 1 star for the line.

We were there the night before our civil wedding! What a sweet memory. Food was great, the portions of meat dish were small, I like the deco but it's a bit noisy, the most important, the wait is soooooooo long and the service is soooo slow. But I still give 4 stars for the food. Love it.

We walked in around 7:00 without and there was a long waiting list but the receptionist managed to put us into 8:15 slot, however we did not get our table till 8:40 or so I believe. Good I had my iPhone to kill time.

and wait for a bit long for the waiter to order, but the dish come pretty fast. The slow service reflect to my glass-- After the first refill my glass was empty for about 30 min and the waiter/waitress just keep forgetting my request of refilling.
author: Snow T.

description:
I think it was a Tuesday night and my coworkers wanted something new. On  to Salt house. For a Tuesday, the place was packed. We must be on an ever growing bubble.
The oysters and steak were delicious, wished I remember the beer i had (hard to find) and after a few hours of good food atmosphere and laughter, I had to go to the bathroom.
I ended up in the lobby of an office building, and there was pounding club music from somewhere near. After I left the lavatories I decided to explore. Behind a door or curtain, was back entrance to a night club. I went back to our table, we paid the bill , and went to the night club for a few more drinks. 
What a great evening, with a night club adjacent option.
cheers
author: Raffi A.

description:
I was torn about what to write on this review, having spent more than I expected going in, but this place serves damn good food, with good service, in a really killer location. 4 stars.

Crowd is well dressed FiDi and SOMA professionals, as you would expect, as well as shoppers from Union Square.  Good energy to this place.

To begin with, you walk in, and are immersed in this environment of wood, brick, and windows.  Great space.  I really dig it.  Small, but good bar, and a really excellent mezzanine dining area.  Grabbed a couple drinks at the bar pre-dinner.  Quality over quantity when it comes to selection of beer and wine.  They were actually out of the beer I initially wanted, and I gotta say, their drink menu is overpriced.  We requested a seat up in the mezzanine once dinner was offered at 5:30.  We were the only party seated up their for a good 45 minutes and were afforded a wonderful view of the activity below, while being able to maintain a distance from the noise and energy.  Neat experience.

Started off with the Crispy Shrimp ($14) and Baked Oysters ($13.5).  The oysters sounded great with bacon, leeks, and spinach, but were underwhelming and bready.  On the other hand, the shrimp, served alongside spicy grean beans, serrano ham, and almonds were divine, offering wonderful contrasts of texture, temperature, and flavors.  This dish worked on many levels, most importantly of which was flavor.  Truly delicious.

Shared the Loch Duart Salmon ($25.5) for the entree.  Once again, truly a wonderful, tasty dish.  Served with brussel sprouts, ham hocks, parsnips, and pimento jus, the flavors complimented each other wonderfully, while still allowing the delicous salmon flavor to shine.  This was also a mild salmon, cooked perfectly.  Decent portion size, but I would have preferred a slightly larger piece of salmon for the money.

Drinks are overpriced, but they offer respectable house wines at reasonable prices.

The Cranberry Financier (satsuma, brown butter ice cream, and toasted almonds) was a pleasant dessert, and served with a well made cappucino, offered a nice ending to a very good dining experience.

Sevice was excellent.  We were served by a gal from Houston who was friendly, well informed, intelligent, funny, and attentive without being obtrusive.  

Gotta remember that when considering value, one has to consider the quality of the food, and not just the dollars spent.  Wish portions were a little larger though.  That said, I'll be back to try some other interesting dishes for lunch and dinner.  Finally...they should start a happy hour!

Food: 4
Value: 3
Service: 4
Ambiance: 4
author: Ethan R.

description:
I found out about about Salt House when visiting the website of one of my favorite restaurants - Town Hall. Salt House serves classic American dishes while Town Hall has provides comfort foods. Other than the slow and laggy service, dinner was wonderful.

Oysters - We started off with two each of three different oyster offerings. Each were amazing delicious. Slurp!

Poutine - Really good short rib gravy. And the fries didn't have traces of oil, which I liked. Of course, we got the cheeses on the side.

Alaskan cod (little neck clams, parsley root, tomatoes, chorizo, salsa verde) - This was soooo good! One of the best fish dishes I've had to date.

Petrale sole - This was also super delicious. The sole was grilled to perfection. The chorizo was almost like thin pepperonis. The bell peppers, lobster mushrooms and fingerling potatoes rounded out this awesome dish. So good!

Dessert was just okay. We got the frozen mousse cake with candied almonds and hot fudge. Nothing to rave about.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Last Saturday, a dear Indian friend, who now lives in Houston was visiting and the concierge at the Clift Hotel recommended the Salt House for dinner.  I had explained that Mr, Kapoor was the general manager of Masraff's, one of the top restaurants in Houston and I wanted to eat somewhere with both good food and excellent service.  When we arrived about fifteen minutes early for our 8:30 reservation, I explained this as well to the hostess.  We had a cocktail at the bar, then were promptly seated at 8:30.  That was the beginning of the LONG wait.

We were next to the open kitchen and, the noise level was so high, we couldn't even carry on a conversation.  After 45 minutes, when our appetizers had not even arrived, the manager brought us a complimentary chilled asparagus soup.  I did not find it expecially appetizing.  When our sweetbreads finally arrived, we had almost finished our bottle of Lebanese red wine ( quite good ).  The sweetbreads were perfect, some of the best I've ever eaten and I practically inhaled them, I was so ravenous!

I had ordered the roast pork loin which was also delicious, very moist and tender and not overdone.  My friends shared the salmon which they thought was quite good as well.

We did not order dessert but, because it was my other friend's birthday, they brough us a complimentary passion fruit cheese cake.  It was unlike any other cheese cake I've ever eaten - served in a small bowl, light and airy and light as a cloud.  I could have eaten half a dozen.

I thought all the food was delicious although I didn't care for the asparagus soup.  The long wait was outrageous.  We did not get out of there for two hours...which wouldn't have been so bad had we been able to visit and carry on a conversation.  With the extremely loud noise level and the sound of pans dropping on the floor from the kitchen, I had a headache by the time I left.  

That is the reason I only gave the Salt House three stars.  I would not consider the Salt House an intimate, romantic dining spot - or even a place to go and catch up on a chat with a good friend...perhaps it's different at lunch or on a week night.
author: Carmen H.

description:
Swear I wrote a review for this place before, but it could be my old age getting to me...

Came here for dinner one night, and the meal just kind of dwindled as each course came out. Everything was decent, nothing to write home about, but at the end of the meal I realized one thing. 

Salt House is SUPER SALTY!!!! I like my meals with flavor, but it was a little too much in my opinion. The restaurant itself is cute and has a great vibe, especially for drinks and a quick bite after work. But if you're going for the food, I think i'll pass on coming here again. Too bad since it's perfectly located near my work.
author: Kristen C.

description:
More like a 3.5.

I arrived at the restaurant a little earlier than my friend. The hostess was very friendly, the restaurant was industrial modern -- the bar space was a little cramped and negotiating around the stairs/ tables/ patrons' bags, but I was able to snag two seats at the bar. 

The bartender was so warm and friendly - she was engaging and asked questions to help guide me to which wine I may like. Yes this may be standard expectation from a bartender, but sometimes coming from NYC you still encounter the 'tude, so it's something I don't take for granted.

When my friend arrived we decided to stay at the bar and eat there... always my preference. We started with the queso peppers, very good, but not for the faint of heart. I was told only 1 in 7 are spicy, but still gotta avoid those seeds if you're not a pro. I asked the bartender to surprise me between the two fish entrees - she chose the cod in clam broth for me and also recommended a different wine to pair with it. I loved the white wine she suggested, it was so vibrant and delicious, it went perfectly with my meal. The cod was good, it was by no means memorable, but it was fine. I wish I had tried my friend's halibut, it came with fava beans.

I was in great company so it did make the evening nice and memorable in it's own way... it wasn't loud or boisterous, so it was a mellow enjoyable night.

I did think the menu entrees were on the pricier side and that's coming from someone used to NYC prices.
author: Jess K.

description:
I took my out of town family here to celebrate my birthday late on a Friday night. We had 915 reservations, didn't wait at all, but also probably didn't need them for that late.

The cocktail menu is boring, though I ordered the Port Royal and it was ok.

We ordered the poutine, it was INCREDIBLE, all be it not all the way hot, even after we sent it back once. At least they made us a fresh order of it. We also ordered the poached egg with pork belly hash and it was great.

Two people ordered the Beef Duo, rare, and it was excellent. My mother had the Green Farro and really enjoyed it. 

Against my instinct, I ordered the pork shoulder cooked with molé spices on the server's suggestion...it was ok, but definietly would not choose to order it again. (The only reason I went with her suggestion was because literally everything looked so good I couldn't make my own decision.)

Can't wait to go back!
author: Chloé M.

description: I received an email from a restaurant manager after posting the Yelp review. They cleared up the receipt discrepancy.
author: Andrew M.

description:
We came here for the wine-makers' dinner on Monday evening with friends.  Sadly, the event was very disorganized and the food was just OK.

To begin with, the hostess had our reservation wrong.  I'd made a reservation for four, weeks in advance and she had us down for two.  There seemed to be quite a lot of drama about whether they could accomodate us.  Later when dinner was served, there were at least half-a-dozen empty seats, so I'm not sure what the problem was.

The first course was served about a forty-five minutes late; and we sipped our wine very slowly, hoping to still have some when the food it was paired with finally arrived.  Throughout the evening, the wine and food pairing never came out together.  Additionally, The restaurant was freezing.   The main course was way too salty, and I usually like things saltier than most!

The ladies' room was a disaster with water everywhere.  It looked like a toilet had overflowed and not been mopped.  There was water dripping off the sink and into a waste basket which seemed to be intentionally put there.  There was even a waitress in there who seemed to be primping and ignoring the mess.  I've seen better gas stations.

The one thing they did right was continue to pour wine generously through all of the disorganization.  While the open kitchen seemed like utter chaos, they kept the booze flowing which went a long way to smooth things out.  The staff also seemed generally very attentive, even if they were clearly in the weeds.

This was their first wine makers' dinner and I hope that they do a little better job with the next one.
author: Amy A.

description:
3.5 stars.

Came here for one of my high school friend's birthday dinner. We had a group of 9 or something like that. Waited a little bit to be seated but nothing bad.

I had a moscow mule cocktail that was quite good.

I saw that some of my friends didn't really get their orders for a while! I think a mistake was made. Also, they didn't do anything special at all for the birthday.

I got the poutine for an appetizer because it's so hard to find good poutine in Norcal! The short rib gravy was just amazing. Cheese was good as well, but not squeaky ;)

For the main dish, I got the seared scallops. It was really good, just.. pretty small. I did have enough to trade with other people for their entrees, so I got to try out some chicken and some lamb, which were pretty good. The portions are a bit small for the price, but are pretty tasty.

So basically I had a good time besides the wait, but I think there was some mixup with my friends' orders.
author: Michael W.

description:
Overall, I came away from my dining experience at Salt House impressed with the decor and ambiance, only satisfied with the food ordered, and slightly disappointed in the service.

Food:
Appetizer - smoked trout with beets, broccoli diccio, cauliflower, and meyer lemon vinagrette; it was my fault that i was disappointed with this dish b/c I was not aware that this was actually a salad with a only a few pieces of trout on top. While I'm pretty sure this would have been a wonderful dish for those who are avid salad-eaters, I didn't like it so much as i expected a dish more focused on the smoked trout rather than the greens. Nonetheless, I have to say those few pieces of smoke trout were delicious haha.

Entree-forgive me, but i forgot the exact name of this dish as it isn't updated on the online menu (must be a daily or weekly special); but it was a pan-seared petrale sole over a celery root puree. Despite not having the exact name of dish, I do clearly remember how delicious this entree was. The sole was perfectly cooked, well-seasoned, and nicely complemented with the bed of cabbage and celery root puree. Easily my favorite dish of the night. 

Dessert - this dish is also not reflected on the outdated online menu, but i had an upside caramel pineapple cake with brown butter ice cream. I thought the cake could have been just a tad more moist and used also a pinch more of pineapple flavor or essence. The ice cream, however, was YUMMY. The brown butter flavor really came out in the ice cream and made it oh so rich and tasty. 

Service: eh. It was decent during most of the night, though our waiter, when asked about whether he liked dish a or dish b more, simply responded "oh dish b." No other comments, no other element of elaboration. Secondly, my date and I waited over 20 minutes for our dessert. The waiter assured us that it would arrive soon, but his promises were always empty. Disappointed w/ the service.

The decor and atmosphere was simply wonderful here. Great mix of old brick walls with modern elements of stainless steel. Great, lively environment that made my evening more enjoyable. I recommend sitting upstairs with a view of the downstairs dining room--it's very impressive.

Overall, I think if I had chosen better dishes for myself, I would be praising the food element of this restaurant in this review. In all, I think even with a better choice of entrees, I would still rank this almost in equal standing to Range in terms of food. Both are very similar in decor, service, and food.
author: Nathan T.

description: Overall Salt House did not disappointed on flavor or atmosphere, I had the muscles over pasta which was fantastically filling and tasty. The atmosphere came off sophisticated and stylishly modern which fits in with the SF motif. Generally I enjoyed my experience and plan to go back. However, due to the price I will probably be a once every six months kind of lunch as lunch for 2 was 60 bucks. Regardless of price this is a "must try" restaurant in the financial district.
author: Joe C.

description:
We had a dazzling 3 course meal at Salt House on Friday. We started with the silky seared foie on a bed of rhubarb puree, mache and strawberries.  We also had the poached egg over a bed of english peas, mushrooms, and foie sauce topped with breadcrumbs and serrano ham.  The 2nd course was a creamy sweet corn soup with an ancho chili puree and truffle oil and a crisp arugula salad with hazelnuts, fava beans and a champagne vinaigrette.  The main course was the most delicious trout I've ever tasted over a bed of potatoes, romano beans and bacon, topped with a bearnaise sauce and surrounded by a briny sea urchin reduction.  My husband had the duck over corn, farro, fava and cherry polenta.  For dessert, we took home the strawberry cream panna cotta, which tasted liked summer and sunshine.

To top it all off, we had 3 incredible wine pairings, a dry Chenin Blanc for the egg, a fragrant Sauternes for the foie and an elegant Pinot Nero from Slovenia to finish things off.  It was one of the most romantic and decadent evenings we've ever had.  What a treat!  Can't wait to go back.
author: Elena E.

description:
I can't wait to go back.  I had the tomato soup.  It was probably the best tomato soup I had in this continent.  With some greens and croutons... I was in heaven.  I also tried the tomato salad that my husband had.  There were figs in the salad!!  I am officially in love! 

For entree I had the chicken.  It was a very generous portion.  It was very soft and delicious but possibly too much food after having soup.  I also tasted the pacific cod.  I am not a big fan of fish but this one changed my mind.  Next time I am getting the cod.

The bread is very good as well but don't fill up yourself with it.  There are many other great things we would like to try on the menu.  So we'll be back.  

Service was great.  I loved how vibrant the restaurant is and bricks and large windows make it look industrial chic.  

It is loud so get ready to shout if you want to have a conversation with your dinner partner.  But you will enjoy the atmosphere and the vibe.
author: Selda H.

description:
Went here for a business dinner and I've got one word for you: Poutine. I'm not sure if this is spelled correctly but what the Loco Moco is for us Hawaiians, Poutine is for Canadians. Hot fried potatoes slathered in melted cheese and short rib gravy. Yes completely delicious and an appetizer to be reckoned with! In fact, I once saw Poutine save a woman from a burning building because that's how damn awesome it is! I think Poutine could be the solution to ending war and bringing about world peace. You just can't be angry when you stuff Poutine in your mouth. I now know why Canadians are always so nice. It's because they grew up eating Poutine.

Also enjoyed the roasted chicken and dessert but really, all I can talk about is the Poutine. Did I mention that Poutine came over and fixed my computer? Thanks Poutine! You're the best!
author: Emi H.

description:
At first glance walking in you think, oh another San Francisco restaurant who's doing the dimly lit, rusty industrial decor... it must taste the same as well right?

Wrong. 

Despite the fact I had the most rich dinning experience of my life, (totally my fault) I still had one of my best dinning experiences since recently arriving to San Fran. To begin my sister, her boyfriend, and I were greeted by an adorable hostess who at times uses the nick name "Peanut." She seated us in their upstairs lofted section, which can get a bit toasty in the middle of the dinner rush so be careful. 

For starters, our first indulgence was our Canadian neighbors' Poutine. Wisconsin cheese curd, braised short rib gravy, and house cut french fries. Upon first bite, I'm trying to convince myself to hate this dish, but I sadly loved it. Sad because it's depressing to imagine trying to calculate the health statistics. 

From there, the table also shared some beautiful Fois and I finished off my evening with a braised short rib. In the bowl, marrow ravioli floated in a light consume along with black trumpet mushrooms. And honestly, any time I can cut a piece of meat with my pinky the chef is doing something right. 

Overall, it was a beautiful dinner even though not balanced well due to our ordering, and I have to shout out to the hostess again. During the dinner I was the third wheel and what do you know, the other two got into a little bickering battle. So, acting like I received a call I quickly escaped back downstairs to the bar where the sweet hostess was more than happy to keep me busy with some chit chat while I waited for the smoke to clear upstairs. 

I'll be back for the food and if I pick the right night, hopefully "Peanuts" number haha.
author: Spencer C.

description:
This is where I discovered poutine, which I'm told is a Canadian staple. 
Poutine= crispy fries topped with cheese and gravy. Why has my Canadian mother been keeping such deliciousness a secret from me? Aero bars, smarties and now poutine...Canada has it all!

Besides poutine we started with a few salads for the table, which we thought would make us feel less guilty about eating fries topped with cheese and gravy.  We pretty much just ignored the salads and devoured the poutine. However, I couldn't get enough of the warm mixed nuts- covered in sea salt and truffle honey!

I ordered the petrale sole for my entree. Perfect for spicy food lovers because the sauce definitely had a bit of a kick to it. The bass was another popular entree. Can't go wrong with either choice. We washed this down with a few bottles of wine- a nice bottle of Riesling for the lushes on my side of the table.

Believe it or not after all this food, but our party of 9 found room for dessert:
Warm Brownie- yum
Carrot Cake- good, but I've had better
Panna Cotta- hmmm-floral tasting?
Cheesecake- My favorite!

I always appreciate good sweets, but I really could have just had some more poutine for dessert.
author: Andrea R.

description: Service was poor & the food was worse. Even our appetizer was over cooked!  $17 for three pieces of asparagus it better be perfect! As for our entree, I had the pork and it was very dry. My wife had the beef cheek and could only eat three bites due to the toughness of the meat. Our 3rd had the sole and said it was "ok at best".  We were a party of 3 and paid well over $300 for an eating experience that I wouldn't even use the term lackluster. U can tell by my food descriptions that I'm not a food critic but I know what good food ( $36 a plate ) should taste like. Very disappointed
author: Dustin W.

description:
I went here for a special occasion for the third time on a Saturday night and it was an overall a good experience. I ordered the NY Steak--and it was served sliced of course--but my issue was that it was served at room temperature. Maybe I'm not enough a "foodie" to know this is how it should be served, or how chef wants it served, but it was truly a let down as it just tasted cold to me. The potatoes and side dishes were a fine temperature so I suspect this wasn't the case. Didn't have enough time to complain or reorder, but most likely won't be going back.

I go to restaurants like this for special occasions only (this was a birthday present to my partner) so spending this much on a meal, and having the entrée be a let down is not something I want to chance in the future.
author: Steven C.

description: The building is beautiful... Brick and old wood look. We went there for lunch, and the food was good but I wasn't blown away. I did just order the salad, which is rarely a mind-altering experience. I would definitely return to sample more of the menu.
author: H L.

description:
I had a memorable, yummy meal at Salt House, even at the table under the stairs that was a bit cramped but at the same time had a romantic, tucked away feel. 

The oysters were amazing, the service top-notch, a trio of dessert bites that were terrific and worth every calorie. 

It's a bit of a happy din inside, especially on a Saturday night at this popular SOMA spot -  so be prepared to yell "I LOVE YOU" 'cause your dining partner won't hear it the first 3 times and you'll startle the table next to you with your unprovoked and puzzling exclamation of love.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Date night for us. Great spot. This was our first time here. The food is amazing from beginning to end. The menu changes so I am not sure what are the staple items. 

We tried the Polenta Raviolo. This was a perfect combo of flavors and texture. The rabbit was soft with the polenta and mushrooms it all melted in our mouths. It was a random pick but a great option. 

My main entree was the petrale sole. The fish was cooked just right. Not dry. There was a crunchy topping that paired well with the fish. The potato gnocchi was light yet perfect amount of starch to go with the fish. 

Dessert was the best. I do love dessert so i would definitely say its the best if it truly is. My husband isn't huge on desserts and he finished all of his choice. I had the nutella pot de creme with ice cream. There was a nutella and chocolate pot de creme with hazelnut ice cream and fresh hazelnuts. The flavoring was perfect. My husband had the apple crisp. It was the perfect size. He said it was like a bottom layer of cheesecake and a layer of very soft apples with a crisp topping. He said it was perfect in each bite and loved it with the ice cream. 

We would definitely go back. If anyone wants a suggestion for a place in SoMa, we would put this on this list.
author: Susan L.

description: I work around the block and have been here a few times for company events. The food is amazing! It's always packed and reservation is highly recommended. I've tried the mussels in Thai coconut broth and the burger, both are fantastic.
author: Connie L.

description:
Had a reservation last night for 3, arrived 10 minutes early, waiting for our third, checked in and the blond hostess told us we needed to wait for our entire party to be seated and that we should have a seat at the bar.  Okay, sure; the bar was packed with no seats and no standing room.  My problem was not that the bar was packed but that the hostess station is directly adjacent to the bar she she could plainly see it was packed!  

We waited outside until our third came at our reservation time and were seated on the small loft area.  We must have waited over 10 mintues before our server acknowledged us.  This was the pace of the evening, our server was mostly absent and the food was excruciatingly slow to arrive.

We ordered the shellfish platter for an appetizer. The oysters were fabuous, 12 of them.  The rest was embarrassingly disappointing.  The clams were no larger than nickles, the mussels were no bigger.  The shrimp were tasty but they were sized around 26-30.  The worst thing was that they had cocktail and minuet sauce on the platter, then 10 minutes later brought large bowls of sauces; but not one spoon on the table and no one around to ask for assistance.  My advice, order the oysters skip the platter.

I ordered the Sea Bass with a ratatouille, sheet pasta, mussels in a saffron broth; our server said this was the best thing on the menu, bold flavors.  Pasta sheet was way overcooked, it fell apart on my fork. The vegetables were mushy.  The worst part was the fish was extremely overcooked, almost dry on the inside, but with a limp skin that was not edible.  I am not a food crtic by any means but if I am paying $32 for a dish, I expect much more.
author: Ken S.

description: Some hit and miss experiences since their opening leaves me with a neutral rating of the Salt House. Many fellow Yelpers are right about the great dishes,  but consistency is an issue. I just enjoy their other venture, Town Hall much more.
author: Michael G.

description: Salt House was great! Menu was simple but very well done. I had the scallops and they were done to perfection. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Atmosphere was trendy and sophisticated. I will be back.
author: Whitney W.

description:
I was so looking forward to checking this place out. However, my experience didn't live up to the anticipation...

It was a Saturday night, and we arrived at 7:15p. We got drinks pretty promptly, but didn't get to order until about 7:45p. We got a little grumpy at about 8:30p when our entrees hadn't arrived yet. 

We asked for the manager, and as she approached, our food was finally being dropped. We told her it had been a long time and were disappointed with the wait. She noticed the food being served, and didn't really acknowledge our complaint. Not very attentive. Bad move.

The petrale sole was "ok". Tender, but not worth the price. The spare ribs were good, but not "OH MY GOD". I did have a few brussels sprouts that came with the pork entree, and honestly, that was the best tasting item on the menu as far as I was concerned. 

Cool space, a bit cramped but with the remarkable restaurants in the City to choose from, I don't need to come back.
author: Natasha M.

description: Excellent business lunch. Good service, grilled chicken salad was uniquely flavorful. Given that this is SF, not too expensive and tables were actually comfortable.
author: Doug B.

description:
I am hesitating between a two and three star rating for Salt House. The beet salad was probably six or seven out of ten. The gnocchi was tasty but way too small of a portion even at french standards. Our food arrived an hour and ten minutes after we sat down! Our appetizers arrived right after we sat down. Then we waited almost a full hour for the entrees. I am not sure what happened. They probably forgot. Pinot Noir by the glass was very well chosen. I am not sure what they served but it was delicious. My friend drank water. 

This place has a nice ambiance.  Mediocre service. And slightly above mediocre food for the price point. We paid close to $100 for two people, in line with high end downtown restaurants. But not in line with the top notch service and food quality you'd expect.
author: bora o.

description:
Straight to the point, the food was mediocre.
We ordered 3 apps, poutine, foie gras, and pork (cant remember the name of the dish)  
Being a Canadian I was very excited to finally satisfy my months long craving. but the poutine, despite the seemingly awesome short rib gravy was just the same stuff you can get a fast food places in Canada for 1/3 of the price. Nothing special at all.
Foie Gras was tasty but the waiter didn't bring us the bread right away... and eating foie gras straight up was a bit too much.
The pork dish was actually very good. nothing to complain there.

Entree I had the lamb shank, which was nicely cooked.  but apparently they buy the lamb already pre-made or whatever... the waiter tried to explain cuz I requested for mid-rare but since it's pre-made they couldn't do that. the flavours were there, but the texture of the meat just didn't seem fresh at all. 

Also the place was extremely noisy. we got seated right under the stairs. which meant if you are a tall person and want to stand up and go to the restroom... you need to watch your head!

bottom line,  poutine was the main reason we came to Salt House. but there is really nothing special about it., except the price.
author: Frank L.

description: I'm officially an oldster.  I'm taking off a star because this restaurant is too loud. And it is a shame because both my dishes were superb.  Strawberries, asparagus and cheese don't seem like a match and yet - magic. And I'm still having the complete opposite of PTSD whenever I remember the red spotted trout.  It was almost a special evening except for the hoarseness at the end of the evening.  Do I get my senior plaque now?
author: Randy W.

description: I've been here twice and it is good.   I mean, really good food in a great atmosphere.  Very nice waitstaff.  Definitely a solid choice for an upscale downtown dinner or lunch.  And I'm tempted to give it 4 stars.  However I think the prices were a bit above what they should be for what you get.    I guess it's downtown, so what can I expect, and they are clearly doing well, so there are plenty of people willing to pay.  Just be willing to drop 60 or so a plate if you go.
author: Travis B.

description: Came here for lunch with my boss the other day. We both got the burger. Had mine with avocado. Wasn't the freshest avocado, but it was good. Usually like my burgers bloody as hell, and my burger looked more medium than anything else. I dunno if its store policy to make sure the burgers are cooked to a certain extent, but they could have told me if it was, because now I just think they messed up my order. Fries were ok, nothing special. Its a good "premium" burger, better than a typical big mac, but nothing that warrants me to want to go again. If friends want to go, I'll give it another try though.
author: Cody M.

description:
I never ordered soups (BORing) except in Salt House where it's consistently *great*. Satisfying the way soup should be, thoughtfully paired with additional texture interests and always seasonal. The quail appetizer should be framed and placed in SF MOMA. Stunningly presented and the roasted mushrooms with purple rice was a perfect accompaniment to a game bird. Roasted dorad got the flesh moist and tender with that thin and crispy skin. Right on.

Poutine was surprisingly off last night. Under seasoned and severely under fried. Even my 5 year-old noticed the difference and refused to take another bite.

I always *wanted to* like their bar menu more. They look great on paper with interesting combo and artisanal bottling, but most of the time they just drink ... diluted. Of the 3 cocktails we tried this time, only Sucker Punch drank like a cocktail came from a high class bar, instead of a Seven-Up-with-floating-fruit-bodies punch bowl at a church outing.
author: Shalese H.

description:
What I Ate
- croque madame with home-made potato chips
- grilled pork loin with fingerling potatoes, spring onions, hobb's bacon, and pork jus

Would I Go Again?
Salt House is one of my favorite spots for business lunches in the financial district.  The atmosphere is a mix of trendy and business professional, and the food is outstanding.  I would order both dishes again.
author: Ben M.

description:
You know, I thought that given there were only like 5 drinks on the menu, I thought the drinks were going to be great. Especially because anything with grapefuit and that type of fruit juice should, in theory, be delicious. Was not impressed, and the drink portion was underwhelming. I'm not one to generally complain about the drink size (because my tolerance is not high at all) but this place was notably bad about it.

Won't go here voluntarily, but they are conveniently located around a lot of businesses so probably will end up there again for happy hour.
author: Chrissy H.

description: Really yummy and great wait staff. I'd come here again next time I'm around. Really great place for a date njght. Very fresh food.
author: Emily D.

description:
OMG... the foie gras was... to DIE for. You get both seared and torchon and really, one should not have to choose. It's the best way to enjoy foie gras and they do it beautifully in both ways. I must admit I prefer seared and I was not disappointed. The only thing I did not love were the crostinis that came with the dish. I personally preferred the neverending supply of bread.

We also went for the oysters and the mignonette was so good that I wish I had more oysters (we ordered 16... yes we love our oysters)

The short rib was a bit on the drier side and maybe I had overstuffed on foie gras and oysters but I didn't love it as much as I would have wanted to. The delicious ravioli with bone marrow and other fats made up for it, as did the veggies that came along. (My dining partner was not a greens fan so I got his greens and he got the rest of my short rib)

A fabulous dining experience. If I weren't running to catch a train I would have stayed for dessert. I was a little too full though. Next time, Salt House, and oh there will be a next time.
author: Karen K.

description: Amazing ingredients. I enjoyed every bite of everything I had. The poutine is not authentic but is remarkably tasty. They even have Maudite on tap!
author: Brandon M.

description: Came into town for a long weekend and happened upon this spot for lunch. We arrived at 12 and luckily got a spot around the bar area. Our service was great, the drinks were amazing and the vibe was cool. The food was on point and had awesome flavor.
author: Jackson H.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday. I asked them if they can do anything special on the birthday dessert plate I ordered for him. They said they'll try, but it depends on how busy they are then.

Food: We ordered the poutine for appetizer, which was good, but not stunning. However, the manager gave us two other appetizers on the house. I believe it was the poached organic egg and an asparagus dish. We think this was because our entrees didn't arrive until about 40 minutes after we finished our appetizer plate. The entrees were okay. I ordered the pacific cod, which tasted too fishy compared to others I've eaten. My friend ordered the pork chop, which was very tasty and tender.
What was the most unforgettable dish was the german chocolate cake that we ordered though. So rich, so good, so amazinnnnnngggg!

All in all, I think I would have given them 3 stars for the experience and the food, but because I was in good company and didn't mind waiting close to an hour for my food to come out, I would give it 4.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
Much better!

The plus one finally took me on a date (YAY) so I requested this place, given its proximity to the Temple Nightclub. I knew from my previous excursion that it was best to order fatty, salty and generally unhealthy things, but I did want to compromise, so this is what we ordered:

Poutine - Just as heavenly as I remembered. Although I would have preferred more gravy, the creamy, salty goodness came through in just about every bite.

Sashimi - This was probably the freshest, most top-grade raw fish that I have ever had in my life. 

Dayboat Scallops - One order was the gastronomical equivalent of a cocktease. That said, these easily knocked Bijou's scallop appetizer out of the water. 

It was a smart idea to just share a few appetizers because we were almost uncomfortably full by the time we got down to the last bits of the poutine.

Of course, date night would not be complete without desserts and alcohol:

Huckleberry Financier - I am not gonna lie, just because I eat food doesn't mean I know everything about it, and when I saw this on the menu, I thought that shit sounded like Mark Twain's stockbroker. Turns out that this is a compote with almonds and huckleberries (clearly), and honestly I thought it was just okay, but the accompanying vanilla-lime ice cream was AMAZING. I happen to adore key lime pie, and each bite of ice cream tasted just like the pie in melty, frozen form. 

The Green Door - Cucumber and mint served straight up. Very refreshing.

Violet Beauregard - Apparently we were the only people in the restaurant who remembered "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" because our server seemed amazed that SOMEONE got the joke. This drink tasted like a berry smoothie from Jamba Juice in cocktail form. I love Jamba Juice so this one was my fave.

Moscato d'Asti - There are two kinds of moscato on the drink menu. This one and the grappa. I should have ordered the grappa, but this provided a decent enough buzz, albeit not so much of the sweetness that I was hoping for. 

As always, service was on point, despite how crowded the restaurant was (it WAS Friday after all). Amazing! Now I will make it my personal goal to try the foie gras,
author: Aivy C.

description:
RSVP's dont mean anything.. I came here for dinner with friends and had a RSVP at 8:15 we didnt get to our table till 9:00 pm really? the hostess excuse was that the people paid but dont want to leave really? that was your excuse? where is your manager to help you with that?  we didnt even get an apology... if you cant honor your rsvp then don't have them at all!
To top it off when we got our table there was another table empty .. WTF really why couldnt we have that table?  get your act right Salt house!
author: Akiliano T.

description:
Everyone I was with really enjoyed their meal. I had a delicious polenta dish and left very full and very happy.

The service was good, the atmosphere was nice. The lighting in the place seemed a little strange. The atmosphere felt like it should be pretty intimate but the giant windows and light pouring in kind of contrasted that feeling. Once the sun set, the mood changed a good bit and the ambience matched the atmosphere that they seemed to be trying to create with the decor.
author: Jared L.

description:
A and I had a date night last Friday and made 7:30pm reservations.  Unfortunately, we forgot to factor in the sucky parking in the area.  Yes, they have valet parking - but we prefer to park our own car.

After driving around for quite a while, we got rock star parking directly across the street from the restaurant.  Take that, valets!!

The restaurant was packed (and super duper loud!), but the hostess was super understanding about our lateness and took us to our table right away.  We had one of the two-tops under the stairs.  Not the ones at the window, but the ones under the stairs.  Very Harry-Potter-room-under-the-stairs-ish.

As I mentioned earlier, it was super duper loud, so definitely not a restaurant for a romantic date - unless, of course, your idea of romance is yelling across the table at your one and only. ;-)

We started with drinks - I think it was called Smitten Kitten.  Or Frisky Kitty?  I don't remember.  Something to do with a cat.  Anyway, it was so loud, A and I didn't even realize we had both ordered the same drink until they arrived at the table.  Whatever the drink was, it was tasty.

For appetizers, we shared the poutine because I had a craving for some since my last trip to Canada almost 3 years ago.  A also had the squash soup, which he said was amazing.

As for entrees, I had the short ribs, which were very tender and quite tasty.  The sauce was really good.  A had the chicken, which was really juicy.  The skin was a little salty and had a nice crispyness to it.  Chicken wins, hands down.

We were way too full for dessert, but our server was awesome and the food was great.  I'd give it 5 stars, but it's way too loud and kinda pricey.  Definitely not a place to go everyday.
author: Kris L.

description:
Lets get straight to business- THE FOOD.

Appetizers orders were Poutine and Crispy Shrimp. Poutine- fries is fine, but the gravy is disgusting it tasted some kind of runny bean made sauce that leaves an unpleasant grainy feel on your tongue. Such a disappointment.  Crispy shrimp, a $20 appetizer that comes with mounts of young french green beans that were tender and delicious (1 star for this), the fried shrimps (was it 6 of them?) were placed on the side like an afterthought. 

Entree: my duck confit was done perfectly. Crispy skin and moist meat with just the right amount of doneness- a bed of sweet apple, cured meat bits and carrots compliment the fatty bird perfectly. I would order this again (1 star for this). Colleagues ordered the burger and asked for honey mustard. The waitress was apologetic and says we don't have honey mustard. I then asked another wait staff for "HONEY" and "MUSTARD" and I blended honey mustard at the table myself. Seriously? More staff training is much needed if such small request cant even be filled.

Drink: No alcoholic mint lemonade was also $5 per glass no free refill. The margin gotta be in the thousands % for those drinks.

Summary: The food came out slow and the kitchen chefs look fatigued before the lunch service even started. The wait staff can use some common sense or some training. The green beans and the duck confit were the saving grace but I would gladly take my business else where.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Well-executed, thoughtful creations. Slightly see and be seen scene

BEST olives - 1st x I've ever enjoyed a green olive. mint/orange/chili marinade added perfect flavor - not too salty, just ripe
friend and I were in love w/tai snapper - well-seasoned, pan-fried, handsome piece atop bed of summer squash, shimeji, and chorizo
dessert was also stellar - peach/blackberry brown betty served in a cute ramekin, a la mode
while we didn't order it, the poutine looked amazing (!)

ambiance: loved loft vibe (albeit a bit noisy)
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I'm a fan of the Salt House.  Been there three times.  My girlfriend loves the Poutine, which isn't exactly high cuisine, but delivers solidly on what it is.  I always find is somewhat silly to go out to eat to order Poutine, but the short rib makes it feel a bit more like something other than food you would scarf down drunk at 2 AM.

Entrees are  honest, delicious food and prepared well.  They have a great space, which is a pleasure to enjoy a meal in.  

Pricing is pretty standard for SF, around $50 each all said and done.   I'll definitely be back a few more times.  Solid 4 stars.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Went there on a Tuesday Night - mostly packed restaurant. Very Nice Ambiance.
We started out with the following:
1. Crispy Shrimp - Very nice, you get 4 pieces of shrimp & mostly green beans & salad.
2. Fries - they weren't to bad, i was hoping for a little more than what i got. They were Fresh, little crispy. the short rib sauce does nothing for the fries. Very Very mild melted cheese, it would have been better left naked with just the fries itslef.  
3. Fava beans with the mushroom's were deelish - very simple & fresh tasting.

On to Entree's
1. Skip the Short Ribs, I was craving it & then when i got it, it came soaked in a very oily broth. However the short rib itself was very dry & veggies was so so. 
2. Pork Chops - FANTASTIC. cooked to perfection & it was slighty crispy on the outside & juicy & tender on the inside. 
3. Polenta was very very good. 

Dessert: Lemon Pie was PERFECT! 

Until Next time ....
author: Nadia N K.

description:
I came here last Thursday on a last-minute business dinner, and it was OK. Just OK. The location is super convenient (next door to work), and the food was good. The service was mediocre.  

First, I do appreciate that they could get a party of three in for dinner around 7:30 with no reservation and basically no wait. 

We ordered beer/cocktails, two appetizers, three entrees, and one dessert. The total bill including an 18% tip was $220 -- not too bad. I'm usually a more generous tipper, but the service didn't warrant it. 

The beer list is great, and the two dark and stormy my dinner partners ordered were quite good. The waiter essentially refused to let us order food before our drinks came, even though we were starving and the drinks took awhile. This was just an annoyance. 

One pet peeve of my business associate: the water is served room temperature in glasses with no ice. Sure, you could ask for ice. But who doesn't appreciate cold water? 

We ordered poutine and blistered piquillo peppers. The poutine was pretty good. The cheese curds were melty, and the gravy could have been a slight bit saltier but was good. The peppers were mildly spicy, and had some sort of buttermilk sauce down at the bottom that was tasty.
