My boyfriend ordered the steak, which was very yummy. I ordered the roast chicken, which was very tasty. Generous portions, brussels sprouts on the side. Very good, and the cheapest thing on the dinner menu. 

We split apple pie for dessert. We almost didn't order anything, because we had to ask for the dessert menu instead of being offered it. Once we'd ordered dessert, we.... waited. And waited. Once we basically flagged the waiter down for the check, it came relatively quickly. But then we waited for my card to be run, and waited to get a not-wet copy of the receipt for reimbursement. 

In sum, the food was good. The service wasn't bad, and at a less expensive restaurant it probably would have been fine. But if you're paying $25 for an entree, then I expect good service. Salt House was slightly lacking.
author: Tom P.

description:
I'm a fan of this place that's right down the road from our office.  REally nice staple to have in your back pocket but make sure to make a reservation as this place gets packed.

I too was disappointed by the poutine fries as I found them pretty soggy - but the fish dishes that they have for special tend to be really good.
author: Matthew D.

description: Dinner on 25 June.  Pretty good Rob Roy in the Bar.  But the server, who was very attentive at first went absent when my guests arrived.  Watch your head on the stairs.  Dinner service was fine but slightly inattentive. Found myself pouring wine for my guests. Food very good. Easy to drop $100 per person here. Setting in old structure quite charming.
author: Philip S.

description:
What a great Friday lunch time treat! 

Went here with my work team and I am already thinking about the next time I am going back to Salt House. 

The place has a lot of windows- woodsy feel and feels larger than it is.  Tables are def crammed in there but that's typical SF.  The seats by the window to people watch seem really fun too. 

They have some very yummy braided up bread with butter to start your meal. 

We ordered the Arugula Salad for the table (so fresh) and Crispy Shrimp and this was my favorite! The curry/spice taste was so yummy.  Green beans so crisp and fresh with fluffy fried shrimp!

I got the Salmon with buttery beans and the pesto taste was amazing. 

Wish I had more room to try dessert but maybe next time. 

Its amazing that the menu always changes too. Loved it.
author: Anya R.

description:
What do you expect of a restaurant when it's titled Salt House?  You know that everything is going to have a plethora of food preparations showcasing SALT.  So, if you're going in with that mentality you're in for some very well salted and tasty food.

I came here for lunch for a business meeting and it's truly a great spot for a quick lunch meeting.  The environment is very hip/modern/well lit and their service is quick and organized.  You will be in and out within the hour with Acme bread, home made salted butter, appetizer and entree.  Add a dessert and it only takes an extra 15 minutes.  

We ordered the fish and it was very delicious!  Perfectly cooked and melted in our mouths.  Texture is great, flavors are good... I was very happy and of course it helps that the meeting went very well!  

I do have to say that if I had no time constraint there are lots of great food options in the FIDI area with similar palette but if you're within a 3 block radius and need to find somewhere professional, trendy and QUICK, this is the place to go.  I can see myself coming back here again given another business meeting opportunity.
author: Sandy L.

description:
My friends and I chose this place because it was recommended to us and I must say it is an okay place, I say okay , because nothing really stood out when it comes to flavor.  Don't get me wrong, the meal was delicious but there are many restaurants out there that is like salt house.

I had the braised chicken and it was delicious.  Chicken had no fat and the meat was tender.  The taro and ricotta cheese was part of the meal and was very tasteful; it compliments the chicken well. My meal was good but I felt like I could have another chicken meal like this at another fine dining.

5 stars for the rustic feel of the restaurant , made it felt cozy. 1 star for the 4% employee charge ( Basically we patrons pay for the employee health care)
author: Phuong T.

description:
The service was great here and the presentation of the food was beautiful.

However, despite the gorgeous presentation, the Pork was very dry, the beet salad was just odd, and the drink I ordered had so much going on it was a disaster. Furthermore, this place is way too over priced.
author: Sean H.

description: Overrated! Flounder sandwich was bland, dry, and to be honest not the best piece of fish to have.  Truffle fries? More like plain ol' fries. Salad with dish was weak, mix of withered greens. Best part no bread,  and slow water refills, the Kreayshawn look a like waitress was rude and no where to be found.
author: Nico S.

description:
Amazing new fav!!  Came here for a Christmas Night in the city and can rate Salt House in my top five fav restaurants.  Had reservations at 9pm last Saturday night.  They were not ready for our party yet, which was slightly annoying, but the manager quickly made it up to us with a bottle of champagne and appetizers on the house.  Mistake was quickly forgotten.

As we were seated upstairs, we were served the amazing poutine (wish I had more of it), the delicious mixed nuts and mixed olives.  I ordered the Spicy Shrimp, green bean and serrano ham salad that was fabulous and perfectly cooked.  For my entree, I decided on the short ribs, yummm!!  Great bread was served as well, always a deciding factor of a great restaurant or not for me. 

Such a fun vibe there, could have been the booze, but who cares. I can't wait for my next visit there, Salt House is a must!
author: Natalie P.

description: I have eaten here with a friend a couple times over the past few months and found the food to be excellent and the service exceptional. We will eat here again soon because this place is fuckin' awesome.
author: Jim L.

description: Went there last night for dinner and the food was amazing but service was super slow.
author: V b.

description:
I should look at the name and expect the food that I got.. but i didnt

Ordered:
Fries with short rib gravy= tastey for the first few bites but it gets to be too much, i felt very full of startch.

Chicken dish= VERY VERY SALTY... it was saltastic. The chicken was really juicey (this was the best part), but because the outside was so salty,  I couldn't really enjoy it

It was towards the end of the night so our service was very poor as well.

No more
author: Elisa T.

description:
My fiance and I came here for an early dinner before his work Christmas party. Their poutine fries are definitely the hit here. But other than that, I thought the main entrees were just okay.

I ordered a white fish(can't remember the name), it was definitely favorable but a bit too salty for my taste buds. It also came with the weirdest clam that I've ever seen, and that wasn't tasty at all--it left a pretty gross after taste in my mouth as well.

The fiance ordered their Fulton Valley Chicken. he said it was overall pretty tasty, but not enough sauce to help out with the drier parts of the meat. 

I like the ambiance of this place, very unique, esp. since our reservations were on the top loft area. Our server was also very friendly and recommended some good drinks for us. Their mint mojito was quite tasty--but also strong!
author: Connie C.

description:
What happens when a gaggle of Canadians get together to celebrate Canada in SF? Somebody mentions they know this place that makes poutine and next thing we know a table of 12 or so of us have each ordered a bowl of it.

Salt House has a great decor, and some great service! Not to mention a pomegranate spritzer like no other. But can they poutine me like some of the places back home? Well, the dish in front of me was yummy, and a fancy version of poutine, that's for sure. Crispy fries, Vermont cheddar and beef gravy that they proceeded to spoon on top of the melted cheese and fries in front of our eyes. But were they Vermont cheddar cheese *curds*? I'm not to so sure. The short rib gravy did make my mouth water a little bit though.

Next time I want to go with a smaller group and sit on the upper level over looking the rest of the restaurant. There are some other fantastic looking items on the menu I wouldn't mind testing out like that veal sweetbread.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Went to Salt House at the recommendation of the Concierge . . . at the Hilton.  Interestingly, the day earlier, on the way to Chaya, I mentioned Salt House and the cab driver said, "huh, I used to take people there all the time, now I never go there."  After eating there, I kind of understand why.

Salt House is a very good restaurant that has a kind-of feel of the Publican in Chicago--upscale bar food featuring things like Oysters (Belgian Bars) and Poutine (Quebec).  But in every case, they were close, but I just can't give them high marks like I woudl the Publican.

Why?

Poutine was made without Cheese Curds.  Had some kind of melted cheese, but it definitely was not curds.  That means it was cheese fries with gravy, in my book.  Also, the beer tap selection was not extensive.  If you are serving Poutine and Oysters, I want a good, Belgian Ale.  

Service was good, the ambiance was nice.  If I lived here and it was in my neighborhood, I might pop in from time-to-time, but I wouldn't go out of my way for this place.
author: Greg B.

description: Love the room, the scene, the service and the food. What else can I say except it's yummy!
author: michael p.

description:
Not too impressed. First of all, we were told that we HAD to make reservations in the "balcony" - the area overlooking the restaurant for a romantic dinner. We made reservations as recommended, but when we arrived, we were told that a "large party" had come in before us and they sat them all in the balcony. 

We ordered the poutine to start, with me leading the poutine charge with the assent of my Canadian wife. While not bad, this variation was quite different from the traditional beef gravy/cheese curds/french fries that make the Canadian version so addictive. This version is much more "Americanized". Don't get me wrong, it was certainly palatable, with the short-rib gravy a tasty variant. As I ate, I couldn't disabuse myself of the thought that Salt House's poutine was cobbled together with these ingredients because they couldn't get such things as cheese curds or thick Canadian beef gravy. The Salt House variation was seasoned fries with graded Vermont Cheddar cheese and red-wine reduced short rib stock. Again, tasty...but certainly not poutine in the Canadian sense of the word.

A review of the menu revealed a pretty nice array of foods. One thing that they have - just like every other trendy-but-out-of-business-in-two-years-restaurant-in-SOMA - is the overly-trendy sweetbreads. Really, Salt House? You couldn't find any other portion of the veal that was more disgusting to serve than brains? What...was the butthole gone or  is that not what all the hipsters are eating yet?

The portions were painfully small. These days, I'm eating less - and dinner is usually a salad or something small. These portions were about the size of a 50-cent piece...and way over-priced. The flavor was average. We ordered the chrispy shrimp for a taste. The shrimp was great...but the "spicy green beans" were absolutely, positively inedible. There was more cumin and cilantro than there were string beans. Note to the chef: MORE CUMIN DOES NOT MAKE A DISH MORE TASTY. It ruins the flavor when used by the bucket-full. Please - I'm sure that the tin of cumin doesn't say "Dump entire contents into dish" on the side label. If you're going to cook with cumin, it must, must, must be used sparingly to slightly flavor the food - not make you feel as though you've fallen face-first into Andre The Giant's armpit.

We also had the sweet corn soup, and luckily, that was quite remarkable. It was the best 

Now for the best part of the meal: I had the Rene Rostaing Coteaux du Languedoc, Puech Noble 2006 (white). My wife had the Sonoma Seghesio 2009 (red). Both wines were excellent, and both wines were perfect for after a long, long day.

Finally -
Reservations: don't bother. You're not going to get what you want anyway. The staff isn't particularly attentive (I guess giving away reservations to other people keeps them quite busy), and they don't care if you stay there and eat or go somewhere else. It didn't seem as though the staff really cared at all. 

We were told that this was a romantic place for dinner. Well, perhaps if you find standing next to a speaker at an Insane Clown Posse concert and having to yell at the top of your lungs to be heard by your date to be romantic, then Salt House is for you. The place is LOUD and I had to yell my order to the waiter and had to yell so that my wife could hear me. Come on - I'm not that old. This place was just too damn loud to be romantic.

Overall, if you don't mind putting up with the indifferent waiters and don't mind the hearing damage, go try some great wine. Otherwise, try Scoma's on the Wharf. Salt House seems to be a food truck that's parked in one place permanently...and doesn't really care if you like their food or even come back again.
author: Ed D.

description:
Don't let the droves of  bleach blonde hair and orange spray tans dissuade you, the food here is 100% legit!  Always a bit challenging to grab a table at the last minute, Salt House is one of the few high quality restaurants serving dinner late.  Every dish is packed with flavor and has some edge of reinvention to shapren its solid execution of well known favorites.  It gets 4-4.5 stars for the food alone with the extra rounding up to 5 stars for offering good food into the wee hours. 

Poutine: It's not your traditional poutine, but enjoyable once you get over that.  The short rib gravy (probably wine based) gave a higher level of sophistication than any Québécois chicken gravy I've had.  The melted cheddar didn't add much so they probably should have stuck with squishy  curd.  I was neutral on the steak fry size instead of frites since it's all potato anyway.

Foie Gras: I'll admit, I'm a foie gras fiend.  Most restaurants that serve it only serve either the fresh seared version or the torchon.  If by odd chance a place serves both, I'm alway tempted to get the seared.  Salt House transcends the dilemma by offering both AND two small bits of tea smoked duck breast.  The seared foie gras was awesome and I love the use of wild huckleberries in the traditional sweet contrast.  The torchon was standard, but tasty.  The duck breast was very rare and very smoky.  Definitely the Solange to the star Beyoncé foie gras, but still quaint in small doses.

Pork Belly: The way I like it, cooked like over sized bacon!  There was some greenage below but I totally forgot about it while caught up in my pork frenzy.  Great crispy outsides with tender meat and soft fat inside.

Cassoulet: The beans were a tad large for my taste (butter beans?), but are more true to the medieval roots of cassoulet than the modern day smaller white beans.  The sausage was hearty and the duck confit was nice, but could have stood to be crispier.

Lemon Verbena Panna Cotta: This dessert jumped on the bandwagon of two widely popular trends in SF cuisine: lemon verbena (where was this herb a few years ago?) and the grotesque looking Buddha's hand.  Like Lady Gaga, not all popular trends are a bad thing.  The lemon verbena gave the creamy panna cotta a fresher citrus flavoring than traditional lemon/lime/orange varieties.  The Buddha's hand was thinly sliced and candied to a soft consistency floating in sugary syrup.  It gave a much more potent citrus burst which contrasted the fresh and subtle panna cotta well.

Brown Sugar & Cardamom Ice Cream: This is so simple, yet so amazing and unique.  Why has no one done this before?  The brown sugar gives ice cream a very caramel and molasses tone that regular sugar can't compete with.  The slight cardamom was just enough to add a hint of complexity.  Also, super creamy!!!
author: Adam B.

description:
Had a really great experience with a minor flaw at this wonderful place.  I ordered the Beef Bavette and it was perfectly cut and cooked.  Our server was quick and very helpful but he had a woman take our drink orders and every one else got what they wanted but I never got my beer.

It worked out in the end though because everyone else had a great Bourbon Whiskey drink that I ended up asking for.

Would love to come back here soon.
author: Phillip S.

description:
Lunch with coworkers here.

Menu changes.  Good food, good service, nice ambiance.  Love the mural/painting...good building view from downstairs seating (there's a loft area dining).
author: Tommy G.

description:
Some things are just wrong.

Big "Aquanet" hair = wrong.

Black pants + white socks + black shoes = wrong.  (unless you want to look like Michael Jackson, or you ARE Michael Jackson!)

expecting a romantic evening at Salt House when you book a 6:15pm reservation on Friday night = wrong.  (unless you count a power-suit wearing crowd, who I'm sure just got off work, screaming "oh shiiit" and "F*** u" romantic)

yelling just so your date can hear you = wrong.  (unfortunately, we were seated behind that crowd)

slicing up a $30 NY strip steak into 5 chunks just so you can make a nice looking presentation = wrong!  Such a GRIEVOUS wrong.

Because, at the Salt House, it's just about the presentation.

Speaking of which...

my outfit?

flowy light gold top + well-fitted black pants + BLACK socks +  leather boots = RIGHT!
author: Janice C.

description: This is a nice restaurant but it's the overall experience that counts. And ours wasn't good last night. They pulled the old trick of serving a different vintage of the red wine we ordered (albeit at the same price).  It's like selling  a 2012 Mercedes when it's really a 2011 and hoping the customer doesn't find out. I get that sometimes they run out of a vintage and don't have time to update the wine list, but at a high end restaurant with a nice and expensive wine list, a professional waiter /sommelier spends the 15 seconds it takes to look at the wine they serve and ensure it's what the customer ordered. If it isn't I expect them to tell me so I can decide between the different vintage and another bottle.
author: Peter J.

description: Food was really good and the staff was incredible.  The vibe/scene was current and fun.  Waiter was spot on with food and cocktail recommendations. I had the sea bass and it was cooked very well. Go with seafood and you can't go wrong.  It can get loud, so if you want a serious conversation, be forewarned.  Good beer selection.
author: Karen D.

description: Super awesome bartenders, equally awesome martinis and creative adult beverages, they have oysters :) :) :)  & we often run into the same great regular patrons.  This place is a definite staple in our SF watering hole locations list.  It is good for groups, couples, co-workers.
author: Price L.

description: Great food but the service is lacking. The first time I went there, they forgot to put in our appetizer ticket, and the second time a waiter only came to our table to take our order and give us the check. I tend to expect more from a place as expensive as it is for lunch. Servers are definitely more attentive when you're seated on the main floor and not the lofted area.
author: Peter S.

description: Really nice staff. The best thing though.... The tunes they are playing are phenomenal. I ordered an extra glass so that I could stay and listen to the playlist some genius put together. Great for happy hour!
author: Lyn L.

description:
This should be 3.5 stars, but I'll round up for the gravy. We started with oysters, one of each. The hama hama was delightful - subtle, ever so slightly sweet and fresh. I got the pork loin and shank which was decent. Tender, flavored perfectly, but a little gamey. The turnips were great as well. We couldn't resist, and ended up getting the poutine, which is essentially fries with short rib gravy. I LOVE GRAVY, especially with chunks of short rib on it, on top of crispy McDonalds esque fries? Winning!

Overall good meal, although I probably wouldn't come again unless someone really wanted to. Town Hall is much more my style
author: Beini S.

description:
When I walked in, I knew I would like it! The ambiance, decor alone made it looked like the food would be good. 

We went during their "in-between" time and the menu was pretty limited. We order the poutine, AMAZED! The best fries by far - the gravy and cheese complemented it so well, not too salty or overbearing like Canada's original version. We also had the Manila Clams & Linguica and a plate of the St. Pat's cheese - washed all the goodness down with a mint lemonade. I seriously cannot wait to go back!

YUMMY!
author: Thao L.

description:
First experience at Salt house - everything was fine.  Why only 3 stars, well dinner for 3 -- shared two apps, three entrees and 6 drinks $240 out the door.  While the food was  well prepared, service was fine, great upper mid tier restaurant.

Tried the poutine - go with the shrimp instead
My sole was really good - excellent flavor.  Pork was served medium rare, but was tasty.  Chicken looked good too.  Didn't have room for dessert.

Net, net better places to go in SF for same money (check my other reviews if you need hints)
author: Jas S.

description:
When I heard that the owners of Town Hall (my current favorite restaurant in SF) opened up a new place last year just a few blocks away downtown, I was really excited.  Town Hall doesn't serve anything that is less than outstanding, and that's quite remarkable for the large New American menu they offer.

Like Town Hall, Salt House features New American cuisine but in a more limited, precise menu.  Similarly, the aesthetic resembles Town Hall's with lots of exposed red brick and aged wood but here, the backdrop is cut with striking hanging modern lamps throughout the single long dining room, giving the space a sleeker, hipper look than it's older brother. 

And ah, the food.  It was outstanding.  I started with a rich celery root soup accented with pomegranates and bits of apple.  There was a touch of creme but it was really the well-balanced puree that gave the smooth, rich flavor; the fruit dancing above the soup (both in presentation and taste).  For my entree, I enjoyed the prime New York steak; generous sliced cuts of NY Strip layered between a mix of sauteed brussel sprouts and other savory vegetables, and a single delicious braised short rib.  I was in heaven.  I cleared my plate and had no room left for dessert unfortunately.  I did get a taste of Beth's fromage blanc gnocchi with kabocha squash and it was quite good as well (just not as good as my steak).

Service was on par with TH; friendly, knowledgable and attentive.  Highly recommend Salt House but make reservations; it was a full dining room on a Sunday evening.
author: Saminda W.

description: I've eaten here a few times over the past 5 years and each time it is a bit of a disappointment.  The menu just does not have much that appeals.  Hard to find a good salad (with lettuce), a good fish, a good sandwich, or much of anything.  I will up the rating one star for service.  There are so many places in SF that have a great menu, I would not waste my time here when there is so little that appeals.
author: Boris G.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars. (Rounded down to three stars because they seated us at a table under the stairs, way too close to another table and were completely unresponsive to my attempts to sweet talk my way to a better table.)

Came here for dinner on a rainy night a few weeks ago. I had a not so great experience at Town Hall a few years ago, so didn't come here with the highest of expectations. I was pleasantly surprised. 

The decor was of the typical "nice-but-not-super-nice-meal-out-in-the-city" style. I was into it. 

Bread was cold, butter was soft.

We split the foie gras appetizer. Decent, but probably wouldn't order it again. We each had a fish entree and they were both very very good. I love it when fish is cooked well. Accompanied by a nice glass of wine, I had a very lovely time here.
author: Nora G.

description:
Keeping with the motif of my first review, I was again tempted by the fruit of another during my last meal at Salt House.

This time it wasn't the steak, but the juicy, tender lamb shank.  Looking at the menu, I gently bit my bottom lip.  Saw the yellowfin tuna begging for my patronage, but the braised lamb shank (with quince and a berry sauce) stared me down lasciviously.  Never one to settle, I ordered the lamb and sipped my cocktail until the most beautifully presented lamb arrived....golden quince and kabocha squash with a brilliant burgundy berry reduction.

I sang under my breath:

"Your shank gets much closer
I fumble for the fork, alarmed by
The seduction
I wish that it would stop
Tempted by the fruit of another
Tempted but the truth is discovered"

...
author: Joanna M.

description:
My wife and had a fantastic dinner here for our anniversary.   The staff is super friendly and knowledgable and the ambiance is perfect for a romantic dinner.  Unlike many super noisy restaurants, Salt House is a place where you can have a conversation with your dinner partner.  

My wife started things with a yummy cocktail, I had a hard cider-both where delicious.  For appetizers we had the kampachi crudo and the burrata.  The crudo is a work of art and taste as amazing as it looks.  The burrata is perfectly delicious.  For dinner my wife had the salmon.  Salt House does amazing fish--the salmon was divine, perfectly cooked and had lovely flavor.  I had the parisian gnocchi, which was my favorite part of our dinner.  The gnocchi was rich and vegetables where all perfectly cooked.   we ended things with the german chocolate cake--the best renditions of a german chocolate cake I've ever had!  

All in all, Salt House is one of the best restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Andres T.

description:
I've come here a lot for happy hours within the past year and will probably frequent it even more in the upcoming years since it's right across from my office! I like the drinks, but not a huge fan of how small this place is. When it gets crowded and you're standing near the bar, waitresses and waiters always hustle around you and you find yourself always stepping aside to let someone get by. 

I had dinner here recently too. Ordered the mixed greens and a medium rare steak, which were both decent. My friends got the fois gras appetizer, which looked pretty appetizing when it came out with strawberries included in the dish, but they were dissatisfied with how small the portions of each were. Our table got fries and shrimp to share, and they gave us the halibut entree on the house as well! Actually, the halibut was probably the best dish on the table that night -- it was delicious! Service was very friendly and always checking in on us, refilling our water, etc. They're usually pretty busy, so food came out slowly compared to other restaurants. 

Still, 4 stars because it's my team's go-to spot for happy hour on Friday evenings!
author: Rose Y.

description:
I remember this being a weird day all around.  But this isn't my journal (I don't keep a journal), so I'll focus on the restaurant review.

So went out with a couple of buddies for guy's dinner.  It was one of their birthdays. So I knew I had to make it at least 51% awesome.  I decided to pick the place and coordinate.   

So had some sort of OpenTable mixup.  I scheduled it for 7:30, but for some reason it showed up at 6:45.  However, Salt House was nice enough to sit us as quickly as possible.  Waited about 7 minutes.  Was great. 

So it was a guy's dinner.  We had the usual conversation of talking about ourselves and critiquing everything about the food and drinks.  So here we go...

The Real McCoy
Sailor Jerry Spiced Rum/Smith & Cross Navy Rum/Firelit 'Blue Bottle' Coffee Liquor/Grand Manier 
Literally ordered it just because of the name.  That and I love all of the ingredients.  Result?  Drink was phenomenal.

Poutine
Kennebec Fries/Vermont Cheddar Short Rib Gravy
This was dangerously delicious.  We quickly cleaned the appetizer plate.

Prime New York Steak
Braised Short Rib/Crushed Fingerlings/Snap Peas/Bacon
I've had a couple of bad experiences lately with places that do a New York Steak.  Salt House did not disappoint though. It was cooked just right at medium rare,  and the short rib was a great bonus.  Very nicely done.

Dessert
We got dessert, but can't remember what it was.  It was good, from what I remember.

So my only criticism?

The server didn't seem like she wanted to be there.  I asked her about the Pork Loin, and she said she didn't know what I was talking about.  I looked up the menu again.  So they have a Beeler Pork Loin and Shank, that I had been looking forward to ordering all day, but turns out the menu wasn't updated on their website.  I looked it up while there, then asked again, and she said the site is updated everyday.  And I showed her, and finally she came around and realized that I was in fact showing her the website on my phone.  She said she would mention it to the manager.  Yes, this part of the story is too long, but I looked again today a couple of weeks later, and it still hasn't been updated on the website.  They should correct this.

The only other thing was that we ordered a dessert for my friend's birthday while he was in the bathroom, as a small surprise.  Which we told our server.  He came back, and then our server came back and set all the forks down in front of us.  The surprise that we had worked all of 5 minutes on was ruined.  

I sound like I hated the server.  Not the case.  I'm sure we could be best friends and travel the world solving crimes.  

Anywho.  At the end of the day, Salt House is highly recommended.  I will definitely be going back and hopefully they will have the Beeler Pork Loin and Shank to go with my Real McCoy.  

That's all for now.
author: John R.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed Salt House. 

Beginning with a nice glass of Chateau Lamothe de Haux Bordeaux Blanc, it was a wine that continued through the evening, and was a nice compliment to the two very different appetizers (Foie Gras and Crispy Shrimp), and then the main course of Atlantic Striped Bass and the Beeler Pork Loin. All very delicious. 

And just when we thought it couldn't get any better we discovered the desserts of Chocolate Stout Dacquoise, Malted Milk Chocolate Tart and vintage Port . . . . . a wonderful way to end the evening.

Thanks again to our server Fabian for helping us with all the different choices and then steering us to the best of all worlds.
author: Mickey A.

description:
only been here once and had a great time.

the hostess gave us extra drinks and the staff were really good at picking up cues, even surprised us with desert for a friend's bday. it was glorious.
author: Omar S.

description:
Wow...five years later and I'm obsessed with this restaurant. 

I work across the street which is the best. I go over for happy hour at least once a week and throw events here at least twice a year! 

The staff is awesome (mostly, there are always a couple not so greats, eh?), but Gabe is especially awesome. Hot, sweet and friendly! You can't go wrong. 

I LOVE love love the poutine, I walk in there and order it before even sitting down. The crispy shrimp is tdf - but really, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu. 

Try it for lunch/dinner or just a drink at the bar, you won't be sorry!
author: Shelley M.

description:
When Mr. Tall Dark and Handsome finally asked me out for a first date this past week, and on a Monday night no less, I figured this would be a good test because most my favorite restaurants are closed on Mondays.

Well, let me tell you, the a n t i c i p a t i o n was driving me crazy because all day long he kept saying we were going to his favorite dinner spot, and then teasing me with tales of delicious appetizers, wonderful main courses, and a really good wine list (he knows how much I appreciate an amazing French Sauvignon Blanc).

He finally told me we were going to Salt House, a restaurant I had never been to. We got there for an early evening reservation and from the moment we stepped in the door it was a wonderful night. 

Our server Fabian took very good care of us and made sure all of our questions were answered and helped us with all the food selections. So much deliciousness on the menu, I can't wait to go again and try those dishes I missed out on. Also would love to go there with a group of friends.

And who knows, if Mr. Tall Dark and Handsome keeps making good dining choices like this, he may be a keeper.
author: Marlisa F.

description: Tragic, cooler-than-thou service but solid food. The poutine is gimmicky and overrated, but the steak frites excellent. Typical industrial decor, looks like a 1990s Chicago loft.
author: Ben G.

description: everything was great...the heirloom tomato appetizer, salmon, white fish and rose...i would definitely go back.
author: C A.

description:
OMG DELICIOUS!!!

Super huge thanks to all the yelpers that went before me, you definitely steered us in the right direction.

Fois Gras two ways: YUM! The cured pork fois gras was a little taste of Paris, and the grilled fois gras was pure fatty delicousness to spread on toast. Plus a tease of incredible tea smoked duck in the middle! More please!!

Crispy Shrimp with Green Beans: A wonderful fusion of Indian and American flavors. Delicious. I loved the way the flavors all mixed together.

The house white wine is super awesome at a great price. Plus the little apothecary bottles are adorable.

Maybe they've been reading their Yelp reviews because their Valentine's Day wait service was spot on. When our waiter accidentally brought out a second caraffe of white wine instead of red, he left it on the table, with a "sorry, that one's on me. I'm just trying to get you both drunk".

Thanks for an incredible meal. I can't wait to come back!!
author: Aaron M.

description:
I was pretty excited to hear we are eating here for lunch. They have been on my list for quite some time since I learned that they are a sister company of Anchor and Hope. 

Made a reservation for our lunch since every time I passed by, it was always packed. We came here a couple of days before New Years Eve, so maybe a reservation wasn't needed after all when we saw the restaurant was half full once we stepped in. 

We decided to order the Tuna Tartare to start with and the Crispy Shrimp. The Crispy Shrimp was really good and had a nice spicy taste to it. Definitely my favorite out of the 2 starters since the Yellowfine Tartare was kind of bleh to me. It tasted a bit bland. 

For my entree, I ordered their special at that time, which I don't remember the name now, but it was a Mexican style beef stew (recommended by the waiter). I had to get it because he said the word spicy. But, to my disappointment, I didn't like my food at all. It was bland and it wasn't spicy. 

The service was really good. Our waiter was friendly and helpful. He was very knowledgeable; when we had a question about the menu, he was quick to answer.
author: Cindy W.

description:
came here for drinks and a few appetizers...the best thing i had was the bread and butter...everything was waaay over-salted and one dimensional in flavor...pernod was the predominate flavor...

drinks

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jk1T4xIb_FH_SsiVng43HA?select=2RP2px1zghyHnDHgcymc_w

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jk1T4xIb_FH_SsiVng43HA?select=hKIMLnOgPIEbfOv97fr9eg

author: Amanda S.

description: I wanted to like it. Food nothing great, portions extremely small and the server was a smoker who didn't use a breath mint or hand lotion (for sure didn't wash hands) after she smoked. You could smell her when she was next to our table, you can't tell me the manager didn't smell her all evening.  Clearly not a place that's crossing their T's and dotting their I's.  Our group agreed we won't go back.
author: CeCe K.

description:
I would give 4.5 stars, but.... 

Had a phenomenal meal here on Sunday, as per usual. Though I was sad to see Robert move on (chef left to open up his own place), their new chef hails from sister restaurant Town Hall and El Buli. I had the creamy polenta with mushrooms and asparagus. It was DELECTABLE. The texture and flavor of the polenta was OUT OF THIS WORLD.  

We had the scallop dish as an app (gotta admit I preferred the last chefs prep better, with the foam) which was solid and good, as well as the corn soup to start-- which was incredible and tasted of amazingly fresh, just picked sweet corn. 

Only slight disappointment (and this wasn't based on the taste/flavor of the actual dish-- just the expectation) the rhubarb crumble is nothing like a traditional crumble. It had a scoop of ice cream, served on top of a slightly warm rhubarb compote. Which is not at all what I had hoped for when ordering it... the topping is soooo where it is at with crumbles, and I got none ;( That said it was tasty.
author: Leah C.

description:
Very nice decor, but tables can be pretty close to your neighbors.   

I had the pork chop, which was a 9 out of 10 - probably the best pork chop I've ever had.   Parsnip puree, with nice veggies (mostly brussell sprouts)  and great presentation.    My wife is a big fan of braised short ribs and it was about a 2 out of 10 - probably the worst she's ever had.    it was served in a bowl with broth, not a sauce and very fatty.   Veggies seemed to be mostly boiled carrots.   WTF?   I'd put it on some polenta with a bit of sauce and some well-cooked veggies.

Foie gras was good too  - seared portion way better than the cured half. 

Wine list was good - we did the Provenance Cab from Napa/Rutherford.   Solid Napa cab at a decent price.

If the short rib was as good as the rest, this would be a 5 star rating.
author: Dave C.

description:
Five stars for the delicious foie gras appetizer, the quince and elderberries really brought out the flavors. They serve both cured and a sauteed foie gras together.  I would come again for this appetizer alone! 

I had the braised short rib dinner and it was excellent.  Very flavorful dinners over all, excellent service, really nice atmosphere. I ended this meal with a wonderful Elderflower osmanthus tea (highly recommend).  Everything was perfect.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Kari S.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Tuesday. Not bad - wait service was awesome but food was so-so.  Flavorful, but not astounding.

Seafood is fresh and varied - they change the menu regularly.  We split a yummy arugula salad and some sad-looking but tasty sardine fillets to start.  Hubby had the Sea Bass on a bed of squid ink beans and other 'black stuff' (pretty nice), and I had the Salmon which was fresh and melted in your mouth, perhaps a little too much salt which says a lot, as I put salt on EVERYTHING.  

Worth coming back, but I probably preferred their sister restaurant better.
author: Beekay M.

description:
Loved loved the Salt House. I was in SF for work so sat at the bar for a couple hours and thoroughly enjoyed it! The atmosphere is fun and chic with exposed brick and kind of an open floor plan - it's like one big room.
I had some oysters and the rabbit bolognese linguine, which was AMAZING. My only "complaint" was that it was too small (but it WAS an appetizer) so I ordered another one and ate both.  The bartender was super friendly and definitely hooked it up. This place definitely has potential for a fifth star if I go back and try some more dishes!! Definitely recommend and will go back when I return to SF.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Salt House on a Sunday night around 6:30, and the place was just filling up. The decor was very warm - exposed brick, perfect lighting, open kitchen. 

We started with the Divorce, Italian Style and Salty Dog drinks - both delicious, though the first packed more of a punch - and the peaches and pork belly appetizer. The appetizer was the perfect start to the meal - light and fresh peaches, crisp pork belly, with a delicious salad on top. 

Entrees - we had the steak with potatoes and chicken with white corn and au jus, both of which were FANTASTIC. We were really blown away by the quality of the food and the flavors on both dishes. 

The waiter was a bit green by very accommodating and super friendly.  The table next to us complained a bit about the "slow" service - given the quality of the food and the drinks, we had no complaints. We stayed for 3+ hours and felt the whole meal was a great experience. This is definitely not the type of place you visit to be in and out quickly - but if you want amazing food and atmosphere, I highly recommend carving some time out and going to Salt House.
author: Krystle K.

description: With the name "Salt House" and the cool decor, I really wanted to love the food, but it was more "Ok" than anything else.  The irony is that some dishes were undersalted (the poutine) and others were oversalted (cod and pork loin).  The gravy for the poutine was also lumpy which was somewhat of a downer.  Best entree was my wife's duck breast - cooked perfectly.  Service was fine, no complaints.  SH may be worthy of a redo for lunch or perhaps the B side menu on Sundays.
author: Tim L.

description:
Salt House is neither a seasoning nor a domicile. Discuss.

I actually didn't eat dinner here, but four hours at the bar has to count for something, don't you think? I met a good friend whom I had not seen for quite a while, so we saddled ourselves onto the first two stools of the bar and stayed put in full-tilt chat mode. The entire menu is available at the bar, a good thing since the place is relatively small and cozy with a densely populated smattering of tables. On the ground floor of an old printing press warehouse, it has lots of masculine banker vibes in here with only a dollop of dot com arrogance and a dab of metrosexuality to let you know you're in SF.

There was an increasing blur of Ketel One cosmos in front of me, but somehow in between, we managed to try three solid dishes - a nice frisee salad with ricotta, caramelized beets and fennel, crispy shrimp with green beans and fresh Dungeness crab with fried baby artichokes. They were all in the $12-15 range, a little on the high side for appetizers but well-prepared in that haughty culinary manner reflecting an innate understanding of the type of customer who dines here.

The place got crowded quickly and stayed fairly congested throughout the evening. The bartenders were reasonably attentive given the streams of customers coming at them. With its proximity to the FiDi, Salt House caters to a professional work crowd. Hippies in flip-flops need not apply nor anyone with a credit card with a low spending limit.

UPDATE - 4/25/2007:

Heart be still, as I was able to sit at the revered community table in the center of this tiny, tony restaurant. The dynamics in table positioning are a startling exercise worthy of the wonderful flora-and-fauna series, "Planet Earth". Call this episode "Territorial Dining Rights". There were four of us who came at different times to the central area, and the glares of the women sitting at the end were on par with the show featuring the snow leopard stalking the poor, innocent oryx. Of course, if the snow leopard had a bad perm and cellulite, it would have been a more accurate analogy.

But I digress...the service improved since my last visit, perhaps the distinction between attentive bartenders holding court versus conscientious waiters maneuvering stealth-like around the squeezed table. I also got to try other dishes thanks to my friends - a ramekin of marinated olives and a mixed winter vegetable plate with all sorts of beets and fiddlehead ferns. Delish. Still sticking with my 4-star rating until I can save enough shekels for a full dining experience here.

FOOD - 4 stars...nice appetizers, good combo of flavors but kinda pricey
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...plenty of wood and brick and rusted metal for the suit set
SERVICE - 4 stars...attentive bartenders...though I think it would have helped if I had cleavage...conscientious, stealth-like waiters
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice FiDi alternative...if you're on an expense account
author: Ed U.

description:
Salt House is a nice restaurant with a bustling atmosphere - the foodie after-work crowd.

Tried a couple of dishes and some wine on a Wednesday night.

Foie gras with cherries and brioche was really delicious, rich, and had a beautiful presentation.
Salmon with lima beans was cooked and seasoned perfectly.
tagliatelle with chanterelle mushrooms - this dish was a bit bland, the chanterelle mushrooms were the best part, little juicy bursts of flavor.
author: Janelle C.

description:
This place has a great classic, rusty yet sophisticated ambiance. I'd say it's a great place after work to grab a drink with friends, chat and relax. They have some classic drink recipes of their own that are worth a try if your a liquor person.

The food, although expensive is very good. I had the pork loin here and I can comfortably say it's the best I've had so far. Can't go wrong with good food and drinks ;)
author: Nitin G.

description: Overpriced and totally underwhelming. On Sat night I spent $30 on a dish of undercooked limp Cod and fried blossoms. There was nothing else on the menu even mildly appealing. If you are vegetarian, don't even come here unless you are willing to resign yourself to a salad. My share of the bill ended up being $70 for an utterly forgettable dining experience .
author: A T.

description:
Not a good place for kleptos . .  They have cool stuff here that we sooo wanted to snag - the Puegeot salt & pepper shakers, the delicately fine dessert silverware, and the neat-o printing press stamp . . . what if they accidentally fell into my purse?
 
Energetic restaurant with a young & happening vibe to it
Fabulous service
Sizeable portions
Cocktails such as the salty dog and ginger julep were refreshing and sharp 
To-die-for crispy potato wedge fries slathered with cheese, tasty beef chunks, and yes, gravy
Everyone was happy with their snapper, chicken, and yellowfin tuna entrees
Plenty of pistachios in the pistachio ice cream that came with the lovely warm chocolate cake
Strawberry trifle charmingly presented with little tiny cut strawberries atop a jar of shortcake cookies (since then, I've had strawberry trifle on the  mind)

4.5
author: Peg S.

description:
Came here for a business lunch. Ambiance is just what you'd expect it to be at noon on a weekday in the Fidi: business casual parties of 2-4 in a rush to dine and dash back to the office. It's clean, modern, and I appreciate that the service was prompt and polite. 

Food:
I had the Petrale Sol and a Fresh Mint Lemonade. Fish was prepared well, but nothing memorable. As in, I don't see myself waking up with a craving for that specific dish again. The Fresh Mint Lemonade was refreshing and flavorful. I'd order both again (and may even be inspired to attempt replicating the lemonade at home). 

Overall, good food and good ambiance make this place a good spot for business lunches.
author: Sabeen c.

description:
In a city with so many amazing and cheap restaurants, how do you rate a restaurant that may be amazing but can't be classified as cheap?

Had the poutine and two other dishes.  Poutine was fresh, hot, reasonably tasty...I think I just don't get this dish.  Drinks were good, waitress was spot on, and definite + for leaving carafe of water on the table.

I'd definitely come here on the company dime again.
I wouldn't mind paying for the food, but I'd probably have 3 or 4 suggestions before Salt House, at or below the price.


On my scale, Salt House gets a (high) 2

Scale:
1: Would not go back alone and would protest if a friend suggested we go.
2: Would not go back alone, but would not protest if a friend suggested we go.
3: Would go back happily and willingly without being prompted by someone else.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Salt House was never a salt house, in case you were curious. It was, however, once a printing press - something the restaurant pays homage to when they drop your check with a metal letter on top at the end of the meal.

We came here last night for a double dinner date. My dashing date and I shared Salt House's take on the much-loved Canadian favorite poutine and a delectable Kabocha squash and chestnut soup to start. It was a struggle to decide on our main course but in the end our desires for the substantial won out and we went with the steak served atop creamy parsnips (I love parsnips!) The poutine was absolutely delicious with its perfectly cooked potatoes and super rich and meaty gravy. The folks at Salt House were kind enough to split our soup which was a nice surprise. I was equally impressed with the pairing of Kabocha and chestnuts - delightful!

We talked our dining companions into sharing the scrumptious butter pecan sundae with us. We needed all the help we could get - this dessert was so huge it easily served four people! 

As far as the interior goes, the light was warm and I loved the postcard rack fixtures that hung above our heads. If you're seated near the communal table in the center, you're likely to get a lot of other people's backsides rubbing up against you as you dine - I watched this happen throughout our meal to my friend seated opposite me. Annoying, but nothing that severely compromised the enjoyment of our meal. The pathway in that area is likely to remain congested so consider yourself warned.

Service was excellent.

It seems Salt House had a few kinks in the beginning but those seem to be well ironed out now. I was very impressed with my meal and recommend this place heartily!
author: Miriam W.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for a couple years now, but when I finally tried it the other night, I wasn't impressed. Overall was costly for dishes that were neither unique nor tasty. What we had:

Beet salad: this was probably the best thing I had that the night, the beets and pomegranate were tasty and the presentation of the food was nice

Tuna tartar: the tuna was relatively fresh, but the portion was extremely tiny

Poutine: the worst appetizer of the bunch we had, it was very tasteless even with the short rib gravy, and the fries were super soggy

Scallops: this was a pricey $30 for 3 oysters and a lot of kale. The scallops were super salty and smelled very fishy (not fresh) and my coworker didn't even finish hers.

Lamb: didn't try this, but another coworker said it was some of the best lamb he's ever tried
author: Linda J.

description: hmmm, The wine was freezing cold and marginal and the food was super salty to the point that I couldn't eat it and I love salt. I had mixed lettuces and the dressing was so salty and the chicken too. The tomato bisque was decent but the salmon was so-so.   The man who brought us cold store bought bread after 20 minutes practically growled at us he was so unhappy and he wouldn't speak to us.  I will steer people clear of this place. The whole experience was LAME.
author: Jill S.

description:
What a snazzy joint (but not too snazzy). The perfect spot for after-work drinks, a first drink on a first date, or a place to throw a martini in your cheating lover's face.

...Not that I'd know about that last one.

Ahem. I made a reservation for a celebratory work function and had a pretty great time. A group of us just ordered drinks and little nibblers. (And if their website was UPDATED, perhaps I could try to provide a better run-down, SALT HOUSE!)

DRINK
Went with the whisky-infused hooch: Waistcoat & Tar. I don't quite recall what all was in it, but it was a tasty beverage and quite strong to boot.

EAT
Appies, only. Tiny portions. The appetizers are really just that: appetizing.
+Chips: fried veggie chips served with a mayonnaise-based dip. Yum. Next.
+Stuffed calamari: served with chorizo, mussels, and white beans. Surprisingly salty (like, contort-your-face salty, but I like that, so it was tasty).
+Collar: I believe it belonged to the Yellowtail variety, but I can't quite recall. What I do recall was that it was pretty good.
+Beet salad: served with goat cheese, cherry tomatoes, and a concord grape panna cotta. The dish itself was very refreshing and tasty, but try as I may, I'm not a fan of goat cheese. The grape panna cotta is basically just jam, but yummy jam.
+Scallops: cooked perfectly.
+Anchovies: served with piquillo peppers and niçoise. Not a fan.
+Poutine: basically, French fries topped with gravy and cheese curbs. In this case, it was a short rib gravy and melted Vermont cheddar. I think we ended up ordering something like four of these. Vegetarians: you can have them "hold" the gravy, but that's just silly; all the deliciousness is in that gravy!

Great service (I didn't ever see my water glass empty), fair prices (it's technically the Financial District), and tasty eats.
author: Adena B.

description:
the restaurant is nice and service was ok but a bit slow.
The food was ok and wasn't amazing.
we were a bit disappointed that the food wasn't as good we thought it would be.  


we ended up walking next door to Roy's for the hot melting chocolate souffle to end the night with a better taste in the mouth.
author: Ronnie G.

description:
The Poutine Fries ($12) are a must have. The fries are crisp and come topped with cheddar and the short rib gravy. You even get bits and pieces of short rib in the gravy.

The Foie Gras ($22) was served both seared and terrine. This dish was decent but I've had better elsewhere.

The Braised Short Rib ($28) was not that great and I would not order it again. Although the meat was tender, the sauce/gravy on top was over powering. Perhaps I had eaten too much gravy with the Poutine Fries already.

We also had the Tai Snapper ($27.50). It was good but nothing to write home about at this price.

The hostess was awesome and initially warned us our walk-in table would take an hour as there was a long line in front of us (it was a Friday night). After we agreed, she came and found us 10 minutes later and said that she would be able to sit us in another 5 minutes. Score!
author: Lester W.

description:
I've been kicking myself for not trying Salt House sooner, as it is part of the Stock & Bones SF restaurant holy trinity (Town Hall and Anchor & Hope, being the others).  

After an exquisite dinner a couple of weeks ago, I would go as far to say that Salt House is inching ahead as my favorite of the three, and one of the best restaurants in SF as well.  Savory and sweet intermingled harmoniously from the cocktails to the dessert. 

For cocktails I chose Always and Only, with  plymouth gin, dimmi, cucumber, reagan's orange bitters, and orange flower water.  My boyfriend had Salthouse Dog, with charbay ruby red grapefruit vodka, campari, grapefruit juice, salted rim.  Unbelievable. 

For the appetizer, we shared the Kohlrabi-apple soup with curry, cilantro, mint.  It tasted as amazing as it sounds.  For dinner my boyfriend had Petrale sole, salsify, mussels, lady apples, cider jus; and I had the Beeler pork loin, phipps ranch beans, winter roots, salsa verde. The pork was  wrapped in BACON and cooked perfectly. There was juicy bits of BACON intermingling with the winter roots. 

The biggest surprise was dessert. We ordered the Chocolate stout dacquoise, peanut and pretzel meringue, with caramel buttercream.  Imagine a tennis ball with a rich chocolate shell and all of the items above delicously layered inside. The presentation was amazing, and it tasted like heaven. 

If you have 20 min or 2 hours, visit Salt House for cocktails or a bite.  And if you need more encouragement, let me remind you again about the PORK LOIN WITH BACON and the CHOCOLATE STOUT DACQUOISE.
author: Lisa R.

description:
loud LoUd LOUD!

L
O
U
D

in there! people all around you are progressively getting drunk.
anywho, really loud so don't bring a date or your 80 year old grandma who is hard of hearing.

POUTINE.. glorious fatty carb laden devil of satan... i have only read about and seen pictures of poutine but i am so lucky to finally have eaten some.  it basically killed my diet but it was soooo worth it. temptation is a bitch, and her name is poutine... 

foie gras - nothing too impressive to gush about, but it was still delicious. i mean, how can you NOT like foie gras??? cherries were a tad overly sweet though. 

halibut - a-ok. can't say much because it wasn't my dish but i had a few bites.

yellowifn tuna - okay it was good but i have a few issues with this dish. first things first, the flavors. the seasonings used on the outside of the tuna are delicious! however, it DOES NOT mesh well with the sweetness of mashed peas. secondly, the texture of this dish reminds me of baby food - it's all MUSHY. you have the softness of the seared fish with the mushy mashed peas, come on. bad texture is a turn off for the palette.. perhaps throw in something crunchy?

was too full to order dessert, but i would definitely come back here for the poutine.
author: Susy C.

description:
I've been here twice--once for lunch and the other time for dinner.  I was not at all impressed the first time.  I wanted to give it another shot.  Sadly, I have to say that the second time was not any better.  For food that is subpar, this place is crazy expensive!

We had the poutine (aka fries with cheese and short rib sauce) for appetizers.  This was ok; but in my opinion, it wasn't worth paying $12.  I had the short ribs for my main dish, which was delicious.  My boyfriend had the pork chops, which was tough and rubbery.  

The service was friendly but slow.  It was a busy night for them, so I'm willing to cut them some slack.  However, I'm not willing to give them a break for charging customers a premium for average food.
author: Khristine A.

description:
Crowded party. But wait--piles of shrimp. OK, that's good. Oysters galore. Hmmm.

It gets better--appetizers that are real food!

Actual grilled cheese, ham and turkey sandwiches, cooked in real butter. Deliciously rich (yet not greasy!) and among the best grilled sandwiches I've ever had.

Then steak fries with a cheesy bechamel sauce and gravy--an interesting choice for people standing up--but it worked!

Not only was the food serious delicious, the staff was inordinately nice, helpful, and able to somehow magically navigate through a room packed shoulder to shoulder.

And wait--there's more. Lots of parking next door! 

(I should mention I was working the party, so I got to see the kitchen and downstairs--all of which were spotlessly clean).

This is a really great place. Really. Great.
author: Daniel W.

description: Service was a little slow, but the place seemed to be pretty busy - like the rest of the restaurants in SOMA.  The burger was tasty and the condiments were like a little salad - couldn't put it all on the burger.  Nothing special about the fries or anything else I saw being delivered to the tables.
author: Keith R.

description:
This restaurant was not just unfriendly to vegetarians but downright hostile and rude.  I was one of two vegetarians in a party of 8 -- many of whom had been long anticipating a visit to Salt House -- about one year ago.  

When I made the reservation, I made a note in the Open Table memo space that there would be one vegetarian and one vegan in the party.  After we were seated, I asked the waitress if she had any suggestions -- she was really rude and said we should leave and go to another restaurant.

I asked for a manager -- he took our request to the chef who created two very boring, bland pasta and overcooked vegetable dishes for which we were charged $25.  It was pretty pathetic.  I know they had truffle oil and many yummy veggies in the kitchen -- but they made a pile of bell pepper strips on pasta that would not have been enough to feed a starving runway model.  

The meat eaters were all pleased -- and the wine selection was fantastic -- so we consider the evening an overall success, but none of us will likely return there again.
author: Jenn C.

description: Food was ok for the price. I left with the feeling of well that wasn't great. The Lunch menu is where it is at for this place as the burger is Bomb!
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I got sick on new year's eve here. I knew that the oyster were bad and I had to fight tooth and nail only to get half of the oyster waved of charges.
They ruined my evening, I used to look forward to going there...
author: Robert F.

description:
I decided to save my very first Yelp review for one of the best dining experiences I have ever had the joy of experiencing. I took my out-of-town parents to the Salt House on Thursday night. Luckily I had a reservation, because the restaurant was packed! 

We started with a round of cocktails at the bar, all of which were very good. I had their newest creation involving strawberries and some other deliciousness I have now forgotten. 5 stars for delicious and creative drinks. 

Once seated, the manager/sommelier came over to offer his suggestions on the wine list my Dad was perusing. (Be warned, their wine list is very short.) We ended up ordering a bottle (and another) of the Seghesio Zin that he suggested. The wine was lovely and paired well with everything we ordered. 

For appetizers, we ordered the poutine and tagliatelle with mushrooms. The french fries were thick and perfectly crisp, the cheese was abundant and the gravy was delicious. My one gripe is they were pretty skimpy on the short rib gravy. Tagliatelle with mushrooms was the tiniest portion I have ever seen (literally 4 small bites total), but was absolutely delicious. The manager also brought us the pork belly appetizer when he overheard my Mom say she didn't like mushrooms. The pork belly was the definite show stopper! 

For entrees we had the chicken, beef and ling cod. The chicken was the best I've ever had, the beef and short rib combo were a huge hit, and the ling cod was perfectly cooked and delicious. The garlic puree accompanying the fish was to.die.for. 

We passed on dessert, but were pleasantly surprised when they brought us a crustless cheesecake in a jar with berries. I'm not a big cheesecake fan, but this was AMAZING. 

As you can see, I am a bit obsessed with Salt House and our wonderful meal. The service was impeccable, from our waiter at the bar, our waitress at dinner, the manager and the personable chefs in the open kitchen. The food was outstanding. Space is pretty small and cramped, and the noise level is quite high, but the service and food make you forget about it really quickly.  I will definitely be back.
author: Erinn C.

description:
Another short weekend trip to S.F. I was on a mission to make up a long over due birthday dinner for my friend. It was her choice to pick a spot and I'm SO glad we made it to the Salt House. 

We made an early reservation and was surprised that there were already patrons dining and folks hanging out at the bar. The interior http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/TQ3Uz7936LhdsJ7BB23Wwg/l has a modern loft feel that's very open with a heavy emphasis on the brick and wood decor. The lighting is dim but just bright enough to make out what you're eating. 

The menu is simple. Nothing really makes you say OooO and AhHhH except for the Foise Gras http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/SCsmPbfySYkK6bxFIuOYKw/l , which was succulent!

The Baked Oysters http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/AG_tIO95wq2VGQk727F3Wg/l were pretty good but I was expecting a little more.

The Mrs had herself the Seared Yellowfin Tuna atop Sweet and Sour Eggplant + Pinenuts + Spicy Shellfish Jus http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/0go7zo9w10lHyyv-UgyosA/l . The tuna was THICK and Seared perfectly. The Shellfish Jus gave the dish a extra flare!

I had the Roasted Lamb Loin with Butter Beans + Chanterelles + Salsa Verde http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/-dRHRiRXcuKoBUG6nTM9eQ/l . Not only was this dish BIG. But the Lamb was awesome and the Salsa Verda added so much flavor!

Their wine selection here is pretty extensive but I wish their House Drinks went a little deeper. I had a Manhattan and the Mrs. had this Mojito concoction http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/995ng8sMf2xNu_xz9xZKyg/l of some sort which both were pretty good.

The desert list was somewhat pleasant. We veered toward the Bread Pudding http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/YyzB82TU4vTH3ZNcu47lsw/l and it was one of the best bread pudding I've had!

The service here is very attentive. Our Waitress was very helpful picking out our dishes as well as making sure we were doing fine.

-----------------
Rye's Notes:
*Ask to be seated in the Main dining area towards the kitchen
*Ask not to be seated underneath the staircase
*Shares Bathroom with Harlot
author: Rye N.

description:
4 stars for the warm and impeccable service from our bartender Crys...When I arrived for my b-day dinner my girlfriends had already tied a few on at the bar...so we just parked it and ordered our meal at the bar. . 
When I was deciding between Town Hall and the Salt House for din..the deciding factor was the fact that the Salt House has a dish of french fries smothered in cheese and gravy...It was good but it still doesn't compare to the tator tots with mac -n- cheese at Q.  We also had the oysters to start..the hama hama was delicious.

I was a bit disappointed with the rest of our meal.  We had the seared tuna, the steak, and the chicken..The chicken ended up being the best dish and everything else was so so so...really..the food itself isn't 5 stars..maybe 3.5...but the service and the wine list alone deserves a return visit.
author: Mimi T.

description: I was looking forward to dining at Salt House but was very disappointed. Went on what was admittedly a busy night but still. I had the ribeye and it was probably the worst piece of meat I've ever had. The cocktails were very small for the price. My other diners had mixed reviews as well. Too bad.
author: Bob B.

description:
After leaving an oyster and wine pairing charity event ($60 per person), boyfriend, little bro and I were still hungry and 'feelin' the wine.  Upon deciding where to saciate ourselves, there were two variables that had the most weight:  reliablility and walking distance.  And thus, 6 blocks later we arrived at the doors of Salt House on Mission Street.

"Are you sure you want to go to Salt House instead of trying something new?" asks boyfriend.  

"Spencer (lil' brother) is only here for another couple of weeks.  If he is going to try any restaurants with us, one has to be Salt House."  Salt House has ambiance and class.  It also has flare and attitude.  I hate walking into a restaurant and leaving bored.  I also am not a fan of being confused and disoriented by a mis-matched decor and a whirlwind menu.  Salt House takes those items we love and makes them better.

The best part about Salt House is that you can dine there to celebrate something special or just because.  This evening I would find myself in a light quarrel with the boyfriend.  We sat down and examined the updated menu. A poutine appetizer (images quickly sent to friends in Montreal a la Facebook); froie gras (because its going to be illegal next year FYI); lightly battered quail over fava beans; braised short ribs.  The little brother noticed the boyfriend and I needed to 'have a chat' and excused himself to the restroom.

All was handled by the time he returned and perfectly timed with our food (I think the servers were watching).  Usually, my appetite is the first thing to go when I'm upset; which is highly disconcerting for a foodie like myself.  Salt House has such a welcoming space and the exposed brick and iron support somehow made it ok that I too was 'exposed' at the moment.  I took a deep breath and started to eat.  

Thank god I did.  Once again Salt House has left this little foodie satisfied and proud.  It could be Tuesday day or Saturday night...either way, get your tail end over to Salt House.  It is a taste not to be missed.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Came here last month for my mom's birthday. 

Must try...
poutin = yum, esp for this Canadien. 
seafood platter = super duper fresh
braised short ribs

the waiter had a really nice sense of humor. great selection of wines. make sure you save room for dessert!

i mos def will return
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Salt House is really really crowded.  Even at 6 pm.  Since I am an old old woman I like to have dinner early, right after work at around 6-630 pm and be home by 8 pm.  So I figured it would be easy to get in and out.  On this particular night our reservation was pushed back 45 minutes and the service was just slow slow slow.  I also am not a fan of restaurants that are so small that they put tables 2 inches away from the other tables.  You basically knock other patron's drinks down with your ass (or at least my big ass does) before you squeeze into 2 inches worth of space praying you won't have to cause an earthquake to make it to the bathroom.  

Anyway after waiting quite a long time and then listening to my neighbors conversations for awhile we finally order.  We had the fries, which are a must - but honestly they could've been Mcdonald's fries it wouldn't have mattered.  We also had the tartare which was very standard.  I do like how they will split things in two if you are sharing.  The BREAD was outstanding, I may have eaten two loaves and was contemplating asking the waitress for some to go.  I also had the pork dish, which came with a fantastic corn side medley  - that was the best part.   

The food was good, but the waiting and slow service would make it hard for me to want to do that again.  And it was just PIZZACKED!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Yay this is my first review on Yelp! =)

Anyways, I went here for lunch today with some of my coworkers. We started with the poutine appetizer dish...it's pretty much steak fries covered in melted cheddar cheese and short rib gravy and it was DELICIOUS! Think of it as a neat twist on the typical chili-cheese fries. haha 

Then, for my entree, I had the salmon dish and it was a perfectly cooked piece of fish...tender and flavorful (I liked that they left the skin nice and crispy on there too!) I thought the veggie side that came with the fish was a little too salty though. The bread was also really fresh and tasty! 

Overall, the service was great...someone was always there refilling our water glasses, changing our dishes, and asking how we were doing. The only downside was that our entrees took a little longer to come out than we expected. 

With all of that said, this is a cute place worth checking out and is decently priced (around $20 or more a person depending on what you order). I will definitely come back and hopefully try their desserts next time!
author: Karen Y.

description:
This review is only for drinks at the bar. 
The beverages were relatively well priced for the area and the bartender was friendly. While my friends and I took multiple shots, the bartender was attentive to our needs and looked like he was enjoying himself as well (even if chocolate cake shots are annoying to make). I do definitely want to check out the food once I get a chance, everything looked pretty tasty.
author: Tony W.

description:
Had cocktails and dinner at Salt House recently and thought overall it was pretty good. Service at the bar was very friendly, and the cocktails we had were almost all tasty (the mezcal cocktail was not for me, despite my enjoyment of mezcal in general). The bar crowd on Friday night was good looking and upbeat,  and the restaurant's atmosphere was definitely fun. 

My sister and I split the short rib poutine, which was rich but delicious! We each had a fish entree (she the Alaskan Ling Cod and the Petrale Sole for me), and while hers was delicious mine was rather bland tasting and the mussel broth tasted fishy in an unpleasant way. We split the Chocolate Stout Dacquois which was delicious (save room - or plan to split it). I might check it out again but would order chicken or meat as a main course.
author: K N.

description:
I'm gonna try not to write a lot here my being review #433, I'm only going to be a teensy drop in the bucket!  Overall Salt House was good but not excellent.  I'm glad I had a gift certificate and probably won't seek this place out again unless it's incredibly convenient.  The food is good - but not up to par with the prices in my book.

Came here after ice skating at AT&T Park during Xmas-time... and we were hungry!  When I think back at what we ordered - man, it was a hearty meat frenzy!  I don't know how it happened that Boyfriend didn't insist on some veggies but veggies there were none...

Starters:
Suckling Pig with quince and huckleberries: this was good; very tasty combination of flavors.  I love sweet and salty together!  The pork was an odd texture - very tender, but maybe a bit dry too.  It had a wonderful crispy piece of skin on top and the quince and huckleberry sauces looping around the plate were a nice combination with the savory meat.

Foie Gras with persimmon jam and something else I don't recall: I've never had bad foie gras and this was not an exception.  There were 2 small pieces; one cured (and cold) and the other sauteed.  I'm not a huge fan of persimmon so I didn't love that flavor with it, but the other [fruit] sauce was nice.  Cut a small piece of foie gras, dab it with the fruit sauce, put it atop a bite of bread - this alone could be one of my favorite flavor combinations in existence!

Entrees:
Roasted Lamb Loin with sunchokes, chanterelles and turnips: this was good and I found myself going for it more than our other entree.  The lamb was perfectly cooked - just barely medium like I had asked.  The sauce was nice and flavorful.

Beef Short Rib with farro, cipollini and a porcini-marrow crust: the meat fell off the bone and was very tasty but still missing that "amazing" factor.  The sauce was yummy and the combination of flavors was very nice.  Farro is a small chewy grain for those who don't know.

Overall nothing left a mark.  Nothing made me go "OMG this is to die for" - well, other than the foie gras, but I do that whenever/wherever I eat foie gras!  And it's a little sad that I actually got bored writing this review... that's a first!
author: Lisa T.

description:
This place was yum in some respects but others not so yum. The oysters were very flavorful with the side dipping sauces. Then our appetizers were good too. The French Fries with cheese and a delicious gravy with mushrooms really did it for me! I ordered the Sole dish for my entree, which left me satisfied and happy about what I had ordered. My boyfriend on the other hand wasn't too content. They usually don't offer fillet Mignon but this weekend they did offer it as a special but it was everything but special. 
The place is basically a loft setting with a second level for maybe 5 different parties. They have a full bar and it can get a little noisy. It reminds me of the loft my boyfriend lives in but with a restaurant in it so I felt like I was eating at home. :)
Overall the service was good, food good but pricey for the overall experience.
author: Priscilla E.

description:
1136 reviews for the Salt House? This is either due to the Palace (an SPG hotel) being down the street and thus an influx of business travelers, OR bc SF is the birthplace of yelp and you guys have been getting the damn thing done for years longer than we have in Chicago.

Took a Virgin American flight into town that landed around 9, and was FAMISHED by the time I got settled in at my hotel.  My friend and I asked where was a place we could get some good late night eats and check out the eye candy(seriously. i asked this.) and were led to the Salt House.  

As it was a thursday night, I'm not surprised that there was a good crowd of people.  We sat at one of the high communal tables (the only one that was available).  There was only seating on one side of the bench, so awkwardly intimate for two gfs that just wanted to chowhouse.  

We got some fruity pink cocktails as an appropriate welcoming to San Francisco, and ordered a few apps to share.  Octopus something (which was too salty), but a pasta dish and mushroom/fish dish that were both outstanding.

We also stumbled upon a networking group of IT VCs/Stanford Bschool grads out celebrating the acquisition of a new company. They sent some wine over for us, but unfortunately they came with the drinks and the social ineptitude of 2nd graders.  At least we got some free drinks.
author: Jaime S.

description:
I am sorry i have to start this with the biggest issue of proper etiquette.
We paid using cash and credit card (we had plan to leave a cash tip, so we told the waitress the amount we wanted charged to the card, and she did charge that amount on the card) and we provided with plenty enough cash to cover the rest of the bill but our waitress KEPT ALL THE CHANGE,  taking with her  a wapping 27%  tip, we where appalled by this since she only brought back my credit card and pen to sign the receipt and that was all (really passive aggressive). I  though the general rule if someone puts more than enough to cover the bill the change should be returned. THE NERVE! she wasn't even a good server. NEVER COMING BACK again to this place! LAME.  

OK now the food, Lets say their menu specially their main entrees lacked to impress. Their starters on the other hand where a little more creative. we ordered four starters for two, it was plenty of food, they did split a salad we had ordered, that was nice. But everything was a bit too salty...enough that we could tell the chef smokes, there was too much salt in general but  specially the salad and poutine gravy.. 

Their cocktails are quite nice, that's about the only thing they do right at this place. Overall, i had way better in the city, for the price-point i would head right over to bluestem or even cotogna, yep.
author: Eric G.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend last night. We were able to make reservations earlier in the afternoon...although it was a Tuesday night so not that busy. 

There were two of us and I did not like at all how all the two person tables were placed, against the wall of the restaurant with very little space between the tables next to us. Therefore, anytime a server would walk by or a guest, I was either bumped in some way or had someone's butt in my face or had to move to avoid getting any of the above.

Our server was very nice, friendly and professional. I was about give 2 stars but up'd it one due to our wonderful server.  We started with some oysters, which were delicious.  After we finished the oysters it took about 30 minutes for our main dishes to come...not sure why since it wasn't crowded at all. I had the petrale sole and my friend had the salmon.  We also had the poutin.  All were just ok.  The sole had a strange BBQ like sauce that came with it. The salmon was slightly overcooked in my view. The poutin was not that great, the fries were extremely over-fried to a crunchy hard to eat texture.
