We ended the dinner sharing dessert, the gingerbread cake with some ice cream....omg WAAAY to sweet.  So sweet we could not even finish it. The cake was drench in some sort of simple syrup sauce that ruined the cake in my view.

Not sure if i would come back...it didn't impress me but also didn't offend me either.
author: Susan P.

description: Funky space with very tasty food. I had a lunch special which was Moroccan lamb with cous cous, it was light and amazingly well seasoned. Great service, and a fun space.
author: Jonah K.

description:
3 stars for this joint. Let me give you the quick rundown:

+ Great interior design- lots of brick , wood, candles that reminds of  some of the better places in West village- New York City
+ Small intimate setting: perfect for meetings with new clients/prospects
+ Friendly staff
+ Diverse menu ranging between $9-$30
+ Ideal downtown/ financial area location.

- Food is OK., I wouldn't say it is the best food ever but it definitely does the trick for lunch- I always have the seafood- scallops are good- Sole is a bit plain..could have used some fresh spices for an extra  kick
 Bread is simple and good
 Fries are old fashioned good.
Espresso drinks are good
- Staff can get busy at times and therefor not all too attentive to your table
-It can get super busy at times, making it extra stressful in a place like that- it is a small place.

Conclusion: great place if you are looking for a nice open area restaurant with great interior design. Food is good but not world class- It is pretty plain according to my taste.
author: Achraf S.

description:
I came here with a few friends on Nov21. One friend tried to make reservations, but no one answered the phone when she called. However it was not busy when we went and we were seated relatively quickly.

We ate:

"yellowtail tartare" - Why is this in quotes? Because they advertise yellowtail on the menu... yet they serve you regular tuna in the dish. Conversation with the waiter was as follows:
me "I'd like the yellowtail tartare"
server "Oh excellent choice the tuna tartare is very good."
me "wait, isn't it yellow tail?... hamachi right"
server "It is tuna"

I thought the guy was just confused, but no. It IS tuna tartare... not hamachi and therefore not really worth what they charged in my opinion. (That said, it was a different take on tuna tartare with the use of Asian pear.)

Poutine - Pretty good, I liked it. But it's hard to fail fried items with fat (i.e. cheese). The gravy was a bit salty

Autumn Salad - This was just ok to me. It was not bad, nor exceptional. Just fine, though it's something my mother would love to death.

Petrole Sole - This was nothing special, although everything was cooked well. There were these little sausage like things in it, which were salty though.

Tai Snapper - the sauce they used for this dish was excellent, as were the chanterelle mushrooms. I would say the mushrooms were the best thing at this restaurant, I would order a plate of just that! As for the fish itself, I enjoyed the crispy skin on top and it was cooked well. Overall, it was pretty good.

White polenta - I don't really like polenta, but I admit this was pretty tasty for poleta. The grana padano was good.

Short rib - The sauce was too salty... it was full of flavor though. The short rib was cooked well, the meat was very tender.

Overall... Salt House is just okay. The ingredients they use are fresh and the dishes are prepared well from a technical point of view. However, nothing screams special to me... and it is salty to boot! Maybe that's why it's called "Salt House?"
author: michelle l.

description:
You've been warned !

The restaurant will bend you over and give it to you good. You meanwhile will experience eye crossing, toe splaying pleasure.

Snacks-
MIXED NUTS. They used to be called warm nuts but people were laughing when they ordered.
OLIVES. Yum! like good for you and bitterly delicious.
PICKLED VEGETABLES. I love pickled shit. Crispy sour Veggies are a damn sight tasty.
 
Apps-
POUTIN. Gravy, cheese, potatoes, salt & pepper. Can you say decadent?..No? How about FAT ASS!
CRISPY SHRIMP. Crispy, firm, curled rounds of kick-ass seafood.
SPICY GREEN BEANS. Not bad, like the name says spicy, and green.


Entrees- 
FULTON VALLEY CHICKEN. This was awfully good. Crispy skin tender moist underneath, with wonderful flavor.
HANGER STEAK. When you order this medium rare it comes out rare. Like red and raw in the center, It was still good though.

Desserts-
COOKIE PLATE. This was foodgasmic. I almost turned furry and blue and changed my last name to monster.
CHOCOLATE MALT BAVARIAN. Creamy coco-eey 'bad for you' yummy stuff. Not too sweet...nice.

1 STAR removed for rude yuppie bar scene and crazy noise level.
author: Mark B.

description:
Brilliant evening.
Started with delicious oysters and a salad - as well as a 1994 Riesling (props to the people who put this wine list together).
Then we shared a number of dishes. The sole was excellent. The lamb shank was superb. The chicken was primo.
Very handsome space. Great staff - professional and accommodating.
author: Rich B.

description: Great food, but definitely on the pricey side. I had the beet salad with goat cheese burrata, which I really enjoyed. I also had the black cod, which was delicious but the portion was very small. I thought that the prices were high compared to similar restaurants in SF. I liked the ambiance and the service was very good.
author: Diana G.

description:
like the decor of the place, next time i want to sit up in the loft area and have a view looking down.

the food was pretty good, to be honest i was not wow'd. i had the pork chops and it was a bit bland and overcooked. the cheese fries were great but dont know if i need to pay $16 for that.

they did have delicious moscow mules which is a plus
author: Eden O.

description: Service was good. Food was ok. Great location , went dancing at harlot just next door. Very convenient for date night
author: Ken B.

description:
Considering the prices here, food was kind of mediocre. I'm used to small portion sizes, but even some of these seemed pretty minimal.

Beet salad - the other veggies on the plate were good though the beet purée/jello part was odd.

Scallops - onions and scallops were decent, though nothing to write home about considering they were $29.

Pumpkin Cheesecake - the crust was overly hard and didn't meld well with the rest.

Overall service was good, but at that price, I expected food to be fantastic and it was just ok.
author: Grace C.

description: I went during lunch with a group.  The food and serving size were good.  However, the service was lacking (i know lunchtime is busy but the server came to the table only two times: to get the orders and to deliver the check), and the food was pricey considering it was lunch.
author: Kelvin S.

description:
Another good restaurant in SOMA! 

Decor: 5 stars - I love any place with exposed brick walls. Plus I really dug the big lanterns that looked like drums.

Food: 4 stars - I enjoyed my pan roasted striped sea bass with oxtail and chanterelles. I didn't go wild over the "caramelized fall fruit" salad appetizer. The leaves were a bit too salty and spicy for my liking.
As for dessert, the dark chocolate bundt cake was so disappointing because it wasn't even moist! 

Service: 2 stars - Salt House needs to look into the pipeline of orders because right now it's not working. We waited a good hour for our main entrees. Our waiter also disappeared on us at times btwn our meals. 
-----------------------------------
Overall: 3 solid Yelp stars.

Sure, I'll try this place again because tonite was super busy and they did just open so maybe it was an off nite on the service.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Really great spot in my honest opinion.  Not quite sure why there have been so many mixed reviews to date.

Spot is easy to find right on Mission Street.  Setting is modern with an airy, artsy flair...kinda the same feel you get at NOPA.  Scene is bustling & diverse...Ranges from SOMA hipsters to stuffy FiDi suits.

Service is excellent.  Food however is even better.  To have a really great meal, start with the warm mixed nuts doused with truffle oil..get a few of their yummy drinks..proceed with the Poutin (aka gravy-covered fries..mmmm), Crispy Shrimp, Yellowfin Tuna, & Wild-Striped Bass..And finish strong with the Chocolate Malt Bavarian.

Do all of the above plus/minus some personal variations and you will be sure to walk out of Salt House as one happy foodie!
author: Justin L.

description: Dinner was good. Purely American cuisine. Make sure u get a few appetizers to share, since their entrees are European size. DELICIOUS chocolate cake, one of the best I've tried. Service was great, 5+. However, be sure to pay a pretty buck, it is expensive.
author: ForgetMeNot B.

description:
It's been sometime since I was last here so I figured it was worth a shot.  I must say things have improved since my last visit.

Staff is still great, wine list made huge leaps and bounds and it's a fun approachable list.  The food is good, the fries with short rib gravy is still on the menu (wish the fries were crisper). The braised short ribs were very good; I tried the chicken and it was well salted and moist -- over all it's still a cool place.
author: G R.

description: Probably the most forgettable burger I've had, though the margaritas were tasty. Everything overpriced. Gets cramped due to the layout, though the upstairs is good for larger parties/events.
author: Aaron M.

description: Interesting menu. Sophisticated but not trying to hard. Wonderful oysters. Great staff. Everyone at my table of four loved their meals and the experience.
author: Christian S.

description:
Yum, yum, yum!!!  Friend brought me here for an early birthday lunch.  OMG - one of the best meals I've ever had!  

We shared the crispy shrimp salad (the small comes with 4 shrimp, the large with 6).  It was so delicious and unique!  Wonderfully fried shrimp over a bed of green beans, with ham and almonds.  I don't know what kind of dressing it was, but it was almost like a sweet curry.  Very strange, but VERY good.  

For the entree, neither of us could resist the pork shoulder confit.  The pieces of pork are seared, so it's a crispy outside, and fork tender meat inside.  Wow.  And it's served over a white corn that's (for lack of a better term) almost like a risotto consistency.  It was amazing.

No room for dessert.  The portions are big, but they really do fill you up.

Washed it all down with a refreshing lemonade.    What a meal! 

I believe is place is from the same owners of Town Hall (another top fave of mine) and like Town Hall, it gets really loud in here, so just be aware, this isn't your quiet, romantic hideaway type place.
author: Denise M.

description:
Alright, I give up.
Salt House is just undeniably one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco and I'm going to have to update my review and give it 5 stars.

On any given night, they have a vast selection of truly fresh seafood.  EVERY SINGLE THING on the left side of their menu under "appetizers" is simply delectable and yields an exquisite experience in your mouth.  The right side of the menu is chock full of excellent fish and meats - and the other night having dinner w/ KK here, I noticed they serve white polenta as a vegetarian entree.

I heart polenta.  Given how much I love meat, it's really a huge compliment that I even considered ordering the polenta.

The crispy shrimp is a must-order dish.  Four perfectly cooked shrimps are accompanied by the most fascinatingly fragrant and delicious bunch of greens, including string beans, and doused in some amazing dressing.  Seriously, I could eat this every single day.
The other night, we shared the pork belly and oysters, too.  The Kumamoto oysters were as fresh and tasty as expected; the pork belly had KK moaning at the table.

I have never been to Salt House for lunch; KK had never been here for dinner.  He says the lunch was just "okay" - but the dinner, Yelpers, is fantastic.

The NY steak we shared as an entree was also perfection (I think; don't ask.).  The kitchen splits everything very generously, and the service is ALWAYS topnotch here.

Salt House is simply outstanding.

Just whatever you do, do not go outside in the middle of dinner for a smoke break.  Just don't do it.  ;-)
author: Grace K.

description:
Last week I was strolling down Mission Street when I noticed the Salt House and told my girl friend that I wanted to go there--and voila, this week a lovely young man took me there. Be careful what you wish for 'cause you just might get it. ;)

The Salt House is a manly restaurant: brick walls, hardwood floors, iron beams. Unfortunately, the food was not as cool as the contemporary setting. We began by sharing the St. Simone oysters--our server advertised them as medium, but they were just a little bigger than Kumamotos. Why can't all oysters by plump and creamy?

Next I had the potato and leek soup and the duck banh mi sandwich from the Dine About Town menu. I've actually never met a cold soup that I liked, but this vichyssoise was delicious! The crunchy taro chips and drizzle of olive oil complemented it well. The duck banh mi sandwich was good, but I'll let you in on a well-known secret: Saigon Sandwiches, roast pork-fancy pork-pate banh mi, $3.75, HEAVEN IN A HOAGIE! Chris had the halibut. It was crisp outside and moist inside, but man was it small. At least there was no way he was going back to work in a post-lunch food coma.

The Salt House is A-OK but it likely would've have left me salty had I shelled out money for it myself.
author: Liz T.

description:
Food was delish, I had the burger and it's going to be up there in my burgers of SF list.  I hadn't meant to eat a burger, but it just looked so tasty and it was juicy and the meat tasted especially fresh.  I didn't like the tomatoes that much and overall it was almost too juicy but that's better than too dry.

I had some of the salad my friend had as well which was quite good with nice flavor and fresh greens.
author: Gene X.

description:
Poutine! I finally got to try it, and it was everything I thought it would be. 

True, the fries were too salty, but overall it was very good. You definitely want to share a dish like this because it's too rich to eat alone: french fries covered with melted cheese, covered with short rib gravy. Wow. I'm not sure if it's the same type of Poutine you'd get in Canada, but that's okay. 

The other stuff Erin S. and I had was also good. We had a window seat, which allowed us to people-watch. For some reason, this stretch of Mission Street is a magnet for local sports heroes. Last time Erin S. and I had lunch two blocks away, we saw John Madden. This time, it was Joe Montana. Cool!
author: Raina S.

description: I have eaten here 4 times and every time the food was great, the service was good, the staff was friendly and the bathroom was clean.  This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Jan F.

description: The restaurant has a cool atmosphere. Great lighting and an industrial feel inside. Food was good but not overly impressed with anything we had. We had a few different appetizers to start. I had the cod for my main dish which I was pleased with. My husband had the steak and it was nothing special. Definitely not worth $35. I do recommend the s'more dessert however. That was a great ending to a mediocre dinner.
author: Valerie F.

description:
We had the scallops appetizer (should be a main course too!) was the highlight of the meal I think -- the scallops were cooked just right and they were dressed with this tasty sauce that incorporated corn and bacon -- can't beat that!  I had the chicken entree -- pretty tasty, and the marscapone pani cota was pretty tasty too.  The Grenache Spanish wine-by-the-glass was very complimentary to my meal - loved that!  

Service was good, ambiance was cool (check out the lamps above you with this cool, postcard rack deco -- very neat!), and I liked the people there -- business crowd but unpretentious, good combination.  I'll be back!

My bill+tax+tip = $56

Once-a-week dinner w/ Geraldine # 2
author: Maile N.

description:
The service was consistently off.  I wonder what the problem is behind the scenes.  This place would be great otherwise.

Examples:

Table not ready for our reservation when we arrived.
Slow to take order.
Slow to deliver drinks.
Bussers repeatedly trying to remove dishes while we were still eating.
Busser not leaving me my oyster fork while still eating oysters.
Half the staff looking either surly or disorganized, kind of wandering around.
Server forgot something.  Just one thing, but along with everything else, it added up.

Our main server and bartender were really nice and I feel bad writing this.  It was just lame to pay for a spendy and tasty meal, but be annoyed by sub-par service throughout that took away from the experience.

What is going on?  Is there an asshole manager that is making these people hate their jobs?  Are they getting stoned out back before work?  I don't know what it is, but something is amiss.  Note to owners of Salt House: investigate why your staff is being like this.  Make sure they have what they need so they are happier with their jobs and can work together better.
author: katie s.

description: The food was good, appearance was decent and clean, service wasn't bad. But it's extremely noisy in here and very crowded especially after-work hours. Two thumbs up for another great find in SOMA!
author: Shari S.

description:
Last time I was in town, this was my first meal after stepping on the plane, appropriately, this was my last meal in San Francisco before I ventured back home.  Tonight at around 530, I had a seat at the bar with a few of my buddies. Dustin with his creepy mustache was working the bar.  He was cool as hell.  He had great advice on the menu and was patience with my friends as we had taboo conversations occcassionally asking him for input.

But seriously, aside from great service from really cool folks, the food and the atmosphere here is banging.  The loft like space with its exposed beams, brick walls, and rustic lighting elements are both hip and rustic.  The bar stools werent the most comfortable but i'll giv'em a pass.     

For food, we sampled, both the Fanny Bay and the Kumamoto oysters, the Poutine, the Diver Scallops, the Tagliatelle with Bolagnese, the Rosemary Spatzel - al of which are small plates. All the dishes we sampled were great. Everything tasted fresh, dishes were all well seasoned and had great complimentry flavor profiles.

In my opinion, its a great option for lunch, after work drinks, and dinner in the SOMA.
author: Ben G.

description:
The food deserves 3.5-4 stars but something about my experiences here always puts the rating just a little lower. The dishes are well made and reasonably sized, but sometimes too salty...given the name and Town Hall background I guess I shouldn't be surprised. Maybe they just need to work on service kinks because the staff are a bit disorganized and our entrees took forever. I get the feeling the staff uses the "we're a new restaurant excuse" to skimp on service...even though most places are over eager when new...no we can't accomodate large groups, no there are no tables ever free, no you can't order something to go, no you can't sit at the empty tables until 5:30...
Overall, this place has good potential though.
author: Lainy C.

description:
A group of 5 went to Salt House for dinner on Friday. I want to say first and foremost, the food was delicious. However, there were a few circumstances that were undeniably gross and insulting. 

We showed up 5 minutes early for our reservation with an extra party. The hostess pitched a fit when we told her. In the end, they rotated a table and added an extra chair. Not a big deal considering the amount of money we spent.

The drinks and apps came quickly, and the foie gras was amazing. 
Right before our plates came out, we noticed a look come over one of our friend's faces. We looked to the open kitchen and watched as the head chef LICKED the spoon 4 difference times as he sauced 4 of the plates (one of which turned out to be mine). 
Let me preface this by saying, I do understand this is a nice restaurant and the chef wants to be sure his plates are going out perfectly. But for crying out loud- switch the spoon! 
When the plates came to the table, we mentioned this to the server who was mortified (but not surprised) and asked if I wanted mine re-plated. I didn't want to hold up the party and I'm not that big of a germ freak. 

My sister then flagged down the General Manager (whose massive amount of chest hair must have been a health code violation) and was completely rude and unsympathetic. He told us "Just to play devil's advocate, the chef wants to make sure his plates go out perfectly." Then he basically said, it was his kitchen and he could do what he wanted. Bad answer buddy. You work in hospitality. 

The server then came by and said dessert would be on the house. This was a nice gesture. However, when the bill came, it was certainly NOT taken care of. We pointed this out and she said that she could only comp. one of them. She never told us that. In the end, she took care of all of them, as she should have. She was a very nice girl and we were appreciative of her efforts. 
Moral of the story: Chef is filthy and no one cares. GM is useless and should be fired. Kate the server did a stellar job.
author: Laura M.

description: It took a very long time to get seated even though we had reservations. The food however was pretty good. The steak was a bit over cooked, but good enough that we didn't send it back.
author: Tu T.

description:
My girlfriend invited us to the salt house for our bi-monthly double night... we went ahead with making reservations and highly anticipated our first visit!

 Upon arrival, like any great restaurant in the city, the place was packed. Unfortunately, I'm assuming they sat all "important" people before the ones who actually called a few days prior to reserve a table.

  We ended up waiting  2.5 hours  (maybe longer) for our table, I'm assuming time flew by as much as 2 1/2 hours can with the company of close friends at the bar. After multiple complaints we were finally seated, my girlfriend had explained how upset she was so they tried to make it up to us with their finest bottle of Champagne which was a kind gesture- We are not exclusive foodies, just wanted to have a nice meal with friends.

Our server was a total sweetheart, she was very attentive and felt it was her job to make up for the non existent maitre d' ?

The food was delicious, It was my first time giving oysters a second chance.....Highly recommend the foie gras!

Really good food, nice servers/bar tenders. waiting 2.5 hours for dinner after making reservations..not cool!
author: Beta B.

description: Seriously the best meal I have ever had. The octopus was phenomenal! The gnocchi was the best I ever had, even the latte I ordered with dessert (the banana cheesecake was especially fantastic) was exceptional. I will be back every chance I get.
author: Erin S.

description:
Dinner Review 

I've been a fan of Town Hall.  So when the jackasses of Town Hall opened up Salt House, I had to try it.

It was a fairly mixed vibrant crowd on a Thursday night, from hipsters, yuppies, to a few groups of folks in suits and ties.  Too noisy for a romantic date, but definitely good vibe to catch up with friends.

To start, the wine list was just okay.  Although there were a few surprises on the list (the grenache and the like), I opted for a pinot from Oregon, just to be safe.  (The wine list at the restaurant was more extensive than the one on the website.)  

For appetizers, my friends and I shared the crispy shrimp and the baked oysters.  The shrimp really did not go well with ham (I removed the ham).  The oysters weren't exactly baked either -- it was baked bacon on top of raw oysters.  It was just too funky for my taste, even though I removed the bacon.  Thank goodness for that pinot to cleanse my pallet.

For entree, I asked the waiter to pick one between the halibut and the shellfish stew (they are not listed on the website menu).  She said, "Definitely go with the stew!"  And her recommendation was excellent.  The soup base for the stew was a light garlic sauce, with a hint of butter.  (I could almost taste the fat, but heck, it was too good to count the calories at this point.)  The portion was just right -- with two lightly-grilled scallops on top of a bed of mussels and clams.  It was just as delicious as the waiter described it to be.  Excellent. 

For dessert, we had the rhubarb pudding and the chocolate bar to share.  The rhubarb was a hit, the chocolate a miss.  But it really didn't matter at that point, as I was still savoring that creamy garlic stew...

My friends had the duck con fit and the halibut.  They liked their entrees, although I could tell they weren't as impressed with their food as I was happy with mine.  

Overall, I'd recommend to skip the appetizers, go straight to the entrees, and then hop back to Town Hall for that famous butterscotch...
author: Shirley F.

description:
After seeing this place always filled with people, I had to come here with my co-worker, as it was right next to our office. 

We got there around 12, and it was pretty empty. But within 15 minutes, the place was packed! 

We ordered the famous poutine for appetizer, and it was pretty good within the first couple of bites. The dish included fries with cheese and herbs. The server poured over hot gravy in front of us, which had bits of tender beef as well. It was my first time eating poutine, and it was an interesting combination. My favorite part was probably the beef bites; other than that, the fries didn't seem special, and everything felt too heavy after the first 3 bites.

We waited for about an HOUR before receiving our entrees, which was so ridiculous. My co-worker ordered the sole. I thought the sole didn't have flavor itself at all. The broth was a bit too oily for me, and didn't really compliment the fish at all. 

I ordered the pork shoulder and ribs. The ribs were extremely disappointing, as they were dry. There were no sauce really - it was only served with the leftover sauce from cooking it. Maybe because there wasn't excess sauce, the meat seemed dry? Doesn't really make sense, but I could only finish 1/3 of the ribs. The pork shoulder was a bit better. The pieces were way too small, but were tender. The pork shoulder was drenched in really salty sauce, and was complimented with jalapenos and this sweet white polenta. Not sure if I had polenta before, but it was pretty good at first bite. Afterwards though, it was overly sweet. Had to mix between the overly sweet polenta and the disgustingly salty sauce to get through about half of my pork shoulder. 

Finally, we ended with the pistachio macaron ice cream sandwich. The pistachio flavor was pretty good, and the macaron was nice and chewy. The fruits on the side was a bit too small and looked dry to me. Too bad the bottom macaron was drenched in white syrup, so it was, again, a bit too sweet for me.

Lastly, I wanted to note that the service was extremely terrible. Although our waitress always smiled at us, she was never attentive. She never even apologized for the extreme delay of our entrees. Our lunch ended up being TWO hours long, and we even saw the neighboring tables come and go before us. 

It's sad to say that my favorite dish was the dessert. With the poorly seasoned and cooked dishes, and the extremely slow/lack of service, I don't believe I'll be heading back to Salt House again.
author: Evelyn S.

description:
I knew when I finally got around to yelping it would be for an outstandingly great restaurant OR a ridiculously bad restaurant. Happily this is a 5 star review.
I was invited Salt House last Saturday night, kind of a girls night/birthday/reunion with 7 others. Everything about the experience was OUTSTANDING. Love the restaurant design and energy. The service was spot on, in spite of it being Saturday night and super crowded. The food is to die for, don't know if we just ordered the right things, repeat after me POUTINE, FOIS GRAS. Scallops were yummy, duck was yummy, Steak was cooked to perfection. Drinks were great, wine recommendations were superb. The desserts definitely blew my diet! All worth it! The only thing I might rate at 4 1/2 stars is the noise level, it gets loud, but I'm figuring a bunch of girls after a few drink were maybe part of the problem? LOVE THIS RESTAURANT!
author: Ann K.

description: I came for a work dinner and the service was good given that we were in a large group of ~20. I had the poutine which was good but how can you mess up fries with fatty gravy?? I order steak for dinner and it was cooked to the temp I wanted but was uber salty....very fitting I guess given that the restaurant is called Salt House! In any case, there are too many other great restaurants around for me to return.
author: Chris S.

description: Love this place!!! I have been several times and am always impressed with the food and service! Definitely better to make a reservation so you don't have to wait, there isn't a large bar area, but you could check out one of the watering holes in the hood! Oysters are fresh and tasty. Great wine menu!!
author: Derwood A.

description:
Salt House would be appreciated by a serious foodie (I'm not a foodie, but I still enjoyed it).  The menu is changed seasonally.  The decor is upscale yet gives the impression of coziness.  

I ordered the salmon ($31).  It was a small portion but beautifully done - the skin was grilled & crispy, while the inside was medium rare the way I like it.  I'm not a foodie but I definitely appreciate crispy fish skin (very few cooks do it well).  It was served in a bowl of pesto-ish sauce with a hint of lemon, with crisp beans.  I really enjoyed the sauce, and I used it to dip my bread.    If it had been less expensive, I would come back here again and again - the food was that good.  The crispy fish skin, the crispy beans, and that sauce really complemented each other well.

I went there with some colleagues on a Tuesday night and it was pretty crowded - I strongly suggest making a reservation.  We got there by 9pm, but there was still a decent late-night dining crowd.  By the time we arrived, there were only 2 orders of salmon & 1 pork chop available...so get there early!  

This place is expensive but good for a night out or if you are a foodie.  Really lovely, flavorful food with textures that complement each other.
author: Bee M.

description: The food here is always delicious, but it is a little loud for a meeting or lunch interview.
author: Gary K.

description:
Nice ambiance, but is the food intentionally too salty?

(I wish I were joking.)
author: B W.

description:
Thought it was a bit weird that they wouldn't seat us until EVERYONE in our party had arrived.  Finally after 15 minutes when our other party hadn't arrived, they allowed us to sit.

The shrimp salad was amazing and so was the sole.  

I'd probably give this place 4 for the food but customer service was a bit off.
author: Chaz N.

description:
The food at Salt House is mediocre. I don't know what everyone was raving about the poutine; but i find the gravy super salty. Crispy shrimp appetizer was fair. The flavors of the ingredients would probably be more pronounced if the dish was warm. Steak was tough and gamey, sauce was heavily salted. Striped bass was undercooked and not seasoned properly. Alaskan cod was somewhat decent but the cioppino broth was cold. Worse of all, the waitress charged us for cranberry back when we ordered shots of vodka. Unbelievable....

Overall, the food matches it's name, SALT. Food is definitely pricey and not worth a revisit.
author: Foodie F.

description: Good decent food, a bit over priced, but makes sense given location, portion sizes werent too big, but everything tasted good.  Staff was super nice and drinks were strong.  food was definitely saltaaaay, in a good way.
author: christopher h.

description:
Besides making us wait 30 minutes after our reserved table was supposed to be ready (an 8:45 reservation is already late!), the food was quite tasty.  The restaurant was much smaller than I expected, and apparently, the tables don't turn very quickly.

You don't see poutin on the menu very often...and I love me some poutin.  They were a little skimpy on the gravy (I thought it would be imploite to stick my finger in the gravy pitcher), but otherwise delish (especially the little beef bits in the gravy).  I couldn't decide between the cassoulet or the ribeye, but the waiter recommended the ribeye.  I don't know what you expect when you see the word "ribeye", but I expect a steak.  What I got was more like a little nugget, morsel...probably no more than 3 oz. of steak.  It was tasty though a little small.  I was envious of my friend's cassoulet; the crispy duck skin (which I got a small taste of) was yummy.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I'll admit, the sole reason for my visit was to try the poutine. 

Poutine, for those of you who don't know, is french fries gone wild. Topped with gravy and cheese curds, who can resist the sound of that? 

While I found their poutine tasty, swimming in a lovely bath of shortrib gravy, they don't use cheese curds, but shredded cheddar cheese. As a result, these weren't much different than chili-cheese fries... although I do love me some chili-cheese fries. 

We also ordered their crispy shrimp appetizer, which was delicious, although it was more salad than crispy shrimp. The entrees tasted great - I got the steak and he got some kind of fish - but the portions were teeny tiny. Fortunately, we were filled up on crispy shrimp and chili-cheese fries ... er, poutine, so it didn't matter, but I would have been pissed and hungry if we had skipped the appetizers. 

The space is cool, the waitstaff efficient and unobtrusive, and patrons were attractive. But while I found everything tasty, ultimately, Salt House didn't satisfy my soul.
author: Jasmine W.

description: I had the chicken katsu sandwich (with guacamole) which was a bit spicier than I expected, but it was pretty good.  The restaurant, however, was a bit too loud for me to hold a normal conversation.  Two other minor things (a) the waitress offered me a separate salad as an appetizer and though I turned it down, then found that my sandwich came with a salad on the plate (I would have been unhappy if I had ordered the salad appetizer) and (b) they don't serve coffee, just Americano.  The food was good, but I probably won't go again.
author: H. H.

description:
Great food, great service, great decor!
We have eaten here twice and loved it both times. Once was a romantic dinner for two, the other was for a group of 18! Both times, they really pulled out all the stops!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Really, really, good beef! They can "crust up" a steak that's still tender on the inside, or if you want a tasty, juicy burger, go to the Salt House. Parking sucks and it's in that dicey section near the demolished Transbay Terminal, but you'll be well protected.

If you're freaked out by tables that are a little too close together and a feel of a communal beer hall, then you probably aren't going to enjoy your meal as it can get really noisy, especially if you're anywhere near the open kitchen.

If you can tolerate the noise and intimate distance between tables, then you'll enjoy a great meal at the Salt House. Reservations are strongly encouraged. Don't just pop up like you're going to McDonald's.
author: Adrienne A.

description:
Salt House delivers, with finesse, pretty much everything we've all come to expect of San Francisco restaurants.  

Inventive takes on old favorites, fresh ingredients, ironic flair like a skull and crossbones on the water carafes, casually competent service, and decor that is hip in a non-threatening way.  They even had the requisite beet salad on the menu (which was, by the way, fantastic).   

All in all it was a solid delivery, but there was nothing that made it really stand out in my mind--other than the noise level, which was so high most of your conversations will consist of "what'd-you-say" and "hrm?"
author: Dana S.

description: Pretty expensive for the dishes that are being presented. Some dishes were too salty, others not salty enough.
author: Shang S.

description: Still the worst lunch experience in Downtown. Inattentive waitstaff. Arrogant and impotent management. Barely above average food.
author: Aaron B.

description:
4 stars for the food.  1 star for the service.  I went on a Friday night and we waited forever for our server, Clemente, to greet us.  Once he did, my friend had a fly in his drink and the server didn't apologize or offer a new one free of charge.  After we asked for a taste of wine before committing to a glass, he brought out a bottle.  Totally flakey.  On our bill we were charged for a whole bottle of wine and the drink to replace the one with the fly wasn't free!  We changed the bottle charge to a glass.  But the service was so bad I don't think I'll be going back.  At that price, the service should be much better!

I had been for lunch once too and the service was really slow.  It was like we didn't exist for 20 minutes before someone noticed we wanted to order.
author: Jill R.

description: Came here for a few drinks, and had a great time.  The bartender was super nice, the ambiance is classy but still casual, and not too crowded but still lively for a Sunday night.  Will definitely come back again.
author: Mel G.

description: Went here during the week for a (very early) happy hour outing the day before midterm exams. I was very impressed. This place is absolutely not what it looks like from the outside. I go to law school exactly across the street from here and I had never noticed it before! I really liked the happy hour deals - included both drinks and amazing food. The service was great, they were on top of their game, asking if we wanted more rounds or how everything was. I think I will become a regular!
author: Dodi G.

description:
Really surprised how popular this place is.  Had a group dinner and the food was really bad.  Poutine was flavorless, chicken wings were weird and not tasty at all, several people had to send back their meat bc it was so rare that it was still cold.
Service was also not great.  The waitress seemed confused and harried.
author: Em C.

description: Awesome atmosphere. Attentive but not over the top service. Seafood dishes were a real treat. Salads were disappointing not in taste but in value. Wine list was excellent, both by the glass and the bottle. I would definitely go again.
author: Roger G.

description: Average, surprisingly. The service was mediocre; our waitress didn't know much about the menu and didn't come around very much. The menu was ok, and the food average at best. Overall, rather disappointing.
author: Firas A.

description:
I went to Salt House last month and have been slow to post my review of it. Based on a friend's recommendation, I stopped by after work one evening. The place was quite busy, I was alone, so I went without a reservation. Luckily I got a spot at the large communal table in front of the bar. Reservations are recommended unless you are not in a hurry. The atmosphere of the restaurant is quite nice, very lively and the staff are all very friendly. The mezzanine level adds a cool vibe, but it doesn't extend across the entire building. I did feel bad for the people crammed up against the window looking outward onto the street, anyone who wasn't petite might feel a bit claustrophobic.

Now onto the food, the Veal Sweatbreads were calling to me. Pan friend sweatbreads, with high end smoked bacon chunks with sunchokes and rosemary honey. A lot of different textures, there was a definite smokiness to the whole dish, but the honey and richness of the sweatbreads all married well together. I paired this with a white wine by the glass, the 2003 Slovenian wine Movia, which is a Ribolla Gialla blend. This wine was oxidized intentionally and I would honestly say not for everyone. Personally, I felt the pairing was excellent as you need a strong white with good weight and flavors to hold up to such a starter. Wine geeks will love the wine, non-winos stay away. A very interesting wine to be served by the glass.

For the main course, I went with the braised short rib with a bone marrow crust. This dish on paper sounded delicious and even looked the part. I did find that the seasoning was underwhelming to say the least. Nothing worse than great ingredients used to make a dish that just needs a bit more salt. There were a number of interesting reds by the glass that I wanted to try, I was looking at the 96 Chianti Classico, but based on the servers recommendation I went with the Washington State Cab Franc, 2009 Wines of Substance. The wine was the highlight over the food, there was no happy marriage of flavors. The wine was decent and good for a by the glass selection, but nothing I would run out and buy. I will stick to the Loire Valley for my Cab Franc samplings.

No room for dessert, otherwise I would be 400 lbs. The evening started out great, I really liked the starter and the wines by the glass are interesting for winos of all levels. I will give Salt House another shot, but you can't under season high quality meat, especially when you add bone marrow on top of it. If I could I would give them 3.5 stars.
author: Robert V.

description:
It was packed to the teeth during lunch, but Salt House was legit. It's a great place for lunch in the fidi, or a dinner downtown. The waitstaff could take awhile to get to you, but the space was nice and Salt House provided a pleasant break from the monotony of grab-n-go fidi lunches.

I got the burger, which was pleasantly quite juicy and well cooked, served simply with cheese and a leaf of butter lettuce, just as I like it. Make sure you call ahead of time to make a reservation.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Great food in a beautiful setting (exposed brick, blond wood lampshades, don quixote painting)

You must have the poutine. We loved the wine by the carafe -- white on a rare warm day in SF. I had the lamb with a ricotta gnocchi (one giant creamy blob) and my friend had the rib eye. Perfectly done and I can't wait to eat it for leftovers.  For dessert, you must get the rubarb tart with lavender ice cream!  The "fudge bar" was rich, downturn turned uptown.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Checked out Salt House for a second dinner after Coco500.  Definitely a cool space and popular for a reason.  There's been a ton of reviews, so I'll keep this one short.

Pro's
Great space, always happening, kitchen open-late, creative wine list, fun desserts, Acme bread, and great service

Con's
Food isn't always up to par.  Crispy shrimp was anything but crispy, the poutine was too salty.

Overall, I like the food better at Town Hall better, but I like the space and location better at Salt House.  And I think that solid service makes up for some of the short-comings with the food here, so I'll be back.
author: Peter L.

description:
Great, fresh ingredients and solid option if you're eating downtown.

Had a spring pea with pickled ramps appetizer that was excellent. I also had the ling cod which was a great pan-friend piece of fish. I definitely like the bright, open atmosphere and the food was solid. I'm usually not a fan of New American cuisine but the ingredients were really fresh and prepared flawlessly. 

At the end of the day, I would definitely go back.
author: Kenneth K.

description:
Really wonderful place. Perfect spot to bring my mom for a little mother-daughter catch up time and a bit of celebration to boot.

First off, the service here is always spot on. They really know how to treat their customers, from the easy wine pours at the bar (with a quick check for those waiting for a table) to the carefully thoughtful table service. You won't go without water, you'll get real menu recommendations and you hardly have to glance around the room before staff is at your side. 

On our most recent visit we indulged in a dozen delicious oysters to start the meal. Kumamoto and miyagi were tasty, though the Fanny Bay won out as a favorite. Plus, the mignonette came with a spoon thankyouverymuch so there was non of that desperate forking at a small bowl of vinegar that often occurs. My dayboat scallops on a bed of sunchokes, brussel sprouts and delectable mini-mushrooms as an entree was perfect. Since I had eaten recently, this nice light seafood meal left me satiated but not full. A good compromise. Though for a hungrier belly - definitely try the poutine. So heavy but so worth it. 

Our champagne and wine were all easy choices, picked from a varied yet wonderful list of California options, though the list is extensive enough to include all major vine regions for your palate. 

Whether it's a date, a family occasion or just a treat - I'm happy to say that Salt House is always a solid choice. Plus, if you feel like a going all out after dinner just swing around the corner to Harlot and dance off all those poutine-calories!
author: Jane K.

description:
Best pork loin I have ever had in a restaurant. Most restaurants overcook and this was done perfectly! 

Service was great, décor very SF. Highly recommend
author: Renee J.

description:
One word comes to mind - blah.  Salt House is unsalted. Nothing great about the food, so-so service, hard to get reservations during lunch time.  We end up going here a lot for lunch meetings since it is located really close to work.  

The only thing I enjoy is the décor.  It makes you take a 2nd look every time you pass this place.
author: Anoo L.

description:
It's been several months since I've been to Salt House, but I felt like I should go ahead and give it a review.

We had a reservation and arrived on time but still had to wait about 15 minutes for our table so we just grabbed a drink at the bar while waiting. All in all, the service, presentation, and food were very good. However, my date and I were at a small two top table and it did get quite crowded with all the plates we had on there. We shared the crispy shrimp and pickled vegetables for the appetizer. For the main course I remember it being a hard decision, but I went with the gnocci dish (I no longer see this listed on there menu which is a shame because it was VERY good). I had a glass of the house cab which went well wish everything I ate. We didn't get desert because we were both pretty full and in a hurry to meet up with his friends, but the desert menu sounded great and next time I go I'll be sure to try something (the chocolate malt bavarian or the carrot cake both sound great!).
author: Krista S.

description:
We went threre for Dine About Town and found out that was only for lunch.  Our bad. Abyway we had the Poutine and it was OK but something I would expect to get at a Milwaukee Brewers game and the gravy wasn't anything special.  Pretty heavy so I laid off to enjoy my $30 entree.  I had the scallops and she had the chicken.  Scallops were good and her chicken was better.
Had a couple overpriced glasses $11 of some red wine...forget what though.

The service was a little slow at the beginning but was good after that.

This is a one-time visit for me.  The decor and the floors/celings/beams were interesting.
author: Mark M.

description:
I had such an excellent dinner at Salt House last night, I didn't wait the normal 3-4 weeks I usually procrastinate before writing a review. Our group of five was seated just after 8 at a table under the stairs near the front of the house. I ordered a Makers Old Fashioned (more on this later) and the ladies chose a bottle of white wine. Service was friendly but not overbearing, with a wine guy opening our bottle and a cocktail server bringing the drinks. Our food server took time to explain several dishes to us and gave us plenty of time to choose. Our table was never without delicious baked bread and butter. 

For apps, I had the tagliatelle with rabbit bolognese-amazing. This was some of the tastiest "pasta with meat sauce" I've had since Il Mulino in NYC. I had to pace myself with the portion which was on the smaller side. My friends had the crispy shrimp, halibut, and some salad that I tried and loved as well. 

I ordered the steak for dinner and thoroughly enjoyed it. You get 5-6 thick slices of beef, veggies, potatoes, and an added gift of a few ounces of a tender cut of beef (short rib, I presume). The chef prepared it to perfectly medium rare. I also tried the pork chop and liked it, though I'm not a huge pork chop fan.

Now, sufficiently stuffed,  back to the Makers Old Fashioned. We decided to have drinks with dessert and I re-upped for an OF. The cocktail server brought me the drink in a glass that was easily 1.5-2 times larger than the previous drink. I immediately dubbed it a cocktail worthy of Ron Burgundy or Don Draper and thanked the server. She said the first drink should have been this size, apologized, and removed it from our bill. This may be the first and only time a restaurant apologizes for not bringing you a larger drink. Oh, and for dessert we had a fruit crisp which everyone at the table complimented for it not being too sweet.

Overall, a dinner I'll remember for a long time.
author: Jonathan G.

description: I love San Francisco and I was excited to go to this place.  This was featured in a food magazine- I think- so as a foodie it was on my hit list.  Went there for a business lunch and the place is hipster cool.  The food was really good.  I had the chicken cesar salad.  The chicken was nicely grilled and had a nice smokey char.  The salad itself was not overly doused with dressing (which i hate).. We also got the fresh roasted nut.. they are Da Da BOMB.COM!!! Highly recommended!!  This is a definite return place in my book.
author: John S.

description:
Oh my gawd those fries! I'm still dreaming about those freaking gravy fries! 

I saw those suckers on the appetizer menu and just HAD to have them. And seriously, I want to recreate that shit at home. They're almost better than queso fries... yeah, I know. I never thought I would ever say that.

We also tried the duck appetizer. Small, but very well cooked and quite tasty. Definitely meant for one or two people, but we somehow made it work with 5 of us. The bread is a little tricky if shared, because gripping that sucker with two hands is kind of off-putting.

For an entree, I chose the sole. It came with clams and mussels in a very flavorful, rich and a bit buttery sauce. I ladled it up like soup and it paired well with the perfectly pan-fried fish and steamed shellfish.Warning: it may not look like much at first, but I had a hard time finishing it off so don't judge the book by its cover.

The service was spot on. We rolled in at prime lunch hour without a reservation, and she fit us in no questions asked. Our server was very sweet and made sure she was there when needed and gone when not. Honestly, it would be a favorite lunch spot of mine if I lived in SF.
author: Nikki B.

description:
Since it was on my must try list for awhile it was time I hopped in here to see the hype.

Walking into the restaurant gives you a loft/old world ship like feel to it. Very cool. 

Our bread comes via fish n chips style on brown butter paper and a nice ramekin with butter. Nothing like good soft yet crispy fresh bread. Love it.

For an app my date and I had the Crispy Shrimp with spicy greens beans, Serrano ham and almonds. So delectable and flavorful. The shrimp were cooked perfect and the spiciness of the green bean were a nice compliment to the dish.

We ordered the Salmon and the Short ribs for our main course and neither were disappointing. Since the menu changes frequently its difficult to say you will have the same dish and i was not able to recall up the details. See pics

Opted out on dessert. but definitely on my list of 'I'll be back again!".
author: Dave S.

description:
This place holds a special place in my heart for a couple of reasons:

1.  It is in the same building where I've worked for 3 years.

2.  I had my first date here with someone really special and has subsequently led to an awesome past year for me.

Beyond that, they always have a really good oyster selection, well crafted cocktails, awesome bread, and various delicious main entree dishes on their menu that fluctuate with the seasons.  And great poutine as well.

Its a solid bet when you want a great, not too formal fine dining experience.  Also, they have a private-ish upstairs area that is great for a secluded, romantic meal or a large private party as well.
author: Genevieve M.

description: Great place to hang out and have drinks.  Cool atmosphere- very mellow.  Bar and standing area is small -biggest downside.  Otherwise bartenders are very friendly - cool place to checkout for sure.
author: Josh V.

description:
Salt House had some high points, but overall I'd say it was not the most consistent.  As many people have noted, the poutine is exciting, especially to a Californian-through-and-through like me.  I actually really liked the poutine a lot, and couldn't help but keep on eating it.  The sharp white cheddar on fries with gravy was a delicious combination.

But the fish was overcooked, and the "crispy" fried shrimp was in a breading that was so soggy that our party left the last two shrimp on the plate.  Now, I don't know about you, but if there's halfway decent shrimp on the table, you'll have to restrain me from finishing them all.

It was also a little unfortunate that my fish dish was about a third smaller than all the other dishes people in my party ordered (including the other fish option...).

Salt House has a beautiful space, and some of the food is done well, but slow service and inconsistent performance mean I probably won't be back any time soon.
author: David W.

description: I've eaten here twice.  Once for lunch (had the fried chicken sandwich) and dinner (pork loin) and both times it was great.  A little pricey, but the food was top notch.
author: Ed G.

description:
Let me start with the ambience. Excellent! Now to the food, I came here on a Saturday night for dinner and sat at the bar. Had a couple of glasses of wine, my friend had a cocktail all of which were absolutely up to par. So far so good. Ordered an appetizer , the poutine, that was french fries and gravy. I am not a big fried food person but my friend really liked it so i will go for a plus there. Now i come to the strange part, we ordered our food, a steak for me and for some reason it took a good 45 minutes to an hour to get. The bar topped off our drinks for free due to the delay. When the food finally did come it was cold. My friend found her food passable but considering the prices passable just does not cut it. 

This is the part that I thought was outstanding and saves the place from a two star. I sent my steak back politely indicating that it was just not good and told the waiter that i did not want it (I had to run for another appointment) but would just settle the check. This is when the hostess came up with the steak redone in a to go box and asked me if i would like to take it to go. I said no. I was pretty done at that point. The hostess then went ahead and comped the food AND the drink. This was done without me asking or even suggesting the same. As i told the hostess, maybe they were having an off night but the fact that they made up for it at the end shows a certain level of class. I will probably try them again and hopefully the food will match the rest.
author: Ravi K.

description:
Dinner was mouth-wateringly amazing! 

We started with the Poutine and Warm Olives. Now in case you have never had Poutine....it is french fries covered in gravy and cheese and it is delicious. This was only my second time trying the dish but it was spectacular; my first time was at Wayfare and was not oober impressed although it was tasty. 

My friend and I shared the New York Steak & the Napa Chicken which were both cooked perfectly and paired with great sides. If I had to pick between the two, I would say go for the steak. Everyone around us was also ordering it and had  the same reaction as we did...happily full bellies. 

We also ordered the dessert item on the menu, blackberry something or other. It takes about 20 + minutes to cook so you have to order it while you order your dinner. I am personally not a big dessert person but it was good. I'd say definitely get it, might as well get the full experience that Salt House has to offer. 

Overall a great meal, good service, and I will be back for more of those artery clogging fries!
author: Amanda R.

description: Excellent Californian style restaurant. Good as well as fur business than for a romantic date!
author: Yosr N.

description:
Be careful what you read on yelp!! We have been visiting Salt House since its opening and have had only great memories!! 

We just dined there Thursday and from the moment we entered the door we were greeted with warmth and hospitality - especially from Jake, the manager. Our server, Rachel, was delightful and even paired wines with our dinner choices. The food was well-seasoned and tasty - always plated well. The appetizer options are unique and always fun to try!

I highly recommend Salt House and you will enjoy the food and the vibe of this restaurant!!
author: Jan H.

description: Went with larger group for exs bday. good service. Amazing gazpacho.  Got drunk and nothing stood out besides the gazpacho.
author: Kasey H.

description: Came here for a work lunch which is way different from the usual dives we go to.  The prices didn't rock my socks off and the food was good too.   Poutine was good and actually had pieces of meat in the gravy,  im a big meat eater so you know I was happy about that!  Burger was good but I felt like I could of gone any where else for that.  And for lunch service was good.
author: Rossi C.

description: Great customer service! I was delighted to have some warm bubbly to go with the poutine. Didn't feel inclined to order any entree as I remember a prior visit was exponentially better when they served foie gras!
author: Eda L.

description:
Had dinner here with a few friends and have nothing but good things to say.  I've been here a few times prior but haven't gotten around to a review.

Amazing food.  We ordered a selection of oysters and then shared some small plates to start out.  The yellowfin tartar was the standout for me; fresh combination with melon and a bit of peppery radish.  I had the polenta for the main, which was beautiful.  So flavorful and indulgent, without being too heavy.  

The space is gorgeous - warm, elegant and a little sexy with the uber-flattering lighting.  Service was top notch, there when we needed something but not intrusive.  

p.s. the upstairs space works well for larger groups, if you wanted to host a dinner.
author: Lena J.

description:
The staff and the atmosphere is nice. I recommend making reservations if you decide to dine here.

This place wasn't a bad experience.. it's just I would taste the food and be reminded that I've had better. 

The likes list:
-Vernita and I shared the crispy shrimp appetizer. Our server brought it out as a split order and that was a nice touch.
-the halibut.. perfectly cooked.

The okay list:
yellowfin tuna (..and the table next to us had this too but they had a larger serving. Thumbs down, consistency.. thumbs down)  
bread pudding dessert

Dislike:
The mojito was terrible. I couldn't even drink it nor could Vernita so it was returned.
author: O M G.

description: It's a good place for lunch.  We had the Poutine, Catalan Mussels  and chicken confit.  All 3 were good except for the poutine.  I was expecting more because of the hype but I ended underwhelmed.    It's an ok place to go.  it's not disappointing but it's nothing great either.
author: Cj P.

description:
Dear Salt House,

I was charmed by your decor but horrified by your service. We had to wait almost 1 hour for your dinner dish. People who ordered after us got their meals before us, I think I went through 2 or 3 servings of your chewy bread.

And why? Your waitress informed us that the chicken was cooked in a very delicate manner which requires at least 45 minutes.. or someone missed our order. That still doesn't fulfill the full hour gap of wait we had for food.

The food itself was tasty, portions a tad small, but very overpriced and not worth the value. Even if cooking such chicken takes 45 minutes, please warn us next time.

The waitress was we had was very inattentive and realized that she had lost our service made no effort to make it up. The bus boy on the other hand tried hard, and we ended up slipping him tip money that he well deserved and not the waitress.

-Ed
author: Ed T.

description:
My fiance and I tried Salt House on Friday night.  Despite being really busy, we were seated right away with our 8:00 reservation.  The service was a little slow throughout the rest of the night, but we were not in a hurry so it didn't matter.

The only real downside was when I ordered sparkling water and it came completely flat.  The waitress quickly made up for it though, and gave us a new bottle.  

We had the crispy shrimp appetizer, winter salad, & petrale sole.  They also brought out Acme bread to start and who doesn't love that?  :)  The food was all good, especially the shrimp.  We would definitely recommend.  We thought the wine selection was a little limited...there's a ton of stuff on the list, but we didn't recognize most of it (imports primarily).
author: Kim D.

description:
Loved the decor. It has an unpretentious familiar feel with rustic wood tables, over sized chandeliers, and small upstairs loft seating area. We had a table near the kitchen and enjoyed watching wait and kitchen staff prepare the meals--it didn't hurt that everyone employed by Salt House is on the hot side of the hot-or-not scale.

Our gracious server brought us delicious Acme bread as we decided on a wine. When we didn't like our first pick, he was happy to help us choose another. Even though it was his first day at Salt House, I couldn't tell. 

We shared the crispy shrimp (my favorite dish of the night) and burrata plate. Each of my girlfriends had a fish dish: Red Snapper, Sole and Sea Bass. Of the three I liked the savory Red Snapper with sweet eggplant and the lightness of the Sea Bass with green onions. All of the fish tasted a bit dry/overcooked (but maybe I'm confusing it with too salted, see next paragraph). The blondie was dry and forgettable. 

One thing is that all the dishes were a bit salty. I feel like I should assume they'd use salt given the name, but sometimes good things go too far. I'd be happy with less salt on all of the dishes (especially the burrata). Great spot overall in terms of ambiance, service and drinks, but a little pricey for the food quality. I think they have a few things to work out still.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: came here with a group. The service wasn't that great, the oysters were YUMMY. But the food I could have found better.  It was certainly over priced.
author: Ting B.

description:
Fabulous dinner in the quieter part of SOMA.  It was pretty empty when we were there, but then again, it was a Sunday, so I guess people may have been glued to the couch after watching football that day.  Anyway, for apps, we got the crispy shrimp---fried goodness served over some mildly spicy green beans, and the smoked halibut which was tasty as well.  The main course of chicken definitely didn't disappoint.  My dining partner seemed pretty happy with his striped bass---so happy that he gobbled it down before being able to offer me a bite (oh well, I was full from everything else anyway).  The dessert of the chocolate stout dacquoise was pretty darn heavenly.  The service was wonderful, with a very knowledgeable waiter who was very friendly (but not in your face), and obviously took pride in his job.

Overall, I would actually give this place 4.5 stars (I'm stingy with my 5-star reviews).  Definitely a place I would go back to to try more of their deliciousness.
author: Danielle B.

description: killer wine list. solid food. great service with character and charm. perfect for shaking off that work day.
author: JenCat S.

description: Loved the experience and the food was great. Bruschetta was excellent. Pepper appetizer was not great. Entree was crispy chicken sandwich. Big portion with a small salad. We went on lunch with co workers. The service was very attentive but the main entree took a while. Overall great place to celebrate !
author: Eastbay F.

description:
Overall, Salt House is a great restaurant. The place is well-designed (albeit a bit tight) and the service is phenomenal. The food has its ups and downs, but when it's good, it's DAMN good.

There's something about the way Salt House is designed that makes you feel comfortable -- it's a fancy restaurant, but possesses casual elements reminiscent of a local gastropub like Monk's Kettle or a brewery like 21st Amendment. Feels very akin to one of my favorite restaurants in the city: NOPA. We went on a Saturday night and it was packed with older, business-casual patrons -- loud, lively, and bustling with energy.

On to what really matters: the food. Our table of 4 decided to share 5 appetizers and 1 main entree, which was the perfect amount of food and gave us an opportunity to try a lot of different items on the menu. For the appetizers, we ordered the Poutine (gravy fries), Crispy Shrimp, Yellowtail Tartare, Asparagus w/ Pork Belly, and the Foie Gras plate. 

The Poutine was good -- very nice touch with short rib gravy (with little chunks of short rib), but it definitely could have been a bit less salty. Taking the restaurant's name into consideration, I assume the extra salt is probably on purpose. 

The crispy shrimp wasn't very good at all. To be completely honest, the fried shrimp (4 small pieces for $14) tastes exactly like the ones that you get from Panda Express or some hole-in-the-wall Chinese fast food restaurant. The green bean salad they provide in the middle is good, but not enough to justify the exorbitantly-overpriced dish.

The yellowtail tartare wasn't very good either. The chunks of yellowtail weren't very fresh and it was mixed in with too many other fruits and chunks of celery that completely overpowered the fish. Stay away from this one.

The asparagus w/ pork belly was awesome. The aspargus is perfectly grilled and the pork belly was nice and tender.

The foie gras was definitely the best dish of the night. Two types of foie gras: cured pate style and seared style. The cured foie gras was incredible -- silky, creamy, and packed in so much of that foie gras flavor. It goes well with the jelly, but don't put too much jelly in the bite, because you don't want it to overpower the foie gras. The seared foie gras was good, but not great. The seared duck salad that comes in the middle of the dish was awesome.

We also ordered a plate of the braised short rib, which was really tender and nicely cooked.  The strawberry tart for dessert was a great finish to the night, with fresh strawberries and a delicious balsamic glaze.

Overall, I really enjoyed my dinner at Salt House -- great  food, nice ambiance, delicious house wines (get the house cabernet), and attentive servers. Stick to the good dishes and you'll have a sweet night out.
author: Roy C.

description: Came here for dinner with a group of friends. I ordered the beehive drink but with vodka instead of tequila, it was ok. For my second drink I ordered the pomaretto which was really good! We asked for the bread that is brought to the table to be warmed up but the bus boy completely ignored us and the waitress said she would but came back with cold bread again. Whatever, that's fine. On to dinner now. I wanted to order the salmon but they were out unfortunately. So instead I ordered the sole which wasn't to my liking at all. There was no mention of it being breaded on the menu and it really lacked flavor. I tried my friend's NY steak and the meat wasn't tender at all. My other friend ordered the chicken plate and once she got it we realized there was pork on it which she can't eat because of her own dietary restrictions. She told one of the waiters and he made her feel horrible for mentioning it and essentially saying that she was at fault for not mentioning it. Umm it's not mentioned on the menu that there's pork anywhere in the dish! I don't eat cheese, eggs, and some other things so am I supposed to mention that every single time I order something? No. Ingredients are listed on the menu as any normal restaurant has it. And if there is a problem, you don't make the customer feel bad about it. They did end up taking it back and throwing in some potato chips for her to munch on while the plate was remade, but the way it was handled was very unprofessional. Overall the place looks nice, but the menu needs to be completely re-analyzed since it's not descriptive and is missing key components to it. Some of the staff also needs to be retrained. Our own waitress was nice, but the bus boys and that one other waiter were horrible.
author: Shabnam J.

description:
Stand back Michael Minna and Gary Danko.  

Town House is going up and to the right.  My wife and I joined her cousin and husband for dinner and quite simply were "blown away" by our dinner at Salt House.

Rarely do you find a balance of bold entrees, exceptional service and innovative flavors the reach a harmony as they do at Salt House.

First, the entrees, braised short-ribs and fulton valley chicken were fantastic, although the desserts were off-the-charts.  I highly recommend the toffee option.  The wine selection was exceptional, we found a delightful Sauvignon Blanc from a hot Healdsburg winery, Teira Vineyards.  Perfect for the evening.

Gretchen was our server, courteous, thoughtful and gifted with the ability to appear at exactly the right time with the right range of options. Kudos to Doug and the team for managing some exceptional team of professionals.

I highly recommend Salt House for a business dinner where you want to show visitors an innovative side of San Francisco dining, a group of friends celebrating a dinner or in our case, our anniversary.

Next time I've got a birthday, anniversary or special occasion, I'm driving by Boulevard, taking an express past the Fifth Floor and headed back to Salt House!
author: John G.

description:
Yes, we've experienced better, from here, actually.  Over the years, we've eaten here about a dozen times, the last time being about a year or so ago.  We've always had fond memories of the food we've had here.  Tonight, however, will not be one of those times.

My partner and I came here looking for small bites tonight and ordered four appetizers between us.  We ordered the Poutine, Kampachi Crudo, Heirloom Chicories and Sea Snails & Frog Legs.  Of the 4 dishes, the one that I think is still on par with what I expected from them is the Frog Legs.  It has chewy and tender consistencies and the sauce was outstanding.  The Poutine was good enough but more like a diner food item and maybe should have been on the separate menu containing the choices of burgers.  The Kampachi fish has something that tasted like soft bones in the middle of the slices that was not pleasant when you bite into them.  Perhaps whoever was cutting the fish for this dish should spend some time with a sushi chef for at least a few hours.  The Chicory salad, at $16, mainly consisted of frisees and radicchios.  But Adam, our waiter, immediately offered to take the dish back when we complained and we chose to replace it with the beet salad, a salad that was truer to the menu description.  

So, good service, beautiful restaurant but disappointing dishes.  i'll be back, but not too soon...
author: Yvette F.

description:
If you really really like me but know that I'll get drunk and embarass you, me, and your friends, it's probably best not to take me to Salt House after a day of boozing at Zeitgeist followed by gallons of Irish coffees followed by several bottles of wine at Universal Cafe and a little nekkid swimming in the St. Regis pool (in front of a family of Dutch voyeurs and their children...but that's a story for a different kind of website entirely). 

When all is said and done, Salt House comes through in a pinch no matter what your state of mind, dress, or sobriety. Once again, I'll give the beet salad a 10 any day and their wine list is delish. Did I mention we were able to get a table super easy at around 10 p.m. on a Sunday? The Euros I was with seemed to dig on it and the waiter did a decent job of translating my slurred speech. What a sweetheart. 

At the end of the day, the oysters were a huge hit and sharing a bunch of little things that were all equally tasty was entirely satisfying. Plus two bottles of wine for three. I imagine we were a delightful bunch. Salt House ain't cheap, but they don't care if you are. And they're open late. And good food and good wine with good friends is always a good thing. 4 stars for consistently good service, food, and the patience of saints.
author: Autumn K.

description: Service was horrible and food was not cooked or seasoned well.   This place is not worth the price.  The sad thing is that it was a Monday night and the place was only half full.
author: Bryan H.

description:
returning here as a carnivore helped me appreciate and try their many dishes.

SH was chosen as the restaurant for sunday dinner.  we started with the poutine (yumm!) and crispy shirmp.  the entrees for our table were the chicken, sole, salmon, and mine the short ribs.  my meat was so tender and delicate it broke away upon piercing it w/a fork.  the chicken was nice and savory, i loved the caramelized onion puree w/the salmon and lentils, and the sole was a nice light fish.

our server was great, and eric, the floor manager, made sure we enjoyed our dinner and constantly checked up on us.
author: Sheri N.

description: Wonderful service. My girlfriend has numerous allergies and the waitress was genuinely concerned and very helpful guiding her through the menu. I had the cod with clams and it was prepared perfectly and tasted great. My girlfriend had a pork dish with 3 different cuts and it was great as well. Our table was even ready 5 min early.
author: Matt L.

description: Their entrees are pretty filling -as in you probably don't need to order more than an entree. I had the flounder sandwich and poutine. Neither one stood out. Wait staff is fairly attentive.  We were seated near the middle and I disliked how hectic and out in the open the table felt but that's just the luck of the draw.
author: Gee H.

description:
One word sums it up - average.  If you happened to find yourself in SoMA, sure, drop by and enjoy a drink and maybe an appetizer.  Their cocktails are alright.  I regret ordering the Waltzing Mathilda - the glass of red wine on my 3rd visit was much better.  

Don't get me wrong - the service was alright, ditto for the food and drinks.  The problem?  Nothing stood out.  Their convenient location is definitely a plus - which probably explains why it's always a little crowded.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Meh! 

Perhaps my expectations were too high for this place but chissakes folks! I take a lady to dinner for her birthday and I end up thinking how I can cook with more care. 

If you are going to charge three dollar signs prices for a dining experience then care in the cooking should be taken care off before the pen starts the vertical line of the $.
author: Matthew S.

description:
I SO wanted to try the sweetbreads, but alas, I will need to return with some adventurous foodies.

Came here w/a group from work and the place was jumping; don't get  me wrong, I did read the reviews and expected it to be loud, but I was barely able to hear someone next to me.

Overall, my fav were the Crispy Shrimp app was surprising - not as spicy as I expected, but the green beans were nice and crisp and the greens and serrano ham did not over power the flavor.

We ordered individual dishes, but shared bites, overall the fish dishes were great, but the pork dish was disappointing, came across like a ham steak rather than loin. I ordered the Atlantic Striped Bass and it was good, but for some reason, the dates with the orange citrus coating did not meld well, but that could just be me.

The service was outstanding, but the cocktails were smaller than I've seen elsewhere and just be prepared for it to be loud. I think the rectangular(ness), height of the ceiling and brick probably were the culprits. :)
author: V K.

description:
I went to Salt House last night with a few friends and had a good time.  The service was great, they had no problem with us hanging out for a while after our dinner, and our waitress' wine recommendation ended up being pretty good.  They also had a good Dogfish Head IPA on tap.

I had the salmon for dinner and it was well prepared and very good.  For dessert I had the chocolate mousse - very rich, but also very good.

The atmosphere was nice - not too crowded, plenty of space, and very welcoming.

Overall, a great experience for a restaurant with mid-ranged prices.
author: Ben B.

description:
Small menu, bad vegetarian options (my co-worker didn't have very many choices; almost every dish had red meat in it, even the fish dishes), tiny portions, high prices. 
My tagliatelle with garlic fennel sausage and mania clams was good, but it literally was half a fistful of food.  I think there was app 8 strands of tagliatelle and 5 clams and small pieces of tasty sausages. I had to sustain myself with the Acme bread. 
Quite ridic. 
Thankfully, this was a biz lunch and i didn't have to pay for it ($18 for my tiny portion of pasta)...but i'd never pick this place for a non-work related meal.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
i walked past this place a while ago and told myself i would love to come here so i ended up making reservations and when i walked in to the place it took the host 3 whole minutes to come greet me and ask me for my reservation name that right there made me not want to eat there but i was deter mind to try those fries i seen pictures of so that's all i ordered and those 13 dollar fries was a waist of money there was no flavor at all 
only thing good about this place as the black waiter that i had was persist ant on filling up my water
author: Donnae K.

description:
Lovely-Every bit of it!

From the exposed brick, white washed accents, modern accents, dark woods, incredible aged steel beems, tall gorgeous windows that made you feel that you were on top of the world.  To the incredibly accomodating, warm and friendly service.  Then the food, it's presentation and intermingling of textures and tastes were divine!

This was a B-day dinner for a good friend and now colleage in the dog industry.  We arrived 45 mins early for our reservation to celebrate here after several recomendations.  We were seated immediately, no problem or fuss.  Just a warm welcome from our server and some wonderful crusty bread.

We started w/the warm truffle honey nuts and shared 3 salads, the crispy shrimp, winter and smoked trout salads.  Those nuts were the best snack I'm sure I've ever had!
