The warmth of the nuts, sweetness of the honey and earthiness of the truffles were amazing.  The salads were a wonderful exploration of protein, greens, sweet, savory and sour and so large we were almost full before our entrees arrived.

I had the Fulton Valley Chicken.  Oh heavenly Cock a Doodle Doo!  Perfectly moist with thin crispy skin, sat on a bed of soft Chestnuts, Spaetzle, more chunks of delicious chicken, bacon and baby broccolini.  I think this may have taken the place of any Thanksgiving Feast I have had and I ate until I thought I would burst!  Unfortunately I was staying in a hotel so couldn't take the rest home thus reluctantly had them take away what I couldn't finish.   

Although my dinner mates certainly enjoyed their choices, a beautifully prepared and melt in your mouth New York Steak and a delicate lemon Sole, I believe my dinner was supreme and one I won't forget!  Thank you Salt House, I will be back to bask my tastebuds in the glory of your chicken goodness!
author: Nicki W.

description:
Ever heard of pink peppercorn cheesecake? Me neither - but it was great!

What about hot nuts? Don't laugh! They're so tasty!

What I loved about the Salt House was their attention to detail. From the 3x5 cards adorning the light fixtures to create a subtle yellow glow, to the open-kitchen where diners can check out all the action, this place is awesome! 

Most importantly we have the food. The Poutine (Canadian style french fries with curds and gravy) was to die for. Again the hot nuts, very tasty. AND HOT! 

As an entree I enjoyed the striped bass with brussel sprouts and braised pork. Just try to stop me from licking that plate clean!

Dessert was equally spectacular with the ever-so-creative pink peppercorn cheesecake. It was so rich and sweet while the heat from the pepper just teased the pallet. 

One of the very best meals I've had in a long time. The wine list was also great as was the service. Couldn't have asked for a finer dining experience!
author: Katy H.

description: Ginger carrot soup was very good. The rest of the meal was less memorable.
author: Peter W.

description: I've been here twice (both times not by choice) and had some things that are pretty good, and some things that are barely edible. I think that it is sorely overpriced, and service is quite slow. It's an attractive space.
author: Olivia P.

description:
Wifey and I and two coworkers ate here last night because (1) one of my coworkers wanted to, and (2) it was about the only place I could get a reservation on 2 hours notice.  The bar was packed full of beautiful people when I arrived, but thankfully they had reserved a table up in the belltower for us and the other hunchbacks.

The specialty cocktails were pretty good, and it's nice to see so many high-end drinks made of stuff I have in my bar back home.  We split the poutine as an appetizer and it didn't disappoint.  (How can you be disappointed by french fries, shortrib gravy, and cheese?  I'll tell you how: you can't.  That particular act won the Congressional Medal of Impossible about 15 years ago.)  Wifey and I also split an autumn salad (I was expecting dead leaves and brown grass, but apparently it's fresh fruit, blue cheese, and dandelions, none of which says "autumn" to me, but then I don't write menus for a living), which was excellent.  I always appreciate it when my salads contain a high blue cheese factor, because I want to make sure the salad doesn't accidentally improve my health.

I had the cassoulet, because I often have cassoulets when they are offered to me.  Same thing with Altoids and bundles of unmarked, nonconsecutively-numbered bills.  Cassoulets are the official food of French rednecks, and I am the official Most Likely to Work for a French Company redneck from my high school class, so it's a natural fit.  Beans, sausage, pork shoulder, in a natural gravy.  Wifey had the steak, because she's a woman after my own heart (literally!) (well, not literally, because literally would be in a Kali Ma, Temple of Doom sort of way).  Now, if only I could dissuade her from ordering it gently mooing (for those of you who do this, please be aware that, back when it actually WAS gently mooing, it looked a LOT different).

I would give this place 5 stars but for the extremely lack-luster service.  I developed table envy for the table adjacent to us, who appeared to get really good service.  From the same waitress.
author: Ben P.

description:
The food is fantastic. You can't go wrong with any of the apps: started with a sinfully delicious poutine, wonderfully seasoned halibut tartare, grilled peaches over pork belly and satisfying gnocchi.

The entrees were equally amazing. Lingcod with mushrooms and porkbelly in a bacon broth was divine. Perfectly grilled New York steak and short rib with torpedo onions had everyone going for a second bite. 

Decor and ambiance is great. There were some issues with timing but it was resolved and they took care of us rather nicely after recognizing the issue.

We'll definitely go back!
author: justin g.

description:
Loved this place for Dinner.  Service isn't amazing but their wine list is, so I was contempt waiting.

My only advice, don't come here with other evening plans in mind, because everything just takes sooo much time (ie. service is one of the slowest in SF I've seen so far) and would therefore only come here for dinners, never lunches.
author: Rebecca W B.

description:
The food here is great. We were able to walk-in on a Friday night before the rush and have a full meal in about 90 minutes and not feel rushed. The atmosphere is lively and the people are beautiful. While the food is good, it's a bit spendy for what I like. But, it seems everyone else there had a great meal, good wine selection, and a few good beers on tap.

I'd visit again if someone else was paying...
author: Devin R.

description:
Salt house needs more salt.  

Had lunch here for the first time today and was a little disappointed.  Given the fervor with which I love Town Hall I had high expectations of this joint. We started with the spicy green beans and crispy shrimp, the shrimp was cooked to perfection. The green beans were good but maybe a little too drenched in sauce.  

My companion and I both ordered the Moraccan Chicken Salad which was seriously lacking in Moraccan seasoning or any seasoning for that matter.  The yummy grilled pita on the side was the best part of the dish.  Given the huge amount of cubed chicken this would have been a dieter's dream if it had just a little more flavor.  

I imagine I'll be back, it's close to the office and attractive inside, I can imagine a nice early dinner.  However, until then, a big boring three.
author: Claire C.

description:
Grabbed a late dinner last night at Salt House. I was a bit underwhelmed overall.

We had 8:45 reservations but we were running late. I tried to change the reservation via Open Table, but the restaurant does not allow any changes after 4:30pm. Not even a cancellation. Kind of a pain. Not very high-tech.

Anyway we arrived at 9:05 and the hostess told us that she would seat us after the other 8:45s. At about 9:20, we noticed that two 2-tops had been sitting empty for a while. We asked about these tables and she told us that she was waiting for the 9:30 reservations to show. I told her that this was unnacceptable. We got seated after about 5 more minutes.

The menu was not very extensive. Not a lot to choose from, but given the small size of the kitchen (it is probably about 10 feet by 30 feet), I suppose that I understand.

Once we were seated it took a while to place our order. It was clear that the very small kitchen was quite overwhelmed. My wife ordered 2 appetizers and I ordered  an appetizer and an entree. 

The first set of appetizers took about 20 minutes to arrive. My wife got the Baked oysters with bacon leaks and spinach. This dish was quite plain. Way too bready, not enough oyster taste, dry. I ordered the pork belly with squash dates and almonds. This was pretty tastey tho it is hard to mess up pork belly. 

After we finished the appetizers, it took about 20 minutes again for the next course to arrive. The waitress did come out and provide a 12 minute ETA at one point, but this was just a long delay especially considering that my wife's second course was just a cold trout salad. 
The smoked trout salad was quite lackluster. Not very trouty or smokey. Not much flavor. Disappointing. I ordered the Atlantic Cod with squid and fingerling potatoes. This dish was very well done. Fish was perfectly done and the accompanying items were quite tasty.

Overall, the service was pretty good, some of the food was quite good, but 2 dishes were pretty bad. Cost was about average for SF. The place was very crowded and lively. Our seats were not comfortable at all. We noticed that the tables in the middle of the room had smaller less comfortable chairs and of course we were lucky enough to be seated there. So I give it a 2-2.5 stars.
author: TJ M.

description:
I have been to salt house at least a dozen times since it opened. It is my favorite of the three rosenthal establishments. I LOVE the interior industrial space. My husband and I actually prefer to sit at the bar and share small dishes rather than sit in the dining room--I find it small and very loud. 

My favorite dish hands down is the crispy shrimp. It does not disappoint. I Love the chorizo stuffed squid that used to be on the menu too. Last night we had oysters, the crispy shrimp, poached egg (delicious) and the trout. All of it was amazing. I also miss their wines on tap, but the cocktails are great and they have a nice, diverse wine list.
author: marianne j.

description:
I am Gluten free and don't expect everyone to know what it is but once I have explained it well then I do expect said waiter to remember.  

Went to the salt house hearing great things but experienced otherwise.  Maybe my waiter was having an off night but every dish I ordered and requested to be gluten free had to be sent back to the kitchen due to some gluten in the dish.  
When making reservations ask to sit upstairs - its more quiet an a better view.

Overall I could say the food was really good but I wish it had come out correct the first time
author: Julie C.

description:
Hope you're not vegetarian ... and have a lot of money.  OK, so admittedly I have a problem with a restaurant in San Francisco not having ANY vegetarian options on the menu, and making me ask for it.  "Oh, it's not on the menu, but the kitchen will prepare something special - it will be fantastic" -- that is a direct quote from our waiter.  What I got was a small plate of some polenta with a scoop of sauteed vegetables.  My friend got the pasta with the same veggies and a duck confit.  Apparently, leaving the duck confit out meant an extra charge, because my little dish was $22 and his was $21.

I'm even OK with expensive food if it's excellent, but there was really nothing special about it - just some soft polenta and veggies.

REALLY disappointing.  I mean, lunch for 2 with no apps, one beer and an iced tea, and the total was over $70 after tip?  That's crazy.

This place is half a block from my office, and I won't be back.
author: Barton S.

description:
Salt House has some innovative ideas, I'll grant:  

- gourmet poutine:  damn, this stuff is awesome.  I could eat it every night.  perfectly crunchy fries, short-rib gravy to blow your mind, and cheese curds.  I'm salivating just thinking about it.

- arrogant bastard on tap:  + poutine = win.

- bar seating between the stairwell and the window:  managed to look warm and inviting even though it was cramped as hell.  Probably an ideal spot for a quiet conversation between two people, but not suited for 4.

- varied sizes of wine carafes served in logo-embossed bottles:  "I'd like some white wine" "what size?" "umm... medium?"

But these are countered by some serious negatives.  Be prepared to yell to your friends or your date, cuz it's loud in there.  Also, be prepared to wait a *long* time for your entrees -- say 30-40 minutes.  Also, be prepared to drop a good amount of money.

Final verdict:  I'll certainly return for beer + poutine, but not for dinner.
author: Jay M.

description:
Excellent food: Oyster selection covered all the flavors. Nectarine salad was unique with summer squash and a citrus marscapone concoction (seemed superfluous with that dish, but was still really good). Snapper was cooked perfectly, had a good crisp skin.

Service was very knowledgeable and friendly. Ambiance was perfect. Energetic but not crazy. Easy to hear your conversation.
author: Bill L.

description:
We went here on a Tuesday and the place was standing room only! Please remember: you have to have you entire party there or they won't seat you. We were seated only 5 minutes after our entire party arrived and were greeted warmly by all that worked there. The atmosphere is loud, fun and hip. The drinks were all very creative and tasty! I especially loved the champagne mojito and the GENEROUS house wine. The food is above average and entrees were priced at $25-$40/plate. The apps were good, we had the shrimp salad and the foie gras. The salad was okay, but it's just my personal dislike for that strange dressing they used - However, the rest of my group loved it. As for the foie gras, it was heaven! The chocolate cake was good but not much beyond mediocre. It was about $200 with drinks for a party of 3.

So, would I come back? Definitely for drinks and maybe for special dinners.
author: Lisa R.

description:
I am giving the Salt House three stars because we showed up for our reservations 10 minutes late and they had already given them away to someone else. Bastards.  

I am giving the Salt House three stars because we had to wait for 40 minutes before we got a table. Thank goodness my dinner date wasn't a snore.

On to the food and drinks.  The Salt House has a fun cocktail menu -- wouldn't you if you made your guest wait 40 minutes for a table? I digress. We had the Old Cubano and Mango Caipirinha -- both quite yummy and an amazing bottle of wine with dinner.  If you get an appetizer, you have to get the Poutine. I don't know another place in San Fran that serves poutine.  Very well done. We also had the seared tuna appetizer  - as good as seared tunas go. The duck is a great entree, but the halibut was slightly overcooked and dry. We opted for a delicious cheese plate for dessert, but at that point I was drunk, so I don't remember the cheeses.

Some things about the decor.  Cute place, but LOUD as hell. No idea what my date said, but I can tell you the ppl next to us had a great conversation. :)
author: Kamael S.

description:
At the Salt House I discovered a new oyster to add to my list of favorites:  Chelsea Gems.  These small- to medium-sized gems have a clean, bright flavor and are just plump enough without being too large.

Beyond the oysters, I discovered what everyone else has already yelped about...the poutine with delicious gravy, nicely cooked lamb shank, perfectly seared ahi, and decent desserts (the chocolate bread pudding had more of a semi-freddo texture than bread pudding, but it was good).  And, of course, the interesting "industrial" interior which seemed to amplify the noise levels to the point where my comrades and I practically had to shout at each other all night.

Service was excellent for the most part, tending to stray away towards the end of the meal.  I wish restaurants would offer full-sized teapots for serving loose-leaf tea; I get tired of flagging down the staff every time my one-cup teapot empties into my one cup and I need more hot water.  Otherwise, a stellar meal in an interesting Manhattan-like space...
author: Sherri C.

description:
Nice atmosphere, not too quiet, not too loud. Friendly staff, very accommodating when we showed up early for our rvsp. 

Poutine: fancy name for french fries + cheese + gravy. 
Beef short ribs: a little salty, but pretty delicious.
author: Roll N.

description:
Super Awesome Bistro Styled food

WOW! What a wonderful place for dinner.  It was expensive but the food was awesome here and if you sit upstairs, you can get a pretty cool view from above.  I really like the food here... the halibut was awesome... and the wine (gerwurtzminer) was delicious.  The soups were wonderful.  I would love to come back here for another meal.

Service was exemplary.  No complaints from me. Go eat at the salt house!
author: Joanne L.

description: I went here for my birthday lunch. Service was a bit slow and I was expecting the food to be better than it was. I'm glad I tried it, as it was next door to my office, but don't think I will be back. Was also very loud during the lunch rush.
author: Lauren W.

description:
The Salt House has is a super cute restaurant on Mission and Second. I was really curious about it and finally tried it when I found out they had poutine. 

I ordered the poutine and a beer. I wish I remembered the name, but I don't. All I know is that it was delicious and tasted like Christmas (had a cinnamon flavor hit you at the end). The poutine was good, but if you want the authentic Canadian poutine, keep searching, because this isn't it. The Salt House's poutine is fries, beef gravy, a type of cheddar and ribs. It was delicious. Though I must clarify Canadian poutine is fries, beef gravy and cheese curds and you definitely feel your arteries clogging with authentic Canadian poutine.

I will go back and try more food at The Salt House because everything I ate/drank was very good. I think I was just a little disappointed because I thought I had found Canadian poutine.
author: Analisa S.

description:
There is nothing like walking into a restaurant, having a look around and thinking... I would LOVE to live here!  Salt House has all the charm of a 20th floor NY loft - exposed brick, narrow floor to ceiling windows, rustic wood plank floors and furniture and great, GREAT lighting fixtures. With the stylistic flair of a five-star restaurant + a rustic ocean-side cannery the decor immediately captured my senses and imagination.

Despite arriving 45 min. early for a reservation we were seated immediately (by a devastatingly handsome host with an alarmingly sexy accent). Our server was patient, pleasant and helpful - even when I made the annoying request of trying to fix an air vent that was blowing freezing cold air over us. And oh the food.... the food. Outstanding.

I had to admit when I glanced at the menu online I wasn't positive I was going to love the food because I wasn't in the mood for fish or chicken - at it was that or steak. So, I ended up having the steak with a glass of Italian Pinot Noir and man oh man was I glad. Every bite was impeccable - salty and crusty - juicy sweet and rich. We also shared a few salads to start - the crunchy shrimp + green bean was my favorite - but the trout and winter salads were close seconds. Each bite was a pairing of unlikely but decadent ingredients that complimented each other perfectly. Even the butter served with the warm crusty bread was creamy and tasted unfathomably fresh. 

If I had to do it again the only thing I would do differently would be to save room for dessert. Yum, yum, yummy. Great way to spend my 28th birthday!!
author: J.Nichole S.

description: Good place to meet someone staying in the Union Squareish neighborhood. The food was good, the atmosphere was better.
author: Jay D.

description:
The vibe is hip yet homey.  I didn't appreciate how the tables were smushed up right against each other, though.  On the one side was clearly a first date with the male desperately trying to impress the not so impressed female and the other side was an odd couple where the girl picked solemnly at her salmon and her dining mate was drinking wine with curious gusto.

Anyway, I digress because you'd like to know that the food portions are SMALL (and I'm one petite girl).  I came famished, we ordered the poutine to share, and figured that our fish dishes would fill us up.  We were wrong.  Both of the dishes were good (although the salmon was a little predictable), don't get me wrong.  But after shelling out $95 (poutine, two fish dishes, and 2 drinks - one alcoholic, the other just a diet coke) we walked over a couple of blocks and hit up McDonalds for fries and $1 sundaes.
author: B D.

description:
Not bad!  Food was well done here! Came here Tuesday night and it was surprisingly busy. The restaurant has a good energy level. We sat upstairs, which was nice and open feeling. A little noisy. Maybe not ideal if you're really trying to have a conversation.

(Appetizer) Crispy Shrimp with green beans - this was really good! The beans were tender and the shrimp was yummy. 
(Appetizer) Foie Gras - was rich. Good mix of creamy and sweet and salty. 
(Entree) Pork tenderloin - only had a bite. Meat was tender and moist
(Entree) Snapper - was fresh and perfectly seared. Very savory dish. A little salty, but overall good. 

We skipped drinks and dessert... they serve yummy Acme bread in the beginning of the meal.  

Service was pretty good. Friendly and efficient.  

Parking was a little bit of a pain here. I circled for 15 minutes and nearly broke down and paid $12 for parking. I lucked out and found a metered spot just as I was about to pay for valet. 

I enjoyed my meal here and I would come back. A little overpriced (I say that about nearly every SF restaurant). Dinner will run you $50-70 per person (w/ tax and tip).
author: Cindy Y.

description:
As a big fan of SoMa's TownHall, it was about time I finally made my way out to it's sister, Salt House.

Once again reinventing an old historic space with modern accents, this venue is a comfortable nook within it's neighborhood. A bustling vibe, beautiful clientele, and a forward thinking menu, Salt House is a mid week gold mine.

We came out Thursday evening, on what turned out to be a gorgeous warm October night. As we strolled in, we were greeted with the warm smile of the hostess and promptly seated with our reservation.

I enjoy being surrounded by activity and still be able to maintain my personal conversation bubble. The ambiance of life brings out the character of this place, and the brick walls charm me like they always do.

We started out with a tasting of 3 types of Oysters. The Fanny Bay, Miyagi and Kumamoto. All were delicious, fresh, and when topped with the 2 table garnishes, eased you right into your seat. Washed down with a cold beer, and I was ready for round 2.

She engaged with the Monkfish as I dove into my Petrale Sole. Both were phenomenal.

The Petrale came on a meticulous bed of chick peas and other vegetables in a delightful curry sauce which truly made you think. The golden outside crisp of the fish played wonderfully with the soft interior and added texture to this dish.

Her Monkfish was equally satisfying, with a delicate touch. The sauce wasn't too rich, but played nice with the origin of the fish, and allowed you to taste, rather than deliver thought.

Salt House is a great Chapter 2 for these brothers, and they once again drove to the heart of what people crave. Authentic venue with current elements, a stimulating vibe with manicured views, and a menu with genuine thought to your core.

I will have to say, I think Town Hall is better, but as always, the little sister has to try a bit harder to impress.
author: Mike K.

description: My first meal at Salt House was via a holiday lunch for our executive team.  Good atmosphere and servcie.  Nice menu including some really great apps.  Their bergamot tea was out of this world.  Interested enough to go back for dinner.
author: Tammy N.

description: Great place for drinks after work. Noise level is fine. Great wait staff!
author: BenHur C.

description:
This place had incredible food but also some incredible issues with service and the speed of the kitchen. If I were rating solely on food I'd give it 4* easily. But the terrible kitchen drops my overall rating to 2*.

Came here with 3 other coworkers expecting a reasonably timed dinner...boy were we wrong. It took us over 2 hours just to have appetizers and entrees. I've had 4 course meals at a Thomas Keller restaurant in much less time than that, and each of those courses were perfectly spaced.

Took the waiter forever to take our order and bring us drinks (nothing complicated, just beer and wine). Appetizers took a good 30+ minutes to come out...how the F do roasted nuts take that freaking long? We figured a "snack," as denoted on their menu, would come out ASAP followed by the rest of the appetizers. 

The poutine was delicious. Normally the concept of poutine has always grossed me out but I was willing to give it an upscale version with shortrib gravy and white cheddar a shot. I felt that the flavor of the gravy was lacking somewhat but at the same time wasn't quite sure what could have made it better. We also got Oysters, the scallops, and crispy shrimp -- all of which my team enjoyed

Entrees took freaking forever as well -- a good 40 minutes after the appetizers came out. We had to ask twice where our 2nd round of beers were as well (15 minutes to get those). Our waiter was infallibly polite but incredibly hard to find; he'd pull these vanishing acts for 10-15mins at a time. 

I had the yellowfin tuna entree and it was very tasty. Lightly seared served with a garlic puree and asparagus. The seasoning along the edges was delicious and presentation was meticulous. The rest of my team got the chicken and the sole and they all thought their items were awesome (their words, not mine). 

Overall the food was delicious but the service was terrible. They really need to get their kitchen in order (seems to be a theme among other reviews here) because there really isn't anything that needs to take that freaking long to cook. Also, prices were on the higher end...definitely don't say no if the expense account is treating you to dinner but I'd hesitate to come back with my own $

Don't plan on coming here unless you have a lot of time to kill. We had to go back to work after this so the 2hr meal really set us back in terms of how late we ended up having to stay at the office.
author: Farhad M.

description:
I promised myself I would stop eating until I couldn't stand up straight. I was doing pretty well for a while. And then they need to open a place like Salt House and ruin everything. 

The decor, the service, the vibe were all great. But these five stars are devoted first and foremost to the food. Everything I tried was amazing. The little sweet/salty/honey nuts they serve are like nothing I've ever tried. For appetizers, we ordered poutine (my first poutine - where have you been all my life, my Canadian love??) and a pretty standard mixed lettuce salad. My monkfish with butternut squash and short rib sauce was delectable. I only wish they had provided more than a small smear of the squash puree...I could have eaten a whole bowl. The most fun dish of the night was the pink peppercorn cheesecake. It comes with some explosive passion fruit ice cream that transported me to some hot tropical location that features someone fanning me with palm leaves. It also features a big chunk of white chocolate integrated with...wait for it....POP ROCKS. Ok, I'm not sure if they're the real pop rocks, but they definitely feel like it in your mouth. White chocolate and a magical fizz? I'm in heaven. The group also loved the brownie sundae. We also tried the carrot cake, which had a great flavor but was a bit dry, and a very aromatic panna cotta that was a bit overwhelming for some people, though I really liked it in small amounts. 

All of the above items contributed to my current state, immobilized on my bed and feeling like I couldn't imagine eating another meal...ever. Well, until I go back to Salt House and try that chicken dish that looked so divine!
author: Christina P.

description:
Great seafood and salads. Nice Wine list. 
Highly recommend it.
I had the smoked trout croque madame as an appetizer ... wonderful, tasty, innovative. Loved it.
Alaskan Cod as an entree, also perfectly cooked and delicious.
author: Chris L.

description:
Had dinner with an old friend here last night. We noshed on a few small plates/appetizers. Everything was delicious and I have missed eating here. 

Sipped on a dirty martini with extra olives while I made my way through the dayboat scallops, the burrata with poached figs, the truffle honey nuts, marinated olives and the crispy shrimp salad. It was perfect!
author: Mika D.

description:
My friend was telling me great things about this place, how she comes with her co-workers, etc etc so I decided to check Salt House out last Friday with 8:30pm reservations. 

First impression: Really quaint place that was comfortably crowded. Then I found out my reservation never went through despite calling in earlier in the week. Okay... so I think I can wait 10-15 minutes no problem since I'm already here anyway. Then the hostess suggested we sit down at the bar while we wait. Yeah sure, that sounds good. We walk the length of the bar and realize there's not a single seat open so we squeeze back out to wait at the entrance once more. 

Eventually we grew tired and left. I'm sure the food and service is great, but caught them at a bad time. I will edit this soon as I return!
author: Jaime S.

description:
Great food :-)
The Petrale and the Pork Chop are great :-)
I really love the interior design and architecture of this restaurant as well. 
It is a really classy joint :-)
author: Conor L.

description:
Went here for lunch with my boss, ordered the salmon, it was a big piece, well cooked and tender. They went easy on the veggies, more would've been better. 

Overall, good service and good food.
author: Ava K.

description:
This is going to be a generic Yelp but I loved everything!  The service was incredible from everyone I interacted with, the food was fabulous, the ambiance and clientele were also top notch.  

My favorite on the menu was the Poutine.  (Of course I'd find the fries with cheese and gravy to be the best thing at an upscale dining restaurant...)
author: DJ P.

description:
really good seafood here.  The fries with gravy are good too!

You might need reservations because this place is small and gets packed.

Stick with their fish entrees... always fresh and tasty.
author: Shawn A.

description:
i'm still having such vivid flashbacks of last night's amazing dinner...

the way the seared foie gras slowly melted on my tongue, the perfect texture and buttery'ness complimented by the slightly sweet cherry compote. 

the crispness of the crust on the snapper perfectly paired with juicy chanterelle musthrooms and chorizo.

and finally the smooth creaminess of the red hawk cheese on butter toasted  salty baguette slices topped with slices of plum and nectarine. 

oh. my. god. orgasm in my mouth.

the only complaint i had was my extra dirty martini wasn't dirty enough. 

nice romantic ambiance, but quite loud. try to find yourself a nice corner table away from the noise (just don't choose the one that's right underneath the stairs) possibly, the seats facing the street.. it's fun to people watch or tease passer-byers with the delicious food rather.
author: Anh P.

description:
A friend recommended this Restaurant so we thought we would try it out on a Monday night.  The menu looked great  with lots of unusual items, not a lot to choose from but the selection seemed unique until I saw a listing for Foie Gras. I mean with all the information available about how Foie Gras is made how in the world can anyone not know this is produced by cruel and inhumane farming practices. At just a few months old, ducks are confined inside dark sheds and force-fed enormous amounts of food several times a day. A farm worker grabs each duck and, one by one, thrusts a metal pipe down their throats so that a mixture of corn can be forced directly into their gullets. In just a matter of weeks, the ducks become grossly overweight and their livers expand up to 10 times their normal size. 

Needless to say we left without ordering. Save your money and spend it where the owners are humane and care about being cruel to animals.
author: John L.

description:
I love this place! You know how sometimes you're down to two choices, order and then end up wishing you had ordered the other one? This will never happen because everything here is amazing! I have chosen to come here for two Birthday dinners in a row, it's just that good. 

Note: You must make a reservation because this place is always packed, even on off days!
author: Monica A.

description:
Okay, I ate there today for the SF Dine about town lunch special.  While I was not really into the choices we had to choose from, I tried them because that was the whole point of going.

So, I had the Curried Apple Soup to start, and the Ciopinno, with seafood and chorizo, for the main dish.  While the soup was tasty, I was not super impressed with it.  I actually thought it was better than the main dish I had, however, once I was finished.  The Ciopinno was traditional with the seafood, but they stuffed the calamari with chorizo and had pieces of chorizo in the soup as well.  It was very over-powering and I felt that the chorizo took over and the flavor did not pan out well.  By the time I was done, the chorizo had over-powered everything and left a bad taste in my mouth.

Would I go back?  Maybe, if I was eating from the regular menu and someone else was paying!  

Our waiter was attentive and did not rush us, however, we were at the tail end of the lunch crowd since our reservation was at 1:15 pm.  While he offered my friend many refills on his coke, not once did he offer me a refill on my iced tea.  Really?  I have never been to a nice restaurant where they do not offer to refill your iced tea!  Seriously, my glass sat empty halfway through my meal and I just drank water.

The ambiance was nice.  I felt the place had a good vibe and was lively, but not over-powering with noise.  So that was a plus, for that time of day anyway.

So, overall I was not impressed.  I would think the whole reason for the dine about town in SF was to impress people and make them want to come back, this selection of food did not impress me or make me want to return.  

I was a little sad, as I have passed this place many times and always wanted to go there.  I was looking forward to it.  Now I know I was not really missing that much in the first place.
author: Shannon S.

description:
We came for the Poutine and it did not disappoint. Fries are covered in a white cheese sauce and you pour brown gravy over it all. The gravy was like a stew, with red wine and chunks of beef and mushroom.

My coworker and I shared the Poutine and the Petrale Sole, and this was the perfect amount of food (maybe even a little too much). The sole was prepared over garbanzo beans, a parsley sauce, and a few littleneck clams. It's difficult eating all those things together, but the flavor was very good and the fish wasn't overcooked.

The menu changes weekly, so check it before you go if you're planning on ordering something specific. We were disappointed that the meatloaf sandwich left the menu.

Notes:
The decor is modern with a dash of pirate (tastefully so).
For some reason, we ended up with 15 different utensils. Our server kept resupplying to our bemusement. There were only 4 clams yet we were given the special fork for them.
White peach lemonade doesn't have enough peach flavor, but it's a good lemonade.
author: Amy N.

description:
The highlight during my dinner at Salt House was the tourist next to us who was going through his photos from earlier that day. He must of got to one at Alcatraz cause he yells "LOOK! I am in jail! I've been a bad, bad boy!" This is a grown man, in a restaurant, yelling. Oh, it was priceless.

...well, that and the fries with short rib gravy. It sounds odd, but it is da bomb. 

I love that the menu is ever changing. The oysters were also fresh and delicious. A perfect way to start a meal!
author: Natalie N.

description: Went on date night with the bf last night, and had a great time!  Oysters were absolutely amazing! I should've ordered more. We ordered the halibut, and the ribs, and I was pretty satisfied with the dinner.  Service was great, and food was yummy, I would go back.
author: Sara L.

description:
Fire everybody and start from scratch
Food is mediocre or boring AT BEST. I've NEVER paid so much for such horrific terrible and slow service. I think everyone is high or drunk working there. I feel bad for the chefs that they put up with such terrible servers, hosts, etc. everything was late and timed so improperly! Why does this place exist. Save your money and time!!!!
author: Dom W.

description:
we came here without a reservation on thursday night and were told that we would have to wait 45 minutes or just go to the bar and communal table.  we sat down within five minutes of waiting at the communal table.  not too shabby.  though the people who come in here to grab drinks and share that space are not the best company ... all in suits etc.  maybe it was just the two douchebags who kept leaning into our drinks and food.  talked loud about how much the deals they were working on were worth, blah blah blah .. hey man dont spit into my food

anyways.  the parking situation was rather horrendous.  we were at union sq and were going to walk over but decided to drive over last minute. took us quite a while to get anything.

the service was really good.  she was really attentive and made sure i always had a drink. oh and the communal table had bag hooks underneath!  details ... the business cards are on little shipping tags.  they weigh the receipts down with typefaces. the mural on the back wall didnt really match anything ... wait staff all in white button downs.

oh yes the food.  the bread that came out wasnt warm.  oh well.  they split the butternut squash for us.  somehow squash soup always reminds me of the kind at trader joes that come in a box.  the autumn salad with endive, persimmon, apple, pomegranate seeds, hazelnuts was pretty good.  she recommended the sea bass and it was good.  the skin was crispy and the meat was juicy and cooked perfectly.

overall pretty good meal.  might opt for table next time to avoid the corporate douchebags
author: claudia y.

description:
Yummy!
Weird that you have to leave and go through a lobby of the building to go to the restroom but it's SF so I get it
My beet salad plate was beautiful and oysters were very fresh with shaved dry horseradish (no one seems to have it anymore). My date had the steak which was cooked perfectly and was very good and moist. 
A bit pricey for the portions but I get it, it's a "fancy restaurant"
Service was prompt but I feel the waitress was rude to us because we were the youngest people in there and we dressed casually (jeans, top, jacket). We have the money to spend just like everyone else there so I would appreciate being treated as such. Also I'm an incredibly good tipper with good service so I'm sorry you missed out by being short with us and never coming back to check on us and never once having a smile while at our table. You work on tips- so you better get with the program or starve sweetie.
author: Kajal G.

description:
Salt House is way overrated, and a terrible value for the money.  It's part of an unfortunate offshoot of California Cuisine currently afflicting San Francisco: the cult of local-seasonal-sustainable.  The menu tells you where every ingredient is from, but not how they are prepared.  And they must want you to focus on the purity and freshness of the ingredients, because they sure as heck don't do much to the ingredients before they are brought to your table.  An entirely underwhelming experience.

And the room is L-O-U-D.  Earsplitting.  What the trendy "foodies" at Salt House found to shout about I have no idea, but it certainly wasn't the food.
author: April M.

description: Very professional staff and they did a good job of accommodating us especially after our many early evening cocktails. Not that we were being obnoxious as this isn't that type of place but were having a lot of fun and part of that is due to the ambiance and the spirit of Salt House. The food was excellent. Maybe not exactly 5 stars for the entrees but the poached egg starter and oysters were a huge hit at our table. We shared the Key Lime pie for desert which was very sweet and tart in all the right places. I would def make it back.  Thank you Salt House keep up the good work!
author: Miles L.

description: big fan, the fries are amazing and overall the food is very good and really great service! great place to meet with friends, have a date night and be in a pretty cool environment.
author: Rob P.

description:
The good:

Friendly staff

The bad:

I ordered the foie gras torchon- see Lisa S.'s pic What did I get? Everything but the foie gras. I didn't know at first but thought the foie gras was in the round tannish patty. I got back to work and Googled it and got the same result. But now that I see Lisa's pic.....I am pissed! How can you forget to give me what I ordered? The FREAKING Foie gras!!!!

They give you bread and butter. The bread comes on a sheet of brown paper. It reminds me of those brown paper wrapped around paper towels you buy in bulk (huge box) at Costco. I thought that was weird and a little gross. Keep it simple.....use a plate.

We also ordered the salmon and short rib. They were ok.

Honestly this place is over rated. I thought it was expensive for such tiny portions of mediocre food.

Service was SLOW! I went waayyy past my 1 hour break. And I had reservations too. 

Will not be dining here again.

I've  come to expect either the food or the service to barely reach my expectations at most well reviewed restaurants. The Salt House exceeded my expectations in both categories. The food was uniquely paired with vegetables and sauces/broth. The poached egg was surprisingly good. From the moment we walked in I felt welcomed and relaxed. Our server, Daniel made the dining experince everything one hopes for when looking for a "nice dinner". He was educated on the wine and food being offered which allowed us to make excellent choices. To top off the perfect service he went out to the street and hailed us a cab! Overall Excellent choice!
author: Kelli M.

description: Honestly it was not that great. I got the chicken salad and it was barely eatable. Plus the bread was given to us cold, we couldn't even use butter on it. Also, I don't think they had a heater either.
author: Nancy V.

description:
My family and I went here for our Christmas Eve dinner a couple days ago and I kinda fell in love with the ambiance as soon as we entered... we were waiting for one more person in our party to arrive, so we waited at the cozy bar. I love the old school light bulbs hanging over the bar, the giant mirror (which I wanted to pocket and take home), and the farm table style bar table. 

The staff was super friendly from the moment we entered. I really appreciated their personalities, and as we waited at the bar and I observed the staff interaction, I was kind of taken back because they all seemed happy and seemed to get along well. Now I have a great respect for all the people who work during the holidays, especially in customer service oriented businesses. However, the Salt House people seemed exceptionally happy and in good spirits despite the fact that they were working on Christmas Eve, and happy servers really makes a difference in my dining experience. 

Anyhow, after we were escorted upstairs to our table we were helped by our kind waitress. The only minor negative part of our dinner that night was that the menus were late to arrive to our table. Our waitress thought that we already had received them, but as soon as she noticed she was apologetic and even made a light but appropriate joke about it... very suave. 

We ordered some apps which included the foie gras, the fries covered in beef stew (?) and the shrimp & green beans. All were very yummy. We also ordered the butternut squash soup and the winter greens salad (I believe this is what it was called... the one with the yummy persimmons). I loved, loved, loved my salad. The food quality was impressive and presentation was tasteful.

We brought a couple bottles of red wine, and they made sure to bring the right glasses and to keep our bottles at a service table, so that it did not crowd our dining space. Little things that you'd expect at a nice restaurant, but it's nice when a restaurant actually gets it all right.

I ordered the monkfish, my husband had the cod, a couple people had the "chipper chicken" (not really called this), another the cassoulet, another the polenta, and someone had the dish with the bone marrow (don't smell that one too closely!). Anyhow, everyone was happy with their dishes. I cleared my plate... the monkfish was yummy and I liked how the outside had the slightest crisp texture to it. 

Oh! The bread, I forgot to mention the bread. It comes out in a cute little twist roll and was delish. Enjoyed that for sure. 

Ok, so moving on to dessert. I think I was the only one who ordered dessert because Carrot Cake was on the menu... HOLY yummy carrot goodness. It was so yummy, beautiful presentation and probably the smoothest carrot cake I have ever had. Taste of glorious carrot heaven. Even my husband who is not a fan of carrot cake admitted that he enjoyed it. I almost want to go back just to eat a meal and have an excuse to enjoy the carrot cake. The serve it with a little pistachio ice cream which is a nice touch too.

Last technical detail... my mother in law made the reservation, and told us that reservations were required for parties of 5 or more. 

Definitely looking forward to going back.
author: Shannel G.

description: Really nice place for a date. Great cocktails, great wine. Really tasty appetizers. Had the steak and was thoroughly satisfied. Super nice waitstaff that worked together nicely.
author: Megan B.

description: What a delicious and cool restaurant. I ordered a burger, and I have to say it was one of the best burgers I've ever had. Also, there version of the classic Arnold Palmer is phenomenal! Also, the location is convenient to anyone downtown SF. I rate this two thumbs up!
author: Christian S.

description: Not quite sure what the hype is about. Hip ambience for the somewhat traditional kind of cuisine they serve but it does get pretty loud and noisy due to the structure of the room.  Food was meh at best. I have never met a poutine I didn't like and was so.excited when I heard this place offers it but it was lousy - fries were basically chunks of tasteless potato, the gravy was somewhat viscous and not great-tasting and the curds did nothing to lift the dish. The cod fared better; broth was tasty and the fish itself was decent. But for the price I was paying, I definitely have had better cod dishes elsewhere for less. I doubt I'd go back; would rather take my money elsewhere considering there are so many great restaurants in SF.
author: Evilyn H.

description:
Kitchen timing was off!  Waited a ton of time but the staff and food made up for it.

I recommend starting with the martini with cucumber and mint... tasty.

I really wanted to start with the poutine but we decided on chilled soup and salad to start.  Sitting by the kitchen we saw the poutine (fries with gravy) pass us several times and we were jealous.  Then we waited what seemed like eternity for our  entrees. Kitchen was working but obviously their timing was all off.  

After over an hour and lots of bread, we asked... what is going on with our entrees?  The manager was really kind and addressed the situation immediately.  She offered us a round of drinks and dessert.  Very nice.

The food was worth the wait...  Between the braised short ribs, yellowtail and chicken entrees, we couldn't decide which was best.  We cleaned our plates.

Finally, thank goodness for the offer of free desserts since we would have otherwise left since we were full.  Between the four of us, we decided to share 2:  chocolate cheesecake with black cherry and chocolate peanut butter cake.  I could have licked the mason jar the chocolate cheesecake came in... if only I was alone, I would have.  It was heaven in a jar!

Overall, I give the food 4 star!  But be aware that there is a wait and the kitchen has timing problems but when you do get the food, it will not disappoint you.  Please order that yummy dessert....
author: Grace S.

description:
I wanted to love Salt House, but it just didn't do it for me. 

Four stars for a great ambiance, pretty people and wonderful wine list. I really loved the community seating up front. It was perfect for those who might be waiting for friends. Great open kitchen format for girls like us who like watching chefs at work! 

The food, however, was a bit of a disappointment. It wasn't terrible, but not stellar either. Maybe we just ordered the wrong things? 

I had the dover sole, and it was a little bland. 

If I had to do it over again, I'd get a bottle of wine, oysters on the half shell and call it a night!
author: Caroline A.

description:
Plain and simple.  Outstanding food.

When we walked into Salt House, the place was packed.  It was a typical SOMA day - some conference in town and Salt House was overflowing with corporate diners.  Although it took a few extra minutes to get our reserved table, from the minute we sat down, it felt like we were the only people in the room - no easy feat given that we were inches from our neighboring table.

Others here have criticized the service, but ours was spot on.  The waitress showed up with the wine list just when you were hoping she would... the list goes on.

And the food!  Yummy.  The nectarine salad to start was hands down the best salad I've ever been served.  I had the polenta and veggie entree and that was also solid - I ate ever bite.  The only downside is that there was only one vegetarian option.  I would've loved to see more so that I'd have more reasons to come back!

All-in-all, I highly recommend Salt House, especially for special occasions.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
We went here for the third time last night, and usual, it was a great experience. The  interior reminded us of a modern ski lodge, and the staff is friendly and professional. 

We tried the following dishes:
- Pacific Cod: manila clams / komochi kombu / lardo /roasted garlic clam broth
- Green Faro: brussel sprouts / carrots / maitakes / turnips / grana padano
- Pork Loin: brandied prunes / golden turnip/ mustard spaetzle / apple cider sauce
- German chocolate cake 

Everything was fresh and well-executed. We had requested that the chef go easy on the salt, and the request was readily complied. Not all restaurants follow through, so we were pleased. In our opinion, the green faro was star of the evening. It reminded us of a rich risotto, topped with sweet root vegetables. The watercress was a lovely and fresh touch! The dessert was delicious -  the coconut ice cream paired perfectly with the moist cake.

We're so glad they are part of Open Table. We can't wait to go back!
author: Twocents F.

description:
After living in SOMA for two years and walking past this place almost daily for 8 months, I finally got around to going!  

First off, I was really really disappointed that the poutine has a meat based gravy on it.  As a Canadian who misses this great dish of Quebec, I was looking forward to trying it out.  Sadly, as a vegetarian I had to pass.  

We tried the Butternut Squash Soup, the Tagliatelle, the Polenta and the Salmon.  As well as some cocktails and wine.  Everything was top notch and amazing.  I was surprised at how well the vegetables came out in my Polenta dish and honestly felt like they were the central piece of it.  Even my partner said that his veggies were almost better than his fish.

I won't even touch upon how amazing the Chevre Cheesecake was.  

The atmosphere of the place is great, although a bit crowded near the bar.  The crowding also contributed to it being a lot noisier than I would have liked considering we were attempting to have a conversation.  The seating areas were a bit more spacious and there's an upstairs area as well.  Next time, I'd probably go for a table instead of sitting at the bar area just so it's less pushy and crowded.  Would highly recommend going here to check it out.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Overall a great experience.  The food was great, but at the prices paid I expect something a little more exquisite.  Anyway, I would definitely go back anytime for more.
author: Peter H.

description:
Came her for dinner and it was good! We split 5 apps and 3 entrees between 5 of us. It was just the right amount of food; although I think next time we'll just do 10 apps instead.

We ordered the foie gras - it was good. The accompanying duck was so tasty, I've had better foie gras before though.
The quail app was surprisingly good, and the tagliatelle also impressed.
Yellowfin Tartare was also excellent!
I can't remember the 5th app - will update if it comes to me.

For entrees the beef short ribs were yum! (tiny portion - but excellently done) the tai snapper was also very good. I'm not a huge pork fan so I don't have much to say on the pork belly entree, other party members said it was good but a little bit on the dry side.
author: Kym P.

description: So I live about 100 yards from the SaltHouse and walk past it nearly everyday however I had never stopped in to try it, until tonight when I decided to take my mom out for her birthday, I had ordered the natural pork loin and was severely disappointed, first to start, I do not mind spending a lot of money for quality food, however this was pretty average (tasted like it was meat from Walmart) and not only that, it was ONE small pork loin and that was it......for 30 bucks......THAT is insane. And not only that, but my mom had ordered the steak and it was nothing but chewy fat, and gristle, That's pretty gross. However I'll give them credit the service was great and our waitress very friendly, but food, let me put it this way, if you want to spend 30$ for about 5$ worth of food, THEN THE SALT HOUSE IS FOR YOU! However if you want to get a decent meal and not have to re finance your house, I'd suggest you go else where, I'm now wishing I would have gone to Umbria right down the street for less $$$ and 10x the quality, moral of the story step it up salt house.
author: Brandon M.

description: This place has great poutine and is right around the corner from my work.  Twice, I have been there for dinner with my boss and they told us that they didn't have room for us and, not until we left the building, were told that they would "fit us in".  I suspect a strange policy or maybe just a coincidence.  Either way, I recommend this place's poutine.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I have only been to Salt House for lunch, but have gone back a few times to eat. I was really disappointed to learn that they do not offer a take-out option. I understand if it is about maintaining the quality of the food, but my office is literally three blocks away. Anyways, back to the food. I have had dreams about their poutine so that is a staple in my order every time. The entrees are a mixed bag. I had a soggy "BLT" one time. The bread was way too oily and soggy by the time the sandwich made it in front of me. It definitely overpowered the delicious shrimp and crab salad. Another time, I had their lamb goulash. I was pining for some goulash from my days in Eastern Europe and this goulash did not disappoint. Though on the drier side (I like my goulash more stew-y), it was really delicious and filling.

I have to point out that the service has been great every time I have gone, but there is one guys who is bussing all the tables who is evidently always angry or just sloppy. He dropped glasses, plates and cutlery multiple times one time I was there. A lot of ruckus for what was supposed to be a calm lunch.
author: Clark H.

description:
Last week my co-worker and I went to The Salt House for an early business lunch around 11:30am. The restaurant was practically empty; two tables had been sat when we walked in. The hostess asked us if we had a reservation when we walked in, and we didn't. She did say we could sit at the bar as that was a first come first serve basis. 
By the looks of the restaurant, it didn't seem like a problem to fit us in. In fact,  we could have been in and out of there before the main lunch rush even arrived. Was a bit surprising they turned us away.....not impressed.
author: Jen G.

description: After drinks at 83 Proof, we were craving something to munch on.  Walking past Salt House we noticed Poutine on the menu!  Gravy soaked fried sounded perfect.  We didn't have a reservation of course, but there was a communal table and window seating tucked behind the stairs.  We ended up getting Crispy Shrimp and the Poutine. Didn't like that there were only four shrimp, but mostly it was nice we were able to slip in, eat our snack, and leave with no reservations.  People watching at the window seat was fun too.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Loved it!! Oysters rocked. Cool decor!
author: Brandy B.

description:
Very good friendly service.  Was able to find street parking fairly easy on a Sunday evening.

Food was okay.  Fries are very good, but eat 'em while they're hot.  Had to send back the seafood platter cuz it wasn't fresh.  They were very apologetic and accomodating.  None of the other food was especially notable or memorable.

The restaurant shares a restroom with a club whose clientele can be a bit aggressive as female members of the group described each time they returned from a trip to the ladies room.

Nice place, but nothing really stood out except for the service.
author: H C.

description: Great place for a business lunch. Food was terrific, portions are well thought out - not too much and not too little...just right.
author: Ping P.

description:
Yum!  I couldn't eat here all the time, but it's great for a nice night out!

We had 6:30 reservations, and only had to wait a few minutes for our table - just enough time to get a couple of drinks at the bar.  All of the food sounded so good that we just ordered several appetizers to share - all of which were quite delicious.  I can't remember all the dishes we ordered (and the online menu has changed!) but I loved the pickled vegetables and the poutine was pretty good, though I think my least favorite dish of the night.
author: Ashley G.

description: I've gone to Salt House a number of times for lunch.  Each time, I've left satisfied but not overly impressed.  Their sandwiches are okay, though I was not a fan of the pulled pork sandwich.  Service is fast, friendly, and efficient.  Should be a good place for lunch.
author: Angel S.

description:
Very good. We stumbled on this place while wandering around, looking for something new. It was very crowded on a Tuesday night, but we got seated quickly. There seems to mostly be an after work crowd, and even though it was noisy, conversation was still very easy. The service was wonderful, everyone was very attentive. It took awhile for the entrees to come, however we were warned ahead of time and drinks and very yummy bread were plentiful. When the food did come it was excellent. I had the chicken and my husband had the lamb. The lamb was fall off the bone melt in your mouth yummy! Then we had the ice cream sandwiches for dessert. They were just meh. I have found that there really are not very many places that have a good dessert, though they did look awesome!

So to summarize:
 - noise level high, but still easy to hold a conversation
 - would not go for a romantic/intimate dinner, but a great fun place to go   with friends or coworkers
 - wonderful decor, simple chic
 - excellent bread
 - excellent service
 - tasty entrees, nice presentation but not over the top
 - skip dessert

Salt House is on my list as one of my new favorite places in SF, I will certainly be back!
author: Rob R.

description:
I came here for a mid-week lunch. Nothing about this place jumped out as outstanding or intolerable. 

I ordered the Poutine. It's rich and heavy but very delicious. It also feels like something you shouldn't get at a fancy restaurant. When I was in college, there was a diner nearby which served french fries with cheese and gravy at 1/2 the price. We frequented that diner past midnight and the "poutine" was my favorite. Well, that was in CT, so revisiting my college favorite food was fun. 

I ordered the chicken pot pie for the main course. It's a true comfort food. My friend ordered petrale sole, which was perfectly cooked. My friend didn't seem to care for it much, saying that it was a bit tart.

Service was impeccable and fast. The total bill came out to a little over $70 for food and drinks. It's a solid place for business lunch but you do need to project your voice. It gets loud.
author: Su K.

description:
Sheik, modern, industrial setting with old brick and exposed weathered steel beams.  High ceiling with lots of air space and minimally decorated, my kind of place.  Not so my kind of place, were the tons of suits and business in the air, a little stuffy for me, to say the least.  Arrived about 6ish on a weeknight without reservations (that's how I roll) and was easily seated as it were mostly happy hour folk around this time.  By the time we finished dinner (7:30) the place was packed, that it always amazes me how the staff can maneuver so well in such tight confines.  Bravo to them.

Started with the Smoked Trout Salad (which they graciously split, w/o us even asking).  Quite good with sweet baby beets, citrus segments, shards of smoked trout, mixt greens and some horseradish cream.  The interplay of sweet, salty, tart and bold just worked.  Trout a little on the salty side but we were at the "Salt House" , right?.  Also ordered the Baked Oysters with bacon, spinach and buttery bread crumbs and this was quite the treat.  I thought for a moment that with all those toppings the flavor of the oysters might get lost, but not the case.  After tasting all the toppings, the sweet/briny flavor of the oyster comes through as it were plump and just barely cooked through.  The bacon with the oyster turned it a little on the salty side, but we were at the "Salt House", right?.

We order the Halibut and the Petrale Sole for entrees.  Both fishes were nice portions of perfectly pan roasted goodness.  Nice light brown, crisp exterior with moist, succulent yet delicate interior.  Props to the skillz in the open kitchen.  The veg under my halibut were english peas and carrots with bacon, guess what?  Yup a little on the salty side, but for crying out loud, I once reminded myself that I was at the "Salt House", again my bad.

Our Sauvignon Blanc from New York state was a good match as it were citrus-y, green apple-y, and minerally.  Nice cleansing sensation for the salty cuisine at "Salt House".  Would I return?  Probably, it's solid enough for me, but I would never bring anyone with high blood pressure or hypertension here, as it just might do them in.
author: D.wight L.

description:
Came here on a double date last weekend because I had heard from a friend that it was good.  We got there 45 min before our reservations hoping to be seated early, but the place was packed so that was out the window.  But, we got to sit (smushed) around a table in the bar area and got some bread and drinks and the gravy fries appetizer while we waited.

The service here is excellent.  Even while at the bar, we had a server who was on top of everything, refilling waters, bringing us more bread.  We were seated after 30 min of being at the bar, and our real waiter was excellent.  By this point we were all pretty full, so only one of us ordered entrees, and 3 of us ordered appetizers as our main meal.  Serving sizes are definitely small, so this isn't the place to share.  I had baked oysters which were pretty good, but not the best I've ever had.  My BF had pork belly...which was just like BBQ pork from china town but cooked too hard (don't order this!).  My friend ordered the scallops...and these were winners.  I would definitely get this again if I come back here.  

Also, before our food came, our waiter came to apologize about our food takng so long, and said "would you maybe like some mixed nuts cooked in truffle oil?"  We said sure, assuming that it was complementary since we had to wait.  But we made sure to check the bill and he had charged us for the nuts!  Tricky Tricky!  But, when we brought it up he immediately took it off...so it wasn't a huge deal.

I would come back here again because of its cool atmosphere and good service, but I think we'd order different things.
author: Cindy K.

description: I came here for dinner the other week and made reservations.  We got here around 7 and were seated immediately.  This place is a little bit on the loud side so it's hard to carry on a conversation. We ordered the poutine which was the fries with melted cheddar cheese and gravy.  You can either have them pour the gravy all over the fries for you or have them place it on the side. Overall, if you like your fries salty you will most likely like this appetizer.   Our other appetizer was our foie gras.  The portion of the foie gras was average. It was paired with a kumquat sauce and a rhubarb sauce.I think i prefer the kumquat sauce more, i felt that the rhubarb sauce didn't match as well.   Overall the dish was pretty good and the foie gras was seared perfectly. However, i was really disappointed in the main dish.. I ended up getting the short ribs, although it was moist, it felt that it had too much fat. It tasted a little average to me, and i felt that i can get the same dish with the same taste at a Chinese restaurant.   Overall, i'll probably come back here for the happy hour special and for their appetizers.  But i think i'll skip the entree for my next visit.
author: Belinda C.

description: This review is for drinks only . . . came here on a late Friday afternoon.  Had the vodka martini, margarita, and shot of tequila.  The service was friendly, the drinks were strong, and they had a pretty good looking selection of tequila.  Will definitely come here again after work!  Also interested in trying the food...
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
I've been here half a dozen times for lunch when I was in the area.  It's your typical yuppie new-wave style food.  Most of the clientele are businessmen on expense accounts and yuppies so they don't mind splurging on a meal.

The food is decent but a little high-falutin and quite expensive for what it is.  This is the kind of restaurant that serves expensive water and gourmet nuts.  Yup, I'm not kidding.  I guess some people just don't feel good about their restaurant experience unless they get gouged.

The interior goes for 1990's dot-com look with brick and lots of brown colors.  Pretty nice and a good change of pace.  

Would give this place 3 stars, except for the service.  They pulled a bait and switch on me during a friend's birthday.  The waitress pushed the dessert on us, even though my friend initially passed.  Then when we got the bill, they charged us for the cake they pushed on us!  Totally base and rude at what is supposed to be a "high-end" spot.

Go there if you are on an expense account.  Or if you are one of those people that believe in paying for special water.
author: John L.

description:
It's so shameful that it's been almost a year since I've been here and just writing a review. I must go again to write in detail what an awesome place this is but if memory serves.... 
I passed this place for many months walking to the bus after work and kept saying ONE DAY I MUST TRY THAT PLACE! 
It's as awesome on the inside as it looks from the cold outside! 
AMAZING FOOD! When you are making reservations (YES YOU NEED ONE!) ask to be seated upstairs especially if you're on a date. It's much nicer and muffles some of the noise of the bar area. Our service was friendly enough although, I think we were ignored a bit because we didn't order alcohol and the people around us were dropping hundreds on wines.
Since there are few set items on the menu the pictures on yelp are a bit of a tease!! I remember dreaming about the seared tuna but it wasn't a special the day we went. I did however have the raw tuna appetizer absolutely mouth watering! And for my main meal I had the chicken! BEST CHICKEN EVER! I don't know if it was the tenderness or the spices but all I remember is deliciousness!  For desert I shared the bread pudding I wasn't sure I could finish it because I had cleaned my other plates and I had never had it before. Although I was FULL at this point, I really didn't want to share haha! It was SOOO good!.
author: I Am Anonymous X.

description:
Had dinner with couple of friends on Thursday night. Because of insane101 traffic couple of us were late by 45 mins. The hostess was nice enough to find a table for us on a busy night.

Food was very good. From the appetizers menu, we tried the crispy shrimp, monterey squid, and autumn salad. The fried shrimp with green beans was really yummy. The squid dish comes with little fried nuggets with ground chickpeas inside - very tasty!

For dinner, I ordered the Coho Salmon. The salmon was cooked right - very soft inside. The sauce that came with the dish was particularly yummy. 

Finding parking can be an issue. We used the valet parking from the night club at the back of the restaurant.

The service was good too. Overall, thumbs up! Would come here again.
author: Bhaskar D.

description:
This place has the look but lacks the substance.

Came here with some coworkers a month ago and we were impressed with the loft decor and the exposed brick. We were seated right away (we did have reservations) and greeted promptly by our server. Once we ordered our food we ended waiting a good amount of time for it to come out. Our server kept assuring us that is was coming but she was wrong. We waited anxiously as we watched people that were seated  after us enjoy our meal. Once the food arrived it was pretty mediocre compared to other nice nice restaurants. Probably only come back if someone else is paying.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Odd hostess offering to go to their other restaurant, Anchor & Hope, instead of waiting but good culinary experience. I had an excellent petrole sole. 
Nice loft type building squeezed between skyscrapers.
author: D T.

description:
Hubby and I were there a few days ago with friends. We're definitely coming back (after we've saved up enough, this place is pricey).

Everything was absolutely delicious. We ended up having the Monkfish, Cassolet, Polenta and the Fulton Chicken. I thought the Monkfish was beautifully done, although the bed of cream and carrot chunks it came in didn't taste of squid as was promised. 

Deserving special mention were the mixed nuts roasted in truffle-honey... so simple, yet ingenious in what it did to a humble bowl of salted mixed nuts. The nuts, I thought, deserved 5 stars.

For dessert, we shared the dark chocolate brownie (super-rich) and the apple crumble with a side of gingerbread ice-cream. I thought the crumble had more cinnamon than it needed, but the oatmeal streusel redeemed it.

I topped my meal off with a latte. That had just the right amount of cream and full-bodied coffee. YUM-O!
author: Corrinne L.

description:
Setting: Close to financial district and union square

food: good food.
author: Sue C.

description: Excellent food and atmosphere.  I went with friends last night and had a great time.  We started with cocktails, which were perfectly prepared. The appetizers we ordered weren't my favorites (nuts and cheese,) though they were very good and loved by the others at the table. The chicken entree, however, was mind blowing. It was perfectly prepared with lots of flavor. I strongly recommend it if you like chicken - it's one of the best I've had.   Can't wait to go back!
author: Brad C.

description: Nice staff and consistently good food, AMAZING polenta! Very cute interior, good date place, yummy bread, and great wine selection :)
author: Lana L.

description:
2 times eat. Delicious. Meat. Different meats. Beef meat. Pig meat. Tasty. Mouth water. Enjoyment. So liking.

Poutine. Exclaim! Flavors. Textures. Satisfy mouth. 

Blowhards wearing suits. Talking about finances. Laughing like men from 1950s. Tacky. Crass. Don't distract me from flavors of meat. Cow meat. Pig meat. Flavors. Pleasure.
author: Colin M.

description:
I had the summer vegetable polenta. Everything was just so -so.
We ordered two entries, an appetizer, and three drinks, and it came to $150.

Salt in my wound!
author: Fonz Z.

description:
This is a pricey place for lunch but with the price comes quality. The decor is very cool and easily makes this restaurant the best place to hang out in the vicinity. Everything we ordered tasted great.

I recommend this restuarant for business lunches if you need to impress someone coming in from out of town and need something near by.
author: Juan V.

description:
There are two words in the English language that hold more significance than any other two words: gravy fries. That's right, I'm talking about gravy fries. There were so many good things about Salt House, but I will start with the gravy fries ... 

Gravy Fries: Yes, they were awesome. Every single one of them. Technically called the Poutine, they were fries, with short rib gravy, and cheddar cheese on top. Hands down, the best appetizer I've ever had at any restaurant ever. 

Entree: I had the salmon and was very pleased. The portions were a little on the small side, but when you have gravy fries as an appetizer, there's no reason to complain. 

Service and Ambiance: Both were very excellent. Most excellent, if you will. The restaurant is sleek and modern and our server was cheery and helpful. We were seated on the top level, which only takes up about half the floor space of the bottom portion. That means you can literally look down on people and make fun of them - always super fun. 

The only thing you should be warned about is the price. It's not cheap, but the food and the location makes it worthwhile. In summation: gravy fries.
author: Lupe P.

description:
Love Salt House!  Went there last night after happy hour and just another great experience.  We didn't have a rezzie but the pretty tattooed hostess grabbed us a prime table on the mezzanine level looking over the busy restaurant.  We ordered the flight of Spanish wines to share, which consisted of a rose, a lighter red, and a dark, hearty red.  Great selections!

We gorged on crusty bread served wrapped in brown paper with some lovely soft sweet butter.  Our tasty SF tapwater came in a old-fashioned glass milk bottle emblazoned with what I am presuming is the the Salt House crest, kind of bad-ass with its little skull!  We also had an order of the olives, marinated in orange, mint, and chili.  I wasn't a huge fan of these (I am boring and prefer plain, vinegary olives) but my partner is an olive connoisseur and liked them a lot.

For an appetizer, we shared the baked oysters, served in their own little shells with bacon, leeks, spinach, and breadcrumbs.  Very yum!  I can never finish restaurant meals on my own so we split an entree of the New York steak, with shallots and black olive crushed potatoes.

I need to give major props to our server and kitchen here - we would have been totally fine sharing off the same plate but they actually made us up two lovely half plates, both of which were just gorgeous and totally above and beyond!  I feel like so many restaurants seem annoyed by requests to share meals, even when most restaurant portion sizes are way too huge for just one person to eat, so this was really appreciated.  

Steak was perfectly done, tender and delicious, and the olive smashed potatoes were shockingly tasty.  I was a little iffy on these after reading the description, but they were really perfect, something I never thought would work so well, but they totally did!

After dinner, we drooled over the dessert menu, which had several delectable looking options, but sadly were way too stuffed to attempt!
author: Jaimie M.

description:
This place was on my list since it opened. I walked by it almost every day and wondered when I would find time to come here. Well that day has come this week. My friend took me here for my birthday. 

I was very surprised at the layout of the restaurant - so spacious, so open. There is a mezzanine level for more seating and a bar stand in the middle of the floor, which probably makes people who drink feel more a part of the eating crowd. 

We were greeted very promptly, the staff were very friendly, helpful and knowledgeable about the menu and the ingredients of the meals. I had the best Fois Gras here in my life. Petrale Sole with radishes and grapefruit sauce (what a weird combination) worked perfectly together. Chocolate mousse was heavenly, especially with a birthday candle in it!

The recap:

Food: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars
Restrooms: 5 stars

Company: 10 million stars!
author: Tatyana S.

description:
Guess what? Salt House is totally veganable! Bet you didn't think so, eh? I just had a very nice and fresh lunch there. We started off with some lovely cured Mediterranean olives. I adore olives. They're such a wonderful fatty rich food for us veggie peeps. They also had other veggie snackies (nuts and pickled veggies). Then, we enjoyed some delicious bread. It was the kind with the little points on it that I fondly remember from France! Extra points in my book for pointed bread! When I told the server I didn't eat dairy or meat, he got it right away. He served me the minestrone sans pesto and a big green salad with red wine vinaigrette. I left feeling stuffed and satisfied. For drinks, the mint lemonade was very refreshing and a nice touch to the menu. 

I would love to see a veggie main at a place like this. I spotted green beans and lentils on the sides of some of the meaty dishes. It would be so easy to take some of those and some of the grains from underneath the chunks of meat and create a beautiful veggie dish. If only all these bougie restos with their fresh seasonal foods would just add one dish made of these sides to their menus, it would be revolutionary for SF cuisine. Plenty of SFers would probably eat a vegan lunch given the opportunity to have an elegant plate at their favorite trendy restaurant, and there is nothing more green than giving up meat in a few meals a week (or uh, yunno, all of them.) Plus, and most importantly, I would be a seriously happy (and probably broke, but worth it) little vegan camper.
author: Jeani H.

description:
One Word: Poutine

So we giddy up to the bar for an aperitif and my friends starts talking about Poutine.  I'm like a whaty?

Um, think Glorified Chili Cheese Fries.....

Fresh Crisped Potatoes smothered with a white cheddar sauce and Short Rib gravy.  Heavenly.

Oh which reminds me... it would be lovely to have this hot dish atop a ski mountain on a cold day.  Mental note.  A plate of these for $20, add a cup of gourmet hot choclate for $5 and a Top Shelf Cocktail for $10 more.  I'd pay that price.  It would be a deal at Beaver Creek Resort where a hamburger went for $39 or was it $49?!?  Would work in Aspen and Vail too.  

Cocktails were great too... but the Poutine was out of this world.
