After we finished up we were off to Anchor & Hope... their sister restaurant down the street.  Apparelntly there is a 3rd nearby, would love to hit the three of them in one night.  

Menage Toi Baby!!!
author: Shiho F.

description: Fun atmosphere and great downtown location but food is tasty but not exceptional.  for the price, I'd prefer exceptional.
author: C W.

description: Not sure why this restaurant had been getting bad reviews. I was staying at the Palace Hotel. The concierge recommended this restaurant and it was only 2 blocks away. We went on a Saturday night and without reservations they seated us immediately. I had to catch a flight later on that night and I was out of the restaurant after appetizers and entrees within an hour! The service was excellent and the food was fabulous. The cocktails were love at first sip! I will definitely go back the next time I am in the area!
author: Thandeka M.

description:
We had a group of four, and everything we tried was very tasty.  Poutine, tuna tartar, heirloom tomatoes and pork belly started us off.  My favorite was the pork belly - the savory crustiness on the edges of the pork was so yummy with a dollop of huckleberries.

For our entrees two of us had the duck, plus a halibut and a monkfish.  My wife and I ended up swapping my duck for her monkfish - they were both good, we just liked each others better.

Deserts were also good - two fig galletes, a brown sugar ice cream, and I can't remember what I had - but it was good.

It was a little bit loud and hard to talk sometimes.  We were seated up top and perhaps the sounds was concentrated up there.

Overall, the food was all very good, the portions were a little on the small side, but if you go appetizer, entree, desert it is plenty of food.
author: Greg H.

description: Went for dinner on a Friday night. Love the decor. It was a bit noisy and we had trouble hearing our waitress. Food was generally pretty good. They give you loaves of French bread with housemade butter. We kept asking for more bread because it was so good. Shared the poutine with my hubby. The fries were good, but the gravy was a little fatty. The hubs thought the fries were too soggy from all the cheese. I had the roast chicken. Very artistic presentation with various sauces and some type of polenta with a dab of something fruity on top. Not sure what it was. My husband had the ribeye. He said it was okay. We were quite full from all the bread and potatoes so we skipped desert.
author: Eve S.

description:
First of all, I like salt.  Lots of salt.  For all those reviewers asking, "I wonder if the business name has anything to do with the seasoning?" Hot Jesus, take a moment and think about it.  In any case, salt (and butter and sugar) makes a whole lot of things taste good.  However, it's not overwhelming here--go to RN74 for that.  I could taste the salt in the bread there, it was that bad.

I love this place because the food is fantastic.  Period.  I've eaten at many different restaurants all over the world, and this is currently my favorite local place.  If you are ordering appetizers with your dinner, the serving sizes are sufficient for you to leave satisfied.  Also, I have always asked for suggestions on wine pairings from the servers, and have never been steered wrong.  Everything is priced on par with similar restaurants.

Only Cons:

--Services is Slooooow.  Not a problem if you're on a great date.  Otherwise, this could be an issue.  It was only a problem for me when they weren't quick enough to refill my wine glass, so I had to take matters in my own hands.  A major no-no all around.

--Service is Slooooowwwww.  Went there on NYE and was seated at 10:15 pm.  Did not get out until 12:30am.  Never guessed I would be ringing in the New Year at this place, but fortunately I had no other plans.  At least they were nice enough to give all the customers a glass of champagne, gratis.

--Restroom is shared with the nightclub in back.  Let your imagination fill in the implications of that.

Plus for the vegetarians:

--They are ultra accommodating in holding the meat elements of their appetizers and dishes.
author: Andrea Z.

description:
I meet a buddy for lunch and as soon as I walked in the hostess asked if I was Jason.  I guess she could tell cause my buddy and I were the only guys in hoodies in the whole place.  Everyone else was in biz attire.  The service was good they def didn't make us feel out of place.

The food was really good.  We had a couple oysters and I had the Duck Confit which was cooked to perfection.

The lunch was $30 a plate with tip and well worth it.
author: Jason S.

description:
Came here for lunch during a conference and we didn't have reservations so we sat at the bar table. I really like the ambiance and presentation!

Started off with a fresh mint lemonade (yummy!) and picked at my companion's Summer Veggie Salad which was nice. I enjoyed the Salt House burger with cheddar (good but nothing special), though I'm quite sad I can't handle onions because the side of onion rings was to die for (yes, I snuck one or two!). Service was friendly and quick.

Overall a nice experience. I'd like to come back and try breakfast or dinner sometime.
author: j k.

description:
Came here for a business lunch today, we had made reservations ahead of time and when we got there we were promptly greeted and shown to our seats. I was rather impressed with the service. - my cup of water and ice tea was always filled, when one of us got up, they would refold our napkin right away, and we were checked up on to see how our food was. The restaurant itself, is a brick and wood decor and has a very warm feel to it. 

We ordered the mixed nuts to share amongst us. It was quite delicious - warm nuts with truffle honey and sea salt! I ordered the chicken pot pie - it came with a side of mixed greens. It was perfectly seasoned, with chunks of fingerling potatoes, carrots, peas, onions and shredded chicken with a baked puff pastry. The burger looked quite delicious - it was huge with a plate full of thin onion rings. I'll have to try it the next time I go. 

Since it was a business lunch we did have to talk - and the place was a little loud. There was one point that the music was blasting in the speakers that I couldn't even hear myself at all. Reservations are def. recommended. By the time we finished eating - the place was packed and there were people wait. It's a little pricey for lunch -approx $15-$25 depending on what you would order. Great menu choices, comfortable decor, overall we had a great time.
author: Betty S.

description: favorite restaurant....love the poutines, ambiance and food. great place to go when your downtown.
author: Brian C.

description:
Went here for lunch yesterday with colleagues.  We had reservations and were seated immediately, and the place was not full when we were seated.  One of our lunch partners had to leave before we were served because it took so long to bring out even our appetizers that she was going to be late for a meeting.  It was nearly an hour after we were seated that our entrees arrived.  To sum it up:  our experience was way too slow, especially for lunch!

As for food, I had the burger with blue cheese.  The amount of blue cheese that they put on my burger could have been enough for 4 burgers.  I scraped off half of it and still found it over powering for the burger.  What were they thinking to pile blue cheese onto a burger?

As with my first visit, the food was the weak link.  Oh wait, the service was the weak link this time.  Too bad because I love the space.  Perhaps I should limit my visits to cocktails only.
author: Scott L.

description:
I had high expectations for Salt House.  Perhaps because I had a wonderful experience at sister restaurant Anchor & Hope and heard many pleasant reviews of Townhall.

The vibe, feel definitely is comparable to both... rustic fare with simple American cuisine.  But the food fell way short.  

The Poutine, french fries with gravy and cheddar, was spotted on many tables.  Perhaps I'm not a being a fair critic here, because I am not a french fry kind of gal, but these were just ok.  I do love that sort of texture of crunchy with gravy, but the fries were a bit run of the mill.  Gravy and cheddar I'd usually hoot and holler about, but I couldn't get pass the saltiness of the dish. 

The seared scallops and deep fried shrimp appetizers were slightly more satisfying.  Whoever is seasoning the dishes perhaps has an affection towards Emeril.  'Bamming' the salt generously did not have this audience member hootin' and clapping.

I found all the dishes to be fair... the ingredients were very fresh indeed, but the flavors were all very regular, except for anything with corn because they knew to pick the sweetest of the bunch.  My sole was nicely seared, but the accompanying chickpeas and cherry tomatoes did not add any real moistness to the crispy filet.   Chorizo was devoid of any spiciness.

Two of my companies fowl dishes (roast chicken and duck) had a substaintial portion, but wasn't anything to cluck about.  

Service and ambiance were a hit definitely.  Clean with great lighting and a nice buzz to the lofty space.  But in the end I had forgotten our dishes and didn't want to complete the night with the dessert course.
author: Chris T.

description:
I went to Salt House last night and I gotta say, I was disappointed. I'd heard great things and we got seated right away (assuming we left by 7:45 pm which was fine by us), but the service was really lacking. Our server checked in on us once (very quickly) during the appetizer and not again until we asked for the check. Call me needy, but I want a little more TLC, especially when I see her whizzing past me no less than seven times.

The other major bummer was that the NY prime, while tasty, had an entire slice (comes sliced into 4 segments) that was fat. Not some fat, but entirely fat. A kitchen that sends that out doesn't inspire a lot of confidence. I would have flagged this to our server, but again, never really saw her and didn't have the energy or interest to bother. (I was over it at this point.) 

Overall, there are too many good restaurants in SF with great food and excellent service for me to go back here again.
author: Jen C.

description:
Good atmosphere, bad food. 

I was most upset by the quality of the food and the prices. I usually refrain from ordering chicken at restaurants because it always seems to be dry. The waitress reassured me that it was really juicy, but guess what, it was dry. 

For the price we paid, I'd rather go to Chez Pannisse.
author: Angela L.

description: Big fan of the Salt House. Recently visited with a larger party (7) and were greatly accommodated (thanks Raegan!). Sat within minutes of our reservation time. Wine, cocktails, appetizers, and entrees were all perfect. It's safe to say that everyone in our group loved it, and the style of the restaurant is perfect from anything from dining out on a date to celebrating a special occasion. I recommend the poutine, blisted padron peppers, and the beef bavette. The space is small but they make great use of it. There is a tiny upstairs landing that houses a few tables which I think I will check out next time. Looking forward to visiting Anchor and Hope, as well as Town Hall as soon as possible. Definitely a solid place to go if you're looking for a nice dinner in the city.
author: Natalia W.

description:
Last night was the night that I finally got to try Salt House.

Where does one start with a review.  Okay, lets start with the service and ambiance. Our server was amazing! She was extremely knowledgeable about the food and wine. We asked for a few recommendations on wine and she described one as "leathery" but highly recommended it.  So we tried it and all I could think to myself was "this woman is a foodie and crazy at best for calling a wine leathery".  Well I ate my words!  While the wine was not my fav it did have a leathery quality about it.....  Next our server recomened the chicken dish based on our situation and it was truly one of the best dishes I have ever had. My girlfriend had the celery root soup and loved it and I had a bitter green salad (not my fav but I know others love this type of salad) 

We had the luck (and I am sure others might not see it this way but I loved it) sitting in the small tight long table in the window right in the corner. My girlfriend and I LOVED it. After a great meal and 2 glasses of wine later the bill was not that bad. 

Inside the place is designed and decorated amazing. However I am not a huge fan of its location in the city. It could be because I mostly do not have to be down in that area and find little need to be (other than this place).  But over all a great experience and highly highly recommend it.
author: Ryan B.

description:
So its been 4 months since I came here and from what I recall the place was not mind blowing.  Came with a friend for lunch, we both enjoyed our  meals but I definitely don't think it was a fantastic.  There are too many other supposedly good restaurants in SF for me to bother going back.

Staff were pleasant, restaurant was packed but they made us feel welcome and well attained to.

Portions were small but food was decent, I don't think it was worth the price though.  None of the meals jumped out at us
author: ORLA L.

description: Salt House has been on my list for a long time and I finally got to try it during a recent lunch date. I ordered the chicken paillard and absolutely loved it... the perfect balance of really yummy chicken, good dressing and veggies. The staff was super friendly and welcoming. Can't wait to go back!
author: Gina C.

description:
Classy urban loft decor with exposed brick and wood, from the same team that later opened up Anchor & Hope.

The menu is kind of meat-oriented so I come here more for after-work drinks.  Cocktail specials are delish (I like the Pimm's Crush) and the apps are all well-made.
author: Sid D.

description:
went again, this time on a saturday and must admit that this time we had a much better experience w/o all of the weekday crowds.

The food is still excellent but what really stood out on this trip was the excellent beer list which includes a few belgians, a california microbrew and then a few of the standard bar choices.
author: Joshua J.

description:
We went for lunch a few days ago and really enjoyed it. The room was full but it did not feel crowded, tables were a good distance a part.

We shared an order of the duck magret as the appetizer and our waitress actually had it split in kitchen which was a nice touch. The duck was rose as it should be. Great.

My main course was the Cassoulet "Ma Facon" - it was an interesting spin on a great French classic. The chef had added a very subtle broth with tiny cut vegetables at the very bottom of the dish. Intriguing at first but it did add a nice touch to the taste. Good dish!

Overall, we had a good lunch meal, it was not rushed. Only negative is the wine choice: nothing great whether it is by the glass or the bottle. And rather pricey for what it is.
author: Reza M.

description: I met a good friend after a while here. The service was very good. Servers were not annoying at all. Wine and food was very good. Would definitely repeat this experience.
author: Sina T.

description:
Lunch Review for 12/24/2009

The Good: 
1. There was an amazing bartender there when I went.  I recommend a cosmo.  It was an amazing color of pink and it was so smooth ... but strong.  Usually a brightly colored cosmo means it's been watered down, but this was not the case. 
2. My friends got the burger and the shellfish stew.  They said they were really tasty.  I stole some of the onion rings that went with the burger and they were a nice mix of sweet onions and salty batter.
3.  The manager that was on duty that day was super nice.  He was cheerful and really helpful for someone working on Christmas eve.

The Bad:
1.  Our waitress was clearly unhappy with having to work on Christmas eve.  She didn't smile or talk to us very much (and we are a cheerful bunch!).  Hopefully she's in a better mood outside of the holidays.

The Ugly:
1. The crispy shrimp need to be taken off the menu.  It look goods on paper.  Deep fried shrimp, green beans, ham, & almonds. Yum.  However, the shrimp are hot, the green beans are ice cold and anything but spicy, and the proportions are way off (six shrimp and three or four cups of green beans). It was bad.  I love green beans and could barely eat them.
author: Lara O.

description:
Thank you Salt House. Still maybe my favorite restaurant in SF. You continue to amaze in every aspect of hospitality. 

Went for my graduation dinner on Saturday, and was blown away yet again. First of all, I originally made an online reso for four, but ended up needing two more seats. I called in and originally they said they were booked, but after double checking were happy to accommodate. 

We sat, and were immediately sent out a round of bubbly for everyone. A very pleasant start to the meal. After ordering a bunch of apps, and opening one of the bottles we brought, they sent out an amuse bouche. A chilled asparagus soup, with some asparagus tempura and creme fraiche. I don't really like asparagus to begin with but I  found it fine and everyone else at the table lapped it up.

On to the apps! 

The poutine (of course): I don't think I'll ever be able to come to Salt House without ordering the poutine. I mean french fries and short rib gravy... come on. Hard to beat. 

The crispy shrimp with serrano ham and green beans: I've had this before and enjoy it every time, they change up the accompaniments depending on season. It was good this time, but I actually found it a bit salty this time. This is me just nit-picking, not to say it wasn't great, I just thought maybe a little heavy handed on the salt. The beans and ham complimented it perfectly.

Yellow Tail: I forget exactly what it was served with, maybe a soy bean and potato puree, or something similar. But it was cut perfectly, and seared beautifully. It was delicious.

Duck Confit: Oh, this was probably my favorite app. It was a rillet confited. Tender and juicy, seasoned well. Amazing. 

The scallops: Ok, these were amazing too. Cooked and seasoned perfectly. So good.

Entrees: 

Between the table, we got the short ribs, white polenta, and I got the chicken.

Honestly, by this time I was already so full, it was hard for me to really appreciate anything, but I've had the short ribs and chicken before. I know they change the menu daily, but they also use similar proteins and change the other stuff seasonally. The chicken was actually a touch dryer than last time, but was still really good. Served with a delicious bacon, potato and leek puree. mmmmmmm. short ribs were excellent as always.

We were all so full by dessert time, we probably would have just order 1 or 2 for the table. Thankfully we didn't have to. They sent us out the three options I'm sure we would've picked anyway. The panna cotta, the chocolate peanut butter cake and one other thing. All I have to say is the cake was out of this world. Some excellent cups of coffee later and we were done. And all so pleased with an amazing experience.

Everything from top to bottom was great. Our server, Jessie, was superb. She was attentive without being overbearing, and very pleasant. We were helped by everyone from the host to the managers, and the team seems to work very well together. Now I have to admit, that I am friends with one of the chefs there, but still, they went above and beyond to create a wonderful dining experience. I brought my best friend along, and I guarantee he will be back. Lord knows I will...
author: Parker H.

description:
solid 4 stars. I got to say i was more impressed with the appetizers than the main course selection... but the food was excellent.
And they have this Green Door Cocktail, martini with cucumber and mint, so, so, good.
author: anna p.

description:
Went here with 4 other couples for a special occasion dinner.  The night didn't start well because they didn't have my reservation.  Instead of apologizing, they grilled me on when I made it, who I talk to, etc.  Instead of offering to seat us at the bar (which was relatively empty) and have drinks while we waited, they made it seem like we were a pain and would be lucky to get a table.

All that said, once we got past the hostess station and sat ourselves at the bar, things got better.  The wait wasn't that long (surprising for a Friday night) and the service at our table was top-notch.  Our server provided an excellent recommendation for the second bottle.

The food was amazing. I'm not a big fan of poutine but it was done properly, the baked oysters & tuna sashimi apps were good but not mind-blowing.  My cassoulet however was dreamy, the steak and monkfish got two thumbs up.
author: Stef S.

description:
I came here with a gf Saturday night. We were 45 min early so we checked in and took a seat at the bar. We were seated promptly at 745p at a table that's been vacant right next to us the whole time. Oh wells...  

The server was very nice and made some suggestions when asked. We ordered the tuna tartare and pork belly salad for starters. The tuna was diced up with a lot of other stuff, so it took away the tuna taste, which I didn't like. The pork belly was crisp and just ok. 

As for entrees, we had lamb and NY steak. I didn't care for the meat too much, it was very chewy to me. I'm usually a prime rib fan so maybe that coulda been it. The corn and sauce it came with was delish though. There was a small piece of short rib that came with the steak, it was alright. Nothing impressive. My friend didn't care too much for her lamb. It came with something that looked and tasted like stuffing, so it was probably that. Weird combo, imo.

I had a very nice cup of cappucino and my friend ordered coffee, which was very weak. We shared the chocolate cake dessert, but it wasn't very rich and the texture was kind of hard. Like it's been in the fridge for a while. 

So, 2 starters, 4 (alcoholic) drinks, 2 entrees, 1 dessert, coffee, and cappucino, $90 each! Dammit, we shoulda brought our boyfriends...
author: Freckles H.

description: I thought the food was about average, the service was slow, and the prices were high.  The pork chop that I ordered was overcooked.  The ambiance was pretty good, and that was the only thing keeping me from giving it a 1-star rating.  I probably would not come back again.
author: Michael C.

description:
4.5 stars

We chose Salt House as the location for the office holiday dinner this year. As is often the case, we waited until the last minute to decide on where we'd like to go - always a fun predicament when you're planning a dinner from across the country. Luckily, I spoke with Colleen, their Special Events person, and she assured me that our group would have a reservation. From the moment we arrived, the servers at Salt House made us feel welcomed. We had a large table where we could talk and relax. The server was very patient with our questions, and our orders came out as requested. Everything was done with care - from our cocktails to our desserts. I had pork loin with brussel sprouts cooked with ham hock (so, essentially pork on pork action), and it was fantastic, with a crispy crust on the outside, and juicy in the center. The maple pot de creme? A little orgasm in a cup, with a side of ginger cookies!

My only complaint? The book that is marketed on EVERYTHING. It's on the website, on the door, with your check when it arrives, and on the bill itself. Really guys? You're such a classy establishment, the book on the table at the front is enough.
author: Morgan W.

description:
I know there's supposed to be some distinction between Salt House and its sibling, Town Hall, but I can't for the life of me remember what that is.  In my mind, the experiences meld together to form an uninspired chyme.

I've been to both of these places many times, nearly exclusively for business lunches, and for that specific function both venues are perfectly adequate, due to the atmosphere and demographics of the lunchtime crowd.  The food is adequate too, in the sense that it does its job (i.e. if you eat enough of it, it makes you full).  I am sure I will continue to return for these humdrum business lunches given the proximity of these locations to my office.  But I certainly wouldn't spend a dollar from my own wallet to eat at either of these places again.
author: Chris H.

description:
No, this was not my first time, and honestly, if I were reviewing my initial visit, it would sadly be a 2 star review.  I was incredibly disappointed with my first meal here, but...  I returned this past Friday for lunch and had a fantastic meal here.  My opinion of this restaurant has definitely changed.  I'm going out on a limb and giving a full 4 stars, in hopes this is a new and consistent change.

Food was stellar.  I started with the chilled spring pea soup... fresh and flavorful.  It was like sipping on a fresh spring pea.  What a fantastic way to start a meal.  My main course was the sole.  It was cooked to perfection, lightly crisp on the outter edges, tender and moist in the center.  There was a light broth, artichoke hearts, raddish, favas, arugula, and carrot.  It was a perfect combination.  Everything was extremely fresh, nothing was overpowering.  It had to be one of the best fish dishes I've had, period.

Service was on point.  She was friendly, attentive, and extremely effecient.  Generally speaking, it's a little pricey, but if their food is consistently on par with this particular visit, I personally don't have any issues dropping cash to enjoy it again.  I'll be back, for sure.
author: Kelly K.

description: Service was top notch even though it was getting close to closing time on a Sunday evening.  Salt House is for food lovers who want something special even if it means paying a little more than usual.  You can see the chefs in the open kitchen preparing their fine masterpieces.  Portions are small, but perfectly cooked, lots of flavor, and great for sharing.  We got the fresh tagliatelle and the Alaskan ling cod and they were excellent.  We ended our dinner with an almond tart and cheese board.  The tart was moist and warm; it was a great closer to our course.  The close-quarter, down to earth atmosphere doesn't seem to match the quality of the food; although, I really loved the mural on the back wall.  I'll def go back next time I'm in the SOMA
author: Sophia P.

description:
Happy Birthday to Me! 

I've been dying to try this place and it was "ok". Nothing special. Torin wanted to take me to lunch for my birthday and I got to pick. My picks recently haven't been great. 

We got seated promptly. Got bread and butter. But then lunch came - literally 30 minutes later. The duck was pretty good but nothing to write home about. I got the salmon. That was ok too. And we got dessert, the peppermint ice cream sandwiches. Eh. 

What is up with mediocre?!?!? 

Save your dollar and go elsewhere.
author: Lisa L.

description: Great ambiance and nice food.  Recommended for a great, low key night out in Downtown San Francisco.
author: Rachel H.

description: I have been at Salt House several times over the years and thought I would share a review. With a client and co worker for lunch and sat at community table near bar area. My co worker set up reservation on the wrong day. Petrale Sole (looked very good), Veggie Entree (OK), and Chicken Torta (Not good) as entrees with a side of onion rings. Chicken Torta was boring, no favor and expensive. Service was solid and helpful. I am assuming I chose the wrong dish. Many of the dishes looked good being served to the surrounding tables. I will the restaurant another try sometime. Back to sister property, Town Hall.
author: Gerry C.

description: All I wanted was poutine and since wayfare tavern took it out of their summer menu, we decided to go to salt house. We went on a Friday evening and it pretty empty. We had four people but still wanted to order two dishes of poutine anyways and it not very traditional. The beef gravy was very thiick but needed more sauce to cover all the French fries but the staff was very sweet in getting us more when we requested.
author: Janelle S.

description: Decent but not exceptional food, very slow service. I probably wouldn't go there again, as there are much better places in the city.  Excellent cocktails, though.
author: Brad B.

description:
Went here for the first time back when it opened and only went back recently. Although the restaurant seems to have lost its trendier clients (always available on opentable and seems to be lots of tourists) the food is still good. The poutine is a must and the main courses are filling although somewhat salty. Deserts are also great - peach pie was fantastic.

Unfortunately, the service definitely leaves something to be desired and drags down this review. Although the hostesses were friendly, our servers seemed disinterested. The bathrooms are also a bit dirty since they're shared with Harlot, the past-its-prime club in the back of the building.

In summary, this is a good spot for a spur of the moment night out
author: Magic M.

description:
I've had good experiences at Townhall and Anchor & Hope. So I had high expectations for this place. Boy was I disappointed.

The place was cramped. The food was not worthy of the price. I ordered the sea bass. It was over cooked and dry; the one sure fire way to waste a good piece of fish. I've heard raves from other people about this place. Perhaps the cook was having an off day. But it's hard to make a second impression in this town.
author: Gary S.

description: I've avoided Salt House for years (like it was ground zero for the bubonic plague) thinking it was going to be similar to its sister restaurant Town Hall (which I'm not a fan of).  You can imagine my disappointment when I was finally dragged to Salt House (against my will I might add).  Lucky for me, perception isn't reality - Salt House was far better than I thought it would be.  True, service was a tad slow . . . and dishes didn't come out in the order in which they should . . . but the food was surprisingly good . . . and at the end of the day the quality of the food is king when evaluating a restaurant.  Star of the meal was easily the day boat scallops with grilled asparagus and bacon.
author: Oski B.

description: Good but not great food and the server was only about halfway engaged.  Enjoyed the gravy cheese fries.
author: Eric D.

description: Great atmosphere, outstanding service. I love this place! Every dish was fabulous and so was the wine. I highly recommend the duck,  best duck I've had the the city and one of the best meals ever. Yummy!
author: Claire R.

description:
Tried this place on a Sunday evening for an early dinner.  Service was well-timed and we all enjoyed our food (and each others').  I really liked the interior decor too.  The building is very bare-bones industrial but has a lot of warming touches, like their funky plywood lampshades and warm yellow hanging bulbs over the bar.  

Food:
For starters we shared the smoked trout salad with horseradish dressing and beets - very well balanced sweet/spicy flavors, and the warmed nuts with truffle honey - which I could have eaten for my whole meal and been happy.  My pork cheeks were tender, juicy and melt-away soft, with an equally tender papardelle pasta that I suspect is made in-house or otherwise very fresh.  The sauce definitely had an asian feeling to it, very umami.  My friends had the halibut (very good) and steak (delicious with horseradish salsa fresca), we were all happy and well-fed.  And OH!  Get dessert.

Cons:
not cheap
food was very rich - watch out for a stomachache!

BONUS: this place is a few blocks away from the ferry building, making it easy for east-bay-ers to enjoy dinner without the traffic!
author: Katrina V.

description:
After eating the Crispy Egg -- a parboiled, deep-fried ovarian confection atop a mound of perfectly prepared lentils and chunks of merguez sausage spiced with enough harissa to make a meat-eater blush -- I finally know what it feels like to sleep with a supremely hot Natural Woman.

Three cheers for culinary heterosexuality. WOO!
author: d s.

description:
Salt House is housed in a freestanding old brick building that looks a little incongruous against some of the more modern buildings that surround it. Although the front door was of the super generic type that you'd expect to walk through if you were getting your taxes done or going to a bail bondsman, once inside the atmosphere is warm and stylish. Exposed brick and antiqued iron beams were offset by modern and soaring light fixtures and a bright clean open kitchen.

"So good. SO good. So GOOD!" The wife and I must have said that like twenty times over the course of our meal at Salt House so, yeah, let's just get that out of the way. The food is delicious. The food is billed as "New American" which loosely translated means "We can do whatever the fuck we want and use any ingredients we want so don't try to  label us, asshole." Like I said, it's a loose translation. I'm a chef of New American cuisine myself so, me and Salt House, we get each other.

The appetizers were amazing and there are lots of options although there was only one salad. Not that it matters when there's braised pork belly and Ahi tuna on the menu. One could easily make a meal of the appetizers alone. There's also a raw bar for those of you trying to get laid.

Entrees had a tough act to follow but they did not disappoint. Everything was nicely executed, beautifully seasoned with the flavors being bold and clean.

The service was great. Professional, relaxed and knowledgeable. And these dudes were on their SHIT. When my wife got up to use the bathroom and dropped her napkin, by the time she had stood up from picking it up there was already someone there with a new napkin. When the little old lady who was getting schnockered next to us sent her wine glass crashing to the floor there was someone there to clean it up almost before it hit the ground. The busboy was awesome as well. If I turned my head to cough (and for a quick hernia test) my water would be refilled, silver set and plates taken away. Seriously, he would be on the busboy All-Star team, you know, if there was that kind of thing.

Overall, a great experience and I believe I've found my new favorite restaurant.

As a side note, for those of you keeping track of my Weight Watchers progress, just let me tell you I probably consumed my entire day's points total before my second glass of wine. That's cool, I was eating "New American" which loosely translated means "I can eat whatever the fuck I want and WHO THE HELL ARE YOU TO JUDGE ME?"
author: Josua P.

description:
For my 2nd visit to Salt House we were to meet up with some friends for a Sunday night dinner. My BF had never been, so I was really excited to introduce him to the beautiful brick room with the crazy Quixote-esqe mural... and to one of the most amazing foie gras presentations EVER! 

We arrived a little early and opted to wait at the candle lit bar. Salt House offers house-blend wines in the most adorable little bottles in small, Medium, and LARGE sizes (small = 6 oz.), and while I'm generally a little leery of "house wine", I opted for the Pinot Gris / Chardonnay / Sauvignon Blanc blend, which was surprisingly really good! 

...as I'm writing I'm feeling pangs of regret for not slipping that cute little jug of wine into my cute little purse! But I digress.

So far, everything about Salt House is lovely. As it was a Sunday, the bar was quiet, the tables, full (with the exception of a 4-top that I  assumed was ours), and my BF is soaking up the exposed-brick and steel-beamed ambiance. But, glancing at the time, where, oh, where are our guests? Good question.

OK, so long story short, we were stood up! Yes, stood up! (Euge *cough* drunk in the East Bay *cough*cough*)  : \ 

But stuff happens, and all's well that ends well... we stayed and made a date out of it.

We opted to share some small plates and one entree, with the possibility of dessert to finish. Of course we had the foie gras (served 2-ways -- "cured", terrine-style, & sauteed perfectly with huckleberries ... or were they lingonberries?) which was amazing! I could have made a meal of it with a salad. But I didn't.

Next, we shared the crispy shrimp with green beans, almonds & Serrano ham. Wonderful! Crisp green beans & almonds, sweet, crunchy shrimp, smoky Spanish ham!  We also shared the mixed greens with baby chiogga beets, apples & Crater Lake blue cheese. I know, I know, typical. But I'm still a sucker for the classic sweet beet - pungent cheese combo!

For the entree, my BF opted for the wild striped bass. Sadly, by the time it arrived I was so stuffed on foie gras and shrimp and stuff that I was only able to enjoy a small taste... a taste that was not at all disappointing! Everything was wonderful. 

Salt House offers a well-balanced wine list, a full bar with interesting cocktails, and what looked to be yummy dessert options (hello apple turnover thingy with butterscotch!!). Just be sure to bring a hearty appetite... and the more guests the merrier so you don't gorge yourself on foie gras like I did.

But MAN, was it worth it.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
Salt house is considered New American Cuisine. According to wikipedia, "New American cuisine is a term for upscale, contemporary cooking served primarily in restaurants in the United States. Combining flavors from America's melting pot with traditional techniques, New American cuisine includes ethnic twists on old standbys, Old World peasant dishes made from luxury American ingredients and molecular gastronomy." 

I would go as far as to throw San Francisco in the same category. In fact I would have to say that Salt House may be the quintessential San Francisco restaurant. Upscale dining yet completely unpretentious. When you check out their website the first thing you are greeted with is this: "From the same jackasses that brought you Town Hall..." (FYI: Town Hall is still one of my favorite spots in the city.) The water is served in an over sized mason jar painted with a coat of arms bearing a skull on it. The back of the restaurant has a Ralph Steadman-esque mural. Modern industrial design throughout the restaurant... All completely unpretentious.

Of course the setting really doesn't matter if the food sucked. Thankfully this isn't the case. It was phenomenal in fact. We started off with the Suckling Pig. Prepared perfectly and disappeared within seconds. For dinner my wife had the halibut served over pesto-flavored beans. I had the marrow encrusted dry-aged prime rib which was served over a corn puree. Both were spot-on. To wrap things up we ordered a basque cake served with earl grey ice cream. I'm really not educated enough in the culinary arts to describe my food in great detail, so you're going to have trust me when i say it was damn good.
 
Along with our waitress, we had a team of employees who kept dinner flowing like a well oiled machine. Baguette delivered in butcher paper, water refilled, plates cleared, food delivered, napkins folded, etc. Not one single complaint. Not one complaint about the whole visit. 

Setting: Check. Food: Check. Service: Check. Will Bucky be back: Check.
author: Bucky K.

description:
I went here for lunch yesterday.
I ordered the hamburger with blue cheese.

The service here is terrific. I sat at the bar. Everything was very clean. The decor is filled with a great combination of wood and metal. The kitchen was in view.

With the burger they threw in some spicy onion fries. The fries really kicked ass. I loved them. The burger was cooked perfectly and I enjoyed every beefy morsel.

+  Good Service
+  Good Food
-   a little pricey for lunch ... my burger was about $17. The prices may go up in the evening hours.
author: Kristopher B.

description:
My husband and I had the best meal ever here!

We were up in SF for business and after a long day our hotel concierge suggested the Salt House for dinner.  We had no reservation and the place was packed.  We ended up sitting at the bar for dinner and had a great chat with the bartender and he gave us free desert wine!  SO GOOD!  All the wine was good.

The decor is great - totally loved all the raw wood and steel beams.  Great place to go to dinner with friends.

OYSTERS WERE SO FRESH! and the sauce was omg omg omg :-D   Best thing ever... I can eat those all day.  Next time I'm up there I am definitely going back for more... and I normally HATE oysters!  thats how good they are!

Everything we tried on the menu was excellent especially the froie gras. YUM.  Also great dirty martinis!  Always a plus with me.
author: becca w.

description:
It was so-soma. The atmosphere was great, loud with lots of people. We got seated after 15 minutes. Their were a ton of tables open but nobody seated?

I thought the food was good not great. I felt like with the size of the crowd the food would have been fantastic. The oysters were really good. 

If I was in the area I would go back.
author: Peter W.

description:
In anticipation of dinner at Salt House on a Saturday night, not only did I brush my teeth, I also washed my hair.  Now maybe you're thinking "wait, you're proud of performing basic acts of hygiene?"  Well, being that I'm currently in the middle of the seventh layer of Hell known as "law school finals," yes, bathing IS a major accomplishment.  As is changing out of my pajamas, eating solid food, and managing to talk to my neighbors in anything other than grunts.  My inability to function in normal society isn't the point, though. 

Salt House made showering worth it.  Sure, it probably helped that I had a hot date, but the food was delicious (salted caramel fudge bar for dessert? Swoon!), and we were able to take our time at the table without feeling rushed.
author: Jess T.

description:
+++++ Foie Gras that makes the eyes roll WAAAAAY back. Artery-clogging!
 --         I am a BAD BAD BAD person. Those poor widdle ducklings. 
++       Cozy seating by the stairway. Though hidden from plain sight, not forgotten.
+          Awesome space with lots of brick and beams.
 ---        Yucky, dark, dirty bathrooms. Most likely shared with the club in the behind.

The rest of the food was good, but not outstanding. I waited a few months to write the review, so that I was not unfairly influenced by the fact that I was at Sinbad's [now THAT place is unacceptable] earlier in the evening. I would definitely go back for appetizers and drinks. I could [and WOULD] probably make a meal of that foie gras. Just add a dessert. Maybe a frozen yogurt down the street?
author: Tinna H.

description: while having lunch there with a friend, first thing i notice is that their menu is printed a simply piece of paper. they can't shell out for more impressive menus?! well, i didn't go there for their menus, right? when we went in, it was crowded and very loud, so we ended up cramped up behind the stairs. not exactly the most comfortable place to be seated, but there frankly wasn't anywhere else. initial observations; i like the space itself, location and the decor. the food wasn't fantastic, but wasn't completely horrible. overall, it was tasty, well-seasoned, but unimpressive. service was fantastic, considering we were in the corner, so i'd think it'd be easy to forget about us. it's a good place in general, but personally, it's overrated from what other people/friends say.
author: Mike C.

description:
Salt House is going to be a hit, and you don't have to be a culinary Nostradamus to know that. First off, it's from the jackasses (their term, not mine!) who brought us Town Hall, so you know you can expect a casual and boisterous elegance. You know the menu will offer interesting takes on American classics. And you know the staff are going to be enthused and cool, but certainly professional. 

But still, when I went in this Friday night, I was thoroughly impressed and surprised. Salt House is a winner on so many levels, even though the space is not even fiNished (the mezzanine level has yet to be built, stairs and all!). 

As mentioned above, the restaurant/bar has a very casual and familiar feeling - it's the sort of place where you can meet new friends or certainly run into old ones, like I did. 

While waiting for our table, I ran into the former owner of Tallula, who is now behind the bar at Salt House. Without getting into how much I miss Tallula, let me just say that having Harveen over at Salt House is just another indication that this place is going to be a fixture for anyone who gives a damn about good food and good times.

Ok, so yeah, I ran into some people I know. Get to the point, right, which is the food. Well in this department, Salt House does not disappoint. The menu is relatively small and simple, but I still had trouble deciding, since everything sounded good. The oysters (miyagis, fanny bays) were a fun and fresh way to get things going, so get a few to split and tease your appetites.

In terms of starters, the crispy shrimp was definitely a standout, but their are also sides like the mixed nuts with honey and salt that seem like they should be at every table.

I went with the New York Strip for my entree, which was perfectly served medium rare, just the way I like it. I'm holding out on giving this place my full seal of approval until I try a couple of more dishes, plus I was somehow not completely happy with the chocolate bundt cake and apple galette we ended with. Both were sweet, but didn't seem like the closers we were hoping for. 

From a wine perspective, the menu offered many choices to suit every taste and price level. Our server was great about recommending the a Domain Charbon Syrah, which managed to go with the varying aspects of our dinner. Quite nice!

With lunch about to be served, I can't wait to make Salt House a regular destination - billed as a "urban tavern," I can see it being that restaurant for all occasions, and solid proof that the sophomore slump has not come down on Doug Washington & Co.
author: Nish N.

description: Went back again and this time tried their poutine!  YAY!  It was delicious and Fatty!  Just as I expected.  I also tried their Italian Divorce drink.  Whew that was strong!  Excellent!
author: Delilah B.

description:
There are at least 49 different reasons I look forward to seeing the lovely Miss Grace on any given occasion.  

This particular evening, however, one of those reasons was to help demonstrate to the staff at Salt House that I am indeed interested in women.

While waiting, I was mistakenly identified as the other half of a gay blind date.  By BOTH guys who were supposed to be on the date.

Now those of you that know me understand that I'm flattered by anyone and anything (don't ask) that is attracted to me so that part didn't bother me.  In fact, the first guy looked a little bummed when I said I wasn't who he was looking for.  Score.

Icing on the cake is when the host then walked over to us and said, "I see your date has arrived, are you ready?"

So when Grace did arrive, I looked back and gave the host a little nod like "that's right dude...eye candy....FEMALE eye candy."

Now having said that I am interested in women, I might have to switch teams to hang out with the chef at Salt House.  

Any man that deep fries eggs, makes fois gras that melts faster than butter and puts that much cheese on a pile of fries is marriage material.  

I am rolling with 4 stars on this one.  The dessert messed with my head a little.  Both Grace and I saw eye to eye on the fact that the tartness of the cranberries should have been left out.

The place is cool for sure and the staff is VERY helpful.  Running next door to get Tabasco.  Who does that?

I would attempt to classify this as a place that serves casual comfort food while you are going there to see and be seen.  

And yeah, there goes my bank account.  I tasted the 18yr old scotch.  

Next time I see Grace I'll be wearing a kilt, playing some bagpipes and will be completely hammered on the stuff.  

Braveheart.
author: Archie R.

description:
If you want to read a more useful review, go read Nish's or Preet's or Phil M's. Especially Preet's since she had the same appetizers that we did. And Phil's because he describes the place better than I will. And Nish's because he'll get mad at me if I don't tell you to read his reviews (kidding). 

But, here's my half assed review - though it's not as half-assed as the reviews that were written before this place even opened. I'm happy this place opened - right around the corner from my office. I wish the bar were a little bigger because I'm a lush and so are my coworkers. The service was great, the wine selection was ample, the cocktails were good. But there's one real reason to go here:

The chicken!!!! Seriously, you will never hear me rave about chicken in a restaurant. But I'm still seeing the Chinese medicine man and he says I can't have beef or lamb or anything fun, so I ordered the chicken on our waiter's recommendation. Holy shit - it was seriously the juiciest chicken I've ever had in my life. And had a great flavor. My friend got the New York strip and he was jealous of my chicken. Yes, it's that good. 

Go there. Get the chicken.
author: Suge K.

description:
They don't call this place Salt House for nothing!  Both times that I've been here, a heavy hand of salt must have been used to prepare my food.  First, it was the crispy shrimp green bean salad I had on one occasion.  Then, it was my corn soup on another.

When Salt House first opened, I was dying to eat here solely for one thing: poutine fries.  I love LOVE LOVE poutine fries!  I used to visit Toronto regularly and was always on a mission to find the best poutine fries (to date, my favorite ones hail from the Costco in Scarborough!!).  Who doesn't love fries, cheese curds and gravy?  Okay, maybe just me.  Well, Salt House definitely makes a much classier version (perfectly cut fries, sparse shredded cheddar cheese, and a separate gravy dish to dip your fries in).  It was pretty good, but I think I prefer the less healthier and less classier version of gravy-drenched cheese fries.

I've only been here for lunch and the food has been okay.  Nothing mind-blowing.  I have a feeling dinner is probably the best meal for dining at Salt House, so I'll give it another try one day.  I really like the decor though.  The brick walls, the cool upper level seating, and the mason jars used as water glasses.  Service is a hit or miss.  The other day, I asked for simple syrup for my iced tea.  The waitress didn't know what that was.  Ummmm...
author: Diane L.

description:
I made my way over to Salt House today for the first time since having wine at the bar with friends once a long time ago.
So... Today it was just me and I showed up pretty late and once seated the hostess reminded me that I had about five minutes to order !
Hey better late than never so I took a strong hard look at the menu and got down to business.

So at this point the server hadn't come around for a few minutes and I was worried about being able to eat today however when the server arrived she made me feel completely unrushed for the rest of the afternoon. Cynthia the angel !

When checking out the menu I have to admit they keep it pretty dry as far as describing the dishes in all their glory so Cynthia did a great job in letting me know about the dishes I would like because today my quest was for comfort food.

My final choices were the Roasted Beets $12 and a Braised Lamb Shank Sheperds Pie $17 along with a Milos(house) blend white wine 12 oz for $12.

While waiting I watched a few other dishes arrive around me such as the Poutine $11 which they are famous for. All I can say is everyone was mmmm'g up a storm about it! Their Chicken Paillard Cobb Salad almost made me change my order, it's a really smart looking larger salad.

So here come my Roasted Beets. It was a good sized (medium) salad with the beets underneath the fisee, chopped fennel,asian pears,endive and Pt. Reyes blue cheese in a vinargarette that was heaven. I swear this was the best Beet salad I have ever had. 5 stars

Then came the Braised Lamb Shank Sheperd's Pie. It had a red onion jam/celery root, pickeled radishes description on the menu.
IMO what I really tasted was... at the bottom with the braised lamb was a terrific reduction of onion with a sweet and zesty savory sauce. Then there were fresh sliced carrots on top of that and then it was topped off with at least an inch and a half of mouth watering mashed potatoes.
When served it was still simmering.

Food...5 stars/ Wine...4 stars
Service ...5 stars, ask for Cynthia she's really lovely 
Ambiance.... 5 stars, I personally like the front of the house.
author: Katherine N.

description:
+2 foie gras - melt in my mouthgasmic
-1 guilt - gavage method on the ducks
+1 awesome decor/ lofty look/ambiance  
+1 friendly waitstaff
+2 cozy spot behind the staircase facing the street!!!!!!!
-1 non-impressive lamb shank (i've had better at half the price)

they gave us three options..
a) wait 45 minutes for a table
b) sit at the bar/shared big table
c) sit behind the stairway

c!!! im so gonna be troll and grab peoples legs as they pass by


I don't know why i realllly love the lofty/steel beams look. If I could live here I would.. 

I will discuss further.. but i have no time.. scallops were ok.. and i don't really like them in general.. yay for that.

Sorry Donald, Daisy, and Daffy... Seeya! Wouldn't wanna be ya! 

As Herbert the creepy old guy from Family Guy would say.. "Get cho fat ass back here"
author: Donna H.

description:
Dear Salt House,

Thank you for serving me REAL duck confit and not insulting me with anything less than a delectable duck leg that had been simmered for hours in duck fat and then broiled to falling-off-the bone perfection!  

Your blackberry lemonade seemed like a good idea, but it was a little anemic.  I confess that it slaked my thirst, but it was also $5... and made me think of how I used to make lemonade from the fruit off the tree in our backyard... and sell it for 5 cents a Dixie cup.  Then I started thinking about the rising price of oil/black crack and how much gasoline costs... (should I buy a hybrid, or an EV?) and then I realized I needed to focus more on my beautiful duck confit.

The white polenta with cippolini onions and spring vegetables was phenomenal, and not overwhelming, but perfect, proportion-wise.  I actually ate the polenta and accompaniments BEFORE I truly delved into my confit... which is (a) contrary to my devoutly carnivorous nature and (b) speaks volumes about the scrumptiousness of the ENTIRE dish.  

I love the loft/industrial decor... although the woman who sat at the 2-top behind me discovered two golf-ball sized holes in the floor, when the leg of her chair took a dive and knocked into my seat.  No harm, no foul.  But plug the holes!

I promise to return with an empty belly to sample more of your daily offerings when I am not pressed for time on a business lunch.  I think that we can really have a long-term relationship.  I think I love you!
author: Kim D.

description: I've been here a couple times for drinks. Its a small bar with not much standing room. I came here for lunch once and ordered the pork chops. They were just OK. For the price, I probably wouldnt order it again. I would come back and try something new though. Good overall experience.
author: Huy T.

description:
A couple of things inspired me to yelp Salt House.  1.  A NYT article mentioning a move towards heartier  (read:  fattier) fare and away from ascetic "California" cuisine (http://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/13/dining/13glut.html?_r=1&ref=dining&oref=slogin) and 2.  Last night's opening episode of Top Chef where the contestants prepared dishes with lesser-known proteins,  in particular, Sara's presentation of her black chicken (silkie) with the claw sticking out in brazen, primordial form.

Salt House is not food for the meek or light tummied.  It is protein fortified.  It is hearty.  It is brazen.  It is welcome. 

The poutin, for example, with perfectly fried, golden fries, short rib gravy and cheese, is seriously filling and could easily qualify as a meal in itself.  The flavors, however, were not overpowering.  You can taste the freshness of the potato (I kept thinking "Kennebec, O, Kennebec") and the cheddar; the short rib flavor is not dominant, however.  The comfort of eating fat + starch + protein is the real draw to this plate.

After the heavy poutin, I opted for their lightest entree, seared tuna with wild asparagus, morels and nettle coulis.  I don't remember tasting nettles before. But take the earthy spinachy nettle coulis with the rich morels and 3 huge hunks of tuna and you have a lovely mix of rich and earthy tones, on their "lightest" entree.

I also tried the roasted fulton valley chicken with fingerling potatoes and merguez, very tasty with crispy skin; and Amy C.'s sole with red wine braised calamari with fennel, also tasty.  Portions are substantial, and, again as the rich and hearty ingredients bespeak, not for the faint of appetite.

The desserts were also homey and filling.  We opted for the strawberry trifle with shortbread cookies and the chocolate fondant with cooked cherries and pistachio ice cream.  Both were good.  I loved the thick custard, fresh strawberries and light whipped cream on the trifle; the sponge cake wasn't for me.  But the shortbread cookies hit the spot.  

They serve the trifle in a preserve jar.  And also in keeping with the unfinished theme of this place, Salt House serves their water from glass jugs stamped with a skull and crossbones and huge hunks of bread on brown paper. 

The decor is intentionally unwrought, but with a modern gloss.  With its exposed walls; restored old hardwood floors; large, unadorned windows with sunlight flooding in; large communal table; and a galley kitchen, I really love the design and feel of this place.

I walked in expecting, "yet another New American seasonal place."  My expectations were not fulfilled.  Happily.
author: Natasha S.

description:
I had no expectations of Salt House other than really cool people checking each other out being cool, and a brick wall.

I probably would not have made too much effort to try Salt House because when so many people talk about a place sometimes the hype can lead to disappointment.   That said, I was invited to SH to be treated for my birthday.  When someone is treating, you don't ask for a different restaurant.  

So WOW.  My evening at Salt House was the best dining experience I've had in SF in at least the past two years.  

Yes there was a brick wall but the rest of the design is perfect.  Not "hip" just plain old great design.  Modern and classic mixed perfectly together to create a cozy atmosphere.  Slight noise but you can hear your mates.  The tables were not crammed together which is super nice.  They thought of all the details down to the seal on the menu.  Nice!

Service was impeccable, not snooty, not in our faces, just right - almost intuitive.  No rushing at all.  We gave our first course order of the shellfish plateau, drink, and starters and our server asked if we wanted to wait to order our main courses.  Sure why not!   My mates all ordered a bottle of wine while I ordered my usual "The 35" which the bar made to perfection.  Whenever my drink got close to being gone, I would blink and in it's place was a fresh full glass.  Where did it come from?!  

Not sure if this is their thang but our menu for the evening had a seafood emphasis.  We ordered the following:

Shellfish Plateau - mussels, clams, oysters (malbec, miyagi, etc. etc.) shrimp ROCKING

Wild Ramp Soup - ROCKING

Spring Vegetable Salad - So fresh and special.  All sorts of yummy fresh/crisp perfectly dressed veggies.  Delicate and just the right amount.  ROCKING

Tai Snapper Red Wine Braised Calamari and fennel,
Petrale Sole Fava Beans Bacon Brown Butter Jus, 
Shellfish Stew Snap Peas Leeks Orange,
Alaskan Halibut Sweet Shrimp Artichokes Turnips.

Every entree was incredible and perfect.  Fancy food without being stuffy.  Just good simple fresh ingredients done right.

Dessert was Rhubarb Crisp with Lavendar icecream (OMG), Strawberry Shortcake (whatever you call the thing that has layers. . .oh what is it called), and chocolate bar with peanuts and salted caramel sauce.  I am so in love with this whole salted caramel fascination.  Everything should have salted caramel in it.  Desserts were hot.  Even my coffee americano was top.  

If I could, I'd eat at Salt House once a week.  My favorite new spot. 

Did I mention how totally great the staff was to us?
author: James M.

description:
Ritual coffee in the morning downtown?!? Say what? 
I highly suggest to those of you still chilling in the dark ages waiting in lines at Sbucks and Peets to actually have a pleasant start to their morning by indulging in Salt House's new morning cafe. I've never had a better breakfast sandwich, the coffee is delish and it's so nice to be in a mellow environment instead of surrounded by CDs for sale and logo coffee mugs. Not to mention that you might be to hang out with Doug Washington for a bit, and who's complaining about that?
author: Emily G.

description:
I've been back to the Salt House several times since my first visit, and it's still a place that I recommend to people for a nice, casual dinner in that part of town.  The environment is always lively and the food is good.

However, I have to give them an extra-special shout out for the EXCELLENT service that I received last week.  Through a series of miscommunications and crossed signals, I ended up sitting by myself at a table for 4 on a weekday night, for about an hour.  While I waited, I ordered a couple of appetizers, a glass of wine, and ate a lot of bread.  I finally ate the appetizers and decided to call that dinner.

I felt bad to be one person at a 4-top, so I kept offering to move to a smaller table in the event that my party did not show up.  They were extremely gracious and let me hang out as long as I wanted to.

When I decided that the evening was a lost cause, I asked my server for the check.  She said, "You have no check tonight, it's on us."  As I was leaving, one of the hosts said that he was sorry that my friends did not show up, and that they were happy that they were able to take care of me in some way.

I was so touched an amazed by their warm spirit and generosity that I hugged my server.  What started out as a disappointing night turned into a renewal of my faith in humanity.  I am writing a thank-you letter to the manager today, and you can be sure that the Salt House will receive a lot of future business from me.

Thank you, Salt House!
author: Liz S.

description:
My lovely dining companions and I had dinner here before heading around the corner to Harlot on Saturday night. It was a good thing we had reservations because the place was packed. We shared the crispy shrimp with spicy green beans, serrano ham and toasted almonds to start. It had a nice kick to it and was a good portion to share. I had the duck leg confit. The skin was deliciously crisp and the meat was very tender. My friends had the tai snapper and the petrole sole -- I had a taste and both were very good. For dessert, we shared the strawberry trifle with shortbread cookies. The whipped cream in the trifle was so yummy, I could have eaten the whole dessert myself!

I really enjoyed the food here, but the service was spotty. Our dinner lasted nearly 2 hours and when we received our check, 2 glasses of wine that we didn't order were added to it. Though our server apologized, the bartender who made the addition argued with her about it. It seems that they still haven't smoothed out all their kinks yet, maybe give it another 6 months?
author: Connie C.

description:
What can I say about Salt House other than, can you please clear out all of the tables and kick everyone out so I can move into this restaurant and live? :)

What a fantastically cool looking space. The natural light surrounded by amazing walls and even a little loft area. Oh my, just fabulous! But the awesome decor and space came in second to the delightful lunch the other Yelp Stephanie and I shared here this week. 

We started with the featured Orange Cranberry soda with fresh lime drink thingamajig and it was really tasty. We then ordered the Poutine and for those of who have never tried a Poutine. Wow. It's fries smothered in a short rib gravy and bravo farms cheddar. Yum! 

We then moved onto the Winter salad with apples, beets, blue cheese and these tasty candied walnuts! Sooo delightful. Finally for our main course we shared a lamb and ricotta gnocchi dish that was really rich and tasty. 

I swear, it is lunches of this caliber that drain my bank account week after week, but ya know what, you can't take it with you, so why not enjoy it while you're here :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
casual cali cuisine.

with 8:30 rezzies, we had to wait 25 mins for our table.  this place was hoppin'  the bar area was small and was very crowded.  i sipped an old cubano while i waited to be seated.

the loft setting with exposed brick walls made me think of a cool nyc apt.  no peaceful zen state here.  the sound was quite deafening.  definitely not an intimate date place.

yes, i do admit, i am french canadian so i had to order the poutine.  the server did warn me that it was an upscale version with bechamel cheese.  i still prefer my hometown's version with cheese curds but salthouse's version was homey and filling.

the pickled veggies and olives were good to nibble on before entrees.

things that could be improved were the wine selections.  all about the same price - affordable and not amazing.  i would rather have a couple of more expensive choices and pay for better wine.  

but i am a pinot noir snob so take that advice with a grain of salt...no pun intended.

i also felt a little rushed with plates being cleared and an unrequested bill set on our table.  how tacky.  and the place was not hoppin' at this late point in the evening.  so i docked them a star.

for entrees: the lamb shank was soft and falling off the bone.  the steak was undercooked but i liked it that way.  

for dessert: the citrus tarte was ok and the chocolate cake was good.  the desserts don't compare to those at aqua but it went with the more casual flair of this place.

overall salthouse had the A16 plating with town hall casual feel in soma.

cool place for drinks and dinner with friends destination.
*though try not to eat at the bar.  too crowded to enjoy a meal.  i was passing my amex to the bartender between two lovebirds.
author: Anh V.

description:
On the positive side ... the oysters were very fresh and delicious.  Our appetizers were very tasty and interesting.  Some of the entrées were the best that we have had for a restaurant like this in the City.

However, ...  Presentation and timing were really off.  The oysters came out at the same time as the appetizers, leaving us with competing decisions and a crowded table.  Some of the entrées were cooked to varying levels - the exact same piece of fish came out at runder done, done, and over done.  

And service left much to be desired.  Everything was off by  1/2 a beat.  Too long for the wine order, too long to check in on us, too long to bring the bill and pick it up, etc.  And, as an added benefit, we were over charged.  So ... we had to wait an inordinate amount of time just to tell the waiter that they had added 3 extra things to our bill that we didn't order.

In short, not what you would expect from a place with this type of reputation and price range.
author: Brian M.

description:
I've been forced to hold back the elusive fifth star due to a lack of molten-like characteristics of the warm chocolate cake.  

If I could, I would give Salt House 4.5 stars.

So jumping right into things, it's obvious that we had the warm chocolate cake for dessert, which was nearly delicious... true I am a sucker for molten or lava-like chocolate desserts, this one was not far off, and in all fairness... they did accurately print it on the menu as "warm."  Why they don't just step up their dessert game and make it molten is a question of which I don't currently have the answer to.

One other factor going into the missing star is that in the middle of being checked in by a friendly host... this woman, whom I think was probably the hostess-in-charge just sorta butted in and was like "I'll tell you what guys, your best bet is to grab a seat and eat at the bar or one of the communal tables over there" in a very biyatchy tone.  We had to remind her we had a reservation and were about to be seated by her colleague before she so rudely butted in.  She was apologetic and it wasn't a big deal but I think it tells you a little bit about their/her overall attitude.... a little bit full of themselves.

Ok.. enough complaining... 

crispy shrimp: delicious
king salmon: delicious
bottle of artesa chardonnay: delicious
the bite of ribeye I had: delicious
warm chocolate cake: potentially delicious

Overall, I highly recommend checking this place out.  It's a cool space with great service and a decent (though at 11pm: rather drunk) crowd.  It's right next to Harlot which could make for some fun after-dinner debauchery.

P.S. We sat by a bridge-and-tunnel-white-chick whose boobs were definitely about to make the leap for freedom out of her halter top.
author: Derek B.

description: Meh, I've experienced much better at what they charge for lunch menu, or dinner for that matter.. yeah much better. Service was good though
author: F E.

description:
I'm pretty surprised how vastly different review to review is for this place.  Having spent the day walking the Embarcadero and Piers like a tourist we missed the movie we were going to catch and waltzed into Salt House an hour ahead of reservation. Explaining our plight to the hostess, she was more than happy to seat us.

The large picture windows in the entry and long room gives the place a spacious feel even though it's not a large restaurant. The exposed brick/metal, wood floors, and surreal art provide a unique ambiance. We were greeted with water and crusty bread immediately as we perused the menu. As we perused the menu I noticed the modernization of an array of international comfort foods. Almost every time I see brandade on the menu I usually get it but I was piqued by the fact that they had Poutine, the food every single one of my Canadian friends talk about. So we had to start with that. For the entrees we went with the cassoulet which included white beans,sausage, plus duck confit and the roast chicken with chorizo roasted potatoes. The poutine came with fontina and a short rib gravy, which seemed very gussied up from the cheese curd version I'd been described. It didn't matter however because it was super tasty. Simple dishes shine with the best ingredients and that showed in the poutine. Our entrees were also simple but well crafted. The familiarity of flavors of the comfort foods enhanced by the chefs touches and twists.

What made the evening better was the service. Not sure if it's the time we slipped in, the fact that it was Sunday, karma was just on our side or what but it was excellent. Very attentive, always making sure we were enjoying ourselves. I couldn't ask for anything more. The crowd was a bit older than I thought it would be but it was also pretty diverse so I'm not sure i could describe it.

A perfect ending meal to a great day. It's unfortunate that from other reviews that it's inconsistent because if Salt House is always the way I experienced it, it would be a new regular destination for me. I'll definitely be going back and hoping for the best.
author: Kim N.

description: Excellent service, the waiters are cordial and have full knowledge about the menu, wine and drinks. The food was delicious. I read on here about the foie gras was amazing and I have to strongly agree. Recommend you go try it before it is banned in California. Also you have to try the duck, cooked to perfection with a soft inside and a crispy and tasty skin. I will go again pretty soon.
author: Alan M.

description:
This reviews marks the last installment of my birthday weekend trilogy. (To follow the chronology, please refer to "XYZ at the W Hotel" and "Kennedy's Irish Pub and Curry House.")

Without my trusty chaperone, two Yelp events prior to meeting my parents for dinner could have been a serious flirtation with disaster. I could picture the following scenarios a) passing out somewhere at the MUNI yard standing up these two fine people who raised me or b) showing up completely sauced, knocking over tables, starting fights, and setting fire to the kitchen. You know when it happens in the movies, but is less funny in real life.

Thankfully neither a) nor b) occurred. I showed up for dinner with my parents and sister, pleasantly buzzed and thus able to communicate and enjoy my family's conversation and the delicious repaste provided by the folks at Salt House. My starter, the corn chowder, was the hit of the evening. The monkfish with clams and bacon was also very tasty, as was my cheese plate. They have a very good menu, and also will deduct corkage fees if you BYOB, provided you order at least one bottle from them. 

Unfortunately, some uninvited guests crashed our party. I believe you may be familiar with the Periplaneta americana, otherwise known as the American cockroach? Yeah, you hate it when they show up too. They never bring anything and they drink all your liquor. Fortunately, they showed up too late and missed out on dinner and dessert, rearing their ugly heads on the wall next to our table, before my moms made mincemeat of them with her napkin. Go mom!! She survived WWII, she's not about to let some critters ruin her daughter's birthday dinner. 

Apparently, the construction next door is responsible for the infestation, and the restaurant has sprayed numerous times. They took our dessert and coffee from the bill, although I think they should have deducted more, but i understand it's not their fault.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
I was promised the addition of a homemade veggie burger to their menu. 
Doug are you reading this?
author: Wakako U.

description:
The place has to be good, if you can't get reservations till 10pm!  The interior has that exposed brick wall\modern theme to it.  It reminds me of Nopa and Town Hall thrown together.  Very relaxed atmosphere!  There were really good things and really bad things.  

It's always better to start with the good:
Pastrami Ribs- taste like a thick piece of bacon. 
Roasted Beets- amazing sauce on top of this salad
Foie Gras Torchon-  It's like buddda baby.   I had to go back for more.
Butter Pecan Sundae-  Half way I got the sweet tooth and I still forced myself to get to 3/4s of the way.  That good!
The Crazy, creepy artwork- I was trying to see how many faces there were in that art piece.  I'd say 5!

The bad:
Terrible service from the waiter-  the other waiters gave us more service and attention.
Pickled Vegetables- a bit  vinegary
Roast Chicken- expectations not fulfilled.  It was too lemony and lacking on the serving size
Seafood Plateu- I only liked the lobster and everything else on the plate was blah!!!  It would be better if the shrimp was chilled and we could select which oysters we wanted.  Not like Zuni's

Overall, the place has potential and they are going through the new restaurant motions.  I'm sure I'll be back after all the kinks are out.
author: Jason A.

description:
I had a fabulous dinner here a few evenings ago.

We had an 8:30 reservation for our party of 4, but it took our table a while to open up, since the previous diners were lingering. The hostess was extremely apologetic and checked in with us constantly. The one problem -- not anyone's fault -- is that there really is no waiting area. Since the bar was crowded as well, this created a bit of a crowded bottleneck, which was somewhat of a stressful start to the evening.

Once we were seated, our friendly waiter, Enrique, furnished us with delicious crusty pan epee and sweet soft butter. I started with the kombucha squash and chestnut soup, which had a few morsels braised rabbit and was finished with a bit of sage oil (I'm pretty sure that's what it was!). Absolutely delicious! It wasn't overly creamy or too rich and heavy, and was somewhat filling.

Our main courses took a while to come out, but our wait was rewarded. For my main course, I ordered another appetizer: the roasted beet salad with smoked salmon and horseradish creme fraiche. This was extremely tasty and the mix of flavors was just perfectly -- they all came together without any one being too overpowering.

I had a bite of my friend's chicken, which was really the winner... I've never had such moist and flavorful white meat before. The chicken comes with chorizo potatoes and is topped with some lightly dressed arugula. My mouth is watering just thinking about the taste of this dish!!

For dessert, I had the chocolate pot de creme. It was a little lighter in texture than most, almost mousse-like. It was perfectly bittersweet -- just the right amount of sugar.

I can't wait to return... I'm definitely having the chicken next time! Mmmmmm....
author: Jill M.

description:
I'M IN THE FINANCIAL DISTRICT. I HAVE MONEY. I'M DATING AN ASIAN GIRL. LET'S GO TO SALT HOUSE.

i'll get to the food in a minute, don't worry.

as we walked in, i noticed a "trend," if you will. everyone around me was very well-to-do, we were seated next to a family talking about the success of their business and their failed attempt to set up the son with the city planner of the city of san rafael on one side, and a pair of affluent women whose conversation somehow merged with ours for a few minutes. nothing special, really, as  we were in the financial district and everything smells of money. even the $6 mineral water we ordered.

but as i looked around the room, i noticed that something was missing. in a city as eclectic as san francisco, i expected diversity, but what i got was a trip to the bars of shanghai with the techies.

let me explain. friends of mine work for a major electronics manufacturer in silicon valley, and have to go to china every few months to make sure all is well at the factory. i took a few vacation days and went with them one time. the nightlife is heavily skewed in two directions, naturally: asian females. white men with money. no asian guys.

so as i scanned the room at salt house i noticed the exact same thing. virtually every group or couple included an asian female, including mine. but there was the rub: i was the only asian guy in the entire restaurant. 

i was the missing link, if you will.

horrified, i decided to concentrate on my company, and the food. which was good, though pricey if you're not used to financial district prices. without wine, us two spent about $112, or, rather, i did, because my companion, to be jettisoned at a later date, never offers to pay for a damned thing. but i digress.
