the food is good. very good. the ingredients are fresh and my chicken dish somehow, some way, tasted better than the phenomenal salty rush of costco chicken, though i did pay five times more for it. we didn't have any alcoholic drinks that night so i can't comment on the bar yet.

the service was good but had its delays due to a packed house. upon leaving your seat, the closest waiter takes your napkin and drapes it over the back of your seat. they refill your drinks without having to be called on. they laugh at your jokes, or at least pretend to, though i do like to think of myself as a funny guy.

but i digress. this place is good. especially if you've got money. and especially if you bring an asian woman with you. you'll fit right in.
author: Charles C.

description: I don't drink to get drunk, but there is nowhere I consistently get as sloppy as I do here. and it doesn't take much... I usually just order one of those medium sized blended white wine bottles, and by the time I walk out of there I am drunk dialing every ex I've ever had.
author: Adam X.

description:
I had the most amazing night here.  And it wasn't just cause the gallon of beer and tequila shot I had just had at John Collins.  It was cause my date was amazing.  He picked me up and surprised me with dinner at Salt House. 

They could have served me dog food and I would still write a raving review.  They didn't though.  The food was friccin amazing.  We had olives, 2 varieties of oysters, halibut with artichokes, snapper with fennel, and 2 great wines.  I'd have more details but I was so distracted by my dinner companion's beauty and ability to knock me off my feet that I didn't see the details.  It was all superb though.

Our server was awesome too.  She was very attentive but never up in our business.  She did have a knack for stopping by every time one of us had a full mouth.  It added some humor to the night.

This is a fun restaurant with enough class to be acceptable to someone with my high standards but casual enough to still be fun.  It is a great place to take a date that you are not that familiar with since you wont be able to get within 3 feet of them the whole night.  No booths here.  But you can save that until later for some Natoma alley necking.  Yay!
author: Ian M.

description:
This place is okay, but I've had better.  I think you're safe ordering anything off the menu for the most part.  But my favorites would be the steak (i love me a ny strip) and the foie gras.  I ordered the cassoulet but there was way too much salt and had too strong of a wine taste.  We all enjoyed the sweetbreads, but I personally thought the bacon around it stole the show.  I've never liked putin, but they do a pretty good job here, provided you also enjoy steak fries, which I'm also not the biggest fan of.  My aunt didn't love her chicken which was super dry, and I thought the monk fish was so-so.

Whatever the hell you do though, stay away from the dessert.  We tried the carrot cake, cranberry financier, apple crisp, and the panna cotta.  And they all sucked.  The first two were dry, bland and oily (not moist).  There's probably a giant sheet cake in the back of their refrigerator that's been prepared a week ahead that they just slice up and put on a plate for you.  The carrot cake literally had a glop of cream cheese on top.  It wasn't even turned into a frosting, it was a legit stool (or quenelle) of cream cheese.  The panna cotta had a good texture but didn't taste like anything, could have used some vanilla (aka flavor), and the apple crisp had only a good crisp, but a mediocre apple filling.  And I mean, it's really hard to screw up an apple crisp.  So SKIP dessert.  Not only are they uninspired and expensive, but they're not even executed well.
author: Biqi C.

description:
Sorry, but for the price this place did not deliver IMHO. 

1. both the seared tuna dishes we had were totally tasteless, don't know where they got the tuna but it was just bland.
2. The $32 jug of wine was some of the worst wine ever. One of my dining friends referred to it as grape juice and vodka
3. surprisingly small entres

Good points, good appetizer selection, very nice Fois Gras, good duck.
author: Karl L.

description: Salt House is comparable to Zuni in both food and atmosphere, if that's your kind of thing...a classy but casual establishment with exposed brick walls, high ceilings and healthy-ish mainly non-vegetarian dishes.
author: Amy Z.

description:
It was a rainy evening in the City, and T and I were headed to a screening of Persepolis at the Embarcadero.  Salt House caught my eye as we were walking by.  Modern and rustic, quaint and cool, we couldn't resist stopping in.  

Salt House turned out to be the perfect remedy for our happy hour discontents. Refreshingly remiss of the deafening cocktails crowd, the folks there were mellow and the servers attentive and eager to please.

I ordered the small sangiovese/syrah house blend, and was surprised when our bartender brought out an extra little medicine bottle of wine along with my full glass.  "Yes, doctor."  The cheddar cheese fries with short rib gravy were a hot mess.

Salt House, I'll be back for more.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Salt house is a very promising but uneven new American restaurant by the creators of Town Hall.  The decor is a little strange.  There's a big weird mural on the wall that looks a bloody musketeer.  The timing and service was also off.  We weren't seated until 15 minutes after our 8:30 reservation on a Tuesday.  I handed the hostess my coat when I came in and they draped it over some railing.  Our server was friendly, helpful, and attentive but our meal took way too long to come out of the kitchen of a half empty restaurant.

The food is what will get me to try this place again in a couple months.  First, I love that they serve Acme Bread's pain epi. That bread is like crack.  I also had one of the best salads I've ever tasted: poached winter fruits, walnuts, gorgonzola, pomegranate, chicory, mmmmmmm.  I had the poutine in honor of my Canadian roommate which was just too heavy and salty.  The chicken with chorizo and potatoes was really the star dish.  The chicken was so moist and juicy I couldn't believe it came from a bird.  The Poutine killed me so I didn't have dessert this time, but I'm sure the flavors will improve in a couple of months and be closer to perfection!
author: Elena S.

description:
After a day of foodie adventures at the Ferry Building and shopping at Union Square we were looking for a place to have a nice dinner. On our way to the Mission District my better half mentioned "How about the Salt House?". She explained that it was related to Town Hall where we had a great meal a few months ago. So we went around the block found parking rather easily and crossed our fingers since we had no reservations. 

It was filled but no one was waiting to be seated. We were informed that they were booked for the night but that they offer a full menu at the bar, and at a community table behind the bar that had ten or so stools around it and one couple enjoying a meal. We jumped at the chance to sit at the community table and were promptly taken care of.

The restaurant is nice. A little industrial with brick walls and girders but it also was warm and comfortable. 

We decided to share three appetizers and one entree. This way we got to try quite a few dishes. The Poutine was the star of the meal to me. I had never seen poutine offered anywhere outside of Quebec before and this version was perfect. The potatoes were fried as perfect as I could think fries could be. With the gravy and cheese it was a true guilty pleasure. A close second was the short ribs which were deliciously tender. The other dishes we ordered (Seared Scallops and Suckling Pig) were interesting enough but not as good as the other two dishes. The banana chocolate tort we had for dessert was above acceptable which was par for the course for our meal. 

Since we were sharing, the server had the kitchen split the dishes for us so we each enjoyed our own presentation from the kitchen which was a real nice added touch that we didn't ask for but our server had them do anyway, Thanks bud!

An enjoyable meal and another place to have tried in the "City". Only a thousand or so places left to try!
author: Johnny J.

description:
Why I Should Pay More Attention to Yelp:  A Cautionary Tale

My birthday is Christmas Eve.  And I am Jewish.  (Cue South Park song here.)  Therefore, I like to be treated very specially by those I love.  Luckily, the husband is also Jewish and has done an excellent job of making me feel amazing on my birthday.  This year we had to go to a wedding on the 24th (yes, it was a Jewish wedding, blah blah) so we arranged an alternate date to go to dinner.  I'd heard some of the hype here and since I loved Town Hall, I thought we could go here for a nice meal.  But I probably should have read the reviews here a tad more carefully because everything that we found wrong with our experience had already been thoroughly documented by other Yelpers. 

The good:  LOVED the decor, was seated promptly, got to have a glass of Schramsberg's 'Mirabelle' Rose which I HIGHLY recommend to all of you bubbly lovers.  (Odd to see it listed under the sparkling section next to the Veuve... discordant much?)  The husband got a huge pour of the Verdejo he sampled by the glass.  The special was a dungeness crab salad that I probably could have eaten 20 of -- lovely and salty with an anchovy and olive dressing.  At that point I was REALLY excited.  That was dashed soon after, though.

The bad:  after being seated with menus, the waiter did not show up with real information for quite some time.  He seemed agitated when, after asking us if we had questions, the husband actually did ask some questions about the seafood dishes.  When we placed our order, we decided to go with a glass of a white each for our appetizer, and then switch to a Pinot Noir for our entrees.  'Cause you know, that is one of the points of having wine by the glass... so you can change it up.  

Waiter says:  OK with the Pinot, but you may have to remind me 'cause I'll probably forget.  (He was writing everything down, btw.)  

Us:  um... really? 

So a long spell passed between our appetizer and our entrees and at some point before the entrees arrived the waiter looked in on us and asked when we wanted our Pinot.  Husband was not close to being done with his first glass, so I said with our entrees.  Finally the entrees came.  Was definitely surprised at how sparse the plates were... for $26 I expected a little more than 3 scallops resting on a teensy bit of veggies.  Husband had the monkfish accompanied by veal cheeks.  The fish was average, but the veal cheeks were actually amazing and could have been a spectacular dish on their own with the correct saucing and accompaniments.  

OF COURSE our wine and the waiter were nowhere to be seen... and he didn't come by to check on us until well after the husband had finished his meal.  Veal cheeks wait for no one!  We said we'd just like one glass of wine at this point and the waiter just kind of shrugged and said something like, yeah, well, that's why I asked you before when you wanted your wine.  No apology. He walked away and I was just confused... because didn't his asking us imply that the wine would arrive when we wanted it?!  My glass did show up a few minutes later and I enjoyed it very much, thank you.

So on to dessert.. we selected the "warm apple galette" with vanilla bean ice cream.  This, too, took quite some time to arrive and was both not warm and somewhat lacking (IMO) in the apple department.  it also really needed to be cut with a knife... but we only had forks and spoons.  sadness.

In short, this meal was very disappointing.  Moral of the story:  sometimes it's worth it to read through reviews.  Then go to Myth instead, where you will spend less, get more food, and will have excellent service to complement a special evening out.
author: Nat K.

description:
A bunch of friends and I came here to celebrate my birthday and the food was okay only. We ordered the following appetizers to share and it was just average: scallop, yellowfin tuna and the pear salad. I ordered the striped bass and once again it was okay only. My friends' ordered short rib, lamb and rabbit and it were only average. The highlight of the whole dining experience was the dessert: Chocolate Bavarian and that was the only thing that my friends and I remembered about Salt House. 

For the ambiance and service was good got seated promptly and the waiter kept on coming by to refill our water and wine.
author: Allison H.

description:
The space is really neat & convenient for groups. I noticed, for example, that the waiters put together a number of tables to create a large table for a single group and/or communal dining. 

Loved the overall design & open kitchen -- think white subway tiles, filament lighting & light wood tables. For street level restaurant below a brand new, super modern SOMA apartment building, the restaurant was suprosingly warm & cozy.  

I enjoyed the sole entree, but the fish was a tad overpowered by the broth and accessories including mussels, shrimp and calamari. I enjoyed an excellent Pilsner -- def my rec among all three draft beers on the menu.
author: The Undercover Glutton N.

description:
I really liked this place.  The industrial space is very well done.  The service on my visit was very good, and they even comped two deserts for my date and I for a very slight mixup in the delivery time for the main course.  The wine list was robust and I tried a Malbec (on recomendation) that was wonderful.  

This place feels very cozy because it seems to always be full. I like that.  Being so close to the financial district, I'll be going here again somewhat often.  Make sure to get reservations though.
author: Matthew R.

description: Very cool 5:01 p.m. spot to hang out and dine.  Shellfish plateau was very tasty.  My honey had the California Halibut and I had the local King Salmon.  Our meals were well prepared and delicious.  Seating is tight, but the decor is pleasing.  The next time you are San Francisco, check it out.
author: Simone H.

description:
So I rang in the new year last night over dinner at Salt House with my boyfriend and my aunt and uncle. All in all, a great experience!

Back when we were trying to make plans for News Years Eve, I logged on to Open Table and picked Salt House simply because it was in very close proximity to the hotel my aunt and uncle were planning to stay at. Well, their reservations at the hotel fell through at the last minute, but we decided to keep our dinner plans and I'm so glad we did! 

We had a few drinks down the street at Roy's beforehand, which was a smart move for me because none of the cocktails at Salt House really piqued my interest. As far as food goes, though, I was really impressed. I would say that, to start, both the poutine and the warm nuts are MUST-HAVES!!! Just do it! The marinated olives, however, were a joke...you could get better olives at the olive bar in any grocery store! 

For my main dish, I got the yellowfin tuna-it was excellent, served seared, with lots of veggies on the side, and it was the perfect portion...I felt like I was eating air! Everyone else got meat dishes...my aunt really liked her short ribs. We each ordered a different dessert, and I was partial to the panna cotta, above anything else...it had a different flavor, but the consistency was so smooth!

The service was top notch. I always feel like I ask a lot of questions at restaurants, but our server filled in all the blanks at her own accord, so I didn't even have to ask, which was a nice change of pace. They served us (a really good!) complimentary champagne at midnight, and the managers went around to all the tables and toasted all the guests! A great way to spend a special evening.
author: Shannon R.

description: Fun spot with good food, but nothing will blow you away, especially when you factor in what you're paying!  The food lives up to its name - everything is doused in salty sauces.
author: Anna V.

description:
Rumor had it that Salt House was one of the three trendy places you had to go this year, but rumor didn't say much for the food. After getting a reservation two weeks in advance I wasn't about to skip out on this meal for any reason (not even the Phillies playing the Giants).

Salt House far exceeded my expectations. Its set in a unique brick building with a decor of thick wood accents and fun mirrors. A communal table resides in the middle of the room (for those of you who like dining alongside complete strangers) and the kitchen is open to the main dining area so you can watch for tasty plates as they get served up.  To my surprise, the feel was casual and maybe only 15% hipster, with most diners wearing jeans.

After reviewing the menu, we chose to go heavy on the apps and split one entree (the steak...YUM), but that's not to say the entree menu was lacking in the least. However, it turned out to be a good choice, because we got to split 4 lovely small (but not too small) plates and try a variety of tastes they had to offer.

The crab appetizer looked like a crab salad but tasted like a chunky crab cole slaw (heavy on the crab, woot!), salty of course, and enhanced by the tiny fried artichokes mixed throughout. The fresh yellowfin tuna came atop a bed of beets and some sort of gelatin mixture, but whatever it was, the result was delicious. I had never had poutine but when I learned what it entailed I knew it was right up my alley. Basically, large, fresh cheese fries with gravy and chunks of beef. Best part of the meal, by far. The crispy shrimp appetizer was just that but nothing to lament about.

As I said, we chose the steak, which was juicy and accented with small carrots, potatoes and a special sauce which made it all the better. For dessert I had the rubarb tart, which was great if you like rubarb. All around, an amazing meal and the perfect break from my two-weeks till Hawaii diet.

When my beau asked me what I liked better, Salt House or its sister restaurant, Town Hall, I couldn't decide. And I adore Town Hall so that's saying something for this place. I'll be back for sure.

Awkward Side Note: When I walked out of the bathroom stall there was a dude washing his hands in the sink.  When he saw me he didn't seem the least bit surprised. I doublechecked on the way out to be sure I hadn't swooped into the mens room after a few too many glasses of pinot, but no, I was right where I should be. When I left the bathroom he was no where to be found. Gotta love SF.
author: Haley M.

description:
I've been wanting to try Salt House for awhile and I must say it exceeded my expectations. My foodie friend tried it sometime back and thought it was good, not great, but that perhaps by now they had worked out some kinks.  She definitely agreed that they had improved the food.

I started with the Green Door cocktail, a lively blend of Hangar One Kaffir Lime, muddled cucumber and mint. It was so tasty I had to have another.

We opted to do appetizers and went with the mixed vegetable salad, the Monterey Squid, the pork belly and the gnocchi with morels.  The salad was divine and bursting with fresh flavor. The squid was stuffed with chorizo and sitting on a bed of chickpeas. This was also great. The gnocchi and pork belly were quite good as well but the squid and salad were my favorites.  No blandness with this meal!

It was nice that they divided the gnocchi and salad into two portions for us, twas a nice touch.

This was a decent amount, even though the poutine smelled good we opted out and went for dessert, the banana cream tart with homeade nutter butter cookies...wow.  

I had to pipe up about this place because I've eaten at a lot of joints in SF and this one surprised me. I'd say the only drawback was the noise but I'm still giving it 5 stars because I think Salt House deserves a lil boost in the ratings.
author: Faith S.

description:
I had a great time here with great friends.  However, objectively, the food, decor (including the noise level), and service were all inferior to Town Hall.  

Supposedly, Salt House is a sister restaurant of Town Hall.  So if I'm paying similar $$ for a similar food in a similar neighborhood, I would choose Town Hall in a heart beat.  I found no dish here to be a must repeat.

And, like Town Hall, their wine list wasn't so impressive.  They had house blend wines, which I thought was unique (although haven't tasted them).
author: Mami T.

description:
I had a magnificent evening at Salt House.

We walked in on Thursday night around 8 pm. It was a packed house - patrons were loud, lots of laughing, wine was flowing. The hosts were really nice. There were no tables but lucky for us in the front corner on the other side of the stairs (directly facing the window) there is a narrow long bar where four or five chairs were... 2 were open! To even get to the seats you had to squeeze yourself behind the stairs. It was a really awkward place, but turned out to be just perfect. What was a busy, loud, and packed restaurant immediate turned into an intimate, quiet, and romantic experience. So we sit.

You could tell that care was taken in building the wine selection. Broken down by New World and Old World, there was a nice range of price as well. The wine we initially chose the server asked us a question on to verify that we would really enjoy it, and when we answered he actually recommended another. I really appreciated that and his choice was lovely.

We ordered white corn soup, the fois gras appetizer, and the petrole sole. I will say that in all honesty, the first two dishes were so memorable that I honestly don't remember a single thing about the entree. My favorite by far was the fois gras. I will shed a tear when fois gras becomes illegal in california. The Fois Gras was served in three ways - 2 cured and one pan seared. I thought I had died and gone to heaven each time I took a bite - it was incredible. Dessert I think was the least impressive, but it may also have been what we ordered... it was just a brownie thing with popcorn. ?? eh?

I do want to particularly note how spectacular the service was at Salt House. They have mastered the art of "just enough" attention and three different servers cared for us that night. They took care in making sure that we weren't forgotten in the back corner and the dishes were spaced out well. Our water glasses were constantly filled and at no time did we feel rushed. 

Delicious. This is a restaurant I would characterize as being a wonderful "experience" - not just the food. it's a complete experience.
author: Annie T.

description:
The Salt House is a very contemporary restaurant in style, with an open-face kitchen and seating in a small loft area overlooking the entire restaurant. Great layout and very comfortable setting without being luxuriously over done. 

The menu also reflects the restaurant's culture, not too many items and nothing complex in preparation nor ingredients. Ordered scallops for appetizers, perfectly cooked and fresh but scallops were very small and there were hot 2 pieces the size of quarters. Tried the lamb and steak for entree, similar story to the appetizer, perfectly cooked but not enough food. No pun intended but the food here could definitely use a little more salt also.

Overall, this place is well-rounded: good service, atmosphere, and food. I wouldn't consider Salt House to be fine-dining, but it definitely is a little bit more upscale then typical and prices are a little high considering what you get.
author: Ed L.

description:
Had dinner here last night.

I really enjoyed the space and the atmosphere.  I especially like the open kitchen.  Our waiter recommended a wine from Lebanon that turned out to be pretty good and exactly the way he described it.  The Spicy shrimp appetizer was very tasty but scarce.  I had the veal which was delicious as far as the taste goes but was more of an osso-bucco instead of a nice veal.  It was very fatty where I was expecting more lean.  One of my group ordered the same thing and had the exact experience.  The bar looked active with plenty of eye candy putting out the "pick me up" vibe.   Bartender was friendly and poured a good stiff drink.  

I would go back.
author: B G.

description:
I slid into Salt House, spilled some oysters down the throat, drank a few beers and gnawed on white rabbit wrapped in pork and finished the night with wine.  


a little expensive.
good beers.
rabbits are for eating not petting.
author: Blake F.

description:
Total dining decadence in a very cool yet casual atmosphere. It took forever for us to decide what we wanted because everything on the menu (and on the tables around us) looked so amazingly yummy. And it all absolutely was. 

Oysters on the half shell, a perfect foie gras torchon, and seared Ahi served with roasted baby beets were our starters. As for the main entree, my duck confit was so beautifully prepared and spiced that I didn't want to share any of it with the date. He felt the same way about his gorgeous steak. (we shared...but sparingly).  Finished the meal with a lovely chocolate fudge dessert, grappa and espresso and then rolled home to deal with our food hangover. As for the rest: loved the exposed brick warehouse ambiance and found the service to be very professional and attentive.
author: Suepattra M.

description: Great ambiance and excellent service when we went. My friend and I ordered the chicken and it was fantastic. I really like the setting, great place to take a friend visiting the city. The only reason I wouldn't put Salt House at five starts is I feel the prices are a bit high just due to location.
author: Justin M.

description: Food above average. Service acceptable. Price moderately high. Interior design interesting, obtuse.
author: Chris M.

description:
Rolled in last night at around 10 for an impromptu dinner for two.  I was poised to like this place because a) Town Hall is good, b) it is walking distance from pseudo-bf's place, and c) they serve until 1am.

Caveat: 4 stars is a wee bit generous - some kinks to work out, as expected.  But the potential is solid, hence the rating.

Ambiance first: I like.  Very industrial-chic, yet still warm, raw space, very open (almost too open - kind of sterile back there) kitchen.   Nicely avant-garde mural on the far back wall.  But as a whole, the place felt unfinished (discarded paint-splattered ladders in the entryway kind of a dead giveaway) - I'm picturing some future sprucing-up, especially towards the back.

Onto food.  Menu was small: interesting but accessible contemporary American dishes.  Not too many great-sounding items at the outset - I was disappointed that the duck potpie was not yet there (according to our waitress, chef is debating on duck confit vs braised duck - how could you go wrong?).  

We had the tomato tart - think pizza kicked way up , on a reeeealy buttery puff pastry crust - and a very basic pear/endive salad to start.  Next was the much-lauded vitello tonnatto: this is a very classic italian dish that I've heard much about but never tried, because it sounds so disgusting: those two words translate to "veal" and "tuna".  Together.

Warning bells were going off: "do not order, do not order... veal and tuna, veal and tuna..."  But waitress talked it up soooooo much, that well, we took the chance.

Hmmm.  Interesting.  Braised veal, very tender, nice flavor, and a little overly fatty and not quite hot enough, covered in a creamy tuna sauce that tasted EXACTLY like the white-trash creamed tuna casserole my mom used to make.  Except hers had frozen peas and we ate it with margarined toast.  Gosh that is embarrassing.

Anyway, probably not a good thing that said dish took me back to my most white-trash meal of youth.  Waitress probably should not have extolled it as God's gift to veal.   And it probably should at least have been properly heated.  I sense this dish will not stay on the menu for long.

But I stand by my four stars.  Because the food will improve.  The wine list is nicely chosen, kind of in the affordable/interesting vein of late.  They will soon have Hangar One.  And the staff could not have been nicer or more accommodating.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Ok. Ok.

I did wait to go here after looking at some early cluttered menus that seemed confused and dis-jointed.  However when asked to go here yesterday and looking over the new ideas on the menu I felt ok in saying yes.

We arrived right on time for our reservations and were seated immediately and asked what water preference we had.

Soon we had water, bread, butter and our server back to tell us about her favorites on the menu.

We had quite a few things to accompany a delicious bottle of Pinot Noir. Started like this:

Poutine (fancy cheese fries with short rib gravy)
Spicy Shrimp (with very spicy chilled green beans)
Homemade Sausage (with fancy mustard and potatoes)
Pork something-or-other (served with poached egg and greens) that was mad rich and delicious

All of the small plates were great but we didn't need that much food to start... that is for sure.

When the plates were cleared we were brought our large plates.

Chicken: Cooked perfectly with spicy chorizo roasted potatoes. Just the proper amount of heat for the chicken and the potatoes to play with.

Duck con fit: Served over mashed potatoes and with a huckleberry sauce. One of the better preparations that I have ever had, the meat was still tender and not stringy and the fruit was a great addition to the fatty skin of the duck.  God, I could have eaten 4 duck legs... If I wasn't so full!

All in all I loved my time here and would challenge anyone that gave this place less than 4 stars to try it again and see if you feel the same.

Full disclosure:

I am old time friends with a woman that is a server here and didn't pay for every dish that I sampled.  I'm very good looking and popular. Sue me... I am honest.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Excellent food
Great service 
ate with random people next to me, but it was nice.  It is one of those new communal things where you get to meet people if you feel like being social.  At first I was skeptical, not a great socialite, but after I was sold.  Great place to meet peeps and enjoy great food.  

Pork belly appetizer was excellent.  Will be back for more.
author: M L.

description:
Very impressed. The space is beautiful. Due to the high ceiling and open-kitchen floor plan, it gets pretty loud in there. The exposed brick walls added a nice touch. Looking behind the line, all the chefs had different color bandanas on. It's mesmerizing to stare at the people who put your food together with such precision. There was even a girl chef! I digress....

Both my friend and I enjoyed our cocktails. At $10 a pop, they were stiff. It might have been my lack of enzyme due to my AZNness, that felt the effects of alcohol too soon. For apps, we shared a heirloom tomato salad and the gravy/cheese fries. They were UBER yummilicious. They used different heirloom varieties and used an arugula for the bitter contrast. Probably the best salad I've had ALL year. The fries were good, but it was OVERseasoned. The cheese AND the gravy were already salty, so there was no need to go overboard with the salt on the fries. I guess if you're drunk enough, you wouldn't notice. I did. And I was buzzed! 

4/5 was given due to the heavy salt. But this would be a great place for a first date as the noise level can cancel out any potential weirdness. You can even sit at the island really close to your date to smell whether he had showered that day!
author: Wing L.

description:
Was told you had to book weeks in advance. Luckily got a table for lunch one day and had probably the BEST meal of my life. A bit pricey, but the savory, punchy flavors I will remember for a long time. My mouth is watering just thinking about this place :)

What we ordered:

Crispy Shrimp spicy green beans, serrano ham, almonds
* the green beans were incredible!

Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken preserved lemon and garlic, chorizo roasted potatoes
* exceeded expectations
author: Daren M.

description:
Interesting space; brick, wood- the materials feel old but the place is seems pretty trendy.
I liked the food it was fresh and carefully prepared with unusual touches. Like the squash soup with mint and curry garnish.
Service was ok nothing special.
It gets for stars for location, fresh nicely prepared food and cool ambiance.
author: Edi B.

description:
My first visit to Salt House was pretty good but I have to say that I do prefer Town Hall. Overall the food at Salt House is outstanding. They have kumumotos right now too so that is a definite plus, we had the poutine and yellowfin tuna apps and my entree was delicious- the ribeye with marrow crust and carrot puree. The staff was also very friendly and engaging except for the speedy busser that was clearing plates and glasses before we were finished with them.

I'm going to minus one star because it was very cramped. My friends facing me had a short wall behind them that was smashing them into the table and the woman sitting behind me was constantly ramming her chair into the back of mine. Also, our server, literally had no room to stand when speaking to us so she was constantly having to step out of the way for traffic to pass through. Another minus is that the noise level was incredibly loud so we were basically yelling at one another across the table and it took a good half hour to get the bill settled as the server was MIA for quite some time (it was really busy, so nothing against her!).
author: Donna V.

description:
Salt House consistently lives up to its excellent reputation.  Having eaten here a number of times I figured it would be a good choice for my first Yelp review. 

The atmosphere is always energetic (but not overwhelming) ,which seems to put everyone in the restaurant in a good mood.  Standout dishes from my most-recent visit include the mixed lettuces salad which, while being slightly overdressed ,nonetheless displayed the flavors of the greens very well and the Fulton Valley chicken (its rare that I order chicken but the kitchen has mastered the technique required to crisp the skin perfectly).
author: Kris K.

description:
Popular and bustling restaurant. Came for lunch during Dine About Town. I ordered the celery/apple puree soup, pork shoulder stew, and blondie brownie.

Celery/apply puree soup was good, light, and tasty.

Pork Shoulder stew tasted like tortilla soup. There was only 3-4 bite size pork shoulder. The stew was boring and forgettable.

The brownie saved the day. It was delicious but not enough for me to come back to Salt House anytime soon. 

All in all it was another disappointing Dine About Town lunch. Definitely not worth the $22 price tag.
author: Terry D.

description:
Salt House from acclaimed Town Hall restauranteurs, delivers fantastic food in an ubercool historic building. The tall ceilings suck up the noise making conversation possible.  If you're a big fan of the exposed interiors like Nopa and Slow Club, you'll enjoy the decor and interior design.  The owner's wife painted a great depiction of one my personal heros Don Quixote on the back wall which adds some whack fun to this otherwise cool, rugged space. 

We shared the pastrami ribs, actually I ate them all, the roast chicken, the chocolate budnt cake and the gingerbread.  For wine we tried the pinot by the glass which paired well with the chicken and the grenache which was a bit angular and maybe needed some air or sleep.  The chicken was the highlight and will have me back for more. The ribs were fatty and uninspiring. The gingerbread was execeptional, almost as good as moms, and the chocolate bundt cake was simple and quickly forgotten. 

Overall I look forward to coming back and trying more as this place screams of potential and the parking was a breeze.
author: Phil M.

description: Came here for catch-up drinks with a friend.  Will need to return for the food... esp the foie.  Brought to you by the folks of Town Hall... hopefully this place is fitting for my taste.  I didn't like Town Hall.
author: Erika C.

description: Nice ambience, good food but very slow service.
author: Beril Y.

description: Good... could have been great. Maybe having the regular downtown office crowd has allowed them to ease up on the level of awesome.
author: Sean D.

description:
For starters we had the suckling pig and foie gras which was excellente'!

For the entree we split the rabbit (w/ Au Jus) with chestnuts, wild apples and ricotta gnocchi. Fantastic. 

For dessert we decided on a wonderful sticky date toffee cake! 

Supreme!

The server was okay a little aloof most of the time but it wasn't busy so we had a pleasant experience. I like the decor except for the staircase leading upstairs which is crazy noisy. What were these fools thinking with that.

I would love to try it again but instead for lunch.
author: Adrienne H.

description:
Yum!  Popped in at 7 on a Friday to get a reservation for 9:30 later that night.  Solid.  Asked for a table by the kitchen, who doesn't love watching cute chefs do it right?, and again, Salt House delivered.  Our lovely server (whose name I can't for the life of me remember) described the rose perfectly--what a great glass of wine.  She also recommended the Tai Snapper; there was one left, and it was ours if we wanted.  Hell yes we wanted.  Smooth taste with a gorgeous presentation.  Split between two of us and it was perfection.  Service was great, even as they were nearing the end of their night.  Rumor had it that the owner was even there bussing tables, as they needed the help.  Here's to teamwork!  Food was yummy and the people were nice.  But wait... then came desert.

Jesus, is that you?  Coffee ice cream vacherin and strawberry trifle.  What a perfect complement these two were.  Cocoa nib brittle? Yes, please.  

On a closing note, how about those milk bottle style water carafes?  Where does one acquire one of those?!  A sweet touch to a fantastic meal.
author: Kelly P.

description:
I don't often get to eat out in large groups. Last night, a friend was in town and nine of us got together and headed out to Salt House. I've been here any number of times in the past and while I've generally enjoyed the food, the loudness of the place tends to make social interaction difficult. I didn't make the reservations on this occasion but I was game. Other than the noise this review gets broken into two parts; food and service.

Food - I started with Poutine. Until recently I'd never had poutine. It's a Quebecois dish consisting of french fries, topped with cheese curd and brown gravy. Two weeks earlier I'd had them in Vancouver where I'd been staying for the Olympics. There I loved them. Cholesterol heaven and it tasted it. The poutine here were not quite as good. Not enough gravy primarily. If I hadn't had them recently I'd probably be a bit more accepting. So...good but not great. For dinner I went with the lamb with root vegetables. This was very good. Everybody around the table seemed to enjoy their dinners. The wine was fine...nothing spectacular. We ordered a couple of bottles of a Grenache blend (Domaine Pegau 2006).

So while the food and wine were fine, the service was lacking. Granted, this was a Friday night and there were nine of us, it took forever to be seated (with reservations), and forever to be served. Once underway things were okay and the waitress had a good attitude but we were famished long before the food arrived.

Overall, good food, decent wine, slow service and loud environment.

3 stars
author: Gary C.

description:
Hey Erica? Yes, you!  The cute, Annie Lennox-looking hottie-of-a-waitress that made my experience at Salt House one of the best I've ever had in SF.  Now, don't worry. I'm not one of those scary hetero stalkers. Actually, I'm "a gay" and recently took my partner of 6 years to Salt House for a belated Christmas/New Years feast (I had to work over the holidays which meant limited time and attention toward my husband).

I absolutely love this place. This food is excellent (I've never left a morsel of food on my plate). The apps are amazing (hello, Poutine? Fresh cut, oven baked fries with melted cheddar cheese AND short rib gravy???). Yes, I had to remember to take my Lipitor after leaving this place, but every once in a while, you gotta remember to live a bit.

And - thanks to Erica - I now have a new Favorite Beer! Delirium Tremens! God, I could have drunk an entire 6 pack. Sadly, Erica's first suggestion (La Fin du Monde) had just ran out. But, her second choice was awesome. If you like Belgium beer, you gotta try Delirium.

Erica also talked me into eating the Sea Bass with chorizo and red cabbage (she said she loves the adventurous types). LOVED IT!  Rustic, moist, sweet and tangy. Sometimes you get a waiter/waitress that only wants to sell you the expensive menu items. Erica was one of those rare gems that steers you in the direction of taste and not the price (unlike so many local restaurants that I could easily start naming). 

After two appetizers, four beers, 2 entrees and one desert, we left happy, content and planning our next visit. And I slept like a baby with dreams of Poutine dancing through my head....
author: Bubbles S.

description:
Let me start with the good: 5 stars for the kitchen. Magnifique! Pure delight. First, the presentation of everything was awesome. I had a cauliflower soup which was surprisingly flavorful and we shared the poutine potatoes covered in white cheddar and gravy; sooooooo good (but they get cold and sloppy pretty quick). My date had the crispy shrimp and it came over green beans with some serrano ham; he was in heaven. We both ordered the skirt steak and it was one of the best medium-rare cooked meats I've ever had (clearly the chef takes his temperatures seriously... many don't and like to merge medium with medium-rare). For dessert we had the vanilla custard with some kind of rhubarbish type fruit and yummy crust at the bottom served with two linzer cookies. Mmmm. Food coma ensued...

I had to take one big star off for service. Hostess was wonderful. Very friendly at the door. We were seated upon our reservation time. However, no one came by for about ten minutes. Once we ordered, we only saw our server once (to check in on our 3 apps and get us another glass of wine). She was friendly nonetheless, but disappeared. My biggest gripe was that the food runners placed our food twice on other tables in our section. Both tables were confused and had to tell them. We were also served wrong food on our table. Not sure if there was section confusion... but three times in one meal? Also, I was ok with the slow progression between courses because we ordered so much but it may have been too slow if we hadn't overloaded ourselves with carbs. In the end, once our dessert plates were cleared... no one came by (this was at about 10pm). We sat for about 15 minutes and I finally flagged down the manager and asked him politely for the bill. Never saw our server again...so odd? Right?

I will be back... I hope the orchestration on the floor improves. I have faith!
author: Meredith R.

description: The duck confit was amazing. Love the Acme bread, too. Thank you!
author: Rebecca B.

description:
I really wanted to like Salt House. The menu was full of interesting, appetizing looking dishes, the service was good and the space is great. Unfortunately the food was only okay.

I started with the poutine and my wife started with the mixed lettuce salad. They were both fine but not particularly notable - and I'm looking for something special in $11 french fries and $9.50 green salads. For our main course I had seared tuna on lentils and chessnuts while my wife Sharon had the new york steak. I thought the tuna was adequately prepared and the lentils were amazing, but they just didn't go well together. The lentils would have been an amazing accompaniment to a more strongly flavored meat like lamb, but it completely overpowered the tuna. Sharon loved the veggies that came with her steak but the steak itself wasn't amazing and the short rib that came with it didn't have the kind of flavor you'd expect.

The meal (2 appetizers, 2 mains, 1 glass of wine) came to $120. I think if it had cost us $70 we would have been happy but for that price we know we can do better. It actually kind of reminded me of my mediocre experiences at Town Hall around the corner.
author: Ian M.

description:
Swankety-swank, new hot-spot from the owners of "Town Hall." Went last night for the opening and really enjoyed it. Great space, good energy, enthusiastic staff, and all the right touches. The owners kept the integrity of the old printing press it used to be, leaving the hard wood floors, window frames, etc. The mezzanine is not yet done, but will be a nice added touch for more intimate dining.

For opening night and a "no menu" meal, the food was delicious. My sister and I split a tomato tart, grilled octopus, foie gras with peppercorn, roast chicken, veal sausage, and some sort of gingered cake. (yes, I left quite full!).  I'm even more excited to go back and order off the menu. 

Side Note: we sat next to a vegetarian who was also very satisfied with what the chef created (although the did roll her eyes in disgust as we devoured the duck liver and octopus...oh well.)

Great addition to this neighborhood. I believe the public opening will be near the end of October.
author: jodes l.

description:
Picked a top rated city restaurant on Yelp to impress my wife that all the time I spend on Yelp is well spent. Being stuck in suburbia, we don't get out very often. Her experience here was more of a 4 where as mine was more like a 3.5. (If I admit it, maybe she won't be as indulgent of all my Yelping.)

Biggest turn off for me was the hostess had tattoos all over her arms. As luck would have it, we were seated next to a woman who had Yakuza tattoos half way down one arm. So maybe I had tattoos on the brain, but let's just say it didn't make my entree taste more appealing to have her serve us. 

Otherwise, it was a good experience. Nice decor. Seated promptly. Waiter extremely knowledgeable and courteous. I guess the overall style of the food is supposed to be around rather straightforward dishes, not especially spiced complexly so that the natural flavors come through. Wine menu by the glass didn't bowl me over, but the waiter suggested good pairings.

My pear, chicory walnuts and ricotta didn't really work for me. Portion of greens too big and I didn't really appreciate the ricotta being warm. My wife's cauliflower soup on the other hand was great. Her short ribs was great. My lamb shank with couscous was rather good but not great.

Definitely quite the scene. Besides the Yakuza tattooed woman to my left, we were later joined to the right by a woman who looked like a Russian mafia mistress with diamonds out the wazoo. We ate on the early side, so we got to see everyone else come in later on in the evening, just as we had to head back to the 'burbs.
author: David P.

description:
I am surprised by all the mixed reviews on this place -I thought it was pretty darn good. 

I have been wanting to try Salt House for awhile now, and found the perfect reason to go with my Sister - to celebrate both our birthdays and do some sister bonding. We had a 6:30 reservation on a Tuesday night - it was definitely crowded in there by 7pm but I did not experience the extreme loudness everyone mentions in these reviews - I guess you should go on a weekday.

Service was very very good. I LOVED that they split our dishes for us - without us asking and thus allowing us to each experience the prettiness of the dishes  - you know, rather than having to scrap it onto a plate and having it no longer look so fancy and nice. 

We had:
(Apps)
Poutine - the fries thing with cheese, gravy and a few pieces of superb rib meat - rich and very yummy

Scallops - some of the BEST I have ever had, but we did only get 2... expected in a fine dining restaurant but I wished there were more.

Crispy shrimp - We each got 2 fried shrimp with this green bean salad that has a light spicy sauce on it. I loved the beans but was not overly impressed with the shrimp - mine tasted fishy and I HATE when the shrimp aren't cleaned and I find their poop on the them. My sis liked her poopy shrimp.

We also shared the Tuna entree - based off the comments in the Yelp reviews, this seemed to be one of their best.
I loved it, and again they split it for us. The tuna is gorgeous and with a great chickpea pesto thing under it. It tasted wonderful. 

We were way too full for dessert :(
I also had the Salty Dog drink - which is expensive and comes in a smaller martini glass BUT it was filled to the brim and strong - a unique grapefruit cocktail.  

I also loved their House blends - the wines are available in different sizes so we got the medium (12oz) white and easily each had a full glass and half. The bread served is very hard. 

The ambiance is nice and open, rustic - I found the gloomy bits weird... for example, the giant black, charcoal-ish drawing of a horseman on the wall, the skull on our water carafe (LOVE when places give you your own water carafe!!) and the darker than hell toilet area in the bathroom - I had to focus to see where to sit. Also, no hooks on the back of the door!! UGH. 

I would definitely go back and I think this place could easily be a 5 starer for me - if  a few minor things changed.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I read some great reviews about the place from the people i respect on Yelp, but my personal experience was not good at all. Their menu did not work for me...not that many options available and everything was kind of plain, nothing out of the ordinary (i usually expect each and every place to add their own touch to any menu, etc)..

I did enjoy the artistic feel to the place, but that was probably it. Prices are OK, but some things such as wine were ridiculously overpriced. 

Service: Indifferent attitude of the staff!

I like to be given a second chance, and since this place has a bunch of great reviews I will give it another try pretty soon.
author: Katja S.

description:
Salt House must be a dating mecca because everyone around was on a first date.  It was hard not to eavesdrop on such lovely first date convos ranging from carb diets and britney's divorce to "corporate faultlines" (who the heck even talks like that?!) since the tables were so close together.  I'm not saying it's a bad thing.  In fact, it's quite entertaining.  Just don't spill your guts and expect it to be private here. 

The "Salt" part of Salt House was no joke.  While the beet and pastrami rib appetizers and pineapple upside down cake with ice cream dessert were creative and excellent, the entrees were salty... and thus we left feeling like we had salty meat overkill overall (granted, we could've ordered more variety and less meat).  

HOWEVER the service was amazingly thoughtful, and they get 5+ stars for service.  They promptly re-did the veal entree (was originally way too salty but the 2nd time around was fantastic) and didn't even charge for it.  The owner apologized profusely and looked like he genuinely felt bad.  So nice!  The duck entree was good, meat falls off the bone, and just a tad too salty.  

I'm not quite sure how this is suppose to differ from Town Hall, I should probably read more about it, but the crowd/ambiance is more laidback and less banker-ish than Town Hall (= good thing).
author: Chris P.

description: Was on a family vacation and had a hungry kid. No way were we going to a kids restaurant and Salt House was a great choice. Don't get me wrong, this is a true dining experience with delicious and inventive food and top service (although most of the bus boys didn't show up on our night -- poor waitress was a real pro though). Food was inventive, the kitchen was open and we all appreciated the precision and care the chefs and cooks put into each dish. It's very convenient to the W and St. Regis and I'd go back often when in town in SF. It's a solid meal, airy high ceilings, lovely service and a nice way to spend an evening with friends or business colleagues.
author: Natalie B.

description:
I love how many of the people who review think going to a place just once is enough information about any type of business to write an intelligent review.  I obviously feel those aren't people who need to be reviewing.  Thus, leading to my long awaited review of Salt House.  

I have been to Salt House now about 5 times in the last month.  Chef Robert Leva is really creating not only beautiful but delicious meals.  As a gal who eats out at various regular spots- Salt House is now on the rotation.  I love the yellow tail and the rib-eye, although I have tried many other dishes.  They have a great wine list.  The staff is friendly and warm, which makes all the difference when you would like a suggestion.
author: frankee U.

description:
Being a guy who grew up in the mountains in Colorado, and having spent so many hours enjoying some amazing steak, I was blown away when I tried the steak at Salt House. If it's not the best steak I've ever had, its certainly in the top 3.

I love the atmosphere, the layout, the service, and pretty much everything else.

However, that would all be downplayed if the food wasn't simply fantastic. Guess what? The food is simply THAT GOOD. If you love steak, you know what to order at Salt House.

For dessert, order the dark chocolate ice cream if they still have it. Quite simply some of the best I've ever enjoyed. The chocolate flavor was so deep, crisp, and full I almost didn't finish it. Talk about a kick!

There's only one place in SF that rivals the food here in my opinion, and man is it a close race for first!
author: Cal H.

description: Salt House's salty upon savory poutine doesn't disappoint, but I can't help but feel like the overall product is a little more Bart than Lisa Simpson (and by that I mean underachieving).  Portion size really hampers the inventiveness of the dishes here, and the price doesn't help.  Their corn cheesecake is the cat's pjs, but it'd be nice to have a big boy serving and not simply a "tasting."
author: Michael D.

description:
This joint has a nice atmosphere, but, the food and service leaves little to be desired.  
I went to lunch and ordered the Po' Boy Sandwich.  Although I've never been to Long John Silver's, this must be what it's like. This sandwich was dry and consisted of a piece of lettuce and fried bits of.... cod, I suppose.  For the price, I was extremely disappointed. 
No soul, no heart....
author: Mastako O.

description:
Well the food certainly lived up to the establishment's name!  I had the petrale sole with dungeness crab and what tasted like a whole bottle of SALT.  

(this coming from someone who usually salts EVERYTHING)...My entree would have been okay if it wasn't so darn salty!  We started with the fresh oysters which were fresh and tasty.  That's not too hard to find in a city like San Francisco however.  

For desert we had the apple crisp.  WOWSA!  It was so sour! If not for the ice cream, I wouldn't have been able to eat a bite of this.  Terribly disappointing..  The best thing I can say for the Salt (and Sour) House is that their service was great.  Everyone from the hostess to our server and anyone just walking around was more than accommodating.  They have a nice big bar that looks fun as a happy hour pit stop after work.

All in all it wasn't my favorite....
author: Candice M.

description: Went here this week during ad:tech ...for the 3rd time in 2 years. Even had my wedding reception there. Always amazing food. Only issue was wait time. Otherwise, highly recommend..
author: Ron W.

description:
Brought to you by the jackasses who brought you Town Hall....gotta love that opening line for a website!

It took me awhile, but I'm a fan of Town Hall, and this place is just wonderful.  Getting a table can be difficult, and since I refuse to make reservations anywhere, (how boring) there have been times when I've had to wait awhile.

Salt House's decor is clever, with masculine, industrial rusty beams and rivets, the clunky, chunky wood tempered with the cool elegance of white marble.  I love the touch of a communal table, adding to the laid back, sophisticated ambiance it's a good place to meet people and you don't feel weird dining alone, as I do quite frequently.  I especially love the gritty, Don Quixotesque painting splashed on the back wall.

The food is very, very good.  My favorites include the Dungeness crab salad, a fresh melange of wonderful textures; tender, sweet crab balanced with salty/acidic capers, crunchy arugula and crispy-creamy pieces of fried artichoke.  The marinated olives are simple, and taste house-cured.  However the Crispy Shrimp appetizer, though a good combination of light, deep fried shrimp, salty Serrano ham, almonds and perfectly blanched haricot vert, the Harissa sauce that the beans are tossed in was just too damn SPICY for my taste.  My taste buds were obliterated after literally two bites.  I couldn't finish it, and I noticed that two other patrons who ordered the dish ate everything but the beans, as I had.  My guess was that the chef either didn't taste the sauce before it was sent out, or they're trying to make some culinary statement.  Either way, that dish needs work.  

The New York Steak was perfectly grilled and at the time it was served with crisp pancetta and smashed potatoes, the ultimate upscale comfort dish.

Desserts, alas, fall flat.  The first dessert I had was described as a Flourless Chocolate cake but in actuality was just a hunk of chocolate ganache, "cake" wasn't anywhere near that concoction. The house made caramel that came with it was well executed.  On my next time around, the second dessert was combination of pineapple and coconut ice cream and sorbet swirled together, which was a little on the icy side and was paired with a Macadamia Dacquoise which was lack luster and tasted slightly stale, but in the summertime, this dessert be a very good choice for something light.  I haven't tried any of the specialty cocktails, but they have a very good wine list, as it is at Town Hall.

All in all, the place is a winner, and though it's still quite young, I think it has become the City's new favorite restaurant.  My only other complaint is the lack of flowers in the place, so I guess I'll send Doug Washington a bouquet and offer my services.  

Lord knows they could use a good florist at Town Hall!
author: Candace W.

description:
Pressing our luck on a Friday night, a few of us walked into Salt House at 8pm without reservations in an attempt to get a good meal in before going out for the night.  I'm becoming a huge fan of the communal table concept.
  Not only did we sit within 20 minutes of getting there, we, randomly, ended bumping into other friends doing the same.  We sat across from some very drunk people, but they were more entertaining than anything else.  In fact, I'd probably go back just to sit at the communal table again.  I really like the whole concept.

Beyond the experience, the food was fantastic and the service was excellent.
author: james s.

description:
Salt House has all the key ingredients for a great dining experience:

1. Friendly service. 
My co-workers and I needed a place to get our grub on before we headed to the Asian American Film Festival launch party, and Salt House is right in the neighborhood. We popped in without a reservation and the hostess had to deliver the bad news that she didn't have any tables available for a couple of hours. Often, news like this is peppered with an undertone of "why didn't you plan ahead and make a reservation" or "don't you know how popular we are"? None of this kind of attitude from the friendly hostess. The bar and the big communal table are first come, first serve, and we decided to hang out and wait. Lucky for us, we got three seats at the bar within about 15 minutes of our arrival. The bartender was really friendly as well despite the fact that he was slammed. Service was prompt and when he was busy he let us know he hadn't forgotten us.

2. Full menu at the bar. 
Always a plus when you're a busy, popular restaurant.

3. Great space. 
The atmosphere is chic, warm and inviting. Totally a place you feel like you want to hang out for a while. Their design is both industrial  and homey/comfortable. It takes talent to pull off that combination successfully.

4. House wine. 
I really, really don't know why so any places overlook this personal touch. It's charming and it's fun to try a restaurant's house blend. Not to mention it is generally a little less expensive and therefore provides an option for the more budget conscious.

5. Good wines by the glass for less than $10. 
'Nough said.

6. Awesome food. 
My companions and I shared the Bellweather Farms ricotta with pears, walnuts and winter lettuces. Awesome. I tried some of the spicy green beans off the crispy shrimp plate, dressed in an orange-cumin vinaigrette. Awesome. My ricotta gnocchi with mixed winter veggies was awesome. And we closed the deal with some - you guessed it -awesome sorbet with little cubes of poppy seed cake.

7. Accommodating to vegetarians. 
I realize this isn't important to everyone, but for those to whom it is, note that Salt House will make you a special vegetarian entree if there isn't one on the menu. 

I am so glad this place is my work 'hood and I am already scheming about my next visit.
author: Angie R.

description:
The good:  Housemade Limoncello, poutine, more limoncello, then the gigantor praline ice cream sunday for dessert (lactose intolerant peeps beware!!), and last but so not least, scott the bartender. ;)

The bad:  I called around 4:30 on a Thursday to make a reservation and was left hanging while they tracked down the host....for 10 minutes!! until i gave up.  when we arrived at the door, it seemed a little helter skelter and even though we said we would wait for a table, we were persuaded that the community table would be just as good and was immediately available.  Sitting up on the high stools, skootched in as tightly to the table as possible, I still managed to get bumped any time anyone passed -- i felt like i was in the way of the servers as they leaned over to present dishes to the table behind us.  i now have a junk in the trunk complex. :( ah well...maybe more poutine will make it come true. 

The ugly?  there was none, to be honest -- lots of hotties and cuties dining, imbibing, dishing, and serving.  Even the mature crowd was lovely.... who could ask for more.
author: iGab C.

description: Great place for a business lunch or an after work cocktail.  The shrimp app is amazing and the service is great.  really nice atmosphere, tall ceilings, good service.  Food is awesome, always fresh and tasty.  Go here pretty often and am never disappointed.
author: Julia B.

description:
I liked this place, but admit that I did not go to the bathroom, having been scared by Yelpers' commentary about its grossness.

The ambiance is urban/art house/industrial. I wish it were more spacious, though. I loved most of the wall art. Very interesting to look at.  

The food was good. We ate the Day Scallop appetizer and found it plate-lickingly delish. Did not order the poutine fries because, really, I needed to be mobile after dinner. I had the sole--yummy! My date had the Pekin Duck and enjoyed it.  Note to Yelpers: the menu does not say "PekinG Duck, " the chinese dish, but Pekin Duck, which is a common breed of duck. 

I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Carrie M.

description:
Lunch Review

Came with coworkers - some of us had the Mint Lemonade.  This is tasty.  Kind of tangy, kind of sparkly (do they use bottled fizzy water? i dunno) but barely minty.  I wish it was more minty.  

Shared the poutine.  Delish! Rich and decadent and worthy of sharing with others.  The small bits of short rib were so smushy and delish.

I ordered the roast pork cubano.  I wish it were more like a traditional cubano.  The entire sandwich was too thick and not pressed flat enough, although it really was because there was too much pork inside.  I also wish the remoulade was tangier like how yellow mustard is tangy.  I also wish the pickle was more prevelant rather than chopped fine into the remoulade.  The bread was too oily and buttery.  With every bite I got a squirt of melted butter/cooking spray.

Others ordered the loc duart salmon, chicken paillard, and burger with cheddar.  Salmon looked good - skin was cooked perfectly crispy.   Chicken Paillard looked moist and the salad beneath looked appetizing.  Burger looked like any other burger.

After this first impression I already like it better than Town Hall.  Will probably be back.
author: Jade K.

description:
Took my husband for dinner last friday. (he's never been, i've been twice) 

we didn't have a reservation so settled for the window seating but were seated asap (amazing for a friday dinner rush!!!)

cocktails here are amazing. quite strong, great price (just the way i like it)

we shared the suckling pig appetizer. sweet and flavorful. mains were stuffed quail and the tuna steak with truffled celery root pure. both were perfect.

the only down side was we waited 30 mins for our first drink order but they made up for it big time by comping our first 2 drink orders, really nice of the manager and very much appreciated.
author: Christine f.

description:
I've been wanting to go to Salt House for months, and despite the mixed reviews on Yelp, I've heard a number of older acquaintances (older as in their age, not in the number of years that I've know them) rave about the excellent food and divine location.  I came in with a very open mind.  My party arrived and we waited by the staircase near the bar.  Our four top turned to a five top and they told us it would just be 15 or so minutes additional wait.  Fifteen turned into almost an hour...as the table we were waiting for apparently wouldn't leave.  As an apology, management sent over a glass of champagne.  Very nice!

We sit, order a bottle of red, and take in the ambiance.  I love the lighting and the rustic yet chic feel about the place.  We all agreed it was a very noisy restaurant, but no real complaints because we were a loud group ourselves.  (OMG!  I LOVE THAT....!  YOU MUST TRY....!  Okay, you get it.)  

Once our appetizers arrive, we divulge into them and start sharing.  I order the Poutine.  I mean how can I pass up french fries with cheese and a short rib gravy to top it off?!   A definite favorite at our table.   I'm not a big seafood fan, but I quite enjoyed the yellow fin tuna as it was fresh and other flavors were clean and crisp.  The spicy green beans and almonds that accompanied the crispy shrimp was very tasty and plentiful.  (Didn't try the shrimp cause again, it's not my thing, but I was told that they were good and the green beans were a very good pairing.)

For main course I ordered the flank steak and it now escapes me what veggies it came with.  All I recall is a green pureed vegetable mix that went quite well with my medium well (small-ish) piece of beef.  I enjoyed my meal immensely as did everyone at the table.  The wild striped sea bass was quite yummy, flaky and buttery (but still not my cup of tea).  

Two bottles of wine later, we knew dinner wouldn't be complete without dessert.  We ordered three to share (names escape me), but our favorite was the ginger panna cotta and this banana, chocolate pudding, peanut butter parfait (I must have at 1/3 of it...it was the closest to me proximity wise too.)  The rum soaked cake with the biscottis was too strong tasting that we all just had one bite and called it quits.  

It was definitely a busy Thursday night.  Our waitress was obviously busy, but did a fair job checking up on us and re-folding our napkins as we stepped away from the table.  

Overall, great experience!  Two bottles of excellent wine, delicious and decadent food and dessert and all  in the company of four other vibrant ladies...made for a great evening and perfect as a precursor to the Sex and the City movie.
author: Marie B.

description:
Great food, great drink, and great service.  I loved it! 

I like Townhall.  I like a lot of restaurants but I just had one of those perfect dinners at Salt House.  The ambience is very warm with a sort of modern/rustic decor.  The food and drinks were delicious, and the service was truly outstanding.  

One of the distinguishing features of this restaurant is their service.  It was absolutely perfect.  We arrived early and the hostess was lovely! This should always be true at restaurants, and yet... I find many restaurants where the hostess is obviously stressed and seems put off by an early arrival or just too stressed in general to be warm and welcoming.  The hostess at Salt House was perfect.  She made us feel right at home, let us know the situation, and let us know she would seat us as soon as she could.  

We started at the bar sampling their cocktails (i.e., Perfect Strangers, Kentucky Heartbreak).  The drinks were good and definitely lived up to their enticing names.  After a drink, or two, we moved to our table.  We went upstairs which is a bit small but super cozy, and now my favorite place to sit in the restaurant despite loving the communal table.  Our waitress was superlative.  She was warm and welcoming, she helped us with our selections, and she was super attentive when we wanted her, and yet she gave us plenty of space when we were busy talking.  At a nice restaurant you expect great service, but more times than not, it's just good.  At Salt House we felt taken care of, and it was really nice.  

The food was great.  The bread is obviously baked on site and it's definitely worth the calories.  For starters the cucumber salad was light and delicious.  The poutine, on the other hand, was ridiculously heavy but so, so good.  In fact, next time I am sad, I am going to drown my sorrows with poutine and a big glass of red wine at Salt House.  The entrees were all great too.  The presentation was lovely, the portion size was good (I hate it when I spend more than $25 on an entree and then leave hungry), and everything was tastey.  After drinks, wine, and dinner we were pretty full but we still managed to split a summer peach pie.  Just imagine a little pie baked to golden brown perfection.  Now imagine the taste of warm, flaky crust, peaches and homemade ice cream in your mouth.  Yes, it was good.

Overall, I had one of those perfect dinners at Salt House.  If my mom was an amazing chef it would have felt like going home.  Sadly my mom isn't, so Salt House was even better.
author: Cantik E.

description:
On a recent weeknight, my friend suggested we try this place and warned that it may be crowded, so we planned to sit at the bar and wait for a table. The restaurant is situated next to a major construction site, so walking there at night isn't the most scenic.

When we walk in, the place is packed. The front window is large and there is a small bar/ledge table that two people were sitting at, so we assumed it was a waiting area. When we asked for a table, the friendly receptionist told us we could sit at the window and eat. We asked if we were "good enough" to sit in the window and she assured us we fit the bill. ;)

So here's the part where I think I'm so cool. Sitting at the window, you see everyone walking in and out of the place and on the sidewalk. At one point, there's a group of businessmen who have just left the restaurant and are standing in front of me talking. One of them looks familiar, but I can't place him and then it dawns on me, it's Willie Brown. Now, this is exciting to me because you know how many times I've read reviews of SF restaurants and people write that Willie was at the table next to them? Lots. But I get to write a review that says Willie Brown was standing in front of me and looked right at me and winked.  How's that?!?

Besides the Willie experience, the food was great. We ordered a bunch of appetizers with the theme being to order things we had never tried or heard of before. I had heard of poutine, but wasn't sure if I had eaten it, so that was a given. We had to get the foie gras, ricotta salad and pork belly. Awesome. Everything was presented well and really, I do not think our service was affected by the fact that we weren't facing the restaurant.

Our waitress and the receptionist came by frequently to talk and visit with us, they were really friendly.

Ironically, I ate at TownHall the following night and I have to say The Salt House blows TownHall away in ambience and a great dining experience.
author: Kittenheel S.

description:
1 star for the spacial planning
2 stars for the service
5 stars for the food
Averaged out: 2.66 stars (so I rounded up to 3)

The layout of this space is really poorly planned in my opinion.  The Hostess station is squeezed right at the bottom of the loft stairs and when you go to check in you're either blocking the entrance doorway or the path to the stairs, its kind of ridiculous.  I also don't like this whole nuevo trend of restaurants towards this huge open space.  The acoustics were horrible making it for a very loud dining experience.  Then they put this huge community table like 4 feet from the bar, so there's no space to enjoy a drink without bumping into the dinners at the table.  Frustrating!

The service started out stellar... our waitress answered all our questions thoughtfully and with a knowledgeable and honest take on the menu and wine list.  So sad it went all down hill from here.  First, she forgot our wine order and asked us twice how we were doing on drinks when we were still waiting for our wine.  Then she forgot to put in our appetizer orders and never apologized for this mistake.  We did finally get our 2 appetizers (the scallops, which were average & the  fries which were a fantastic gourmet take on chili cheese fries) in the middle of our dinner and were told they'd be comped.  However, when the bill came they were still on there, so we had to ask to have them removed.  Oh, and the bill is literally just a slip of paper placed on your table like you've just finished a meal at Denny's.  Classy!

Good thing that the food was so good, otherwise this evening would have been a total waste.  I enjoyed my sole, and my dinning companions loved their tuna and calamari respectively.  The chocolate malt dessert was divine... I've never had anything like it before and was pleasantly surprised. 

Overall, I'm not sure if this restaurant knows what it wants to be: just another casual dinning experience  or a special occasion gourmet experience.  The food and the prices support the latter, while everything else is very casual.  If I'm paying higher prices I expect better service and not to have to yell across the table in order to have a conversation.  I'm glad I tired it... but I won't be coming back unless they do a complete overhaul on their service and space planning.
author: Ms. M. M.

description:
hm this place is ok.... the food is prepared well and is flavor. it is definitely fine dining which means tasty food, but small portions and high prices. the poutine was quite tasty. for entree i got the sole and i guess it was good. fish itself was under seasoned but the overall combination was quite nice. the overall place was nice, they even have a coat service for free.

it sure does take quite a while for the entrees to come out.. i've watched a lot of gordon ramsay's shows and i think he'd flip if he was at this place. 4 chefs in the back and it took over 30 mins for our entrees. i dont wanna super anal but cmon.. maybe i've been watching too much ramsay to think that i dont have to wait for too long. anyways, its a good place but a special occasion place
author: edward k.

description:
Salt House = new SF "old favorite." 
To me, this is the kind of restaurant where I could eat every week. Open yet cozy atmosphere, happy vibe, mixed crowd. Attentive service and excellent food with simple ingredients prepared in innovative ways. My friend and I were seated promptly for our 7:30 reservation. Our food was very good -- I think we both enjoyed the Dungeness crab app (baby fried artichokes -- yum!) more than our mains (but the cassoulet and the rib aren't slouches!). Perhaps a bit more wait than I would have expected for the second courses to arrive. My favorite touch is the monogrammed, skull-embellished milk jug that serves as water pitcher. It's the new winner in the "restaurant accessory most likely to be pinched" category.
author: Kate A.

description:
How'd you like...a nice, greeezy, pork sandwich served in a (no, not a dirty ash tray) on a sodden piece of wax paper with a side of "spicy" potato chips?  That sums up the "cubano" that I had for lunch.  Still, aside from the pool of grease, it was grub.  My dining companions both had the sole and it was niiiice, one might even say "soleful".  

Yes, its one of the hippest restaurants in an otherwise unhip restaurant part of town, and yes, they've got some damn good things on the menu, but with that diggityness comes great responsibility.  Attitude of the waitstaff was bearable, it was more the clientel that will drive you nuts.  

Interior is very well done, as is the presentation of their food/drinks, and the nuances that they put into the settings.  

Why only 3 stars?  The food ranged from good to very good, and its worth experiencing the venue, but I don't know that I'd bother with the wait to get in and I'd prefer if my fellow diners could somehow lose the 'tude.
author: Nils E.

description:
My sister and I had a leisurely lunch there last Friday.  I hate to admit it but I really love the look and feel of the place and I had a wonderful time.  We sat at the bar and received very friendly service.  We bonded with other patrons sitting at the bar and sampled each other's food.  The martinis were icy and delicious.  We ordered kumomoto oysters and the charcuterie plate.  The chef came out to explain to us about the items on the charcuterie plate, most of which are made in-house.  He was a nice guy and we got into a lively discussion about pork belly he was preparing for that night's dinner menu.  Happy to see our enthusiasm for pork fat and pork skin, he later sent out the pork belly dish for us to sample and it was delicious!  

Okay so it was an expensive lunch but it was also a lovely way for two sisters who love pork belly and martinis to bond on a Friday afternoon.
author: mia s.

description:
After hearing nothing about good things about Salt House, and thoroughly enjoying its sister restaurant, Town Hall, a bunch of friends and I decided to try it out.

The food was amazing!  The flavors that gushed from the food was broad and unique.  The service was exceptional.  We were arrived early and grabbed a drink from the bar.  When our table was ready, the hostess found us and asked if we were ready to be seated.  The waitress regularly checked up on us. 

I was told that the noise levels would be very high, but I found it to be quite bearable and still conducive to normal conversation.

I will definitely be back!!!
author: Marc E.

description:
