Another hit on the ever-hot SF dining scene. The Town Hall folks have opened up a more SF-centric place just a few blocks from their last success. Nice for getting a cozy meal downtown with a minimum or fuss or FiDi rope burn. Definitely a destination for the corporate-hipster crowd.

Plusses: Attentive, flexible, friendly service. Zero pretension in a place you might expect to find it. The house wines were reasonable and tasty, and the glass-bottle presentation is trez cute. Food came in very generous portions, although it's certainly not cheap. Salt cod brandade was light and delicious. And as others have said, that chicken is gustatory orgasm on a fork.

Minuses: Loud as all get out. After awhile, I noticed my voice was straining... Just to be audible, I was shouting. Not that much of a minus, but I wouldn't go here for a romantic (read: quiet) dinner for two.
author: Aaron L.

description:
This current Open Table hotspot is brought to you by the same fine people who brought you Town Hall.  

Food:  5 stars.   Like it's sister restaurant, this place fails to disappoint.  The pork belly appetizer, with poached egg and lentils, was perfect.  I'm a sucker for the duck leg confit and it's crispy skin and tender meat, complemented by the quince and huckleberry sauce.  

Service:  3 stars.  What a way to ruin a perfectly good evening.  The server needed an attitude adjustment at the beginning of the meal.  When we asked for his recommendation between 2 different wines, he grabbed the wine list from my friend, looked long and hard, and stated "I've never tried the wines, you're gonna have to give it your best guess."  The server recovered later on in the evening and tried to be nicer to us, but I'm sure he only had the tip on his mind at that point.  Isn't it proper etiquette to wait until we leave before picking up our signed copy of the bill, as well?

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  The restaurant is appropriately housed in an old printing press warehouse with exposed brick walls, hardwood floors, perfect lighting, and an awesome mural of Don Quixote showcased on the back wall.  The restaurant attracts primarily a 20-40 something GQ crowd.  The only knock is that the tables are situated too close together and it was quite obvious that the tables adjoining us were eavesdropping on our conversation.  

Hits:  Crispy shrimp, pork belly, muscovy duck leg confit, pineapple coconut ice cream cake

Misses:  Inconsistent service, eavesdroppers

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Town Hall, Nopa
author: Keith C.

description:
I loved everything about Salt House! Liz S and I came on a Wednesday night and the place was busy! The bar was full of people and almost every table was full. Although the restaurant is fairly small and tight, we were lucky enough to get a cozy table near the back with a little more room. The decor is very lofty industrial, but it felt very inviting with the cool "index" card lighting and bustling open kitchen. 

The service was fantastic. We were greeted right away and the waitress was very attentive throughout the entire evening. I started off with the dungeness crab salad. I was very impressed by the portions! There was tons of sweet, juicy crab meat piled high over a small bed of greens. It was delicious! For my entree, I had the shellfish stew. It came with two huge, plump scallops, mussels, and clams. The sauce was very unique. Not your typical tomato broth, but a creamy, rich sauce that was very tasty. I really enjoyed it.

Dessert is not to be missed. There were so many great things on the menu, so it was definitely hard to choose. We ended having the walnut tart and chocolate fudge bar. The tart was amazing!!! Delicious, buttery crust filled with a sweet walnut mixture. It was topped with a large scoop of roasted banana ice cream! YUM! The ice cream was so good! It was perfect with the tart. The chocolate fudge bar was good, but a little too decadent and rich for me. I loved the roasted nuts on the bar though. 

Overall, I had a great time at Salt House. I would definitely come back soon!
author: Denise L.

description:
What a wondeful experience, both in terms of the food and the attentiveness of the staff.  We arrived and were told that our table was just paying their bill and it shouldn't be too long.  Ten minutes later one of the hosts comes up to us and tells us that our table has paid, they're just lingering now.  He apologizes profusely and offers us a glass of champagne on the house.  I accepted, and my dad (who does not drink champagne) asked if he could have a glass of red wine instead.  He was given a glass of a Hahn Estates Pinot Noir that was wonderful.

We were seated soon after that, and quickly offered our choice of waters.  For appetizers, we ordered the Heirloom Tomato Salad which was very fresh and delicious, and the Crispy Shrimp.  The shrimp were cooked perfectly and the seranno ham was a lovely touch.  My only complaint is that the green beans were a bit too spicy for me, but that's just personal preference.  Our main courses were the Fulton Valley Roast Chicken and the Petrale Sole.  Both were perfectly seasoned and cooked, with great little vegetables on the plate too.  I loved the touch of big grains of salt on the chicken, because that's what I do at home when I cook a roast chicken, yum!  

Throughout the meal, our waitress (a petite blonde who looked very familiar) was very attentive and checked in on us just enough to be there if we needed something.  We were too stuffed (the portions are quite generous) to order dessert, but some of the options looked quite tasty.  Maybe next time!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
We went there last night for dinner and in one word -- ohmygod. 

We started off with the baked oysters and yellowtail sashimi. Both delicious! FYI: They also have raw oysters.

For dinner I had the duck leg. I've been eating a lot of seafood this past week, so I was craving duck like nobody's business. I guess I wasn't the only one because my Mom had the prime rib and my bf had the duck, beef, bean casserole dish. All were out of this world! We finished off the meal with lemon pudding -- who would've thunk to put marshmallow on top?! It was a delicious touch.

I loved the atmosphere, the place was packed on a Sunday night. They also have a long table near the front of the 'strant for diners who didn't make a reso. Definitely worth a return visit.
author: Defne A.

description:
I had a friend recommend Salt House to me recently, so I decided to try it out for dinner tonight and ended up having a wonderful time!

We started with the oysters, asparagus, and shrimp for our appetizers and then the lamb, tuna, and halibut for our mains.  Everything was incredibly delicious!!! 

We also sampled some of the house cocktails and a few wines by the glass, also a huge success.  

The server, Josh, was very sweet and efficient.  He made sure to check in on us when needed, and otherwise just let us enjoy our wonderful meal.  The whole experience was wonderful.  Will definitely be back again soon!
author: Kim R.

description: Food is delicious and very well presented.  This restaurant is good for formal dinners and good for special occasions because it is expensive, but worth it.
author: Puja J.

description:
I've been dying to try this place for months now and I was finally able to give it a whirl...

Appetizer: Butternut Squash Soup ($8.50)
Entree: 
Chicken Paillard w/ Savoy Spinach, Bacon & Crimini Mushrooms ($20)
Drink: Fresh Mint Lemonade ($4)

Lunch total: $32.50 + tax and tip

Yep. That's a steep lunch price, but I was lucky enough to be taken here on business. I loved every part of this meal. Each dish was very flavorful and the fresh mint lemonade was sooo refreshing that I'm actually craving it right this minute. I would order everything all over again, but I would probably come back for dinner -- I don't fancy paying that much for lunch.

The set-up has a total modern/urban vibe to it with the exposed bricks going on. I like that you can sit upstairs (though only a few tables can fit up there). It can get very loud during lunch - I imagine since it's in the FiDi tons of meetings are going on at this time (hence, the business lunch). You have to really lean in to hear one other even if you're right next to the person who's talking. Altogether, I had a great dining experience & outstanding service.
author: Melissa P.

description:
This place is great.  I love the decor and the quirky little touches (the light bulbs hanging over the bar, the coasters, their business cards and the cute bottles they use for water and their wine from the barrel).  The staff is so friendly that we decided to sit at the bar for dinner instead of a table.  Gabriel and Harven are the type of bartenders you hope to have behind the bar when you're having dinner...giving good recommendations, checking in on you, making you laugh, etc.  

We order four appetizers:
- squash soup:  I will go back just for this!  It was so delicious that I seriously wanted to lick my bowl
- smoked salmon & beet salad:  I just love beets and smoked salmon, so I had to try this and I wasn't disappointed.  It was lightly dressed, which I like.  They had their beets in cubes, which is find, but I prefer my beets sliced thinly.  
- pastrami spareribs:  so tender and flavorful!  I wish we would have skipped Ame for apps (even tho it was good) because I was too full to have the second rib...what a waste!
- house of pickles:  not really my cup of tea.  They used, I think, cumin in their pickling process, or some spice that I don't like, but my friend loved it.

The other reason it gets 5 stars is because I did a major party foul and knocked over my glass of wine...wine all over the bar (and me) and broke the glass, but within 20 seconds, the bartenders and a busboy had it all cleaned up and another glass of wine in front of me.  I even forgot it happened until now!  That's what I call good service.

I should also note that Maz and Doug, along with Gabriel and Harven, did all these nice extras that made for a very fun night!  Thanks everyone, we'll be back!
author: vanessa c.

description:
CHILD FRIENDLY!!

Our waitress was way cool and babysat our daughter for a few moments!!!  took her to the window, took her upstairs, while my husband and I scarfed down our food

then, when we knocked over a glass, spilling all over the table and breaking the glass, the head of staff was so smooth and professional. Cleaned it all up really fast. Brought another glass, fired up another soup ASAP.

Wow!!  impressive service

the food - yummy. who could do white corn soup wrong? great bread.

even the plain pasta that I ordered for my daughter, my husband loved! that's something!

had the suckling pig with grapes, a little dry but perfect mushy food for my 14 month old!

Chicken was good.

Dessert - Basque cake, perfect not too sweet and was delicious!  came with earl grey ice cream (not sweet enough for me, a little weird)

Loud- so that was good to cover baby noise. and with the big window, good entertainment for the kid and with the big bench, good for kid again

Very clean, modern bathroom, though down the hall.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Yummy! 
*party of 10 seated promptly
*friendly waiter
*nice high ceilings
*open and airy w/out the cafeteria effect
*great wine selection
*Real foie gras...it was so good that we tripled the order!
*suckling pig...tripled the order!
*rotisserie chicken-juicy inside, light n'crispy out....tripled!

We ordered much much more, but I entered a food coma, and everything else was a blur. I do remember us all leaving completely satisfied, and I've been trying to coordinate pig-fest-salt-house edition- part 2, ever since.

Alright,  so my friends and I are just as piggy as our suckling counter-parts, but. it's ok, that's what the gym is for. Meet you at the  treadmill!
author: leyen t.

description:
Anthony Bourdain said it best: Never order fish on a Monday. 

But on Monday when my server recommended the Petrale Sole as her favorite dish, I took the bait (no pun intended). First bite told me something wasn't quite right. I thought maybe it was the chanterelles or even the green olives.  Second bite, still not right (and definitely not because of what I originally suspected). Third bite + a bite given to the beau made it pretty clear: the fish was fishy--as in, it's been sitting there since last week and is past its servable freshness. 

Now, I don't want to jump to conclusions here. I don't want to assume that my very nice server told me that this was her favorite dish without really meaning it. I don't want to accuse her of using a sales tactic to get rid of the old, old sole inventory. After all, isn't that was "specials" at restaurants are for? And even if all these things were true, I'm sure she was only doing what management wanted her to do. I work for the corporate big wigs. I know what it's like to be a powerless peon. So my dear Chloe, these aren't points docked against you or your service. Don't take it too personally. 

What saved the dinner (and finally overpowered that fishy taste out of my mouth) was the dessert. We wanted something to share. I was leaning towards the fruit crisp while the beau voiced a strong preference for the panna cotta. Since it was his birthday, of course he got to decide. It was an excellent choice--probably one of the best panna cottas I've had. 

Still, I didn't come here for the $8 dessert. If that was the case, I needn't spend the other $150+. The good ending makes for an easier forgiving of a less than satisfactory entree, but it's just not enough for a total forgetting.
author: Rona J.

description:
Been here a few times and the food and service had been good. I like it better than Town Hall.

The last time we were at Salt House, the only complain I have was that we were seated below the stairs and it was so noisy from people walking up and down the stairs. It was annoying.

I haven't been back since and it has been a while. The last time we were next door (Roy's), I noticed that Salt House wasn't open, and it was a regular business evening.  Not sure what was going on.  I guess perhaps it's time to head back to check it out again.
author: Florence W.

description:
Starting with the 'mixed nuts' I was sold. These are no ordinary nuts, be forwarned. mix in truffle oil and sea salt and they are TASTY!
Only seating around 75 people...Salt House makes for an intimate & comfortable dining experience. Great for a date night - and as usual, the service is impeccable (4 stars for Doug Washington!). Love the old SOMA warehouse design and exposed brick walls, Small bar and exposed steel structures. Very fitting for it's surroundings.

And the food....WOW. Nothing was overlooked - from the oysters, to the special crab salad, to the entrees (try the scallops) We were impressed over and over again.

So happy to have a new late night eatery in the hood.
author: Melissa W.

description:
So crowded! And what a tight squeeze between tables! We were sat right next to where the people were coming out of the kitchen, and every time I got up out of my chair I had to look both ways (like I'm crossing a street) in order to avoid being crashed into by a server, or someone heading for the bathroom.

I realize that this is San Francisco and every square foot of space is valuable, but when you're at Salt house and spending multiple $$$, you would expect to have some elbow room. I really think the average stars for this place would go up if management would bite the bullet and take out a few tables.

The service was excellent, the only downside being that when our main dishes took for-ev-er to come out. I ordered a sauvignon blanc and the tuna, and my wine was long since warm by the time the tuna came out. I actually thought about asking for an ice cube for my wine but I didn't want to appear gauche, since we were dining with my significant other's parental unit. But, I see on Craigslist that they are adding a line cook, so maybe the slowness problem is about to be fixed!

Other than those two gripes, which cost 1 star each, everything was excellent. I enjoyed the tuna, but not as much as I enjoyed a bite of the lamb, which my boyfriend ordered. GET THE LAMB. I also really enjoyed the chili cheese fries, UM, ER, I MEAN, the poutine. There was little chunks of steak in the gravy. Mmmm. And the shrimp/prosciutto appetizer was great as well.

The service was also very good!

We went for dinner, but I see from the other reviews that they have a different menu for lunch. I would like to go back and try lunch.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Overall, this place was great. Ate here while catching up with a friend I don't get to see very often, and we both loved it. 

Ambiance: pleasant. There's a good level of buzz in the place, but not so much that you can't chat with your dining partners. 

Staff: great. We had a res and they were late seating us, but the host was apologetic, kept updating us,and we only had to wait 5-10 minutes. Normally this pisses me off but the host's attitude really made up for it. 

Food: delicious. We started with the poutine, which is fried potatoes, gravy, cheese and shortribs. I LOVED THIS!! Might not be for everyone, but we licked the plate. We also had the crispy shrimp, equally delicious, with a nice spicy dressing on the greens. Also, plenty of greens, it's practically a shrimp salad. My friend had the chicken, and I had the cassoulet--both of which we enjoyed. 

I was so stuffed from the starters that I only ate about 1/2 the cassoulet, server checked in to make sure it was ok, that I wasn't leaving so much behind because I didn't like it. Another plus for the staff. 

The only downside--the bathrooms are way too damn dark. Ladies, don't plan on touching up makeup or hair in here--you can barely find the toilet paper, let alone see your reflection. I'm all for interesting design and lighting, but a girl needs to reapply her lipstick, you know?
author: Courtney M.

description:
This was my first time to the Salt House. My BF wanted to take me somewhere nice and someplace he really liked. Now I can see why.....I was really impressed with all of the courses. The bar is really cute , the whole restaurant kinda gives a nice yet rustic feel. We got there a few minutes early so we ordered martinis. I was impressed right off the bat, maybe one of the best martinis i have had in a while. 

Once seated we started with a bottle of Reisling, a German bottle....very tasty =) Fruity but not too sweet.

Then moved along to the Poutine, yummy. For our main dish we both ordered the Steak. It came with a sunchoke puree, short rib with a mustard crust and brussel sproutes...OMG this was delicious. We were both very happy wih our choice. Cooked to perfection, needless to say there was nothing left on either of our plates. 

Of course we had to order dessert. So we went with the Chocolate Cremoux...so good. It's very rare when every single thing you order is SO SO SOOO good. Usually you can walk away saying the apps were good, or the main dish was great but the rest was so-so...not this night. Everything was perfect and we had a very good date night =) 

Very nice atmosphere, good service, great food and good company...couldn't have asked for more =) It was a 5 star night.
author: Leza B.

description:
Came here for cocktails with two friends.  Not only was the decor way chic and calming, but I got to overhear FiDiners in suits talk about STI's.  (I is for "infection."  Get with the lingo update).

I ordered the "Apuro Grande" - In a "great hurry" for what?  Hmm.  Enticing.  Ripe with innuendo (isn't everything).  Lovely the relationship between cilantro and tequila - I'll have to have them over *in my mouth* some time again soon.  The menu didn't present anything I felt I just HAD to try, but I needed a snack and so opted for the soup.  Crispy "croutons" were more aptly labled "fried batter" and they were a tasty crunchy complement to the smooth creamy concoction with a hint of spice.  Not big or ostentatious enough to cost $8.5 in my opinion, but satisfying - given the bread I suggested they give me on the side.  As for my friends' drinks: the salty dog didn't seem like much, so diminutive in its martini glass after I'd enjoyed a big honking one at Von Kleef's the night before.  The Ginger Julep impressed.

Not a bad spot at all.  Somewhere between "yay" and "OK.*" Recommended to me by the bartender at 83 proof when I noted that booze before something in my belly might be disasterous and he helped me realize that (obviously) 83 has no kitchen.  I'm not intrigued to come back for dinner, but may have another cocktail-with-culture here next visit to the MoMa.  This seems like more of an after-work gathering spot, but single women who don't have STI's may find a willing pickup partner who is very "straightforward about these things, and clean."  Also a few dates appeared to be in swing at those sexy tables by the window.

*Surely you must have by now figured that my star ratings are arbitrary at best.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Had lunch here for the first time last week.  I was a couple glasses of wine into the meal and excused myself to the restroom.   I thought I was experiencing an epic shampoo effect as I walked in and felt a hazy yet powerful sense of deja vu.  I almost stumbled as my mind sifted through a smoky maze of fragments that seemed to be backed by the thump of house music and the taste of tequila.  Thats it!  I HAD been in this bathroom before.  At  ... Harlot!?  Oh yeah .. that night was bananas. 

I came back from the bathroom smiling to myself and ordered a coke.  Ah ... memories.  

I had the cuban sandwich and it was so-so.
author: Brad C.

description:
edited: 
Gabriel and Rory ROCK!

Since the date, I've returned a few times and tried:
+ poutines
+ ahi sashimi with asparagus puree and asparagus, sugar snap peas, radish, and scallion w/ a lemon coriander vinaigrette (the chef personally came out to serve us and i grilled him haha)
+ oysters... a bunch of oysters... i'm a fan of the champagne vinegar sauce thingy

Bottomline: I LOVE the environment and the staff!!

ps
The calamari is filled with chorizo and last night it was a tad salty =/
________________________________________
A date took me here and I enjoyed every second of it!
There's parking RIGHT next door.
The hostess is extremely lovely!
Our server was attentive, friendly, and hot.
The bread was perfect and the butter was delicious!
Calamari was unconventional (not fried) and my date was a little taken back but I LOVED it! The chick peas had a nice bite, it was seasoned just right, and whatever the filling was in the squid thingies was sooooo good!

Our mains:
Alaskan Halibut with shiitake mushrooms and asparagus with shears of something (I forgot).. it may have been a little Asian inspired for I tasted a bit of soy sauce/dashi... it was light but a taaaad too savory (if that makes any sense) for my palate but not bothersome, at all.

Grilled Ahi (medium) with marmalade something and vegetables... not my dish so I forgot... but I was fortunate enough to try some and it was yummy! A very very spring like dish that made me smile =)

Dessert: cheese plate... there was marmalade with a spice i couldn't decipher and some argula with candied nuts. 


My only two complaints are:
1. The Asian bus person (Vietnamese man) is a little hmmm... over  eager? He grabbed my plate not once, but twice, without asking if I was finished... then after that he kept coming back too soon to clear plates.
2. Of course the bathroom. ugh. What a disaster

But other than that, I am a fan!
author: Mona N.

description:
Happy hour spot!
Front window people watching
Big-glass Manhattan
author: HaikuReview S.

description:
The sauteed foie gras at Salt House has changed my life.  Yes, it was THAT good.  The pate kind was good as well and the cherries complimented the dish nicely.  It was so good, that as soon as we finished the plate, we immediately ordered another.  That's right.  Two orders of the foie gras!!  I think that was a first.  

The other stand out were the oysters--I have never had a kumamoto before and I was thinking my god--why haven't I??  They are so good!  Smaller and sweeter.. yummm!  

The entree monkfish was good, but I could've had a third helping of the foie gras.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Miranda S.

description:
What a unique name, definitely a notable restaurant. 

Came to check out this place with a new lunch partner, was smart in calling in for a lunchtime reservation. This place always seems to be so busy, and I can see why. 

The space is open and airy, great for conversating..  there is an interesting painting on the wall of a charging horseman.

Service was attentive, efficient and friendly.

I asked if the chef could come up with a vegan dish, and to the surprise of my lunch companion, they were very accommodating.

We ordered the shrimp appetizer.. the shrimp was crispy-battered lightly, and served over a nice portion of green beans in a creamy spicy sauce. Delectable!

For the entrees, my lunch partner ordered the pork sandwich. Served pub-style with potato chips. He thought it was 'ok'.. 

However, my entree was awesome! A nice mixture of warm beans, green beans, baby greens, creamy mashed potatoes flavored with minced olives, served on a heated plate.. Amazingly good, and a perfect portion!

For dessert, we settled on the molten chocolate cake, with double espresso. Cake was topped with warm cherries and homemade pistachio ice cream w/ warm nuts to the side. Creamy chocolate lava on the inside. Excellent, but may have been orgasmic if the cake was served a bit meltier.

I give it 5 stars.. a lunch experience that left me happily nourished for the rest of the day-- It turned out to be one of those late night work days, and I didn't even mind.. :)

So make it a point to come here for a lunch experience that is sure to make your day go right!
author: Vicky P.

description:
There isn't much on the menu but most of it is well prepared.  Where Townhall is unfocused and bland, this place hits it on the mark.  Less choices also means you know what you want right away.  I usually get oysters, gravy fries, smoked trout, and crispy shrimp.  They have a really nice selection of wines and the bartendars mix up strong drinks. 

It's a good spot after work since it's centrally located between the financial district and the rest of SOMA.  The space isn't that big but the high ceilings makes everything feel spacious.  I also love the vast number of places where you can sit, by the windows facing the street, at the bar, at the communal table, or in the back dining area near the kitchen action.  I like it by the bar though, you get your drinks faster.  ;)
author: Kimmie N.

description:
I treated my frenemy Christina here to congratulate her on her impressively high GRE score. (The deal was if she got a high score, I'd take her somewhere nice; if she got a low score, we would dine at the nearby homeless shelter.) I ordered the roasted duck -- the other dark meat -- and Christina ordered the rock cod sandwich. 

My duck portion was merely a thigh. I was a little disappointed (kind of like how my parents felt when I majored in English), but I wasn't starving, so it filled me up anyway. Although I wonder what they did with the rest of the duck. Do they serve one body part per plate of duck? Or do they kill ducks just for their thighs and throw away the rest of their bodies? I can't help but feel bad for the feathered rascals nowadays: My vegetarian ex-girlfriend dumped me because I was an insensitive carnivore. The girl she's dating now is vegan.

Christina compared her rock cod sandwich to a Filet-O-Fish. Sigh. So much for unbuckling the chastity belt.
author: Brian C.

description: Place is snazzy with the ambience and all. Ordered the poutine and crispy shrimp appetizers and both items were good. Not sure if I would go back, but the drinks were sure dee-lish :)
author: Kristina T.

description:
Oh crap. I want you to read this review and then drop everything and immediately go to Salt House and order the crispy shrimp. This is the most  bad ass thing on the planet, besides the hottie that brought it to me. 
If you read my review of Town Hall, uh wait if you haven't you better do so right now!, you know how I feel about sauce. The sauce that enrobes the greens and green bean mix that the serrano ham and fried shrimp lay upon is effin fantastic. Poutine was delish too, I mean how can you go wrong with crispy fries, melted cheese and short rib gravy. Add the Fois Gras torchon and I am surprised my heart is still beating today. 
I will be back for dinner soon, maybe after I get my new pacemaker.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Simply put, I like this place.  If it wasn't so freakin' loud, I would be more effusive in my praise.

I've been here several times and the food has always been very good.  The poutine is my absolute favorite and probably the reason I've been here more than once.  The staff has always been congenial, but not necessarily always fast.   I've also had good luck with the house specialty drinks.  The wine selection is adequate, with a small selection 'by the glass'.
author: Tom Y.

description:
so, since i live like 3 feet from this place i've been dying to check it out- went on a monday night and it was great! people running out of the rain and into a very warm, woodsy, relaxed atmosphere.... had a couple glasses a wine with friends and some bites of bread- can't report back on  the food but will once i have eaten there! I hear this place does get packed....oh and i guess it's owned by the same people as town hall...that's the word on the street!

update: went here for dinner this week and it was yumy....a little pricey....got the tomatoe salad and some fish....mmmmm mmmmmmmm
author: Ricquel N.

description:
The Foie Gras was excellent, the Steak I was excellent, the wine list was nice but not expansive.  The service was ok, if not "bursty" in terms of responsiveness.

Prices were higher than I'd expect for the quality/etc, but I didn't feel short changed too much.

You should visit if you can see dropping about $200 for two people.
author: Tom S.

description:
I think that every server I have ever known has ended up at the Salt House.  It's like a homecoming every time I go in.  I love it.  Which may be why I have always had great experiences with the service and the food.  Everything I've had there has been great and the Manhattans (made with rye bourbon of course) are some of the best in town.  

Love it.
author: Jessica B.

description:
I was impressed by Salt House, although I didn't have the complete dining experience.  Glowing from an accomplishment earlier in the evening, my dining (eh, drinking) companion and I stopped for a celebratory late drink and snack.  This was the first (and probably only) time I tried pork belly.  It was surprisingly pretty good!  The texture turned me off, but the flavor was full and juicy.

What impressed me most was the bartender.  When my cocktail was too sweet he gladly remade another, no charge.  Both were veeeeery strong.  He was very conversive and gladly gave a rundown of the menu even though it was just about time to cut off food service.  He rushed our order without making us feel guilty at all.  Great service!

I'm a sucker for sleek brick interior decor, and the decor here is right on.  Hopefully I'll be back before long.
author: Marina Maven C.

description:
Fantastic.  I've been there several times and I have failed to review the place.  They have a nice ambience and it's very festive, albeit a bit loud when busy.  The food is exactly what you would expect from a solid establishment.  I tend to be repetitive and order a few shellfish, the poutine and their special.  Everytime I get their special, it's phenomenal.

They have a small bar to grab a drink so that can be fun as well, as you wait for your table.  All in all, Salt House is my top pick at this point for places to grab dinner in SOMA.
author: E L.

description:
Just had dinner at Town Hall last week and noticed Salt House was owned by the same guys.

Although, the loud atmosphere isn't for everyone, I enjoyed it. It gave a natural energy to our conversation which filled time between courses.

Enjoyed the pickled vegetables and olives as an appetizer, and the mixed lettuce salad was fantastic.

The fiance ordered the braised short ribs while I had the yellowfish tuna.  The tuna was just a touch overcooked but was delicious accompanied by fondue sauce that perfectly complimented the fish.

The short ribs were juicy and were quickly finished off before I got a second bit off her plate.

A great date spot!
author: Chad K.

description:
For the prices Salt House charges, everything should be impeccable; food, service, ambiance, decor and drink. The night we went for birthday party (8), the service was a bit offline, and the server's wine recommendation was crap. Ambiance and decor are nice, but let's not have barely legal children serving wine they don't know.

I didn't like the putain and the duck was just OK. Others had some beefy stuff, maybe mutton; whatevs. Like I said, a bit expensive for what it isn't. I know larger parties (eff going to din w/ more than 4!) suck it, but overall not really hitting switches with me. Much the same as Dosa; not really loving it.
author: Jafon H.

description: eh! Seriously not that impressed. The wine recommendations were price-based and while the food was certainly *good* it wasn't anything special. I enjoyed the appetizers the most (the fries with gravy, the foie gras, and the scallops were quite tasty). I had the Tuna which was yummy, but again nothing special. There are a million other places I would rather return to than this.
author: Nikki M.

description: The food was actually well presented and flavors very well developed.  Service was TERRIBLE!   Reviews have many complaining of the same but we gave it a shot.  15 minutes in - no cocktails served but oysters came which was a bad start.  1 hour in - no entrees yet, manager brings 2 salads apologizing for kitchen delays - not a word from our waitress.  Seemed to be a lot of staff running around but not a whole lot happening.  Finally at an hour and fifteen min in - entrees arrive    My husband ordered med rare ribeye.  I looked at it and asked the waitress if it was really ribeye - she said oh yes absolutely.  It was in chunks/pieces not anything like a ribeye should be so asked Him for a bite.  Seasoning was great but definitely not ribeye - you can't pull this shit over on me as I am a meat and food industry professional.   Manager comes back and asks how we are doing?   I asked her if it was ribeye and she quietly acknowledged they had run out and it was skirt steak which I know it wasn't that either.  I told her I was in the food and meat business and the waitress should have been upfront from the get-go.   Had I been the manager I would have comped something off the bill but they offered nothing and I refuse to ask if not offered when they should be.   We will NOT be going back.  Very good food but massive service failure = overall bad rating and we are never returning.   Same company that owns anchor and hope in SF own salt house - both suffer same crappy service.   If you are going to be in the hospitality business - GET IT RIGHT as you won't survive otherwise.
author: Greg W.

description:
I've been twice now and yes, I'll be going back. 

From the friendly staff, to the perfectly portioned appetizers and entrees, to the warm woody/contemporary concrete ambiance, I enjoyed it thoroughly. 

I had the beef short rib and the poutine (of course). The short ribs were delicious and tender with just the right seasoning. And the poutine... well I liken that to the ultimate in comfort food. Tasty for sure! 

I do have to disclose that the manager of the restaurant is an acquaintance and he did bring over a nice bottle of bubbly for our table of four. That aside, the second time I went back, the staff was just as pleasant and helpful as ever! 

Nicely done Salt House!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
"Hey, you two!"

I am fortunate to have friends and family who don't mind sharing a meal with me.  I don't know if they really want to, but at least they're polite enough to pretend they do.  My point is, when I go out to eat, I usually go with somebody else.  

Still, until today never had I heard the waiters address us as "you two."  The first time our waitress did it, I thought it was a little weird.  The second time she did it, I pointed it out to my friend.  My friend didn't find it unusual, however.  Maybe it's just me.

Anyway, back to Salt House.  The place is very SOMA chic: exposed brick walls, metal beams, etc.  The decorators did a marvelous job of maintaining the old printing press warehouse feel, while making the place look classy, not cheesy.  The lunch crowd here consists mostly of people with corporate credit cards, because lunch here is NOT cheap.

"Something to drink, you two?"  They brought me a glass of iced tea and some water in a clear glass carafe with a black pirate flag and letters "SH" on it.  Then, out came the  bread: delicious baguette presented on a piece of brown butcher paper.

"Are you two ready to order?"  Sure, why not.  I had the mixed lettuces salad, which was very good.  The butter lettuce was so buttery (pardon the adjective) that it distracted me from the rest of the salad.  The red wine vinaigrette dressing was very good.  I had the gnocchi with eggplant, tomatoes, corn and squash blossoms.  I very rarely enjoy a vegetarian entree, but this was one of those rare occasions.  The actual gnocchi were fluffy and light.  I secretly wished for some cheesy Alfredo sauce, but it wasn't meant to be.  My friend really enjoyed her Petrale Sole.  I tried a small piece, and I have to agree that the fish was tender and even a little bit sweet.

"Dessert, you two?"  Dessert for lunch?  No, thanks. 

As we were leaving the restaurant, the hostess said "Bye, you two.  Thanks!"  I politely waited until I was outside to laugh.
author: Yan G.

description:
I was very disappointed with the food and service at Salt House.  I have previously been a big fan of this establishment, having enjoyed its food and style many times over the years.  This last visit was sad enough that I feel obligated to review it negatively.  The hostess was disorganized, rude and unfriendly when we showed up, on time, for our reservation. Despite the presence of a half dozen empty tables. the Hostess sat several folks who arrived after us, including walk-ins, had time to chat with the bar patrons and was barely able to speak to us long enough to ask us to wait, three times. Apparently, we didn't seem eligible or interesting enough to merit her attentions, unlike the young men at the bar she was fawning over shamelessly.  It was as if we annoyed her by being there.  

Once we were seated, the wait staff failed to notice us for quite a while. When the waiter finally did approach our table, he was obviously put out that only two of us were drinking alcohol - his attitude got somewhat unpleasant and dismissive.  He made absolutely no attempt to describe the food, engage us in any way or answer simple questions about the food.   He seemed so very sad and bored, a feeling we also got from the busboys, the cooks , the bartender ... the whole place seemed surly and depressed.  

The waiter only managed to show up twice more through the rest of the meal.  He wandered by once, dispiritedly asking "how was everything?" in a mumble without looking up.  He took our orders, then disappeared for parts unknown, leaving the delivery of the food to others.  Towards the end of the meal, he briefly showed his face, slapped a few desert menus down on the dirty table and stalked off without comment.  

The food itself was not as good as it has previously been - overcooked, dropped onto the tables without concern, plated sloppily and really somewhat bland other than the preponderance of salt on the meat and fish courses. The Poutine, for which they are somewhat known, was a massive disappointment - I had talked it up to the other couple dining with us, having enjoyed it a great deal in the past.  The fries were overcooked badly, the cheese was melted haphazardly over one half of the plate, leaving the other side bare and the gravy was cold and congealed.  First time we've ever left fries on the plate ... 

It seems they've toned down the menu, almost certainly lost their old chef and have apparently refocused on being a local bar that serves food, no longer a restaurant with a bar.  For what it's worth, the the drink I ordered was not well made at all, watered down terribly, and not even filling the glass.  From where we sat, we could see the bartender work and I watched with a certain envy as the bar-side regulars got very long pours in their glases while our table got weak, overpriced drinks.  

We felt ignored, unwelcome from the moment we walked in to the moment we left.  For the price, this is no longer a good restaurant. It cost us $250 to eat there, a slightly higher than average price by local standards - in all honesty, the food and service didn't merit that price point.  I'm sorry to say I won't be back - there are too many equal or better choices available for the money, or less, and I'd rather feel welcome.
author: Paul G.

description:
I picked today to try to start eating better.....uh huh riiiight.

I went to the Salt House for lunch and ordered off of the appetizer section. I had heard the Poutine was delish but did not really know what it was....

Poutine is a dish made with crispy potatoes/short rib gravy and white cheddar cheese. Sounded very yummy but bad for the waist line, I figured it would be small since it was on the appetizer list.....

Who knew it was a BIG bowl of fries! Yes, the cheese was on top and I asked for the gravy on the side but after tasting it I poured the gravy over the golden goodness. 

Oh, I ate the whole bowl (sans two fries as my friends wanted to taste)! Unfortunately, I did not conversate much I- was heaven shoveling those babies in my mouth.

I love this place and the service was wonderful....I would come back again.

Well, I am going for a run  to work off  the Poutine.....
author: Deanna J.

description:
In Wisconsin during deer hunting season there are two constants found in the woods - racks of animal lard hanging from trees and water heater sized bricks of salt on the ground. It was until this day that I remained confused about Bambi's attraction to random clumps of salt and fat. My dad would patiently explain, speaking to his clueless, city-boy son, that the deer "just need the salt to make it through the winter." Just like he needed the clumps of fat and salt to make him a better hunter, eh?

Like our venison flavored friends, I was hoping to find some sort of salt lick, salted pork, or just goddamn salt at the Salt House. Ironically we had to ask for salt.

My friend and I sat at the bar - it's hard to get reservations and I scored two seats. The bartenders were busy but cool, letting me squat for two until my friend arrived. Folks around the bar were friendly and hip - an entourage from Slanted Door, Straights Cafe and Roy's chatted with me about their biz. Holla to Huey!

After having some wine and bitter lemon drop we got to eating. I was all eager beaver about the menu - we selected five kinds of raw oysters including Kumamoto (holla Kuwamoto!), yellow tail tuna, crab salad, pork tenderloin, merguez and chick peas, and the rib eye steak entree.

The oysters were heaven. But we freaked out when we had our bite of yellow tail - there was an aspic-like citrus gelatin forcing puckers on our faces. Was this sashimi or ceviche - yikes! Things were not looking good. The crab salad was unique tasting but had a strong overtone of olives which led to horrible onomatopoeia in our adjectives about it's olivioliness. 

At this point I suggested to my friend that "our palettes were being challenged." I wanted loveliness not olivioliness. Fortunately the uber decadent pork belly warmed our bellies, and loins, and made everything better. By the time we made it to the perfectly seared rib eye, with adorning accents of chunky bacon and spinach we were in meaty bliss.

At times, dining at the bar sucked. People passed glasses over our heads and screamed to get the bartenders attention. But stick around till later and things will clear up, just like your highschool acne. The brickhouse ambiance was easy to enjoy, especially with such beautiful company. In summary, we had our fill of animal fat, but were hard pressed to find the salt in our San Franciscan forest.
author: Brady K.

description:
We went there on a busy Thursday night without a reservation, but they were happy to seat us at the bar.  I ordered the house specialty mango caipirinha, which was very good and made with fresh mangoes.  The bartenders are very friendly but don't try to push drinks on you.  

For the appetizer we split the poutine because we used to live in Montreal and have a craving for it - so hard to find outside of Quebec.  The owner brought it to us personally and mentioned he used to live in Vancouver.  The fries were crisp and the gravy was good - the gravy comes on the side in a small gravy decanter.  The cheese was a big disappointment - it was shredded white cheddar.  Authentic poutine has cheese curds, not shredded cheese.  The cheese kind of lumped up and overall the dish was too salty, and missing the distinctive "squick" of cheese curds that makes a good poutine.  So, if you're a Quebecois expat craving poutine, this is not the poutine you are looking for.

Entrees were good-sized portions; I had the ribeye steak which was cooked perfectly and my partner had the duck breast.  All very delicious and brought to the table at a reasonable time.

All in all a very pleasing dining experience and I would go back.  The interior is very tasteful, the service is warm and friendly - no snobby attitudes - and customers are elegantly dressed, there is a nice atmosphere, and I like the idea of the communal tables.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Salt House is welcome culinary addition to the SoFiDi (South of Financial District) area. 

I found the atmosphere casual yet warm. Lots of exposed brick (I like), high-ceilings, and a variety of seating options (bar, bar-height tables, booths, 2 person tables, etc). The open kitchen is a nice addition as well if you like seeing your food being prepared. Interesting medieval-esque artwork, warm glowing lamps near each window. Kept the music volume at a decent level for maintaining a conversation.  

Could be good for a business lunch since it was nice for a casual dinner, but it might be noisier during the daytime with current construction going on next door.

I recommend the crab salad with fried artichokes to start. Highly recommend the duck dish entree. Lots of flavor and a generously-sized portion.

Minus one star for the length of time it took for our food to come out, but if I could I'd give it 1/2 a star more because the food was certainly worth the wait.
author: John Eric S.

description:
Ah Salt House, I can give you a soft four stars. I don't know that I have a whole lot to add beyond what others have said. Overall, I enjoyed the food (Crispy Shrimp, Duck, and Apple Gallette for desert) but was left with the nagging feeling that something just didn't work about the whole experience. For example, the crispy shrimp were tasty (who couldn't love battered shrimp on top of enough greens to convince yourself that it's healthy?) but seemed out of place with a lot of the other selections on the menu. The duck entree was quite good, but I actually prefer the presentation and sides at Town Hall. 

The decor is good, but I had a table near the door that was a bit drafty. Service was snappy and good.

I wish I could put my finger on exactly what didn't feel quite right about Salt House. As good as this place is, I fear it might be destined to be "that place across the street from Town Hall that's owned by the same people" as opposed to something that can stand on its own. Hopefully future visits will change my views.
author: Charles H.

description: Some gastronomic delight. I could tell they've put their heart and soul into every dish. I enjoyed my Sea Bass - very tender and delish. I liked my cocktail (One and Only) too. The service was kinda slow, though.
author: Kara Y.

description:
OMG OMG OMG

Wow what a night!  Five of us headed here for Father's Day, being that all our fathers were on the east coast.  My friend Elizabeth knows one of the chef's from culinary school, so her friend definitely took care of us.

So here's what we ate - and here's what I thought

APPETIZERS:
1) Poutine - these just looked like glamorized french fries with tasty cheese on top.  If I was picking just one appetizer, this wouldn't be my choice, but they were tasty.
2) English Pea Soup - my friend got the soup without the creme fraiche.  They serve it cold, she got it warm.  I liked it, it just tasted very very fresh.
3) Spring Vegetable Salad - my friend got this as well.  I didn't try it, but she finished it and it looked good.
4) Yellowfin Tuna Tartare - the apples were a really nice touch.  It was a spin on your traditional asian style tartare.
5) Crispy Shrimp - So awesome!  Highly recommend this one.  The green beans were in a spicy orange sauce.
6) Foie Gras - I'm not a meat eater, but I do try meat, especially when its a delicacy.  shit was good. 

Entrees
1) Petrale Sole - two of my friends got this.  The fava beans were green, which was different, but again, everything tastes so fresh.  The sole was crispy on the outside (not fried crispy, just well done on top)
2) Monkfish - this isn't on the online version of the menu, but this is what I ordered.  It was in a nice tasting broth with green chickpeas, which was different just like the fava beans.  It came with mussels and shrimp. Very tasty, the kind of sauce you want endless bread to dip in.
3) Vegetarian Dish - you can ask for a completely vegetarian dish.  Another friend got this and she said it was really great.

DESSERT
1) Strawberry Trifle - i didn't care that i was lactose intolerant when this came out!
2) Pistachio Ice Cream with Chocolate Cake - I didn't eat the ice cream, but my friends said the pistachios were to die for.  The chocolate cake had a chocolatey-creamy inside that melted in your mouth
3) Coffee Ice Cream - again, I didn't eat the ice cream, but this was also finished (AND LOOK AT HOW MUCH WE ATE!)
4) Cheese platter - I didn't partake in the cheese, but they're selections are great, with apple slices, figs and apricots.
author: Lindsay T.

description: Reliably good, and close to work.  I like dinner better than lunch.  I prefer it to Town Hall, and Anchor and Hope.
author: Matthew C.

description:
Love the room, not so much how popular it is.. always ending up eating at the bar, that however keeps the IPA (or wine) flowing

Great
- merguez
- poutine

Good
- oysters (Kumamoto)
- foie gras
- halibut

Minus
- pricey

To try
- sole
- dessert
author: xo x.

description:
I'd probably say 3 1/2 stars - worth trying,  there's so many places in the city to try out, so it's hard to say if I'll be back again soon.  I'll be back, just not sure if it'll be sooner rather than later.

What would bring me back:
The poutines - crispy french fries with cheese and shortrib gravy that they pour table side YUMMMY
The crispy egg - I want to try that at home
The espresso chocolate pot de creme

What else was good:
The short ribs
The sole with chantrelles - I think it's the chantrelles that make it yummier
My hubby really liked the lamb, I wasn't a big fan, but I'm not normally a fan of lamb BAAA

The scallop appetizer was ok as was the fruit crisp with five spice ice cream.  The marscapone panna cotta wasn't very good.

There were four of us - so I wasn't a complete pig eating all of the above food.  It's so much nicer eating out with another couple so you can sample so much more of the menu.

It was a Sunday evening so our service was attentive, read that others had hit or miss experiences.   The butcher top tables were a nice touch - different.  Also liked the rest of the decor although it was a bit chilly sitting in the back - the heat from the kitchen helped, but there seemed to be a draft.  (I hate being cold)
author: Mabelle A.

description:
Had a business meeting over lunch at Salt House today. Our reservation was for 11:30am, and when we arrived the place was empty save for the staff prepping for the lunch crowd. 

The hostess gave us a private table in the upstairs loft, as removed as possible from the oncoming lunch rush. The wait staff was attentive and respectful: at one point our waiter approached in the middle of a vigorous discussion, thought better of it, and opted to come back later.

I had the chicken pot pie, which was delicious.  The mint-lemonade was odd, but tasty. 

Our meeting took close to two hours, and never  were we rushed by the staff. My water glass was always full, and I loved the old-school milk bottles turned water bottle. 

Great place for a business lunch. The staff gets respects your space, and works well with the concept.
author: Greg Q.

description:
I went to two restaurants for the first time over the Memorial Day weekend - Spork (Yay!) and Salt House (BOO!) I'm sure the food was fine, but the experience was completely spoiled by the worst service I have ever had. Lest you think I'm exaggerating, here's a rundown:

We waited an hour (no kidding) between the appetizer and the main course and the waiter snapped "it's coming" when asked (nicely - I know delays are usually not a waiters fault).

Five minutes later the manager came and said the kitchen had made a mistake and he would provide us with food to tide us over - it was nuts and olives for which they added $20 to the bill.

The waiter consolidated two glasses of, not only completely different wine, but different people's wine, into one glass and handed it to one of the diners

For vegetarians there was a "mystery meal" that was not on the menu and the waiter could not describe.  What came was basically a plate of sauteed vegetables, for which they were charged the same price as the chicken meal.

Though we were a group of 7 and expected the tip to be included, our (terrible) waiter hand wrote his own tip in the tip line. it was significantly too high for the service, and if we weren't so completely trained to tip well, we would have, and should have, crossed it out and written in our own tip. 

Bottom line, not worth the price or the headache.
author: Nancy L.

description:
I've eaten at Salt House a number of times and have enjoyed it every time. The latest time was the best - our server was outstanding and really made our experience delightful. It was a crowded Saturday night, and she managed to indulge us, split some courses, and did a great job selecting wine pairings. Really great!

As for the food, the celery soup was mmm yummy. The scallops were great, but nothing special (every restaurant in SF seems to offer scallops), the pork belly was out of control (I'm seeing this more and more), and the sole was really nice and light, while still being super flavorful. Decided against dessert.

It's a little loud, the decor is cool and modern, and it goes well with the rest of the SF restaurant scene. Not mind-blowing, but a great choice for any night.
author: Josh O.

description:
Went here for lunch today and had a great experience. We ordered a bunch of starters for the table - everything was delicious. 
And for a main course I had the clams with Portuguese sausage. So yum. Everyone else seemed to really like their lunch too.
Service was really friendly and quiet in the background.
Nice interior too!
author: Alexandra D.

description: Nothing special about the food at the salt house, too expensive for the food that it can offer, only the service was great.
author: T B.

description:
Everything at Salt House was pleasant, but nothing wowed me.

The poutine and foie gras were good starters.  None of the entrees on the menu jumped out at me, so I went with the Fulton Valley chicken which was decent with a good crispy skin, but not spectacular.

Go to Town Hall instead!
author: S L.

description:
Lunch Review.

GREAT crab salad.  At least 50 dungeness died for my sin.

Baguettes are fantastic.  Get caffed up on the americano!  Do it!

The waiterstaff have sexy accents.

It's a little loud in there, though and the walk to the bathroom is a little ghetto.
author: Jessica M.

description:
OK, I was not as happy as I thought I would be.  The decor is cool, and the service was pretty prompt, but I do not understand why everything we ordered was delivered at the same time.  Appetizers, entrees, etc.  We weren't the only one who had this problem.  The folks sitting next to us had a platter of oysters on their table, then their salads arrived, then a bowl of soup - how are you supposed to fit all that on one table?

Anyway, what I ate was amazing - best yellow fin tuna I've had anywhere but Hawaii.  My friend's scallops were sweet and tasty - but she got two of them for about $25!  

My favorite was the poutine.  Jesus Christ on a plate.   Crispy potatoes covered with cheddar and chunks of slow cooked beef.  I am planning to go back for just that - and a nice glass of red.

Four stars, but it's more like a 3.5 event.
author: .Hon H.

description:
Yay!  Another new restaurant checked off the list.

For those of you who have been to Town Hall, you'll feel right at home in this new-ish SOMA establishment.  The feel is very similiar, and the food is along the same lines (quality wise).

We were quite lucky as we only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table...granted, it was about 10pm on a Thursday night.  We sat down and ordered straight away as we were starving.  The menu had a decent selection, but fair warning goes to any vegetarian.  They have VERY little choice for you veggies!  A friend of mine was going to order a soup but then found out that it wasn't truly vegetarian.  However, they did say they had a Veggie dish that wasn't on the menu.  She went with it, but in the end was disappointed as it was essentially just a bunch of vegetables cooked in a way to make them look more appealing...all for $17...yikes.

But I had the Halibut and it was pretty tasty.  What I would expect.  Not earth shattering, but competently good.  

The service was good....waitress was attentive without being annoyingly overbearing.

Overall, I'm not sure if this would be my number one choice to go back to...but I wouldn't say no if someone suggested it or took me here!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I liked this restaurant, and if I had gotten another entree I think I would have given this place four stars.  I took a friend here for his birthday, so we got lunch one afternoon, and I was really excited.

I got the squash soup (Im pretty sure it was butternut), and the chicken salad with humus fries.  I know, hummus fries?  WTF are those....well, they were delicious and I'll get to those later!  

The soup was delicious!  It was just the right amount, too.  I wish I had stopped there because we had gotten the olives as appetizers and by that point I had some bread and wasn't all that hungry anymore...but so it goes with me (my eyes are always bigger than my stomach).

So, after the soup, came the chicken salad.  I thoguht it was going to be a sandwich...just because most chicken salads come that way, but not this one.  It was just chunks of chicken mixed with other stuff...I loved the flavor of the dish, but I tend to get bored with so much chicken...not a huge fan (that is my fault too for ordering this!)

But the hummus fries....oooo the hummus fries, they were so good, and inovative.  I had never heard of them before, which is partly to blame for me ordering the dish in the first place.  The hummus was lightly breaded and fried, and just really really flavorful.  

My friend got a bunch of food (bastard, cost me an arm and a leg! haha, I joke :) and a couple drinks, and we had a great time.  I will probably give this place a higher rating when I go back for a second try...but for now, the three stars stands...great place though, and I do reccomend it!
author: Kristin E.

description:
San Francisco --- you always do this to me.  You *know* I've already got a city.  We're committed.  I like my place.  Why have you always got to be tempting me like that?

I was in town for a very brief, very hectic few days of business and only barely managed to escape my across-the-street office for an hour-long snack with my best local friend.  We ended up at the Salt House for the simple, unpremeditated reason that it was directly in our line of sight when we walked out of the door --- and, wow, what a lucky find.

Had a couple of drinks and just one split entree --- the fried shrimp on a bed of green beans and parsley --- and it totally knocked my socks off, and made me wonder what the heck it is that I've been paying for in Los Angeles these last few weeks.  The drinks were perfection; and the food was just amazingly careful, delicious, and interesting.  It made me want to move to San Francisco, just to eat there again.

I came back to Los Angeles with parsley and gin still sticking to my collar, feeling dark, ashamed, and totally satisfied.
author: Ashley A.

description:
When i heard that the parents of Town Hall were going to have a second baby, i couldn't wait to try it out.  So, i made a reservation and headed to Salt House.     I was excited.  I love when brilliant owners of yummy restaurants feel the need to open another one.... then i ate.  It was the same disappointing feeling i had when i learned that Nicolas Cage was a Coppola.  Salt  House is the Nicolas Cage of the Town Hall family.

Food = mediocre.  Kind of like NOPA.  Good, but not worth $30 for a breast of chicken.  And the nuts... everyone raved about the nuts.  They're just nuts. 

Ambience = good atmosphere, cute building/ decor.

Bathroom = HUH?!  Just follow the yellow brick road out back, around the corner, and you'll see a port a potty.  (or something like it.)

Service = when i sat down the bartender was talking about how he was the "fluffer" for the bar.  His co-tender apparently was the real star.
author: lindsay f.

description:
I went here for lunch with a couple of people from my office, and it was pretty packed! Good thing we had reservations. I really liked the way the place looked. It was an old brick building with hardwood floors and wooden tables, which gave it a kind of rustic, antiquated feel. Wine glasses were lined up neatly on shelves, and the lamps hanging from the ceiling had some kind of thin index-card-sized wooden boards on them. I'm not really sure how to describe them, but I was intrigued by the lamps for at least a few minutes when I walked in. 

Aside from great decor and service, this place had fabulous food. My tuna tartare was very fresh and had a variety of colorful veggies and herbs to keep the textures interesting. The other folks at my table had the roasted chicken, the dungeness crab, and the seared ahi tuna sandwich with a cold asparagus soup, and they all loved their entrees. We also split an appetizer that had crispy shrimp on top of spicy green  beans, serrano ham, and crunchy almonds with some sort of vinaigrette. Since there were four of us but only three shrimp, we asked them to give us an extra shrimp, for which they only charged us an extra dollar. The desserts were also excellent. 

What really impressed me here was the plating. We were sitting in a table right by the kitchen, so we could see how meticulous the chefs were in arranging the food just right. And the servers would often use white towels to wipe off excess grease or smudges from the sides of the plates so that they would look perfect when they arrived at their tables. 

Also, they serve lemonade in wine glasses. How cool is that?

I think I need to come back to Salt House for dinner :)
author: Lisa M.

description:
We checked this place out last night.  I have to confess that nothing in the menu sounded good to me.  Because of this, I told the BF to just order something and I'd try it.  

Imagine my surprise when everything ... EVERYTHING was delicious!  Great food, great wine selections, great atmosphere.  The only downer was that it was a bit loud for my taste, but other than that, great place!
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
I wanted to check out the place for a while now and finally decided to have an early Sunday supper here.  J and I sat at the far end of the communal table since the bar was kind of full already.  I thought it was the perfect place to sit, as it was in the middle of the restaurant and a little higher to people watch as I sipped on my Salty Dog and Summer Peach Cobbler.  My two vodka based drinks were both yum.

Mealwise, we went tapas style and tried the Crispy Shrimp w/ spicy green beans, almonds, and serrano ham, the Heirloom Tomatoes w/ pecorino, and the Suckling Pig w/ figs.  All were delicious but my favorite was just the spicy green beans w/ the serrano ham.  For dessert, we had the Roast Peach and the Basque cake w/ Earl Grey ice cream, which in the end, I proclaim the ice cream as the dessert star.

All in all, it was a lovely place to have some bites.  I must say the service was really terrific.  Everyone, from the hostess to waitress to the busboys, were all very attentive, friendly, and seemed really happy to work there.  It translated to the dining experience.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Came here with the same girlfriend I went to Town Hall with. It was mid-week, after work. This place is busy with a cool after-work crowd but seems to be going through an identity crisis. It doesn't offer a wide variety of wines, nor beer, nor anything for that matter. It's a quasi neo something place that doesn't quite specialize in anything. It has a French leaning but seems to serve tapas type of food and the deco is modern-industrial. Anyhow, it's a cool place to visit after work. The crowd's hip. Perhaps having a small plate or two and a glass of wine or a beer before moving on to another location, but not a place I'd make my main destination.

I do like this small seating area up top (a mezzanine of sorts). It's a cool look, but it looks quite small. In fact, we sat in the middle community tables and they weren't very comfortable and servers had a hard time getting through. Somehow the traffic in that place doesn't seem to flow very well.

In terms of food....we had appetizers only: Poutine (okay); crispy shrimp (good); crispy egg (not really my thing); and two artisinal cheeses recommended by our server (wonderful!). The bread they bring out is also quite fresh and good. 

Bottom line: Cool place to visit and have a drink or two after work with a cool crowd. Other than that, I'd pick any other of the many extraordinary places one can find in SF as my final stop.
author: Becky O.

description:
I'll try to make this short and sweet because I know you Yelper's want to get out there and enjoy happy hour pretty soon.

Ambiance:  The restaurant was very cozy and warm, which was nice since it was so cold outside.  I've read about how loud this place can get but it was very quiet when we began our meals, albeit it did get louder as the night wore on and carafes of wine started flowing like, well, wine.  Even though the tables were close together the high ceilings made it possible to have an intimate conversation.   There is also a cool upstairs deck thing that looks fun to sit on.

SERVICE:  I don't know how to describe the service here in eloquent words so I'll stick with awesome.  The FOH staff always seemed to be there when we needed them and away when we didn't.  Our server was very nice and wasn't bad to look at either. ; )  She wasn't too forward or too quiet and was very friendly and approachable.  
--My only issue is that there was no specials for the night.  This is not a huge deal but I was looking forward to something off the menu.  I don't think it's too much to ask when you are paying $40-50 per head.

DRINKS:  We had a carafe of their red wine blend.  It wasn't bad but it wasn't too good either.  Then again I don't expect much from house poured blends to begin with.

FOOD:  We started with the Poutine and the squid.  Both of the dishes were marvelous and well portioned.  The broth that came with the squid was on the salty side though which kind of hurt it.  We also had the braised short rib which was good but not great.  I had the duarta river salmon with potatoes and pureed leeks.  The salmon was amazing and they even left the skin on!  Nothing like some nice crispy fish skin.  The leek puree was out of this world too.  Minus points-- the potato vegetable dish that was served next to the salmon was way too salty.  I mean I know this place is called the Salthouse, but they may be taking their name a tad too literally.

Overall:  I wanted to give this place 3 stars to be honest but the ambiance and service bumped it up a star.  Also, I think the salthouse can be a 4-5 start place if they tone the salt down and start offering specials that highlight seasonal ingredients and exude innovation and creativity.
  I would definitely go back soon, but only for apps and drinks since I'm pretty broke as of current.

Happy eating you weirdos!
author: Nick L.

description:
Everything we had was absolutely delicious, but the stand-out dishes in my mind were the pork belly appetizer (with a poached egg!), the crab salad (little toasty things!) and the lemon pudding cake (was that marshmallow fluff?).

One highlight of our meal concerned the open kitchen, where you can watch the chefs prepare food and bicker over plating.  We were also fortunate enough to witness the woman from the next table trot up to the kitchen counter and ask one of the chefs, "Are you single?"

Chef: "Um, no, sorry..." [sheepish grin]

Woman: "Really?  What about for my cute friend over there in the polka-dot shirt?"

Chef: [glances over at the table, where polka-dotted friend is smiling in an embarrassed, yet hopeful way] "No, sorry. Not single."

When the woman returned to her table, she engaged us in conversation, letting us know that she is very protective of her hot gay friend George who is originally from Spain.  Then she pulled out her camera and started scrolling through pictures from a trip to Croatia.
author: Marcus C.

description:
The food was good. It's nothing to write home (or a raving Yelp review) about. The only thing I would recommend is the poutine. It's just average. What really bugged me was the service. It took at least an hour for our food to come out after the appetizers had already been brought. The server never once came by to apologize or explain the problem in the kitchen. We were sitting by the kitchen and kept seeing dishes that we ordered come up thinking they were ours. No such luck. The erver actually seemed to be avoiding our table (which meant we didn't ever get refills on water and had to flag her down to get refills on drinks).  

Bottom line, go there if you want average food and bad service.
author: Malinda T.

description:
Service is slow as molasses.  Went here for lunch.  Took 10 minutes for the server to bring over water.  And the food took forever.  Our server rarely checked on us.  If you need a speed lunch, this is not the place.  The lunch took us 2 hours total.  I have never experienced such sloooow service.

The best thing was the free bread.
author: Caroline I.

description:
CAN'T WAIT!!!!!

I believe they'll be serving dinner starting next tuesday!

EDIT:

SO! I finally get my butt over to Salt House with a gaggle of ladyfriends.
I was BLOWN AWAY by the ways that it was different from Town Hall in cuisine, yet still had that gene se qua or however french people spell that, that Town Hall retains.

The service was better than expected, as I had read some rollercoaster reviews of the service on here, prior to our reservation.
But perhaps that was because we came in at 10pm.

Being the happenin' new spot, I'm not surpised that they might be so busy and chaotic that service skips a beat or three with some people.
BUT BACK TO ME ME ME:

So we started with the Poutin (A MUST have!)
I nearly scarfed the whole damn thing.

The sausage, which I never order on my own, so I can't review that here.

We then split the Reserve chicken breast with lemon-garlic glaze, and the Steak.
BOTH WERE *SINFULLY* GOOD. I ate most of the steak, and two pieces of the chicken.
I was also concerned from the other reviews that the steak or chicken would be small in size, but those two dishes were enough to satisfy four hungry ladies! (though we filled up on bread and drinks too!)

Then on to the deserts!

I was REALLY concerned about the quality of the deserts going in, again because of mixed and generally poor reviews on here, but since then they musta heard you guys out and improved!

We had the chocolate bunt cake (with caramel and almonds center) and I nearly 'gasmed all over the place!

We then began to brawl over the candied pecan ice cream, which may have been my favorite, but honestly I'd just like a giant bathtub of the two together.
A trough, if you will.

It was decadent, the ambiance was top notch, lively, sinfully yummy. 
Definately a hit!

It's only lacking quality, is a highly carnivorous menu that's not too veg-friendly.
But the cuisine is vegetarian-wagon-fallin' good!
author: TheJane N.

description:
the poutine was definitely the right way to start off the meal. however, i wasn't blown away by the entrees - the halibut was kind of bland, my chicken was on the dry side, and while my friend's duck confit was pretty good, it's not something i would order since im not a huge duck fan. one friend ordered the crispy shrimp appetizer as her entree, and she was pleasantly surprised by the large portion size and fresh, light taste -- although she did admit that it was overly salted (and i agreed).

after sampling the entrees, i understood what previous reviews meant by "there was too much going on". there were several elements in each dish, and for the most part those elements seemed disparate and didn't really come together.

i liked the rhubarb tart for dessert, but i can't even remember what the other was... which means it didn't really make an impression (and i dined there exactly 1 week ago). 

i did like the design elements (the stamped logos on the menus, the piratey design on the water bottles, etc) and the bread, and i'd definitely go back for the poutine, but overall i liked town hall better.
author: Clara K.

description:
Salt house is not an ideal place for a business luncheon. However, yesterday, I found myself here with two men playing "Let's make a deal". However, instead of closing said deal, we shouted, "what?" time back and forth. Salt house is noisy-great for creating a buzzing atmosphere but not so good for negotiating details. 

I had been to SH a year ago and was completely underwhelmed by the food. The shrimp was rubbery and salty (I get the irony) and I didn't feel inspired to yelp about it. 

However, the food yesterday was pretty good. We ordered the Poutine to share at the recommendation of our hipster waiter. Frankly, I was too intimidated to refuse his suggestion-I'm afraid of hipsters. The Poutine is ridiculously rich and should only be shared by parties of 3 or more. I believe Poutine is Canadian hangover food and I can see why: french fries, melty cheese and gravy will coat that stomach nicely. 

I had the petrale sole and found it to be nicely prepared. I like the quinoa it was served on and the chimichurri sauce but, found it too steep at $22 for the entree. The worst part of the meal was suffering from entree envy because one of the other diners got the hamburger with the most amazing thinly sliced onion rings. I feel the need to go back to taste this burger and gorge myself on the onion rings. 

The one thing I was glad to negotiate was not paying for the bill.
author: Monica L.

description:
Again, the hype had lured me in. It's ok, I knew I was entering a well talked-about and trendy little spot. But, every time I do, I have the wishful thinking that people are actually going to be friendly and nice! Not so much the case. Not rude. But, just, not the kind of service you would want at a place like this.

It's interesting, Salt House has the combo after-work drinks and a bite lets mingle and get buzzed crowd early in the evening... along with the hip yet casual friends and couples who want to have a special night out without going all the way (in terms of price range and attire).

They have the current favorite, Communal Table, if the others are filled and a small bar area where you can also eat. I tried to come here with girlfriends once and it was just too hectic and unpleasant to stay. I also came here with my boyfriend and sister and we had a pretty decent meal. We started off with a dozen oysters, which weren't memorable.  

The decor is cool. Has that loft feel with the high ceilings and exposed bricks. It definitely adds to the hip vibe of the place, so if you're ever in the mood for something like that, then definitely give it a shot- but that's pretty much all it needs.
author: Nina H.

description:
Salt of the earth...

Now while i love this fair city, the thing that drives me up the wall is that post 10PM most nights of the week you are heading to Mel's diner, or dealing with the packed confines of The Globe cafe to get your late night 'foodie call'.

From the fine people at Town Hall that brought you mini-corn on the Cob shaped corn bread, amazing pork chops and BBQ shrimp toast, The Salt House, which opens in two weeks, promises to bring another late night haunt to the SOMA area.  

Seating roughly 80-90 urban yip-sters and stocked with staffers from Delphina, Town Hall and other local foodie favorites this new spot will surly be a hit among the dinner and lucky lunch crowd.
author: Derek D.

description:
I came here for lunch on a Friday and the food was absolutely delicious! 

Pomegrante Spritzer: It was okay.  I'm neutral on this one.  Then again, I'm more of a water person.

I forget what it was called, but I got the chicken breast dish with heirloom tomatoes.  I generally don't like eating raw tomatoes, but I ate more than half of them!  They were so good!  

I'm giving this place 4 stars because I generally expect a lot from chicken dishes when ordered from restaurants since I feel like it is a basic dish that is hard to mess up.  You can add to the chicken via sauce, etc. but it's generally always decent.  Not great, just decent.  What makes a good chicken breast dish is 1) making sure the chicken breast is not uber dry and 2) the garnish that compliments the chicken.  For me, Salt House passed on both counts!

Good lunch option if you're not in a hurry.
author: Kristine B.

description: love the chicken sandwich...perfect. had the corn coconut panna cotta for dessert. really unique. pandan, whatever that is, added something. overall. great experience. a little loud but fun.
author: Amanda J.

description:
I liked the staff at the salt house. They were friendly and fantastic. I like the interior, the owners made good use of space. I thought their food was good. 

I hated the crowd, people were tight asses and also a bit unfriendly. It was also very crowded. I also thought the food was quite expensive.
