Two of us, had a salad, a sandwich and dish which including tips came out to $60 for lunch. I can go to better places in the city with better food ( specially someone like me who enjoys cooking ) and better crowd.

I cant say I wanna go back. I might try it once more before i write it off my list. I would not recommend this place unless you have nothing better to do.
author: Amlan S.

description:
Ways to improve Salt House:  
1. Less salt (seriously, I'm not being a jerk -- the food was too salty)
2. Better acoustics (so, way, far too loud in there)
3. More tables to capitalize on the business that will surely disappear once word gets out that the food is too salty and you can't hear anything your dinner companions are saying
4. Rougher flooring (the floors were either greasy or too laminated because I could skid from my table to the bathroom on my heels with very little effort, provided I kept my balance)
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Friday night, pre-Giant's v. Dodger's game, happy hourish time frame = decibel levels too far reaching to have a normal conversation.  It did quiet down about 1/2 way into our entrees ,however it was hard to hear the person next to me talking.   The service was excellent, our server was helpful and attentive...in fact the service was a little too attentive to grabbing stuff off of our table.  On at least 4 occasions things were swept from our sight before we were done with them, the weirdest one was when the birthday girl went to the bathroom to come back and find her plate missing and no way to eat her portion of the heirloom tomato salad.  

As for the food, it was tasty.  We started with the mixed nuts in truffled honey and two of the cheeses.  Next the heirloom salad, fois gras, crispy shrimp and the potatoes.  Things were a bit too salty for a couple of the guests, speaking of the shrimp and the potatoes, however I thought that they were just plain tasty.  My fave was the shrimp dish....the cilantro with the green beans was really tasty.   For dinner we had the monkfish and the B-day girl had the chicken....I wasn't completely wowed by either, but everyone seemed to enjoy their meal immensely.  

The wine list was impressive and the desserts looked yummy as well.  Solid 4 starts for this place...not to mention everyone is too groovy for their own good.  Buon Provecho!
author: Brye L.

description:
YUMMY!  I went to Salt House on a date and I must say it was out of this world!  The restaurant was pretty good too.  Salt House came highly recommended so I decided to check it out.  And it was fantastic!  The decor is rustic, modern, and warm all at the same time.To start we enjoyed the selection of oysters which were fresh, clean and varied.  That was followed by the suckling pig and foie gras appetizers.  I would highly recommend the suckling pig.  For our entrees we had a fish dish (it was the special) and the roasted lamb loin with sunchokes. But were delicious.  The house blend wine was served in the cutest glass jar/bottle.  

I will definitely be back.
author: Johnnie T.

description:
Scallops, sea bass, petrale sole...so good I almost cried. 

Small bar area, but strong drinks.  Only inconvenience is that the wooden slats on the floor were uneven and not very conducive to 4-inch sling-backs.  Plus, every time someone walked by me, my chair had a little earthquake moment -- the vibrations were not intense enough to induce an oh-my-god-sitting-on-a-motorcycle-is-sooo-hot sensation (girls uknowwhatimean), but frequent enough to be annoying.  Otherwise, I think I found a new frequent dining experience!
author: Liz C.

description:
I love everything about this restaurant! The inside design is exactly how I pictured my fancy bachelorette loft with the exposed brick, rustic hardwood flooring and the lightbulb tracked lighting, open kitchen, two levels, huge windows. Fantastic! 

For food: 

Crispy shrimp - huge and delicious! 
Foie Gras - as always, the seared foie gras was my favorite 
Duck with lentils - I ABSOLUTELY loved the lentils. Super flavorful. 
Fulton Valley Chicken - Super tender and juicy and they gave me a big piece of white meat, which is my favorite! and the skin.. OMG... The skin was SO GOOD!!! 

The service was ok, but our server didn't know what everything was. Maybe she was new. Oh well. The food was definitely the star. WONDERFUL! But just like the name of the place, everything was really salty. I remember needing a lot of water in the middle of the night that night.
author: Jen D.

description:
This gets a five star after I've been here several times. It would have gotten a 3 star a few years ago after I was underwhelmed on one meal. You really just have to know what to eat. 

The shrimp and green beans are my go to appy after a 14 hour day at work. Pairs well with dirty martini.

I had breakfast here this morning and had the chicken breakfast sando - DELISH! I had half for breaky and a few bites for lunch and I still have a few bites of biscuit left for a snack tonight. The gentleman behind the bar replaced my friend's latte after he thought the machine wasn't pulling correctly. She didn't even notice. Now that's mother trucking service kids.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Went here for dinner last night and we were pleasantly surprised.  Even though the place was packed and we had no reservations, the tattooed but very accomodating hostess was able to seat us at the last open table.  This put us in a great mood for the rest of the meal.  

We started with the egg appetizer which was simply divine.  The egg is poached with a soft center, battered and lightly fried.  It is served in crockware in a savory yet light tomato, potato and homemade sausage stew.  Sooo flavorful!  I mopped up every bit of stew with my bread.   The other appetizer we ordered, the apple salad was okay if you like salad.

For mains, we ordered the yellowfish, which we happily devoured, and the Sole, which was okay...  We skipped dessert since nothing jumped out and we were both full.  The couple next to us ordered the warm apple turnover with ice cream.  They didn't love it.

Overall, a good meal in a lively urban setting, if slightly pricey.
author: Tina T.

description:
A great little spot. Been here several times for lunch and dinner and I always leave very impressed. Love the upbeat (sometimes loud) atmosphere as well as the wall mural.. very modern. Not a huge fan of the bench like seating, but I can deal. 

For starters they have a great assortment of oysters.. the mixed nuts are really really tasty also. Who doesn't love a few nuts? :)

For main course the Halibut, Chicken, and lamb are all really tasty. Can't go wrong with either. Unfortunately I can' t say that I've had dessert here yet but they do have a nice cheese selection. 

The staff was very friendly and accomodating to our party of 8. Which shrank to 6, then to my surprise additional guests arrived and I had to tell them it was back to 8. They were very nice about our everchanging number of guests which deserves 5 stars in my book!
author: Sarah W.

description: I had to bump them up to four stars because they might make the best poutine in the city.  The duck was also perfectly done and simply presented. Jonathan the manager really provided personalized service even though it was hella busy.
author: Roger H.

description:
After noticing some of my fellow Yelpers rave about the recently opened Salt House, I decided to take a good friend of mine out to celebrate his 30th birthday. 

What caught my eye: 

1. The food exceeded my expectations, but perhaps they were a bit low to begin with. Though usually I tend to gravitate towards seafood, I decided to go with the lemon chicken based on a strong recommendation from the waiter and the fact that I've been a bit burnt out on seafood lately. For appetizers, we tried the olives which were too strong for everyone else, except for me -- though a couple of them were a bit tangy. The chicken, however, was cooked to perfection and presented on a light bed of greens and flavorful potatoes. For $19, the value seemed high. 

2. Excellent service. Though our waiter clearly didn't know everything that was on the menu and was learning the ropes, he did an excellent job of keeping an eye on us. Amazingly, they were out of tea, but given that they're still new, small slip ups like this are to be expected. Nevertheless, the service is to be commended and when dinner was served, it felt as if we were served by those who had cooked our meal as at least four different people presented our plates. I always find that to be a treat and something you might expect at an ultra expensive restaurant. 

3. There's a fascinating art piece on the back wall that is a work in progress. I believe our waiter said this was created by one of the owner's wives, but I may be mistaken. At the time we observed it, there was what appeared to be a black knight in the center of two abstract outlines of horses. We were told that it would evolve over time. 

4. The exposed brick and metal beams combined with the soft lighting create an amazing ambiance. 

5. Located close to the Metreon, it's an ideal place to grab dinner and then grab a movie. It's roughly a ten minute walk or four blocks from the Metreon, but the walk is pleasant and it beats paying for parking at the Metreon garage which seems to get more and more expensive every year. 

Congratulations to the Salt House for opening up and offering a very hip restaurant that is bound to be an immediate success. Please just keep it consistent! 

- Rob
author: Rob C.

description:
I like this place...lunch and dinner offerings are very good.

Latest venture, lunch.

I was getting over/half-way through this winter's vicious cold/flu thing.  I wanted some comfort food.  A co-worker and I trekked the whole block and a half to get to this place.  After that seemingly endless walk, I was famished!  (Does anybody actually use that word anymore, "famished". )

I ordered the meatloaf and my co-worker ordered the turkey sandwich.  All I've gotta say is that I'm glad I ordered the meatloaf and not the turkey sandwich.  Not that the sandwich was bad,  it was just so huge!  I suppose for the price it should be but anyway, it was a very good value for the money spent.  My co-worker took half of the sandwich to-go because she couldn't finish it all.  BTW, she said the sandwich was excellent.

The meatloaf was very, very good.  The mashed potatoes and gravy heaven.  I couldn't finish it all.  Too much food.  On the verge of exploding.  Good to have to make the block and a half trek back to the office to work off all of those calories.
author: Maggie K.

description:
WORST LUNCH PLACE EVER! 

SERVICE SUCKS:  I don't think these folks cracked a smile the whole time I was there, except when they were apologizing for the late food.  Also, the place was half-empty when we arrived, and they said the only openings they had was the bar, communal table, or bar by the window.  When we left, they still had a 1/4 of the tables open.  Also, the service was slooow.  Folks who arrived 5-10 minutes after us, got their food 10-15 min before us.

FOOD SUCKS:  If you love grease, then order the grilled steak sandwich.  The  bottom piece of bread was covered all over in grease.

Overall Experience:  Horrible!
author: Jen C.

description:
Came here a couple weeks ago, and had a great dinner. I believe we had like 4 or 5 courses before our actual entrees and desserts! Everyone was extremely pleasant, from the hostess, to manager, to our server. I don't remember the exact order of things, so I'll just go with what I do remember.

1st course - white corn soup which was absolutely light, creamy, and delicious. I LOVED THIS!

2nd course - foie gras which came in 2 ways, so you really couldn't go wrong with that. I liked the sauteed version better, and the duck that came with it was amazing.

3rd course - crispy shrimp, yummy as well.

4th course - yellowfin tuna sashimi. The tuna was alright for me, but the mixed salad w/ fennel, beets and lemon was close to perfection.

entree #1 sole was good, but not the best

entree #2 lamb loin was great! It actually reminded me of steak, and didn't have the lamb taste/feel to it, which we enjoyed.

We had two desserts, and although I don't remember which ones we had, they were both amazing! We also had a dessert wine that was extremely tasty. 

Everything was great from the service to the dishes. I think that I enjoyed my dessert and the white corned soup more than any of the other dishes. I would definitely come back.
author: Elaine H.

description:
I'm giving Salt House a 3 because its a pricey adventure.  Stopped by for a small bit and a beer with a friend.  On a heirloom tomato kick as of late, so I thought I'd try this dish ($13).  It was mediocre at best (more balsamicy than appropriately seasoned).  We also ordered the freshly roasted nuts -- which were actually really good...they wet roasted the assortment with honey and olive oil ($5.50).

I'd go back for the beer and small side plates - the entrees are pretty pricey compared to the surrounding options.
author: Sheetal S.

description: This is really only for the foi gros . I do with they had more on their menu I liked however i was craving foi gras one day and stopped in . To my surprise they gave me both seared and the buttery kind. Servers were nice , good atmosphere . I just wish they had more items I liked but I am a fan of their Foi Gras!
author: Ms. P.

description: Great food, great service. They had charged my fiance's card twice. When we contacted them, they fixed it and sent us a gift card by mail which was a great gesture. Will definitely go there again!
author: Flha H.

description: Popular & packed.  Ate at the bar which was cool since bartender was awesome.  All the food was amazing & fresh.  Oysters - yum! Tuna tartare tasty with beets.  Rib eye generous portion & cooked perfectly.
author: Kim S.

description:
Went here for dinner on a Monday around 5 pm .

Sat at the bar ordered:
 Poutine appetizer- bland tasting and the short rib gravy was kind of sweet and I like it to be more savoury, wouldn't order it again

Summer vegetable salad- this was great

Chicken Entree- O.K when it finally came. Staff did not keep us abreast of the hold up. It took approx. 45 minutes for it to come out. The bartender finally said that whoever prepped the kitchen, forgot about the chicken.  Our apetizer was comped, which was nice, but we got the feeling that the staff really did not care that much. They were not very friendly or inviting at all. 
 
Dark Chocolate cake- was very good but the espresso was flat, lacking flavor and crema

I would like to try this place again, hoping that they were just having a bad start to their evening.
author: Linda V.

description:
My experience at Salt House has forced me to resort to using cliches.

I was always told not to judge a book by it's cover, but I couldn't help myself in this case. Salt House was busy as a bee as I walked up on a Wednesday night, packed to the gills with happy hour revelers. The hostess was cute as a button, with gorgeous tattoos, and seemed like a virtual welcome wagon of hipness when I came through the door. 

And that is just the tip of the ice burg. The decor was really chic, everyone seemed to be having a good time and the smells were out of this world.

I think I just  may have jumped the gun here.

The first tell tale sign? I asked the bartender if they was anything special that was not on the menu and he kind of blankly stared at me for a minute, like I had two heads. I gave him  a brief flavor profile of what I like and he said, "well, we have Hendrix."  So I just ordered my usual martini. Specialty cocktails are just not some people's cup of tea. I can accept that.

So if we wanna talk turkey here, and by turkey I mean the food, I'll cut right to the chase. It just didn't do it for me. I got all jazzed up about the decor and the utter hipness oozing out from the walls, but when it came right down to it, I left feeling uninspired.  So much so that I am forced to review in obvious cliche.

A brief cliche-free rundown:

Hendrix martini straight up with a twist, 1/2 dozen kumamoto oysters, the fried shrimp app and the hangar steak, rare, with a glass of zinfandel.

Zinfandel = excellent
Oysters  = excellent with some interesting sauces. perhaps a bit too powerful for these plump little guys...took away a little bit from the natural flavors kumamotos are known for.

The rest of the food wasn't bad...just nothing spectacular. The shrimp dish was really heavy, but good flavors. The steak itself was cooked perfectly but lacking flavor, and beneath it was this mushroomy puree that didn't look nor taste very good. Like they just put some mushrooms in a food processor and plopped them on the plate. And with morels starring in the dish, why put another mushroom in there at all? 

The service was good, the atmosphere very cool, but the food just didn't measure up, in my opinion.

I'd give it a second try, but since money doesn't grow on trees, I don't know how soon that may be.
author: Leighann F.

description:
I think 3 stars may be a bit generous...it's more of a 2.5 star place, so we are settling on 2 stars.  

We walked in on an early Friday night without resos and the place was packed.  I was a little nervous, but the hostess smiled and said that she could seat us.  Then it made me think, this place must have great cocktails and I'm so having a drink! 

Our server came by and I gave our drink orders and I perused the menu. We decided to have 2 apps and 1 entree. 

As I was drinking my martini, I realized my drink was almost gone??!!  Was I really drinking my drink that fast? Or were the glasses the smallest martini glasses ever???!!! We are going to go with #2- the smallest beverage glasses ever.  

We had started with Poutine which was frites with cheddar cheese and short rib gravy.  So good, maybe I should have stopped there...

Then we had Yellow fin Tartare with apples and beets.  Sounds great right? Unfortunately the dish didn't really have any flavor.

Main course was a Monk fish with mussels.  It was fine but kind of in the middle of the road.  

After waiting for 45 minutes for our server to bring over dessert menu or ask us if we'd like another drink...we were done. We asked for the bill and it was definitely more expensive than I thought.  

Damn, that was probably one of the most disappointing, expensive dinners I've had in quite a long time.  

So, if I'm feeling rich and not real thirsty for a cocktail- I'll be back although I'm not too sure when that's going to happen.
author: Valarie A.

description:
What can I add considering the volume of reviews? As usual, not much. But here goes anyway. 

It can get crowded. That's pretty obvious. And the setup isn't the best with no waiting area and all. But my useful tip of the day - make an early reservation. On the weekend. I can see how a dinner could be negatively affected by the wait and crowd. I've seen this place on a weeknight after work, and it's not the most relaxing of atmospheres. 

So I needed a dinner place for between 4 and 5 on a sunday. I figured lots of options, right? Not really considering most places open after 5. So who's feeding all the senior citizens? Anyway, SH was open early. And it's a couple blocks away. Perfect. The restaurant was not crowded, maybe about 5 other tables were occupied at the time. Not sure about all the salty (pun intended) references, but the only thing slightly salty was the crab app. Not too much so, but it was slightly saltier than it shoulda been. The mains were good. Service was attentive and not intrusive.
author: The Sock S.

description:
Entering this this new little gem from the people of Town Hall I expected exactly what I saw.  The room was very open, loud and rustic.  I loved the scene I walked into.  However, I am still unconvinced if the unfinished balcony is there for decoration or will actually become something else.  

Immediately seated by our lovely hostess and within minutes waterered.  I love how they put a little carafe on each table. I drink lots of water and this touch helps to eliminate the time the server needs to hunt down a picture or a "water boy" to fill the water glass.  

The menu was very small but all seemed to be quality items.  I was very intriqued by some of the appetizers but the one I chose was the squash soup.  It was out of this world tasty.  Very velvety and not filling with loads of flavors and paper thin slices of chestnuts. 

when I placed my order I inquired about the shellfish stew.  I specifically asked what shellfish were in it.  she told me shrimp, muscles and clams all for $19.  Fine that is what I will have.  My companion chose the Skate Wing.  We had our appetizers, I enjoyed a nice $9 savignon blanc and within 20 minutes out came our entrees.  Or were they our entrees?  Nope the food runner brought both of us the Skate Wing.  I told him what I ordered and he took both entrees back (bonus points for not leaving one while I waited for mine to come out).  

Our server never came back to us to apologize and reassure us that she had the correct order and it would be right over.  We waiting another 15 minutes...not exagerating.  My companion went to the rest room and over came the food runner with two more plates.  He had the Skate Fish correct but then a plate with a Grilled Cheese Sandwhich and Bisque.  I told him yet again this is not what I ordered and informed him that it was the Shellfish Stew.  He was embarassed and appologized, took both back and came back to me in minutes plopping down the grilled cheese and saying it was on the house and they would put in my order for the correct meal.  

I felt my options were as follows:

- tell him to leave my companions meal while I waited for the correct meal to be prepared for me. This way he could eat.
- tell him to forget about the stew and suck it up and eat my wrong meal
- have us both wait until mine was ready and then my companion would have a hot meal but no doubt it would be dried out. 

I chose to suck it up and eat the grilled cheese and allow my companion to hae a hot meal and not feel pressure to wait for me.  Although my grilled cheese was comped they should have comped both main courses as my companions meal was waiting because of mine.    I give them credit for trying to offer something for the mishap.  But guess what?  My waitress never once came over to apologize for this mishap.  When our meals were done she came over offered us dessert and then finally the bill for what we ate and they never took off the price for the my meal as they said they would. I had to ask our waitress about it and again no apologies. 

IN summary, the food was good, the soup was memorable, the rest of the food was not. My service could have been so much better.  I won't allow one bad waitress to totally ruin my opinion of the place. I will try it again but please know for lunch it is a bit more than most people like to pay.  However, you are not at Chevy's so expect it.
author: Scott P.

description:
I liked Salt House, but I didn't love it. The food was good, the service was good, but for the money the portions were small, the food not unique or impressive and the prices were big.

It doesn't surprise me that Yelpers are mixed about their reviews for Salt House because the place could be much better.

I took my sister to dinner here on Friday night since she was in town and staying nearby. I have deducted 2 stars for the following reasons:

1) RESTAURANT VOLUME TOO LOUD
2) Food was good, but not remarkable and for the money the portions are small. I didn't think anything was special or worth coming back for again.

To start we had a beet salad and a calamari dish. For our entrees we had scallops and the halibut. All the dishes were good, but not great. 

The best part of the meal was the bottle of Pinot Noir I ordered. It was a Whitethorn Los Carneros Hyde 2001 for $58.00, It was light and perfect. From the research I did I don't think this winery is in business any longer, too bad 'cause it sure was good.

I doubt I will come back to Salt House. It just wasn't worth the money and there are so many other better SF restaurants.
author: Yvette K.

description:
I think of this place as Townhall's little brother...younger and hipper, with all food that goes with alcohol!  
Healthy portions, friendly service, great atmosphere, lively crowd, and nightclub in the same building (with a separate entrance).
The acoustics can be challenging, but try the upstairs mezzanine...great people watching.
The only thing stopping me from giving this place 5 stars is the somewhat limited menu.
author: Michael A.

description:
Something about this place just didnt do it for me. We started with champange while we decided on wich bottle of wine and appetizers we wanted. Let me just say that the wine was really good. The oysters where delicious. The poutine was incredible.But the salads and the entrees seemed thrown together and lacked flavor.

Over all to me it was an ok dining experience. Not a bang for your buck type of place, but the decor and layout make it a very good dining atmosphere.
author: Ryan O.

description:
**UPDATE June 11th 2007**

I have been back to Salt House at least 4 times since my original review... they have been consistently turning out good food, service, and efficiency.

I'm officially a fan.

Just make reservations at least 3 days in advance.

***Original Review***

Great! 

My dining companion and I had lunch here today and we loved everything: the meal, the service, the friendly hostess, the knowledge of the servers...  never had to ask for refills and execution was perfect. 

For appetizers we had the salad and some other appetizer "dip" that came with bread (both delicious) and for entrees we had the Cuban Sandwich and Free Range Chicken (again both very good). The portion for the chicken entree was smaller (4 pieces about the size of golf balls) but overall I was satisfied. 

Salt House is a warm/modern "loft like" space that's comfortable and energetic. I'm confident they will be a hit... as a matter of fact I already have another reservation set for this Friday... !
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Sorry to say but this place totally disappointed.  Ironically, as we sat waiting for our food, I made a comment on how I liked much of the decor - the steel, wood, and brick with great art on the walls -- but put it together with the odd light fixtures, pinstriped couches, and modern open kitchen and it was quite a cacophony.  

Little did I know that would foretell the food to come.

We ordered the crispy shrimp (which came with green beans, prociutto, nuts, and tons of greens) and the seared ahi (which came with beets, fennel, and orange segments).  While each component in and of itself was well prepared -- WAY too much going on on those plates.  We both ordered the steak, which was decent though it also had quite a bit going on.  

The best thing we had was the dessert (rhubarb tart with lavender ice cream) but it was certainly not enough to bring us back.
author: Jenny S.

description:
So glad I didn't read any yelp reviews before I came here because I had the most fabulous time! But then again, I'm always in good company so having fun in any establishment  is easy. That being said, I had dinner there to celebrate a friend's birthday. I got a last minute reservation for 5:30pm, but it worked out beautifully because the place wasn't crazy yet. The dinner area is small, the bar area even smaller but it is bright, squeaky clean, and you can see the kitchen staff working. So hot. Our server was gorgeous and so were the rest of the staff. We complimented her on her chic outfit right away and got the best service all through dinner. 

All the entrees were well executed. We started with the heirloom tomatoes (good but been there, done that). The lamb sausage is a must! I would've eaten that all night. The flavors melded so well together, salty lamb, curry, chickpeas. Yum! And then had the sole, rib eye and the lamb. The sole was excellently prepared and presented beautifully. The rib eye not fatty at all, which was weird, but it was just OK. The lamb, however, was cooked to perfection. We were all so very happy. 

I will definitely go there again when I can afford it because it is a bit spendy considering how petite the portions are.
author: TaDao V.

description:
Really, how can you possibly go wrong?  Great location.  Great ambience.  Great interior...

uh....

so, so food?  SORRY!  I'm SORRY!

The poutine was bland and there was no salt or pepper on the table!

The burger was so wet that my bun was soggy before it even got to me!

Ack, ok, ok, the onion rings/fries were super yummy...but that was about it.  

I wanted to like you.  I tried.  I really did.  Sorry.  Ugh.  Oh...and I would give you 3 stars, but you ain't cheap...you should know better!
author: Susan L.

description: It was delicious and really liked the atmosphere! It's an open kitchen and you can tell that the chefs were very much into their craft. Best (and fanciest) poutine I've ever had :)
author: Doris T.

description: Service was bad an distracted from the experience but the food was good enough to counter balanace a bit.  30min before we received first bread or water (at 930 on a not so busy evening).  Maybe it was  abad night.  Duck ravioli was good but a bit small. Crunchy shrimp tempora on top of a bed of arugula and cured ham was fantastic.  Salmon with pork ternderloin, polenta and chanterelle mushrooms was some of the best salmon we had for a while.
author: Chris H.

description:
We came with no reservations, it was packed. But the hostess & staff was very lovely. We ate at the communal bar - the food was delicious and had good drinks. The crowd that night seemed more buttoned/suited up than I had expected. Not a good place to bring a first date, way too loud to have a conversation.

Great place to grab food with friends.
author: Lola L.

description:
Upon walking in to this place, I pretty impressed with the way it was designed and decorated. It was sleek and modern, yet had a vintage vibe to itself. 

The menu offered an array of deliciously sounding appetizer's, entree's snacks, and desserts. For some reason, I wanted to try their mixed nuts in truffle honey and sea salt. I think the truffle honey part is was lured me in. I thought they were good and well balanced in flavor, but pricey for a measly small bowl of nuts. 

Same goes for their entree's. They all were well balanced in flavor and the portions were generous.

This restaurant is a cool hangout for those wanting to unwind after work or just have a good time with a bunch of friends.
author: stacy k.

description:
Salt House was really nice in every respect: the food was nice, not incredible considering it's so expensive, but tasty nonetheless. The service was nice and the decor...all very nice. We sat upstairs and I felt like I was in a NY loft or something with all of the exposed brick and beams. 

It is a little loud but hey, at least it's lively. Even on a Wednesday night there were tons of large groups, first dates and everything in between.

They had run out of ahi which was disappointing, but the bass was great as it came with mini-oysters. Yum!

I was amused by the bathroom. As it's connected to Harlot, they have a bouncer guarding the two to ensure one does not cross over into Harlot without going through the velvet ropes. But in the bathroom there is a window that looks directly into Harlot, which I found kind of amusing.

So Salt House is a great restaurant, but I wasn't blown away. I'm very glad I tried it, but it won't become one of my favorites any time soon.
author: Sophie D.

description:
MMMM turkey sandwich!

I came here for lunch with my coworkers the other day. The staff was nice and attentive.

I had the turkey bacon sandwich with a side of mixed greens. I have to say that this has got to be one of the better turkey sandwiches I've eaten in a long time. It was juicy, full of flavor, a good size portion, and it had several strips of crispy bacon! 

Relatively speaking of course, for $13 it wasn't a bad deal at all. Most of the places in downtown a sandwich can cost more and you don't get quite the atmosphere.
author: Bert T.

description:
I really like the SOMA chic setting, and how cute the servers looked in their nonuniform uniforms of white shirts (good cuts on cute looking peeps) and tightwrapped black aprons but the food was just mediokay (somewhere above mediocre and right about at OK but still not fully OK K) for the price and the flavors were sorta boring. Seriously- I thought the new in new american was so we can bypass the blandness. 

I had just a stuffed squid appetizer for main: I wasnt that hungry (right after work- 6:30) but I had all of the family's stuff and most of it was well balanced, flavor-wise and well made but not at all outstanding or memorable.

The best dish was their beets and endives (or maybe fennel) salad: beets were cooked amazingly, the flavors were subtle but multifaceted. But it's a salad, and I wouldnt go to a restaurant to eat salads: unless_UNLESS it's a liver salad, shout out to Vio, on that one.

I didnt really like my dish- they stuffed the squid with chick peas and smoked it. the chick peas hella beat up the delicate textures of the bivalves and squid, and the smoke was distracting. I tried the duck plate, it was ok, and I love duck, but they had it 2 ways (roasted/sliced and braised/torn on the bottom) and it was funny, cause Josh and Lil got the same dish and Josh liked the braised part but not the roasted and Lil like the roasted but not the braised bit, which was soo like them to be: so neither of them were quite happy. The fat chunks I had (Lil wont eat it and I was like yeah~) were not was caramelized and flavorful as it could be. and the braised chunks were good but tasted like pork: please dont insult my duck like that. 

D1 got some fish dished he liked. D2 got something with something she almost liked except for a few items she thought was a bit esoteric; I had a taste but cant remember the dish.

The service was good, if not a bit too careful and a bit hush hush like everyone's trying so hard to not step on your toes or something (maybe it was a bit crowded), eitherway, a bit strange. I guess it's hard to be relaxed when you're trying to be soo 'new american' AND classy profess, or something. To that I say: let the servers breathe normally, shall we?

We made a reservation and I was stuck on at the head of a 4 person table with my back really close to the table next to me. I hate that in restaurants. I know 5person tables are like sooo hard to deal but Everyone, try to space things better, k? 

I would give 2.8 stars, but there isnt a .8 and 3 is a bit much for me especially in this economy, so 2.
author: Jonas D.

description:
My bf and I had dinner with friends of ours before a show. 

My bf and I shared a salad and I had scallops for my main. They were probably the best scallops I had ever had. The beer selection is also quite good. For the quality of the food, I thought it was reasonably priced. Also, the service was pretty good, despite us being all the way upstairs in the corner.

For a special occasion I'd definitely go back!
author: Emily M.

description:
Great food from the jackasses who brought you Town Hall. The wine list skewed a little towards the high-end of prices (such is the biz I guess) but no major complaints. 

my wife took me on Friday for my birthday and it was perfect. lively atmosphere, great food, good people with an attentive, knowledgeable waitress.

as an aside, one thing that struck me was the crowd. There were TONS of hot, older (i.e. my age) women. Single, in groups, on dates. So a tip to the single guys who like to go cougar hunting, the bar at the Salt House isn't a bad way to start a weekend.
author: James F.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant. I've been here many times now and each time I've been extremely satisfied with the food and the staff. I've pretty much have tried at least half of the menu and have not been disappointed with any of my choices. Also Gretchen rocks as a server. 

Their entree size was just right. I think too many restaurants tend to super size their entrees that it just becomes overwhelming after having rounds of appetizers.
author: Clodel G.

description:
I have been there twice... coincidentally we went both times really late. I have loved the food, I think it's delicate, exquisite and simple at the same time. My husband and I would love 
go back. 
Five months ago, we have eaten the better salad that I have ever tried before... It's one with green, pear, cheese... They have also a good wine selection. I like the place, I don't  know if there was another restaurant before, but that I can see now is an very architectonic interior space with good taste.
I have never been early or for lunch...
author: Lorena F.

description:
Ok, so, I'm not 100% sure about going to this spot for dinner yet, but, I can tell you that lunch is frickin' AWESOME. 

So, for a quick lunch, the pricing is a little high, but if you want a GOOD sit down meal, not some FiDI sandwich shop type meal, then this is a bangin' spot. 

Started off with some olives just to snack on, a nice fat bowl of 'em, garnished with mint and orange peel for a nice zip. Moved on to the Poutine...french fries from HEAVEN! I cannot even begin to describe to you the awesomeness that is the Poutine. I'd suggest splitting a plate between two or more people though, otherwise there'll be no need for lunch! For lunch, I had the pork shoulder with gaujillo chilis over parmesan polenta - SO PERFECT. My friend had the salt house burger with bleu cheese - which I didn't taste, but holy CRAP did it look delicious. Judging by the way he tore it up, it seemed that it tasted that way too. 

Perks to the visit....

1. Bartender (Justice) was knowledgeable and helpfful for wine pairing and damn friendly to boot. 

2. Very attractive staff....is it just me or are some of the hottest women working at restaurants in this city? At any rate...Salt House has 'em in spades!

3. Food is delicious, perfectly cooked and in perfect quantity.

4. Nice decor!

5. Did I mention an attractive staff? (well, if you're familiar with my reviews by now, you know this is something I take note of, deal with it, lol)

Anyway...I like this spot. Can't give it the full 5 stars yet as I haven't done dinner there, and to be honest, it gets CRAZY packed there at dinner time, so I'm not sure it's in the cards for me. But I will be back for lunch...oh yes, I will!

Thumbs up Salt House!
author: Marco M.

description: This place is always full. I tried to walk in a few times without any success. The bread is amazing and the food overall is great. The venue is very small. The bar is small as well so it is better to make reservations way ahead of time.
author: elena a.

description:
Love the location of this place. With a shared bathroom with Harlot, it's a skip and a hop away from my favorite lounge. What a great place to start the evening off- fun crowd gathered at the bar area, the bartenders are awesome! The entire staff is friendly and attentive. There is nothing pretentious about this venue, it's simply great food.

The Poutine, fois gras, delicious starters. My favorite was my main course, the tuna- pure tunariffic perfection.

It's a fun place, I would recommend it for a starting point for a night out.
author: Rada I.

description:
First things first. The food was great. The food gets a 4.5/5

Now on to other matters. While the food was good, they brought everything out of order. We ordered drinks first as well appetizers and salads. A LONG time went by  and then our salads came. After that the appetizers. Wait for it. Now our drinks finally come. Then they bring the bread. I don't know about you, but if I order drinks at dinner, I expect them to come before anything else. Because I try not to eat a meal without getting drunk. I'm a very sad person. After dinner we ordered dessert and coffee. Again, the food came before the drinks. 

Also, the waiter was very unfriendly. Maybe her cat died or maybe she was tired. Either way, she was very :(
author: Justin C.

description:
After reading fellow Yelpers reviews, I had dinner at Salt House on a Wednesday night.  The restaurant is very hip, really nice inside.  I was promptly greeted, the staff is really nice there.  

I had the Wild Striped Bass, which was served with brussel sprouts and ham hocks.  It was really well-cooked, very fresh tasting, and quite delicious.  My friend had the Polenta with vegetables, and it was very good too.  For dessert, I had the Yuzu Panna Cotta, which was light and refreshing.  

It is loud at Salt House, it was hard to hear what my friend was saying, but we managed (we're not *that* old).  Not a great 1st date place, but a great place to come with friends.
author: Sarah F.

description: The table next to me received their main plates about 30 minutes after they feasted on a gargantuan bowl of shellfish, at which point they complained to the server how unsatisfactory it was to wait so long for their food.  After eating, they promptly apologized to the server and pronounced it was absolutely worth the wait.  Enough said.  Sweetbreads are highly recommended.
author: Peter M.

description:
great food, but they are still working out some of the new restaurant kinks. The staff was super attentive and helpful. 

the appetizers are the highlight of the menu. (spicy shrimp, yum!!) the ribs had great flavor, but the cut was weird and they were difficult to eat. 

All in all, the menu and decor lack cohesiveness (um, where is the salt? amazing mural, but who designed the seats?) but  its a good start.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Took one of my teams out to a dinner recently to celebrate their good work and they picked the Salt House as the reward....

Overall a good experience and the Steak I had was excellent (although a little small).  It got loud as the bar got crowded so carrying on conversations got to be a bit challenging.  If you want to have an intimate conversation (a working lunch/dinner or romance night out) keep that in mind.  Also remember that you will need a reservation.

Beyond that, the service was solid, the prices are what they should be (it is the City) and the experience was what one should expect at one of the areas "popular" dining choices!

I would go back......
author: Michael C.

description:
Office associates and I dashed in for an early lunch without reservations ... no problem. We were seated and service began promptly. We explained when we came in that we were under the gun on time and couldn't stick around for a leisure lunch. Again, no problem. Before we were finished with our plates, the server discreetly asked if we wanted to see the desert menu early because he knew we were in a hurry. We passed, but appreciated that our earlier request to the hostess had been communicated to the server (impressive).

Food: Excellent lunch selection.

Pickled Veggies - perfect!
Spiced Nuts - very tasty, loved the crunchy salt crystals.

Cuban Sandwich - not the real deal, but I wouldn't have expected an authentic Cuban sandwich in a place like Salt House. This was a variation on a theme and it was exceptionally well executed. The "spicy chips" that accompanied the sandwich weren't special, but they were certainly good.

My lunch companions both enjoyed their Bacon Egg Tomato sandwiches (a messy tower of tasty fixins') and the summer veggie soup.

We were in and out in 45 minutes from seating to exit. Incredible! I recommend the place and will be heading back soon to try more of the menu.
author: Steve J.

description:
We had a phenomenal meal here.  Only downside was that we had to wait a long time for our table, 25-30 min past our reservation.  That usually ruins it for me, but the food and the service more than made up for the hassle.  

We brought a bottle of Walter Hansel Three Rows Pinot, and our waitress was exceptionally knowledgeable about the producer and appropriate food pairings.  I ended up having the mixed lettuces, petrale sole, and we had cobbler for dessert.  Everything was superb.
author: Emily M.

description: Spent the evening with friends for a special occasion at SH and had a wonderful evening.  The food was amazing from start to finish.  I started with the burrata appetizer which just blew me away.  Then I moved onto the coho salmon entree and finished up with the gingerbread upside down cake and the goat cheese, cheesecake (which I shared of course) they both were great but the cheesecake was stellar.  The service was excellent and the atmosphere albeit a bit noisy, was beautiful.  I highly recommend Salt House for your next dining adventure.
author: Keith B.

description:
So I have been here twice, once for lunch, once for dinner. Both times I was not paying. 

Would I go back if I was paying? No. Would I say it's not a bad place to go for a business lunch or dinner? Yes, as long as you don't mind the noise level. Would I recommend it for a romantic date? Not really. There are better options for that in SF.
author: Abby W.

description:
I've been to Town Hall few times so I really looked forward to try Salt House.
I really love their graphic concept - I know I should pay attention to food, but the packaging is part of details that I enjoy. : )

Pork Belly was excellent - salty mixed with sweet flavor - nice.   My halibut dish also came with pork belly, which complemented uneventful flavor of fish.  The only thing I wasn't crazy about is the 'veggie' bedding - I'm not a big fan of fluffing the dish. : )
author: N. C.

description:
I came here the other night with a friend visiting from Seattle around 7pm and while the dining room didn't have any open tables available until 8:45pm, we were told by the hostess that we could sit at the single table under the stairwell that faced the front window.

We were both hungry and weren't all that particular about exactly where we sat, so we said, "Sure!  Why not?"

What a fun + intimate spot!  My friend and I were able to catch up on our own time while the bustling restaurant buzzed all around us.  Sitting behind the stairwell shielded us from the noisy happy hour crowd and sitting perched in front of the huge main window gave us a great vantage point to people watch all the SOMA passerbyers.

As for the food?  Delish!  I ordered the Sole + the Fig Salad -- yum yum delight!!  I'd come back again and would definitely consider snuggling up to the front window again.  Super fun!
author: Katie C.

description:
Aaaaand with the 389th review of Salt House, me.

Three Hundred and Eighty Nine People have written explicitly about Salt House. Is that a little crazy to anyone else? Has the Cult Of Yelp taken over with the masses? Does anyone know if there's a place with 1,000 reviews yet? Is anything close?

ANYWAY, Salt House was really good. I had the lamb & it was pretty damn delicious. The waitstaff were friendly & attentive, & the atmosphere was distinctly classy, but not too stuffy. The folks who dine there are clearly doing well, professionally speaking. 

Ohh, fine...go read the other reviews. Talk to me when you're done, around this time tomorrow.
author: Pete J.

description:
The food is good but not memorable.  This isn't a place where I have to go for any particular dish.  Everything is great but I don't crave for it.  Does that explain?  I feel like everything on the menu is safe, nothing really wowed me.

Service is great but it's so noisy.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Underwhelming. The service was excellent, and the restaurant is beautiful but I left hungry (after an appetizer, main course, and dessert). The portions were beautifully plated but kinda small.
author: Lucy M.

description:
Mmm, Gravy.  On french fries.  (Excuse me.  I mean, "crispy potatoes.")  With cheese.  For (gulp) TEN DOLLARS?  

Yeah, but they were actually worth it.  The gravy had chunks of some of the most succulent, tender beef I've ever had, and the potatoes were huge and lightly, lightly fried.  We also had the rabbit appetizer (which was only slightly difficult to eat after my boyfriend refferred to it as a "little bunny"), some pickled vegetables, and some nice wine, for a total of about $60.  But we left as full as if we'd eaten a full meal, so it was probably worth it for a once-in-a-blue-moon, special occasion happy hour.

The atmophere was lovely, woody and lofty and softly lit.  Our bartender/server was extremely gregarious and attentive, which was bothersome at first because I was in a really foul mood... but maybe he rubbed off on me, because I was happy-go-lucky again after half a glass of wine.

P.S.  Since 95% of the other yelp reviews refer to their affection for Town Hall in their reviews of Salt House, I'm NOT GONNA DO IT.  I'm original, see?
author: Sharon M.

description:
4 stars for the food alone, -1 star for having to tell the staff on 3 seperate occaisions for 3 different dishes that, No, in fact we were NOT done with that yet. Sheesh, you need the table or something?

The waitress also tapped my shoulder in mid conversation to get my attention rather than waiting politely for a break.

That said, I really enjoyed the Duck Confit and the chocolate dessert was excellent.

Wines were a little on the pricey side IMO, but we did manage to find a nice Spanish Tapanillo.
author: Peter T.

description:
Pros - service, atmoshpere

Cons - food just wasn't memorable.  Been here twice now, great service both times, but our food was uninspiring.  Will give it another try as we haven't tried everything on the menu as of yet.  hopefully we'll be inspired as I really want to like this place - love the people and the space.  Fun vibe to eat in.

3.5 stars overall
author: kristi j.

description: I returned yet again this week and had another five star experience.  This time I had the mint lemonade, celery root soup with pomegranate, and the duck confit with bacon and lentils.  Everything was a hit.  I just had a duck confit at Chez Papa Resto up the street, and the Salt House version takes an already great dish to another level entirely.  Great lunch.
author: Laurence W.

description:
Salt House is consistently at the top of every restaurant review site, so I was definitely looking forward to my Sunday night reservation.  Well we all know what comes along with big hype: BIG DISSAPPOINTMENT.  I really wanted to like it, but I couldn't force myself. 
The two fish dishes we ordered we too SALTY; and though it was the best thing we ordered, I have also had authentic poutine from Canada which the Salt House just couldn't match.  
My "foodie" friend, Kevin, says Sundays are surprisingly the worst days to try out a new restaurant.  I guess they give their chefs the night off and bring in the bench warmers.  The ambiance, decor, and service were good enough for me to give it another try. Maybe on a Wednesday?
author: Jen T.

description:
Good: the polenta, the sole, the pineapple desert. And the wait staff was plentiful and present.
Meh: poutine. I'd never had it before so I wanted to try the "nachos of the north". But many people love it, so tastes vary.
Unfortunate: the loudness. All those brick walls and open spaces are nice visually but it does echo alot. And our primary waitress couldn't describe the wines. She did get us a sampler, though, which was good.

All in all the food was OK, but not great.
author: Nicolas D.

description:
they may change their menus often b/c many of the items reviewed by others were not on the menu.

This place has decent food, and an open airy space...but for me it was forgettable. The Fresh Tagliatelle was a great starter but small portions. Would come here again for a drink or appetizer, but wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: lore f.

description:
This was my first visit to Salt House on a recommendation from a friend.  He said it was fantastic and I would have to concur.  

I requested a more private spot and they put us up in the balcony overlooking the entire restaurant and kitchen.  Not only was the view great but we could talk privately and still see all the action.  Of course, a great location won't trump bad food.  Luckily, the food lived up to everything we expected and more.  

We ordered two appetizers: the fois gras and one of the raw fish dishes.  Both were excellent and fresh.  I am not always a fan of fois gras but this was done superbly (especially the grilled fois gras).  Both myself and my companion were so enamored with the nightly special that we both ordered it - locally caught (they said it was that morning) sea bass on top of almost too many things to count.  I thought it might be too much in the place but I ate every last piece.  The hazelnut desert was also great and topped things off.  

Service was fantastic.  The waitress never rushed us and brought us our next course only when we were finished with the one before.  No joke - one of my new top restaurants in SF.
author: Adam S.

description:
Good: Reasonable prices, good food, cool decor.
Bad: Shoe string onion rings and creepy bathroom.

Unless you have a desire to drink oil, stay away from the shoe string onion rings. Otherwise, the food is pretty decent.
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food at the Salt House was very good! My wife and started with the Poutine, and house made Pork Headcheese plate. Both items were perfectly well executed. The Headcheese was some of the best I've had! We each had a fish entree for our mains, and they were both excellent. The service was perfectly timed and very friendly. The atmosphere was is best described as "hipster industrial"! I recommend this place!
author: P K.

description:
Mixed nuts anyone? No, I'm not throwing a cheesy cocktail party or Superbowl gathering - I'm suggesting you order them at the Salt House...now! They're served warm with a fantastic seasoning on them; what a great twist on something so ordinary!

The short ribs were unbelievable - I can't recommend them enough. The meat was so tender and flavorful that I was fighting for the last bite with my date. The wine we ordered, while I can't remember the name, was delightful and really complimented our meal. 

My only complaint - we were seated upstairs and it got really toasty up there. All that heat from the ovens were heading straight for the ceiling. At one point I had to excuse myself to make sure I wasn't sweating profusely! Suggestion: ask to be seated downstairs. It's a lot more lively, comfortable and cool.
author: Julia N.

description:
Continuing with my "week of significant lunches", today I was at Salt House -- on my recruiter's dime! (So, it was a free lunch for me, but unfortunately, I was expected to pay attention to their sales pitch -- leaving me less opportunity to enjoy my lunch!)

Salt House is the quintessential downtown "let's do lunch" eatery -- the crowd is made up almost completely of the well-heeled expense account types. Despite this, the place feels friendly, and the space, while a bit bare, and quite noisy, is bright and inviting. We arrived a bit after 11:30 -- an early lunch hour for me, and for Salt House too, obviously - we were the first diners in the place -- and were seated in a smaller upstairs area, with a view over the rest of the restaurant and bar area. The menu seems very unpredictable -- I've been to Salt House a for lunch a few times, and there seems to be almost no consistent item (with the possible exceptions of the Burger and the Poutine). As a result, I'm always scrambling to choose something --  forced out of my comfort zone! -- and attempting to read between the lines of the servers' glowing recommendations. (Everything is "wonderful"...) This time, the recruiter ordered the Shrimp & Crab BLT, while I got the Lamb Goulash -- it turned out the BLT was an open-faced sandwich with *very* creamy seafood innards, not really to my taste -- but the goulash was  excellent -- a delicate dish (considering what it is) in a large bowl - meat and carrots and soup and spices on a bed of little new potatoes. Very enjoyable -- not a huge meal, but memorable.

Now, back to the tedious tech shop talk with the recruiter...
author: donal c.

description: We showed up for a reservation booked through open table and were seated 30 minutes after arriving. We watched others come in after us and get tables right away. The noise level is very high making it hard to hear and the bathroom situation is out of control while waiting in line because you are sharing it with the nightclub next door. I went here to catch up with old friends and could barely hear anything they were saying and no one was hungry after waiting so long to get a table. It's a hot spot but not for the right reasons. The food was good but not worth the other issues stemming from the restaurant being overcrowded and the service seeming to be overwhelmed. I liked the decor and can appreciate the menu- but would not go out of my way to go here-especially with people I want to catch up with.
author: Laurene R.

description:
I did something today I promised myself I would never do, I ordered off the Dine About Town menu (GASP!). Yeah I know, hang my head in shame and all that, but I had a really good reason to, the dish I wanted wasn't on the regular menu and it just sounded so good, and it was only for a moment, and well, we've all done things we weren't supposed to at one point in our lives right?

Salt House. I didn't know what to expect from a place named after a spice or even a place tucked away next to Roy's. When you walk in, you see how deep the restaurant really is. In the front, there are stairs that lead up to an elevated balcony/platform with additional tables. The ceilings are high and the beams exposed. The walls are exposed brick and the tabletops remind me of thick maple butcher's blocks. There's a bar along the right side of the restaurant and behind that, an open kitchen. You get the feeling that you really are in a Salt House (whatever that may be). I really liked the way the space was laid out.

Perusing over the menu, I was immediately drawn to the Pomegranate Refresher (pomegranate/cranberry juice, simple syrup, fresh lemon, and soda). I'm usually not one for Pomegranate drinks, but my curiousity was piqued and I'm glad I took a chance on it. It was delicious. Crisp, refreshing, not too sweet, like drinking some sparkling jam. We then moved on to the appetizers, the DAT menu came with a Beet and Blue Cheese Salad and I also ordered the Foie Gras Torchon (get it while you can, it'll be gone in 2012 thanks to those damn tree huggers). OrangeJenn went with the Trout and Citrus Salad while my other companion JLau went with the Poutine (French Fries topped with cheddar and gravy). Beet and Cheese salad was excellent, I hate it when the cheese overpowers everything else or if the beets are overcooked. Neither was the case here. The julienned D'anjou pears added to the texture and sweetened the plate a bit. The Trout Salad paired trout (usually a bold flavor) with citrus (orange and grapefruit) which really married well with the fish. I only had a few bites, but I wanted more. The poutine was only ok and a little heavy for me. Potatoes, gravy, and cheddar all in one plate. I'd avoid it again next time. The Foie Gras Torchon featured quince and apple butter. The tartness of the quince tempered the intenseness of the Foie Gras and at the end of the bite, the  taste of apple butter was left lingering on the palette, making each bite better than the last.

For our entrees, OrangeJenn got the Beef Brisket Chili, JLau got the Salt House Burger (Medium) and I got the Posole of Pork Shoulder. The Chili was only ok, nothing to jump for joy about. She thought the brisket would kick it up, but it didn't. The chili came with a side of grilled cheese (smoked gouda) which turned out to be better than the chili itself. JLau liked his burger, but I noticed it was cooked closer to Medium Well  than Medium and the accompanying finely sliced onion rings seemed to clump and were a little greasy. My own Pork Posole was a whole other matter. The Pork Shoulder was cooked to tender perfection, as if it had been stewed for hours. Coupled with the garbanzo beans and the bold sauce, all that was needed was some heat, readily provided by tossing in the accompanying pickled red and green jalapenos. I was in heaven. Spoonful after spoonful, I soaked up all the varied flavors and texture, leaving behind only an empty plate.

For dessert,  the DAT came with a Brown Butter Blondie, Butterscotch Gelato, and Maple Cream. This was the perfect ending to the meal. The Blondie was dense and flavorful and went well with the gelato. I couldn't really taste the maple in the cream and I thought the chocolate sauce on the bottom was a little too dark and bitter. All in all, I was impressed with this place. My only caveat to anyone wanting to try this place is to stay away from all the plates that sound heavy initially. Stick with the lighter stuff and you won't be disappointed. Solid 4 stars (4.5 if Yelp ever figures out how to do that).
author: Tony V.

description: Came back a few more times and I'm bumping the rating up one star. Same as before but after sampling a few more dishes, maybe the duck in my initial review was a one time thing. Still packed as always and they really should remove 4 tables or so...
author: Steven T.

description:
I never really cared for Town Hall, but wanted to try the latest restaurant from those "jackasses."  Not bad, but nothing really stood out.

Since it's only a few months old, I'm not going to criticize the service (friendly waitress, but she didn't know anything about the menu) or the appearance of the restrooms (think Chevron station undergoing remodeling).

Great space, although it gets crowded.  The layout is terrible.  They've got a community table right up front that is just completely in the way and I would definitely try to sit as far to the back as possible.  The restaurant can get loud...probably a three-beller by His Holiness Michael Bauer's standards.

As for the food, my companion summed it up perfectly: Hearty.  You get a LOT of food.  Some of the starters could be entrees, like the pastrami ribs where you get three huge short ribs.  We got the famed crispy shrimp and were a little surprised that there were only three shrimp perched dangerously on yellow and green beans.  What's with the threes?  How am I supposed to share?  I'm an only child so sharing is hard enough, but how do you share three shrimp???

Anyway, we had the veal and the chicken.  I have the say, the chicken was excellent.  I'm not normally one to order chicken at a restaurant, but it was fantastic.  The veal was well done and fell off the bone, but there was just too much of it and it was quite rich.

Good wine list (although our wine arrived above room temperature) albeit limited.  And well priced.  The desserts were quite good although not particularly impressive...everything looked somewhat standard.

Overall, a good experience, but nothing really stood out.  It's not easy opening a restaurant in this town and having it stand out, but it was frankly somewhat boring.  They've got some kinks to work out with the space and the menu, but I'm sure that will come with time.
author: Geoff K.

description:
Everything was yummy and service was impeccable.  Thank you boyfriend for wrangling us a table even though we didn't have reservations.

Excellent:  foie 2 ways, baked oysters, cheese fries
Good:  Tuna tartare (not enough flavor) and ribeye steak (portion too small)
author: Jen C.

description:
I've been to Salt House a handful of times and each time it puts a nice dent in my wallet, but it is so worth it.  The restaurant is in an old early 20th century printing press building, and the industrial loft-like decor is matches the atmosphere that they are trying to convey.  

Yes some  people may compare Salt House to NoPa, but in general I don't think that this is a valid relevant opinion.  Yes, they both have cool cocktails and a communal table in case you didn't make a reservation, but the food is a lot better at Salt House.  The fois gras is to die for, and  the autumn salad is minimal but so delicious.  I think the handful of times that I've been there I've have a perma-smile on my face, and that says a lot because I don't smile as much as I should.
author: Ishmael V.

description:
Went for dinner on a Friday night - late and this place was still packed! We were able to get sat pretty quickly and that was pretty exciting...since we were starving!

The bread was yummy and the drinks were good (pretty strong).

I had the bass for dinner and it came out done perfectly and totally hit the spot on an empty tummy.

I would recommend this spot for a nice dinner...I really enjoyed it.
author: Amiee L.

description:
Visited Salt House just before the holidays, having missed lunch, and after a couple hours of shopping, in desperate need of a drink and snack.

Love the interior - very cool exposed brick, vaulted ceilings, and steel beams a la SF retrofit. Since we missed lunch, we dove immediately into the Acme pain de mie (no it is not odd shaped and tastes delish) with the yummy butter. Then ordered those heavenly potatoes with the beef sauce (I was so delirious I couldn't register any of the proper dish names), but those potatoes were heaven at that moment. Oh right Poutine - they also had melty fontina which hit the spot!!  We also had the crispy shrimp - nice spicy harissa sauce!! And perhaps we had the foie gras torchon but I can hardly remember through the cloud of low blood sugar.

Service was good - wine list was nice - more to be explored here for sure!!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Every year, certain establishments enjoy the honor of "hot places to go".  Why and how these places attain this attention is nebulous at best.  My guess is that a small group of SF's restaurant elite, hipsters, and the wicked witch of the West get together yearly to bestow this coveted award.  Some of the choices are great and endure from year to year... some fall by the wayside (remember Gordon's House of Fine Eats?)

This year, the contenders are NOPA, Pres a Vi, and Salt House.
The current trend seems to be a relaxed atmosphere, communal dining, and simple food for sharing.

Step inside the Salt House and you'll see an eclectic mix of business diners blowing off steam after work, students from the nearby school, and those goddamned hipsters I hate so much.  If you don't have a reservation, you'll likely be shown the bar or one of the communal tables.

The food is pretty straightforward and unpretentious.  Nothing wild or crazy here, portions are decent.

Likes:  1) the casual vibe that says "I'm cool, but I'm not trying that hard to be cool".  2) The glass milk jugs they use as water pitchers with their very own Salt House logo painted on it.  3) Pork belly, who doesn't like pork belly?

Dislikes: 1) Hit or miss menu, fairly standard fare.  2) Those goddamned hipsters!
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Crummy service, plus a dash of you're-two-feet-away-but-we-still-have-to-yell-at-each-other.

The food was actually good.  We had a dozen oysters to start, then I had the petrale sole and my husband had the tuna.  The bouillabaise with the petrale sole was a little too acidic for the fish, but it was well-cooked, and the tuna was perfectly cooked.

Major, major downside was the completely disinterested service.  She forgot my husband's beer.  We had to wait an hour between the oysters and the entrees.  

Our waitress was just totally avoiding us at that point.  Everyone understands when the kitchen is slow.  And virtually everyone can be made happy again when the waitress comes by and says, "The kitchen is running a little behind, your entrees will be up shortly, can I get you some more bread and butter in the meantime?"  But no,  that never happened. 

After some meaningful eye contact with the waitress across the restaurant, she finally comes with the entrees and puts them down on the table, doesn't say a word, then walks away.  I mean, shit, we're paying nearly $30 apiece for these entrees, can I get a "this is the petrale sole, this is the tuna, enjoy your dinner"?  Guess not.  And I guess she got a crappy tip, and I guess we won't be back.
author: Charmaine Y.

description:
ugh, never again.  

3 of us walk in from a Giant's game in some casual wear.  already, we feel young-lookin' and perhaps too chill for a place with "POSH" written all over it; but whatever, right?  we're customers with money, and we're ready to spend.  upon ordering a bottle of wine, sweetened olives and their famed poutine, the waitress snaps, "that's not a lot of food."  

ooooh... i wanted to be like, "woman, that's almost $60 worth.  are you for real?"  

she comes back with our wine, pompously laughs at my partner for "improperly tasting" it, then "educates" him on the correct way of serving it to us as his guests.  so blatant.  so rude.  i couldn't believe i was watching her treat us like this.  that's the last we hear of her.  other attendants swing by w/ our appetizers. she never checks back with us.  

wow.

we sit there wondering what the deal is: maybe her boyfriend broke up with her.  maybe her dog died.  my partner writes a note on the check: "notice you're in a funky mood tonight.  hope things get better," and hooks her up w/ a sizable tip anyway.  

turns out she rejected his tip.    

um, Salt House, maybe we didn't "look like" your typical customers, or order $200 worth of fine cuisine.  neither case should have warranted such poor, poor service.

RETRAIN your staff, please.  
or find that woman a therapist.
author: melissa n.

description:
Not a bad place.  The decor is nice.  I especially like the painting on the back wall... almost anime in design.  I had the yellow tail appetizer - not very good, and the duck entree - much better.  She has the crispy shrimp and chicken - both were very good.  For dessert, the apple crumble thing with vanilla ice cream was awesome.

I've never been to Town Hall, so I can't compare, but this place was pretty average.
author: Anthony R.

description:
3.75.  I thoroughly researched the menu before going to this place because I wanted to make sure I got the best dishes.  The oysters were great.  The poutine was fantastic.  My halibut entree - eh.  The fish was pretty good.  It was presented in a seafood broth/sauce with shrimp.  I thought the shrimp really didn't make sense with the fish and didn't do anything to bring out its flavor at all.  Somewhat of a disappointment.

I went for carrot cake for dessert.  I LOVE carrot cake.  To my disappointment, the carrot cake was completely overpowered by tangerines. I couldn't taste anything but the tangerine at all. It ruined the carrot cake.  

My guy got the chicken after I told him how many yelpers had reccommended it.  I felt bad telling him that after I tasted it.  It was pretty good, but it wasn't as remarkable as the reviews I read claimed.  However, the accompanying asparagus was delish.

The service was great and attentive.  The waitress was very nice.  My one complaint about the service was that the buss boy who clears the tables was a little too eager to clear us out.  He kept asking if I was done with things when I wasn't.  I had lots of food left.  Also, I had 1/2 a glass of wine on the table (along with my dessert wine) and he really wanted to clear it. I almost felt as if I disappointed him that I wasn't done with it.  At a place like that, I want him to be a little more attentive regarding where I'm at with my food and less concerned about turning the table for the next party (or at least don't make me feel like you are).
author: Angie C.

description:
I have been jonesing to go to this place. Really jonesing- Like it has been on my list for ages. So at my turn to choose a restaurant, without hesitation I selected the Salt House. Downtown, close to work etc. etc. From the start let me say, the consensus at the end was unanimous- we aren't going back. 
 
Salt house, I wanted to like you. Really wanted to. All the makings were there. Good reviews, good location, nice decor, great company, but the two things that actually matter- the Food, and the Service were severely lacking. 
 
First introduction was the none other but the tap water or bottle water question- (Please see review of Jardinire to explain how this already drives me up a wall.)
 
Time to get foie gras (the best thing all night) from sit down was 50 minutes. Time to get our entree, post poor sacrificial duck- about an additional 40 minutes. (Our server took a "break"- which would have been fine, had the food actually arrived in a timely manner.)
 
Mine, Petrale. Salt less (I thought this was a SALT house) on some very unexciting beans. There was mention on the menu, and I was very much looking forward to of a very fancy broccoli/ asparagus fusion vegetable that made an appearance in the form of about half the size of my pinkie (and FYI, I have v. small hands) Way to many beans. I didn't finish it at all. 
 
No one actually checked back to see how things were. Anyone who has waited tables knows that after the first, second bite it is helpful to check back to see if temperature, cook etc. is good. Regardless, we are such polite people I am sure we would have said things were fantastic no matter what. However, it is the asking that is important/
 
At that moment I wished I had eaten the bread. 
 
His, Much Much better than mine. I had food envy. The Dry Aged Rib Eye was perfect, and very tasty- if you go there, get the same thing and don't feel guilty about it.  (He would give them 3 stars)
 
The best line was the end of the night when the one thing we liked on the dessert menu, some pear thing wasn't being served because "the chef doesn't feel like it is up to par and is refusing to serve it". I wish he had felt that way about my fish!
author: Danielle V.

description:
Interesting location and brick design off of Mission.  This place has become a hit among all of the office workers South of Market.  Pricing is moderate for a Financial District type place.

The place is very loud and always packed -- so much so that the wait staff has a difficult time serving tables and moving plates around.

I am ambivalent to this place.  An ok place to have an after hour drink but in no way a good place to have a relaxing dinner.
author: Laurence H.

description:
While being Review #557 is pointless, as an avid Yelper I gotta throw in my two cents.

LOVE this place. Our server was awesome, the rustic meets industrial decor is super cool, and the food rocked. Don't miss the decadent poutine (steak fries with white cheddar and short rib gravy).
author: Jenny K.

description:
I think this is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. The ambiance, location, decor, food, service-- everything is just so super cool and awesome. 

Come here for some absolutely amazing seafood- the menu changes regularly, but I can speak personally for the striped bass and yellowtail. Although seafood might be the specialty, the salads are really great as well. And some very yummy wines to boot. Although reservations are greatly recommended, they're not always a necessity. It also seems like everyone who works here is very friendly, which is a huge plus in my book.
author: Jon N.

description: We were sent to Salt House tonight by our hotel concierge and were definitely happy with our experience.  The first good sign was that the place was packed on a Wednesday evening.  We nabbed one of the last tables in the place.  The service was friendly and speedy.  Yes, the menu is small and we only ordered entrees but I'd love to try more (especially the oysters) on another visit.  The wine list is a bit strange as was said by a previous reviewer but I had a decent glass of Tempranillo.  The monkfish was fantastic as was the sole.  The ambiance is lovely but it is loud.  I think this would be a perfect place for a group of people for drinks or dinner after work.
author: Meghan M.

description:
This place is definitely pricey, but the food is pretty good.  I came with a friend late one Friday, and I was surprised by the set-up.  It really reminded me of a loft, very small and cozy with young professionals everywhere.

We shared the Seafood Plateau, which was HUGE and served in a large, metal mixing bowl of ice.  There were oysters, clams, and peeled shrimp.  They came with a dipping vinegar/garlic/pepper sauce which wasn't bad.  I'm not a huge fan of oysters so I left those alone, but the shrimp were fresh and firm.  

I can't remember what we had specifically, but we each had a different type of white fish served on a bed of vegetables, corn, beans, etc.  Mine was served on a pork-stew with veggies, which smelled and tasted so good!  I really liked the number of ingredients used to accompany the fish.  Very unique and delicious combinations.

For dessert, we shared the Medjool date cake with caramel sauce, peaches and butter pecan ice cream.  I didn't really like it, although it sounded really good at first.  The dessert menu didn't really impress me at all.      

Overall, the staff and atmosphere were great, and the main entrees were amazing!  I would maybe do dessert somewhere else though or just stick to a dessert wine/coffee instead.
author: Jen Y.

description: Great location, the space is funky, and has the potential, however if you are a restaurant the food better be good.  The food was very average...the apps were ok, but the mains that the server recommended where hit and miss.  The Swordfish was great, but the Pork duo was dry, overcooked and the pork belly was so fatty that it felt like you were eating fat.  The pork belly ended up being a pool of fat on my plate.  Too many great restaurants in SF to go back to this one!
author: Edmund L.

description:
This stylish litle spot has friendly, professional staff and great food.  When an appetizer didn't get delivered, the manager promptly came to the table and made an adjustment to our bill.

Went with 3 other people, so I got to taste 4 different dishes - they were all fantastic.  Everything was good including presentation.
author: Marsizzle M.

description:
Very solid restaurant. Foie gras and scallops (app.) were very good, the scallops especially. As an entree, I had the calamari which I was very satisfied with. He had the lamb which he liked, but I could have done without. The dessert wasn't anything fabulous. I actually found it completely unmemorable but I'm also not a huge dessert person.

The service seems rather hit or miss. Some people were nice, others not so much. I think maybe our waiter was bipolar or something. One minute he'd gush about something, the next he was as cool as could be. Odd. 

All in all, I recommend it.
author: Anita B.

description:
Nice place, nice decor...pretty good use of a small space. The baked oysters (with bacon, spinach) were okay. The hangar steak has good flavor, the petrale sole is pretty nice, and the California bass was a thing of luxury--not too flaky, like cutting into an edible piece of ivory, surrounded by an excellent ham hock/bean ragout. A Downtown Brown ale washed all this down. Okay, two ales.

Pricey and slow (we sat in the small upstairs area and saw that half the restaurant was empty and still our food took ages to arrive). But I liked it so much I'd come back.
author: Maximillian M.
