description: Meh...Its overpriced for mediocre food...I am usually a big eater and stepping into this place i expected still be hungry after (which i was) I was going to be spending a lot of money at this place so I might as well go big..So i got the steak...It was OK...but not the greatest steak i ever had.....We had a large party and i guess they wanted to bring our food out at the same time so it took FOREVER!!!! it was nice that they gave us a couple appetizers and later some free desserts....but this place should be nice for dates but not big groups.....ended the night shelling out $60...my meal, birthday girls, and some appetizers and desserts.. I ended the night going to a bar for a going away party and ate more there.
author: Brendan L.

description: I came here for lunch with friends. I never order a hamburger, but I was hungover and it sounded fantastic. And it was. It had blue cheese on top, the bun was perfectly crisp in the right places, and the side of shredded onion fries can easily become a guilty pleasure. We didn't have very good service, but he seemed to be handling more tables than he should have, and we were upstairs in the loft. I'd go back again though.
author: SHANE S.

description:
Salt House always makes me happy.  Every time I have eaten there, from birthday dinners, to business gatherings, to family in town, it never ceases to impress.  They consistently deliver great food and great service.  

From the recommended squid appetizer special to the Petrale Sole each dish was fun and delicious.  The affordable Athena wine blend is also my favorite.  Don't miss dessert!
author: Brenda T.

description:
Stick to the drinks.  The food is truly atrocious.  We had some "aged" oysters that had our entire table wondering if we'd be driving the porcelain bus later.  To be fair, I'm not sure it was the oysters, it could have been the greasy pastrami ribs.  Whatever it was, it sure wasn't pretty.

It's not all bad - the bar staff is great and they have some really interesting wines.  Just don't eat there.
author: Robyn H.

description:
If you only order one thing here, make sure it's the Poutine - a sinful combination of crispy fries that's smothered in cheddar and short rib gravy. They're so delicious, I have to have a cigarette after eating them. That said, the beef short ribs are almost as good, as is just about everything else on their diverse menu.

Definitely make reservations and plan on standing around sipping cocktails while you wait for your table.
author: Eric G.

description:
Had dinner with 2 friends here last nite for the first time.  Love the exposed brick, rusted iron girders, and dark hardwood floors of this old 1920's printing press warehouse.  I love these restaurants that blend old rustic charm with modern decorative elements.  

As we perused the menu we decided there were more interesting appetizers than there were entrees so we agreed to get about 6-7 apps and share one entree.  We started off with the shellfish plateau which was a melange of oysters, clams, mussels, and peeled cooked shrimp on a mound of ice served in a large stainless steel mixing bowl.  The seafood was fresh and delicious.  The 6 appetizers we ordered included Poutine (steak frites w/ short rib gravy), Cauliflower soup, Crispy Shrimp (served over spicy green beans, almonds and serrano ham), Yellowfin Tuna (seared and served with leeks and a green garlic truffle vinaigrette), Suckling Pig (served w/ lentils and roasted garlic, and Foie Gras (both seared and torchon).  The one entree we ordered to share was their grilled hanger steak (figured "eh" we don't have a beef dish yet).

I really enjoyed having the variety of different appetizers rather than your traditional 3 or 4 course meal.  It really gave us a true sense of the "new American" cuisine that the Salt House offers.  The Salt House is the second restaurant of the founders of Town Hall.  From my recollection of eaten at Town Hall on 2 other occasions, I like the ambience and the food offerings of Salt House better.  If coming here in a group of 3-4 people, I really recommend sharing 4-6 appetizers and sharing a 1-2 entrees...depending on how much you can put away.
author: Rick P.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner on a Saturday night and were able to get seating at the bar, where you can get full menu and service. The atmosphere is very urban and, as my friend put it, "new york," with exposed beams and brick walls, spot lighting and a few unique art pieces. 

We checked out the menu and wasn't blown away by what was offered at the time for entrees - lamb loin, hanger steak, petrole sole and a couple of others (also seemed a little pricey for what they were offering). The appetizers though caught our eye so we picked a couple to share - foie gras, seaboat scallops, baked oysters, and poutine - all of them were great!!! The foie gras was buttery, the scallops were done just right and sat atop a bed of corn, black-eyed peas and bacon bits- yum! The poutine was yummy due to the use of Gruyere cheese and a savory meat gravy. The baked oysters were good - they had some breadcrumbs piled on top and broiled, but were under done for my taste. I assume they were more for people who liked them raw...

We got the apple dessert and that had a very delicate phyllo crust that was delicious with the chunky apple filling. There was also a small scoop of tart apple sorbet which I felt didn't really go with the dish but hey, it was good nonetheless. 

Overall, a great place to go on a dinner date. It looked like the place would get a bit crowded for guests if you had a party of 5 or more.
author: Vicki F.

description:
I had never heard of salt house, and just had lunch here with some coworkers. 

Love the exposed brick and bare steal beams and stairs. I know this de rigueur in SOMA/Protrero Hill, but between that and the tall ceilings and large windows, it really opens up what would otherwise be a fairly small restaurant, into a really pleasant space with plenty of natural light. I loved the light fixtures that resembled those large metal racks that hold postcards. 

Vegetarians beware, as the menu is very meat oriented. I had the Cobb salad, and it was really two large pieces of chicken breast, with some salad underneath. The chicken was cooked perfectly, and the salad was wonderful, but if someone was really expecting a "salad," they might think that the server brought the wrong order. 

The service was wonderful. We will definitely be back when we have time for a leisurely Friday lunch.
author: James M.

description:
How slow can a dining experience really be? Some say dining is generally slower the fancier the place in question. Salt House will test this theory in spades. If its a "power business lunch", go elsewhere. Ours took around 2 hours to get apps and mains and complete. I literally had to run back to south soma to jump on a call and made it 5 mins late.

Food was good. Oversalted for most palettes...guess the name they picked gives them a slight amount of brevity in this case, which really should not be the case at any fine dining establishment. Luckily from years of Argentinan family BBQs I've developed somewhat of a liking to heavily salted dishes & good flavors make up for this. Fau gras was okay dish, the apricot sauce seemed to be hiding the actual flavor a bit, so while it was good it was not worth the price. 

Poutein on the other hand was a great deal! Gravy was basically a thickened French onion soup, but it was a tasty addition. French-Canada would be proud. My Sole was hot and well cooked w/ sold complements on the dish. Everyone seemed to enjoy the burgers and stuffed pork loin that were ordered as well. 

Not recommended for those on the go but solid food and solid presentation makes for a good meal in the right situation.
author: Nick V.

description: We have been to all three for lunch or dinner (Salt house, anchor & hope, town hall) this review is for the breakfast they have just started to offer. The scones are yum, not sweet almost biscuit like and great service. When we were there the owner kept running to get us hot dauce and water. Without even a need to ask.
author: Mindy C.

description: Good food.  But wow...talk about taking a long time.  I went here on a Saturday for a friend's bday dinner.  We had a party of 11 people.  Reservations were at 7pm and we probably ordered around 8pm.  We finally walked out of there are 10:30pm.  They told us as they brought out our appetizers that entrees were going to take a bit longer, but seriously, for it to be THAT late, it was bad.  Other tables kept waiting too, not just ours.  The waiter did bring us extra "munchies" to hold us off...and ended up giving a few extra desserts.  For the price we paid, I would have expected better.
author: B C.

description:
Went there for a business dinner and liked it.   It is outside of my walking distance from the office or home comfort zone, but it was worth the trip.  Get the roasted lamb.   The sauce is just the right combination of savory with a hint sweetness.   

The appetizers were good, but nothing special.   Your pretty standard California Cuisine "seared tuna something."    In fact, I was a little disappointed until the lamb was served.  

Prices were reasonable and I would go back again, but I didn't really see anything else on the menu that looked interesting.   I will wait a while and allow them to change up the menu a little.
author: Jim Z.

description:
I enjoyed dinner here, but was blown away by the sweet treats.

File Salt House under "D" for Desserts.

The Baked Alaska was amazing.
Chocolate Mousse was spectaular.

That pastry chef is  fantastic!
author: Suzanne A.

description:
First time diner at Salt House, noise level was not so bad, I had heard it was unbearable at times. Tuesday night crowd, super great wait service and great menu. We had beet salad (great) and peach salad with pork bacon (really good) and the Poutine (crispy potato fries with bechamel sauce and then drenched lightly in pot roast type gravy) WOW WOW WOW, I'd go back again just to eat those from the bar with a glass of wine.

Entrees were chicken which was cooked very well, hanger steak which was really good, sole which was good and gnocchi which was just so-so, nothing to write home to mom about.

For dessert shared the Ice Cream Sandwiches which were great and the Bittersweet Chocolate Mousse Cup which none of us liked, the chocolate was like eating melted baking chocolate, there was no sweet at all in it, extremely bitter, no sweet. I'd pass on that one next time. We left half of it and sent it away.

All in all a very nice experience....I definitely would go back.

Thanks Salt House!
author: SFCAFOX S.

description:
We went here last night (upstairs) for a work-do.  All in all, the company was good, so it made for a nice dinner.  It was yummy but pricy.  Overally, I felt they were stingy with the sides--they were more like garnish than sides.

Still, my favorite part of the evening, aside from my AMAZING heirloom tomato salad, was our high-off-her-rocker waitress.  She was floating through life.  She messed up orders, forgot things, and her best conversation with me went as follows:

[waitress has already poured a fancy, decanted bottle of red for most of table.  Then she pours my glass, again, from a decanter]

Me:  So, what am I having here?

Waitress:  Ah yeah. This is a beautiful Napa cab.  It's well aged, but still young.  It has a lot of structure.  You're really going to like it.

Me: So...what winery is this from?  How old is it?

Waitress: Um. Yeah.  Um.  It's just beautiful.  You are _so_ going to love it!

The good news was that the waitress was an attractive blonde. I am sure they'll keep her around, despite here questionable competency at waiting tables.

Plus one for fun decor, good presentation, and an excellent wine list. 

Minus one star for extreme loudness.  Minus another star for extreme slowness--we were a table of 9, but after our dinner orders were taken, it still took nearly an hour after apps to get our entrees. 

One other warning--they cook meat French-style here.  That is to say, everyone, regardless of how they ordered their meat, received it rare.  If you want your meat medium, be sure to stress you mean it.  

I've never really had bloody lamb until last night. However, it was tasty--moroccan-spiced with a nice crust.  Reminded me of Zebbibo's lamb.
author: alli h.

description:
Attending Ad Conferences comes with perks. Perks that partners will take you to lunch to wine and dine you. Our partner recently took us here for a lunch meeting and it was fantastic. The place looks very rustic and the service was good. After reading reviews on yelp, I noticed that most people raved about the poutine which I had to have. French fries smothered with gravy and topped with cheddar ($12), slightly different than how the Canadians would do it. I prefer cheese curds but this appetizer was pretty good nontheless - yum.

I had the duck confit ($18) which came plated perfectly on a bed of lentils. The duck - juicy and moist with a nice crispy crust seared from the ducks fat - yum. The lentils which I didn't care much for so I won't waste my time describing it. The meal was a little over the top for a lunch meeting but quite delicious. I'd definitely come back to try their other dishes.
author: Janet T.

description:
Hands down favorite restaurant of 2007.

My father doesn't hear very well so it's hard to go to restaurants as a family, and Salt House has a reputation for being really loud... but I *really* wanted to try it.  When I made the reservation they put a note down requesting a quiet table, and the hostess went to enormous lengths to situate us where my dad would be comfortable.  It worked out really well.

Impeccable service continued.  Our server despite having to crouch not to hit his head on the stairs insisted on delivering things in front of me without my help, saying "You'll miss the fun of being served if you do that for me."  He played a little joke on my mom (he had a very fun sense of humor), and when my dad dropped his fork it barely hit the ground before it was snatched up and replaced.

Food arrived in good time, hot, and was incredible.  I ordered as many different dishes as I could get away with: crispy egg, seared tuna and autumn salad for starters, Mom and brother had lamb, sole for Dad, and ribeye with grated marrow for me - best ribeye I've eaten all year.  I ate every bite.

Dessert was shared chocolate thing, shared quince upside-down cake, and a comped dish of rum raisin ice cream for me simply because the server thought it the best rum raisin he'd ever tried.

We had two bottles of wine throughout the dinner and afterward I crawled home with my belly bursting.  I believe that it was the marrow that gave me horrible nightmares all night, but on the other hand, I believe it was Salt House that made me smile until I went to sleep.

That or the unexpected late-night phone call. :-)
author: Ani T.

description:
The service at this place was fantastic.  We had a reservation and arrived early but they seated us in the back where you really couldn't get any of the ambiance or excitement of the restaurant.  Instead we waited and sat in the front so that we could people watch.

The salads are different, the environment contemporary and the bar has fun interesting drinks.  I would definitely go back and take any out of  town guests to the Salt House.

You should definitely order an appetizer though because they don't give you a lot of food.  I had the prime rib and it was good, but the sides are lacking.  My friend had the chicken and she had a tiny bit of sides.  

All in all a good treat and an enjoyable evening.
author: Jachyn D.

description:
Maybe this is like a fine wine which needs to age a bit before it can be enjoyed. My companion and I sat at the communal table which is normally found in Berkeley or Oakland so we were game for it. However, the seats were a little less to be desired because they never offered to check our coats and being winter time....you need a heavy coat which we had to place over our stools and sat on. 

When we found out it was under the same management as Town Hall...let's just say I nearly fell off my stool aka seat. The comparison between the two can be likened to one being the distant cousin you never knew and you sort of wish you didn't. The service was spotty to say the least and the food was okay. 

Sitting on the communal table affords you the pleasure of fighting for table space and getting a chance to listen to your neighbors sexual escapades. Reminder to all Yelpers...keep that *hit to yourself. 

The space is loud just like Town Hall however it will be the new happy hours joint to be seen. Blame the lack of restaurateurs willing to take a chance in finicky San Francisco. If you open it, we will come!!! 

Try the Poutine which consists of fried potatoes with bits of pork drenched in sauce. Everyone at the communal table seemed to enjoy the steak sandwich as well which my companion and I missed out on. 

Warning: do not order the chicken because it took over 45 minutes to come out of the kitchen and our table neighbor had to be comped a bowl of olives as they waited for their food to be cooked. It was not even busy since it was lunchtime and the crowd thinned out at 1:30 PM.  

I gave it two stars because it definitely doesn't deserve a lone one since the food was alright. Not the best I have had and I'm not very picky. Believe me when I say a "hole in the wall" satisfies my taste buds.
author: S L.

description: This place has the best bread ever.  (It's from Acme bakery for those of you who just want the bread.)  The other food is good too.  I'm also a fan of the decor except the last time I was there, the fact that there's a balcony-style second level proved problematic.  A diner above us spilled her wine and it dripped all over my friend and her white pants/beige coat.  The servers and owner flocked to help my friend.  They brought her soda water and when that didn't work the owner even went down the street to the Walgreens to look for a Tide pen.  He returned with bleach and her pants were ultimately ruined but it's the thought that counts I guess.  In any event we got a free meal and ate good food.
author: barbara b.

description: Food was really good, service was awesome. Everyone was really friendly. Jonathan is the man! He made an awesome experience even better!
author: Rich P.

description:
Went there with a friend for dinner Thursday evening and overall experience was FAIR.

PROS:
1. Great location, good atmosphere, nice set up and interesting menu
2. Service is very good though our waiter was probably new so stumbled on some of the explainations
3. Great wine list

CONS:
1. Bad sound proofing so the noise level is really high
2. Portions are European so if you're looking to tank up, go elsewhere
3. Some of the food items came to us lukewarm to cold
4. Some of the flavors in the food items were definitely very different in terms of pairing
4. Place lacks a personable feel but it IS the FD

Not a bad place but its sister restaurant Town Hall gets all my votes and my loyalty. Salt House is relatively new so I'm sure they're working out their kinks.

Would I go there again... sure.
author: Amit S.

description:
Clearly,everyone who works at Salt House has a very high opinion of him/herself. That is lovely for them, but not entirely deserved.

I was quite late joining my friends for lunch here, and I thought I'd come in and order just as they were getting their food. But when I arrived, my party had only just been seated -- and there were two hungry pregnant women in attendance. 

The waitress said she'd bring some nuts to hold us over, and then charged us for them at the back end. She also kept referencing that we were a LARGE PARTY. As in, "Your entrees are going to take about 20 minutes because you are such a LARGE PARTY, is that all right?" and "We already added the gratuity because you are such a LARGE PARTY." For the record, there were eight of us, and the place was maybe half-full. So, come on.

The food? Half-good. My meatloaf was really wonderful -- great texture, and a beautiful chanterelle sauce. My friend had sole with a pureed-carrot sauce that was really delicate. There were house-made potato chips that were pretty light and tasty. But my mashed potatoes were inedible. In. Edible. So much salt, it was as if the chef had been thumped on the back by one of the Three Stooges while pouring salt into the potato pot. Screwing up mashed potatoes -- I mean -- I don't even know how you DO that. So it's impressive in its own way. 

But the waitress was so clearly irritated by us that i felt it would be pointless to bring it to her attention.
author: Amy K.

description:
I've heard all the buzz about Salt House from friends and office buddies. It was finally my turn to check it out. The two of us popped in last night at 9:30ish without a reservation and were promptly seated on the first floor by the kitchen. It was surprisingly crowded at this hour but service was still ok. Our waitstaff kept changing (we had a different waitress take our drink order, our entree order, and dessert order... strange, huh?). No minus points given, just thought it was interesting.

We started with the pate, which was yucky to me (can't place my finger on it but I really didn't like it). My luck changed because I had the fried chicken as my main dish... which was darn good! Because I am not a fan of skin, I tore off all of it and just ate the meat. I bet I lost a lot of flavor doing that... but I still enjoyed it! The portion was fairly large, too! 

We ended with the pumpkin mousse/pie thing. Our waitress told us that it's not very "pumpkin" so we ordered it. Sure, it wasn't super duper pumpkin-y, but it definitely had too much cinnamon. I wouldn't recommend this dessert unless you're a big fan of both pumpkin and cinnamon.

As for vibing, the restaurant was just the right amount of noisy to satisfy both large parties and couples on dates. It's trendy and still hip, yes.

I'm not sure I'd come back, though. I do think the meal was more expensive than it should have been for the quality of food. :x
author: Han C.

description:
Love, love, love... I have been twice and the food was so good. Our 1st trip when they asked if we wanted dessert, we said no, we just want you to bring the whole thing again from appetizer to entree... we didn't really but it was that good, we wanted to. 2nd time, we sat at the bar (that is always the best at any restaurant for great service I think), and again the experience was spot on... we will go again for sure. 

Also, the decore and style of this restaurant is so soupy... there is an amazing piece of artwork painted on back of the restaurant wall... I guess the owner or owner's wife painted it. So killer.
author: Tsuni S.

description:
Very positive experience.

First, we did not have a reservation and the hostess "made a deal with us" to compelete our meal by a certain time and she seated us immediately. The deal began a delighful evening. 

First, the bread rocks, plus is served on brown paper. nice sort of earthy touch. 

If you like beets, the beet appetizer is splendid topped with smoked salmon and a creme fraiche style topping with a hint of horseradish. It balences the salt nicely.

The pastrami ribs turned out nice - fatty but flavorful. The apple butter was fantastic. Again, a nice balance. The theme is salt based for sure. I'm not a fan of salt but was pleasantly surprised when the dishes were not over salted at all. We also ordered the roasted chicken cut in medallions. Nice lemon and garlic flavor. 

The service was impeccable. Our waiter (french) was able to speak to every wine we questioned and made perfect recommendations: The Latour Chardonnay and Claiborne & Chruchill Gewurztraminer. He was very attentive, we appreciated his service.

The atmosphere is in the tradition of Town Hall: mixed elements, warm, inviting. The painting (criticized by one yelper) added an interesting, artistic flair. Certainly a conversation piece, but not offensive.  The night we were there must have been "friends of Doug" night because when owner Doug Washington strolled in quite a many patrons acted as if a rock star entered the room. They were rising to greet him with handshakes, high fives, hugs, kisses and shout outs. It was quite a spectacle. Not letting the superstar welcome get the best of him, he quickly got to work checking in with the staff and patrons. 

Why not five stars? It's a bit pricey, especially the wine.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Good food, good atmosphere, a little overpriced.

We tried the Poutin and pickled vegetables for appetizers, which were both very good.  I had the chicken and my girlfriend tried the halibut, which were both good but not great.  

My favorite was the dessert....rhubarb tort.  

Overall, it was a good experience, but they could vary their menu a bit more (was pretty limited) and they could add more vegetarian dishes.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Just good.  If you're in the neighborhood, and that's where you find yourself, then by all means have dinner there.  But it's not worth a special trip.  The descriptions on the menu sound inventive, but the finished product is just so-so.

The place was very crowded and incredibly loud.  Like yell-at-your-dining-partner-to-be-heard loud.  The service was mediocre.  I was almost done with my entree by the time the waitress brought my second glass of wine (she asked if I wanted another after I had finished my salad).  Plates were slow coming from the kitchen - my fish was verging towards just warm by the time I got it.  It was also slightly overcooked (the Tai Snapper).  My friend enjoyed his tuna immensely (but he's from Denver so I think his bar is a tad lower than mine).

Overall, I don't think it was worth the price-tag ($150 for 2 ppl). My impression is that the restaurant is in conflict with itself - are you a $28+ well-executed entree place (a la sister restaurant Town Hall)  or fun, loud urban-y great drinks + food joint (e.g., NOPA)?  Decide and be that thing.
author: darla s.

description: I am never dissappointed, I come her to lunch often and I think the food is great. The service is awesome never had a bad service here.
author: madi b.

description:
The place is really pretty and our waitress was great.  There was some time in between courses, and yes, it's pricey and small portioned.  But that's not what this review is about.

We asked to speak with their sommelier because my friend is a bit of a wine lover, and he was paying, so what the hay!

She came over, introduced herself, Nicole, and they proceeded to banter about wine.  I noticed about a minute into it that she was completely arguing with him about what he wanted to order.  He said Cab, she said no.  He said Pinot Noir, she said no.  He said Blend, she said no.  Along the way, she insulted his taste and questions about some of the wines he was inquiring about.  I understand that wine is subjective in a lot of respects, but insulting guests, putting them down, and arguing with them is probably not in the job description.

Incredibly rude.  I'm an event planner and i used to send lots and lots of groups of 4 and 6 to Salt House over the years.  But after this, i will never again.  Like many of these reviews, just skip it and go to Town Hall.  

I read up on this Nicole on the Salt House website.  I wouldn't call her Up and Coming, but rather Down and Out.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I had dinner reservations this past weekend. Based on the reviews I knew better than to set my expectations to high. The ambiance is very cool, the open kitchen and the brick walls are a great touch. I started with a cosmo and my bf with a glass if wine.. Both very nice...

For starters we ordered the Baked Oysters and the Foie Gras. The oysters were pretty nasty, very fishy - yuck. The Foie Gras on the other hand was excellent. It's served in two forms; foie gras with cranberries and pate with a cream sauce- served with crosintini.  

For our main course I had the Dry Aged Rib Eye, medium rare. It was perfectly cooked and oh soo delicious. My bf has the Alaskan Halibut with a summer squash sauce, which was very light and very tasty. I think he wished he ordered the Rib Eye, because he came back for seconds and thirds. Thankfully the portions were good. 

We didn't make it to dessert, too stuffed. 

Oh I almost forgot: service was fine, neither here nor there. 

I give Salt House a thumbs up, but you need to know exactly what to order, which is why I read the reviews before I went. Thank you yelpers for making the great menu suggestions.
author: Monica S.

description:
3.5 stars.

I've been here a couple time and have always had a nice time. The food is good - not great, but definitely solid - the service is nice and the environment is fun. Prices are definitely a bit steep for what you get, but overall it's not enough to make me pissy.

The good-good: POUTINE (yumyumyum!) - crispy fries smothered in cheese and short rib gravy (yes I am a McFatty); house wine that came in a cutesy bottle; baked oysters.

The so-so: Notice that all of my "goods" are apps - entrees are just ok here. Scallops were ok; the steak was saved from boredom by a delicious piece of tender, braised(?) meat on top of the actual steak.

The no-no: Calamari app. Just plain "no thanks" on this.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Complete disappointment and I wonder how they pay their rent?  Overpriced small selection of entrees.  The appetizer menu feature poutine, which is a fun selection you don't see on many menus.  But, the fries were cold and soggy and the cheese wasn't the cheese you'd find on traditional pountine (which is curd).  Big disappointment all together.  There was nothing appetizing on the entre menu, so I got the chicken, which I NEVER get at a restaurant because it's usually boring and Salt House didn't disappoint.  My guest got the PASO ROBLES BEEF BAVETTE  and had to send it back because they overcooked her medium rare to well done.  I don't get the décor, how it fits into the menu or atmosphere.  Save yourself some time and go eat at the Wayfer Tavern!  I am giving it one extra star than it deserves because they give you a nice piece of bread and butter to start.  Oh, and don't get a mixed drink!  They come in the smallest glasses you've EVER seen.
author: Lori G.

description: The food was amazingly delicious!! I started off with the velveteen cocktail, which I was afraid might be too sweet or alcohol-y tasting, neither of which happened....then I ordered the celery soup..amazing(tons of flavors) and the crispy shrimp, which was served on huge bed of green beans, and field greens, tossed with an excellent dressing. Service was a tad slow, but the delicious food made up for it. You won't be disappointed!
author: karisa b.

description:
This place is pretty solid for a newer restaurant.

I went here a few months ago but I have a laziness disorder. So here goes. I had the bf meet me there since I was in class across the street at GGU. It is a cool little building, with a soft glow coming out of it that makes me just want to get right in there. And so we did.

We didn't have reservations, so we waited in the bar area with wine. There isn't a ton of room there, and it always always is crowded in there, so that was a little awkward, but it's just such a warm and inviting scene that I didn't mind. The hostess and waitstaff is pretty nice.

We were seated and ordered the fois gras pate, which was deeeelicious. Since this was awhile back I can't remember what else we had, but it was not poutine, but I do remember thinking it was good.  This is not cutting edge cuisine, but it is really good, a nice mix of things, and our wine was good. We ordered wine by the carafe which is a great deal.

Also have to say that I spilled my water all over the place and literally four waiters came rushing in with spare towels and helping to clean. That was really refreshing and nice.

UHHHHHHHHHHH I just remembered that we had gone here once before just for drinks and snax at the bar....duh. Ok sorry for the disorder, but it's worth a mention: basically chilled at the bar and the bartender was rapping with us and showed off a couple of good wines they had and made us some killer cocktails. It was fun.

In any case, not a destination restaurant but it's a cool place to stop by for drinks or for dinner, if you are not in the mood for a quiet relaxing dinner. go there if you want a scene.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Wow...not since my review of "Bob's Chop House" have I felt so ripped off.  I don't mind paying for a good meal but it kind of has to be "good" in order to walk away feeling content with my investment.  This place has a purpose: happy hour.  The drinks are great, along with the wine selection and you know, several of the menu items make for a great appetizer.  If you come here for a traditional meal though, you may be somewhat disappointed.  

We tried the crispy shrimp appetizer which was great except for the shrimp vein still intact in each shrimp and the presentation (which included 4 small/mid sized shrimp) for $13.  Our second appetizer was the Yellowfin Tuna Tartare which could have easily been mistaken for "Seared Ahi Salad" - served over a bed of insane greens.  Slightly salty, but good nonetheless.  

My companion opted for the Baked Oysters as her entree.  You really can't screw these up (I could make Oys. Rockefeller over a camp-fire) and you know, they managed to serve a plate of four baked oysters sprinkled with rat pellets.  First dish I have seen sent back to the kitchen in a long time.  $13

My entree was the Dry Aged Rib eye ($28).  Another dish impossible to screw up, right?  This is the first time I have seen a Dry Aged Rib eye served like a bavette instead of an actual steak.  Nothing against "beef bavette" (had a great one at the Four Seasons Palo Alto for a business lunch for less $)...this was just a "steak gone wrong."  The culinary genius in the kitchen also decided it would be a "neat little trick" to cut and serve this piece of flesh against the grain so even their nearly-new steak knife required 6 strokes to make it through a 3/4" piece of meat.  

I will say, our server was a pleasure - she made every effort to try and keep our dining experience on track but the kitchen just flat-out can't deliver.  I left her over 20% - and only because she gets to walk home with that 20%.  This was the kind of place you want to just slip a wad of cash to your server in a James Bond sort of way and not pay the check.  Sad.

I don't hate this place as much as Bob's Chop House (my nemesis) and I will continue to give my business to Salt House in the form of drinks & apps but never again for an $85/pp meal.
author: Ari G.

description:
Huh, I don't get it.  I've been 3 times to the Salt house and just a so-so experience.  It would get 2 stars if it weren't for it's very aesthetic decor.  

The first time we went for happy hour.    DON'T order their "bar food."  It's not fit for eating with drinks...messy messy messy.  A bowl of hot nuts with honey on them?  What is that?  Good, yes.  Bar food, no.

The second time, the food was okay.  My friend ordered a grilled cheese sandwich.  We were expecting a gourmet concoction...no luck...a $15 grilled cheese.

The third time, the food was good, the wait staff nice, but nowhere near deserving of a 5-star review.  Sorry Salt House....and from the people that brought us Town Hall...
author: Eric E.

description:
Salt House was fine, but that's what it was - just fine.  For the price (although I was taken there by a client), I just expected more.  The service was attentive and the decor was great, but the food was just fine.

I had a butternut squash soup that was good, although I was told that the heirloom tomato salad is out of this world (I like heirloom tomatoes, so it's hard to ruin that for me).  The sole was tasty, the portion was a bit more than what I liked, but it was great with the bacon bits and brussel sprouts.  I had the apple turnover with rum raisin ice cream, nothing to write home about, but the presentation was nice and it wasn't bad.

A lukewarm, slightly positive review here - nothing went wrong and I had a delightful meal, but I wasn't blown away.  I have to agree with Charles C. though, the crowd was very bankerish, speaking as someone who lives in NYC.  I was there for a business lunch meeting, so who am I to talk, but I did notice that it was a restaurant where everyone did seem very well-to-do and the crowd was basically filled with a blend of internet entrepreneurs and bankers.
author: Albert C.

description: Had a very enjoyable meal here last weekend. GREAT cocktails, a creative wine list, well prepared food. A five star restaurant in any other city in America, probably, but not in San Francisco, where my standards go up a notch. Slightly salty, ironically enough, but enjoyable. Nice oyster menu and cheese selections. An intimate place that feels modern/lofty at the same time. Well done. Their pisco and tequila drinks, by the way, are to die for.
author: Paul S.

description:
Loud and bustling but I go there for the food.  Love that menu change regularly and that they are all local-ish ingredients.  

Wine list is good but not great.  Wish I didn't have to ask for the reserve list but I usually take wine there any way.  

Food is always well prepared and the portions are the right size for me.  Service is always good and sometimes great. 

Lastly, I love that they were able to get me in with some friends for a last minute seating.  Great when this place is almost always fully reserved ahead of time. 

Lastly,
author: John A.

description:
Came for dine about town lunch with a girlfriend.  Very cute restaurant and service was pleasant and competent.  We got a table next to the window towards the back of the restaurant so the noise level was good for a chat.

Food was also nice - not spectacular but enjoyable, though chef was a bit heavy handed with salt on the frittata.  Will consider returning to try dinner.
author: Lev E.

description:
Finally we have another place to dine when Town Hall gets too crowded! The Salt House, Town Hall's sister restaurant is equally as impressive, if not better. Once you walk through the door, you immediately get the same warm, rustic feeling you do at Town Hall. The bar is packed and tables fill up fast, so make sure to book a reservation. 

There are more probably more winning appetizers on their menu than the entrees. Make sure to share with friends. The poutine seems a bit strange but who can resist fried potatoes, gravy, cheese, and let me remind you, fries. Although it's mixed all together, you can't beat sopping up the extra gravy with the fresh Acme bread. Definitely try the crab salad and seared foie gras if they have it available. I thought the entrees were slightly overpriced but still winners. The cassoulet had a delicious duck confit with crispy skin and the fulton chicken was juicy and tender. If I had my way, I would get the crab salad and get double portions of the pork belly!

The dessert menu leaves something to be desired. The walnut tart and lemon cake were tasty but nothing to write home about. I would just stick with coffee and stop for ice cream on the way home. 

Last comments on wine - a little pricey, might want to consider bringing a bottle. House wine was not so good so stick with a bottle on the menu. We had a great French grenache that was reasonably priced. 

We had a little mix up on our orders but had about 4 people gather together to try to make it right. Service was fantastic and friendly. They definitely didn't have that snobby attitude you sometimes get with restaurants that know they are the hottest thing (at the moment).
author: Josephine H.

description:
The Salt House is not for the meek or the timid. Fortunately I went here with a friend from New York, and she is loud--her inside voice is most people's outside voice. The food is good, my Mom is Canadian so I was excited about the poutin, this is a French Canadian staple. I have soaked up many a Molson with a late night snack of poutin, this fancier version did not disappoint. 

I know the reviews are mixed here, but if you don't mind a loud somewhat raucous scene, then Salt House is not a bad choice.
author: Seamus M.

description:
Went to lunch at the Salt House last Friday with my sister.  Since the opentable cutoff for same day rservations is 10:30 AM, we werent able to get a reservation so we walked in and sat at the bar.  Our waiter/bartender was contstanly refilling our bread basket and our drinks so that was a huge plus for us, it was Friday and about 80 degrees outside.

We started out with the poutine, boy it sure was heavy, but delicious.  I love poutine!  I had the sole and my sis had the aged rib eye.  My dish was so-so but her's was soooo delicous.  Her perfectly cooked rib eye was laid on top of a bed of fresh creamed corn (?) and pearl onions. I'm so getting this dish next time.  My dish consisted of a sole fillet on top some vegetable and a very good broth, which was satifsying but not extraordinary.    Good experience but they need to work on getting some air conditioning in that building.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Indeed very salty.

I wanted to like this place a lot.  I had high expectation.  But the food came in close to the rest of the restaurants in its league, if not slightly behind.

I have always preferred my foie gras to be exactly that.  So when it came in two forms on the plate, one being the real foie gras I have always expected on my table, the other in the form of pate, I was a little disappointed.  If you do that to your customers, you are bound to have the pate foie gras untouched.  

And the main entrees were salty (definitely no irony there with the name of this place).  If I must, must compare, based on the similarity of food and price, my pick would be to go to either Range or Brick instead.  In my book Salt House is a place worth visiting once.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
Correction: Someone pointed out to me that the snapper my husband ordered was Tai snapper not Thai snapper which is obviously different and would not have any sort of curry or coconut or any other Thai flavoring. With that said, this dish still left much to be desired and my rating below still stands.

Skip it.

I wish I could give this resturant a good review but with all the great resturants in the city to dine at this is just not one of them.  

We took some out of town guest here thinking it would be great to all try this place for the first time and hopefully love it. Sadly we were all dissapointed. I ordered the chicken (the very dry chicken) with some sort of sauce that did very little to moisten the meat. My husband ordered the thai snapper which usually implies some sort of thai influence like curry sauce or maybe a hint of ginger but this fish had neither and as he says "left something to be desired". I won't get into what our guests ordered because it's just not worth the time to describe. 

The space is really great and if I were basing this review on the interior, I would give it 5 stars but since I'm not it's only getting 2, which is actually generous considering the price of this meal. 

Spare yourself the hearteache of paying for a meal you won't enjoy. But hey, if you don't believe me try it for yourself, it's a free country but don't say you weren't warned.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
This is my 3rd time at Salt House now and it is consistently excellent. Everything that came to the table was wonderful . . . . especially  good were the baked oysters, crispy shrimp, crispy egg, fulton valley chicken (most of it is off the bone). The sole and bass looked amazing as well. 

The ambiance is sexy and cool . . . and a nice mix of people. The staff was so on it . . . . great service, friendly and genuine waitresses. The owner is constantly around and interacting with patrons (every time I've been there he's stopped by several table to chat with guests).

In every way, food, ambiance, staff, this place hit five stars in my book. I hope they keep it up!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
My husband made early Friday dinner reservations (6 PM) since this place seemed to be booked from 6:30 - 9 PM.  We were one of the first ones in the restaurant, but as soon as it hit 6:15, the place was completely filled!

We ordered a dozen oysters from all the 5 different varieties they had (the Drakes were my favorite) which were very good.

Their specialty drinks were pretty good...my husband had the Kentucky Apple which was made with bourbon and other liquids to make it taste like an apple!  Definitely too strong for my taste, but my husband seemed to like it...and it didn't really taste like an apple to me, unless you marinade your apples in bourbon!  I chose a Champagne infused with some grapefruit with a lime rind and touch of mint, which was good, but a bit more tart than I thought it would be.

The seared scallops and ricotta cheese salad were both good appetizers.

Our entrees were left to be desired - nothing spectacular, but not bad either!  I had the seared tuna, and my husband decided to be adventurous and try the squid.  The seared tuna is served just like any other place...so it was good, but not unique and needed salt.  I don't ever salt my food and this was the first time I had to.  The squid on the other hand was, again, adventurous.  The sauce itself was overwhelming.  Its as if they used the squid's ink to make the sauce.  Which in some cases can be a delight, but in this case, it was too powerful, too saturated.  Although the calms mixed in the dish were extremely good, but they weren't cased in the sauce...they only soaked up enough sauce to compliment it in flavor.  We should have tried our waitress's recommendations for the steak and chicken, but it just sounded too boring to us at the time!

The dessert was fantastic!  We shared a "sticky date cake" - which was some chocolate infused with ginger topped with muscat toffee sauce.  SO YUMMY!

The people who go here are trendy 30 somethings and up.

The decor is modern with a rustic feel, exposure of high ceilings with brick walls and hardwood floors.

The bathrooms were a lot nicer than I would have expected them to be!  Its located in a common space outside the restaurant, shared with an adjacent bar.  There's a curtain covered window right next to the sink, which I couldn't help myself and take a peak - the window gave a view right into the bar next door!  :)  How cool.

Our waitress and bus person were very good and always attentive.

Overall we had a great experience outside the squid dish.  
It might be worth going back again and trying different entrees.
author: Gina K.

description:
This place was nice.  The hostess was so accommodating, being that my girlfriend and I showed up for our 8pm reservation, our table wasn't ready.  To ease anxiety, she offered us each a glass of champagne until they were ready to seat us.  For that alone, they get an additional star.  

I am a vegetarian, and there really wasn't much of a selection for me to choose from.  Luckily enough, the waiter told the chef and he made something for me "off menu".  It was good, vegetables, gnnocci, and the flavors were yummy.  I would totally go back there, i just wish they had a wider selection for us non-meat eaters.
author: Brenda H.

description:
I need to REALLY be in the mood to eat here. I love the food. It's delicious-o. I'm big chicken pot pie fan, and they sure have a great one.

Coming here, I feel like I'm going to a "fancy" restaurant that doesn't feel too fancy. They give off the persona of a sophisticated place but it feels homey. 

I had to take off a star because the service can be ridiculously slow. 2 hours for a business lunch, not cause there was a lot of "business" to talk about...but because it took forever to get any of our food. Was it worth the wait? I'd say so, but I'm just not a waiting type of person...especially when it comes to my food.
author: Jon C.

description: Salt House is the kind of restaurant you're only going to find in Manhattan, SF or maybe Chicago.  The focus is on the cuisine where it should be.  Even though the decor and staff are West Coast laid back, they didn't miss any of the finer points of dinner service.  My friends and I were all very please with our selections, from apps to entrees to dessert.  Only one miss out of our three desserts: a strawberry-rhubarb tart where the cake was kind of dried out.  But the server didn't miss a beat and took it off the bill, apologized and said she would let the pastry chef know.  Salt House wasn't as expensive as it could've been, given the quality of our meal.  I know some local foodies (my cousin among them) are over Salt House, but coming from the lowly DC dining scene, I was pleased.
author: Ryan W.

description: One of my new favorite restaurants in San Francisco! Their crispy shrimp salad appetizer is absolutely stunning. It contains Harissa, a rather unique Tunisian hot spice. I'll be bringing friends there tonight and will most certainly be ordering the shrimp salad again.
author: Paul S.

description: Had lunch with a friend here a month ago and forgot to review. We had the Dine About Town menu.  We had the poutine, sea bass and the tuna tartar salad. They kept refilling our bread basket with warm bread which made me full. I can never stay away from the bread basket! Also, the poutine's gravy was very filling so that put me over the edge. I enjoyed the meal and would come back. Kinda cramp space but what do you expect from SF.
author: Bj S.

description:
This restaurant is Amazing! perfect ambiance and the food is to die for. Exquisite!

we had:
oysters- usually I am not a fan but these were clean and wonderful
sashimi - love it!
scallops - royal
pork belly, chicken, sole..... all so goooood!
author: Lauren M.

description: Ahh yes, the kind of place I love to hate.  Been there three times and it's always felt loud and overcrowded even with a few tables left unused.  Expensive entrees, tiny portions, unimpressive service, and constant overrating by pretenders.  Don't let comparisons to Town Hall fool you, just head to Town Hall instead.
author: Gary D.

description:
I like Salt House, probably more than it rightly deserves. If you've ever had a friend who is somewhat of a terrible person, but you're really very fond of them anyway, that's kind of the feeling I have for Salt House.

It's been... on the surface kind of inconsistent. My first Manhattan there was perfect (yes, brandied cherry and all), but the poutine, which is why I came was... not poutine. Wedge fries and gorgonzola? Meh. Service was friendly at the communal table, as were all the people around us.

My second time, the Manhattan I received was almost undrinkable, but everything else I ordered was absolutely delicious. We sat at the bar this time--the place is always packed. My companion and I split an appetizer and an entree. The fois gras was delicious, as was our monkfish with veal cheek. (To the person complaining about this dish: You know what? You deserve what you have coming to you if you're ordering your meat well-done). They were nice enough to put the entree on two plates for us, without being asked. 

I'd be back a whole lot more, but the price, while not unreasonable, certainly doesn't put it into the "value" category.

UPDATE: I've been back several more times now, despite the sting on my wallet. On my last visit, service was especially stellar. Three people other than our waitress came by during the course of the evening to check on us, despite, once again, being packed. Coming from a string of really bad dining experiences, this was exactly what I needed to restore my faith in eating out.
author: Daniel K.

description:
My manfriend took me here for my birthday dinner and it turned out to be the perfect place for us to go to.  If I had a restaurant, this is what I would want it to look like.  We were sitting at a table on the second story that had only a few table so it was pretty small up there, and it was was partioned off by glass walls that only came up about four feet high allowing us to look down on the first floor.  There was an open kitchen downstairs and it was great to people-watch.

They served us water in their own little milk jar things that I wanted to steal but I was in heels and a dress so I had to keep it classy.  Our waitress was friendly when she interacted with us but wasn't bothersome and overly attentive.  One of the hostesses looked like Amy Winehouse.

And the food.  
Oh jeez the food.  
I love oysters and they had five different kinds on their menu, so we tried one of each.  I always forget that I hate Fanny Bay oysters.  That one oyster turned out to be the only thing I didn't like that night.  After the oysters, we shared the foie gras appetizer which consisted of a torchon with this pear chutney thing and a piece of seared foie with a blackberry sauce.  See, I don't really dig foie gras that much, it leaves this acrid taste in my mouth that I get when I fall down really hard, but this foie gras did it for me.  The accompanying sauces with both preparations were lovely, and somewhat of an inspiring culinary experience. 

And my entree?  
Oh goodness my entree.  
I had a dry aged rib-eye steak with a marrow crust, farro, salsify, and a short rib bordelaise (that had hunks of meat in it that were so tender they were falling apart).  First of all, I love rib-eye steaks, I love marrow, I had been looking to try some salsify, I never come across farro as often as I'dl ike, and sauce bordelaise is my favorite sauce.  When I saw this on the menu, I thought it would be a match made in heaven.  And it was.  

If I had the money, I would go to Salt House every week. 
I can't wait to try their sister restaurant, Town Hall.

And I swear to god, that hostess looked like Amy Winehouse.
author: jillian b.

description:
The $19 i spent on the foie appetizer might possibly be the best $19 I've ever spent.  They dont skimped either, so you're definitely getting your money's worth of liver. yummmm!! The chelsea gem oysters are amazing as well.

The food was pretty darn good (and both the lamb shank and halibut came with hearty portions), as was the service. My only complaint is that it is a loud ass restaurant.  Apparently, the bar is a happening place for after-work drinks so you do feel a bit crowded if you have the unfortunate pleasure of sitting nearby. 

I haven't lost my voice yet from having to shout my conversation but if i do, it was a small price to pay for such excellent cuisine.
author: Carol T.

description:
1 star: got my work to pay
1 star: got my work to pay

almost a star: the cool lampshades that look like they were stolen from a library card catalog.

minus three stars: where's the ?@?!! salt? at least i didn't pay for that overpriced shtick. sigh.
author: eliza w.

description:
still catching up on reviews....salt house is always jammed and feels busy from the moment you walk in.  the food is good, i wouldnt call it great.  a nice variety....i think the place wants to be a little more than what it can be.  i am a picky sob and good gets me back quite a few times.  the place is convenient, which drive most of the return visits.  its kind of a fun vibe....definitley some business dinners, but also plenty of friends and dates around you.  i dig stand up, high seat community table that parallels the bar.  its cramped, but you can squeeze on in and make some new very short term friends.   my first visit started with a blown wine tap (yes, they make those) and somehow red wine flew all over me....i didnt like the shirt anyway and they comped a good chunk of the meal despite how forgiving i was.  i tossed the shirt on my way out.....undershirts do come in handy.  

i'll go back....its easy, fairly reliable, cool atmosphere, new people like it more than regulars but the regulars are there....
author: Dustin S.

description:
Salt House was the first restaurant I went to after moving to SF from NYC.  Overall, average intro to the SF dining experience.  Good atmosphere and decent food but nothing too remarkable.  The food has lots of flavor but the portions are too small.  Every work lunch here has been followed up by a stop for a second lunch on the way back to the office.  I have been back a few times since my initial visit and have experienced much of the same. 

If you do find yourself here, I recommend giving the duck confit a try.
author: James M.

description: Amazing meal! Make sure you get the poutin and the foie for starters and I loved the Sole for dinner.. Beautiful space and great attitude with the staff. Amazing Amazing Amazing!!
author: Scott L.

description:
Very solid!  My coworkers and I went by for dinner one day after work, w/out reservations.  The friendly hostess ceded to our begging for a table, which was nice.

The food was pretty good - on par w/ Town Hall.  The oysters were fresh and tasty, the pork belly was my favorite.  My duck was well-prepared as well; yummy and just different enough w/ the huckleberry glaze.

I think the place used to be an old printing press or something - the space is long and narrow w/ exposed beams and brick - cozy, but classy.  

By the time we left the place was packed. Yes, a little loud if you're sitting by the exposed kitchen in the back, but I'll definitely make a return visit.
author: Mstar P.

description:
Been there multiple times - one of my favorite new mid-range restaurants.  

I've had most of the items on the menu: the Crispy Shrimp and the steak (probably one of the best prepared/bang-for-your-buck steaks I've had in SF) are fantastic.  

The poutine isn't true poutine, but a frou frou version.  When done well it can be quite good, though a bit of a gut buster.  The pork belly and the boudin blanc are very good, as are the baked oysters.  The foie gras torchon was probably one of the best I've had (I tend to prefer seared).

Desserts ARE hit or miss, regardless of Michael Bauer's "Rising Star Chef" accolade for the pastry chef.
author: Jesse H.

description:
There is something missing here, but I can't seem to figure out what it is...  The food was fine, though nothing spectacular.  As expected, the place looks like every new place in this city: generic, slick -- what is up with that?  The painting/drawing on the back wall is great, I will say.

My overall impression: fine, but I probably wouldn't rush to go back.

UPDATE:  I went back (no, I did not rush)  and had a very delicious meal, so I'm rethinking the review....
author: marie m.

description:
If I had been in a rush, or needed my lunch to take less than one hour, I would have given this place 2 stars. 
The wait staff was nice enough, but a bit slow. Sure there were 6 people in my group, but it doesn't take 20 minutes to figure out what we're going to eat off of their very limited menu. I made plenty of eye contact and all the standard body language that says I'M READY TO GET MY FOOD NOW!

I decided to get the lamb. I discovered that I don't like lamb. I don't know if it was the way they prepared it, but it was greasy and had an odd aftertaste.  Maybe it was just the guilt of eating a baby animal that was getting to me. 

The dessert was wonderful. 

2 hours for a lunch seems a tad too long for my liking.
author: Towanda S.

description:
Consistently delicious!  I've been several times for lunch and for a lite dinner last night for my first time.  The food, service, and atmosphere is great.  I went with a friend and ordered several small plates including the crunchy shrimp and green beans, heirloom tomato salad, and the scallops.  Our server spaced everything out very nicely.  

Just to note that the noise levels do tend to get pretty high during peak dinner and not a lot of sound absorption.  Around 10:00 the sound levels came to a very pleasant level.

Good for a late date.  I'd go again!
author: Chris C.

description:
This place exceeded my expectations! I went in thinking that the food may just be okay. To my surprise every single dish we ordered was pretty darn good, especially the sole!! 
Its a nice, cozy place in SOMA to meet friends for dinner. Definitely want to venture out again to try their dessert menu :)
author: sandhya ..

description: It's ok. Wait time is rather long.. and burger was missing the nice char I love...
author: Y. Abigail H.

description: Good food, fun atmosphere, bartenders could use an attitude change.
author: Ken G.

description: We're new to the area and the in-laws wanted to treat us to a nice dinner. He had heard about this place from a friend who said we had to try the poutine fries. He was right and they were amazing. When I first saw the menu I was afraid it was too limited for me but the poutine fries and the glazed wings appetizers were amazing. The wings are as far from your average wing joint as they can be but are succulent and well flavored.  My ribeye steak was very good and had a great sauce on it and desert to was an amazing chocolate mouse cake. I really enjoyed the atmosphere of the place as well. The building is from the 1940s and has a lot of character. We ended up sitting in the loft which I enjoyed since it was out of the way and a little more quiet. I give props to the servers who have to walk up and down the stairs. I would also like to through in that the hostesses and waitresses were all very cute.
author: Brad C.

description: Cool, trendy atmosphere... celebrated my birthday here a few years back... Food was tasty but as common with many restaurants, the portion size is more like a teaser.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Went on a Sunday night. The place was just full, but not packed. Service was absolutely perfect. Just the right amount of attention from all the staff. Our drink glasses were never dry and every waitperson from our server to the managers had a smile for us. 

Drinks, appetizers and mains all came in reasonable time. Our fois gras was quite good and realy generous with the portions. Very nicely done. We both ordered steaks with the marrow crust. They were cooked to perfection and the marrow crust was rich, salty and delicious. My dinner companion wasn't crazy about the rock shrimp appetizer in that it was overly spicy. 

The house blended wines were a great value and surprisingly good.

We are definitely going back for more.
author: Richard F.

description: It's fun, the room is cool, and the service and wine are great.  It's pricey but not much more than anything else around here.. it's not like we're in Waco.  The quality makes up for it.
author: Jack M.

description:
I really don't have much to complain about after my visit to Salt House.  I loved the urban loft-style atmosphere, but like Town Hall the noise level was way too high.  I hate screaming while trying to enjoy a meal.

To start, I had the duck salad with grapefruit.  I loved this salad.  I almost wished I had ordered 3 of them for my lunch, and I am honestly not big on eating salad for my entire meal.  My main course was the petrale sole.  The fish seemed like it was perfectly cooked--lightly browned on the outside and very moist on the inside.  For dessert, I had the pot-de-creme with cocoa nibs.  It was an intoxicating dessert!  Absolute chocolatey, velvety luciousness.

I would most definitely recommend Salt House, but not for a business lunch.

Also, I don't like salty food, so I was pleasantly surprised that the name of the restaurant is not a reflection of the food.  In case you were wondering too....
author: Kandi K.

description: Great seafood, very cool ambiance. A great place to meet up after work for some good food and drink if you work in the FiDi.
author: Clay M.

description:
First off, I am a huge fan of Town Hall so had a lot of expectations before heading into a Sunday night dinner at Salt House.

The ambiance and decor of the restaurant are good.  It's advertised as an urban tavern and by the looks of it, the designer did a good job of catching that exact effect.  It's much more casual than a restaurant but has a modern feel with it's distinctive touches throughout the space.

The service at Salt House is excellent.  From entering to exiting, we were greeted and frequently checked upon.  As for food, it's hit or miss.  I highly NOT recommend the monkfish.  It was not thoroughly cooked through and left a bad taste in my mouth.  After I finished my entree, I observed the table of 6 next to us, 4 of whom had ordered the monkfish.  Bon appetite!

Otherwise, the beet appetizer, olives and my companion's steak entree were above average.  The food is good, but nothing to write home about, folks.  The menu's entrees tends to be overpriced.  Might as well just go to Town Hall at those prices.

This place is worth trying out.  Just don't order the monkfish.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I was visiting my friend Eric in SF a month ago, and he took me to The Salt House.  The hostess was quite tatooed and I told him to get her number.  Our starter drinks were not so good...look at his review of the Salty Dog and...min ewas something with the name "widow" in it..totally nasty - too much campari.
Cool Vibe, great heirloom tomato salad.  We both had fish and a pint of ice cream for dinner.  It was OUT OF PROPORTION!.  But very tasty - vanilla bean i think...

I'd go back!
author: Katie M.

description:
Mmm....love the flavors

I have been to the Salt House twice and have not been disappointed.  The first time may or may not have been highly influenced by the enjoyable date I was on, but the second reaffirmed that I like this place a lot and since it is the second closest restaurant to my current office- i will likely be back to say goodbye to my hard earned money.  The interior is ala New York or SOMA loft apartment which gives it a little edge.   The service was great- attentive, but not in your face even though it seems like this place is packed all of the time

Drinks- the fresh mint lemonade at lunch was very much to my liking- not too sweet like most lemonades.  They served me two strong sapphire and tonics which was great after a long day at work.

Starters- Butternut squash soup with creme fraiche was good and the crispy shrimp with serrano ham and spicy green beans was even better.  I'm not the biggest fried food fan- but the batter on the shrimp was light and nicely complimented the shrimp.

Mains- the most recent was a sole with butternut squash puree,butternut squash and  brussel sprouts (I hated these as a kid but love to find them in dishes when i go out now)- this was delicious!  I may have to go back if they still have this on the menu.

Desserts- Apple turnover with rum raisin ice cream: ice cream was quite good, turnover was average.  I had been told this was better than the pear tart- so I'm not sure what that says about the tart.... Also tried the chocolate semifreddo- decadence at it's best- you will not finish this if you have eaten anything else here, but you will want to.

Four stars because I think it has the potential to wow me even more:-)
author: Maria F.

description:
I ate dinner here with my business partner who, like myself, is a serious foodie and cook.

We loved our meal. Amazing and complex dishes, prepared perfectly with a range of techniques and flavors and highly seasonal ingredients. Overall one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco, very tasty, and priced quite fairly for the quality. 

For the two of us, without any wine (I had to work and he was still on East Coast time) our dinner came to $98 before tip. We each had an appetizer, entree, and coffee.

My appetizer was the day scallops, two large, perfectly cooked and seasoned scallops over a great sauce and vegetables, for my entree I had the Pekin Duck which was a perfectly balanced and flavorful plate of two preparations of duck over vegetables and fruits. Great flavors with every bite. 

My business partner had the Yellowtail for his appetizer and the prime skirt steak for his entree. The skirt steak was served over short ribs and a mushroom preparation along with lots of seasonal vegetables. A dish which he was greatly inspired by and will be attempting to make himself at home (did I mention he's a very, very serious and talented chef).

The space is upscale, open, and attracts a professional crowd. We ate there on a Tuesday night and while we were able to get a reservation at short notice the restaurant filled up quickly though our service was excellent and the food was great.

(and though my neighbor did spill wine on me that had no negative impact on my meal or experience and everyone handled the accident with great attention).

I will be back and will recommend the Salt House to many people for a range of occasions. This is serious, great food done well and priced quite fairly. (not cheaply but for the quality quite reasonable).
author: Shannon C.

description: They were really on point.  Everything I had was awesome and perfectly done.  I'm starting to think the chefs of SF need to teach the world how to cook vegetables.  It would single handily reduce obesity in West Virginia if people tried the food.  The salad I had was divine with a perfect dressing/green veggie balence.
author: Justin T.

description: I had dinner here for a friend's birthday and absolutely loved everything about this place.  The ambiance, the food, the wait staff.  I woud definitely go back in a heart beat! This is a place if you want to splurge for dinner and drinks, but it's so worth it.
author: Pam M.

description:
Went to Salt House last night and since Town Hall is one of my favorites I was looking forward to it. 

Overall the food is good, cooked well and presented correctly. I guess that was the problem there was very little invention and I have had and seen pretty much all the dishes somewhere else. I agree with an earlier reviewer that this menu is still trying to figure out what it wants to be when it grows up.

By far the biggest disapointment was the service. For starters, and this is a pet peeve of mine, don't put the tables so close together. I know that a restaurant is there to make money but feeling like I am sitting on my neighbours lap and hearing way too much of their conversation does not make for a good time. Please remove one or two tables and spread everyone out a bit. Secondly Salthouse is an upper priced restaurant, agreed it is not a Coi but you are paying a decent amount for a meal, so I do not expect to be rushed. I do expect to see water glasses refilled, a smiling wait staff and genuine interest in my experience at the restaurant, I mean this is basic stuff. 

So to wrap up I really do feel that if this restaurant improved on the atmoshpere and service it would be a good place and until this happens I will not be going back, there are far better choices in the price range.
author: Alex H.

description:
I like this place, it has the feel of a 'special' bistro.  Not knock down, drag out, but a notch above the fray.  The food is PRETTY good, they do a respectable job of it.  I love the Fulton chicken.
The service suffers from too many people involved.  Last time I went, it was just me and another person.  Seated by someone, drinks by another, food order taken by another, each course brought by someone new, no one checked after main was delivered, and then magically the check brought by the original smiling waiter.  All really nice people, but a little one on one attention is a good thing.  It's not exactly a cheap place.
author: Matthew G.

description:
The price must reflect the pennies per calorie.  The poutin: $11 of AMAZING.  Don't believe me?  let me re-direct you to this video of my boyfriend, standing in the kitchen, nibbling at my left-overs like a PMSing teenager, hand over fist, both hands engaged in stuffing his face.  Ah, well, I don't really have that video.  He wouldn't let me take it.  But it's about the saddest, weepist movie thing you've ever seen.  Like that scene in Sex and the City when Carrie and the Red-Head were spending New Years together, man-less, eating chinese food.  The pity that only a woman can feel for another woman because they've been to the depths of despair.  Yeah.  Don't tell him I said that.

The other thing that makes me want to cry is the foie gras.  I'm saving up my pennies and spluring in this after finals I think.  It's $20.  So it had better make my taste buds stand up and sing.  

Will keep you posted.

BTW, I like sitting in the window, tucked behind the stairs, watching the lonely, wandering, properly dressed businessmen wander by, trying to find an acceptable happy hour where they can imbibe the day's toil's away and possibly hit on some eager new assistant.  LOVE IT.  I thought it was all a stereotype, like I was being too cynical, like it was all a cliche.  But there I was, on Thursday evening, right at 5:30, and it was like a scene out of a movie.  I love this city.
author: Christina C.

description:
I met a friend at Salt House last night for dinner and drinks in high hopes that it would be everything and more on what past 'Salt House' visitors have remarked on the restaurant, and also thought I'd give it a try since I go to law school right in the area. We tried the house chardonnay, the polenta as well as the scallops w/o chorizo, being that one of us was a pescatarian and the other gluten-free. We found the food to  be incredibly delicious but also relatively over-priced taking the SOMA area into consideration ( a glass of the house chardonnay was $14). 

The passive-aggressive service was what began to slowly deteriorate our views on Salt House. Right after we ordered our selections, the waitress responded by informing us that the amount of food we ordered was definitely not very much ( I suppose implicitly implying that we should order more food to vamp up our check?!?) I've never worked in a hospitality food service area, but what I do know, is that a server should definitely not impose such inappropriate comments on the guests. Before we were even done eating, they began to clear our table, at which point we had to tell them that we weren't done yet. I wonder if they ever heard of 'asking if we were finished prior to assuming and clearing the dishes'..astonishing)

The food was pretty good, but the service left a very bitter taste in our mouths. I'm definitely not returning to Salt House at any point in the near or far future.
author: Amy L.

description: I believe I may have come here with expectations that were a little too high, but I will admit while Salt House did not meet them all, they still served an admirable meal. I had always enviously eyed the bread at salt house on my way to the food trucks, but had never venture in.  Finally today, because of the dine about town menu, a couple of coworkers and I gave it a try. For about $18 we each were given a small cup of corn puree soup, and a choice of either duck or seafood. The corn soup was great albeit a little sweet, but all in all a good dish. I was able to try a bit of both of the entrees and I was very pleased by the duck, and a bit underwhelmed with the seafood. As far as entrees go the duck was more than enough food and had amazing flavor, the seafood on the other hand was a very small portion that was more akin to a tasting plate or individual appetizer. Likewise the flavors in the seafood for some reason did not quite do it for me, as a lover of all food ocean related I felt like it was most definitely missing something. All in all I think I'll have to come back to try some of the more interesting items on their normal menu, but on this particular outing I was hoping for more.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I think this place would be perfect for a metrosexual squirrel.  Great modern decor, good martinis and a mixed nut appetizer to die for...  For us people however, this place is below average.  The wait is horrendous (it took us almost 90 minutes to get our food after we were seated) and the food was uninspired (not to mention overcooked).

One star for the really cute girls sitting at the table across from us...it made the wait "almost' bearable. Another for the nice hostess, bartender and the excellent hendricks martini.
author: D S.

description:
I'm not sure why I can't figure out how to give a place a 1/2 a star.  So, my 2 stars really mean 1 1/2 stars (and I am still on the fence about even that).

To start, it's loud....or my table was full of quiet talkers.  Don't go here if you are a spy and need to whisper secrets or sweet nothings in someone's ear.

The mixed nuts were mmm-mmm good, and so were the marinated olives.  However, the yellow fin tuna melt sandwich was soooo saturated with butter, one little crumb stained my dress as it slid off my lap (as a matter of fact, it was so oily, I just scraped the tuna off the bread, and left hungry).

The service is tremendously slow (although maybe our server was just being coy) except when it was time to pay the check...and then I barely had time to get my credit card out of my wallet.  

If you need to go to the restroom take a flashlight or night vision goggles (or wear something less...complicated) because not only are the walls painted black, there seems to be only a jar of fire flies above the sink.  (What do you do at night?)

The uneven knotted pine floors make it difficult to maneuver in heels, and ladies, it's a loooong walk to the bathroom (so keep your eyes on the floor or limit yourself to two glasses of wine).

They tried, but...
author: Laura P.

description: The place is spacious and beautiful. The food was wonderful. I came in for a business lunch and had the Moroccan spiced lamb shoulder. It was wonderful and very flavorful. Now, why 2 stars you ask? Well, need I repeat..it was a BUSINESS LUNCH meaning I had clients with me. So what was wrong? the SERVICE.  The last thing you need when you entertain clients is bad service at a good restaurant. The server we had was not attentive and very rushed. The place was not even busy...how can you be rushed? He forgot my drink order also. He didn't even check on us throughout our lunch.At the end, he kept us waiting forever for our bill. At a restaurant of this calibur, things need to be running and moving at a much more precise level. I finally had to get up and tell the hostess to to get him. Salt house has great food but get it TOGETHER GUYS!
author: Shaz D.

description:
For all the hype about this place, I was seriously let down.

The good stuff first:  The service was EXCELLENT!  YAY for them.  Awesome staff.  The Poutine was great.  That was some awesome pork gravy I had there with the fries and cheese.

The bad stuff: Their food, in general.  We ordered four appetizers to share with the table and they were fun.  We ended up waiting 45 minutes for our entrees.  We had a calamari and clam dish that tasted like school cafeteria food.  The meat dish was boring.  They did cook the farro well that the piece of meat sat on.

The GM apologized and comped our desserts because we waited so long.  Great!  Who can deny free dessert?  I was like, awesome, you guys rock.  Dessert came around and I couldn't finish it.  I had a Baked Alaska and it was so sugary sweet with a hint of the 70's, only a quarter of it was eaten.  Don't get me wrong, I usually never let dessert go to waste.  I will eat even the most mediocre Tiramisu.
