So, go for the service and the hype.  Don't stay for the food.  This is San Francisco, after all, you can get awesome food almost anywhere.
author: Lynn L.

description: The decor is inviting if a little claustrophobic (could they GET anymore tables in this place?) The food was overwrought with ingredients and they all seemed to be fighting for dominance.However,everything was fresh and the service excellent. I am not Canadian, so I don't crave poutine as comfort food - but saw a lot of people enjoying it. In a city with so many great restaurants I left feeling like I had just squandered a lot of time and money that might have been enjoyed more somewhere else. Only stand out was the nectarine and blackberry crunch dessert - fabulous.
author: Debbie N.

description:
The food is great, the service was terrible. After ordering a bottle of wine, oysters and apps - already $100+ in 5 minutes, she asked us to order our "mains." We said we weren't ready and she insisted that "our entrees take a really long time, i just want you to know that." 

Well, I've been there about 20 times and spent 1000s of dollars, i recommended it to friends, clients and coworkers - so yes, i know how long the food takes and please don't push me to hurry up and order, thank you very much!

It was horribly awkward and sucked the fun out of my (and my friends) evening. In the end we stayed for 2 hours - you can check the ticket - spent $300 all the while another 4-top table remained open the entire time - i took a picture of it. I am very sad by this, because the food is so good. This is the second time I've been rushed to order there, and another time they forgot about us at the bar while we were waiting for our table, so i don't think I'll make it back.
author: Brendan K.

description:
Today was my second visit and I must say I'm now officially a fan of the Salt House!  The decor is spot on and the food was also great the second time around.  So nice to see local business booming. Reservations are a must, even for lunch!!! The beet salad and cheeseburger were spot on today! Can't wait to try their hi/low version of the sloppy joe.

XO
JS
author: jerry s.

description: I'm sorry to say I was a little disappointed. My food (polenta with shaved cheese, chanterelles and other fresh veggies) was decent but not to die for. Mostly there were very few things on the menu that interested me. Could just be overall food prefs was the problem. The atmosphe was lively and clearly it was a popular place. Sitting in the window facing street was a bonus.
author: Lisa K.

description:
So we walk in and my friend gives his name and that we have a 9:30 reservation.  What I assume is the manager looks at the reservation book, asks his name again, looks confused, looks at the book again, mumbles something, looks around nervously, then is saved by the lovely tattooed hostess.  She immediately walks us to a table.  The manager broke the golden rule--Never Let Them See You Sweat.

We are greeted promptly by our server and order a round of drinks.  I order pickled vegetables for the table.  Our drinks come out promptly and I order for the table--we're sharing everything.

We started with the poutine and a glazed peach appetizer.  Both were yummy.  Beautifully presented and full of flavor.  As we were eating them I realized we never received our pickled veggies.  I decided we had enough food and let it slide.

We shared the Peking Duck, Sole, Gnocchi, and Chicken.  Each and every dish was spot on.  At first glance the plates looked like they didn't hold much food, but we were all satisfied.

At some point we ordered a second round of drinks.  I had ordered the Ginger Julep--a mint julep with ginger ale added--and it was really good so I ordered the second one.  I drink a lot of mint juleps and the variation was nice and balanced.  The second one-however-I almost sent back.  The server event noted that (in a joking voice with a bit of laughter) "You can tell the other bartender made this one, its a different color".  When you have a specialty cocktail on your menu you better make sure it is made the same by all your bartenders.  You expect that of each and every cook in the kitchen and I expect it from each and every bartender behind the bar.

Overall, the food was good.  The service was adequate but not special.  If I could give half starts it would be 3.5.  But since I can't I'm rounding up to 4 stars.
author: David H.

description:
3 stars based on vibe. I went with a friend visiting from nyc. he said "classic san francisco style" restaurant. and i suppose it is. it's that knack that we have for sophisticated meets casual. exposed brick. nice light. nice looking and feeling place.

however, the food didn't stand out. we had the yellowtail appetizer and a salad to start. they were both just ok. then our entrees came (which took a loooong time). i was very surprised at how small the plates were. my bass was on the small side, but just fine for the amount i'd generally eat anyway (i can never finish an entree), but i looked over at my friend's fish selection (i think it was trout) and it looked like a plate with two anchovies on it. i was surprised that our waitress could deliver it with a straight face and embarrassed, like i should be apologetic on behalf of the restaurant.  I had great dining companions, thank god, and the moment passed into animated conversation. Dessert was a nice change of pace and a nice ending to an otherwise very average meal. 

overall, you can still win my heart with a great environment, nice staff, and decent service. I wouldn't rush to recommend this place next time we're trying to find a place to go....but i wouldn't mind going again if someone else suggested it. probably not exactly what the owners had in mind.
author: heather m.

description:
I came back for dinner the other night and I'm upping my stars from 3 to 4.  We shared the roasted beets, the crispy egg and the grilled calamari appetizers.  All were really tasty and flavorful.  I particularly liked the pork belly bits that came with the crispy egg appetizer (a soft-boiled egg with fried bread crumbs on the outside).  Very inventive.

I ordered the halibut for my entree, which came with asparagus flavored with pork.  While not astounding (halibut just isn't that kind of dish that you get wowed by), I did enjoy the textures and the flavors of the dish.  I sampled the other entrees: the steak with shortribs was awesome, the scallops were extremely tasty and the tuna was also good.  

We ordered the trifle and the chocolate cake for dessert.  I could eat the trifle every day -- luscious layers of custard, cake, fruit and whipped cream.  Really fantastic.
--------------
Lunch review: good crab salad and duck confit.  Lots of choices.  SLOOOOOWWWW service.  Cool atmosphere, pricey menu.
author: Mitzi C.

description:
I had an overall enjoyable lunch here, but I don't feel the need to go back anytime soon. I liked the ambiance (feels just like Town Hall of course) and the light fixtures that look like giant index card holders are very cool. 

The bread was great, so I found myself eating too much of it even before my salad came out. The petrale sole was prepared nicely, and I polished it off quickly. 

It's a little hard to carry on a conversation, as the restaurant is basically one giant room with poor acoustics.
author: lindsay w.

description: The food is simple, presented well, and very good.  The service is INCREDIBLY slow, and I hate to nit pick, but especially when I'm waiting long periods for food, a little bread would have been appreciated.  Way overpriced and I wouldn't return unless it was for convenience.
author: Danielle B.

description:
amazing foie gras appetizer!  this appetizer comes with foie gras two ways (cured and sauteed) and tea smoked duck.  the sauteed foie gras is paired with kumquat and brioche which brought out a lot of the flavor even though it was simple.  the cured foie gras came with pear and quince.  the quince tasted like a sweet apple chutney sauce where this part of the dish was better without it.

i love the ambiance of salt house, and would definitely recommend this place, but be sure to make reservations in advance!
author: Carli F.

description: I don't know what their normal menu is like because I went for Dine about town lunch and had the duck rillette and chicken salad. It was really terrible. The rillette was forgettable and paired with candied orange peel AND pickled vegetables. (what?) My friend and I both could not eat the main course (and my friend is a hungry pregnant lady) I took both portions home for my husband because I thought on some off chance he might like it, but he couldn't eat it either. It was really terrible and at $18 a rip-off. If they are not going to take DAT seriously and use it to show themselves off to people who might want to dip a toe in before committing to spend $$$$, then they should not participate. It is truly a disservice to their own establishment AND to the customer who picked this place out of the many options available.
author: mazzy s.

description:
While they couldn't find our reservation, they did seat us after a few minutes - even with a full house. Much appreciated.

The parsnip soup was sweet and very delicate - not your typical parsnip. I wish i could remember what I ate next, but who knows? I do remember the short rib entree. Delicious and a bit unusual. I think there was some type of mushroom, perhaps morel, crust - light and airy. And the healthy rib meat was served over a bed of corn - in the middle of winter! Corn, I say. But it was damn good.
author: A. P.

description:
I want to love Salt House, I really do. I love Town Hall, and this is from the same owners, so you would think it would be easy for Salt House to gain my affection.  Alas, only three stars from me.

Designwise, Salt House is great -- an urban feel that you might expect in Soho or Tribeca. But, the restaurant's kind of like Jessica Simpson -- beautiful, but not entirely there...

Good
1) Burger (lunch only)
2) Poutine (highbrow chili cheese fries)
3) Mixed nuts with honey and truffle oil

Not as good
1) Spotty service (and the restaurant wasn't packed)
2) Could have more wines by the glass on the wine list
3) Hanger Steak and the potatoes served with them didn't have much flavor
author: Gary B.

description:
Nice ambience, good drinks.
I really enjoy the experience
at the salt house restaurant
and my fever dish, was an appetizer
made of a mix of peanuts deep fried
with salt and spices....that made my day
author: Alex M.

description:
The atmosphere is relaxed with a modern/ranchesq feel to it. It's not your typical restaurant decor that's for sure. 

The food was good, it didn't blow my mind. Especially for the price. The house wine blends were terrible. DO NOT ORDER the cab/syrah/something. I've never made such an ugly face sitting in public at the dinner table in such a nice restaurant. But I made it twice. I ordered the Moscato asti' Nivole in which I made an even fuglier face since that tasted like rubbing alcohol. Terrible. Take them off the menu. 

The waitress/bartender were cool, they didn't charge us for the rubbing alcohol and brought us some other dessert wines that we 'thought' we had ordered. 

Overall, I would have to go back to here since it seems that they're not very consistent and for what you're paying, it should be.
author: melissa g.

description:
A very special lady brought me to this SOMA eatery, and I was surprised by the larger than expected portions. We weren't able to make it to desert, considering the app and main gave us quite a robust meal...

I got the crispy shrimp as well as the fulton valley chicken. As previously mentioned, the portions were larger than I was anticipating, but the food wasn't mind blowing. I think if you want to impress someone with some great decor and drinks, this place would be a good one for the neighborhood. But I'd have to take a star or two off for the food, which was a tad on the pricey side.
author: Andy A.

description:
Hmmmm, where to start? This is typical SOMA restaurant decor...ceiling beams visible with a pretty industrial yet upscale look.

You start off with some good bread that is placed on a piece of butcher paper & a jar of water that has some cool looking skull logo on it with SH (Salt House).

Our waitress was friendly and the atmosphere was not too loud and very pleasant...many people seemed to be on business lunches (I definitely would have used my company's credit card if I had one!).

I ordered the petra sole, which was served with spelt (a grain), corn and some fava beans. My dish was DELICIOUS!

I will definitely go back...preferably on someone else's tab!
author: Elaine S.

description:
One of the best meals of my life. 

Hands down.

Place was packed, but we managed to get a seat at the bar. 

Wine was incredible!!!! Service impeccable!!! We ate for HOURS!

Wish the owner could open a spot down here in LA!!
author: amie a.

description: Showed up without a reservation at the Salt House on a busy night, but they worked to get my friend and me in.  Staff is very friendly and helpful with wine and food selections.  We split two appetizers and a main course, which was more than enough, especially since one of the appetizers was their signature: Poutine.  This is a completely decadent bowl of chunky fries smothered in cheese sauce and short rib gravy.  I was hoping I'd hate it, or at least just be satisfied with a few bites.  But it was so tasty - worth every calorie, and yes, we finished the bowl. The other appetizer was their signature shrimp and green beans, and we had a very nice fish for dinner.  But really, it's the fries that I remember.  One downer - the rest room is shared with a night club, and it is not well cleaned.  Overall, though, it's a fun, bustling spot with well prepared food, and worth a try!
author: Sarah F.

description: Flawless food. Would give five stars if it wasn't quite so pricey. I had halibut which was prepared perfectly with a side of asparagus which was also delectable with a little dollop of strawberry puree and smokey cheese. The combined flavors were wonderful and not the least bit fussy. I blindly picked a white wine off the "by glass" list and enjoyed it more than any white in a long time. I shared the german chocolate cake which left me satisfied but not weighed down. Cappucino was sized just right for after dinner. Service was attentive even though I sat upstairs - two servers asked me within 2 minutes of finishing my wine if I wanted another glass. (I stopped at one glass though.) There is a carafe of water at the table which makes it easy to pour more water when you need it. I would come here more often if it wasn't for the price tag - we spent just under $200 for 2 people, all in. I'll definitely be back when I want a reliable fix of excellent, excellent food.
author: S E.

description: Three stars for the food and one for service. All I can say is the Poutine kicked ass and the service sucked it! Yes, I know it was lunch hour but when I have to ask to be seated, ask for a menu and then ask for my check that's a bit much. If you've seated me I obviously want a menu and if I've ordered from the menu and devoured the food, I must be ready for the check! You'd think sitting at the bar would give you faster service not the case.
author: Leanne S.

description:
Bar - got there about 20mins early and grabbed a couple of seats at the bar for a cocktail.  Just as we ordered a drink the hostess let us know that we could be seated if we wanted.  We held off so that we could finish our drinks first.  She was very accommodating.

Gabriel the bartender was great.  Great conversationalst. Mixed us a couple of very tasty cocktails.  Would go back just to have more.

Dinner started off on a high note.  I had oysters which were extremely fresh and tasty.  Husband had the crab salad.   It was tasty although a bit salty.  We were both starved already so those two items along with the bread didn't last long.

Here is where the breakdown occured.  I was having a ball chatting and taking in the crowd.  Very lively, everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves.  Then Husband said, "I wonder where our food is?".  I hadn't realized we had been waiting a long time between first and second courses.  Then I peer around and pay more attention.  It looked like the kitchen was backed up.  Others around us were also showing signs of food depravation.  

Finally, entrees arrive.  We were already done with our wine and bottle of water.  Major buzz working due to lack of food and a whole bottle of wine.

Food was gone in a few minutes.  Nice flavors, a bit too much going on with the rib-eye but it was good.

While the overall experience was good, I may need to come back again and give it another try before I give it highers stars.  I hate to write off restaurants based solely on a slow kitchen on a Saturday night.  If that happens consistently then it would be a problem.
author: Rick G.

description:
You know, going out at nite to all different lounges could be very beneficial at times. I pass by this place as I was going to 111 Minna lounge and It looked pretty cool on the outside so I wrote a mental note to myself that I will try this restaurant out sometimes in the future. And that is exactly what I did for my cousin's 21st birthday dinner :) 

First of all, the waitress is super friendly and she was very patient and helpful at the same time. Besides the atmosphere and good food...I love friendly helpful waiter n waitresses. Second of all, this place has a full bar option! so it was not only Wine or specialty cocktails but a FULL BAR!! hahhahahhaha...gotta love having that option in nice restaurants. I had the grey goose and pineapple juice combo and my cousin had the tequila sunrise. It was really good!! I think I finished that drink before the appetizer came out! LOL! Third, the food was pretty good. I mean it was on the small side but hey birthday dinner! can't complain cuz its free! hahhahhahhahha...when the waiter brought out my steak I thought it was chocolate dessert for another table! hahhahhahha...then I realized it was my small steak! me n my cousin were planning to share cuz she had the salmon...but the salmon was small too! so I told her "girl...sorry I cant share. Its not even enough for me! I'm sure u understand me..." The chicken and halibut was really good as well. 

Last but not least, they told us that there would be a cake cutting fee for $5 per person cuz we brought the birthday cake to the restaurant. But when the bill came, they never charged us for that cake fee! they were really nice..so we gave them a big fat tip! ohh before I forgot, we had the famous fries with cheese and gravy plus the fried shrimp appetizers...they were really good! Even though I ate again after I went home cuz I was still hungry...this place is def one of the MUST TRY restaurant in SF :)
author: Rika K.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner at salt house last week. The yelps were luke-warm on this spot, but I had heard good things, I love Town Hall, and it has a more seafood based menu than Town Hall, so I thought I'd give it a shot.

I was not disappointed. In fact, I was presently surprised how much I enjoyed it. The had a very nice wine list and we had some great appetizers before our main course (the poutine - aka french fries with cheesy gravy goodness; crispy honey shrimp on a bed of spicy kale and green beans; winter salad with pears and parmesan). I had steak for dinner, also delicious, but the potatoes were a little strange that were served with it. Dessert with less exciting admittedly, but go for the food and the fabulous ambiance!
author: Jenica M.

description:
In the trifecta of businesses (Town Hall, Salt House and Anchor and Hope), owned by the trio of Washington and the duo-Rosenthals, Salt House would only Place or Show.  The clear winner is still the first and best - Town Hall. Although the sketchy slow service and abominable noise levels caused by overcrowding at Town Hall are some of the worst in the city, the food there is by far the best of the three. 

As an aside rant... If you have already finished your dessert and you have already paid or the check has been on the table for longer than 5 minutes, you need to get your sorry ass up and leave the restaurant. I don't care if you are having the time of your life and you just dropped $100 a person on dinner. That doesn't give you the right to hangout for an extra hour squatting on your table while other people are waiting to dine. Take your party elsewhere. If you don't get that point, you are either an ignorant foodie wannabe or an asshole.  Trust me, there are plenty of both of those types in SF. 

To me, where Salt House shines is in ambiance and service. A unique bar setting, subtle skull-crossbones, beautifully-inked hostess and dark and disturbing artwork on the back wall gave the place a bit of an edge. Our waitress, a stunning 'Catherine Zeta-Jones look-a-like' was on point all evening. She was the perfect combination of charmingly engaging attentiveness, without hovering or making us feel harried at the end of the meal, as the restaurant became crowded. With a gorgeous intelligent server like that, it is hard not to be one of those bozos who hits on the waitress, thinking he is charming, without realizing he is really just being a douchebag.

Our appetizers consisted of the foie gras/tea duck and crispy shrimp. The sauteed foie gras and accompanying torchon were phenomenal. With the apricot reduction pairing giving the perfect accompaniment of sweet/tart to offset the fattiness of the liver. I would have to wonder whether Blenheims or Candycots would be even better in this combination? The tea duck was nothing special and needed a few pieces of crispy duck skin for texture. With the crispy shrimp, I kept thinking they should have reversed the preparation and batter fried the green beans with toasted almond slivers and done a sautéed shrimp-style dipping sauce. 

The main courses were the Steak, Pork Loin and the Halibut.  While the fish was cooked perfectly, the other meats were not. The steak, requested med-well came back med-rare and the pork loin requested med-rare arrived med-well. I don't know how many times I have harped on this point, but the cook level of meat changes not only texture but taste, creating a different dining experience than intended. This is a point I can't seem to emphasize enough!  The sides were executed better than the meats with the bed of stuffing under the pork loin being near perfect (tad too much salt), but hey it is the Salt House. 

Food presentation excelled, but preparation did not. The style is there, the substance needs a little work. All in all the price point was a tad high for the overall food quality, (especially if you factor in drinks/dessert and local competition from Boulevard). Also the outside bathrooms were a negative, but the edgy upscale urban loft ambiance and excellent service make Salt House worth a visit.
author: Dave H.

description:
We went here for a late valentines day dinner.  It was the perfect low key place that still had enough going on on a tuesday night to keep me interested.  I wil definitely go back here, probably better for a "friend night".

Menu:
Franziskaner
Poutine
Crispy Shrimp
Steak
Sole


The poutine was by far my favorite.  I had this once in Montreal and loved it.  SO good.  Fries, yes please.  Cheese, yep.  Short rib gravy?  Ummm, why not.  The crispy shrimp was perfectly done.  My steak was alright.  For 30 bucks I could have gotten something way better at Bobo's or another steak house.  Keith got the Sole, and the only reason I mention it is because it had some amazing Celery Root Puree under it.  I could probably drink it with a straw, it was amazing.  Almost like butter.

We passed on dessert, nothing seemed like a must have. Our waitress was super cute and friendly and answered all 60 of our questions about the menu and wine list.  I would love to go back here for some oysters!
author: jessica b.

description: I didn't know much about Salt House before I was invited to go with friends, but I'm glad I went.  This wasn't an amazing, mind-blowing meal, but I walked out very pleased to have found a great place to eat well prepared food and drink good wine.
author: Russ S.

description: I didn't think that I was going to be a fan of Salt House because I had heard so many great things that I didn't think it would live up to its reputation but it definitely did.  We ended up sitting upstairs which didn't sound as fun as downstairs but was lively nonetheless.  The decor was great and reminded me of Nopa.  The food was really good as well and I would have to recommend the potatoes (french fries) appetizer as that set the whole meal off to a good start.
author: Blake B.

description:
Great for a stop in or if stranded in the tip of SOMA without other options. 

Drinks here are dazzling and surprising... although it might make the menu look a bit nice had they charged us in £uros. 

Ice cream = whiskey manhattan island? err delicious. be prepared to order many an appetizer so I suggest eating before you come here :-P // Unless you are ready to trade 1/12 of your rent for a hearty/tasty meal...

That being said the crispy shrimp is a good bet and the crisp fries could have been something to remember. The environment is wonderful and if you want to shift from shiek rustica moderna to even more lodge style chilling go to bloodhound after! And please take a cab :-D
author: William J.

description: This is pretty good place.  The drinks are delicious but unfortunately not that strong.  I had the chicken and two my friends had the steak (sooooo good!).  I loved the poutine and it's definitely worth getting although it's not 100 percent authentic.
author: Thea B.

description: Barely OK. I've definitely had better. 30 min wait for a burger when the place is dead is way too long, and i didn't get the curly fries or or a reason why they were unavailable.
author: Serge N.

description:
Had lunch here -- poutine (with beef sauce) is great with crisp potatoes but need salt and pepper.  Main entrees Crispy edge Tai Snapper and Steak sandwich are both good. Service is slow so plan on spending at least an hour and a half lunch there (no wonder how difficult it is to reserve a table there...)

By chance next table patrons were doing champagne pairing for their NYE party (brought their own bubbly drinks) to decide which to get and shared their bottle with us! What was the chance of that?! :)

This is a great business lunch place-- simple, bright light, high ceiling, and no unnecessary decorations.

Update on Dec 14, 2007: the restaurant built a loft during the Summer and opened up the area by the window to accommodate more patrons. Came here without reservations at noon-ish and we were being seated at a table (not communal!) immediately! Totally impressed! And this time I had the Moroccan Chicken salad which was excellent!
author: T L.

description: Salt House does live up to its name - my duck confit was quite salty (but nevertheless delicious).  I recommend the yellowfin tuna tartare to start, and wash things down with a signature drink (mint lemonade, anyone?).  Definitely skip dessert (selection was not to my liking, and they're not worth the calories)!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I worked down the street and would always see the comparatively small, modest sign proclaiming this place Salt House. My first reactions were a mix of  "Oh, that's kind of a cute name" to forgetting it was even there.

I went in for the first time waiting for a friend also looking for a light, shareable item and a glass or two of wine. I was into the service, food and drink in this street corner gem, and I may come back if feeling a little spendy but not too celebratory. The much-discussed Poutine (crispy potato, short rib gravy and cheddar) is pretty damned good, but, duh, given those ingredients.
author: Tara R.

description: Great selection of oysters. The poached egg was wonderful. aaaaand so was the Poutin, obviously. Good cocktails.
author: Tom W.

description:
This is more of a 2.5 stars.  The food was outstanding, the design and decor are impressive, but the service and bathrooms put a damper on the experience.  The hostess gave us attitude because we showed up with an extra person (granted, not ideal), the meal took almost three hours (so long that they comped our desserts), they plated 3 out of 5 mains and then the other 2 didn't show up for 10 minutes, plus the bathrooms are shared with Harlot, so by around 10:30 the floors were sticky and toilets were gross.  Dinner cost about $50 each including tip (not including dessert) which I thought was reasonable until I noticed that they charged us $3 for the bread.  That just seems wrong, particularly given the wait.  

That being said, it has a great menu (the Poutine was amazing, even if it's not really poutine - no cheese curds and far too pretty) and a decent wine selection.  The lavender ice cream was an interesting twist.  I hope they work out the service kinks.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I had been dying to check this place out for quite a while and suggested it for months during the usual "where should we go to eat," but wanted to save it for a special occasion. I brought my mom here on her recent visit and was truly disappointed. 

The service was slow and well below par. We ordered a few appetizers. The potatoes were soggy on arrival from the chili like sauce and had clearly been sitting under the heat lamp for far too long. I ordered a light fish for my main course and the flavor pairing was awful. It sounded interesting but ended up being a blindly thought out combination of curry, olives, squash, and almonds which overpowered the flavor of the fish. 

Things that were good were the pig appetizer and the steak we ordered. The warehouse design offered and unusual treat and the lighting was excellent as well. 

The crowd appeared to consist of overdressed tourists or business associates, mainly men. I wonder if the chefs tried to be too creative or lacked creativity at all. I do know they put a huge price tag on their food. I can't help but question if anyone dines here repeatedly? In a city with so many gems, this is not worth a stop.
author: Alicia J.

description: It all boils down to experience, and the experience I had here was awesome. The service was great, they were very on top of things. The ambiance was lively and fun, it was so buzzzzing! The food was awesome, from the bread to the shrimp app to the Thai Snapper entree. Wine bottles well priced. We didn't have time for dessert so that means I'll have to go back!
author: Jessica G.

description:
Great atmosphere with brick, big wood beams, steel, and high ceilings.  Cool funky mural art.  Cool old school lights hanging over the bar.

Awesome friendly service.  I think 10 guys and 1 girl server, which was fine for me actually..

The menu descriptions are overly minimalistic where they don't do the dishes justice.  

The "Fall Fruits" was actually caramelized apples and pears (I think) with frisee and chicories, pomegranate seeds, a mild bleu, and creamy vinaigrette.  Really a tasty salad. 

Not so hot on the pastrami ribs or brandade...  The pastrami ribs were interesting with apple chutney and wild arugula.  It's apparently brined then smoked, but it's a little too sweet where it tastes and textures like a hot-dog.  Bummer.  The brandade with lemon crumbs was more potato than cod, and definitely too salty to go with the uber-salty toasted crostinis.  Maybe intentional being the Salt House, harhar.

I think it'll be a fun bustling crowd whenever and a reliable social spot....
author: Melanie C.

description:
I can't say anything good about this place besides the ambience. 

Anything on the menu is over-priced for the quality presented. The pork belly was poorly paired with lentil and the foie gras torchon is the most diluted foie gras I have ever tasted.  The steak was as good as the TGIF' but I have to give them credit for the tasty cipollini  next to the steak. 

In the end, I found out why this place is not good... Apparently the owner also owns the over-rated Town Hall.
author: Fred F.

description: We showed up here as a group without a reservation during a conference. They were very accommodating and the food was fantastic. The ambience was unique. It was a bit pricey, but that doesn't surprise me for the City. I would recommend this place to friends.
author: Mena B.

description:
This place has no soul. We ordered a whole bunch of things; cocktails, shellfish platter, goat, tuna and desserts. Everything was eh. Decor was eh.

If you want what this place strives to be in it's dearest dreams, go to Flora's in Oakland.
author: Rachel G.

description:
The service is so bi-polar that there is no point to squeeze yourself into this busy restaurant.  While the hostess are super nice, comping some celebratory cocktails, the waitresses have serious attitude problems.  Our entrees took 50 minutes to get to us!  and the waitress did not seem to care at all.  She was actually rude to us.  

The food is not great enough to deal with that....they get and extra star just because that hostess was so nice.
author: Lesley H.

description: Great place to drink. Nice atmosphere, good service. Try Poutine with gravy.
author: Toshi K.

description:
A nice, good, original spot. I think it's decent for it's genre but not fabulous.

  I had wanted to visit the Salt House for months before the opportunity finally came my way. I took a client out to lunch and we SPLURGED. We ran that menu starting with specialty drinks and apps straight through to dessert. My mint lemonade was good but made me wish I had ordered a mojito. The fries were, of course, awesome and I even like the gravy which is out of character for me. For my entree I had a fish sandwich which was good but waaaay too big. I felt like I had wasted food as a fish sandwich doesn't exactly = tasty leftovers. We split a dessert which was berries and sorbet which was again good, but not memorable. 
   Salt house is worth a try and even a repeat visit, but on a scale of hole in the wall to The French Laundry it's a small step up from a chain restaurant.
author: chelsea b.

description:
this place is loud and crowded, but the food is simple and good.

one star knocked off cuz our waiter was kinda stupid and service was reallllly slow.

the raw oysters were very fresh
the fries with short ribs sauce was interesting (a good thing)
the scallops were cooked to perfection and so yummy i wanted more
the yellowfin tuna was good but nothing super special
the foie gras 2 ways. seared and pate w/ a brioche....very good
the star of the place was the duck-excellent

dessert-some chocolate thing that was ok cuz i don't remember it.
author: Karen H.

description:
LOUD.

Service was polite but impersonal.  Never got her name, she didn't care to know who we were.  

Food was decent.  (Shrimp/Green Beans app was the best of the 7 dishes.)

LOUD.

Wine list was strange.  No cocktail menu.  

Mixed salad with croutons was mostly frisee (the non-lettuce) and ONE crouton.  

Apple/rhubarb dessert was great.  Oats were perfect on top.

Overall,  IT WAS SO LOUD I COULD BARELY HEAR MY HUSBAND!!

The kitchen looked like a fun place to work, though.
author: Plaid B.

description:
I went here one week after this place opened because it is two blocks from my house. My fiance and I actually stumbled across it while walking home from happy hour. Since we were only able to secure a 10pm reservation, we were STARVING.

The restaurant itself is cute but I was annoyed that the hostess ignored us for a few minutes in favor of chatting with her friends. But once she acknowledged us, we were promptly seated so I was willing to overlook this.

The food was good but I do have some complaints. First, the soup was scalding hot. McDonald's-boiling-coffee-hot. Second, the coffee I ordered with dessert didn't come until AFTER we finished dessert and it was also scalding hot. The kicker was that the cream they brought for my coffee was (any guesses?) HOT. When I poured it into my coffee, it started to curdle! GROSS!!!

Then we were ignored by our waitress when it came time for the check. We had a two hour dinner and not by choice.

I would give this place a second chance because they were so new when we went there. Maybe they just have to iron out the wrinkles. 

If my cream comes boiling hot again though--this place is decidely a stinker.
author: Cindy P.

description:
The cobb salad was one of the best I have ever had but waiting an hour for this during a slow lunch took a star away. 

They were nice and apologetic but still, I was on a business lunch and we needed to eat and scram. This did not help matters when we were both starving and forced to sit on the bar when no-show tables were kept empty. 

How do I know they were no show tables? 

I asked, plus we were there long enough to know who owns cats or dogs in the kitchen.

Too bad, I was looking for a good sit down place to bring clients. So far Maya is what clients seem to like and the service has always been outstanding there.
author: James T.

description:
(Actually, this is 2.5 to be fair.)

Went there for a going away the other night.  The Salt House was pretty crowded for a Wed. night.  
My friend told us it was the same owner as "Town Hall" - i haven't been there, so not sure what the comparison would be - but just in case you may find that tidbit useful...

For me, when i go anywhere, i expect the evening to be pleasant - i mean, otherwise, why the heck would i even bother going??  So i guess i would say i'm a "glass is 1/2 full kind of gal" and with that, most places start with 5 stars in the beginning and away we go from there...

Half of us got there early and there was a slight mix up in our reservation, initially it had been for four people but ultimately we had eight and so when we got there they (Salt House) some reason, didn't "cancel" our first one, but luckily, our "new" one was down lower on the page.  A slight minute of worry since it was already 8pm.  (minus two stars for the worry and not being organized better!) 

Another friend's hubby thought the place was slightly pretentious, but eh, i didn't think it was overly so, i mean, the crowd was the office after work types who probably thought they are something they're not.  But frick them, i'm here to eat not to be seen. 

I didn't look at the drink menu and got the house sangiovese and it came in this little bottle that you pour into your glass yourself.  Cute idea, but not really if you're standing in a crowded bar and barely have hands to hold all your drinks anyway.  But i will give 'em "cute" for the thought. (minus 1/2 star)

Our server was very very accommodating. Not sure what her name was, cute, petite blond that suffered through waiting for our late friends and our indecisions.  (plus 1/2 star)

For starters we had the crispy shrimp and the baked oysters.  Both were good but luckily we got two b/c they were rather small.  Presentation of the food was nice.  LOVED LOVED LOVED the bread, well, then again, we were like super hungry but the bread was very good.  (for serving size, minus one star)
oh, and it was slightly inconsistent b/c our friends also ordered the baked oysters and they got 5 small oysters and we got 4 large ones... we probably wouldn't have known if, well, they're weren't sitting at the same table...  

ok, so what star level are we at now.. i think two? 

so anyway the night progresses and I ordered the striped sea bass with calamari as my entree.  The serving size was fair and fish was tasty and the broth it came in was good.. only bad part was that the plate was cold so my dish cooled down very quickly... (plus one for taste and serving size, minus one for the cold plate)

Adequate selection of after dinner "digestifs" and desserts.  We ordered the "quince" cake, which was interesting, but not super great. also got the brownie was was eh, ok.  Also ordered the tart, but didn't taste it, but it looked good!  :)  (good selection, so 1/2 plus)

so in total, ladies and gents, i think that nets us two point five stars for the evening.  I would go back and it's a decent place, just a few tweeks in the minor issues and i'm sure it'll be on it's way to 4.  

Although for service, i would definitely give 4.  Btw, for the night, including drinks, appetizers, entrees, desserts all and all it was about $60 per person.
author: Ella B.

description:
Okay, let's just get this out of the way: Pretty much everything I put in my mouth during a recent visit to Salt House was tasty. Some of it more than tasty (the duck) and some of it less tasty (some dessert with rhubarb that was too tart). But, all-in-all, TASTY. The service was sloooooooow as molasses. We were with good friends, though, so it was okay.

What's really important is the poutine. Oh, poutine. So delicious. So fatty. So awesome. While Salt House's poutine doesn't quite follow the strictest standards of poutine ingredients -- it's way too fancy -- I am willing to overlook it. The short-rib gravy was wonderfully salty and meaty, the cheese melty and mild, and the fries crispy enough to take the onslaught.

I'll definitely plan another dinner outing, but am dying to drop by for a drink and poutine.
author: Katie T.

description:
The drinks sound good, but no matter, I want to talk about a particular menu item.
We ordered the "Crispy Shrimp."  I know that this is a small plate, but I really didn't expect it to be so.. small.  It was three shrimps and a mound of green beans--there was about 4 times as much green beans as shrimp!  
Dude!!...  They should've called it Crispy Green Beans!!...
author: Yohanna B.

description:
Salt House wasn't at all what we expected given it's Town Hall parentage. 

Started off well- a bottle of Pinot Gris from their well selected wine list (good variety of price points, diversity, etc) and both the crispy egg and suckling pig apps.  Both recommended by our genuinely cheery-yet-not-overbearing waitress. Egg itself was nothing short of unique, and actually quite flavorful (breaded and cooked whole- but not overly done). The accompaniment of sausage and a tomato based sauce was less than thrilling- no spice, no bite- didn't really add anything.  Suckling pig was the winner of the night - served with a lightly-flavored maple sauce, grilled figs and turnips. 

The entrees really lacked focus. I'm not trying to be a foodie biotch, but this is really the phrase that comes to mind. FI's halibut was cooked perfectly, but the light fish was overpowered by the butternut squash accompaniment. So overwhelming that the fish could barely be tasted/enjoyed. My sole was cooked well, but I was truly confuddled at what went on around it. Cranberry beans, pancetta, greens, clams, peppers, wine, butter, oil, other peppers, etc. etc. etc.... went on and on and on. And I don't think that the menu's description prepared me for the mess. 

What really blew it though was what happened to the aforementioned service. Once our entrees were dropped off that was it. We never saw a server (ours or any other) for the next 40 minutes even though we were clearly done with our entrees.  Finally a nice busser took pity and cleared our table, plopping down dessert menus. Another 10 minutes, not a waiter/ess in sight.  I flagged the hostess for our check which, despite not being her job, she brought promptly. I don't know if our waitress went on break or what, but for a tab of $150, someone needs to be tending to the table... 

Overall a $150 disappointment.
author: Jenni D.

description:
What can I add that 485 other reviewers haven't said? Probably nothing, but I'm compelled to write anyway. 

As a San Francisco native/snob, I like to think I have some standards relative to the rest of the region. I was in town for work and met my sister for a late after-happy hour dinner. She suggested this place and I was pleasantly surprised. 

The restaurant was populated but not overcrowded for a Monday night. Having moved away from SF a little over two years ago, I'd forgotten the joys of communal dining tables - Salthouse reminded me. We didn't wait at all and took the last two seats at the communal, next to some interesting folks. The service was friendly, prompt and unpretentious. 

My sister and I shared a striped bass ($26) and an autumn salad ($11) and 1/2 chicken ($18), along with wines recommended by our waiter. It's generally hard for me to praise a salad, especially considering dishes that hours of preparation, but this autumn salad was amazing. A perfect salad - simple, crisp, fresh, complimented by a light fruity dressing without taking anything away from the focus on vegetables. 

The atompshere and the staff encouraged us to stay and hang out. With so many restaurants to try, I would still return some time. It's comfortable, tasty, and I got out of there for just over $100.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I liked it right away when a server pointed out a space at the bar my dad and I could snatch up (they were being seated in a few minutes) before anybody else got it.  Nice to know somebody's watching your back, right?!

It's a big open space with a loft-like second story.  Next time I want to sit up there.  Lots of exposed wood, steel, kinda industrial.

Dad and I shared an order of the baked oysters and crispy shrimp with serrano ham and spicy green beans (cumin, cayenne?).  Yum!  I really wanted to get the foie gras, but nobody to share it with, as my dad refuses to eat that sort of thing.  I made a joke about how he used to pay us to eat food when we were kids, and offered him $5 to try it--no dice.

I enjoyed the perfectly cooked wild striped sea bass with chorizo and diced root veggies.  My dad had the chicken with mushrooms and fingerling potatoes.  He was very pleased with his choice as well.

We were too full for dessert, though I didn't see any of my usual choices (fruity baked stuff).
author: Aimee B.

description:
Nice oysters (I had one each of 5 varieties, all very different and spectacular--the buyer did well), excellent drinks (I had the Kentucky Apple, which was memorable and a solid glass of wine that I can't recall), and the beef short rib--most of which melted in my mouth.

The only negative was the shared bathroom with Harlot.  I agree with some others on whether Salt House knows what kind of restaurant it wants to be--upscale dining or more casual.  The club in the back screams out the latter.
author: Em P.

description:
My friend found out about this restaurant in the San Francisco magazine and wanted to check it out so we booked a table and went there on a Friday night.  It was busy and there was lots of noise.  Since we don't eat much, we didn't order entrees and had 4 different appetizers instead (but then we had to cancel one since we wanted dessert).  We had beets, fried shrimp, and the halibut. The dressing they put on the shrimp fits so well in the dish.  The halibut was really fresh and the beets was really sweet!  Overall we enjoyed all the appetizers.  As for the dessert, I can't remember the name but it was ginger flavored and similar to custard.  It was light flavored, fantastic and quite refreshing to have.

Service was also great.  They actually divided the appetizers into two dishes for us before bringing it to our table.  The waitress we had was very friendly and helpful in recommending us to the appetizers and wine.  

The prices for the appetizers ranged from $10-15 a dish and entrees were above $20.  After having all that with each of us having a glass of wine and coffee, we each had to fork out about $45 which isn't too bad.  I would definately come here again to bring a friend or loved one to try out the other dishes.
author: sidney c.

description:
My wife and I tried out the Salt House for Valentine's Day last February, on the suggestion of a former co-worker, and we loved it. Phenomenal space, fantastic dishes. I fell in love with the poutine appetizer and honest to God, couldn't wait to go again just for that!

This place would get five stars but for the very noisy environment and the wine menu that lacks any modestly-prices choices.
author: Christopher S.

description:
After years of hearing about it and what seemed years of trying to schedule a time to catch up with an old friend, we finally made it to Salt House. It was delicious and lived up to everything I've heard.

We had the foie [2 ways], a few hama hamas & chelsea gems to start. A place that actually knows what they're doing when preparing foie correctly! Absolute heaven! The oysters were fresh and not too briny. We both had fish - sole & ahi seared perfectly. And for dessert, we shared their blondie brownie.

Not 5 stars because the place gets really noisy and you have to fight to carry a conversation. But the staff from when you walk in to when you leave are friendly and accommodating. 

Ready to go back!
author: Michelle M.

description: I stumbled into Salt House after a VIN12 wine event. I vaguely remember sharing a dozen oysters, foie gras and something else. The non-oyster items seemed particularly tiny, like doll food. The doll food tasted delicious!  Overall, we spent $61.50 for two. I will try to return another time when I am not wine tasting and can remember how to tip properly.
author: Camille K.

description:
Updated - 2/12/07

I went back to Salt House to give it a 2nd try the other day and I was very impressed with the how much the service and seating issues had improved. We had 12:00 reservation and were seated immediately upon arrival This time around we decided on the Crispy Shrimp salad (highly recommend), the Crab salad with fried artichokes, we then moved onto the Duck Leg Confit (my favorite) and the Roasted Chicken. All the items were great and appetizers and entrees were timed very well. 

Final thought - I am looking forward to trying the Salt House out for dinner sometime soon.
author: Raymond M.

description:
I've only been here once and nothing on the menu really stood out. We ordered a bunch of appetizers, some of which were good and some of which weren't so good, but the only stand out that is worth noting are the mixed nuts. Yes, the mixed nuts!! They come out piping hot and they roast the nuts wtih truffle honey and salt so they're a great combination of sweet and salty. 

Next time I'll come back and just order some drinks at the bar with the mixed nuts.
author: A and K W.

description:
Lunch was not astounding.

Waitress had some excellent recommendations for wine.  The interior of the restaurant is very well in done in the modern, airy, nouveau-San Francisco style.  

We started out with tempura shrimp on green beans and dungeness crab salad.  The shrimp fell short, the batter was too heavy and they were over-cooked.  The green beans were undercooked and the sauce didn't leave any impression.  The crab salad was very good, but nothing remarkable.  

For the main course, I had the snapper served with clams and a white wine sauce, again good but not remarkable.  The pork cubano sandwich was excellent.  The main course did take a long time to get especially for lunch.
author: Evan A.

description:
We arrived in a large group that clearly was not going to be seated easily even if we had booked ahead.  The restaurant isn't big and they've packed the tables in pretty tightly.

The staff were friendly about it but eventually we had to split into two groups of 4.  I had the medallions lamb, which was delicious but consisted of about 5 bite size pieces of lamb and some salad.  And that was in the $30 price range.

The starters that others had (I passed, assuming my entree was going to be more significant) seemed pleasant enough.  My friend ordered the cocktail special and couldn't drink it as the mix of flavors was unpalatable.

This is a new restaurant so I'd give it a second chance in a few months time - but if they are reading this they need to increase their portion size if they want to satisfy diners at this price point.
author: Ben M.

description:
What a great restaurant! Very interesting space - smaller than you would think but a lot of great details.

They were able to accommodate our large group of 12 with very short notice. The hostess was very welcoming and friendly which was a plus for my out of town visitors.

We started with the seafood mixed platter of oysters/shrimp/mussels/clams and it was well received. It was plenty for our table of 8 (4 people dropped out last minute and Salt House was totally cool about it).

I really enjoyed my sea bass with some chorizo. The small diced chorizo was really tasty and the crispness of the see bass skin was perfect. It stayed crispy even after sitting in the light broth.

We did not have room for dessert but I sure would love to come back for more.
author: Glenn G.

description:
Expensive, trendy, good location.  The Burger was good, but the bun was dry.  Dessert was phenomenal.

From the owners of Town Hall, I expected just a bit more.  Good thing the company paid for it.
author: Curtis C.

description:
All I can say is YUM. Owned by the same owners as Town Hall, the quality of the food is just as tasty and well prepared as its sister restaurant, although the menu doesn't seem as extenstive at this establishment. 

The service here was also very friendly and accomodating. The only real negative I have about to say about this place is the configuration. The lack of separation between the bar area and dining area makes this not an ideal happy hour location.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
Loved the scene here, but I don't remember the dish names. We ordered a few things so we could all share and it was all fantastic. You can't seat large groups comfortably, so do just a double date or something simpler.

Parking was free and easy in the 'hood, too. That's not easy in the city. Check out the menu. Food and wine selections are superb.
author: Tracy O.

description:
Ok, like many San Franciscans, I eat out A LOT.  Always go to the newest, most talked about restaurants...  What a tough life, huh?  Well, it is, when you become so used to good food that not many places "WOW!!!" you...  There are so many great restaurants in this great city...

'Nuff said.  My top two "WOW!!!" restaurants, Salt House and Kokkari.

Salt House was really amazing.  I went with two friends, and of course tried everyone's entrees.  I think what makes these dishes so different are the incredibly tasty sauces and the vegetables that accompany the main dish.  Everything was absolutely perfect, including the ambiance and scene...

Make a reservation though, even with a reservation, you'll end up waiting a little bit...  But definitely worth the wait...
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The food at Salt House tastes quite salty (should have guessed as it is the SALT house). 

The poutine appetizer is basically salty french fries, like overly salted, and with some sauce on it (gravy on the side.. and honestly, sauce and more sauce is overbearing). The sole was good, but again, too salty for my taste (I don't even salt my scrambled eggs). More sauce on this dish, but honestly, it didn't do much to make the sole tasty. Average food, basically. 

It does get loud, and you notice yourself slowly yelling to get your point across, or at least, leaning in to listen to the person not yelling. It's not bad, but hard to have a good conversation with your meal. Service is decent, but not extraordinary where they go out of their way.

And what's up with a lot of pork or bacon being put into every dish? I feel like that just adds to the saltiness. Hm..
author: Yosie G.

description:
I ordered the lamb. It was nice and melted off the bone, but was not something spectacular.

The waitress was kind enough to help recommend a great Scotch. I like them peaty (sp?) 

Unfortunately , we didn't get to the sea food.

I was hoping for more from this place and tried really hard to like it, but the the food just didn't knock my socks off. 

One star for the good service, and one for the good Scotch.
author: Eugene L.

description:
My girlfriends and I had a late dinner here last Friday.  I ordered the steak medium rare with potatoes and carrrots.  The meat unfortunatley was dry and crunchy on the outside.  I not kidding it had a burnt crunch on the outside of the steak.  Very chewy.  I loved the sauce and the sauteed veggies but the steak I would have sent back.

My friend ordered the shrimp appetizer that looked really good with a greenbean salad. She did not like it saying that there were large chili flakes that was so spicey that she could not enjoy the dish.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Been here a few times and always have them make me a vegan dish, which is basically- seasonal vegetables. And it's not bad except that they charge me approx the same price as all their other meat/seafood entrees. So for a plate of veges, mostly potatoes I might add, with some olive oil and herbs, it's pretty outrageous to be paying $20+

Another thing, had a salad there once and requested no cheese- so of course they bring it out WITH cheese. 

Other than that, the decor is nice and the waitstaff and hostesses are all pretty cool. The bar can get really packed though which can be annoying if you happen to be seated close to the bar.

Also like going for a late dinner and making my way over to Harlot, or other bars nearby.
author: JJ W.

description:
Not the best place to bring a date.  If you get LUCKY, you might get a table in the back where it is quiet.  otherwise, your sitting with people who are only 12 inches away from you, and the noise from the bar carries over. 
HOWEVER, this is a good place if you are coming with a group. 

FOOD: was average for the price, nothing "wow."
author: Mike L.

description:
I came right when this place opened, and found the food to be heavy, overly salty (perhaps not surprising, given the name of the joint....), and mediocre.  

Having given it several months, I returned recently for lunch.  And found it was still just okay.  Maybe it's just not my style of food.  I adore Town Hall and Anchor and Hope, but Salt House's food tends toward to heavier, more rustic side of Contemporary American.

Very hip place, but a tad loud for me and not worth the price.  I'd take Zuni every time if I was looking to eat comfort food in a boisterous environment.
author: nicole l.

description:
3.5 stars.

Gawd, I am so full. I am writing this review 2 hours after eating lunch here and I'm still trying to digest.

I think the people who opened Town Hall manages Salt House also. It was nothing like what I would have imagined. It was kind of casual -- the decor was industrial -- exposed bricks and beams and there was also this interesting  pirate theme or something going on -- large painting of some pirate on the back wall and the water jugs had pictures of a skull I think.

Random. But anyhow, onto the food.

MY GOD. I am so stuffed. 

Glass of some 2004 German Riesling. VERY good stuff. 

The Poutine was awesome. It was quite a heavy appetizer -- fries oozing with gravy and melted cheese. Talk about a heart attack but SO good.

Foie Gras -- bit too salty for me. Maybe I am just not a fan.

Salt House Burger -- Huge patty, and the onion rings that came with it -- AWESOME. Perfectly seasoned!!

The ahi tuna sandwich was massive!  Made my burger look like such a wimp.

I was too stuffed to eat dessert but both my boss and my intern raved about their desserts -- the chocolate brownie (hits the right spot for all the chocolate lovers, according to the waiter), and the caramel blondie,.

Service was fine. They let me change my reservations like 4 times in one day (meetings/projects galore) which was nice of them. Our waiter left us to ourselves pretty much the whole time but that was ok... he was just not one of those totally-in-your-face and not over-the-top kind either. Just basic service.
author: J T.

description:
This. Place. Rocks. 

Love the industrial feel of the place (exposed beams, etc.) 

Love the tatted up staff. If you're a good server/cook/host, you should be able to work wherever you want. Unfortunately, that's not always the case. I'm glad Salt House doesn't play that game. (This coming from the blond, white, most untatted girl you've ever seen. Moving on...)

Awesome wine list. Lots of variety (Old & New World) and extremely well-priced. Believe me. I've sold wine. I know what the majority of bottles go for before the mark-up and these guys obviously want you to ENJOY the good wine they've got in stock.

Awesome food. My wife, my pop-in-law and his partner shared the heirloom tomato salad and the scallops. MMMM. Then passed around the duck, chicken, bass, and short ribs. YUM. YUM. YUM. 

Then for dessert, we ordered the brownie and the cookie plate thinking the plate would have a few little cookies on it. WRONG. Like, 10, big-ass, motha' f***ing good, homemade cookies. We sighed the "we're never going to be able to finish those" sigh when they arrived. Then promptly cleared the plate. 

So happy we finally made it. Very pleased with the end result.
author: Kate P.

description:
If you are a poutine purist, you may be disappointed.  I know cheddar cheese is no replacement for cheese curds, but the rib gravy is a welcome substitution.  
I went with a group of friends for dinner a few weeks back and had a really good time.  The drinks are solid, and the food was good.  True, I have never met a tuna tartar that i didn't like...but that doesn't mean that theirs wasn't good.  3 of us wound up with the Striped Bass, and all 3 were happy.  How can yo miss when drizzling truffle oil on anything? The sole and pork were also given a thumbs up.  I would have liked to see lamb on the menu, but you can't have everything.
The cornmeal butter cake was less flavorful than I would have liked.  I was hoping it would be more buttery (like a shortcake) with maybe a hint of almond. It does say toasted almond on the description, but it isn't really IN the cake itself.  Did that stop us from eating it? Of course not. Don't be silly.

Would I say it was excellent?  I think the menu could be a little broader, but overall I think it is a decent place to dine.
author: Christie F.

description:
Another terrific restaurants in San Francisco, with a few added bonuses you don't always get with SF Chic.  Nice artwork, airy feel, and really close to the bridge.

I've now crossed the threshold of this place twice.  I sat once at a table and once I chose the bar.  Both places have their own advantages, but the tables are noisy and a little close together, so if you want a more peaceful dining experience, try the bar.

The food is new American (what we called nouvelle in the 80s), and the mix of offerings makes it a great place to take friends of disparate tastes, but not of disparate bank accounts -- the food is pricey.

One of my favorite appetizers was the Warm Mixed Nuts with Truffle Honey.  A little messy to eat, but really delicious and filling.  The appetizers are not what I'd call "share" size (or maybe they were too good to share), so if you do split them, you'll want a main course.  I've never had any of the red meat dishes, but the fish and chicken dishes were all tasty.  I'm a salt fan and the food is salted well, some might say excessively (I wouldn't), so consider another place if you're not a fan of those delectable white crystals.

All in all, thumbs up.
author: Tsan A.

description:
Not impressed.

I got a hamburger that was way overpriced and was too rare for medium.  The onion rings it came with were too heavily seasoned and greasy.  I could barely eat a handful of them before getting a little sick to my stomach.

The two most memorable things about the place were the bread and the service.  That's not good.
author: Wesley B.

description: Very good. I was impressed. Sweetbread flavorful, bass great, banana coconut dessert awesome. Service a bit slow. I'd go back.
author: The Mouse G.

description:
Pricey but pretty great food. "Cute" bread with reallllly good butter. Octopus (app) was interesting, not really a fan. Fried veggies (app) good stuff. Good fries (app) with yummy gravy. Chicken (main) decent size and a great choice. A lot of beautiful people in the restaurant :)

Will probably be back for drinks next time.
author: Rubes L.

description:
Good location, cool-looking place. Service was attentive at the beginning of the night, but it took a long time between appetizers and entrees and between finishing our meal and getting the check.

The food was hit and miss -- an appetizer of pasta and squid was delicious. The two fish entrees we had were unfocused -- way too many elements on the plate that didn't work together. 

Overall, I'm unlikely to return.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Let me say first that the food is absolutely glorious!
However, don't go there hungry: we waited for our food for over an hour, and the waitress' only explanation was that they were busy, no apology, no offer to check, just busy.  Although there is ample waitstaff, drinks were slow to arrive, and a request for a cocktail not on the menu, although quite commonplace, was discouraged.  Also, our waitress "did not like" one of the desserts.  
Snooty staff, in my experience, has been the demise of many a fine and popular restaurant.
author: Milena M.

description: From the moment I walked in, on this rainy night, the hostess set the tone.  She greeted me with a warm welcome.  I didn't have a reservation.  I was waiting for a friend to dine with.  She assured me I'd get a table and in no time, there it was.  The space is very open with high ceilings and an open kitchen.  I liked the decor and it felt cozy.  The food I ate or rather devoured, was so good.  They carried my favorite soup, Butternut Squash soup.  Yep, had it and it was better than tasty, it was quasi-orgasmic!  My chicken with fingerling potatoes and bacon rocked too.  I'd say, my dining experience here was A+ and a :).  I'd throw in a gold star, if I could.
author: Ryan B.

description:
how can this place only have 3 1/2 stars?! it definitely deserves at least four.

i came here with my boyfriend and his mom a couple months back and it was DELICIOUS. they have great flavor in everything they make but their food is RICH RICH RICH. as my boyfriend says, if he comes back here he'll need some tums. 

i have a terrible memory so i dont remember exactly what i got but i just remember it being wonderful. i recommend this place if you have the cash but i do agree with my boyfriend.. tums are definitely advisable. :)
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Even though the food is pretty good here, the service is just not quite there yet.

I understand that the place is popular (even on a Sunday night), but my friend I felt that all the attention went to the larger tables.

Between ordering and paying for the bill, our waitress was only at the table half the time.  The rest of the interactions was with a couple of the hosts and bus people.  There was a lot of waiting in between each steps.  Enough of a wait for us to look around for someone to help.  Not a good sign.

The best part is the wine.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Update:  I went for my 4th time, and was having high expectations.  This place has done me well.  I still had great service but the food took a dive.  Maybe it was the night, but the duck confit was sitting on a sweet marmalade sauce that was all wrong and my green beans were extremely overcooked.  I was disappointed.  It is not banned yet, but  I need to give it some time before I go back.

I went with a girlfriend and they had us at the communal table to start which was a bit too crowded.  Once we moved to the bar we were very well taken care off.  Great wines, loved the duck confit.  The bartenders were fun a very hospitable.  I will definitely go back.
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
There were several reasons why I dragged my co-worker here today:

1. I heard that Town Hall had good bloody mary's and this place was owned by the same people - yeah I know, not the best assumption. 
2. It was called Salt House, and I love salt - especially a salty bloody mary
3. It's only a half block away from my work. 

Well, my co-worker said the place was pretty snobby, and well lets just say there were way more people drinking wine than beer.  It was really not my scene at all.   The only reason why I am not giving it lower stars is because I didn't try the food - so that's not really fair to make that much of a judgment.

***Bloody Mary Review****

Let's just say i wouldn't go back for one, even if it is close to my work.  The bar tender did make it from scratch and it was in a pint glass, but the taste was not good at all.  Way too much horseradish and the horseradish was all you could really taste.   No veggies - and it was 8$ during happy hour.

Read some of my other Bloody Mary reviews at:
http://www.yelp.com/list_details?list_id=YHu-iA23Xj2c1bVa7JROhA
author: Josh M.

description:
Nice staff but not enough room to move. 

I loved the decor but still, not enough room to move!

Interesting people watching...but nah, not enough room.
author: Christina R.

description:
Definitely hit or miss for both food and service.  I've eaten here three times.  Service in general is pretty slow.  They never provide the drink menu with the dinner menu.  And except for the last time, our waiter didnt take our drink order for almost 10 minutes.  Then the wait staff kept trying to take our drinks away before we had finished them.  

I love the way this restaurant is decorated.  The exposed brick, art work and fixtures are very interesting.  However, the space is extremely crowded for an upscale restaurant.  I think they removed one of the "communal" tables in front of the bar, which has opened up the space considerably.  Still, you should expect to be bumped into repeatedly by wait staff and patrons while trying to enjoy your meal.  The acoustics are terrible.  Dont expect to hear what your friends are saying--just nod politely.  

Love the mixed drinks, particularly the salty dog.  Oysters in the past have been quite yummy.  The roasted beets are very good.  The warm bowl of nuts with honey and salt are usually the best thing on the menu, except that they burned the last bowl we ordered.  The shrimp and green bean salad appetizer was very disappointing (I'm sure I've seen this shrimp before on Popeye's dollar menu).  Last time we ordered the snapper which was nothing special.  The dish included pretty much just the fish and really needed some accompaniment like rice or potatoes or something.  

Havent had a memorable dessert yet, but the dessert drink menu is pretty extensive.  They offer port and scotch, but also stock sauternes, moscato, calvados, armagnac and others.  

Overall I like the Salt House. This still is a relatively new restaurant, and I hope that they work out the kinks because there are a lot of other good restaurants in the area without all of the problems.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
Overated and so-so.

I had a reservation at 8.30PM on a recent Wednesday night, only to be told a few times by the host that "it'll be 2 more minutes or so."  It soon approached 8:53PM and our table still wasn't ready, we were waiting for a previous party to pay their check.  The host told us again, we'd be seated soon.  2 minutes is OK, but another 20 minutes is unacceptable.  So to hush us, they offered a free round of drinks at the bar.  That was a nice gesture, but we were finally seated a few minutes after 9.00PM.

Overall, the food and service was so-so.  I had some starter that was french fries with brown gravy on it.  Oh, it was called Poutine or something like that. A good 25 minutes passed before our entrees arrived.  I had the steak, it was average.  I didn't even want to bother with dessert at that point.   Overall, our waiter did the bare minimum of his job.  The support team (bussers, etc) did a nice job and filled our waters regularly and cleared our courses on time.

One thing I did notice that night and the next day, I WAS THIRSTY!  The food was too salty.

Overall, tried it, but won't be going back!
author: W D.

description:
I found the food good but not particularly incredible for these prices.

However, my dining companions loved their dishes.  So it could have just been the items i ordered.
author: Animal K.

description:
Town Hall is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in SF, which is why I was utterly disappointed in their sister effort, Salt House.

The food was good, but the menu reflected a lack of direction and identity/style/etc. Was it elegant comfort food? Continental? Californian? I still can't decide ... And the dessert menu was so mundane that we opted to go for donuts and coffee at our local donut stop instead.

Now for the real rant - the service was so horrible that it ruined our overall experience considerably. Our waiter clearly played favorites, paying the most attention to the party of four in his section of four tables (his other tables, including mine, had two guests each). There were too many moments when we tried and thought we had successfully grabbed his attention, only to gawk at his retreating backside when he took off in the OPPOSITE direction.

Of course, the other side of the restaurant might have had an entirely different experience, but new restaurants need to make the most of each and every opportunity to shine, and unfortunately, Salt House was rather dull in my opinion.
author: Grace C.

description:
I had a business lunch. Service was slow (it was a packed house, but still..) The food was salty (hum, perhaps the name? ~I had the halibut in salt sauce & our table shared the salty fries). and it was ridiculously LOUD. It was hard to carry on a conversation across the table. 

Nothing was "so fabulous you have to go". In fact, enjoyed my lunch this week at Perbacco MUCH more. 

It was pricey though, if you have to flash your wallet to feel cool.
author: Rose J.

description:
We decided to come here on a whim on a Saturday night. The beauty of it was they found us a seat right away, right up in the front with a full window view to the sidewalk, which was great people watching. The space itself is super cool, very open, sleek and urban. The cocktail menu is inventive and the food was very good, but nothing in particular stood out.

With the location, it's the kind of spot that would be good for after work drinks or dinner, not really a weekend destination as there aren't any great bars nearby. 

It's also pretty pricey, so you would want to make this more of a special treat than a place you wander into any ol' night, even though it treated us well on a whim!
author: Kim M.

description:
Salt house is good, but there are better.

The service is noteworthy, but the menu felt sparse and the portions were a little shy.

best pick: small plates, especially the Shrimp.
author: Ken p.

description:
As the wife says . . . "good enough to ride the bus"!  Which we did there and the way back, and it didn't tarnish the experience in any way.  That's really saying something for those of you unfamiliar with the wonders of SF Muni.

They started us with some really nice bread and a bottle of their least expensive, but very good, sparkling wine.  We had the oysters (really spectacular -- extremely fresh), the sole (light and delicious), and the halibut with pork hocks (amazingly complex and each ingredient was perfectly cooked)

We were delighted up to this point, and so ordered a couple of desserts;  the English trifle and the pineapple upside-down torte.  The trifle was Laura's favorite, but while I found it tasty it didn't knock me out.  I loved the torte;  falling-apart tender and a great balance of sweetness and spice.

The ambience is really cool;  perfect for a really nice dinner where you don't want to get dressed up.  Very rustic but charming with an open kitchen.  Our service was attentive, but not overly so, and we got attention from everyone when we needed it.

I would give it five stars if the price were lower.  We ordered a ton of food and a very good bottle of champagne, and the bill was $160 before tip.  It was clearly worth the price, but I wouldn't call it a screaming deal.

I can't wait to check out Anchor and Hope by the same owners when they open on April 22 . . .
author: Gary B.

description:
We had a party of 5, Sunday evening.

Food was great, a bit pricey but very fresh and tasty. You can tell the chef really thought of what goes well with what. My halibut was cooked just right, very juicy and the vegi that goes with it has a great concentrated meat taste, very very tasty. 

Service was ok. Nice atmosphere.

I will still give this place another try. :)
author: E C.

description:
Surprise dinner to celebrate brother Mitchell's new job was a winner, great room, attentive service and above average food.
Small complaint on the shrimp/green bean appetizer, 3 shrimp for $14?  Still loved the spicy dressing/mint/parsley/green beans.
Mitchell enjoyed the scallops and my lamb shank was fall off the bone perfect.  
All complimented by a perfectly balanced oregon pinot.
And kudo's to anyone who puts an aged rum on the after drinks list.  Salt House is a place to celbrate.  
Next time I will try that Poutine dish...crazy canadian as it sounds.
author: Jules K.

description:
This is a great place to meet for drinks and I like the little loft area for dinner. I have only eaten here once, but the food was really good. Not fabulous, but a step above the normal. 

I give the owners of Salt House and Town Hall props for re-inventing spaces that are already standing instead of insisting on new construction. I love places with history.
author: Lora C.

description:
The foie gras made me want to cry tears of joy. Then I thought about how un-PC and inhumane it was to cry tears of joy over liver...NOT! 

After I cried tears of joy, and let my taste buds finish their orgy with the foie gras, I had a blast watching my friend squirm while trying to figure out what it was. (I eventually told her) Seriously, the piece we had was exceptionally fresh and rich. 

The duck with apricot was really good as well. Tried some of my friend's steak, and my other friend's gnocchi. (Like soft pillows as the waitress described) All delicious, and that's coming from a born and bred SF foodie. However, the menu's probably changed since I ate here since it's seasonal. 

Salt House looks like a restaurant that you would see in Manhattan. Kinda reminds me of Mercer Kitchen in Soho, probably because of the exposed brick. Only drawback is the noise level. Eh well, encourages us to shut up and eat. Yes sir!
author: Jenn C.

description:
Meh.

Not super impressed, I'm not going to lie.

I had the chicken salad which, without slogging on the dressing, was very bland. It had a nice combo of celery, mixed greens, grapes and apple under it, but the apple was like an asian pear- not sweet enough and not enough candied nuts to compensate. I didn't eat all of the chicken because the salad wasn't enough to spice it up.

My boss had the Salthouse burger ($14..whoa) and already told me she's going for a two on her yelp review.

We shared the poutine (thank God because one person would have an immediate coronary upon ingesting that themselves). It's fanfrickintabulous, but I've had poutine at an A&W in British Columbia and it was equally orgasmic. French fries + cheese + gravy = 5 million calories of happiness. Really, you can't go wrong with that combo.
