Aside from the poutine and the decor which is really nice.......MEH.

Maybe I'll come back for drinks since it's such a nice space....Drinking always makes me less critical...
author: Eli B.

description:
It's a fact; the owners of Salt House are jackasses.  They say so themselves on their website.  But they might not find themselves jackasses for the same reason I do.  I don't want to be cruel - there are, after all, many reasons to praise Salt House, but the service was largely disappointing and difficult to ignore.  

We arrived at 8:55pm for our 9pm reservation on a calm, Sunday evening.  There were four visibly empty tables, and yet for reasons unbeknown to us, the hostess decided the table wasn't ready and told us to start with drinks at the bar.  After 9:10pm she seated us at one of tables that had been empty all along.  That was one of many instances in the evening that didn't make sense.  Another example followed at the bar when I apparently upset the bartender because I wanted to pay for the drinks.  He took my card without saying a word and traipsed off to the other end of the dining room.  Shortly after being seated at our table, he returned my card to me without a word.  Sadly, that wasn't the only confusion with my credit card - I was later charged for my part of the final bill as well as a friend's part of the bill.    

As the dining room started to clear around 10pm, there was a notable difference in the demeanor of the staff.  The mildly aloof servers and the manager seemed to catch a second wind and pep up.  Unfortunately, they used that energy to leave us painfully unattended so they could consume their dinners in the back stairwell.  When our server returned to our table, she was still wiping her mouth of the food she had just devoured.  

But, I can't entirely blame them, since the food is quite good.  I would go back just for the Poutine.  Typically a Québécois street food, Salt Houses version is a beefy, rich and delicious plate of crispy French fries slathered in short-rib gravy and cheddar cheese.   It's elevated junk food for gourmands.   Gnocchi with sautéed porcini mushrooms was tasty and accurately prepared, although the portion was precious, especially compared to the half-chicken my friend ordered.  Served with mushrooms, roasted fingerling potatoes and bacon, the chicken was so crispy and flavorful that I was tempted to pull a caper and run off with it.   We ended the meal with a few delicious artisanal cheeses, which was around the time our wine arrived that we ordered for our main courses.  

We lingered to enjoy our wine and discuss our experience.  It is truly a shame when I know I'll crave a chef's food again but don't want to spend money on poor service.  How can they get away with such neglect, we asked ourselves, trying to make sense of the evening.  Surely they are aware; surely they know better; surely they have given away lots of drinks and desserts to pacify disgruntled guests.  Or is this another case of a trendy, good-looking restaurant that gets away with minimal effort and still makes a profit?  Perhaps the owners are jackasses, but I'm sure I am one too, because I'll go back for that poutine, even if it means I have to go to the kitchen and make it myself.
author: T. L.

description:
I know I'm a little to the party, but for some reason I have never been inclined to check out Salt House. I got invited for dinner last night and was delightfully pleased. 

The staff was super friendly and fun. The food was delicious. I did check to see what was most popular on yelp, so of course I got the poutine. It actually was my least favorite of the dishes I ordered. Fortunately it came last and I ended up taking it home. It's good, but there are better options at Salt House. I ordered a bunch of starters; oysters, butternut squash soup, yellow fin tartare, honey nuts, and pickled vegetables. I like variety. Everything was up to par. I can't complain. ;)
author: S A.

description:
I was really looking forward to this meal because I love Town Hall.

However when I went there for a business dinner and I was pretty disappointed. The pace was packed with people so it was a little deafening in the room. Normally I'm fine

The food was so-so... I ordered  trout wrapped with serrano ham  which sounded more interesting than it turned out to be but the worst part was that it took 30-40 minutes between the appetizers being cleared and us getting that entree. Would not recommend..
author: Chris L.

description:
Salt house is "good."  Not as fantastic as Slanted Door or Spruce, but defendable.

My brother and I sat at the shared table and received very, very nice service.  A nice touch, was when the friendly manager came over and offered us refills on our drinks.  He knows what he's doing...

the gravy/cheese fried were decent, but when it came down to it, just fries with gravy and cheese...

the vegetable salad was delicious.  Probably the highlight of the meal.

The short ribs were tender and moist, they were crusted over with some sort of mustard rub, which dried out the dish a little overall, but the meat itself was yummy.

If you make a reservation, dont go with super high hopes, you wont be disappointed that way.  If you expect decent food and a nice atmosphere you expectations will be met.
author: Krissy P.

description:
This restaurant came recommended to us by friends and I tried really hard not to yelp the restaurant but my eagerness got the best of me. I only read the 4 plus star reviews and I have to say everyone was really off. 
To start, the place was really really loud! We could hardly hear our waitress and the table conversation was to the point of yelling. The entrees were well portioned and perfectly cooked; however, the h'orderves were really skimpy for the price. You can't share the appetizers and don't fool us by putting them on these huge plates and give us enough for my husband to inhale in one bite! After ordering our drinks they came out at the same time as the appetizers and by then we were ready for wine. And the seating--Yikes if my 130 pound 5'7" body couldn't fit Good Luck to the poor sucker who has longer legs and gut. 
The 2 stars goes to the wonderful waitress (not her fault the bar tender couldn't get the order out) and the entrees.
author: Jane K.

description:
Had dinner here the other night.  The food was great!  (I tried the lamb shank, it was excellent).  Dessert was a treat too.  Service was right on point and the host (ess) was especially helpful with arranging seating.  If you do want a quiet atmosphere this is probably not the place for you though..  Its a tad loud, and with the weirdly long tables (forget about it if you want to reach out and touch someone across the table... er, or play footsie :-) you end up shouting/yelling at each other most of the evening.  I saw a few couples actually scoot over to one side of the table to carry on a conversation.

I would suggest some furniture upgrades to suit the rustic nature of the decor in the restaurant.  For instance consider smaller tables of the same texture/style akin to the community table
author: Leroy R.

description: After countless recommendations from various people, I decided to hit this spot up with some solid company and give it a shot.  I was expecting this Euphoria after what I had heard, but after going there, I came to the realization that everything on that menu has been done in one way shape or form at every "Nouveau American" restaurant that I've been to. Not to say the food was not executed well or the service was bad, it was just something that I have had plenty of times and I expected  something a bit more special.  It's definitely a solid place to eat, but if you're looking for something new and refreshing, this isn't the place.
author: Edward P.

description:
Salt House gets 3.5 stars for the food, zero for the service.  I won't be returning, and I usually give places a break the first time around.

Three of us went for lunch at 1:15 on a weekday. When we walked in the door, the server who greeted us gave us the once over, apparently unimpressed that we were daring to wear jeans into her fine establishment.  We were seated at the communal table, which gave us a nice view out the window, but left us between servers and ignored for some time.  When someone finally came to our table, we quickly ordered drinks and food in hopes of returning to work in a reasonable amount of time.  Little did we know -- 

My friend received his appetizer in about 10 minutes, which was completely reasonable. He had a lovely salad with smoked trout, and said he enjoyed it.  

Then we sat...and sat...and sat for almost 25 minutes.  My other friend grabbed a passing server (ours had long before disappeared without a trace) and asked where our food was. Instead of simply apologizing for the wait, the server gave my friend attitude, muttering about how there was an appetizer on our table (even though the plate had been cleaned and pushed aside 25 minutes before). She huffed away.

5-10 minutes later our burgers came out with the beautiful, golden onion ring strings. The onion rings were barely warm (though still tasted wonderful). The burgers were incredible, cooked perfectly and covered with the right amount of creamy melted cheese -- but the burgers would have been so much lovelier had the server remembered to bring the ketchup before I had finished my entire lunch...

I'm not impressed. While the burger was extremely good, it wouldn't be worth the $14 even were the service not crap at Salt House. I don't need sass during my lunch, and I expect to be fed in a reasonable amount of time during lunch time -- particularly when I'm only blocks from my financial district office.
author: Meg K.

description:
I would have given this place four stars, if they didn't make us wait nearly fifteen minutes for our table. I mean we had a reservation and we showed up exactly on time, but they were behind so we had to stand around in a crowded hall way and try to not to bump into people leaving.

But, the food made the wait more than worth it. We shared two of each of the oyster specials they had that day, which were awesome. The yellowfin tuna here is amazing - one of my favorites in the city. The way they prepare it is unique and delicious. The beef short ribs that my friend got were delish as well.

Looking at the prices, they were definitely on the high end, but if you ask me the meal was worth the $$.
author: ting b.

description: My wife and I took a quick trip to SF and headed straight to Salt. We got there a little early and the hostess was great, got us a table in 5 minutes. We took a look at the wine list and there was plenty of great names to choose from. Atmosphere is great, servers were great in suggesting dishes to try. We had the scallops and the yellowfin tartare, both excellent. Oysters were as fresh as we have had. A terrific restaurant we highly recommend it!!!
author: Aaron N.

description: The ambience was nice but the menu a bit limiting. The fish my friend had was a bit fishy. Best dish we had was the tagliatelle - but it came only in an appetizer portion and was a bit too cold by the time it got to the table.
author: Betty L.

description: Had a delicious lunch here (sausage merguese) and loved the ambiance. Plan to visit again soon!
author: Tadeek P.

description: Although the food here carry a component that is only for the trendy palatte...they have really perfected the bone marrow.  However, this is only seasonal and they did not have it the last time I went.  Serving this dish as a permanent part of the menu would boost my rating to a 4.  Otherwise, this is another overcharged restaurant in the city that can easily be outdone by RN74 down the street.
author: Love P.

description:
Decided to try this place after walking by it a week earlier and hearing some good buzz.  First thing is call to make a reservation, the first attempt I made to eat here with my friend was greeted with a hour wait, maybe more.  So a few weeks later I just called and made a dinner reservation (9:45 was the earliest, so call two days in advance).

I love the atmosphere of the place, they did a great job designing and creating a very upscale vibe, but not in a snobby way if you ask me.  I wound up having the Chicken after reading some Yelp reviews, and it was excellent, so if you like chicken dishes you must order this.  My friend ordered one of the fish plates, I forget which one but she enjoyed it as well.

They also have a very complete Wine menu which is nice, lots of variety.  I didn't give it five stars because I felt the portions were a bit small for the price (Small portions, larger price is not cool or upscale if you ask me).  But that small complaint aside its a great place to go for drinks, or maybe a date if you are looking to take someone to a nice place thats fairly new.
author: Ryan D.

description:
Uh....I guess I just didn't get it.  Trust me, I tried.

Lunchtime with reservations on a Thursday, promptly seated and courteous hostess (thus the .5 after the 2 stars, if possible)...but simply that's where the charm ends....

Prices were a bit "inflatey" for what you got....service, though polite and attentive was slow (albeit the Dow hit an all time high that afternoon, so they were a bit packed with happy campers).  The "Cuban sandwich" was unremarkable and the salmon, sized for Kate Moss appetites was passable.

Space was OK...if you enjoy the dining space of Asia De Cuba (e.g. watch your elbows) you will have no problems here.  Otherwise, simple lines, nice and clean.

Overall, don't expect a lot, you wont be too let down.  Maybe dinner is better.  Again, maybe I just didn't get it, or I was waiting for the next Dow highpoint.
author: David C.

description:
Mmm...


Good food, really really good. String bean perschutto appetizer, spicy to perfection perschutto adds a nice salty touch. Yellowfin Tuna Entre was so good, lick your plate good. Finish off with something sweet. Marshmallow chocolate mouse thing with rice crispies on the bottom, awwwww. Ok I cant remember the name of the entres because I had a lot of wine, which was also... really good. My Dad ordered the rabbit on gnocchi, if the thought of eating bunny doesn't bother you, this is good order, tastes kind of like turkey in a good way.

Ambiance was nice too, it's an old print house, and it has the whole SOMA industrial feel to it. It did not hurt that our hostess looked like Amy Winehouse's sister. Made for some good conversation.
author: Lisa M.

description:
I enjoyed a nice lunch here.  The table was ready early, in spite of the restaurant being completely packed.  I had the shellfish saffron stew which was tasty and fresh.  My colleague ordered the petrale sole and she was very happy with the order.  

The room is a converted warehouse space which adds a very SoMa-ish feel and yes, it's noisy.  I saw a lot of complaints about the noise - but some restaurants are noisy - If you want quiet, go elsewhere.  As a native New Yorker, I call it atmosphere and I felt comfortable.  Service was good, too.  

I will be returning.
author: Chad K.

description:
A large,  bright venue with an open kitchen.  Good bread and a waiter who knew the menu and was prepared to provide more information than was really necessary or desired.  

Started with chilled pea soup.  The taste of the peas was somewhat difficult to detect, although the soup was helped a bit by some fresh peas on the bottom of the bowl.

An appetizer of crispy egg over fresh carrots and peas accompanied by some crispy/fatty pork.  The dish was overly salted and didn't come together as an integrated plate of food.  The egg was one thing. The vegetables another and the pork still another unrelated thing.  

Petrale sole with some shrimp over the now ubiquitous peas and carrots followed.  The vegetables were fresh and nice enough.  The shrimp just OK. The fish fine.  But again the plate was overly salted. 

Overall, pretty good ingredients that were handled poorly.  Too bad.  The place could be very much better with some tweaking here and there.
author: David D.

description:
OK, so I had been here once for a drink and loved the decor so much I wanted to give it five stars but felt I needed to hold out until I ate. So ate I did! I went with two comrades and we started with the poutine and cocktails. Dear god what is better than french fries with cheese sauce and short rib gravy? NOTHING!!! 

I had the sole as my entree and it was so so good. Usually I get sick of fish after two bites but this was crispy and delicate and moist and came with a delicious sweet corn puree. Yum. We chatted it up with one of the servers who brought us a complimentary dessert just cause "I thought you should have something sweet." How nice is that?!

Only awkward thing was the restroom situation outside and down the hall. If you like lesbian raves and pounding techno music you'll fit right in. Otherwise you might be confused.
author: Shira G.

description:
Salt House has a fun, lively atmosphere, which can be both a benefit and a hindrance. You feel like you are part of "the scene," but it is also hard to talk and there can be a bit of a wait, for both the bar and community table, as well as the dining room.

The space is nice, it has an open-air feeling, great wood tones, and a few great seats in the front of the room. 

I think the food is great. They are known for there fish, which is good. My favorite foods are the crispy shrimp and green beans, as well as the Poutine. I am from Northern New York and have had Poutine in Montreal many times and I like Salt Houses much better. Poutine at Salt House consists of french fries, melted cheddar cheese, and short-rib gravy put on table side. Poutine looks a little messy, but the flavors just burst in my mouth, making me want more. I could eat it all myself, but I know it's not exactly healthy.

What can I see, the food is first rate. If you are going with more than a friend, I would certainly make a reservation, sharing the Poutine and Crispy shrimp and green bean appetizer for the table.
author: Christopher W.

description: Had a great lunch here today of the Roasted Pork Cubano sandwich w/ spicy chips.....Absolutely delicious! And the atmosphere -- a tasteful collision of rustic and contemporary design -- was comfortable and welcoming. Good service, too. Definitely recommended.
author: Marie L.

description: I came here for dinner on a Saturday night. It wasn't that crowded but we made reservations anyway. We sat upstairs and it was really cozy. They have huge glass windows and the upstairs area overlooked the entire restaurant. It was a nice dining experience. Food was okay though. For starters we had a dozen assorted oysters. They had my fav: Kumamoto oysters! Our platter also had Fanny Bays and Hama Hama oysters. Delicious! We also had the Crispy Shrimp and Dayboat Scallops for appetizers. This is one of those restaurants that have really small serving for big prices. 2 pieces of shrimp and 2 pieces of scallops came out on each plate. Same thing went for entrees. I ordered the Alaskan Halibut. It was grilled perfectly, but wasn't enough to fill me up. Everything I had was a bit on the saltier side too. Maybe that's why it's called "Salt House?" I don't know...but 3 appetizers and an entrée? Call me fatty! There wasn't a wow factor to this place. Good to try once, but not good enough to come back again.
author: Lynn V.

description: The food here gets four stars. It's been reliably REALLY GOOD during my five visits over the past year or so. And the ambience is charming, warm and inviting. So, again, four stars. My gripe with Salt House is actually a gripe I have of some of SF's best restaurants -- the hostess(es). Seriously, is it that hard to smile? Or to say good evening and somewhat mean it? I know it must be hard to always be "on" but I think some of these gals could work just a little harder at it.
author: Brent H.

description: Not sure what happened since the last visit. Warm nuts and dessert was great, but entree was too busy.  And $140 with no wine?  Nice space and fun atmosphere--maybe next time some wine and skip entree?
author: Lucas M.

description:
Well.... Not good enough. Great space, but snide, disinterested server coupled with disappointing food, resulted in our party of four bailing out before desert.
When asked about the tagliattelli appetizer, the waiter said that everyone laughs when they get it because it's so small. The menu Is badly written, difficult to picture just what the dish might look like . Couldn't find more than a flake or two of crab with the sole.... Beans/shrimp very salty, battered shrimp were dull and soft.
Waiter never bothered to ask us how the food was, but smirked at us as he would walk by... Very odd. Overpriced, underwhelming, dull food served by disinterested staff in what could be a great room. Don't bother.
author: Douglas J.

description:
had the burger w/some beer. the burger patty wasn't that flavorful and the works weren't anything to write home about. the bun was far too hard and dense. the fries were the biggest culprit -- not crispy, room temperature and tasteless.

better off to come to la for these burgers on my site's latest burger roundup.
author: N J.

description: Poutine -- a bowl of downright deliciousness. Had a great lunch here. The service was rushed because we were the last table seated before the lunch kitchen closed.
author: Bridget K.

description:
Went here for lunch with coworkers.  The executive summary is that it's not bad, certainly better than many downtownish destinations, but carries a steep price tag.  I ended up with a wild mushroom gnocchi.  The pasta was of pleasant firmness and chewiness, though the sauce, a brown cream-based concoction not unlike a confit marinade (sans the meat) was too rich and didn't allow the flavor of the somewhat paltry portion of chanterelles and shiitake to come through.  Portion size was adequate.

The service was infrequent and slow, understandable given that it was high lunch hour, but certainly pleasant when it did arrive.  I'm not sure I'd go back on my own dime, but wouldn't put up a fuss if it was chosen as a corporate or group destination.
author: Susuk L.

description: Great lunch on a Friday! Service was impeccable, food was delish. Location is convenient for FiDi or SoMa businesses. Will definitely return again!
author: Denise V.

description:
Takes a bit to be seated, if there's room grab a seat at the bar and drink up.

Two words: POUTINE FRIES. If I could make it a requirement for everyone that eats there, I would. Super heavy appetizer, but WORTH EVERY BITE.

nom nom nom. I'm hungry writing this review.

Shared appetizer - scallops - delicious. Really nicely done.

I ordered the Cassoulet - SO YUM. Flavors are so well integrated and gives you that super warm happy feeling. It gives you that reminiscent feeling of all the yummy happy meals you've had in the past. It is on the heavy side, so be prepared.

My friend ordered the Monkfish - I could eat this everyday, but I would get fat.  So buttery and breaks beautifully, the veggies and sauce tie in perfectly.

Win.
author: Angela T.

description:
Probably more like a 3.5 but I am feeling charitable today. Took the GF out for Valentines day. Had been planning on celebrating over the weekend, so was a little late in trying to find a reservation and was happy that one opened up here.

On the positive side- Liked the setting, cool lofted building.
The poutine (french fries with vermont cheese and short rib gravy) were amazing and large
The atlantic striped bass was a very good with escarole and bit of pork shank was quite good and my girlfriends salmon was also pretty good.

On the negative- Food took forever. Nobody even apologized
The general overall service was slightly lower quality than you would accept given prices, which while not exoribinant were not cheap either..
author: Andrew D.

description: Punishingly loud and uncomfortable room. I've been twice now for weeknight dinner and both times have left with my ears ringing and my throat hurting from shouting to make myself heard. The tables are packed very closely. There's no room in the bar to wait for a table, being full of people eating food. It's not a pleasant place to be with friends. Too bad, because the food is quite good.
author: Nelson M.

description:
I understand that it is downtown and you should expect to pay more, but for $12 for a glass of wine, could you at least fill the glass up. I only went in for drinks and an appetizer so I don't know about the entrees other than their descriptions on the menu were less than exciting.  I got the smoked salmon appetizer, which was yummy.
Totally California cuisine (small portions, large prices). Probably won't be going back.
Not sure why there were two five star reviews before the place even opened, wouldn't you want to at least check the place out before saying it's amazing?
author: Amy W.

description:
We had reservations and our table wasn't quite ready when we arrived.  The host apologized for the delay, took our drink orders and was back in no time with our wine.  The restaurant is fairly small though and other than the limited bar seating, there is really isn't a comfortable place to stand and wait which was a bit awkward.  The space is very lofty (old warehouse) and they were smart to design sort of a trellis over the bar area to make it a bit more cozy.

We were seated in the back of the restaurant (by a really interesting wall mural) where we had a great view of all the action in the exposed kitchen.  I can't remember what the chairs looked like, but I remember I loved them.  Random, sorry.

The food was good.  I didn't think Town Hall good, but good.  We started with the poutine (which btw- our friend, who is Canadian, was way too excited about- french fries with gravy and cheese- who knew?) which was good, but a bit rich for my liking.  I had the duck confit, which was fantastic and would highly recommend.  My boyfriend however, opted for the chicken by the servers recommendation.  Neither of us were impressed.  I can't recall what else we had which is usually means I wasn't blown away.  

Two things bugged me about the servers: they didn't announce the menu items they brought to the table (I know it is kinda lame, but I like it), the second is that they kept serving our dishes over the divider between the kitchen and our table.  I mean honestly, you can't walk around the partition to properly serve my dinner?  I thought that was borderline rude.

I love the space and will mostly likely return, but probably for drinks/apps at the bar, not dinner.
author: Shelley M.

description:
I went for lunch. Between my wife and I we had three dishes. The Poutine (a French-Canadian dish) was quite good. It's a combination of fries, cheese and gravy. The fries were very good because they were crisp on the outside, fluffy on the inside and tasted very potato-y. Unlike the Canadian version which uses salty, but bland tasting curds of cheese (that hold their shape more) this version used a very flavorful white cheddar that melted nicely. The gravy was perhaps the best part since it was a lush sauce made with braised short ribs. There were even small chunks of the short ribs in it.

For mains, I had the shellfish stew and my wife had the petrale. My dish was pretty good. It included a fair number of mussels, clams and shrimp in a buttery aioli-type sauce with fingerling potatoes. My wife's dish includes a carrot side that was spiced with Moroccan spices and topped with a mint chutney. It was quite good, but her fish was woefully under-salted.

The service was somewhat lackluster. We got menus and bread right away, but then our waiter seemed to forget about us. We actually had to call him over to the table to take our order. I really wish waiters would read your body language and tell that you want to order. Once the food was ordered things seemed to flow fairly smoothly. 

I liked the decor, and the prices were steep (1 appetizer, 2 mains, no drinks = $56 before tip), but not any more so than the typical upscale place in that area and we did order two of the more expensive mains. There were many cheaper options that looked good. Nonetheless, Salt House seems more geared towards a business lunch than than a lunch with friends.
author: Yogi B.

description:
I immediately liked the interior, rustic bricks with exposed structures. I also liked our table under the stairs, until folks started walking up and down them, which created a kind of "percussionist playing steel drums in the subway" sound. 
We decided to share 5 apps, a salad (that failed to mention it was bitter and full of frisee) and a "suckling pig" dish over lentils that was dry and simply bad.
On the other hand, the service was right on and 3 other apps we had were creative and tasty. The poutin (potatoes, short rib gravy, and cheese), crispy shrimp with spicy green beans and serrano ham, and seared tuna over blanched leeks were all fantastic.
I would go back if invited, but would not make an effort to revisit on my own.
author: Clara I.

description:
Been here twice now, and have had two good, not great food experiences here, but my date was fantastic, so I do have to give credit t0 a restaurant that facilitates a good time. 

I love Town hall, and expected a lot from these guys,and decor wise they nailed it. It's cozy and kinda European baroque, the bar is small but charming. We had 8:15 reservations, showed up at 7:45 and saddled up to the bar. But, when I ordered my Manhattan on the rocks, it came up. When I very politely asked for the bartender to change it she informed me, not rudely, but cluelessly, that most Manhattan's come up. First off, they come both ways about the same, second, who cares, make it how I ordered it, third, don't justify your ineptness by an incorrect observation. Still, the date was going well, so I didn't really care and she made it right for me.

We sat down on time and ordered a nice bottle of Alsatian Riesling and enjoyed our appetizers,  but neither of us were wowed, as was my experience last time. The crab salad entree was good, but not from heaven, my pork tenderloin was good, not great, dessert was certainly competent, not one-of-a-kind, a couple ports at the end of dinner and we went back into my hood and finished off with drinks at the Madrone feeling a bit unsatisfied by the Salt House, but not especially bitter against it, and if offered I'd probably go back again, but their sister restaurant down the street, Town Hall, is greatly superior if not a bit more yuppiesh!
author: Steve l.

description:
Visited 4/11
   Like Town Hall, I thought the starters were much better than the mains - we had the shrimp and the smoked trout ($14, $13). A nice wine list to accompany everything as well as a full bar. Unlike Town Hall, the dessert menu was rather mundane. Service between starters and mains was slow, and two people next to us, who arrived after we did, got served ahead of us. I'd give it another go if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Chili Bill E.

description:
I liked this place. Nice ambience, great room and excellent service. I had the scallops and the ricotta gnocchi with crispy eggplant and pecorino - both were great. Others had the duck, sole and crispy shrimp with serrano & green beans appy - both looked great. Dessert for me was the medjool date cake with caramel sauce, peaches and butter pecan ice cream - it was as great as it sounds. In all courses, the portion size was perfect and thoughtfully prepared.

My only complaint was the watery espresso - you figure a restaurant that can pump out high-caliber food could make a decent espresso to pair with dessert...but then again I could just be picky :O)
author: Seann G.

description: Good food, nice fun ambiance.  for festive type of social business lunch it's works, but if you need a private quiet setting then go elsewhere.  it gets loud.
author: Dindy H.

description: Their dayboat scallops are delicious! I'm a big fan of the restaurant vibe as well. I love brick in any atmosphere. Thanks for making it an enjoyable night Salt House!
author: Mei F.

description: The food is ok.  The ambiance is cool.  The only thing that sucks is the layout.  It's almost uncomfortable to go there with a group.  Also, if you just want to stand up at the tables by the bar, make sure not to bring any bags.  It gets in the way.  Even when I was seated with just one other person, the next table was way too close.  Other than that, the food and service is good.
author: Christina B.

description: First time and I got burger.  Not worth the money nor the calories.  (Much better burgers within 3 blocks.)  Burger served raw and onion rings are not that good.  It was nice of them to comp me for me not eating it.  Also  no one checked on me sooner.  I would go again because other items seem to be a hit.
author: Patty M.

description: Been here a couple times - it's grown on me. A really cool space with great ambiance and a super friendly staff. Had dinner here last night and the food was delicious - I had the salmon and the tuna tartar.
author: Ossama A.

description: Great vibe to this place. Typically it is a bit too crowded for my taste, but what awesome service.  Hostess - polite and attentive; waiters - beyond reproach.  duck liver (fg) was one of the best I have ever had. In fact, it was perhaps the best I have ever had.  Place is certainly "Cool", and has lots of late 20s early 30s types. There is some nightclub next door.  Overall, I am truly a fan, and would definitely go back!
author: Yuri V.

description: Had dinner there last Sat. night (12/11/10).  The food and service was excellent.  Had the Tai Snapper and it was delicious.  Also the Kumamoto oysters were excellent.  Wine list was reasonable too.  Nice job guys!
author: Hawk M.

description:
I am very confused by this restaurant and the people who own it. The menu makes no sense I have no idea what their flavor concept is. The Baked Oysters was probably one the top ten worst things I've had the misfortune of ordering and eating. It was a pile of dry breadcrumbs on top of the oyster, foul! The shrimp in the appetizer salad was fishy and the dressing on the salad tasted as if Miracle whip was involved. 
The service was fantastic however, that's why they got two stars! The bartender made me a delicious Hot Toddy and the Waitress was terrific. I will not return and probably will not try Anchor & Hope either as I have now been to two out of three of their restaurants and if you read my Town Hall review you will see my experience was mediocre at best. Maybe it was a bad night for the kitchen.
I wish them luck maybe getting a better Chef and not relying on the great staff and interior will improve Salt House. But either way I'll never be back.
author: Matthew B.

description:
I happen to be at Salt House the night Obama was elected president.  At the moment CNN called the election at about 8:01pm there wasn't a peep in the place.  I'm not sure why.  You'd there would have been a big woohoo or an awww but things just moved forward in the restaurant like nothing had happened.  We toasted to the good news and enjoyed our food.

The monkfish was pretty amazing, broiled just right and served on top of red cabbage and corn with an amazing pork-based sauce.  It wasn't a very big portion, but I was satisfied with it and the bread the brought out ahead of time was excellent.

It was the first place I had been to in a good long while where the coffee was good & strong.  I drank it black ad it went down smooth.  Others in my party enjoyed their food very much, too.

It was pretty noisy.  The inside had the hip unfinished look.  The ceiling was raw and unfinished but looked great.  There just wasn't a lot of acoustic dampening and we all had to basically yell to have a decent conversation.

There was an amazing painting of don quixote on the far back wall which loomed over us as we ate.
author: Tracy R.

description:
I really should give this place five stars for being able to seat myself and the girl I was with instantly on a Friday, with no reservations. 

The food was very good and the fresh oysters were excellent. The wait staff was knowledgeable and very helpful. I spent $200 on food, a bottle of wine and appitizers, and for that price, I was VERY satisfied...
author: Adam L.

description:
Really great food. We came here to kill time before a movie at the Metreon. Ended up ordering several appetizers: pork belly, nectarine salad, a yellowtail or tuna tartare, and poutine. The last time I had poutine was from Pomme Frites in NYC. This was more upscale, but still very good. 

I definitely want to come back to try everything else on their menu.
author: Cyndi L.

description:
"Lainie, we want to go out to dinner - will you pick the restaurant?"

Ugh.  I get this a lot.  If you pick a restaurant and it sucks, your street cred tumbles.  Poutine popped into my head so I picked Salt House.

My whole goal in life was to have a bowl of Poutine to myself.  Yes, that's greedy but I don't care.  Fried potatoes, topped with cheese curds and short rib gravy.  I'm sorry, but you expect me to SHARE that?!?!?  But since the birthday boy said the following:  "Let's just order a bunch of things and share."  I had to acquiesce.  Altho I did not want to.  Frickin' birthdays.  

We ordered poutine, crispy shrimp, baked oysters, Monterey squid and the foie gras.   When the appetizers came up they sat the squid and oysters at my end of the table and the poutine at the other end.  I don't eat fish except for shrimp, scallops and sole.  I DO, however, eat potatoes smothered in cheese and gravy - I just stared as the plate of poutine made the rounds, landing at my seat LAST.  *sniff*  By then, it was almost cold and all the good stuff was gone. . .what I did get was good - a little different than I expected as I thought the cheese would be more cheesy  - it was more of a mornay sauce but tasty nonetheless.  The short rib gravy with little nuggets of meat was quite nice.  Once I got past my poutine preoccupation, I realized that the crispy shrimp was quite delicious - the shrimp itself being expertly cooked - tender, juicy and amazingly fresh.  With little shavings of jamon serrano, almonds, green beans and fresh greens, it was a lovely plate of food. . .the beans had a slightly spicy finish that I really enjoyed.   The foie gras was also a lovely plate - one coin of torchon and a small piece of expertly sauteed foie with a couple of thin slices of tea smoked duck breast that was flavorful and juicy.  

Dining out with civilians (i.e. non-restaurant type people) is sometimes taxing.  There are rules, dammit. . as in if you have a party of six that means you get to try SIX DIFFERENT entrees - huzzah for big parties!!!!  Well, boo for this one because four of those fools ordered the same thing.  WHAT?!?!?  Don't y'all know how to eat?!??!  Phooey!  (I know, I am sounding quite high maintenance, aren't I?). . .  So we had four orders of the Petrale Sole, I ordered the Fulton Valley chicken, and the person seated next to me ordered the New York Steak.  That chicken shall be what I judge all other chicken from now on.  An airline breast (which means it's the whole, boneless breast with the little wing drumette) and boneless thigh meat seasoned and seared to juicy perfection - it was perfectly executed.  With a creamy spinach puree, black trumpet mushrooms, roasted rutabaga and little tiny sticks of crispy bacon.   The steak, oh the steak, was also quite lovely.  Sliced and cooked to  perfect medium rare atop roasted sunchokes, Brussels sprouts with a little bonus piece of mustard crusted short rib.  At first, when I saw that little piece of short rib, I thought it was incongruous to the rest of the plate - it didn't seem to fit but it was so good. . .tender and well seasoned - the mustard crust off-setting the richness of the meat perfectly.  Besides, they gotta get that short rib gravy somewhere and what a great way to use the gravy dividend!  The four petrale sole eaters where also very happy.  A beautifully bronzed  portion of fish with clams, a delicately spiced red wine jus and the most delicious salsify puree - you never see salsify on a menu so that's one bonus but to have it so deftly prepared is wonderful.  I got stabbed with a fork for going in for one too many bites of that puree!  OUCH!

My mom loved her bread pudding and it was nice. . buttery and not too sweet.  The mint chip ice cream sandwiches would have been better if they had not used so many mini-chips in the ice cream. . I know, I am complaining about TOO MUCH chocolate?  But it was hard to eat - the flavor of the ice cream itself was great but perhaps more like a stracchiatella would have been nice.  The birthday boy got the Bittersweet Chocolate Cremeux - essentially a giant ball of smooth ganache atop a piece of genoise.  He kept saying "he couldn't possibly finish it all" as he CLEANED his plate. . this was my favorite dessert, too.  The pear/french toast dessert was not as well conceived as each component - it just didn't come together well but I loved the idea of brown butter ice cream!  The panna cotta was a little too tight for my liking but I loved the idea of the fennel fronds on the dessert. . .anyone who knows me knows that I have a personal vendetta on desserts with the ubiquitous mint leaves. . .. if it doesn't have mint in the dessert please for the love of Lenotre, leave off the mint leaves!  

All in all a great night - excellent food, deft service and happy friends.  

Street cred intact!
author: Lainie L.

description: So I admit, we were a little drunk when we arrived at Salt House after visiting the Press Club so that may have skewed our taste buds slightly.  But this place was wayyy enjoyable.  The food was amazingly, the service was great, and ambiance super cool.  Not sure if this is a "first date" place as the room is rather noisy, but definitely a good date place otherwise.  Would love to go back when next in SF again!
author: Catie B.

description:
Solid food, good staff, great location and atmosphere.  They change the food periodically, the most recent PBLT, pork belly lettuce tomato is out of this world.  Don't forget the burger with the shoestring onion rings, awesome.

Only reason why they don't get 5 stars, is that I have been there over 15 times and no one would recognize me.  In any case, SF dining establishments are horrible with personalized service, unfortunately we (I) accept it as the norm.

Try it, doubt you will walk away hungry.
author: Command C.

description: Can I fairly review a place after only having a glass of wine there? Probably not, but here I am anyway. I was their by myself having a mini celebration in my head so I got a lot of time to look at the interior details. Its kind of like Old English, meets American Colonial, meets Urban Industrial. Think unfinished and nobby plank wood on the floor, black leather studded bar stools, exposed steel beam for a small upstails loft seating area, a few high back chairs in the dining area, a long wood high top behind me that extends the bar area. I could see this being a perfect after work place. My pinot noir was nice (yes the 18 dollar glass, but like I said this was a mini celebration so no expense was spared). The bar tender provided good conversation and the rest of the staff seemed really friendly as well... will have to go back for food so that I can give a more well rounded review.
author: Kelly W.

description: Nice atmosphere but mediocre food. Pleasant service. Seems like a nice place to pop in for a drink but not if you're looking for 4 star meal
author: Royce L.

description: The Salt house is nothing less that euphoric, the food is perfection with no detail left to chance, each flavor herb and delicate touch of taste is a absolute treat for every taste bud. The wine, cocktails and dessert are enchanting. This place starts off amazing and finishes with just as much attention to detail. A real San Francisco classic.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Nice atmosphere.  Good service at the bar and table.  The hostess seated us promptly.  The food was OK.  I started with the scallops and moved on to the sole.  The scallops were good, served in a nice sauce with beans.  I was excited about the sole as it included shrimp and squids, but it was just OK... could have been tastier.  Not sure if I'll go back.
author: Nury Is S.

description:
Four of us went to Salt House on Saturday night.  We sat at the communal table (which is smaller than the one at Town Hall, but which has a similar feel).  

The restaurant is beautiful and well designed.  We certainly appreciated the rustic, steel, wood, brick and concrete materials and the follow-through on the serving dishes (milk jug for water, e.g.). For people who appreciate good architecture, Salt House will be a joy.

And, then there is the food and drink.  Overall, I would say there are still some kinks to be worked out.  We had five appetizers, three of which were good. The other two need work and were too complex (perhaps too odd) for our palate.  The beets didn't work for us.  They were served roasted with cured salmon and horseradish sauce.  Very strange mix -- and the horseradish was overpowering while the salmon made us wonder "why do these beets smell oddly like fish?"

The sprimp (overly battered and fried) and green beans (which themselves were good, spicy and crisp) were served in an almost Indian (orange) curry sauce that was at once too milky and too flavorful for the beans.   The combination of flavors did not really work for us. The shrimp were covered in a heavy batter that left the shrimp feeling, well, shrimpy.  The green beans (prepared as they were) would be better served without the gloppy Indian curry sauce, in my view.

We liked the -- get this -- mixed nuts with honey and salt.  What is not to like?  (Also, not exactly the most difficult dish to prepare).  At $4, this should be at every table.

The quartered potato with spare rib gravy and Roquefort was quite good.  The potato was fried crispy with a bit of spare rib and spare rib jus and some Roquefort on top.  Hard to complain about good cheese and spare rib jus delivered on a potato.  This is the McDonald's approach:  start with a fried potato and add anything to it and it will taste good.

The spicy roasted (or broiled?) oysters were quite nice.  The oysters themselves were tasty and the spicy topping (with green chilies) was a good compliment with good flavor.  Some of the oysters were much more spicy than others, but in general this dish worked well; even the non-Oyster eater in our crowd enjoyed it.

The acme bread was, as always, good.

In terms of the wine list, I would give it a "B".  There was nothing to be excited about, though it did touch each key San Francisco base (organize the wine on some principle other than color and region; have some decent, under $50 bottles; have a few expensive bottles; throw in a curve ball or two for the guy looking for something unique).  No wine awards for this list because it simply isn't that interesting or unusual.  Prices were fine.  You can find a good bottle, but this isn't a "wine restaurant" -- the list is quite limited. 

They also have a concept I have never seen before which is "wine barrel" wines, which they offer by the 8 oz, 12 oz or 24 oz serving out of the barrel.  I had never heard of the wineries and they did not carry vintages.  Seemed a bit pricey for garage wine -- if that is what it is.  We didn't try it.    

Overall, I would say:  this place will be mobbed with the crowd that wants to try every new "cool" restaurant. The decor insures that.  The foodies will enjoy the experiment, but if they can't reduce the complexity and some of the odd pairings, many of the foodie crowd will likely give up on the place. Wine people will be bored and show up just once. Fortunately for the owners, there are enough people in this town who will like the decor and won't care about the food to keep it busy for the next year.
author: Greg T.

description:
Too loud.  Too Crowded.
I'm fine with dropping the money on a meal.  However, I want a warm welcoming feeling, with a great meal and service.  
There are too many great places to eat...but I'll try to get around to this one again.  Perhaps on a random Tuesday would be better than a Friday?

I went again on a Thursday.  The food is good, the service was better.  Honestly, it is still not living up to the hype.
author: Mackenzie O.

description:
The food was good but not great.  The prices were high for the portion sizes.  The service was fantastic, except for the bartenders (who were more interested in the single girls than the patrons).

For apps, we had a dozen oysters (three each of four different varieties) and the suckling pig.  Both the oysters and the pig were good!

For mains, two of us had the ribeye ($29) and one had the sea bass ($25-ish).  The sea bass was good, but a bit too fishy tasting and smelling.  The ribeyes were good, but we had to wait extra long since we both ordered rare and they let us know that they over-cooked both on the first try.  Not a big deal, but we did have to wait about 15 minutes longer than the "two minutes" that the runner told us to expect.  Again, everything was good, but not great.

For dessert, we shared the chocolate pot de creme.  That was fantastic!

All in all, it's a *good* place with solid food and a hip vibe.  Downsides are the high prices (compared with other SF eateries with much better food) and the inattentive bar staff.
author: Jason R.

description:
Decent sunday evening meal, didn't need reservations and only had to wait 5 mins to get a table.  Shared their poutin for starter just fancy cheesey fries with gravy, good but not up to the class they are trying to meet.

Their bread is better than most.  I had Duck for main course, it was ok, small portion even for this kind of restaurant.  Partner had gnocchi which went over very well.

House wine was decent.  Not the most amazing ambiance.  Prices were good. Just as well because there was nothing amazing.
author: Louis M.

description:
My fave dining partner and I met at the bar for a stellar martini (although she was charged $8 and I was charged $9 - smaller tip for the 'tender, since I only got $1 from my $10).

We had some outragously good oysters to slurp with the vodka. I had the petrale sole - incredible! It was sauteed just crispy, served on farro and corn - it rocked all over the place. My friend had the steak on morel mushroom puree, with more morels - they must have a great mushroom connection. Outstanding food.

We walked in w/out a rez and were greeted nicely and told the table we could have needed to be vacated at 7:30 - we were in and out with three courses (oh, we had a incredible dessert like a toffee pudding - I'm blanking what it was, aside from knocked out socks off. The espresso wasn't so much, though.

Highly pricy -  two glasses of wine, 8 oysters, two mains and a dessert and two espressos we hit $150 with tip. It was worth it, but the menu prices are breathtaking.
author: Renee R.

description: Consistently excellent.  The only downside is that the bar area can get crowded and the open space noisy which can make conversation dfficult.  However, the service, ambiance, and food are all first rate.  Quick tips: Grey Goose martini with a lime twist.  Anything on the menu involving foie gras or scallops, or both. Brunello di Montalcino (or the Montepulciano).
author: Liam S.

description: Just returned from an amazing meal at the Salt House. I had the halibut and it was cooked to perfection - moist and delicious. You may say, what is so fascinating about chicken, but my partner had it and I must say it was superb - came with an interesting combination of veggies including black-eyed peas - yummy. Overall, the presentation was lovely, the service impeccable and the food quite delicious!!! From the outside, you wouldn't think that this place was anything special - but REALLY not to be missed!
author: T F.

description: I came here on a Saturday night and it was pretty crowded (had to wait about a half hour before we were seated).  The service was okay, but wasn't the greatest...our waiter kind of lagged.  The food was fine, but I've had better...I ordered the Ahi Tuna as my entree and the Peanut Butter bar for desert, which were both okay, but nothing special.  Nice ambiance but probably won't be on my "go-back-to" list.
author: Jules A.

description:
We loved Salt House.  But loved it.  Once you find it, it's all good from there.  It's sort of the little short building amidst all the other stuff.

Inside the space is really cool, sort of industrial chic.  Love the open plan, open kitchen thing.  It was full, but not grossly crowded and annoying.  Not near as loud as I was expecting (nothing like NOPA for god's sake), but had a fun, vibrant energy.  And the food, was a hit with both of us.  

We got the nuts as a yelp recommendation and, I don't know if we were just really hungry or what, but they were just scrumptous.  Get them.  I know they are just mixed nuts, but throw some honey, truffle oil ,sea salt and  serve them hot and all of the sudden it's like they are some sort of gourmet thingamajig.  

We did fish for the main courses and both the halibut and the sole were spectacular.  They weren't tiny either like most places these days.  They actually gave you some food to eat.  It wasn't like a bucket of chicken at KFC, but it was enough to not feel ripped off.  It wasn't cheap, but again it wasn't like so many of these places where you feel as though you are being robbed and starved at the same time.  

Thumbs way up.
author: Matt R.

description:
Overall, OK at best...
(this review is long overdue so forgive me for being vague)
Didn't have to wait too long to get seated...
Was not impressed with the appetizers....i.e.  the taste oysters was overpowered by bacon bits...
The entrees were pretty good... i ordered the steak, and the ladies ordered bass and duck... the presentation of the entrees were aesthetically pleasing...
I'm usually not a fish person but the bass was really good... firm and lightly marinated.. duck and steak were really tender..... 
Portions were pathetic.... 
Desserts were disappointing.... the chocolate cake was decent... ginger tart on the other hand... pathetic... couldn't even taste a hint of ginger... 
Good selection of beer/wine/port....
Unfortunately, it wouldn't be a restaurant I'd want to go back to...
author: Johnny Z.

description: An old paper factory? That's a cool venue I have to say. I came here for "dine about town" but got more than the menu had. For appetizer (not on dine about town menu) we got the famous poutine, which had rather simple ingredients, but was very delicious. Following the dine about town menu, I got the butternut soup which was about 5 tablespoons in a huge plate, but it had a very rich flavor. Also, the bread they served with butter was delicious, and in an interesting form (like a log). For my main dish I got the morrocan chicken salad, which was alright. I feel like they may have been "experimenting" with the items on the "dine about town" menu, so they were not as great as some of the pricier options on the menu. But still the salad had an array of ingredients, and it was rather filling. Lastly, for dessert, we got the pomegranate cheesecake, which was delicious. Everyone must try it, it was beyond what words can explain. Definitely will try this place again.
author: Nikita K.

description:
I had what could only be described as the worst service ever here. It was a comedy of errors for the whole night. 30 minutes with just water, some bread and then no one took our wine order for another 15 minutes, meanwhile the people next to us were finishing their meal, despite the fact that we sat down at about the same time.

When the food arrived my girlfriend's meal was undercooked, but both plates were very tasty. Can't comment on the price as it was my birthday and I didnt pay.

So why did I give the place 4 stars? When we spoke with the manager about the horrible service and the undercooked meal, he immediately comped everything and gave us a voucher to come back at a discount.

Everyone has an off night and my dinner was actually very good, so I'll give them another shot based on the managers atempts to fix things.
author: Sean M.

description:
i used to drink alot. i mean ALOT. 

like drink a couple bottles of grey goose in a night..... 

i started to restrict the drinking a bit....

then in 2006 i think it was, i started to hang out with yelpers.

typical starter drink would be a triple grey goose in a cup. id usually have three or four of these. 

these days, after three or four drinks, i tend to cut if off. i get tired. my face makes the drunk face...... 

i digress....

so this one night, i had dinner reservations with a certain couple.... HI JEFF!!!! HI TIFF!!!! congrats once again!!!!

come the night of the highly anticipated dinner...... the couple theres. me? im drunk in oakland.... 

*palm to forehead, D'OH*

sorry guys!!!!

its a good thing ive calmed down the drinking. i can remember things and for the most part i dont make an ass of myself.....

but dont worry, there will STILL BE EUGETASTIC EVENTS SOON, just not  liquor fueled.

the lady and i decide to do date night last night. she made a reservation at an undisclosed location... she done did good.

this is how i want my house to look. exposed brick, a hovering loft area, big open kitchen..... enough room to park a few motorcycles and a ferrari.... nice. 

right to it. 

salt house. i knew i would love you. SALT how can you not like salt. 

list of things that were excellent.

foie gras, two ways. 

crispy shrimp!!!! damn good

duck confit

chicken seemed a bit dry, but i dont like white meat. so meh. the skin was DELICIOUS

the duck breast....

ok everything was good. service was good enough. i love this place. 

and theres parking next door. 

you will see me here all the time now.
author: Euge L.

description:
The service was great. The food - ok. Tried the scallops for appetizers - they were a bit overdone and a bit salty as well. The sweet corn with the scallops didnt go too well. 

Tried the halibut for the main course. The fish was again a bit over crisped on the outside and the green sauce and the peppers didnt really do much to augment the fish.
author: Getafix O.

description:
I went here yesterday evening (Sunday) on a balmy evening about 7 PM or so..it was mostly empty, and quiet...what a lovely spot though, exposed beams, very old San Francisco, but also modern in a way...

Started with the Fois Gras, and I thought it was just perfect, and we wiped the plate up like peasants...

Then a Breaded Deep Fried Egg, which was tasty and interesting but a little awkward as an appetizer.

I ordered a steak over Vegetables (gotta watch those Carbs!) and it was just perfect... we had brought a bottle of Papapietro-Perry Russian River Pinot Noir, Peters Vineyard 2000, which was lovely, Corkage was $20..

Dessert (which I didn't touch) was an Orange Tart, which my dinner companion did not like, so we had a couple of 18 yr old scotches to make us warm an sleepy..

The staff was very attentive and non formal (which I like), but there were probably more staff there than patrons!

Then we walked home, to watch the current installment of "John Adams", on HBO (wonderful as usual) , and drifted off into the night..

What a great evening - thanks Blake!
author: Eric H.

description: Went here for a lunch.  Glad she made reservations as the place was fairly packed.  I had been meaning to try it and I was pleased with just about everything - although it was a little hectic.  Had the chicken cordon bleu sandwich which was outstanding.
author: Robert U.

description: This place is just consistently solid.  Great food, great atmosphere, great drinks.  The poutine is a wonderful starter to share (ask for extra gravy) even if not traditional.  The foie gras dish is great--delicious portion of seared foie plus a disk of torchon which goes great on the toasted brioche they serve with it.  This is one of those perfect consistent and casual places that you always know you will have good food and a fun time.
author: Andy K.

description:
I tried this place for dine about town b/c I've heard good reviews about it.  

The service is 4 star.
The food is good, about 3 star.  Average is 3.5 star.

I had their salad and pork shoulder.
Both were a little on the salty side, but tasted great.  Nice salad, very few on the greens and lots of peas, and some fava beans.  I really enjoyed this salad, but the dressing was overly salty.
The pork shoulder was nice and tender, but again, the sauce was overly salty. 

Is this why they call it the salt house? lol
My companion had the creamy leak soup - this is good, but very very creamy.
The pasta - this was very good and well seasoned.

For my dishes they were overly salty, so I give it a 3.  If I had the soup and pasta - I think it would have been a 4 b/c those were seasoned perfectly.

I would try them again.
author: Lillian M.

description:
id rather go to Town Hall.

good, friendly service.  nice looking place and good atmosphere.  crowd is whatever.

fairly tasty, decent sized dishes.  didnt really wow me though, and for the price theres better options.  skip the suckling pig - not what i expected at all, and the way its prepared (pulled and cured and mashed into a cube) is really a waste of a tender suckling pig.
author: Junglist S.

description:
i used to work literally a block away from this place but never actually managed to make my way over until the last week of my previous job. since it was done by the same guys over at anchor and hope (which i love) and town hall (which i like), i had moderate expectations for this place and ended up getting a shrimp & lobster roll. the flavor was good and the house-made potato chips were great, but i don't know if it was good/unique enough to justify the price tag. maybe it's just what i ordered but i'd still stick with town hall or anchor and hope going forward

bottom-line: great ambiance and service + quality (but not exceptional and slightly overpriced) food.
author: wendy q.

description:
ANOTHER UPDATE: Salt House is definitely a class act operation. My follow-up lunch was wonderful. True to their word, SH did a major bombing over the holiday and there wasn't a heebie jeebie dance inducer in sight, and I looked hard to be sure I would be telling the truth in my follow up. Although my first lunch was only a week ago, I couldn't help ordering the same thing this week - delicious corn soup and a vegetarian spring vegetable ragout (not on the menu, just ask for a vegetarian entree) Again, both were wonderful. I also couldn't help asking for a side of the spicy potato chips - they are sooo amazing. My friend, who loved his burger last week (with gourmet cheese and a beautiful roasted tomato), got the duck this week and polished his plate clean. Apparently it was really good. :)  This week, we had time for dessert and we each ordered a warm chocolate cake (what I call 'melty cake') with cherries and pistachio ice cream . It was beyond perfect.  On both visits I really enjoyed the expertise of our servers, making astute recommendations on both wine and food based on what we were ordering and how we described our tastes. 

I also have to say I was not only impressed they caught my first review, immediately corrected the problem I described and invited me back, but they also handled the freebie with complete grace. We didn't have a single second of the awkwardness that can come with saying 'um, I'm not supposed to pay for lunch today' or some such. All the way around  the staff at this restaurant is well-organized, graceful and definitely concerned that their clientle has a great experience in their restaurant. 

I am looking forward to going back.

UPDATE: I've received a wonderful PM from Salt House explaining they are bombing this coming week so no more heebie geebies! They've also offered a meal to apologize for my dancin'. Im very impressed with their customer service. I've given them one star back, and if the next meal is as great as the last pre-visitor, I'm  sure I will be giving them back the other as well.

ORIGINAL:

I'm really torn about what number of stars to give this one. 

We had a wonderful lunch. The corn soup (veggie!) was extraordinary, and the vegetarian corn risotto thing the chef made for me was so fresh and yummy you wouldn't know it was a spontaneous creation to feed the veggie in the house. Service was warm, friendly and fun, and they have a great selection of house blends on the wine list. I like the Athena! We also shared the spicy potato chips that were sooo good, and I ate all the onion rings from my friend's burger plate. Total heaven.

So, seems like a 5 star no brainer right?

Well, it was perfect up until the very end when I picked up my purse to go. There was a ROACH on it. My friend, being the chivalrous guy he is, attempted to brush it off, but then it ended up *in* my purse. Yup. I had a roach in my purse. 

So, minus two stars for making me do the OMG THERES A ROACH IN MY PURSE heebie jeebie dance in the middle of a crowded restaurant.

I need a drink now.
author: Lise L.

description:
It's hard to walk down the streets of San Francisco without tripping over a good restaurant, and that's exactly what happened to us on the way back from some Commonwealth Club Yelp talk thingy. While walking to the parking lot we discovered Salt House. (Great parking lot right there, something like $10 for four hours. A steal compared to a lot of San Francisco lots.) The place looked inviting, so we wandered in.

For schlubs like us with no reservation, there was a half hour wait for a table (7:30pm on a Thursday), but they did have some first come, first serve seating at the bar, at a communal table (which looked pretty cool, if a bit cramped) and at the window.

Now, when you think window seating, don't think romantic little tables in a prime spot, it's like they squeezed a shelf into the window behind the staircase leading up to their enticing looking upstairs area...you have to duck under the staircase to get to your seat, and once they found us another chair, we joined four other patrons also dining on the window "shelf".

Please don't think I'm complaining, it was kind of cool and the staff were really good about checking up on us and giving us good service even though they had to squeeze under the stairs and contort themselves to wait on us from behind our backs. The only part I didn't like about this seating, as the only one there with a skirt on, was that our legs, probably my cootch, or whatever, were exposed under the table, through the window, and somewhat elevated, for all passers-by to gape at. A tablecloth or some sort of window covering for the area below the shelf would be a nice touch. Who knows, maybe they feel it makes the place look more inviting? (It may depend on what exactly is being exposed there, and who your target audience is. And, it didn't make me feel any better when some jerk on his parked moped across the street turned on his high-power headlight, pointed it at the restaurant and just left it there for about five minutes.)

Oh yeah, and we had some food! That's why I'm writing a review, and probably why you're reading it.

I was worried when we first got the menu. The wine list looked very promising, but the short-ish menu had NO vegetarian entrees. No worries, though...they made me a special vegetarian entree including "the vegetables they have that day with a starch". The starch was barley, which I love, and my dish was very creamy and delicious. I tried to tell myself that the creaminess was from the barley, but it may just have been cooked in a crapload of butter. It was topped with some curly greens which I would normally just push aside, but they had a tasty, lemoney vinegarette on them that made me want to eat every bit of food on my plate (which I don't normally do. No, really!)

We also had some delicious poutine, although of course I asked for the gravy to be on the side, so technically it wasn't really poutine any more. There were also some tasty, tasty olives that were highly seasoned with something like lime, chili and rosemary (or was it thyme?) and my bf had the lamb which he said was quite good.

For dessert, we had the apple turnovers with rum raisin ice cream. It tasted like a little slice of Thanksgiving, totally delicious! The rum raisins make it seem like you have a bit of apple AND a bit of mincemeat. The cheese course was also a nice surprise...I ordered the sheep camembert for $6 and because of the price I was expecting what I've had at other restaurants; a miniscule portion of cheese with a tiny garnish on a huge plate (I'm looking at you, Marche in Menlo Park) but instead received two nice little wedges along with some seasoned, croutoned bread slices.

This restaurant reminds me of why we go to so much trouble to go eat in San Francisco sometimes. They got everything right, from the service to the perfectly portioned and seasoned, interesting menu items and awesome wine list. Even the price is competitive for the food/ambiance/location. 

I have no hesitation in giving this restaurant five stars based on MY experience here, however I thought I'd mention that the noise level is a bit high (it didn't bother my bf, though) and the people seated to one side of us arrived some time before us but didn't receive their entrees until we were having dessert. They didn't seem too put out about whatever the problem was, though...their server brought them a couple complementary bowls of soup to make up for the wait and they slurped up every last drop.

Next Commonwealth Club event, I have a feeling we'll be back here again. Maybe...with a reservation even.
author: Laura 'jinx.tv' K.

description: The scallop appetizer was one of the most memorable I've had.  Great atmosphere and an awesome space.
author: Vitor L.

description: I just finished dinner here on their first night open to the public, and it was fantastic. The attention to detail and follow-thru of the rustic/artistic feel is amazing. Water was served out of old milk bottles imprinted with their skull and bone logo. Lamps were designed from postcard racks, and the Acme bread was wrapped nicely in brown paper. Our waitress was fantastic and extremely knowledgeable and made sure everything came on time. We ordered tomato tart and fries with gravy to start, both very good. Our main dishes were the bass and chicken and both were perfectly portioned and paired with great small sides and presented beautifully on the plate. Salt House is going to become a favorite and for a first night, everything ran so amazing. Main dishes will run about 15 for the burger and 27 for steak. Menu is said to change and I hope they add a vegetarian plate soon.
author: Alyssa C.

description: This place is okay NOT great.  The service was fine, food was nothing special.  The best part about Salt is being able to park my motorcycle right out front.
author: Mia T.

description: I intend on frequenting the Salt House, not only because the location is conveniently a stone's throw from my work, but because the food is solid, the service is kind and the upstairs seating is charming.  I enjoyed everything I've ordered at Salt House (especially their salads!) and appreciate it when a more expensive restaurant serves hearty portions. Do give it a try.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
What could have amounted to disdain or fury resulted in a pleasant surprise.  A free lunch.  After nibbling on a delicious appetizer of smoked trout with green goddess dressing and tender baby butter lettuce leaves my cohort and I awaited our lunch time main course.   And waited . . . and watched the table adjacent to us receive their main course despite their substantially later arrival.  My wine was gone.  I had hoped that a smidgen of it would be left to sip along with the cool creamy wild nettle soup, but alas my thirst outstripped my patience.  Still on the clock and not desirous of a two hour lunch, my dining partner and I were displeased with the error in service.  However, due to my previous visits to the Salt House and the courteous and truly compensatory way in which the glitch was addressed, I encourage all wondering around in SOMA to duck into the Salt House and enjoy peering at the old rafters and rough hewn eating surfaces.

Recommendation: the house white wine (a pinot gris) is fabulous and even more fabulously priced.  The indulgent poutine will knock your socks off and can easily be split between three people as an appetizer that should be followed by a lighter course.
author: Chalk A.

description: This is a solid 4 yelp star place.  Townhall has an edge on their sister.  The poutine is still soaked in my arm fat.  You can't beat fries with beef gravy.  Yum.  The oysters with spinach and bacon were just ok.  My braised short rib was really good.  Very tender and nicely seasoned.  The lamb loin was also pretty good.  Not gamey and cooked perfectly.  The fulton chicken was also good.  Mi madre said that was the best chicken she ever had.  Next time I need to take her to Range in the Mission.  Their version was freakin ridiculous.  The chocolate layer cake was fresh frozen.  The icing and the center of the slice of cake was literally frozen.  W.T.F. mate?  As a foodie that should be negative 10 stars for serving frozen shit in this type of restaurant.  If you are going to server frozen desserts please defrost it before you serve it.  Noobs.
author: Fatty A.

description: It's pretty much as good as it gets here.....what more can i say?? I went there for valentines day and had the BEST time.  The food was delicious; I had a crab and artichoke appetizer and then an amazing chicken dish for my main course, both were outstanding!  The wine we had was also great(although I can't remember now which one we had), the staff was extremely accomodating, and the decor was very cool.  They also had a nice bar which seemed like it would be a very fun place to go for happy hour drinks too....5 stars for this place!
author: Liz L.

description: I love town hall- but I really love the Salt House. The exposed beams and brick make me feel like I am back in the south. The food was on time, and indulgent, and I had uber great service. I am a huge fan of the owner and his management style.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
don't even THINK about taking any white trash family members that are in from out of town here... heh. 

also, you may want to consider NOT wearing the sweater you stole from your granny's closet last christmas.  well actually, strike that.  it may keep you from being hit on by drunk investment bankers after the kim kardashian look-alike turned them down.  ouch, that was mean.

the food here is actually quite good.  awesome oysters, delicious poutine, great cocktail menu, perfectly cooked seafood and the wait staff is very friendly, helpful with suggestions and overly efficient.  the issues are with the clientele, who seem to be between hashing out business dealings and trying to get laid.  that, and the pricing. 

simply said, salt house is delicious, but overpriced and WAY not my scene.  i would suggest coming here if you were being treated, you had an actual reservation at a private table (not the communal table for walk-ins) and it was on a tuesday night.
author: Jessie J.

description: Love this place...what a great addition to SOMA dining.  It's no surprise that this gem comes from the same people as Town Hall (another fantastic place). The decor is beautiful, the service is good, and the food is delicious. The poutine and crispy shrimp are yummy apps and the striped bass is heaven on a plate.  But the best part is the desserts - the cookie platter is a must-have for a group.  The only thing I would change about this place is the salt! For a place called Salt House, I would have a cool salt presentation on the table like Hawaiian black salt or a salt block.
author: Aimee G.

description:
Like someone else said... I can't put my finger on it, but it just didn't feel right.

1.  Service was GREAT.  Our wait staff was very attentive. That is  the only reason I am giving it a 3.
2.  The food was okay... I had the scallops and their special soup was french onion for the day... both were fair.. not great... not bad.  My companions all the hamburger, which looked good, but the onion rings were very very very and I do mean very greasy!
3.  The menu doesn't have a great selection.  I was surprised that they didn't have anything that they would or could make a standard salad with.  
4.  Absolutely and I do mean ABSOLUTELY no flexibility on the menu to meet diet restriction.
5.  The bathroom is co-ed.  Like the show Ally McBeal.  Very odd... and you have to walk out of the rest. through a hallway to find the bathroom
6.  We sat at the front of the rest. which is probably the best place to sit because if you sit in the back the ventilation from the open kitchen wasn't great and you could see a hover of smoke.  

I wouldn't go back.. nor would I every recommend this place to anyone to try.
author: Robin G.

description:
i agree w/ niki.  the food here is pretty good, but the service was awful.  the wait staff was great and courteous and all, but the kitchen moves WAY too slow.  first of all, we had a reservation for 745, but we were not seated until 815, so i was starving by the time we were finally seated.  

we started w/ appetizers, and the best one was by far the poutin...french fries smothered w/ gorgonzola and brisket gravy...YUM!!  i think this was the highlight of the meal.  the ribs were not that great, as it came w/ 3 ribs that were mainly bones.  this made it quite difficult to share among 5 people.  the crispy shrimp were pretty good.

for my entree, i had the shellfish stew, which was basically a big bowl of clams, mussels, and shrimp.  i was hoping for something more like a cioppino or bouillabaise, but no such luck.  it was tasty enuf, but i was left wanting something more.

the desserts were pretty good.  i would definitely go w/ the butter pecan sundae, which apparently is made w/ homemade ice cream.  i believe it, b/c it literally took 20 minutes from the time we ordered dessert to the time the sundae arrived at the table.  it had me thinking that they were actually churning the ice cream in the kitchen after we ordered it.

by the way, i wouldn't come here for a first date, b/c the place is LOUD!
author: Helen T.

description: This place just has a great future.  Relaxed but trendy atmosphere, a great wine list, attentive and smart service and the food holds its own.  The oysters are especially good here...as is the smoked salmon starter.  It is always crowded but the staff does a great job of getting you seated.  I went at 8 on a weeknight with no reservations and was seated in about 5 minutes.  Definitely worth checking out.
author: Graham A.

description: PROVISIONAL REVIEW: Doug Washington and the Rosenthal brothers have snapped up Harveen Khera, the former chef-owner of the now shuttered Tallula, to run the bar at their new tavern.
author: Hao L.

description: It's all about the poutine!  If you don't know what poutine is, find the nearest Canadian and ask them what greasy snack food puts American chili-cheese fries to shame.
