Real poutine is made with cheese curds that are then melted via hot gravy over a bed of fries . . I know, it sounds questionable, eh?  Well, Salt House's take on poutine is heavenly . . . crisp potato wedges topped with rich gorgonzola sauce are then doused with a short rib gravy.   Accompanied by a cold beer or crisp white wine, it makes for a little slice of foodie heaven :)   Now if only the rest of the menu could bring such pleasure . . .
author: tiffany t.

description:
I was planning to write a review of my Friday night dinner at Salt House anyway, but after reading the 7/28 posting by marinmezz, I am even more inspired to do so!  

Yes, our table spilled red wine on the bag.  We offered to pay for the purse and provided our contact information on the spot.  The guys at the table were very gracious and we hoped the incident would end at that.  Unfortunately that was not the case.

When marinmezz got back to her table, she stood up and yelled "Who the  #@!* spilled wine on my bag!".... We again apologized and explained the situation, but it seemed to do no good.  The owner tried to help and took her over to the bar area to talk with her, but she was having none of it.  When she got back to her table, she continued to make snide comments about "how rude and careless" we were and that we had better learn manners.  We tried to apologize yet again and kept saying it was a mistake, and she replied "the only mistake was you being born."

I had it at that point and even offered to write her a check on the spot to please put this behind us, but she would not calm down.  At that point, the owner came back and asked their group to leave.  We were surprised, but grateful.  The bag was not a family heirloom, nor did she pay thousands of dollars.  I understand her being upset, but she took it to quite the extreme.

The staff apologized to us and the other diners.  The service was excellent, the food was amazing, and we were happy to go back to our meal.  The biggest surprise of the evening was a good one -- Salt House comped our entire meal... everything was on the house.  Of course we left a generous tip and will certainly be back with more friends... and no spilled wine!

Thank you to a great staff and co-owner Doug Washington... truly great customer service.  Thank you to all the other diners that had to unwittingly share in this event.  We appreciate your support!
author: Christina C.

description:
What makes a good Monday? Drunkenness under the stairs. 

J. and I were going to go to John Colins for drinks, but I showed up first and grouchy and was in no mood for the office stiffs that were milling aimlessly around the place. (Mind you, I too am technically an office stiff. But these folks were extra stiff.) So I left J. a message telling her to call me when she was on her way and I'd let her know where I landed. 

Next came a frustrating stroll around SOMA in search of a bar that wasn't too over-the-top anything (crowded, expensive, pretentious, divey). I was looking for middle of the road and let me tell you I was walking in aimless figure eights between Mission and Folsom and Fremont and 4th and getting no boozy love and getting grumpier. 

So Jessica called and suggested Salt House. We'd been there once before, and we had a great time, but it was also our third stop on a Wednesday night bender, so the details are a little fuzzy. I remember a friendly bartender and a pork belly appetizer that was better than bacon. 

This time, we arrived and sat in an awkward but very cozy spot at the low counter in the front window under the stairs that lead to nowhere, presently, but will eventually lead to a little mezzanine area. Our waitress had to duck to accommodate us and we worried for her noggin. But she was incredibly friendly and gracious, she checked in with us regularly despite our hidden spot under the stairs and kept us in gin and wine to our hearts' content. 

We shared two appetizers, the yellow fin tuna tartar with roasted beets and candied hazelnuts. A truly weird and unexpected combination, but it was delicious and full of pleasing textures. We also shared the asparagus salad with smoked trout that was very good. Though it was a little stingy on the trout, but not so much to make a fuss. 

In all, we spent almost three hours there, mostly wining, but also dining, and we had a fabulous time. I will make a point to go back for the full experience soon and hope I won't have the bad luck that others seem to with the mediocre service and food.
author: Sage R.

description:
The trio behind Town Hall appears to have opened up their 2nd venture to be. The space mixes a similar crowd, like Town Hall, that is just down the street, but I must say the I liked the crowd at Salt House better -- WAYY better. *nods* yesh, a yuppie crowd to be... it's got an interesting set up, with seatings upstairs, and a lower level - for some reason, even though I sat on the lower level, I felt a bit scared even looking at the upper level. Iono why. Drinks were relatively average priced, ranging $5 for beers, and up. Their cocktail, I ferget which one I ordered wasn't all that great either, and of course their wine wasn't something to be impressed about, since I knew what I had wanted.

We first ordered several hama hama's and they were quite tasty ($2.50/oyster). Rather than pigging out, we decided to grab 3 appetizers and enjoy each other's company. 
-crispy shrimp (served w/green beans, almonds, and ham) $14 - PASS. Basically, tempura style shrimp but worse. Not worth it.
-Dayboat scallops ($14): sry Salt House, PASS for the 2nd time. Something about it just didn't taste right.
-Foie Gras (cured/sauted) $19. As a foie gras whore, I wasn't thoroughly impressed, it was probably the better of the 3 appetizers we had ordered, but it wasn't all that wonderful. It was good, but not $19 good. You'd expect some hot stuff, but eh...

When I requested for Tabasco, they serve it in this genie type bowl, and lacked a few points there..

iono if i'd return...
author: Jennifer S.

description:
more hits than misses..but man was the wait & food service gnarly.  was here last nite (tues) for a friends birthday.  party of 5, reso at 7:45, didn't get seated until 8:15.  one strike.  our server was nice and the starters came out in a fair amount of time, but i think we waited a good half hour for the entrees to come out.  two strikes.

what saved the experience for me was the food.  savory, salty & succulent.  best starter was the poutine.  i guess you really can't go wrong with starch, cheese & gravy.  crunchy shrimp was also tasty and packs a lot of heat.  pastrami ribs were so-so but i really liked the creamy apple sauce that came with.  i had the duck leg confit entree which was fabo.  perfectly tender and loved the crunchy greens it was served with.  for dessert: homemade butter pecan ice cream (yum) and the apple galette (so-so).

but for the wait and slow service i think i'd go with 4 stars.  it definitely helped that our server & runner were friendly.

would i go again: probs, but hopefully the kinks will be worked out.
author: Niki M.

description: Guys take note! This restaurant is an amazing place to take a girl on a date... the food is amazing, and while it is definetly an upscale restaurant the ambience is more classy casual than fancy- which makes the whole experience all the less awkward.
author: Kristina C.

description: The decor is definitely really nice.  The bar area is way too small, considering you don't get seated on time with a reservation.  We had to wait about 15 minutes, which is not a big deal, but there was just nowhere to sit or stand at the bar.  The service was nice, not too overwhelming, and there when needed.  Overall - somehow very mediocre, and if I do go back it will definitely be more so for the atmosphere than the food.
author: Nellie L.

description:
J says: We've always liked Town Hall so when I read that the Rosenthal brothers opened Salt House this week we decided to give it a try.  We didn't get there till 9:30 last night but the place was still 75% full and it was happening.  I loved the high ceilings with exposed beams and the vibrant bar area and open kitchen.  The place just had a great buzz.  I liked that the hip host asked us if we wanted a quiet table or if we preferred to be among more people, that was a nice touch.  We just chose to be closer to the open kitchen to watch the chefs in action.  They have a tightly run kitchen and waitstaff for a place that just opened to the public a few days ago.  The menu was simple, maybe in the future they will add more items?  I chose the putin appetizer which was a dish of thick cut potatoes baked with cheese and then drenched in a short rib sauce.  It was awesome!  K had the preserved tomato tart which had a nice tangy sweetness.  For mains, I got the New York Steak and K got the Veal Breast "tonnato" and both were substantial sizes and delicious.  We split the sinfully rich dark chocolate bundt cake in the end.  I loved that they added smoked almonds and caramel inside the cake, yum.  Together with 2 drinks, the bill was $60/person, reasonable for a fun and tasty night out.   This place is sure to become very popular.

K digs. Go check it out before it becomes reservations only.
author: Jen Ken H.

description: I love the classy wooden/glass structure of the restaurant. Ambiance is upscale but with adequate noise level, making it a good place for groups. Good wine, good food. You can sit at the bar or make reservations for lunch and dinner. It is close to where I work so my co-workers and I like to stop by after work.
author: Janie Y.

description: Good downtown lunch spot. They get busy, so make a reservation for lunch. Have the oysters and the smoked salmon croque mousieur.
author: Helen B.

description: I have never been disappointed here.  Each dish is delicious, and the atmosphere is really fun and has a cool vibe.  I actually prefer it to Town Hall.  The service is ok...it could be better.  It seems tables of two are neglected (for obvious reasons).  Big parties are welcome and served quickly.  Nevertheless, I will go back.
author: Carrie R.

description: Service was frightfully slow.  The ambience was really interesting in a good way.  The food was above average, but not mind blowing.
author: Ash T.

description:
(see pictures of my meal starting here):
http://www.flickr.com/photos/bittermelon/420531541/in/set-72157594550762890/

wow.

as predicted, the rosenthal / washington troika rocks the house yet again.

if i had a restaurant, it would resemble something like salt house, ESPECIALLY in terms of its look and feel...what a beautiful space. the ambiance was perfect, and i was simply taken with all the decorative elements...from the hanging bulbs that blanket the bar with a nice, subtle buzzy glow, to the handsome leather bar stools and chartreuse/mustard chairs with rivets, to the large iron beams flecked with rust. even the water carafes, which were essentially oldschool milk bottles, had little salt house insignias on them (which, okay, could've been rendered better). the dining tables were well-made, as the tops were basically quality wood cutting blocks. like town hall, there's a big communal table. 

the memory and feel of the old press warehouse is definitely honored and kept alive. and i like that. 

it's the perfect marriage of old + new. 

oh, and the natural daytime lighting was SPECTACULAR. 

all this crazed adoration aside, the food in itself was incredible. 

first off, they grace your table with a gorgeous branch of acme bread's pain epi. 

the poutine (canada's beloved french-fries-with-gravy-and-curds) was so OUT OF THIS WORLD. i won't even attempt to describe the flavors and textures...the mixture of the pot roasty gravy and cheese left a silky smooth feel in my mouth. 

all of our dishes were good:

poutine
crispy shrimp salad (okay, this was a bit disappointing)
the cheeseburger
crab salad
chicken w/chorizo potatoes

and dessert was lovely as well. 

perhaps i love salt house so much b/c it's all about textures, whether it be in the form of its aesthetic or its delicious food.
author: jennifer y.

description: Ever since Myth closed (my absolute favorite restaurant in SF) I have been scouring the City for a replacement.  After going to Town Hall a few times and being underwhelmed, I was not expecting much from Salt House.  I was completely blown away!  The wine list was interesting and had several by the glass, and the menu recommendations from the waiter were spot on.  I had the scallop ceviche with fresh peaches - DELICIOUS (and I'm not even a big fish fan), then the english pea gnocci (salty perfection), and finished with the ice cream sandwich for dessert (yay for the childhood throw back).  I've found a new favorite!!
author: Liz C.

description: Went on a Friday night. The bar was packed but the bartender came right over so I could get a glass of champagne. With all the people you could barely move or talk but it was worth it. Like Town Hall, the food is perfect. We had potato patine (did I just make that name up???) and the crispy shrimp to start, and the rabbit as a main. The menu is short but often suprising- stuff you didn't even know you craved. Good service and wine list plus parking, so no doubt that I will be back.
author: Lauren D.

description: Might be one of the best burgers I've ever had.  Seriously.  Cooked perfectly, juicy and flavorful.  Even the bun was good.  Could it get better?  Enter the pile of fried onions on the side and the answer is yes!  Crispy, salty, heavenly little fried onions.  Problem is going back to work afterwards.  Hrmph.
author: Carrie L.

description: Love the venue.  Service was very friendly, but entrees arrived slowly.  Food was really yummy, once it arrived.  The restaurant manager stopped by to say hello, apologize for the slow and make sure everything was ok.  The manager sent out complimentary desserts, too.  Overall, they have a few little tweaks to make, but this place is sure to be just as popular as Town Hall is.
author: Tara H.

description: Really nice atmosphere, but I felt that it was very overpriced.  The menu didn't really describe what you were ordering either.    Maybe my taste buds aren't sophisticated enough?  Nice presentation, but the meal was not very fulfilling.  I felt like Salt House was just trying too hard to be "fancy".
author: Kyle W.

description:
mr. x and i had dinner at salt house on a recent saturday. while they seem to be still quite popular judging by the number of reviews, tables did not seem hard to come by. one of the few positive perks of being in a recession....availability of restaurant reservations.

the decor is rustic and creates a warm atmosphere enhanced by the semi-open kitchen, slightly uneven wooden tables and unpolished floors. its a comfortable atmosphere, good for a date or for a small group dinner. probably not a good option for a large group since they don't take reservations over 8. 

as for the food, the entree offerings were typical and i had a hard time deciding as they all sounded so blah....sole, salmon, duck, or steak...paired with some sort of side such as mashed potatoes or lentils. nothing really jumped out at me except for the poutine...i'd never heard of this dish before so i asked mr x. he was as clueless as i, and being the techie dorks we are, i had mr x google it on his iphone prior to ordering. according to wikipedia, a sort of fried potato, canadian in origin. that plus "topped with cheddar" was all i needed to know. it really was pure indulgence. thick cut fries, melted tangy cheddar, all smothered in a short rib gravy...i finished half the plate while mr. x, having much more willpower than me, watched. i'll probably end up here again at some point or another, but next time, i'll just have the poutine and many many glasses of champagne :)
author: helen l.

description:
we were three ladies, each recovering from very nasty bouts with the stomach flu. so i didn't feel particularly attractive. it must have been the "easy prey" look about us that encouraged the playboys at the next table to chat us up. incessantly. we tried to be nice, until one of the owners - bless his heart - came over and said about these regulars "be careful - once you open that door, there will be no leaving you alone!" i laughed the entire evening, and the comp'ed champagne (from the restaurant, not the sleezebags) didn't hurt. 

add to this the delectable crispy shrimp and the scallops...i'm wrestling with giving them a fifth star. on the way out, the same owner forced upon us some tartine meringues...if i could move right in, i would.
author: Autumn W.

description:
A really memorable meal.  The menu selection included interesting combinations, as well as comfort food, so a wide appeal to many palates. Interestingly, the comfort food had a slant to its flavor in that a unique taste was introduced.  I wasn't expecting such a good meal - and it was just lunch!  

Service staff did a great job, and water is served without ice, unless it is requested.    I've already recommended this to others, and plan to go back again, but for dinner this time.
author: Rikki C.

description: I LOVE this place.  Everyone I take here, LOVES this place.  Amazing oysters, great bread and everything I've had from the menu has been fresh, tasty and enjoyable!
author: Caitlyn M.

description:
my experience at salt house started out with 3 people, then 3 appetizers, 3 main courses, 3 deserts and it ended in 3 very happy people.

our server was outstanding and the host staff was extremely friendly
author: David F.

description: This is an airy, rustic-looking restaurant that offers lots of seasonal options and interesting appetizers.  My favorite was the crispy shrimp made with spicy green beans, serano ham, and almonds.  It was hearty but refreshing at the same time.  I also enjoyed the celery root soup with bits of quince, pear, smoked bacon, and walnuts.  Husband had a delicious sole paired with a creamy brown butter sauce and shrimp jus.  Everything was well-prepared and service was efficient.
author: Nina L.

description: At there for lunch with work. I had the cubano sandwich...pretty tasty, nice ambience and reasonably priced. I would go back! If you have a group of 5 or more its kinda hard to get a reservation...
author: Julie F.

description:
Absolutely wonderful! 

I should mention that I came here on a date, and my review may be colored by the fact I was in such good company, but I'm gonna roll with it, since he was smart enough to pick the restaurant. I went here for the first time on Friday night around 7 before an opening at SFMOMA. The placed was packed, and they were turning people away, so like most places in the area, make sure you have a reservation. Even though it was busy we only waited about 5 minutes for the table- just enough time to get drinks from the bar and for a host to magically appear and take my coat the second I took it off. The service was great and the menu delightful. I highly recommend the foi gras appetizer and the Sole. They were both the best I have ever had of either dish. My very favorite part though, is the portion sizes. They are huge! And when eating such delicious food, I like to leave with a full stomach. Mission accomplished. Definitely give this place a try- you'll probably see me there!
author: Jillian W.

description: Went here for lunch with mi jefe and some ninjas from work.  We had a pretty badass lunch, I think everyone liked their meals.   I had the chicken potpie, which made me feel like crap for knowing that potpies could be this good, while ive been eating frozen ones my entire life.  Thanks Salt House, for opening my eyes.
author: Todd F.

description:
So happy to find a place open late in this area. Went last night and found it packed but they still squeezed us into a table that just opened up. I was anxious and feared that I would not like it as they were a tad disorganized and the hosts were seeming to wander aimlessly around not really sure where to be and who to help. I know this will be straightened out soon enough. The space is awesome with exposed brick and a beautiful loft setting. Our server was great, recommend a wine by the barrel and took our order quickly. 
I had the New York Strip for my meal and loved the way it was cooked and the onions & mashers that it was served with. Perfection. Date had the chicken which I was shocked to find was unbelievably good. Who makes chicken that tastes like this? Well apparently Salt House and I can't wait to go back and get that next time.
author: Cbr A.

description: Salt House has been sitting pretty on my "2011 Restaurant To Do List" for a few months now, and I finally had the opportunity to check it out for a business lunch this week. I must be on an ordering roll lately, because I've loved virtually every restaurant dish I've tried over the past few weeks, and Salt House was no exception. I had the Bellwether Farms Ricotta Gnocchi, with spring garlic, broccoli de cicco and pork shank, and it did not disappoint! The gnocchi was perfectly rich and the pork fell apart on my fork just as it should. The serving was generous and I ate ever last bite, but it wasn't so much that I was in a food coma immediately following. On top of it all, I loved the exposed kitchen and decor (great art and rustic brick and wood combinations). So why not five stars? It was too noisy for a weekday business lunch, and if you're in the heart of the financial district, that can be a big problem.
author: Brittany M.

description: Went here with a couple of friends. Between the 3 of us we had the Poutine, 1/2 dozen oysters, and the foie gra as appetizer. The Poutine (french fries, cheesy sauce, and short rib meat) was the best. If you're gonna have the Poutine (which you should) don't get the short rib. The meat basically the same and your gonna want something different.    Excellent food, friendly wait staff and people from all walks of life makes this place work for me.
author: Jeemster C.

description:
I'm sure the Salt House will be a hit, but not just yet.  They still have a few substantial kinks to work out.

When we arrived, we were quickly lead to our table.  Good.

It didn't take long before the waiter came over with water and took our drink order.  Also good.

We ordered the crab salad and lamb saugages in moroccan-style (neither are mentioned on the online menu, in case you're looking).  The moroccan frank and beans were tasty, but a bit salty.  The sausages themselves were well-cooked, but not too crispy.  The beans were seasoned to the point where they almost overwhelmed the sausages.  A little less salt in the beans and it would be great!

The crab salad was tasty.  Some sort of fried crispy critter mixed in with the sweet crab and unknown greens, but not enough salt.  Seems the frank and beans got some of the salt destined for the crab salad.  Good, but a little bland.

Entrees ordered were the seared scallops and chicken.  The problem was the scallops arrived with a duck cassoulet.  The waiter noticed this within a minute of it being placed on the table, but didn't take it away.  Another server asked if everything was OK and when I mentioned I had ordered the chicken, not the duck, he said OK, but didn't take the plate.  Our waiter finally came back after 5 minutes, said the chicken was on its way and suggested we go ahead and eat the duck nonetheless.  So we did.  It was ok.

The chicken was far better.  Very tender pieces of breast wrapped in crispy skin, served with a pepperoni- and fingerling potato mix.  The potatos were topped with arugula.  Very nice, but, after sharing two appetizers and two entrees, there wasn't enough stomach room to enjoy.

Biggest downfall?  It was *very* loud in there and the tables were very close together.  You had to move the tables in order to get in and out.  This may have led to the mix-up with plates, as the table next to ours had ordered the scallops and duck cassoulet.  Ooops.

Hopefully it'll be better nexttime.
author: Chris D.

description:
We were so excited to go to Salt House but didn't end up having such a superb evening there.  The food was the highlight- very yummy all around the table.  The heirloom tomato salad was my fave.  Unfortunately the service was rather spotty; we had a normal delivery of our appetizers but had to wait for almost an hour between that course and the main.  Also, we had a little cockroach try to join our dinner party via the short wall against which we were sitting.  Thankfully we, er, took care of him without causing a ruckus.  The staff was gracious (apologized, said there was nearby construction and it wasn't the first non bi-pedal guest they'd had recently- and they comped our appetizers) but it still irked us out a little bit.
The decor is modern and great, but partly due to the exposed brick walls, the volume is pretty darn bangin.  But I DID talk about the tasty food, did I not?  Maybe we'll try it again in a number of months...
author: Kate K.

description: Absolutely fantastic! The food was extremely well prepared and the space was excellent. We were upstairs, which was a bit more intimate.
author: Mike D.

description: I  have dined out  in SF for long. Salt House is one of the best new spots in town for me. Hama hama oyster is the best with friendly bartenders. I have never seen this place empty. It is very high end premise with high price rangebut trust me it is woth paying for it.
author: Puangrak A.

description: For such a beautiful and expensive restaurant, a resounding MEH for the food.
author: Steve S.

description:
Had dinner with a work group at the Salt House last night.  The food was very good.  The steamed vegetables, the scallops, the ravioli appetizers were fabulous.
I had the halibut entre and it was very nice.
I didn't get to stay for dessert so left with a longing for several of the items I'd seen on the menu and on their way to other tables.
A bit loud due to all the hard surfaces, but they kept the music at very tolerable levels.
author: L Gordon M.

description:
Salt House is the type of restaurant where you find yourself spending the entirety of the meal reassuring yourself and the person(s) you are with that this is absolutely one of the best things you have ever eaten, over and over again. And, again.

Being a college student, pork belly, new york steak and meyer lemon panna cotta aren't usually in the realm of even wants. However, this is worth saving up some cash or sacrificing well, pretty much anything. The meals I have had the pleasure of enjoying here are ones I still can recall every detail, but the service and atmosphere are also remarkable. 

I would recommend this restaurant to anyone, but particularly to those with a desire to have a truly memorable meal.
author: T D.

description: Once a week I kick my healthy bent and indulge in a burger and beer. Last week it happened to be at Salt House where I went with a friend. We ordered two burgers, both medium rare. Hers was cooked well and mine was raw. Pretty sure they forgot about making mine and left hers on while they flash cooked it. I've been in a few times and would completely recommend the location for it's great setting and fresh ideas, but those aren't the mainstays of a restaurant. Let's get back to basics guys.
author: Chris A.

description: Fuse the interior design of a hot SOMA loft (something I know a bit about) with an eclectic menu and thoughtful vibrations and you create a hip place to dine, date or just be seen.
author: Keith R.

description: We entered the restaurant with reservations at 8 p.m., the hostess informed us that unfortunately they were running behind, something about how Open Table had F'd up some earlier reservations. No problem, but it was going to be 1/2 hour, WTF! To my surprise they showed classic restauranteuring and service skills that are becoming a rarity in the SF dining scene, they took care of us. One bottle of bubbly and a free starter later and we had forgotten about the wait entirely. The meal was mostly delicious, with an amazing duck leg confit, a perfectly prepared monk fish and a little muttony lamb shank (2 out 3 ain't bad). One thing I will say about the Salt House is that they've got class, and not in the way some of those haughty joints that force you to make reservations 3 months in advance. They've got the "keep you happy skills" that make you coming back for more. Very Nice
author: Matthew R.

description: Not bad, not bad. Sort of on the pricey side, for sure. The food was pretty good, but not good enough to be those prices. I had the chicken, not too dry, and it was pretty decent. The dessert with the peach and ice cream was fantastic, unique in flavor. This seems to be the place where a lot of the working crowd goes for happy hour. Decor is awesome, its got that modern shabby chic thing going. Great champagne.
author: Angie K.

description: It's from the folks at Town Hall, and it's similar:  Stars/Cafe at Chez Panisse vibe to the food, very good.  I've only had lunch, but it's been terrific.
author: Laurel B.

description: WOW.  Holy freaking great food!  I consider myself a connoisseur of braised short ribs.  I have had them all over the world.  I LOVE them.  And, people, I'm here to tell you that this place has the best braised short ribs I have ever tasted in my life.  To make things even better, you can bring your own wine!  I recommend this, because the house wine that comes out of the tap is "eh" and not really worth the swallow.  The waitress we had was darling and really helped us pick our food from the menu.  Be prepared for a hefty bill, but it will be worth every penny.
author: Emily S.

description: Great place! Fun space, cozy (but crowded bar) and delicious food. I got there a bit early so sat at the bar waiting for my friend. The bartender was super friendly and attentive. When my friend arrived we ended up having to wait about 20 mins past our reservation - we didn't care, we were enjoying ourselves - plus the bartender filled up our glasses after we paid the tab - free of charge. The food was awesome. We split the salt cod for our app, which is a must try. I would have skipped it, but the waitress insisted so we ordered it and loved it. For the entrees we had the skate and duck, both great.  I can't remember the name of the dessert, but it had apples in it - it was the perfect end to a super meal.
author: Samira S.

description: The noise level is unnerving at lunch (been there 3x's now). The dishes are all great tasting, but in my opinion overpriced. The 'poutine' (French Fries with gravy and cheese) is really good, but be sure to ask for extra gravy and cheese or you'll be disappointed!
author: Aaron S.

description: Definitely go for poutine. Everything else has become somewhat average sadly.
author: Nikki T.

description: After 2.5 years in SF this is only the 3rd restaurant I actually thought was exceptional. I've only been once so far but my first experience was DEE-LISH!  Yum!  I had the foie gras, so awesome! Followed by the quail they were having that night. It was perfect. I'll definitely go back with high expectations of yummy goodness.
author: Gregg T.

description: Can't say that I've ever had an exceptionally good or bad dish here. Given that fact, I'd say only come here if you run out of really good places to go in the city (which you shouldn't), or if you just want to tell others that you've been here or mark it off your list. It's a nice enough space, crowd is good, service is good. It's just nothing to write home about. One positive worth mentioning is that they do have a good cheese platter. So, if you want to check this place out, I'd go on a weeknight around 8:30/9ish for some wine and cheese with friends.
author: Shreya C.

description:
The Big Man and I had more than a little indulged at the Yelp Elite Event and I needed food in order to remain upright...as we were practically there anyway, we walked the short stroll over to Salt House. Miraculously, even at prime dinner time on a Friday night(!!) we were escorted to 2 seats along the window/counter. It was a tad tight in feeling, tho' we were lucky to get seats immediately. The place was full to capacity and it seemed like "Date Night".

The waitress brought our glasses of wine quickly and we were given a portion of baguette wrapped in a piece of brown paper (are they trying to be rustic??). Water was filtered tap, served in what looked like a former milk bottle (cute. recycled. eco-friendly. I get it)...what I didn't quite grasp was the pirate/skull & cross bones on the bottle...We looked over the menu and saw that the price range is pretty steep. We really only wanted some dinner, not a big production, so we ordered entrees only. Stuart ordered the lamb shank which he declared to be cooked perfectly. I ordered the petrale sole which proved to be delicious. The "shrimp jus" served with the sole was so-so. The shrimp tasted as tho' they were on their last legs, so to speak. Everything else was exceptional. We had to ask for more water as well as a bit more bread. Desserts looked very heavy and none of them seemed compelling to us. If we had ordered anything, most likely it would have been a sheep's' milk  cheese plate. We passed as we were both full. The portions are generous.

I'm conflicted about just how many stars to give. The food was good tho' not spectacular. The service was efficient, tho' by no means friendly or particularly engaging. The bathroom was a disaster (4 stalls with only 1 clean & functioning toilet...come on!)...so I am being generous by giving 4 stars. When asked what he thought, Stuart felt 3 stars would be appropriate. I'm left with the sense that it is another expensive destination date spot, or a place for tourists or the Bridge n' Tunnel crowd. No complaints about the food, but for the amount of $$ spent, I would expect the auxiliary amenities to be stellar. Still, I would return for a drink & appetizer sometime.
author: Suzanne F.

description: Despite the pork belly arriving not as warm as we would like and some of the bus/runners being a bit too lightning-fast about taking away our food, I'd still give Salt House 4 stars. I like the styling --- steel beams, exposed brick, glass, and great lighting. Service, wait staff & hostess, were all very friendly and helpful. For me, the whole place felt "warm". My salad - Asian pears, chicory, hazelnuts, and a fluffy-like quenelle of Bellwether Farms ricotta --- absolutely delicious with layers of flavor. The Muscovy duck confit with wild huckleberries had gusto. We ended our meal with a tasty lemon pudding cake with huckleberry. A 2001 Ch. Grange-Neuve Pomerol enhanced the entire evening. Overall - great, will be back. My only regret was not ordering the poutine --- especially when my husband has lived in Canada --- shame on us!
author: Lizelle G.

description:
Here is yet another circumstance wherein I wish Yelp offered .5 star-ranking options.

Entering Salt House, the first thing I notice is the slanted mirror above the bar, the low-hanging wood plank strung up by chains to keep the acoustics more manageable, and the warm red brick walls which hold the delicate light streaming in from corner windows in a playful yet exciting dance. 

Our second time in, the Texan and I sat in the coveted corner spot of the bar, between the host's station and the giant steel pillar, behind which rested a large stack of corrugated cardboard coasters with "Salt House" imprinted in red in on the bottom right corner. We came in after a long day of drinking wine and eating food whose preparation we'd witnessed during Two's Saturday afternoon cooking class. Which reminds me, I need to update my review of Two after Saturday's mind-blowing event.

Admittedly, we were still slightly drunk (even after a two-hour wine-influenced break, or shall I say "break-down," which tends to come from walking down the street with someone you're just starting to fall for, unsure of the other's feelings about you, and so you just have to ask, but you forgot you were drunk, so it tends to come out all wrong), so my descriptions come from the annuls of something so primal that it would be impossible to forget. Ps- that's a disclaimer for any inaccuracies, particularly where the wine is concerned...

Ruari, amazing bartender of the evening (and of many more in the future, I do hope), offered us tastings of a few wine varietals so that we could make sure we got just what we wanted. Starting off with (if memory serves; the image of the bottle is much  more clear than the name, sadly) a glass of Pinot from Alfaro Family Vineyards in Santa Cruz, we snacked on slightly sweet and delicately crunchy pickled vegetables. The hama-hama oysters slid down with a fruitiness that was masked a little too heavily by the amount of shallots I added; next time, I think just a little lemon will do. We moved on to the crispy shrimp, which were four large shrimp battered in tempura and set over chopped green beans with serrano ham; the saltiness helped carry the deep fatty flavors of pork and fried goodness across the palate, with a fiery bite at the finish. The merguez sausages were small and fell apart like loosely packed feta, and the chickpeas were just on the right side of al dente-- any more firm and I would have found them too dry. Still hungry, we shared the seared yellowfin tuna: an opera of delight: an alto of glorious firm yellowfin flesh kept steady on the palate with the tenor of morels and wild asparagus. Complemented deeply by the wine, this dish is a celebration of life itself, and reminded me once again of how fortunate I am to be able to participate in the opportunities this fantastic city provides.

My usual problems with restaurants and service are the only thing that keep this restaurant from receiving 5 Yelp stars: The Texan's napkin fell to the floor and nobody picked it up; it shares a bathroom with a really lame dance club, so there are way too many hoochie mamas in a dark, danky restroom; it's laid out so that it feels impossible to move (I like the illusion, at least, of space while dining, though I get that they're using natural light to compensate for it).

Overall, an amazing, if pricey, experience. I'd say at least $50 per person, but to get the most out of your time and money, make sure you ask your server for his/her recommendations. Thanks again to Ruari, a most awesome bartender!!
author: Molly A.

description:
Very good food and extremely helpful and friendly staff!  We ordered the olives and poutine to start, and the poutine could have been our entire entree... My husband had read about the poutine, and had to order it  (I thought it sounded a little scary) -- french fries covered in Gorgonzola and then smothered in gravy???  I realize that it's a variation on a Canadian specialty, but what stoner came up with that combo?  My husband is already craving it again the next day, but I can't say that I am.  The olives were good, but a really large portion, and too many for 2 people.  I think they should offer a 1/2 portion for $3.  As for the entrees, I had the roasted chicken and it was good, but not nearly as good as the steak that my husband got  -- damn, that was wonderful, and the best I've had in a long time.  We also shared the pineapple upside down cake for dessert, and it was mighty tasty...

 My only complaint is that I thought the wines were a little bit on the high side, and the tables for 2 are really close together... I'd say that if you plan to go to Salt House, go with other people so you can sit at a table for 4 -- those tables are further apart and offer more privacy.  It's soooo hard for me not to eavesdrop in a restaurant, and since you are pretty much sharing a table with the people you are sitting next to at the tables for 2, it was quite a challenge not to eavesdrop at this joint!
author: robyn s.

description: This place was good, but as the name applies salty. LOL! We didnt' have reservations so we sat at the communal table which was kinda cool. Not that many people came in so we had the table to ourselves for some time, almost until we finished eating. Another couple just happened to come by. I had the seafood stew which was similar what I had at Bouchon. The difference a little more salt and less saffron. I still enjoyed my meal at Bouchon more but this was a close second.
author: K T.

description:
guess what? i didn't love it. our service was fantastic, and i love the ambiance of the place, but our food just didn't do it for me. we had the ricotta salad (a bit dull), the poutine (i found the gravy to be too salty) and the chicken (tender, but the chorizo and potatoes waaaay too spicy...and i swear, i'm not a wimp)
meh.
author: Maggie K.

description: I wish this place was my home, it's that san francisco loft i couldn't quite afford. Regardless it's a great little spot to go for a business lunch. Eclectic and interesting menu. Of course, I have to also mention the Paul Smith fabric covered banquette. It's awesome.
author: Larissa Z.

description: Excellent!!  I have been coming back to Salt House several times already.  Love the decor, the lofty layout and the staffs at Salt House are friendly.  Their lamp chop dish is exquisite!!  I never tasted lamb so flavorish and just melts in my mouth.  I also like their wine list and the delicious maple banana tart!  Highly recomend this place if you haven't tried it.
author: Gina W.

description: Great wine list, good selection of oysters, and freshly marinated olives...this is my new favorite place.  The decor is nice and simple and the service was very good.  We both had the parmesan crust lamb shank, which the waiter highly recommended.  It was rich, moist, and I quite a large piece of meat.  It was one of the best meat dishes that I have had in quite a while.  The apple tart with vanilla ice cream was also very good, a perfect finish.
author: Jamie C.

description:
I finally had dinner at Salt House the other night. I was very impressed when I first enter the restaurant  however, that feeling left rather quickly. The wait staff was kinda odd and a bit pushy. From the moment we sat down, I felt a bit rushed. Mind you, I had a 5:30 reservation on a rainy Wend night, so I'm not sure why?
As we looked over the menu, the waiter wanted us to make a wine selection. My husband asked for a minute and he responded with, I can make a suggestion for you. No thanks, we can pick our own. We ordered a bottle of Turley and a few appetizer's. Since  so many people rave about the poutine, we asked to start with that. However, he brought out the other two dishes first. Perhaps he wanted to go from lighter to heavier?  
All the dishes very very tasty, although expensive. Not sure I would come back here for dinner, but if you want a place to grab a drink and some small bites, this could be your place. BTW, the place is VERY loud.
author: Lisa A.

description: I don't understand how this place is keeps them coming like they're serving ambrosia. It's good but not worth rescheduling your plans so you can have coveted reservations at the salt house.  Their chicken is better than Zuni's but their steak didn't do a thing for me.  The drinks are stiff so watch out.
author: Amber L.

description: A co-worker and I went her for a business lunch and I was thrilled with the service and the food. The portions are perfect and the service is prompt, professional and friendly. I highly recommend their Baked Alaska. Oh. My. Goodness. Divine. A great place for an intimate business lunch.
author: Becky M.

description: I can't say enough about Salt House.  I will definitely be back.  I had the steak and it was amazing.  I loved the interior design.  I've always liked their "sister" restaurant Town Hall, but this is a step up in my opinion.
author: Jeff S.

description: I may be in the minority on this one, but between Town Hall and Salt House, I think Salt House is the better of the two when it comes to the complete dining experience.  Friendly service, fantastic atmosphere, and well-done--if not life-changing-California cuisine.  The foie gras remains a favorite.  Still--and maybe I am getting on in years by saying this--the Salt House is a little too noisy for my taste.  I don't need to eat in a monastery, but I do like having the option of exchanging at least a few words with my wife during a meal.  You kids turn it down!  So I'll take a slight deduction there, but all in all, Salt House is a fun, consistent option in the Financial District.
author: Ty D.

description: This place is one of my new favorites. The beautiful exposed brick loft-style interior is accented with wonderful lighting and a charming mural of Don Quixote. The service is polished and professional while still being warm and inviting. The food is delicious and presented well (and the portions are just right). The wine list has a great selection of affordable and splurge options.
author: Mishka L.

description: I wanted to try this place out since I live so close and it wasn't half bad. I think the wait staff is still trying to come into their own since the place is so new so I am hoping that over time the vibe will losen up a bit. The food was decent and I especially like the poutine (but anything smothered in cheese and gravy tastes good, right?). I think it is worth checking out - and grab your waiters ass when your there. If we all work together we can losen them up!
author: Julie C.

description: Town Hall has always been a favorite (pot de creme a must), and glad to see the expansion with Salt House.  The rustic yet classy decor makes it a comfortable dining experience.  The lamb shank is huge and tasty. So is the steak.  Crab salad filled with hearty crab and a light dressing-snappy.   Desserts tough to stay away from--that chocolate cake was worth scooping on the little sugar cookies.  I could go on, but instead I'll go back when I'm in SF again soon.
author: Ross W.

description: Went here for my bday dinner recently with my hubs -  great experience.  Tastey food, friendly service, pleasant atmosphere.  This is a relaxed, casual, SF-hip restaurant.  Good place for a date or dinner with your BFFs.
author: L W.

description: Awesome atmosphere.  Great food.  pricey but you get what you pay for in food and drinks.  Low key for a relaxing Friday or Saturday night.
author: brandon d.

description:
almost 5 stars  ... beautiful city restaurant, very ultra modern looking and sleek interior .. expensive but worth every penny ... really excellent tasty food  / not over the top but great flavors and quality ingredients // super nice servers .. the manger was very cool lady and very helpful in suggesting a great bottle of wine. 
would most definitely repeat.
author: Nick l.

description: this place was decent. the atmosphere is pretty cool, but seemed to skew on the older side (like 40-50 range). i liked what I had, but i remember that the pork belly appetizer was extremely tiny and most of it was fat and for $12, I was expecting a little bit more on my plate. Don't get me wring, I know that pork belly usually has a lot of fat, but this particular dish was just on the tiny side. We ate in the front of the restaurant facing the street, and those chairs were not very comfortable. I don't really like have my back towards the waiter which was the case since the chairs are so close together. it seemed to be a forced seating area. the communal tables are nicer and seemed to be more fun of an experience. i probably won't go back, but it was an ok experience, and maybe i just ordered wrong or sat in the wrong spot.
author: Pumakat K.

description:
Where do I begin?  I was so impressed with this restaurant. (I think my experience was enhanced by the company I was in --- we had a lot of fun) 

Food: Upon arrival my friend and I sat at the bar and waited for one more person to show up. We sipped on Schramsberg, "Mirabelle", Brut Ros and crunched on their mixed nuts with truffle honey / sea salt. Yum-O! Once seated we moved on to the Oysters. I don't usually enjoy bivalves but I thought I should give them another chance. We got a plate of the Kumamotos, Miyagi and Fanny bay I smothered them in their fantastic minionette.  The wine director helped us pick out a bottle for our appetizers and another for our dinners.  Excellent pairings I must say! To start I had the crab salad which I can't stop thinking about! It was so delicious and basically just a pile of crab meat. There were some pieces of butter lettuce on the bottom.  There was the perfect amount of dressing and I love, love, loved it!  For dinner I ordered the Halibut which was good but not as outrageously good as the salad. I definitely can't say anything bad about it.  

Service: The wine director was incredibly helpful and couldn't have paired our wines better. The waitress was good but not the best. She would take out orders w/o writing them down and then come back and ask us again what we wanted.  And when the food got to our table the runner "auctioned it off". "Who had the halibut? Ok and the..." The kitchen shorted us an oyster but that happens and were quick to correct their mistake.  I love that they fold your napkin if you leave the table!!!

Thank you jackasses that brought us Town Hall --- I like this place so much better!
author: All About Town ..

description:
Salt House is wonderful.  There are so many great things about this place that make it such a pleasant dining experience.  However, in the sake of time and effort, I will highlight a few things that struck out at me.  
It comes to me as no surprise that the rest. is so similar ot Town Hall.  Prices for food is on the steep side but its worth it.  The menu is short but each dish offered is really well made.   Proportions are a little smaller than I remembered at Town Hall but still gets you full. Great bar with a good variety of choices.  I personally thought the aesthetics of the place was not as good as Town Hall, but it still brought the same warm, social atmosphere that we all love in our dining experience.  The most important thing that I want to stress about this place is the service.  Kudos to the whole staff at Salt House for trying so hard to make each person's dining experience truly wonderful.  Everyone working there was on point, alwys ready to help switch a clean plate, offer another drink and fold your napkin as you go to the restroom and overall just very friendly.
I highly recommend coming here for a great solid dining experience.  Its worth your time and money.
author: Charles C.

description:
Once again, our good friends at NorCal made their usual 6:30am rounds, waking us up in the process (can't you bastards be a little more quiet on a holiday?), so while the wife was stuck working on this gloriously rainy San Francisco holiday, I figured it was a great time to catch up on, like, 8 extra hours of sleep. Of course, a couple of my clients had other ideas, and my CrackBerry got me out of bed for good about 8:30. So I figured I'd be a good hubby and meet the wife for lunch in the FiDi.

We chose Salt House for 3 reasons: First, a serious foodie friend of mine RAVED about the joint when it opened, Second, it's right around the corner from the wife's office, and Third, they were serving a price fixe lunch as part of the SF Dine About Town. To my delight, I was able to score an 11:45am reservation on Open Table around 9ish, and set out into the now sunny SF morning (seriously, is Mother Nature battling PMS or something?!?) to catch the Muni limo to head downtown.

We walked in around 11:50, and the place was empty. I guess that's par for the course on a holiday, as most of my mates were still up in Tahoe themselves for the long weekend. It did start to pick up around 12:30, but there were still plenty of free tables when we left around 1. To their credit, both our hostess and waiter went out of their way to tell the wife and I about the D.A.T. special, and our friendly waiter did not at all make us feel out of place (read: ghetto) for taking advantage of the deal like some places in town (I'm talking to you Ruth's Chris! Get over you're effin self!). Salt House kicks off every meal with fresh, crusty bread from the wonderful Acme Bread Co. in the Ferry Building with house-whipped butter, which for the carb-addicted like yours truly made a wonderful starter in and of itself. As part of the price fixe menu, I had the pork pozole, a hearty stew of braised pork shoulder with chickpeas, pickled carrots and onions, and jalapenos. The stew was absolutely phenomenal, with the succulent pork melting in your mouth as the chickpeas exploded with flavor with each and every bite. The charming gay couple next to us both ordered the same, and I overheard one of them mentioning that he detected the flavor of fresh saffron in the complex broth. I devoured the entire bowl, and even though the portion was more than generous for lunch, the pozole was so delicious I was left craving seconds. The wife had the Salt House burger, an expertly cooked patty of pure perfection topped with cheddar cheese and onion straws served on a fresh Acme Bread roll. The burger was so juicy, my wife literally had juices running down BOTH her arms! She said it was definitely one of the best burgers she's had in the FiDi, hands down. The burger is not served with fries, which I guess is all the better if you order the famous poutine as an app. It wasn't offered on the price fixe menu, and as we took it a little easy on the drinking yesterday, we decided to pass for now, but will definitely be back after a few happy hour pints to give the poutine a try.

The price fixe lunch was served with only 1 choice, the Meyer Lemon panna cotta, for dessert. I decided to pass as I'm not big on sweets in the middle of the day, but wifey really enjoyed the subtly sweet vanilla custard, which was topped with fragrant candied Meyer lemons and served in a pool of raspberry sauce. Salt House has a decent wine and beer list, with Trumer Pils, Anchor Steam, Dogfish Head IPA and Widmer Hefeweizen on tap. Our tab came out to $67 including drinks and tip, not too bad for a place that on a normal weekday is filled with power lunchers with expense accounts and the like. All told, the Salt House is a solid FiDi joint that is worth the little splurge. We'll definitely be back the next time my clients decide that I don't deserve a day off during the week.
author: Michael T.

description: Any place that serves poutine (fries with gravy & cheese curds) will always win a place in my heart. We were with a big group so we tried all the small plates. The foie gras was exceptional and the others were hit-or-miss with nothing else overly memorable (the monterey squid and the baked oysters). I had the sole for my entree which was good but having tasted a bite of someone else's prime ny steak made me envious. The desserts were a highlight - rhubarb/apple crumble, choc pot de creme, and my lord the cookie plate. We also had a cheese plate which was solid too. Cool space with mediocre service.
author: Bill R.

description:
Quite the little hotspot.

I won't repeat the same reviews as my other 5-star Yelpers, but this place definately lives up to its hype. Check it out!
author: Nicole R.

description: I am definitely a fan of this American joint... the food looks so simple on the menu but when its served to you its so much more then that... The presentation is great and its a real relaxed place to dine... usually a lunch spot of mine!
author: Kara G.

description:
This is the 3rd time I been to Salt House and each visit had a negative result.  I'll not go back.

First visit a few years ago we were given a table directly under the stairs.  The worst place for a table and total out of place.   I see its no longer there.

2nd experience last year I  ordered the chicken - it was raw in the middle.  They quickly re-fired a fish for me.

Most recent the wait was unacceptable.  Reservations were at 8:30 - were not served out food until 10 PM.  In fact a quick trip to the rest room I noticed that not one table had food.  Not a one...

What was finally delivered (Pork) was dry and bland at best.

On the positive side service (Less the wait) was very good.
author: David C.

description: I can't comment on the food because I just had drinks with coworkers.   The management made a big stink about the 6 of us being seated at a table for 4.  It just made everyone feel unwanted. I think the problem was that we weren't eating, but we were taking up prime real estate.  It's a nice mellow place to go after work, but I don't think I'll go back.
author: Benita S.

description: great delicious food and superb service.  i love their variety dishes and wines.
author: Jeene L.

description: Happened to stumble on this place as I was going to the Tea Garden a couple of doors down. I feel like the appetizers (scallops and the frous gras) were way better than the entrees (salmon and the petrale sole). The food overall was good and even better since I didn't pay because I wouldn't want to spend $60 bucks per person for this meal. The waitress was nice and attentive and the hostess resembles Amy Winehouse which is a plus. Overall good but not great....until I make a six figure income.
author: phil c.

description: Seared tuna... quinoa... fava beans... green olive and almond tapenade.  YES!!!  Absolutely delicious.  Anthony ordered the duck, which claimed to be peking duck but was nothing of the sort.  Not bad, but not what it said it was.  The Washington/Rosenthal concept of cool urban spaces, inventive but classic food, and stylish presentations holds true here.  It took me a while to check this place out, but I'm glad I did and I will be back.
author: Julie L.

description: I thought this restaurant was great. The server was really friendly, the atmosphere is very cool, and the food/wine were really good. I don't remember any one dish that was amazing that would draw me back, but a good experience and would be happy to go here again. Definitely worth checking out in my opinion.
author: Alex R.

description:
The food was ok, but definitely not great, and the service was below par.  Someone in our group summed it up best - "underwhelming".

I had the crispy shrimp to start.  The shrimp were good (would have been nice to get more than 4) and the salad on the dish was also good.  For main course I had the lamb shank.  It was salty and there wasn't a lot of meat.  Also, I think a lamb shank should come with the shank, both the orders at our table came sans bone.
author: Mike H.

description: Let me see....where should I begin....I really have too much to say so let me keep this short. We would have had a great dinner but we had a horrible waitress. Her favorite line was " one moment please "  enough said! Management was wonderful we got complimentary desert and Italian wine because our entrees took forever to come out maybe our  " one moment please " waitress forgot to put in the order. Our waitress manage to screw up one last time...she charged us for the deserts $55 worth. The manager quickly removed the items and apologized once again...poor guy. I'm giving them three stars cuz of his efforts.
author: lil miss kitty n.

description: Had a great lunch here today of rich and tender duck confit served over an herbed mix of lentils, veggies and bacon in poultry jus. Absolutely delicious, and, while bustling, the atmosphere -- a tasteful collision of rustic and contemporary design -- was comfortable and welcoming. Good serivce, too. Recommended. (3/26/2009)
author: Rommie J.

description: Another weird name.Why Salt house?Why not Sugar house?Another great place.All I have to say is potatoes and gravy is an awesome combination that should be tried over and over again.Why because it is damn good and life's short.If you're going to die why not die happy.
author: Sophia C.

description: Loved this place. Reason number one, excellent service. This ranks higher to me than menu price, menu choice and interior decoration. The host, the bar-tender and the waitress all could not have been sweeter. Reason number two, speaking of menu prices - the menu itself. I would have sampled everything on their had I been able to, I settled on the Beef Short Rib - probably one of the tastiest I have ever had. The wine selection, too, offers a unique and inexpensive selection of both carafes and more expensive bottles. This is the place you can eat at and still afford wine, as much or as little as you like without the need to even think about your AmEx Black card. The third reason for me was the urban warehouse setting, the exposed brick walls and apparent steel retrofitting gives it that Boston meets West Cost chic that I love about many of SF's downtown establishments.
author: Jack G.

description: Who doesn't like curry ketchup, but the rest was just OK.  I'm not sure that i'll go back as I didn't try anything that blew me away, but it's worth a try if you're looking for something you haven't tried before.
author: Nick S.

description: You know those places that you consistently recommend to people who are looking for a great place to eat in the city?  You know, a place that offers top notch food, nice cocktails and the kind of environment that represents our beautiful city of SF well?  Yeah, this is that place.  I always recommend it to people and they always come back with a big smile and thanks for doing so.
author: Piper B.

description:
For the past 5 years, a few of us who used to work together get together for dinner out. We try for every month (doesn't always happen) and take turns choosing where to dine. This month it was at Salt House. We originally had a reservation for 6 but our smaller party of 4 arrived a little early and fortunately were seated within minutes. That was a plus. Service for water and wine was good - we got a couple recs and she gave us time to look at the menu. I am 5 months pregnant so I just went with the white house blend - 6 oz for $6. I drank about 2oz of it (just wanted a taste) and the others finished the rest. 

We started with the crispy shrimps - very tasty breaded shrimps over spicy green beans and the Poutine - thicker fries drizzled with cheese, then they pour some gravy on them at your table. Everyone loved these 2 dishes! The others - baked oysters which I am not a fan of and the Calamari - one large tube stuffed atop a bowl of tentacles and diced accoutrements (I remember the garbanzos as I only tried these non-squid bits. It could have been good but just wasn't appetizing to me). We were mixed on the apps.

Dinner. We usually clean our plates and sample what the others ordered. One ordered the steak ($30) medium and it came out medium rare at most. He ate around the edges of some pieces and overall most of the dish was uneaten. One ordered the tuna ($28) and got a gristly piece. He was trying to cut through it to much disappointment. One ordered the Sole and thought it was good - everything was cooked right and so she got to enjoy her dinner and ate most of it. Upon ordering the salmon, I was asked how I wanted it cooked. I have only been asked this once before - usually I like my salmon cooked but not dry. I guess I could have said that but I was put off by the question thinking I had to answer it like ordering meat. She asked if Med Rare was ok, and being pregnant, I said at least Medium, thinking it would be ok and more cooked than not. When my fish arrived, it was pretty rare, like seared because it was mushy and raw pretty much all the way through. I had a couple bites and gave a huge raw piece from the middle to the steak eater. As I picked through it and got others to try it, everyone noticed how raw it really was. After much hesitation I sent the half piece back on a small plate to be cooked more. By the time it returned about 10 mins later (in a smaller dish on a new bed of sides, everyone had pretty much finished their dinner (or what they wanted of it) and I was practically eating alone. I had a couple more bites and decided that I wasn't into any more for the evening, I would take it home. 

When the server came around, I compared a raw piece left on my friend's plate to a cooked piece and just asked out of curiosity about the differences in cooking temp. She seemed a bit defensive but I was merely asking for information - again, not used to that question for salmon. She said the piece was Med Rare, why? I reminded her that I asked for at least Medium. Anyway, that was for info only - she didn't cook it, the kitchen did. But how did she write up the order?

The busser came around and I asked for my fish to go, just as my friend was saying just I should just eat it. I said no, I would just take it home, so my friend then asks for a box. The busser took some dishes and came back for the rest, getting mine last. I did not remind him that I still wanted to take it home but that it was ready for him to take. I think there was a language barrier so I really should have?

The chocolate dessert was tasty and at least we could end the meal sharing that.

When the server brought our bill, she mentioned that she took the salmon off. That was appreciated. Even splitting the bill 4 ways and somehow including a 20% tip, each share was still $58. I expressed I didn't feel good about this bill, and everyone else said they didn't really eat theirs either. Point. Way too much $$ for such a disappointing meal from the kitchen. Most dishes were over salted and no one cleaned their plate which was definitely a first.

My leftover salmon??? I really thought the busser would remember that we asked for my salmon to go but it never appeared back at our table. It was about half of my $25 salmon with pretty much all the new mini diced sides and puree that I was looking forward to giving the chance the next day. Even though it got comped, I am still entitled to it right? And especially since it still seemed like I paid too much money for it.
author: Kristi M.

description:
The food at Salt House is great!  The portions are generous.  I really liked the foie gras plate that had different versions of it (pate, sauted and some sort of a roulade).

The service is decent, but if you don't have a reservations, it is definitely a long wait.
author: Alla M.

description:
I LOVE the Salt House. There are not a ton of great restaurants located near Golden Gate University, but this chic joint, quietly nuzzled on Mission Street which is always busy, is a reprieve for the selective foodie. Prices aren't cheap, but you will be happy with pretty much anything on the menu. I have been here for lunch and dinner for work, and I was very happy with everything I ordered. 

For lunch, I had the oyster po' boy (and this sandwich is nothing but rich). It might have been a special, because I don't recall it being on the regular lunch menu, but it was awesome and bursting with flavor. Then again, it was fried, so what wouldn't be good?

On other occasions, I had dinner. I had a few glasses of sauvignon blanc and was very pleased. Not only that, the olive snack was great. Then again, who couldn't love a briney melange of meaty olives?! For my entree, I had the Petrale Sole. The portion, the texture, the flavor, and the presentation were all spot-on. I recommend you trying this dish if it's your first time, and you will be happy you did.

The only draw back is that it is quite small in there. They have this seating area near the window underneath the stairs and you feel trapped. It is hard for waiters to deliver food and wine to you, especially if it's busy. Try to get them not to sit you there if it's just two of you. Unless you are desperate and famished, I would opt for the wait. 

All in all, Salt House is a great, accidental find in SF.
author: Anna B.

description:
The first time I came here I was very impressed by my meal. The "Crispy shrimp" app. was fantastic. And I also ordered the chicken which was so moist and tasty. Wine list was excellent.

Second experience:
 Came with a large party and kept raving about the crispy shrimp and chicken. I kept saying "Get the shrimp" well.... while the shrimp was cooked perfectly,  it was like someone dumped 5Tbsps of cumin in this dish. The others agreed. sucks! The chicken came and was delicious. Thank God! Everyone liked there entrees as well. Wine was great again. And yummy "Blondie" dessert. Service was excellent, we had a party of 8 and had two servers!
I will be back.
author: diana q.

description:
Let me start of with something positive:  the space is quite pleasant to look at .  

Now let me continue: Blech.  Poorly mixed cocktails (I sipped several of my friends', not just several of my own) average/overpriced food, incredibly long wait between courses.  We're talking at least 45 minutes, if not an hour or more.  After about a half hour waiting for my entree, I walked by the kitchen to witness a flurry of frantic activity but absolutely no plates coming out.  And at every table, as far as I could see on either side of me, no one was eating either.  Desserts included a yellow glob of cornstarch trying to pass itself as lemon something, and a custard that tasted like a mouthful of a certain bodily fluid that we won't mention here in polite company.  Extremely loud, extremely empty water glasses, extremely not worth going to.
author: Kyle F.

description: If the poutine is always as good as it was the night we were there, then definitely a must try.    I spend a fair amount of time in Montreal so have become a poutine devotee and this version albeit a California-gourmet one, is yummy.   There were 12 of us the night we were there for a Christmas get together and everyone's food was top notch.   One negative:  the restaurant doesn't accomodate large parties - the largest table seating is for 8 people, so 4 in our group had to sit separately (yeah, I know, really stupid).   Hence the 3 stars.
author: N. M.

description:
Overrated and overpriced.

The service was good.  The food was good, but not great.
author: Garrett H.

description:
Reviewed by Scottie D! Edited by KenMac.
Date: 3/21/07

I've wanted to try the Salt House for a few months and when a friend said they wanted to try it as well I no longer had any excuses. Though I wish I did.  I've been to Town Hall and since "the Jackasses" from Town Hall opened this location I expected a similar experience.  Our meal began with a couple of small plates.  My dining partner started with the Crispy Shrimp w/ Spicy Greens, Serrano Ham and Almonds ($13). This dish was simply overpowered by the heat of the greens/ham/almond mixture the shrimp rested on.  I suggest ordering the greens as a side dish w/o shrimp. I ordered the Poutine (a Canadian dish similar to gravy fries) w/ Short Rib Gravy and Fontina cheese ($10)  I was looking forward to this dish because crispy potatoes covered in gravy is one of my comfort foods. Unfortunately, the potatoes were limp, just like Bob Dole before taking a tab of Viagra. Needless to say anytime one eats at a restaurant and you start comparing your small plates to erectile dysfunction it does not bode well for their future.

On to the on trays, I mean entres. My friend had the Fresh Dungeness Crab Salad ($21) I have to say considering the outrageous price one pays for crab in this town, this was a bargain! The crab was piled high and deep, so much so that my foodie friend couldn't finish it. Though, that may have been the result of too many pieces of bread dipped into the Short Rib Gravy.  I had the Roasted Pork "Cubano" Sandwich ($15) while the bread was toasted to perfection and the pork was flavorful, the remoulade that accompanied it was lackluster ultimately destroying what could have been the best "Cubano" sandwich I've had in this country! If I were to go back I would ask for the sauce they put on their Spicy Greens instead of the remoulade. 

Miscellaneous issues!
First, be forewarned, if you've been to Town Hall then you know it can be quite loud. The Salt House is even louder. I imagine that the tall exposed ceilings plus the narrowness of the building itself amplifies the internal din to a cacophony of clangs/clutter and talking.  Our waiter was overly enthusiastic about clearing plates of food while we were still eating (extremely annoying).  Please note these comments are specific to a lunchtime meal and not dinner.

I would recommend this place with the caveats explained above. The food, while searching for a place on the palette, is good!  Just remember it is very LOUD at lunch!


Addendum: I returned to Salt House on 4/18/07 for lunch and while the counter staff was very knowledgeable, the food has taken a turn for the worse. I ordered the White Bean Soup ($9) the soup was creamy, yet bland. Perhaps a twist or two of cracked black pepper would have helped but I doubt it. I then had the Yellowfin Tuna Tartare w/ Bosc Pear and Red/Golden Beets ($14) which I regret to say was a horrible combination. The tuna was flesh was a milky pink not the deep red that one sees in better restaurants in the city (think Aqua, Michael Mina). I've never tasted anything like this anywhere. I'm a huge fan of all things tuna but I would NEVER eat this dish ever again.

I no longer recommend this restaurant.  It is all talk and no substance!!!!
author: D Scott D.

description: I love this place!  This restaurant has been around now for several years and is quite often the place we go for business lunches.  The food is always very consistent here and I've never had a plate put in front of me that didn't taste fantastic!  There are several items that are always on the menu, the Crispy Shrimp and Green Bean Salad is amazing.  Other starters that will melt in your mouth are the Poutine (French Fried Potatoes topped with Gravy & Cheese) which is absolutely divine.  On the entre side, there is always a variety of selections including chicken, fish and maybe lamb.  Sometimes there are entrées that include items with duck & beef.  The Salt House Burger is always on the entre menu and is really good too.  I have had the Petrali Sole and Halibut dishes several times along with beef short ribs when it is on the menu.  The blend of flavors is insanely tasty and keeps me going back.  They can accommodate small parties as well as ours which was a party of 10.  Prices are what you would expect for a restaurant of this caliber and you won't walk away hungry.  On the down side, it can get crowded with tables placed pretty close together.  Also,  the noise levels are often on the high side.
author: Chris F.

description:
we went there once for dinner, as I love salt and salty things, and couldn't help but be drawn to the place. 

setting -- huge loud concrete boxy place with enormous cafeteria style table in the middle a la Nopa, and gigantor open kitchen on the side. luckily we were seated in a wee corner, but otherwise, husband and I would have had to abandon conversation and just make moon faces at each other all night. 

service -- crisp and perfunctory. not too much, not too little. just right.

food -- I remember virtually nothing other than the suckling pig. crisp, wafer like skin over creamy meaty melty pork... husband was so overwhelmed that he (and he NEVER has done this EVER) insisted on shaking the chef's hand at the end of our meal. 

I would've given 5 stars for the food. just one star less because it was so loud, and I am getting old, and not as enjoyful of the raucous noise as I once was.
author: Sasha R.

description: Solid, great food -- perfect for a lunch with old friends or colleagues. I went in February with my longtime mentor and a new mentor for some silicon-valley-girl-power-lunching. This was the perfect spot. We sat upstairs (perfect for people watching) and had a nice leisurely lunch. Of course we tried the house specialty: poutine. I didn't quite get the mania - but cheesiness and fries just can't go wrong. Our lunches were great -- perfect in that they were just really good. It was also one of the best lunches I've had from a conversation perspective and so that made the place even better. The staff was also friendly and unphased by our leisurely lunching.
author: Natala M.

description: Nice place and good atmosphere. My friends and I made a reservation here and we were seated promptly but our food didnt come till 45 minutes later after we ordered. Food was decent, but there's better.
author: Nancy N.

description:
We were excited to try Salt House, part of the Town Hall family, for Dine About Town.  What a disappointment.

The portions were quite small, mediocre (especially the blondie dessert, which most of us didn't finish and I rarely fail to finish dessert), and uninspiring.  The beet salad was the best part of the meal, but at most, just good.

While the ambiance is nice, it's not nice enough to make up for the quite slow service (lunch took almost 2.5 hours!).
author: C.S. K.

description: Great atmosphere, nice staff.  Had the pork chop--my favorite thing to order when out--and it was delicious.  I've only had two other chops that would trump this one (The Globe used to have a roasted chop to die for and stopped making it a few years ago for some crazy reason. And the best--my mom's) The brussell sprouts that came with it threw it over the top.  I always look for what comes with the main dish, and salt house delivered.  I went with a friend who ordered the short ribs, both of us loved our dishes so much we didn't share--and that's saying a lot.
author: S D.

description: The food was only outshined by the restaurant itself... and my handsome date!  I am thinking about going back for happy hour - wine and poutine.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Ate at the bar with some friends. The gnocchi  (which I think was the only veg option) with mushrooms and squash blossoms was good, nothing exceptional.  Fun atmosphere, and the service was excellent.
author: shoba d.

description: My husband and I had an amazing dinner there last night!  The food was incredible, the crispy shrimp, albacore tuna, petrale sol & a variety of oysters. Our server roshana was great and Jonathan and jake the managers were great too!  We'll be back. Thanks for a great dining experience.
author: anne f.

description: Excellent!  Despite the economy, Salt House was lively 6pm-10pm last night.  The space is great, although a bit loud, voices carry, tables packed together, which inevitably brings your guests closer together for a more intimate meal.  Foie gras, squid, steak, petrale sole, and chicken were outstanding!!  I don't often order chicken out as it's a staple at home, it was a staff favorite so I gave it a whirl.  It was delicious!  The staff was thorough, gentle and attentive.  It was a leisurely dinner and we did not feel rushed through.
author: erin s.

description: It's a small menu and they seem to execuye it well. I had lunch here with my cousin. He ordered the "soup and sandwich" which is an ahi tuna sandwich with a small bowl of chilled pea soup. He really enjoyed it. I had the Cubano sandwich and I loved it. We started with the Poutine that I'm sure I would love after hours of drinking but that was not the case today. I don't like the cold atmosphere, kind of had enough of the industrial look. I would say that I would go again if someone else wanted to go but I probably won't make an effort on my own.
author: Reza E.

description: Nice establishment, good food.  The acoustics seem to amplify the sound of people talking to a level where it is hard to hear your dinner companions, but other than that a good dining experience.
author: C C.
