description: I went to this restaurant a week after it opened. The place looked great.... I loved the new renovation. I loved how they kept the floor and a lot of the interiors on its original state. I love how they also have one of those community tables. Our server, was great, always had a smile and was attentive, but not too much... (I hate servers that come every ten minutes to ask if everything's alright while you're in the middle of chewing your food down). The food though wasn't at all impressive. This Salt House restaurant was a little too salty for my pallett. I don't know about you, but I don't take a lot of salt in my food. But if you're into that like my friend Jovy is, I'm sure you'll love it!
author: Dhoris P.

description: It's worth going here for the french fries drenched in bechamel, cheese and gravy alone.  Also had a "salty dog" which is grapefruit vodka plus grapefruit juice in a salted cocktail glass.  For desert we had a strawberry trifle, which damn.. was worth the calories.  I had the yellow tail for the entree but let me recommend the chicken, as that what what my friend had and I kept eating off her plate.  We sat at the group community table, which was actually quite fun.. you're in the center of the restaurant and get to watch them make the drinks at the bar while still feel like you're seated at your own table.  Easy parking on a Saturday night, had no reservations and got right in.  Crowd is a little older.  I'd say 45+.
author: kimberly k.

description: A lot of kinks to work out.  The shellfish stew isn't a "stew" at all, but the onion rings that come with the burger are delish.  The service was SLOOOOOWWWW and not particularly good - the guy actually forgot to take our drink order.  I also don't know how I feel about the open kitchen, it's really loud in there, hard to hear the person across the table from you.
author: Ann E.

description:
We have visited this rustic looking spot a few times and absolutely love the food. All I have to say is the chicken is to die for. The most moist tender chicken I have ever eaten. Oh and we just love the crispy shrimp appetizer. 
The old printing press warehouse turned retro tasty restaurant makes for a great atmosphere. The only problem is that the tables are very close together and in a small area so it tends to be a little loud and lacking privacy. Also don't arrive early and think you can have a seat at the bar to enjoy the delicious cocktails. There's no room!
author: Melissa P.

description: I almost gave it 4 stars because the service was a little slow, but then I was reminded of the incredible foie gras that I devoured and decided that five stars it is! The dish included both the mousse and the pate version of foie gras and my friend and I were both fighting for the last bites. The baked oysters were nothing to write home about. The wine though was excellent, an interesting and varied list, which made me have a few glasses too many. The atmosphere is fabulous, the space is large with floor to ceiling windows in the bustling SOMA.
author: E. N.

description: Absolutely divine from start to finish.  I had the lamb ribs with tzatziki sauce, cucumbers, and Israeli cous cous and it was just perfect-- the meat fell apart in my mouth, it was so tender. Good lord... I also love the decor- rustic chic, exposed beams, Edison bulbs, lots of wood.  I took off one star b/c the tables are too small AND, there's nowhere to hang one's handbag.  That may seem like a petty grievance, but if you're like me and you work very hard for your ONE nice bag, you really don't want to put it on the floor when you go out to eat, and if you can't even hang it off the chair (they have rounded backs), then you're left with the option of putting your bag on your lap and then covering it with the napkin. Again, it may seem petty, but things like this do affect the experience-- it's just kind of a pain in the ass. But, amazing food, and I'll definitely be back-- I'll just leave my handbag at home:)
author: Elle L.

description: A great place to grab a drink or dinner with your collegues after a long day at work!  The decor is warm and welcoming and their service is great.  Downer about this restaurant though....not to easy to get a reservation....but you definitely have to TRY TRY TRY again!
author: Alice T.

description: Just go for a drink.  Noisy, slow service, Town Hall is better by two stars (food).
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
loved:
the service.  we asked about the wine, how to describe the wine, how the restaurant got its name, etc, and got knowledgeable, un-pretentious answers.  thank you to our server howie for a job well-done.  

the wine.  we went for the house blends.  an excellent bargain and unique wine choice.

the food.  the sole was delicious, although salty (ha).  also had to get the caramelized banana tart and was thoroughly pleased with the decision.  

the only complaint is that it was quite loud.  and by loud i mean i was shouting at times.  suppose that's part of the vibe but i was enjoying a nice meal not ordering shots at a packed bar.  

but i loved it, as did my fellow inquisitive food loving roommate.  we talked about it the whole way home.
author: Kristin K.

description:
Salt House is a cute little restaurant on Mission St. They have a limited menu and a little on the pricey side, but most of the food is pretty good.

I've been there a few times and I was never totally disappointed... I say that because there have been a couple of appetizers that I didn't like too much. On my most recent visit, I had the Alaskan Halibut in a sweetened soy sauce base -- excellent dish. I also tried the calamari and umm -- I don't recommend it. It's not like any other calamari you are used to -- first of all, it was not battered... Hello?!?!?! And it was not fried... Excuse me?!?!?! What's wrong with this picture? So it was fresh calamari sauteed in a curry-ish sauce and stuffed with some kind of sausage.... I know, so weird.

But overall, I was not totally disappointed with this recent visit to Salt House and would recommend the restaurant at least once. It does have a friendly atmosphere and a delightful ambiance. Oh yah, and the 3 cooks were all white guys -- thought that was kinda cool and different. ;)
author: Michelle R.

description: ..went on a whim to this restaurant only to try the house blend of wines...last night, though, they only had reds, no problem, i still ordered a glass- tasted very nice...trying to watch carbo intake, so observed bf devour the bread and butter which was "really good"..rib-eye steak was cooked medium where 1/2 was juicy ...other 1/2 was a little dry...striped bass was yummy and tender but was a bit salty overall- just kept downing that wine- overheard person next to me comment the same thing to his server... tried one of their homemade desserts - listed first on the menu- which was nice to complete the meal...a bit of a pricey establishment...
author: Beignet W.

description: I get it. It Costs alot of $$ to run a restaurant in SF....wages, healthcare, rent, etc, etc.....we were there last week....food was good, ambience nice, service nice......but $ 15.00 for two ( 2) ...count 'em two scallops !?...huh?!...These were average size, maybe the size of a 50 cent piece ...maybe. There were 3 of us.....one of us watched. For $ 15.00 we were not expecting a platter, but.............two? Are they really that expensive?....Come on Salt House....... Two ?
author: Jose C.

description: A couple friends and I went out for a bite, this place was fabulous. It has tone of the best atmospheres. The service was great, he recommended the Poutine for an app and those (french fries) were to die for!  The drinks were fabulous as well, I got the Spanish Kiss which was so refreshing. I love the portions, you can actually have a appetizer and entree and not feel uncomfortably full.  I will be going again soon.
author: Korissa S.

description: We had an early dinner. So, we had the loft all to ourselves. I had the braised Short Ribs. With so many outstanding restaurants in San Francisco, this could be easily passed up. I assure you it's worth it. Check out Opentable.com for reservations before committing.
author: John K.

description:
We had a great time at Salt House last night...
First off, love that they have a parking lot next door. Also, love the decor. Great lamps, very cool feel.
When we first got there we almost had no where to stand it was so packed, but the crowdedness actually was a good thing because it made you feel like you were in a fun spot. We were saying we're over the frumpy austere places - on a Friday night out with friends a loud crazy place is kind of what you're after. So, cocktails in hand, the night was off to a good start.
And then we waited, starving, and waited. They need to maybe book more time for each party to stay at a table - because I know it's not a restaurant's fault if a group won't leave, but also, when you show up for your reservation, you want your table to be ready!
On to the food. It was good! Poutin - excellent. Seriously good drinking food. Crispy fries, cheese, gravy = goodness. Oysters - fresh and tasty with an excellent mignonette. Merguez - good. Loaf of bread wrapped in brown paper - cute touch. And the mains...servings weren't massive but still I don't think one bite was left on the table so that's a good sign. Between us we had the steak, both duck entrees and the striped bass. Only tried the duck leg which was perfect - crispy outside skin cooked to perfection. 
A good time fo sho! Good spot to go with friends for a night out. Probably a bit pricey for what you get? We paid our initial bar bill separately, so with 2 drinks a head, three shared starters and 4 entrees, including tip it came to I think $65 a head. Not bad but not great either. I definitely like the new trend toward cheaper entrees these days so if this place dropped their entree prices a couple bucks I think I'd definitely like them even more!
Give it a go though - and try the poutin! :-)
author: Sarah R.

description:
i celebrated my birthday on saturday at salt house.  even though i had 7:45 reservation, we were seated til more like 8:20ish.  our apetitzers did come out quickly.  we shared the crispy shrimp and the poutine.  both were good, but the poutine was by far the better.  fries in fontina and short rib gravy?  yes, please!!!!  i would go back to just have this over and over again.  between the apps and the entrees, we had to wait quite a while.  when it did arrive, i was most happpy with my duck leg confit.  the skin (as Connie C. said previously) was crisp and the sweet meat melted off the bone.  for dessert i had the strawberry trifle and salt house was kind enough to put a candle in it.  I had noted on my reservation that i was celebrating a birthday.  it was nice of them to remember.  the place is VERY cozy.  my party commented on how they felt like they were in the way.  


all in all, i had a pleasant experience and the food lived up to expectations.  i did like how the staff accommodated my change in reservations and called to confirmt he change the day after.  great follow-up.
author: Sharlene C.

description:
2.5 Stars

Hmm...  I hafta say that I was really really underwhelmed with this place.  Not that is was bad, but it wasn't great either...
Maybe it's because I was expecting so much more from the reviews it got on Yelp, but the food was pretty unremarkable, especially for the price point.
I went last Friday night with my best girlfriends for our Ladies night and as we usually do, we each got something different so that we could try a little bit of everything.
We started with the Poutine, which essentially is a fancy way of saying Cheese Fries wit Sauce.  This was actually my favorite part of the meal and that ain't sayin' much...  Especially since, next we had the Foie Gras, which was just mediocre...  I know, how do you make mediocre foie gras?  Isn't that an oxymoron of some sort?  Well, they succeeded and I adore foie.  It was not bad, but I would say that it was nothing special...  
As far as the entrees, there were 4 of us and we had the chicken, steak, lamb & pork dishes and all of us were underwhelmed...
honestly, i don't even remember who had what...
In a nutshell, the service was good, the food was just ok for the price...
The Ladies' consensus is that we will probably not be back...
author: Rose C R.

description:
this place was OK.  the apps were good, the mains were OK. did not have dessert. 
major criticism was how loud it was.
author: e c.

description: I have been to Salt House about 5-6 times, many of them on an expense account, and enjoyed the bar a few times more and I think it is a solid contributor to the Rosenthal-Washington empire, and the space and ambiance is superb, but it is just OK in my book.  It lacks the wow factor of Town Hall and the cool factor of Anchor&Hope, both of which I have been to many times, and it is quite over-priced for what it is as well. I do love the fries and have had several very nice if not memorable meals here, but nothing that makes me want to write a recommendation on Yelp.  I would highly recommend it as an after work meeting spot on anything other than a Thursday or Friday night (it gets PACKED in the tiny bar) and it is wonderful business lunch spot - airy and chic, and the service is pleasant, usually.  But something, maybe it is the somewhat inconsistent menu (there is a tuna sandwich and a fancy sole dish on same menu, just sort of all over the place in choices - which actually some people may like...) that leaves me a little cold and wondering what creators were going for - is it a fancy bistro? is it great bar, that happens to have ok food? is it fine dining? It tries to be all these things and does not quite work.  I'd still go back but it is not high on my list of go to places -- take a wander over to Anchor&Hope instead (2 blocks away) and prepare to be wowed by the same ownership team!
author: Kirsten M.

description: Great a place for a casual business dinner  with a good acquaintance or a meet up with a friend. The bar is small and the entrance was crowded and might not lend to a first time meet up unless you're really comfortable with close quarters or the person you're with. Food was solidly fabulous but short of a religious experience. Wine list was respectable but they were out of my favorite, the Albarino. Atmosphere was lovely and the service was friendly, polite albeit a tad slow. Still an impressive place to take someone special. Almost 5 stars.
author: Sirima S.

description: I love the food here. I've always eaten at the bar or the communal table and I think I might like it better than a table. Atmosphere is cozy and modern, yet rustic. The food has always been really good. I can't recommend just one thing. Everything I've tried has been tasty and satisfying.
author: S. P.

description:
I won't lie at all... This is my preferred first lunch date spot--NOT! But I don't understand why all of the suits and skirts come here in the evening for happy hour. I'd much rather prefer Harlot next door for drinks, then take the backdoor entrance to Salt House to have dinner. Service for dinner seemed stale and stoic, while the lunch staff seemed much more attentive and warm. 

Sure: the place looks nice, parking isn't too bad, and the drinks are delicious. The selection is pretty eclectic, but the food isn't anything to rave about. The things that irk me are the clientele who dine here--"nice hair, nice shoes"--and the fact that they got rid of the bacon, egg, and cheese sandwich for lunch. (I think my palette is pretty good, so don't be surprised with what I'm about to say...) That was the best item on the menu. Nothing else is really memorable.
author: Travel Swagger R.

description:
MEH.

HYPED. What's the big deal about this place? I'd heard so many good things about Salt House and finally went today for lunch. My conclusion: overpriced mediocre food that is presented nicely. 2.5 Stars.

My first thought upon reading the lunch menu: Not enough selections in the main entrees.

I decided to go with the Grilled Steak Sandwich (with carmelized onions & chimichurri) and Crazy Chips. Our server was helpful in explaining to me that Chimichurri is a sauce that they put on the steak made from different chopped up herbs (almost reminded me a bit of a variation of a pesto). The sandwich was greeeaasy. So greasy that I almost felt I shouldn't eat it. It tasted okay, but it was nothing special or impressive. Aside from the Chimichurri that they put on the steak, it was almost a bit bland. The Crazy Chips (which I think are made from sweet potato) were so oily and greasy that I couldn't even eat them at all. I had a few to taste and left all the rest. I only ate the sandwich because I was hungry and didn't want to waste. I am definitely no health freak and love unhealthy and some greased up food, so if I think it's way too greasy, that should say something. BLEH, I feel like I just poured some oil down my throat. I need to detoxify. NOW.

The steak sandwich & a glass of rose plus tax & tip = $30 for a lunch not enjoyed and obligingly eaten. My co-worker ordered the Crispy Shrimp appetizer, which had a great presentation, but I don't know how it tasted.

I did like the interior and feel of the restaurant, and their service was friendly, so those were both pluses. I would only give Salt House a second chance to try their dinner, which MUST be better given all the talk about this place, but I would hope it's not as greasy as lunch was today. Let's just hope today was an off-day for them.
author: Felicia C.

description: I'm a big fan of Salt House and Anchor and Hope. Both restaurants have great seafood. Grabbed a drink at the bar first before dinner. The bar area is cute but its rather small. Overall, I liked the feel of the restaurant though. I do think its funny that its connected to harlot. We ordered a bunch of oysters which were delicious and I had the tuna. Cant remember much more because I went a while back but i do remember leaving feeling very satisfied by the meal and my company.
author: shadi m.

description:
I usually prefer dim lighting, but this brightly lit, crisp and contemporary atmosphere was a refreshing way to change things up a bit.  Brick, wall art, and high industrial loft ceilings gave this place an energetic flare.  And while the place was somewhat narrow, things felt plenty spacious once we were seated.  The ambient volume here was a tad on the higher side, but nothing too overwhelming.  

In addition to the food being prepared well, dishes were inventive and well-balanced.  The truffle mashed potatoes were great, and the meat was cooked to perfection.

Will be sure to return to this one some day.
author: Jon F.

description: Count me among the converted. Every time I've come back to Salt House I've been more and more impressed. The chicken I had on Saturday clinched the extra star and I'm upgrading my review from three stars to four.
author: Tal K.

description: Fabulous mileau and fun, tasty food, but the timing and service need work.  Hopefully, this will start to come together as the kitchen and dining room staff find their groove.  I ordered two starters and my companion ordered an entree.  The entree came 25 minutes after I recieved my dishes (even though we told our server that we wanted everything together).   When we made mention of the gaffe to our server, she got defensive, which bummed us out even more.  However, the restaurant recovered mightily, when the manager sent out three amazing desserts gratis (try the pecan ice cream--divine!), bringing along the pastry chef to introduce and explain them.  He was yummy, too!!
author: Shannon M.

description:
we went here the other week and found this place to be pretty good.  we had a reservation for four and only waited about five minutes for our table.  we stood in this oddly placed but interesting waiting space that seems like a dinner table should be sitting there.  we were essentially standing in front of the bar and on either side of us were people eating their dinner.  it was kind of cool, though.  the lights above the bar are tres cool as well.  one of us had even decided that they were going to install them into their new house in marin!

when we were sat we were shortly greeted by our slightly over the top waitress.  she was definitely knowledgeable and present- but she seemed almost as though she was on stage performing for us.  at times it wasn't all that authentic.  but she did the job- so i can't complain too much.

the first thing i noticed was the bread that was served.  it was yummy and beautiful shaped- wrapped and delivered in a piece of white paper.  the only thing missing- which i found to be very odd- was something to dip it in or spread on it.  they literally just plopped bread on the table with no oil or butter.  so i requested olive oil- which was forgotten but then brought when i asked again.  the olive oil was really good quality- pungent and green- just the way i like it!  i am not sure why they don't serve the bread with the olive oil to begin with- like most italian restaurants do.  but at least they had good quality olive oil on hand when i asked for it (unlike globe- see my review).  

so the four of us ordered several things.  for appetizers we got the salt cod, something made out of pork (can't remember), a really yummy shrimp/salad dish, and one other thing that is seeming to evade me right now.  for entrees we had the kobe beef, the snapper and i think the salmon (right now i wish i had asked for the menu so i could be more specific- sorry!).  the fish dishes were amazing!  as was the kobe beef.  for dessert we got the sorbet with fruit tart and some other delectable thing.  all in all the meal was very good.

in terms of alcoholic beverages- the cab by the glass was great.  the boys had dirty martinis- and they liked them.  but how can one go wrong with a dirty martini?  we did ask for extra olives and our waitress forgot.  

all in all the place is good.  i give it four stars because of the waitress (who did her job- but it was just kind of fake).  i am open to checking it out again and re-reviewing it though :)  when i have time! although there are too many restaurants in the city to check out- and too little time ;)
author: Harmony R.

description: Very similar to a lot of other places these days, but the food was tasty and the service was fast (but we were sitting at the bar, which tends for faster service anyways...).  No real complaints but not totally wowed.  I'd probably opt to go to some new restaurant (to me) before I'd paricularly go back, but I would never turn down the offer to go back either.
author: Kerry L.

description: The duck is amazing. The sliced pieces were excellent, but what was crazy good was the little square pressed leg (?) of duck. Not quite sure how to rate this place. Baked oysters were good but not to gush over. The desert with some type ginger cake, not so good. Service was decent, but something about the overt casualness of the place that made the experience a little less special. Nice looking folks in the kitchen roasting my duck though. I'd hit it.
author: D'arcy N.

description: I am feeeling fine with a nicely padded tummy from the yummy I just devoured.  I started at the top of the menu with the breakfast sandwhich since this is my first time.  Why not try their headliner nosh?  We are talking Biscuit Sandwhich with a chicken hash middle covered with light cheddar and a softly scrambled egg.  Did they know I was coming?  The biscuit was Sage inspired and I do mean inspired!  The young lady who took my order was pleasant and engaging which is why I started at the top item and not the bottom.  Fair price I would say, since I could have gotten 3 biscuits sands from Micky D's for this price.  I will go back...on payday...with upscale clothing on...ready to run ten extra minutes on the treadmill...Chow...or is it Ciao.
author: John S.

description: Took a friend here for his birthday last thursday.  It took a ridiculous amout of time to get our food.  We had to asking every employee who passed to either check on the order or send our waiter, who was no where to be seen for a good 30 minutes.  One of them apologized and promised they would 'take care of us' but we were not offered so much as a complimentary cup of coffee even though when the food finally came my order was wrong.  Waiter said he would check with the kitchen but never came back except to bring the bill.  Celery soup was very good but only about three tablespoons of it in a tiny well of large plate.  Chicken was good but nothing amazing for the price.  Vodka tonics were served in very small glasses and mostly ice - for $11 each.  Overall, a very irritating experience considering i spent about $140 for dinner for two.
author: Jeralyn S.

description:
I had the pork belly appetizer and the petrale sole with fava beans and bacon butter jus. The pork belly was really soft and anything cooked in a bacon flavored sauce can't be bad. The rhubarb tart was decent and luckily the lavendar ice cream it came with didn't taste too much like eating flowers. 

The spring peach cooler was also good (it has both grey goose and sparkling wine in it) although I remember it being a pear cooler when I was there? The restaurant itself is nice with lots of hardwood and brick but it was way too loud for dinner with just a couple of people. Apparently it's where all the people in suits come to hang out at the bar late on a Thursday night. Someone should tell them you can at least take off your tie when you're having a few drinks.
author: Jane C.

description: Great Dining Experience for my birthday.  We were recommended by Sai's Butler Service.  The service was great even thouth it was very packed on a Saturday night.  We ordered the heir-loomed tomatoes, the best I ever had.  We also had the baked clams which were good.  The two main  entrees that we ordered were the monk fish and tuna.  The monkfish was moist and tasty.  It tastes like lobster.  The tuna was above average.  It's a great dining experience near Market Street.  Also you have to reserve in advance for dinners.
author: Alex L.

description: Met the chef what an ass, I wanted to try this place, not any more. Guess they don't need the business.
author: Dee D.

description:
we sat at the bar where they also serve the full menu.  started with a glass of chardonnay (yummy!).  amy winehousey receptionist gave off a bit of a 'tudey vibe (for a place as popular/trendy as this, would you expect anything less?) but was nicer than expected.  

my girlfriend and i ordered 2 appetizers - the crispy shrimp with string beans and the poutine.  we split an entree - the sole over some type of legumes - and a dessert - the carrot cake with carrot granita (first time i heard the word 'granita' and now i see it everywhere).  everything was cooked to perfection...and though it took a while to get the food, it's a place where you can appreciate taking your time.  

i think it's a perfect place for small groups (2-4).  cost wise, it came out to about $75 incl tax + tip.  NOT BAD!
author: Adela K.

description: Forget reading the menu, just order the roasted chicken (it's quite simply unparalleled in this city) and the poutine fries. Now admittedly, when I heard about these cheese and gravy covered fries, the combo sounded a bit unappetizing. But as you can't go here without trying them, I did and they were AMAZING!  The next time I have a really trying day, I'm headed back for more. My only suggestion is to serve them in a warm skillet, since they got cold rather quickly.  Our server also gets a gold star - service was outstanding in every way!
author: a p.

description: Had a great time here last week, mainly because of the company I kept.  However, the food was also a good time.  We were seated upstairs on this little balcony-area-thing, overlooking the main dining room.  Very cool.  (I prefer not to eat with the commoners.)  We ordered almost all of the appetizers, all of which were excellent.  I had the yellowfin tuna, which I couldn't finish because of aforementioned apps.  Best part of the night: hanging out with hilarious boys and having one steal the water bottle from the table because it contains my initials, "SH" with crossbones.  All around great night.
author: Shannon H.

description: I had a great meal here period.  The restaurant has a great rustic feel that gives this place a relaxed feel. the food was spot on as well as the service. I tried one of their "blended wines" that come in 3 sizes. I was surprisingly happy.  For the price it was a great value in my opinion.  I would definitely suggest adding this to your list.
author: Brian K.

description: Hate to say it but the hype brought us to Salt House and as it usually goes with hype it generally doesn't deliver. The cool ambiance and great bread offset the over-priced, average food and ordinary service. Not a dining thrill - there are plenty of other places to try again.
author: Taj A.

description: I'm not a big fan of seafood but my friends wanted to try this place and so we did.  I thought the portion was too small and the price was too expensive.  The service wasn't exactly that great either but for some reason the restaurant is always packed!  I definitely won't be going back there again!
author: JenJen W.

description: Great food and a good bar. We sat at the tall share table and certainly didn't have any service problems!
author: Jerry M.

description:
Friends and I are driving around on Saturday looking for somwhere to eat, and seeing we're in the Embarcadero area, someone mentions Houston's.  Meh...!  I love Houston's, but I'm getting tired of their never-changing menu, so I sugget we try somewhere else.  Someone pops up with Salt House.  Never heard of it, but it never hurts to try. 

 We, party of three, roll in without reservations on a Saturday evening, so we're not too hopeful, but we luck out, and the hostess sits us upstairs.  Industrial/chic decor greets us mit der requisite bare-brick walls, hard (and wobbly) chairs,  and hello-neighbor-ack!-but-your-table-is-right-next-to-mine seating, but at least we're away from the noisy atmosphere down below.  Friend starts with a glass of waiter-recommended white which my picky-friend raves about, so we're off to a good start.  I notice that the ppl next to us who are seated after us get bread and we don't.  We flag down someone who gets us bread.  This seems to be an unfortunate pattern which continued throughout the meal.  Stuff came if you asked for it, but you had to ask for it.  Regular water initially.  We asked for Voss water.  Voss water shows up 10 minutes later, and no, the joint wasn't -that-busy!  

Briefly, I order the Goat shank, friend the Ahi tuna, and his son, the Gnocci.  Raves all around!  Definitely good stuff.  To me, food is either good or not.  No point in going into detail.  Just go and try it.  You won't be disappointed.

Oh yeah, one final gripe......our server changed three times.  Why...?  Heck if I know, but this might have been one of the reasons for the slow service.  A minor point, but there it is if you're into service.  4 stars.  The Junkfoodjunkie says, "Check it out!"
author: Dan S.

description:
Short review -- was just there for lunch, sat by the kitchen and cooked (rare, sunny SF day so it was hot).  Unremarkable and not very memorable food, mediocre service.  

Won't be coming back and given that a few blocks away is their sister restaurant "Town Hall" with the same motif, style and crowd, I would have thought they'd at least try and create a different menu, persona, approach...
author: Joe S.

description:
Nice decor and good waiting staffs to start with.
Food was good but I have to say it was way over priced for the portion.
4 little pieces of pork belly for $12?  Poutine was good but how much? Squid was good too, but ....  All the entree was over $23.  Salmon, Monk fish, Lamb shank, Steak.  Talk about steak.  Do not slice my meat before bring it to me.  Effort to cover up the fact the steak is small, ruined the experience of slicing the MEAT. Desserts were good but Rhubarb and apple crisp was cold.  Not because of the ice cream, the middle was literally fridge cold.  When did they bake it? Yesterday?

You are paying for the atmosphere.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: Went for a leisurely lunch today.  Tried the crisy shrimp starter, really good, split the chicken and the burger.  i thought the burger was yummy and the chicken just ok, but my lunch guest lvoed the chicken.  we got some wines by the glass, the $8 rose was fantastic.  look forward to trying the dinner menu and more of those great looking apps.
author: e w.

description: I haven't been there for awhile but I enjoy the wine selection and the food. The salads are good too! After you have dinner you could party at Harlot.
author: Loren T.

description:
i adore salt house. 
ADORE.
a friend and i went awhile back and now that i've succumbed to making my own personal yelp profile, i figured salt house is most deserving of my  first official review. 
housed in the center of SOMA next to the overappreciated roy's, salt house is tucked into this small square space. you open the door and its all clean lines and industrial-based structure. high ceiling, wooden and metal beams, exposed brick, low lighting in a warm comforting kind of way.
i was immediately inclined to be in love with the place.
then our waiter was adorable and flirty and absolutely attentive in a non-claustrophobic kind of way. 
so again, i was completely ready to be swept away by the place... but was waiting on the food for complete scope.
i can tell you that everything i ate was absolutely fantastic. the food was savory and wine was full-bodied and well-recommended. 
but the one thing that sticks out, aside from waiter mchottieness with the killer jeans, are the poutine fries. these are steak fries in a white cheddar and short rib gravy. OMGOODNESS. these are amazing. like, amazing. like, AMAZING. 
go to salt house. it's kinda wonderful. it's unpretentious, high quality, and worth the slightly steep price. 
it was the perfect place to go before our night out salsa dancing but i'm under the impression that it would be the perfect place to go at anytime.
author: rachel b.

description:
I've eaten here a few times, and the experience has gone from a little disappointing (high-expectations) to a much enjoyed meal. Great options to have something delicious that doesn't necessarily make you feel too full. I love the soups. I also seem to recall the hostess' always being very friendly. Not only because they tend to be cute, but just pleasant, looks aside.

That said, had dinner with my mom here a few weeks ago, and as we were waiting for our table, a man with a weird, thin mustache I believe tried to hit on her. This terrifying experience shall always be linked to this establishment.
author: Kaveh A.

description: I thought Salt House was great. Great flavors, great service, beautiful restaurant. Lots of folks I wouldn't want to hang out with normally, but I think that's true for most good restaurants in the city...
author: Fred A.

description: literally a-ok....just went here for the poutine really, the appetizers are better than their entrees........the tag and crab dish was good, but they refused to make it an entree.....nice space though.
author: Monster E.

description:
Staff was very friendly. Older folk (odd for that area except now I think about it Town Hall is kinda like that) but nice. Foie gras comes as two - a pate and seared. They recently changed the glaze/sauce the foie is in, and I wish they would change it back. They give you toast too which was cool because not all restaurants that serve foie remember to do that. That sounds lame-o enough to get shit from my guy friends, but something about duck fat on toast is so damn delicious it makes butter seem healthy. Not as good as Gary Danko's but it's conveniently in SOMA and not super-crowded. Oysters are as fresh as Hog Island but more expensive.

Oh, and the hostess with the tattoos all over her back is caliente. But there is an odd smell coming out of that restaurant of late - does anyone else notice this?
author: service p.

description:
We met up unexpectedly with another couple Friday for dinner.  Everyone agreed they wanted a drink but we were indecisive about food.  We started walking toward Thirsty Bear but before we got there, passed Salt House.  They looked crowded but we walked in anyhow.  Since it was only 6pm the hostess found a table for four but we had to promise we could be done by 7:45 for a reservation to arrive.  

Everyone was friendly and approachable.  The communal table was crowded, as were the bar and tables.  When we sat down I think there was one table open which was quickly filled.  We ordered almost all of the starters on the menu and glasses of wine.  We tried the poutine, (the Montreal gravy and fry dish), homemade pickled vegetables, crab salad, roasted beets with ahi, foie gras with marmalade, the crispy shrimp and a few other dishes I cannot recall.  The crispy shrimp and foie gras dishes were my favorites.  

Service was prompt and unobtrusive, all of the food was delicious but the bill was higher than I'd have thought, at almost $200 for the four of us.  Looking back though, we did have 6 glasses of wine, 2 desserts and probably 6 dishes (all appetizers).  We were definitely full upon our on-time departure and enjoyed our meal.  It was a fun way to enjoy dinner, sampling a variety of dishes and they were all well-executed.  All of us were thrilled with our early-dining timing and how welcoming the entire staff was to seat us without a reservation!  And a big thank you to our dear friends who paid!  We owe you a tasty meal-
author: Elke B.

description: Underwhelming.  I've been here twice and walked away both times thinking I just paid a lot for what I got.  It's ok.  Portions are small.  Restaurant is loud.  Nothing special.  You can do better.
author: Katie A.

description: A table full of older gay men were totally eye-humping my boyfriend and plotting to steal him away when we came here for dinner, but I couldn't have cared less  because I was too busy enjoying my delicious meal.  We got various types of oysters to start with and all were perfect.  I got the sole for my main dish, and I dare to risk my love affair with The Big Four by saying that the sole at Salt House was totally better.  3 star bottom-feeder.
author: Victoria G.

description: Not a great experience, made reservations for 10 so i understand some issues but sat us 30 minutes late and it took them that long to get us a beverage. Service slow but friendly until restaurant winding down, getting empty and we still had no entrees. the food was good but service terribly slow
author: cheri w.

description: I had a decent salad here, but this restaurant isn't very memorable.  It's good for a business lunch though, as it's not too noisy or quiet.  The other members of my party got sandwiches, and they weren't too impressed.  A couple wished they had ordered something else.
author: Robyn F.

description:
I am all about the atmosphere and service as well as good food when it comes to semi-fine dining.  I went to SH with a party of 11 for a not rehearsal wedding dinner.  The service was outstanding with the server being incredibly knowledgeable about the food and extremely pleasant.  the table ordered 11 mojitos' to which I was concerned that there would not be enough mint left for all of it but they managed to do as well as make a second round.  Delicious!
   The ceilings were very high despite semi-close quarters for the tables.  most nice restaurants in Sf usually feel a little cramped due to the low ceilings and small space.  i did not get that claustrophobic feeling at SH.
    The food was actually surprisingly good as well.  I had the bouillabaisse, NY strip and bread pudding for dessert.  Everything was cooked well, served in a timely fashion and the pudding was orgasmic.  They also sent out trays of fresh baked cookies and some mousse thingy on the house.  Go there for a mild celebration, let them know and they hook you up!
author: Donnie N.

description: Was able to grab a couple of seats at the communal table on a packed Friday night.  Started off with a martini with a twist and split the suckling pig appetizer with some friends.  I highly recommend this appetizer.  Simply delicious on top of polenta.  For entrees, they had a lot of fish selections on their menu.  Whenever I see monkfish on the menu, I always order it.  I was disappointed though.  The saffron broth sauce was super salty.  And my friend's rib eye had some weird salty bread crumbs garnish on it.  Is the theme here salt??  Btw, the hostess that night was a dead ringer for Amy Winehouse.
author: J I.

description: I really enjoyed my dinner. The decor was also pleasant. I've read that some reviews that pple don't think it lives up to it's hype. I went when it first opened (despite the date on this post). I didn't have any expectations other than it was supposed to be good. I think you should go with the expectation that it will be above average, but not earth shattering.
author: Lin N.

description: I dig catching dinner at this place. I usually order the poutine, as I am a unabashed fan of fries smeared in unhealthy things. My favorite part of the Salt House experience though is drinking a touch of Chateau Musar from Lebanon. Goodness me is that great wine.
author: Chris S.

description: YUMMY!  Just an awesome place to sit and hang out with friends and enjoy a delicious meal.  I've always felt welcomed there and the servers just have amazing wine knowledge.  Ever plate that comes from the kitchen is beautiful and the flavors are marvelous. And....  I have a little crush on that tall, cute girl that works in the kitchen. Great food, great staff, and a cute girl to cook for me... What more do I need from a restaurant!
author: Michelle G.

description:
Salt House is really a 3.5, but I have a lot of 4s, so I think I need to round down and hope they earn that 4th star over time. 

I really want to like this place: the decor is cool in an exposed brick/stuffed pheasant in branches/oversized paining of Don Quixote sort of way, the food is quite good, and the first time I came I had a pleasant exchange with the bartender while I waited for my date to arrive. I went back again with some folks from work and we had a great time, but I've come to a conclusion about the food: I think it's trying a little too hard. I'm not a culinary expert, but I enjoy a good meal and am up for a little adventure. But there were some downright odd things going on on our plates. I had a really tasty short rib with brussels sprouts (inspired from a positive experience at 1300 Fillmore the prior week), but the crust/topping was weird tasting and I ended up scraping it off. My colleague ordered the grilled chicken, which was good, but the creamed spinach was so... creamed... it turned her off (she said it was more like a spinach reduction). For dessert we tried the butternut squash pannacotta, which was easily overpowered by the sweet/tart strawberry sauce. 

Net, net: A lot of really solid elements, but if it sounds like a weird combination on the menu, it probably is.
author: Greenballoon X.

description: I think this place is awesome! The rib-eye gravy with the fries is the most delicious thing ever! I know it sounds heavy and it is, but it is truly one of those things that you crave after you had it. Good stuff!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Well at least they named it correctly, because they sure put a lot of salt on everything I had. They even cooked the fruit that came on the salad. THEY EVEN RUINED GOOD FRUIT, and of course, they salted it too. I must have drank a gallon of water after eating here to clean my system out.
author: Ricardo O.

description: i can't understand why people aren't more pumped about this place!  i actually think it's quite good and innovative, especially for downtown.  I have been a few times now and really enjoyed it each time.  maybe the fact that i haven't had to pay yet explains why i like it so much??  regardless, the food always seems extremely fresh and tastes wonderful.  last time i was there for lunch and had a beet salad which was awesome, and then i had chili with grilled cheese sandwich for my entree.  okay, maybe the chili was a bit pricey, but it was pretty darn tasty...  in my experience, service has been good as well.   all in all, one of my favorite downtown restaurants.
author: Yvette H.

description: I really want to like this place, but it's not happening. I went back last week after staying away for one (far more delicious) year. This place is so mediocre that I don't know what to do with it. The atmosphere would suggest a great place to meet friends for an easy dinner. Well, easy is right. So easy that I probably could have made what came to my table in my very small kitchen. This time around, I tried ordering smaller plates to share. I was less than impressed. The best thing that came to the table--well besides the Cote de Rhone--was a bowl of mixed nuts in truffle honey. Almost needless to say, I'm still not impressed by this place.
author: candace a.

description: I made reservations for 3 people ahead of time. The hostess sat us at table right by the door while there were several open tables, we were cold and wanted to move. When we asked to be seated elsewhere she said that we could ONLY have the table by the kitchen (I should have worn my sunglasses.-the bright lights were annoying). She claimed it was because the other tables were for 4 and we were 3. Well some of those other tables were open until we left! After spending a few hundred dollars it would be nice if it was a pleasant experience all around. When I mentioned this to the manager she only had excuses. While the food was good and the actual food service was good, it was a negative to be told that we had to sit at the worst table when they were saving them for I don't know who.
author: Janet l.

description:
enjoyed a post-work holiday dinner with a couple of co-workers here - my first foray into the town hall/salt house/anchor & hope trifecta. typical sf urban-industrial-chic casual setting, with exposed brick/concrete walls and beams, large windows overlooking the street (and alley), comfy banquette seating along one brick wall, hardwood floors - not the best acoustics as it can get pretty noisy with all the hard surfaces (also bare tabletops) but not to the point where you have to yell across the table - still manageable to have a decent conversation. 

great service - our waiter deftly answered questions about the menu and portions, made good recommendations about how much to order and what types of wine, and was generally available and always gracious. busboys also promptly served the bread and kept water glasses filled. 

and yummy food! 

apps: terrific beet salad (here i go again w/ the beets!) - golden heirloom beets that were hardly recognizable as beets - so fresh and tasty with mixed greens, blue cheese, walnuts. nicely seasoned crispy shrimp contrasted with crisp-tender spicy green beans, salty serrano ham and almonds. and the poutine - talk about comfort food! perfect for that cold, foggy evening....a heap of crispy fries topped with gooey melted cheddar and flavorful short-rib gravy. definitely an upgrade from chili-cheese fries! i was worried that it would be too filling but easily devoured by three women and we were left wanting more... 

good thing we saved room for the entrees - the gnocchi was perfect, both in texture and flavor. (and went well with the riesling i ordered, as the waiter had confirmed). 

and for dessert? peppermint profiteroles in a rich dark chocolate sauce. yum.... 

the place quickly filled up considering it was a monday evening in the midst of tightening budgets - must be the holiday season. but definitely worth a return trip for those times when willing to splurge a bit. 

one minor negative - we were seated near the entrance and while the door remained closed for the most part and there wasn't any draft, you could tell you were in an "urban" location (read - city smells wafting in...either through the windows, the ventilation, the brick...who knows) i didn't notice it but one of my coworkers did...i guess you get accustomed to it?
author: Jen P.

description: The food at Salt House is fantastic!  We enjoyed each and every dish.  Loved the space and the service is great as well.  Very low key, but on the ball!  We will definately be back for another wonderful meal.
author: Laura M.

description: A more delicious burger cannot be found in all of downtown SF. Sat at the bar during an early lunch and washed it down with a glass of Roshambo Zinfandel.
author: Rene D.

description: Awesome upscale American. What else can you expect from the people who also brought us Town Hall? I can see how Salt House is one of the top ten booked restaurants on Opentable. Came here on business lunch, of course, and I had the poutine, winter salad, and mint lemonade. The poutine was a great, heart-attack inducing (potatoes, cheddar, gravy) starter and the winter salad balanced it all off nicely. The mint lemonade tasted like a refreshing (virgin) mojito. My colleagues had the chicken pot pie and they gave it rave reviews. Minus one star for the 40 minutes we had to wait to get our meal only to devour it in 10 minutes since we had to rush back to the office for a 2:00 meeting. Booo.
author: Natalie T.

description: Perfect! This place is so well done. Manageable, friendly, fun. I love the communal table.  Those gravy fries, the tuna, and the house white blend is a great kickoff to some girls' night out FUN!
author: Susan A.

description:
This place is owned by the same guy that owns Town Hall, which is rightfully famous.  I had high expectations for this place...and...well, the bread was AMAZING!

I ordered Portuguese Braised Calamari with manilla clams, mussels and white polenta.  It was the MOST AWFUL thing I ever ordered at a restaurant.  I was damn hungry, so I downed my dish with 2 tall glasses of water.  The yellowfin tuna appetizer looked good, but was a bit dry. Decent, but not memorable.

Supposedly, the Foie Gras, cured and sauteed, was heaven and witnessing the faces of the girls who tried it, it was definitely more than heavenly.

The hanger steak was dry and overcooked and we didn't bother to try dessert.  But did I say that the bread was AMAZING? I went through a whole loaf and even had to ask for more butter...
author: Alex C.

description: I guess it could be worse, but in this price range and neighborhood you can honestly do much, much better.  I work very close by and have eaten here many times, and while it's never been downright bad, I've never once had anything I would call memorable.  The food is bland, predictable, and pretentious, and the wait staff lacks polish.  The atmoshere is noisy, busy, and claustrophobic.The only reason I'd go back is for a work function - unfortunately the proximity to my office makes it a popular default.
author: Sarie L.

description: Very swanky.  The bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable, but my issue stems from the bread being better than the entrees.  I love bread, but it should never eclipse interesting and eclectic selections.  To be honest, for the same price and quality, you might as well stop by Zuni and enjoy some decent fries.  Save this spot for an after-work drink and an appetizer.
author: Lane K.

description: I came here to check out what SF's restaurant scene had to offer. I sat at the community table since I was dining by myself. Ordered the poussin dish and from what I can recall it was a lot of food. They sure don't skimp out. Good but not great. Met some interesting people while dining at the community table.
author: Christine D.

description: We tried to go here awhile back but it was impossible just to walk in and get a table. So planning ahead, I made reservations!  We started with the mixed nuts as a snack and OMG - hot nuts drizzled in honey truffle oil, can it get any better!? I had the scallops ( I had to refrain from licking the plate clean as the portion was a bit lacking) and the Yellowfin Tuna which was SO good.  I think that the food and service is worthy of a 4 star rating, but I was tempted to knock it down to 3 star for the noise factor. I could not hear the person sitting across the table for me and my throat was hoarse from yelling to be heard.  It was such a noisy restaurant...And I am partially deaf from going to too many punk rock concerts in my youth.
author: Jenn C.

description: Just tried out this restaurant today. It was better then I expect. it is the same owner as Town hall, my experience at town hall was just so so. They have some good oyster selections, good selections of seafood dish and desert. :) The waiter was SUPER attentive that's always plus. I have to say this just made it to one of my top restaurants (other then gary danko and ducca)
author: Ervinna L.

description: This restaurant is beautiful. I'm in love with the lofted space, the soft lighting, and the architecture's tribute to the building's past industrial life.  The ambience created a perfect setting for celebrating my boyfriend's birthday.  i set it all up over the phone, and the staff did a wonderful job making it happen, and so smoothly at that.  Our first visit left us with no memorable meals, unfortunately, and my dishes were a bit too salty (no pun intended) for my tastes.  I'll give it another try sometime, but four stars until then.
author: Andrea U.

description:
What a lunch!  
My husband and I went to see the Cartoon Art Museum for free first Tuesday.  What a fun museum, worth the trip from the East Bay.  We then stopped off at SFMOMA for a quick tour of their latest exhibits before we headed over to the Salt House.  The place was jammed!  Luckily we had thought about that possibility and had made reservations. 
We were a few minutes early, so started our date with a glass of wine at the bar.  That was a bit of a tight fit.  The table closest to the bar was full of folks so that their chairs made it difficult to navigate, however we managed.  We barely got a sip of wine before our table was ready.
I had the burger and my husband had chili with grilled cheese.  Both dishes were excellent.  The service was very friendly.  The wine was good.  What more can you ask for...dessert!  Yup, we shared the brioche pudding.  YUMMY!  We will definitely go back to the Salt House.
author: Carol H.

description: Amazing service but more importantly amazing food. Had the best experience and definitely going back.
author: Kylie L.

description: my husband works right by this place and says it's overrated. service is lacking, food is ok, Town Hall is much cheaper (and owns this place) and you're paying extra for the ambience. It's a good place though for business.
author: jenn w.

description: We were really lucky to be squeezed into a table last minute with no reservation, around 6pm. Unfortunately, the food sucked. We ordered 4 appetizers (including poutine) and the only decent one was the merguez lamb sausage. Suckety suck.
author: Marina N.

description:
this is the sister restaurant to town hall and so far I like town hall better. the good: a friend and I sat at the bar during happy hour and were treated to wonderful service. the bartender actually made something delicious from my strange, vague, non-alcoholic request. the decor is contemporary yet respectful of the building's old, ragged facade.

the bad: on the other hand, the graffiti-esque art on the walls is kind of overkill. with the prices and the fidi location, the whole yuppie/graffiti art combo annoys me. also the happy hour clientele is, for the most part, less-than-charming. 

and the food: the poutine was very good, but then, fries in short-rib gravy are hard to mess up. my petrale sole with chantarelles and almonds sounded much better than it tasted. if you want to go swank and leave with a smile, do town hall instead.
author: rachel m.

description: Ok so there was soooo much hype over this joint, and truth be told I don't get it.  I believe the best thing was the foise gras, but unfortunately that was the beginning and end of a great meal.  Everything else after was ok.  I had something like striped bass or yellow fin tuna, it's that forgettable.  Not only was the food mediocre, but the wine pairing brought the level of our taste buds down.  The wine offering was dismal, I'd come back if someone else was paying...
author: Kelli M.

description:
Felt a little under-dressed for a casual dinner in the SOMA on a sat night, but non-the-less, a good place to eat.  

Pre-meal: log of bread wrapped in deli paper- haha, creative yet cheap. The bread looked very interesting - like they just chopped off a tree branch - but it tasted great.
Meal: My girlfriend and I both ordered the steak (I forget what they really called it on the menu - something fancy tho). It was great - melted in your mouth with the delectable sauce . + local IPA (very potent).
After-meal: ordered a specialty drink: the salty dog. (Grapefruit flavor, salt, vodka) - sounded interesting, but not our style. Sort of like a punch in the mouth. The bartender, however, was very gracious and recognized that we weren't falling in love with the drink (even though we didn't say it out right). So he said he would try again with something we would like. We picked the Kentucky Apple, but again, found the bourbon to linger a bit too long like a drunken college girl who just hurled all over your bathroom and passed out on your couch. So no go there.... but good on him for trying. Guess it just wasn't our night in picking the drinks we liked, but for what they were, im sure it is an aquired taste for some. 
Overall, price was a bit steep, but i don't mind paying well for the good/attentive service and tasty food we received. 

I would definitely go there again, as it does offer a lesson in food terminology on the menu that you don't run into very often unless you only eat in the SOMA.
author: Tania E.

description:
came here for some late night drinks
wine and cheese plates were perfect
dessert was forgettable, think it was some sorta cake, i dunno, i don't remember

although the food looks good
so, i shall be back

p.s. they share the bathroom with Harlet (nightclub) 
not a good idea, mirrors were totally jacked, maybe because they weren't real mirrors
author: Heidi L.

description:
This was the first dinner we had on our visit to San Fransisco and no other restaurant we went to on that trip was even half as good.
The people were really friendly and the service was great. Our server was really knowledgeable about the various shellfish and they even found a cucumber to serve in our Hendricks and tonic (I am so surprised how many restaurants cannot give you a cucumber in your f-ing cucumber/gin. Apparently walking back to the salad area in the kitchen is too strenuous).
 The house wine is also pretty good and it is served in these cool little old-medicine-esque bottles. 
We started with the calamari which was prepared in a way that I had never had before. It was superb. I will remember it for the rest of my life.  Spices were right on with just the right balance of textures.
My dinner, halibut, was fantastic as well. I would have liked to have had everything on the menu actually. 

We skipped on dessert to have cream puffs from Beard's Papa, but from what I saw, the desserts looked good, too.

If in San Fransisco again, I will for sure go back.
author: Jessica M.

description: Wonderful place. Great service and food. I came here for lunch and had the duck confit. The skin was crispy and the meat was perfectly seasoned. I like the loft space of the building.
author: Robert C.

description: Good service but the food is a lot better at their sister restaurant, Town Hall albeit it is a different style.  I like the decor of the place and the location has very convenient parking nearby.  It's really like a 3.5 star for me.
author: Dan Y.

description: I was so excited to go to the Salt House but left so totally disappointed that I had to join Yelp just write a review.  The food was bad, the shrimp wasn't deveined at all and the Poutine was NOT a real Poutine.  They served the wrong bottle of wine and only one out of four of us enjoyed their meal.  Only redeeming feature was decor. I am a Montrealer and was really excited to make this a place regular due to the Poutine but will never go back.
author: M G.

description:
Atmosphere was good, nice ambiance but food was a big disappointment.
Ordered the Seafood Platter, which was over priced and it wasn't even 
that fresh.  The rest of the food was really nothing to be excited about.
Bathroom was dark ,no soap and they share it with the bar behind the restaurant.
2 stars for the atmosphere and great service but that's about all
author: tina c.

description:
It was almost impossible to get a restaurant reservation in San Fran on a Monday night and someone suggested the Salt House.  

The decor is cute but the high ceilings and exposed brick make it hard to hear.  But who cares, because the drinks were sublime.  I had the Blue Door - divine combination of cucumber juice, mint, simple syrup and gin.  Not too sweet, light and delicious.  

The food was pretty good and the staff were fabulous.  We had a very helpful, charming woman who was really good about my long embarrassing list of allergies.  I had the pork belly - a little dry but still a wonderful combination with asparagus etc.  I then had the new york steak with white beans - great piece of meat and a good textural and flavour combination.  The desert was half great and half not so great (it was ice cream sandwich, served in three separate components).  The marshmallow was divine - light, fluffy crispy - and they also gave me some meringue sticks to taste - the best I've ever had - the crispy/chewy/soft combination of the best pavlova shell but in a toothpick size.  Apparently the ice cream cake was average but the lemon tart got high marks.

They should redo their website - it's slow and the menu must be an old one because only the main we had was listed.

We went on a Monday night and it was packed.  Fun atmosphere.
author: Amanda W.

description: This place has really delicious hamburgers. I'm not going to critique anything else they have on their menu, but I just wanted to say that their hamburger with bleu cheese was amazing!
author: Simon L.

description:
I ate here for my birthday a couple of months ago and I have been meaning to write my review. Before I went here, I heard it was a great place so my husband and I tried it out. The ambiance was great but the food was average. I was disappointed because I was hoping for a real nice birthday dinner. :-( I had the steak and my husband had the chicken. It's not that the food was bad, we just felt that it was missing something that made it original. We felt it was a little bland. The highlight was the french Canadian poutine, which we shared as a app but even that actually lacked salt - isn't that ironic! :-) 
Anyway, perhaps I have very different tastes than the others here but I sure know what poutine should taste like because I am from Quebec!
author: Caroline K.

description: Overrated and overpriced.  The only good thing about this restaurant was the service.  Our waiter was very attentive.  Came for the first time through the Dine About Town promo and our table ordered whatever was offered: 2 courses for $17.95-an appetizer plus one main dish.  You had only two options each.  I had the duck terrine and it was fine.  The bread that came with the terrine was too dry and broke apart every time you chewed into it. The marmalade was in one quadrant; the pickled vegetables in another; the terrine in the third; and the bread, in the fourth.  I then had the chicken salad and had two bites and that was it.  Too many ingredients, not enough flavor, not enough greens.  Someone else ordered the seafood dish and he had no complaints but it didn't look that great, way too many mussels.  The soup looked appetizing and the other friend enjoyed it but wasn't impressed by it.  Just because this was a promo doesn't mean the quality of the food has to be shoddy.  We were auditioning the restaurant we heard so much about and now do not plan on coming back for dinner.
author: Nadine H.

description:
A lot has already been said, so I will try to keep it short:

-It is one thing to wait for your dishes while the kitchen is bustling & slaving away.  Quite another to wait for your dish while the chef is chatting up the staff (yes, a downside of open kitchens guys: we can see you!). This may be a totally unfair comment, because our dishes might have been cooking away under someone else's watchful eyes. But in general, the staff seemed to be hanging out a lot next to the bar & kitchen.
-Salt cod brandade: I LOVE salt cod. I LOVE olives. The 2 mixed together just walk all over each other and make it ... well, one big olivish tasting puree.
-Monkfish: well done. Audacious mix of fish and meat that comes out very nicely. Go with red wine with it.
-Clientele: bean counters & bankers. To be expected based on the location. Good for gold-digging, not good for wild night on the town.
author: L. N.

description:
ok, this is a mini review, or a mini gripe,  since i only had lunch here, which was a petite crab salad. it was good but for $15 it was teenie, really teenie, like that was a nice taste, can i get the rest of the salad? but the bigger question is why is a hamburger $15 at salt house but $10 at townhall? i love the hamburger at townhall and for $10 it's a great deal, but why $15 at  salt, considering that i think townhall is the "fancier" restaurant of the two. 
if i ever go back for dinner, i will write more of a proper review. but for now, way overpriced restaurant but love what they did to the space and love the vibe of this place.
author: Jen S.

description: I went to Salthouse on a Friday night, had reservations, so I wasn't worry about how packed it was. The hostess told us that they are wrapping up our table....that took 30 minutes :(  We sat down and checked the menu: appetizers: The tuna tartar was very good and the foie gras was delicious. On to the Entrees: The Petrale Sole was nothing special, the pecking duck was a bit bland and the monkfish was again nothing special.  The biggest disappointments were the desserts. We ordered the corn custard tart...interesting but nothing to write home about, the molten chocolate cake was lacking some flavor and the raspberry poppyseed cake tasted like a muffin. So all in...if you want to go here for a drink and appetizers and to see and be seen - I guess its an ok place. For dinner I would go somewhere else.
author: Conny F.

description: I was REALLY anticipating to like this place from everything I've heard. Finally decided to take a client there for lunch today. Talk about underwhelmed. People seated to the left and right of us got their food way ahead of us and the server could care less. Aside from the hostess, the service in general didn't look so great. The concept's great, the food selection was good, but the food was just decent and not worth the price. Might give it a shot for dinner sometime, but probably not until I forget about today's lunch experience.
author: Michael A.

description: Went for lunch.  Waited for fifteen minutes in crowded upstairs seating before any water or waiter sighting.  This should have been an hour lunch.  It took nearly two hours, because the service was incredibly slow.  The food was fine, but nothing special, with the exception of the bread that hails from Acme, I think, that was delicious.  Both my friend and I agreed that the food was not nearly good enough to get us back for another over-long lunch.
author: Matthew R.

description: Came here for dinner for an anniversary with the boy, and we wound up loving our appetizers and liking our entrees.  Like every other review here, try the poutine.  Soooooo delicious...heart attack on a plate, but delicious nonetheless.  We also had the suckling pig with a fruit gastrique (which I think is off the menu now) but the little square of pork on my plate was yummy - the meat was moist, and the skin was oh so crispy.
author: Courtney B.

description: I'd recommend coming here on a wknd...a bit crowded during the week w/people drinking/eating here that work nearby.  Food is not out of this world.  Not all that impressive...but wasn't terrible.
author: Nana S.

description:
my coworkers LOVE this place.  I dunno why...but they go practically every friday, and the coworker that sits next to me can't stop talking about the foie gras (sp?)

I had a particularly late night at work since my coworker dropped a last minute project in my lap, but he made up for it by taking me here.  fancy dinner?  okay I'll be your friend again.

good food, but didn't really feel it was worth the price tag (but what am I complaining about, I didn't pay for it).  would recommend the foie gras myself, but you can probably skip the sole/pekin duck (yes, it's pekin duck, not peking duck.  who knows why)
author: jozilla w.

description: Hours for there "in between" menu were from 2pm-5:30pm got there on time but the chef  was a "stickler" and cut it off at 5:15pm! I'm a "stickler" with my money and went to Roy's down the street and had a great meal.  I hope the Salt house updates there website.
author: Ken S.

description: Stopped in for a quick late night bite at teh bar.  The crispy shrimp, served with green beans, Serrano ham, and almonds was very delectable.  The Poutine was amazing with short-rib gravy and Vermont shard cheddar.  The decor/atmosphere was spectacular, next visit will be for a full meal I can take my time on.
author: c d.

description: Business colleagues love to meet here for lunch.  I was VERY impressed my first visits.  But the food and service is getting a little less than what it once was.
author: D B.

description: I love the decor, the food, the wine list & bartender who modified drinks for those who have creative tastes! I admit, the wait's a bit long to get a table.  The servers, however (especially Jenny) were SO much fun, you didn't even remember having waited.  Lovely time, both!
author: Amber S.

description: The food and service was amazing!  Just hadlunch and still full!  The tri-tip french dip was sooo yummy - Apps  were a little pricey but still were very good!  Very happy will go back again and again!!!  Super service from the hostess to our server to the table cleaner (bus boy but that sounds rude -but so does table cleaner)  Excellent!!!!!
author: Jodi B.

description: Maybe it was the two times that I dined here but I wasn't that impressed. Appetizer portions were very small, the entrees seemed slightly overpriced for what you get. The petrale soul or the black bass is nice but again for the price it didn't seem that great. This is a good place though to meet friends after work and a good place for groups.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Great location and nice atmosphere. Nice wine and beer selection. Love the bread. However took 45 min between fist course (salad) and main course w/ no apologie. Pluse the food was not very warm and flavor was bland.
author: Trevor S.

description: Service was pretty poor.  Food was taking forever, so you would think they would at least be quick with drinks. Drinks took about 15 minutes after ordering them for both rounds. Food (pork loin) was very average. the atmosphere was cool. I was hoping for better.
author: chris r.

description: I have given this place 3 tries and i just do not think it has good food.  Service is a little spotty too.  The decor is cool though.
author: Natasha L.

description: I have mixed feelings about the Salt House.  I liked the atmosphere and how it feels trendy and young.  The food was pretty good, but nothing notable.  I think there are some kinks being worked out since it is a new restaurant, but I think it will be a great place for years to come.
author: Mary S.

description:
Good eats, bad eats, nice decor, overpriced.

I took my date here on a sat evening and wasn't totally impressed. The best part of the meal was the entree. Both my date and I ordered fish (Halibut and Wild Bass). Both entrees were prepared perfectly. The fish were soft and tendered on the inside and slightly grilled and seasoned on the outside. Both dishes were accompanied by a medley of veggies, cooked to perfection. 

My main gripes with the restaurant was the appetizer. We ordered Yellowtail sashimi, based on a recommendation from a Yelp user. Boy was that the worst choice EVER. First off, have you ever found bone in your sashimi? Not only was there bone in our sashimi, the fish did not taste all that fresh. On top of that, the lemon garnish was way over the top (perhaps to mask the age of the sashimi?). Now, imagine paying $14 for this dish and you have yourself the worst appetizer ever assembled. 

Overall the meal was delicious, barring the appetizer. If budget is a concern, prepare to spend easily $40 per person. The overall decor is quite nice and contemporary. But in order to get a quality dinning experience, I HIGHLY recommend you make a reservation. Otherwise you'll be paying high-end prices and dinning on a low-end countertop with barstools.
author: George H.

description: I came here for dinner with my classmate and teacher for our last day of school. What a treat! We shared a lot of the appetizers and each ordered an entree. My favorite was the poutine, raw oysters, and baked oysters. The oysters were very fresh and sweet. baked oysters made perfectly. not  overcooked so you could taste the sweetness of the oyster. froie gras was okay. i usually enjoy the seared froie gras more, but this time i thought the cured one was better. I had the aged rib-eye for my entree. It was okay. could have been better. The service was great though and the atmosphere was nice. i had a pineapple coconut ice cream cake for dessert. I thought it ended my meal well. not too heavy, but tasty. I would recommend this restaurant to people.
author: Connie C.

description: This place is friggin loud!!!  While the entrees were boring, the appetizers were great.  Great place for a drink after work and a quick snack before heading out, but I am in no rush to go back for dinner.
author: Pele N.

description: I had higher expectations after reading all the reviews about this place.  Unfortunately, it didn't quite meet them.  I didn't really like the fact that this place was extremely loud and tables were very close together.  The service was good though.  Our waitress was helful with menu selection.  The food was just decent....nothing spectacular.  I don't think I would come back again.
author: Foodie B.

description:
The wine, service, and space get 5 stars.  There's nothing wrong with the food, but... let's put it this way... some restaurants I only eat at when work is paying because they are amazing and spendy.  This one I eat at only when work is paying because for my own money, I want something more memorable.

Also, very few vegetarian options, so tough for unpredictable work groups.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
As the name implies, Salt House emphasizes sea food in their menu. The locale has great ambiance, with its old wood floors, exposed structural beams, bar, loft and open kitchen. The one detracting aspect in this area is the disconnected bathrooms, which you get to by walking outside the restaurant through the back door.

The menu is interesting, but the performance does not deliver. The one highlight of our night was the crispy egg. It was a poached egg, crusted with panko, quickly deep fried, and served in a bed of lentils, bacon and frisee. It was also delicious. As you cut into the egg the still liquid yolk flows out and mixes with the lentils and bacon, while the fried panko crust adds a nice crunch. Others in my table had the tuna starter, which while not bad, was not remarkable in any way.

For my entre I ordered the sole, of which I have little to say as it was bland and unmemorable. Other at the table had another fish and the lamb. Both commented that their dishes where overly salted. One of them stopped eating it half way through for this reason.

We then decided to try desserts. We ordered the mascarpone panna cotta and the cookie plate. The panna cotta was tasty, but I would be hard pressed to tell you there was mascarpone in it if the menu did not describe it that way. The cookie plate, once again, was unremarkable.

To finished off we ordered mint tea. This seemed to cap off an off night for the food. I am very fond of Toaureg mint tea, but in this case the spearmint flavor was overpowering and there was no sugar to balance it.
author: E L.

description: It is good and I love the interior for the historic building it is not for what they did.  The food is good not great.  Same old california stuff but very expensive in my opinion.  The staff was great; they were a good laugh with the group I was with.
author: Cristof E.

description: In a way, the ambiance was a little on the sterile side for my taste, however, I really enjoyed my yellow fin tuna.  I think it was the marmalade taste that made it worthwhile.  Other than that, not a big fan.
author: Yve T.

description: I agree about some previous comment maybe he food do not worth the price here... but compare to other restaurants around SOMA is not that bad. I like the place (**), part of the food (*) but not the ambiance.
author: Matt W.

description:
Our waitress had a great sense of timing--She was attentive and knowledgeable, without being overbearing.  We got a bottle of the Malbec on her recommendation, and it was a perfect pairing with everything we ordered.  
Just about everything I tried was a great as I thought it would be.  I (reluctantly) tried the pork belly (which I believe was served with caramelized peaches--delicious), and once getting over the thought of eating straight fat, enjoyed it quite a bit.  The scallop appetizer was delicious, as was the beet salad.  For dinner I had the Ahi steak, and I was a little let down.  It was cooked perfectly, but the seasoning was a little too strong, and tasted like a boring herb de Provence mix.  It was served with a pesto garbanzo bean salad (?), and that was good, but a little oily for my tastes.  Desert was ice cream sandwiches, which were a million times tastier than the ones sold at the grocery store.
author: Rebecca M.

description: EXCELLENT Food!!!  From the appetizer all the way to the dessert.  The food is just awesome.  Everything is cooked to perfection.  It's a bit of a noisy restaurant so not the best romantic place but the food is 5 stars.  Try the fries with rib gravy sauce and the chicken!
author: K T.

description: I'll keep it brief. Nothing special to report. I've eaten here twice for biz lunches. Plane is the word I would use to describe the food. Clean napkins though, always a plus.
author: Rachel S.

description: Another excellent dinner at Salt House. Its good to go back and find the menu fresh and to have the challenge of choosing between dishes. Finally with four of us, we had four different starters and four main dishes, followed by three desserts. So everyone shared the tastes and delights.
