It was the 11 year old daughters birthday meal and she chose fois gras as a starter - pan fried, mousse and standard, with nicely chopped quince jelly. Highlight for me was the salmon, beautifully cooked with a rich reduced sauce and assorted diced vegetables. This is what modern american cooking should be like. I will be going back again and again.
author: Vera N.

description: Just got back from dinner at the Salt House. It seemed to take a long time to get our water, drinks, appetizers, bread and food. Everything tasted good and salty but it just seemed to take forever to get to the table and some of it was cold upon arrival. The waitress was lack luster and seemed annoyed to be there. And that's really all I have to say about that.
author: Kerry W.

description: Had a very tasty dinner. Everything on the menu sounded good so the three of us grazed on 3 appetizers and 2 entrees. First the good stuff. The fried shrimp salad with green beans was wonderful, so tasty with the harissa dressing. I don't eat shrimp so the 4 shrimps were devoured by the others who commented on the great frying job. On the other hand, the poutine, french fries+gravy+cheese was good but the waitress poured the short rib gravy on the fries and in my opinion ruined them. Didn't like the gravy much less on what were once nice crunchy fries. Maybe next time we'd have them serve it on the side for dipping. The yellowtail tartare was excellent in taste but I was disappointed with the skill of the prep chef, all the dice were of different size and shape. Didn't effect the taste but I just expected a more skilled presentation. The pork chops were cooked excellently and were just delicious, so juicy and flavorful. The white polenta was $22 and not worth it. $22 bucks for mush? It was beautiful but was not tasty, the flavors of the mushrooms and other toppings didn't meld or compliment the bland polenta. The grana should have been grated so it could be in every bite instead of the small square sheets perched on top. On top of that the serving was really small. It's bad enough to be a vegetarian with so few menu choices but to starve as well? Would I go again? Yep.
author: bongo c.

description:
After hearing nothing but good things, a friend and I decided to check out Salt House.

Which turned out to be a terrible idea.

We decided to start off with cocktails and appetizers. Always a safe bet, right? Boy were we wrong. We ordered poutin and the squid which took about 20 minutes to get to our table while our waitress fretted next to us with a blank stare and a...why am I here? stance. 
In the time it took our appetizers to get to our table we should of polished off our cocktails and been ready for at least a glass of water (which didnt arrive til long after the apps did). But neither of us got past the first few painful sips. If I wanted a shot of tequila, I would of ordered a shot of tequila. You could taste nothing but the alcohol in the drink which, correct me if I'm wrong, should of tasted like honey/jalapeno/lime with a nice tange of tequila.
Salt House did live up to one part of it's name. The salt encrusted on the fries which were doused in salty gravy could of flavored a whole stock pot of the blandest soup imaginable. The squid...well if I wanted one ounce of squid stuffed with a jumble of salty whateverthecooksneedtogetridoffastbeforeitgoesbadcauseIdidn'tknowwhatitwas inreality...I don't even know how to end this sentence.
Bland, salty and unappetizing.
We quickly paid our bill and left our still very full plates sitting at the table unable to bring ourselves to try any of the other unimaginative dishes on the menu.

Needless to say (but I will any way) this is one of the trio I will not be going back to.
author: Jude B.

description: Wandering the streets of SF after getting off a work assignment around 11 p.m.  This was the only place that was serving dinner.  I had the short ribs with sweet breads.  It came out quickly and was tasty.  The sweet breads were perfectly crispy and the ribs were moist and well-seasoned.
author: Daniel H.

description:
meh.  

Good, but not great.  Nothing subtle about the flavors here, everything is big, and maybe too big.  I like big but this was obnoxious big.  Like fat person sitting next to you on a long flight fighting over the the armrest big. The other bummer was that the portions were small.  The NY Steak was a couple of pieces of meat.  The chicken was three smallish pieces of bird.  Two of us also had 2x appetizers and some oysters and I was still gnawing on bread when we were done with dinner.  For 20-30 bucks a plate, I want to be rolled out the door.

The house Chardonnay sucks ass, too.  

We did have a nice bottle of Zin but for 60 bucks, it should be good.  Pretty good wine list with good descriptions and a wide range.

The space is nice.  It's got that hip communal table that is all the rage these days and is in a cool brick and timber building.  There is a cool fresco on the rear wall and neato lights above the bar. The room works well.  

The service was excellent.  No complaints there.

I don't think I will go back.
author: Tony A.

description:
Too loud!  Serivce was ok.
Food is inconsistent.  The appetizers were ok and my steak was over-cooked.  My dessert was great, forgot the name.  
I expected this place to be like Town Hall, but it isnt.  Feels like you are a crammed into a super small space, which is why it is so loud.
I wouldnt recommend this place since it's overpriced for low quality service/food.
author: amy l.

description: I dont understand the big deal with this place.  Nice ambiance but food is OK.  Walk down the str to Roy's instead.  Better food and the portion fits the price.  Or go to NOPA.  Love that place.
author: Marcia B.

description: I'd give it somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. Atmosphere was good and the seats were fairly comfortable. Food was good but not great. I had the seared Ahi. I had the trout at Town Hall and enjoyed it better. I think it's because the trout was wrapped in bacon but who knows. If you're in the area, try both.
author: Mike C.

description:
foie gras torchon wasn't impressive.  a bit too gamey.  

i like the interiors, especially their bathroom ;)
author: kulas a.

description:
This is a really nice place for dinner.  There are some outstanding flavors to be had in the calamari appetizer or in the tuna entree.

However, there is too much tendency here to add pork to all the seafood dishes.  If I wanted to eat pork, I would go to a Bar B Que place and I wouldn't be ordering fish.  Chefs should figure out how to serve tasty seafood without relying on pork or butter for flavor if they want to be respected for their skill.

Service was great except for one overbearing bus boy from hell!
author: Richard P.

description: I really liked the design and the service was excellent.  The majority of the food was great-- my friend got the duck which was killer.  I think the only thing I was unhappy with was my steak.  The rest of the dish was great and the steak was cooked the way I like it, but it just wasn't very juicy or flavorful. The sticky bun for dessert almost bumped the review up to 4 stars, but I'm going to have to stay with 3.5
author: Jessica T.

description:
Overall, I enjoyed my experience at the Salt House.

(Beware, I rate for the quality of the experience - including the food!)

I went for dinner on a Monday night with a few friends + a supposed potential labbie.

The appetizers were ok - we ordered:
Crispy shrimp, which didn't really hit the spot for me - most of it was decidedly un-crispy, and the presence of bacon was overpowering the dish.

Yellowtail - tasty and fresh!

Beet salad - in my book, you can never go wrong with beets.  This is no exception, although I wasn't a huge fan of the greens they paired with it.

Scallops - probably the best appetizer we had, although the scallops were a tiny bit gritty.  The scallops were cooked to the perfect texture, and were paired with sausage.  

So, no sign of overwhelming saltiness yet!

As my entree, I had the steak, medium rare.  The steak was absolutely amazing!  Cooked properly, with a lovely crust - and just the right amount of salt to top it off!  The mushrooms were also very nice, cooked in a meaty broth, but I didn't really dig too much into the mushroom puree/sauce.  The steak was enough for me! :)

Our server was very friendly and helpful, and he paid the perfect amount of attention to us.  It is a bit loud in the restaurant, but it wasn't a problem for us.  :)  The bathroom is located outside the restaurant, which I find to be slightly strange, but whatever.  The atmosphere of the restaurant was great! 

I am afraid that I cannot comment too much on the dessert menu, but I did have a bit of the ice cream sandwiches - tasty!

The appetizers may be a tad overpriced, but the entree I had was totally worth it.  I would definitely go back for seconds.
author: Bithi C.

description: I'll keep this one simple....Salt House is a solid experience.  The food was great, the atmosphere classic San Francisco and the service good.  I can't say there is anything specific that stands out but I walked away with a grin and look forward to going back.  Nice!
author: Bryan G.

description: On Saturday, 01-29 , we spent the day at the MOMA and walked to the Salt House without a reservation. Upon arrival at 5:15 PM, we learned that seating wouldn't take place until 5:30 and they were booked. After a bit of cajoling, the manager said we might get in right at 5:30 and we volunteered to sit at the bar for a glass of wine. We each had a glass of wine and were promptly seated at 5:30 as promised. As an app and main course, my date had the shrimp on a bed of greens and they were wonderful. I had the pork sirloin that was cooked to  perfection, being slightly pink in the center but extremely moist and tender. For dessert, we split the cheesecake with peanut brittle and orange marmalade. The cheesecake was light and all three flavors and textures made our taste buds explode. Thanks to management for getting us in and thanks to the chefs for making a memory.
author: Stanton W.

description: I just had a very disappointing evening at this much talked about venue. The service was SO SLOW that my friend and I practically fell asleep waiting for our entrees (45+ mins) and when we asked to speak to our waiter, the maitre d' came over and simply said, "There are no excuses, it will get here sometime soon." It was another several minutes before it arrived. Then, they didn't clear the plates forever. They didn't offer to comp us anything for all our waiting. The food was acceptable ( I had chicken, my friends buckwheat pancakes and vegetables) but nothing special and definitely not worth the wait!! I will not go back.
author: Logan B.

description:
Was a walk-in the other night. Luckily they have communal tables and a full service bar. I can't offer a full review, but have a few comments....

First, the place is very inviting. A really nice vibe and attractive clientele.

The reason I am writing this review is to call out the fries. They serve this French Canadian concotion of fries smothered in fontina and covered with a beef short ribs gravy. At first it looked and sounded odd, but wait until you taste this. It is sublime. Such a wonderful comfort food I could eat it daily.

The rest of the food was very tasty. The crisp shrimp app was solid. The John Dory with a fine herbs sauce was very well prepared, presented and devoured. 

I'm looking forward to another visit to try more. Will update the review accordingly.
author: Shaka Z.

description:
Being a big fan of Town Hall, I was very excited when this place (same owners) opened next to my office but I have been here several times for lunch and have not been too impressed.
The service is good and the decor is nice with exposed brick walls and beams, but the food has been less than satisfying.  Dishes are small, not very filling and not too tasty - sausage, cubano sandwich, cheese sandwich and soup.  Burger was average.  Best dishes are the shrimp appetizer and the crab appetizer.  The bread is good.  Overpriced for what you get.
author: E H.

description: All I have to say about this place is Lamb shank and bring back the warm nuts. And avoid sitting under the stairs. And there ya have it. Enjoy!
author: jason b.

description: Food tend to be spotty as well as the service. I waved at my waiter and he seem to be nonchalant.  Anyway, I had the meatloaf with chanterelle gravy which I thought is salty. Both meatloaf and the gravy are pretty spiked with sodium. I downed so much water after that...well it's the "salthouse".   ooooh the citrus lemonade seltzer drink was close to $5. After that I was gastronomically impaired....I can't down my $5 lemonade...it feels wrong. I felt pickled after....citrus and sodium like a brine concoction isn't it?
author: girl e.

description:
Well let's atart with the good
Its an attracticve space,and I was able to find street parking.
After that we were highly dissapointed with average service,(except for one annoying bus boy who kept hovering around our table waiting for us to have the last bite on theplate!),and overpriced mediocre food.
I had  what was advertised as Blue Fin Tuna, but was really run of the mill seared ahi, with a a non descript mish mash of potato, olive and fennel
My gal- pal had  the duck which was ok, but what was advertised as a side of duck leg confit, wa little more than " duck burger"
So there it is: we split one salad (the smoked trout- definitley the best dish we had),had two drinks, one $14 mini caraffe, of a strange house blend wine, and two entrees, and our bil came up to $106!!!
Overprived ,mediocre food, very average service
We will not return
author: Daniel W.

description: I met with a friend for dinner but I had to go somewhere fairly soon afterwards, so didn't feel right ordering an entre, so I only ordered 2 appetizers, thinking that would be sufficient food.  Wrong.  The soup came in a 1.5 inch diameter shallow hole in a large plate; the soup was, however, quite tasty.  And the pasta appetizer I ordered came with 2 strands of tagliati; seriously, 2 fucking strands.   The meat sauce was also quite tasty, however.  But, WTF, who the hell serves baby sized food to adults?  And it was super noisy in there.  I don't know how people like dining in such loud places.
author: Frank S.

description: I have been here three times, and each time the food has been good. It can get pricey, but it's worth it. Loud for sure.
author: Fabian M.

description:
A blanket 'shame on you' to restaurants and their designers who don't control the noise levels. These days it seems the more $$$$ the louder it is.  If you are here with more than 1 person you will be hoarse at the end of the night. Why on earth would I want to shell out upwards of $125 for 2 people for dinner, and have to yell to my date?

I tried this place because I'm working on an MBA at Golden Gate which is right across the street. Appetizers: pretty seriously overpriced for what you get. $2.50 per oyster? Ouch. $14 for 3 shrimp? 
No place to be a vegetarian. Slow service, and a ridiculous $20 corkage fee. I know you make all your money on booze, but come on. $20? Couldn't recommend it for dinner, perhaps for beer and poutine after work, but that's it.
author: Scott K.

description: entrance and bar convenient...early arrival and barstool seated...pint of liberty ale while wait....$five and cold refreshing brew...a pint and another...another and another...four pints and self control stop...for bare brick and steel, salt house cozy...use every inch of spacing....carry pint upstairs....seeminly best seating and view....fresh twist of bread munch...butter and salt sprinkle....menu and order....starting from most appealing...duck confit a soft brown hearty dish...square block of meatloaf texture...unique touch, taste and texture....second liking poutine...although forgotten and brought at end....melting cheese thick cut fries..pour of dark salty gravy....sinful savor for such simple sample...oh foie gras..how do i love thee?...sauteed the best...warm, shiny and browned....just a bite and gone....trio sampler, each very different...only loving one....mixed lettuces a light change...big rough flavorful sourdough croutons tossed...nice crunch and green chomp....so far so good, but not all can be perfect....seared tuna a flavorless large block of near tuna sashimi...only one bite...enough no more...losing confidence in main entree from first visit....get by with $fifty per person....small drink and little gluttony...$sixty-five per person norm....
author: Hen A.

description:
We dined here this last Friday for a good friends birthday party. We were a larger party but had made reservations an entire week in advance. Half of our party arrived fifteen minutes early and we proceeded to the communal table at the center of the restaurant to enjoy a few cocktails. My Sazerak was quickly made and well done, so bonus points to the bartender. I have to say that the placement of their very large communal table is very awkward, there was little to no room for the service staff to pass down a very busy corridor. I felt bad for the guests dinning at the low lying tables surrounding us as we often found ourselves having to step in-between tables to give room for passing dishes. 
    Roughly thirty minutes passed (meaning we were now fifteen minutes into our reservation) and our party had not entirely arrived. I let the host know to simply seat us whenever ready, I figured we would simply start ordering appetizers buying time for whoever was dragging. Another fifteen minutes passed before I had to inquire into our table. We were seated shortly thereafter but roughly forty-five minutes past our initial reservation time and by then all our guests had arrived. Here's where things went really sour. 
    We ordered two of their shellfish "plateaus" and a couple orders of the poutine. $40 for five or six oysters, several clams and three boiled shrimp is not a plateau, it's more like a "mound of shellfish." So we burn though the shellfish and it takes another thirty or so minutes before the poutine arrives! Hold on a second, french fries, cheese and gravy. Albeit, the gravy was very tasty but unless you're stewing it to order, no one should ever have to wait that long for french fries. Then the long arduous wait for our entree began, after I asked the server to fire the food when the poutine arrived. What's the average fire time in this place, thirty minutes? So here we are again, sitting and waiting for our food. It arrives and, to be frank, is so so. Everything was plated beautifully and my girlfriend loved her chicken, after admitting that she would have found anything delicious after waiting over an hour and a half from arrival to entree, but my pork was chewy and obviously hadn't been brined long enough or at all. I had also asked for our friend to receive a shot at the end of dinner, since it was his birthday, which never arrived.
   The extra star goes to the server and hostess who were both very sweet. The management compensated our corkage and bottle of wine, which was very much appreciated. Would I give them a second shot? The magic eight-ball says all signs point to no. Would I ever bring a large group of friends here again for a celebratory dinner? Snow balls chance in hell.
author: Essam K.

description: I had a pretty good time here but Town Hall is definitely superior.  That being said, the chicken here is the best I've ever had.
author: Jake B.

description:
This place seems to have settled into a cool groove. I'd been a few times before during their opening phase when they were working out the kinks. Tonight was a fantastic experience where everything came together. I was greeted on arrival by a friendly, hip hostess who offered me a choice of seating options.  I was alone so my initial preference was the bar but it was crowded so she suggested I sit in the window seats. Good call as I enjoyed watching the passing scene on Mission Street unfold - including a Paris Hilton wannabe negotiating with her X-Ray friends about which clubs to visit next. 

My server was genuinely friendly and very knowledgeable about the menu - she really knew the wine list as well. The one wine question she couldn't answer was quickly solved by the friendly and expert wine director. Food highlights were:

Heirloom Tomato Salad - perfect tomatoes in a simple and elegant presentation. Run to Salt House today and enjoy these before the tomato season is over.

Yellow Fin Tuna Tartare - beautiful fish cooked perfectly.

Crispy Shrimp - the combination of yellow and green beans with Serrano Ham and Shrimp was perfectly balanced.

Marsanne Blend Wine - crisp and complex, the perfect accompaniment to each dish above. 

OK, so I've used the word "perfect" four times to describe three dishes and a glass of wine. Salt House deserves it. If you haven't been - go. If you were there in the beginning - go back.
author: William K.

description: I love the ambience, the food was alright nothing spectacular. Maybe because I had the meatloaf (it was a bit salty for my taste).  Also, the lemonade with fizzy h20 was $4 a glass with mint, I think it's overpriced.
author: freewill m.

description:
We went there for the first time yesterday and had a nice time. However, I am not sure if I would go back regularly. The ambiance is nice and the service is good. However, the food is good but not great. We felt that the prices were a bit steep for what you get.

The good: Poutine (appetizer),  and the halibut (entre)

The OK: Crispy shrimp (appetizer), yellowfin Tuna (entre), Fulton Chicken (entre), and the Panna Cotta (dessert)

The no so good: The steak (entre)
author: Hiren C.

description:
Very plain front door - but when you enter it is very quaint. Simple decor with great space.  
Service and food was excellent. One small thing - it greats louder in the restaurant when it fills up quickly. 
Otherwise, I would highly recommend this place.....
author: Marianna M.

description:
We got one of those tables under the stairway - funky, but great vantage point for the street, front door and bar scene.  Out of the wait staff hustle-bustle, too.  We liked it.

Service was excellent - table next to us was complaining she didn't know her winemakers - guy was was quizzing her about a woman and she referenced the winemaker as a male.   We thought he was a kook and trying to impress his date, but still, she probably shouldn't have tried to bluff wine info in SF....I'm just sayin'

That pouline creation is pretty heavenly, too.  Net-net, I liked the place and service better than the food, but it was pretty close.  I'd go back.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Three of us had a wonderful feast at Salt House.  The service was excellent.
The staff was friendly,knowlegeable and made us feel welcome.  They made it clear that they wanted us to have a wonderful time and we did!


The food was center stage.

1st Course:  Dayboat Scallops on a bed of black eyed peas, carrots, bacon, and more.
      Smokiness of the bacon enveloped the scallops in complexity.  Worked!
      (Later one diner remembered the smoke of this dish as her favorite.)
      
2nd Course:  1. Autumn vegetables.  Squash, brocolli romanesque, and spelt grain.  
      Wonderful balsamic sauce which brought out the wonder of winter squash wihtout overwhelming it.
      WINNER!  Another favorite.
      2.  Foie Gras.  Foie Gras rolled in cheesecloth to remove moisture, then cured with salt overnight.
          Absolutely amazing.  It is the pure essence of pate, and even won over a liver hater.
      3.  Breaded Shrimp and green beans with toasted marconi almonds.  Tasty.
  
3rd Course:  Gnochhi with an arugula pesto. Brillant!  Must order item!!
      Heavenly light pillows of love with a little rougher arugula bite surrounding them.
      (arugula =  "party in your mouth")
      
4th Course:  Petrale Sole.  Crisply,and primly breaded on top of a riot of vegetable flavors.

5th Course:  Short Ribs.  Grainy mustard topping first grabbed the senses,
  then the meat melted softly in your mouth.
  Finally the bed of carmelized onions and veggies fill the mouth with round flavors -
  especially the brussel sprouts. 
  A fully satisfying,fabulous dish.
 
Dessert:     A glass of bittersweet Chocolate Pudding with a little whipped cream and cocoa nibs, 
  plus three mini cupcakes dotting the I of Indulgence.
  Seemed like about 70% cocoa solids with about 10g sugar per 100g.
  Made me wonder what it would taste like with 88% Hachez, my favorite chocolate bar,
      Cookie Sampler - a lovely plate of freshly baked cookies was the last delight from our dinner.
         The cookies are beautiful to look at and delicious...great with the house latte.
      

It was a fabulous meal and we highly recommend it.
author: steve h.

description: I was so excited to try this restaurant!  When I'm in Vancouver, I always make sure to get some poutine.  This is the first place in the States that I've heard serves the dish.  I rounded up a bunch of coworkers and went to Salt House during the DAT season.  The DAT menu was only okay so only about half of us ordered off of that.  We also ordered some poutines and sliders to share as appetizers.  Poutine was pretty good.  They used beef short rib gravy to fancy things up but at the end of the day it was still just fries with cheese and gravy.  Not even close to being worth the $11 per small portion.  My pork shoulder dish was pretty good because it came with some pickled vegetables that spiced up the dish and gave it a bit of a tangy offset to the smooth gravy.  Also, a coworker knew the general manager who then sent up a few desserts to try.  The chocolate one with almonds was by far my favorite!  I remember when the DAT lunch  menu used to come with 3 courses and they were usually kitchen highlights that would cause people to come back.  Now they've started cheaping out with 2 courses and sub-par items that are probably cheaper to make.  I think DAT's reputation is going to go down the tubes soon and people will stop trying restaurants under this pretense.  Most of the time I don't even order off the DAT menu anymore.  And I almost never walk out without spending at least double of what is expected.  In this case, my DAT lunch ended up costing $36, including the free desserts.  That and the service was ridiculously slow!  This place was definitely not worth that.  I think Town Hall is the only restaurant in this family that is worth the price point.  The other ones are just depending on its halo effect.  That being said, maybe I'm just a skeptic because I can get most of the same food down south that is just as good for just a fraction of the price.
author: Susan L.

description: Salt House --- now who would expect an innocent evening at this serious establishment might turn into something crazy. it had been a loooong weary Monday.... so when preet sent out an afternoon SOS saying she wanted to get some girls together for drinks/food afterwork I happily accepted. I arrived way before the rest of the group, sidled up to the bar and ordered the usual double. I couldn't help it, but I started to eavesdrop on the couple next to me.... It turns out they were both in town for the Macworld thing and making overtly flirtatious introductions. I tried really hard not to laugh but.... from what I gathered they had literally just met. (right there at the bar before I walked in) and this guy was on a mission! he was using every cheesy line known to man. The hilarious part was, this girl was taking it in like a starving man at an all-you-can-eat buffet in vegas at 3am. She was gazing at him with fascinated eyes, a huge cheerleader smile plastered to her face and doing a high pitched girly laugh. I was totally mesmerized at the whole scene unfolding.... Damn, and then my group showed up so I had to leave for our table. so sadly I'm not exactly sure how it all turned out....  but if I had to GUESS I would say it was probably wild monkey sex in one of their respective hotel rooms. So anyway.... back to the Salt House. I'm not shy about saying I'm definitely NOT a fan of its ugly step sister Town Hall, so I wasn't expecting anything mind-blowing here. but surprisingly this place has a little more going on. The decor is simple, stylish, spacious, and perhaps a little cold but very "SOMA". The service and the food elevated the experience greatly. You can count me in as another fan of the Poutine dish--- yum! After indulging ourselves here we were in such an agreeable mood that we proceeded to have a little impromptu Monday night after party at DJ Hard Kaurs high rise wild party condo....complete with disco ball and turntables. haha!(ok, no disco ball but it sounded good) After drinking an entire bottle of Aqwa, the events of the night get a little fuzzy.... But it was an eventfully fun night and Salt House did not disappoint. a great after work drinks/dinner spot. *(and extra entertaining when there's a convention in town---make sure to get front row seats at the bar)
author: Michelle I.

description: Let's just say that I would not recommend this place to ANYONE.  The food is fine.  I have no complaints about the quality of the dinner.  If the rating were only on the food, I would give it 2 stars overall, 4 for just quality.  But first and foremost, the meals would be highly overpriced at HALF of what they charge.  The only thing that positively impressed me on my visit was their attention to detail concerning making sure you had all the right utensils (even though someone took the wrong fork after I finished my salad...) and folding your napkin for you when you go to the restroom.  And yes, you will likely need to visit the restroom at least once during your dinner, since they are EXTREMELY slow.  Bottom line: avoid this place.
author: Jon K.

description: I love salt, so when a place calls itself Salt House my mouth begins to water. I'm expecting something savory, comforting yet exciting. That's what I got at Salt House. My non-yelp buddy and I headed over to this place after a fun time at the Yelp party at Harlot, but whew. Maybe a little too much fun involving gin? We needed food fast. We walked into Salt House and were seated right away. Granted it was late into the evening, but I love restaurants that stay open late. I also liked airy feel of the place. Maybe it was all the wood flooring? Maybe it was because it wasn't too crowded at the time were were there. Our waiter was totally accomodating and had a good sense of humor. We were tipsy and hungry--whoa! We had a fried potato appetizer. My friend had the seared tuna which was cooked just right with the right amount of seasoning. I had a lamb and veggies dish. I can't remember what was all in it (maybe I was a bit more than tipsy) but I remember the flavor of the gravy and how tender the meat was. Mmm...salt! I had my leftovers boxed up. Unfortunately I left it on the Bart train, man was I unhappy the next day.
author: Farah S.

description: Reservations were for last night at 8:45 pm. Finally got seated at 9:15 pm. Waitress was rude, did not come back to table until 9:30 pm. Ordered, and was told that the entree dish would take 35 minutes because we asked to have everything brought out at once. Removed entree, ordered 5 appetizers for party of three, and food still took 25 minutes to come out. Never had any service, water glasses went empty, butter was gone, as was the bread. We had said we had to leave by 10pm for airport, and after plates were not cleared, I finally just took out the credit card. Got out at 10:15 pm. Shame, cause the food was good! Not in any hurry to go back with rude hostess and waitress.
author: Zozo B.

description:
everytime i come to salt house they do a great job. solid service, great drinks and a friendly staff in a pretty space. what more do you want?

i also relly love their style. town hall and their fish restaurant are also cool.
author: thad b.

description: one word- poutine fries.. well i guess thats two! this is a local fav in canada- gravy fries.. but this is the american WAY better version..short rib gravy and some local farmers cheese- yum yum yum!! i only went to salt house for a bottle of wine and a few apps but everything was fantastic but the poutine.. well that is constantly on my mind! good thing my bf goes to GGU Law school across the street..."sure baby ill meet you infront of your school and we can grab something to eat" little does he know.. poutine is on my mind :)
author: Lisa Z.

description: Amazing! I LOVED the duck and pot de cream. Service was flawless. I would recommend to make a reservation ahead of time. This place has an excellent reputation, and has never been disappointing.
author: E D.

description: Now here is a restaurant that "gets it".  The folks that brought us Town Hall, just opened up this place late 2006.  I went there about two weeks after the opening and was totally blown away.  The service was spot on, and the food was delicious.  We ordered the sea bass and the roasted chicken.  The roasted chicken was pretty much crack for food-lovers and I think that I will not be ordering anything else from now on.  I am totally hooked.  Of course, that night I had ordered the Sea Bass and while equally good, I "lost" the dinner contest and was somewhat envious of my dinner guest since she had the entire chicken to enjoy.  As for dessert, they had this great apple galette which we modified with a scoop of their homemade pecan ice cream for a little a la mode action.  The waitress was more than happy to do this for us at no extra charge.  This is what its all about.  Atmosphere-wise, space is an old renovated printing press which is usually filled with business-types and students from the law school across the street.  If you get a chance, wander towards the back of the dining room and check out the painting of Don Quixote on the back wall.  The owner's wife painted it....
author: Barrett F.

description: Still love Salt House.  It's become one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  Had the buckwheat polenta this time, great veggie dish.  Also tried the poutine which was a major hit among all at the table. Love it, love it, love it.
author: Dave P.

description: Another one of those "trendy" bar/restaurant establishments in the city. It's located in the SOMA area, so it's easy for me to get to after work. The restaurant is amidst buildings that are under construction, so if you don't already know about it, it's unlikely that you'd come upon it. We got there at 6 on a Friday, without reservations. Big mistake, the place was packed. But no worries, we decided to sit by the window behind the stairs. The decor is kind of modern/ industrial. The lighting is dim, but there are candles. Not terribly loud considering the amount of people. The reisling I had was pretty good. I wouldn't say it was as good as the reisling at the W, but definitely a nice wine. We ordered poutine, a french canadian dish consisting of french fries, cheese curds, and gravy. The potatoes were crisp, the cheese curds creamy, and the gravy was not too strong and meaty, although there were some chunks of meat in it, I just avoided them since I don't really like beef that much. Overall Salt House is a happening place, and next time I will try their specialty drinks.
author: Kate A.

description: Went before Wicked and I will be back for sure.  Plus our waiter was super cool.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Sorry I didnt read the reviews here first...I believed the hype and I literally paid for it, big time. Mediocre food, limited selection...I will say that at least the ambience and service were good. We shared the lamb sausage to start which was decent but not for $15. My bf had the steak which as he put it, he could make better at home. Translates to: not that special. My fish was dry on the first few bites then disgustingly fishy. I thought that dessert had to be good over the warnings from the table next to us who shared our enthusiasm for the place. We chose the rhubarb tort with lavendar cream....tasted like granola in cream. I picked up a pint of B&J on the way home. Next time I read Yelp first.
author: Rachel B.

description: On my first visit to the Salt House I was pleasantly surprised with how lovely the interior of the restaurant is.  The building is 100 years old and the guys decided to let it speak for itself.  There are exposed beams, brick walls, and gorgeous old shiny wooden floors.  The service was great!  Our table was ready five minutes before our reservation and our server was gracious and knowledgeable.  The button on her blouse did pop open at one point exposing her bra to us and the rest of the restaurant.  We let her know and she was very grateful.  The food was good.  We had a selection of starters which were all good but the stand out dish was the house made boudin blanc with sauerkraut and grainy mustard.  For entrees we had the fillet, seafood stew and chicken.  All of which were cooked and seasoned properly.  The desserts failed to impress but all in all it was a pretty darn good meal.  These guys know what they're doing and they do it with style.
author: Anne D.

description: WOW!  I was not expecting a lot from this place after a bud made the reservations through OpenTable.  I truly liked the atmosphere - it was noisy, but the the place was packed!  I began to become excited after looking at their menu online.  It was a dinner and catch-up night with a bud, and the meal could not have been better.  We started with the poutin - French Canadian comfort food of fries and gravy with cheddar cheese (I know this this dish well, living in Vermont and going to Montreal often) - the cheese would normally be un-pasteurized cheese curd, but this rendition was very good...we also had the crispy shrimp with ham and greens - YUM!  For entrees we shared the lamb and aged rib eye - again totally impressed with the taste; it was all delicious including the desserts!  I'd even add an extra star for the excellent service we received.  Oh, and awesome wine selection, too!!!   Enjoy!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
after hearing lots of mixed reviews about this place, i finally made it for an early dinner yesterday.  i liked it - good food, great space (i really loved the decor and setup), and our service was spot-on.  i had heard that they kind of rush you through your meal, but i thought our server was attentive but without making us feel rushed.  we started with the poutine - which my friend that i went with compared to chili cheese fries, gourmet style.  oh my god - so good!!  i had the halibut for dinner which was very light and fresh.  it was done perfectly and came with shrimp and artichokes in a delicious broth.  my friend had the chicken which he said was great too.  for dessert we shared the carrot cake, which i will say i am not always a fan of (although i do love me some cream cheese icing!!) but i thought it was very good.  
i would definitely go back again - i wasnt completely overwhelmed with salt house, more just whelmed.  but i liked it enough to go again and try more!!
author: Carolyn B.

description: Let me preface this by saying that I am a self-confessed salt lover.  However, I didn't find the food overly salted like most reviews here.  I went for a dinner with a girlfriend on a Friday evening and was pleasantly surprised!  The place is quite loud, making it slightly difficult to have a conversation but everything was De-Lish!  We got the poutine(sp?) on the suggestion of our server which is this yummy fried bread thing with the best sauce.  I got the duck for my entree (also, on the recommendation of our server) and it just about melted off the bone.  It was so good!  Perhaps, my expectations were lowered bc of the previous reviews but I found this place to be great!  I must say that I was very disappointed with the dessert selection.  There were only about 5 different things on and none of them sounded irresistable.  Kudos to the very friendly, attentive staff on a busy Friday night!  Recommendations of the people that work there and know always works!  Btw, their name comes from a tavern in London - not salty salt, as has been the experience of some of the reviews.
author: T N.

description: I came here (for the second time) the night I proposed to my girlfriend (and not because she said "no" and I needed to drown my sorrows and eat the pain away).  I was completely blown away by the experience we had.  I usually don't like extra attention - but the staff was absolutely amazing.  They gave us a great table, champagne, and continually passed by our table to give us very sincere well-wishes.   It really made the night extra special.  So, I want to give the entire staff a shout-out for taking such great care of us - Thank you!
author: Greg S.

description: Great atmosphere, food and above all great service.  We had a large group of 12 and they did a great job bringing all of the food at the right time, filling the wine glasses, asking if we needed anything extra, etc.  We even talked a long time after dinner and they were gracious enough to let us chat without asking us to leave.  I would go back again.
author: Patrick C.

description: Poutine is canadian and so am I!  Although, the poutine here is fancy, shmancy and they don't use cheese curds.  The gravy was delicious and had little meaty chunks in it.  Gravy with fries!  Why doesn't the rest of the world eat it like that?!?  I thought the service was great, a little snobby, but very very attentive and informative.  Our server described the preparation of foie gras torchon, which is supposedly the most difficult to prepare.  We'd only had pate style and seared style... my fav being seared. so in the end, it's like salty (brined)  foie gras and with a pate like consistency.  The small plates were a lot more pleasing than the entrees.  We ordered a smorgasboard of food.  Oysters were fresh and tastey, soup was delicious and they were sweet enough to split it into 3 bowls for us, pork belly was just ok.  I'd definitely be down with coming back here. I thought the food overall tasted great and the service was superb.  Maybe less one star cause they had to wait until we ordered before they gave us some bread.
author: Dune N.

description: Came here for DAT lunch.  It was good, but for the price, didn't feel it was really worth it, even for the DAT menu.  We ordered the Poutine fries for appetizer - very tasty, very flavorful, but still just fries with some gravy on top.  All the other dishes were good - we ordered the pork shoulder and roasted pork cubano.  Service was decent.  Would probably only come here if someone else wanted to try it, but wouldn't come back on our own.
author: Yolanda T.

description: stopped in for a bite twice in the last week, and the food was good.  they weren't reinventing the wheel, just offering good solid food.  the cocktails were very good.  they call one a voyager, essential a side car with calvados as opposed to brandy.  not a far stretch, and one i have played with behind my bar, and i must say it is what brought me back and damn they had a good heirloom tomato salad.  i know every one has one in sf, it  is standard, but it does not change the fact that is was tasty.
author: brian m.

description: Beautiful ambiance, underwhelmed by the food and wine. Service could have been better as well. Overall a good experience but expected more.
author: Dawn C.

description:
big portions, great food, awesome service!

2 people shared 4 appetizers:  winter salad, crispy shrimp, foie gras, and poutine....and there was too much food.  next time, i'll pass on the poutine because it was nothing special, but the crispy shrimp and foie gras were both excellent.
author: Jay M.

description: Overall, not too shabby!  When we got there the hostess had given away our table, but we were 12 minutes late, so I guess that is the risk you run when you insist on seeking out street parking.  I had the Voyageur cocktail which was a bit tongue-puckering at first, but it improved as I kept sipping.  We were seated soon after we ordered our drinks and started things off with poutine.  I had tried this dish in Montreal, and Salt House's version was far superior.  Crispy fries, melty cheese, and glorious gravy.  Mmmm.  Then I had the crispy shrimp which were extra-scrumptious shrimp tempura with an overly-hammed serano/almond/haricots verts/greens concoction.  The greens were odd (parsely?  what exactly was that stuff?) but the beans, almonds, and some of the ham was good.  My bf had the duck confit and it was tasty, albeit a trifle overdone.  Dessert was the big downer here.  We did not choose wisely!  We had the coconut- pineapple-dacquoise-granita-brittle dealy and it was lame.  I regret that I did not just get the chocolate bar (I avoided due to previous Yelp postings, but it sure looked chocolatey and delicious when the woman next to me ordered it!).  I would go back, but order carefully.  The appetizers are just as good as the entrees and feel like less of a rip off.  Entree portions are just small!  And I would not get the cocktail or that dessert again.
author: Eleanor E.

description: Ive been to Town Hall 4-5 times and Im not sure which of these I like the best.   Both are great.    The service was terrific. Gretchen, our waitperson,  should be a part owner .. she's that good.    The food was great.  I had a rib eye which was absolutely delicious as well as the suckling pig starter.. awesome.    All in all a great meal.   Highly recommended.
author: B M.

description:
from the folks that brought you town hall and (most recently) Anchor and hope comes the Salt House; i think firmly in the middle of those two establishments - not location but as far as price, and imagined target snootiness maybe....  

the only other time i went to the salt house, i took 2 customers and one of my sales guys and we blasted through about $400 bucks - for lunch.  so it is possible to blow the doors off the bill at this place even though at first glance, it doesn't seem that expensive.  i think it was all the holiday champagne that we had about this time last year.  

well this time around it was dinner.  this place is about 50 yards from where i park my car during the day so isn't it just so typical that the places you walk by every day, you hardly ever go?  when i lived in san diego, i hardly ever went to the zoo and when i lived in LA, i never did go to Universal Studios.  anyway, so i went here for dinner because i suppose i should go to the places that i walk by every day at least once a year.  and ya know, going to those familiar spots once in a while actually does make you think: wow, the place is pretty darned decent.  i never thought it would be as good as it was crowded.  it seems way too crowded for what it is but the food is pretty exceptional.  we had a couple appetizers - maybe we were hungry.  the crispy shrimp with serrano was unique so i would recommend that.  the baked oysters were, well, baked oysters so not sure how highly i'd talk about those.  but then again, i've never been a raving oyster fan so maybe i'm the wrong person to ask.  the lamb with couscous on the other hand was pretty amazing. 

we didn't try the wine list, which looked very ordinary.  the place just isn't that big so i don't think they have a very large cellar and i don't think the "wine crowd" is what they are going for anyway.  but i didn't turn my nose up at the wine because of the limited wine list. i'm sure they have some incredible and affordable drinking wines, but i just happen to have about 75 bottles of wine that i've purchased from a half dozen trips to napa this season and i realized that i was never, in a million years going to drink it myself so maybe bringing it to restaurants will help me finish it before the sun explodes.  i brought the 2002 VanderHeyden Cabernet. 48 months in french oak, thank you very much. beat the pants off anything on the list, i'm sure. so the wine was excellent!  not that that will do you any good.

anyway, the thing that really put the place in the 5 instead of 4 star category was that - when the waiter took a bit too long to take our dessert order - the CHEF came out to check on us, took our dessert order and, when he no longer had the dessert we wanted, he proceeded to buy us 2 desserts himself.  the sorbets and the chocolate pudding with muffins were just great and the price was right.  

so go check it out.  it's slick and hip and happening and not really that expensive.  a little crowded maybe but that's the price of hipness in this town.
author: dan h.

description: I guess I'll start with what I liked: the service was good and the staff was very friendly. The food was delicious. I had the diver scallops, which were accompanied by a turnip and bacon cake. The scallops were perfectly cooked: seared on the outside, slightly raw inside. This is difficult to master; I was impressed. The bacon/turnip cake was like an explosion of flavor and paired excellently with the scallops. The wine list is extensive. I have to admit, the food is good. But what I can't get over is that this place feels like just another trend. The staff is clad in jeans that don't seem mesh with their button-down shirts. The tables are bare and they serve bread on what looked like a brown paper bag, which I guess is their attempt at creating a rustic, comfortable feel. Maybe I'm more traditional in my mindset towards restaurants, but by no means did I expect some fancy, stuffy place. I just expected that for the prices I was paying, it would be reflected in table setting. Unfortunately, that was enough to knock my rating down to 3 stars. If I could give half stars, I'd give 3.5. But I can't, so this stands.
author: Veronica W.

description: Possibly the only place in SF that serves poutine. Crispy French fries topped with cheese curds and gravy...a Canadian staple! Not so good for the heart but tantalizing on the soul. Doesn't sound too appetizing but 33 million can't be possibly be wrong eh?....I was the only one that ordered poutine in my party of 10 and as they brought it out, looks of disgust circled the table...I offered some to Robin who politely sampled a fry with a nervous smile...mmmWow!!! She exclaimed as she grabbed a fork full. Pretty soon the other vultures joined in and I was left with a plate of crispy crumbs :( damn shysters! We wound up ordering 3 dishes for the table along with a couple pints....the perfect nightcap!
author: Roger T.

description: Awesome spot for late dining! Arrived at 11:15pm after movies...place still had some peeps.  The duck was AWESOME!  And I have duck a lot.  Service was excellent and friendly.  Andrew and Ryan are the managers and do a great job!  Can't wait to go back.
author: Steve S.

description: i've had two fantastic lunches at salt house, and would highly recommend it to any carnivore in the financial district. an excellent choice for impressing clients- but not terribly vegetarian friendly. the decor is very hip, and the drink menu loverly.
author: oona m.

description: If it wasn't for the price, I'd eat here weekly.  I'm not trying to knock the restaurant for their prices, I'm actually fine with paying for it from time to time, but I love the food and I love the ambiance and I love the decor and I love the location and I just wish I could afford to eat here more often.  I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys something original and super yummy.  Definitely get the Poutine, it's super adult chili chease fries.  Eat here, you'll like it.
author: Your E.

description: some friends of mine took me out for my bday here last week. what a good idea! i loved this place. of course, being that i am from montreal, i HAD to try the poutine. now this isn't your typical traditional poutine you get at la belle province at 4 am after the bars close in montreal, but it was great nontheless! the gravy was excellent - i only wish they gave you more of it. poutine is all about smothering your fries in gravy to the point where you have a bowl of soggy cheezy fries! for my main course, i ordered the salmon, which was great! the service was good too. i had an all around good experience and i'll be back.
author: James J.

description: This restaurant is disappointing partly because its the same people as Town Hall and Town Hall is so spectacular.  The first problem is that a reservation at this restaurant is absolutely meaningless.  I had a party of four and a reservation and still had to wait 45 minutes: "they know how to take the reservation, they just don't know how to hold the reservation and that's really the most important part of the reservation, the holding."  Second, the restaurant is loud as all hell.  You can hear everything but the person sitting across from you.   Third, the place is really crowded and the tables are very close together.  Despite the service and atmosphere issues, the food is decent.  Try the fries with gravy (I can't remember the french name they've given to this appetizer)--they're quite delicious.
author: Nick K.

description: I have been looking at this place for almost a year.  I take a night class across the street so I am always without my hubby who is my main restaurant buddy, and I was waiting to get him there with me.  The other day I read the reviews and saw the crispy egg description which pushed me over the edge.  I went with about an hour before my class.  I sat at the "community table," which was a bit cramped in terms of space, but entertaining.  The crispy egg was fantastic - I am an egg fan, and it was a soft cooked egg, rolled in something crispy and fried (?) and it came on a lovely bed of English Peas which are a favorite of mine as well and had two small cuts of bacon on the side which were smothered in a wonderful brown sauce.  Usually I can tell to a pretty good degree what things are but I have no idea what was in that sauce - I would almost guess a classic brown gravy with a bit of soy but that is just taking a wild stab at it.  Anyway, it was tasty.  I would have been fine with that alone but I was so excited to be there I had ordered the dayboat scallops as well, which were delicious.  The scallops were pan seared in butter and delicious.  They came with manilla clams which were good and a parsnip bacon tourine that was quite tasty.  The whole thing was on a chard mix, so pretty much all the food groups were covered and nicely, I might add.  The bar was tempting but as I had to be alert I had a cappucino, which was really good.  All in all I liked the busy and eclectic atmosphere, the food and my waiter.  My one complaint would be that I really waited a long time between the appetizer and entree and even if I had not been under a time crunch, that could have been annoying to someone, not me, who was happy to be there rather than at Chipotle which I have been frequenting all too often as my pre class meal stop. I would probably give this a three and a half stars just because of the wait between courses. On the other hand, it may have been the fact that I was in the "bar" area and not at a table and I will give it another try with my hubby to check it out again.
author: Maria M.

description: If I could give a negative 5 stars I certainly would.  My experience was a big disappointment.   My food was not preparpared well or shall I say too well.  I ordered a well done NY steak and that is a tough order but a good restaurant will always succeed.  No apologies for well done meat considering that not all cultures eat medium rare or variation thereof.   I was bothered that they were just in a hurry to get the order done not whether I would enjoy it.  The quality of the meat was just average.  The wine list was predictable; no suprises; for a restaurant like this I would expect a couple of excellent and not so predictable Champagnes.  Having Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin for this restaurant is an alarm of non-imagination;  VCP in my opinion is like having Kendall Jackson VR Chardonnay on your wine list; the Champagne and sparkling was marked as "M/V."  To the best of my knowledge there is no such thing as M/V it should be N/V - Non-Vintage.  The best thing was the server he was very nice and attentive.   I do like the environs but I would not go back.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: As a fan of Town Hall, I was pretty excited about going to Salt House.  The decor is super modern with some exposed brick, this kind of trellis thing above the bar, a communal table in the middle and is just overall a very nice room.  Anyway, my friend and I must have arrived at around 8:13 for our 8:15 reservation, but the hostess made it seem like we had arrived an hour early.  After waiting at the bar for about 15 minutes, our table was ready.  I didn't really care for the bread that was served.  It was cold and oddly shaped.  For apps we shared the Crispy Shrimp and Baked Oysters.  The Crispy Shrimp dish was kind of strange.  All of the components were fine but just didn't go well together.  There were some large batter-dipped shrimp, some crisp cold green beans with a lit bit of heat and then some ham.  Maybe if the beans were served warm the dish might have worked better... just a thought.  The ham didn't do anything for me either.  I wanna say it was pancetta, but it was kinda tough and just not that great.  The Baked Oyster dish was much better.  My friend who doesn't normally like oysters really enjoyed it.  For entrees, I had the steak and my friend the chicken.  My steak was pretty good.  It was exceedingly tender.  It was served atop a really meager amount of potato puree and cipollini onions.  My friend's chicken was quite tasty.  It was very moist and flavorful, although not at the level of Zuni.  For dessert, we split the Warm Apple Galette.  The actual galette was pretty good.  There wasn't a lot of fruit in it, but it was tasty and delicate.  However, the scoop of vanilla ice cream served with it was super hard.  It reminded me more of kulfi than ice cream.  I didn't even realize I was doing it, but my friend pointed out that I was cutting my ice cream with a knife.  Overall the service was pretty good.  There weren't long wait times between courses.  Our waiter also recommended a nice bottle of Pinot that complemented our meal well.  I wish I could remember his name... sounds like he's one of the better waiters according to all the bad service reviews on here.   He made a reference to the "Play it again Sam" line in Casablanca that I totally didn't get but my friend did.  It was kind of random so she asked him if his name was Sam, but it wasn't.  I think the restaurant has great promise but is still going through some growing pains.  I would definitely go back.
author: Saw T.

description: I'm a little surprised this restaurant doesn't have a higher average rating.  I had dinner this week there...my second visit.  The atmosphere was really hopping which was nice, and even though half our party arrived an hour late for our reservation, they quickly sat us.  The servers were good, but the menu was a little uninspiring--not bad, but I wasn't thrilled with the options.  So, I ordered the gnocchi, which is usually boring but filling...a good back up entree.  I have to say, the gnocchi was the best I have ever tasted.  I'm not exactly sure what was in it (and it is not on their online menu) but it was awesome!  I definitely would go back to Salt House.
author: Dave B.

description: The bread they serve you comes with the most amazing butter. The first time I went there I fell in love with it and that is what I was looking forward to when I went this second time. We ordered a glass of wine each and when we were almost done, the server came and poured us another glass, complimentary! They don't always do that though :) Also we ordered the crispy shrimp salad, which had a refreshing dressing and cilantro. The poutin is basically fat fries with short rib gravy poured on top, it's a canadian dish I think. It's good, but heavy. Then we tried the foie gras, cured & sauteed. It was my first time eating foie gras and i preffered the cured version as it melts in your mouth. The sautee version comes with this delicious fruit jam/spread which is a nice compliment to the savory flavor. As the entree I got the fulton valley chicken which is really juicy and comes with potatoes. For dessert, it was a chocolate pudding thing which is pictured on their website but is not on the dessert menu- it was melt in your mouth good!
author: S K.

description: My boyfriend and I were very excited to try out Anchor & Hope for date night.  But when we called to make reservations, the restaurant was closed for Memorial day, and we were referred to Salt House, its sister restaurant.  We were assured that the menu was quite similar in fare.  I hate to say it, because I wanted so bad for it to be good, but I was pretty disappointed.  The decor was typical of this type of restaurant-exposed brick and beams, large mirror over the bar, open kitchen, distressed wood-a style I like, sure, but i could've been in Nopa, or Serpentine, or a number of other places.  The service was excellent-our server (Carrie) really knew the menu and wine list (also excellent) and was able to speak intelligently about the ingredients and pairings.  So far, we're at 4 stars...but the food was disappointing.  I truly don't know if this is "a thing" like the stinking rose has with garlic, but I found every single dish to be WAY too salty.  From the salad to the halibut to the vegetables, every bite evoked the same reaction.  Don't get me wrong, the food was good...just not great.  What wasn't over salted was bland.  I can't say that I would recommend it to a friend; but I wouldn't NOT recommend it either.  I found the experience, like the food, to be somewhat forgettable.  Great wine list though.
author: Allison D.

description: My husband and some friends of ours went to the Salt House for dinner last night.  The food was absolutely delicious.  The butternut squash soup was excellent -- some of the best I've had.  And the chicken entree was wonderful.  The chicken was cooked perfectly and had the thinnest, crispiest and tastiest skin.  I would give the Salt House five stars except there was a slight unappetizing odor in the restaurant.  My friend described it as 'pee,' which is definitely something I hope they fix because otherwise it was a perfect dining experience.
author: Jessica A.

description:
We had a terrific dinner!  Not necessarily traditional dinner because my wife picked only appetizers, but it was all very well prepared. We had reservations and we were seated within 5 minutes of our time. We were seated upstairs and in their reasonably comfortable space.
 We ordered the shellfish plateau to start. We were three and this platter of oysters, shrimp, mussels and clams were all extremely fresh and gave us enough to get ready for dinner.
 After that we tried the warm nuts and the house cured olives. The nuts were interesting and were welcome. The olives were so so. Nothing to write home about.
We followed that up with Baked oysters, Peaches and pork belly, scallops and Foie gras. They were all very well prepared, interesting really good. The best by far was the Foie Gras. It came two ways and was simply brilliant. 
My daughter ordered the chicken and I ordered the special of the evening, a lamb prepared two ways. Perfectly prepared, med. rare and very interesting. Loved it.
Dessert was shared by all with Panna Cotta and another dessert with Frangelico Ice cream. Very nice.
Service was excellent and our waitress was charming and knowledgeable.
author: solomon R.

description: Salt House is aesthetically fantastic and culinarily just alright.  The warm nuts are to die for but apart from that, nothing quite came together. The poutin, that everyone raves about is made with a starchy baking type potatoes and results in a dried, mealy potato that is saved only by the delicious cheese and gravy sauce that is slathered on top.  Our subsequent dishes (all 6 of them) were equally as unmemorable.  The elements are all there but somehow nothing quite came together.   The presentation is beautiful and when the dishes are delivered to the table, one expects them to WOW because they are all so beautiful but ultimately, it wasnothing more than your average but beautiful ly presented pub fare.  However, the ambiance and the use of space are absoltely amazing.  The high ceilings, rough steel beams, brick walls and simple furnishings are really stunning..and the neighborhood really needed a place to sit down and enjoy a drink after work.  Set your expectations on the lower side for the food but I would go back to this resaurant in a heart beat to sit at the bar, enjoy the scene and some more of those truffled honey roasted nuts.
author: Lulu L.

description: I went there with 4 old coworkers to celebrate a birthday. One of the girls that I was with brought some home-made cupcakes in a plastic and clear container. We liked the ambience and the food. Afterwards, 4 of us had one cupcake each. When we got the bill, there was a $10 cakeage fee charged on it. We asked the waitress "Raegan" what that was about, and she said it was for "cutting the cake". We were like WHAT?? it was a freaking cupcake, you didn't cut it, you didn't even bring extra plates for it. And she tried to justify it by saying "oh it should be $5 per person, but I gave you a discount". I mean are you serious?!?!  I knew there is such a thing as cakeage fee, but you should inform us ahead of time. The cupcakes were on the table the whole time. We weren't even sneaky about it. You didn't tell us that you will be charging for eating cupcakes. If we knew it was going to be "$5" per person, we would just eat them on the freaking sidewalk. She had to call over the manager. Luckily, he salvaged everything and took off the fee. We were still pissed! I don't think I would ever return, it was ridiculous.
author: Tony S.

description: oh the dry aged ribeye was too dye for.. perfectly seasoned and the morel mushrooms what a nice compliment to a perfect meal.. I would give it 5 stars if the portion was a bit bigger especially for the price. i will be back
author: Michelle F.

description: Good food at decent prices.  The fries with the amazing meat sauce was the highlight.  We had a heirloom tomato salad which was nice.  The service was very nice and the menu is varied.  A bit pricey though.
author: Brian L.

description: I've always had good experiences here. I love the Hostess and the fact that she makes a point smiling even on a busy night. The food is inventive and the wine selections are fun. If you want/need a cocktail they've got that too. Love the Decor! Just an all around great place.
author: Scott M.

description: really... i've been talking about this place for the past 10 months. the food was amazing and i'm still dreaming of it. we had these amazing fries covered with gravy panchetta and cheese. oh.my.god. then i had gnocci with beef and a savory broth and it was dynamite! i'd highly reccomend to anyone (and have), i plan to check it out again next week when i visit again.
author: Erin J.

description: On friday the 8th of October we had a meal at the Salt House.  We selected the Peking duck, it was raw.. the gracious manager substituted the meal for "White Bass".  Also came back to the table in 5 minutes "raw".  This Chef doesn't know how to prepare a meal that is cooked.  All the trimmings were fabulous but the actual fish and foul were RAW.  Wonderful manager, but how  much can you do when the Chef doesn't care enough to even cook the food.  Disappointed and expensive.
author: jp p.

description: TERRIBLE Service and average food. Went for dinner last night and had some of the worst service we've ever gotten. No one even approached our table for 10-15 minutes. We ordered a bottle and an appetizer, the food came before the champagne; we had to ask another server for it. Waiter was very unfriendly, never checked up on us - we had to pour our own champagne. Food was average, had the crispy shrimp, tuna tartare and halibut. I would not recommend it; many other great restaurants in the city.
author: Adam C.

description: Food & ambiance GREAT but the service is sketchy at best.....I had the monkfish w/ morel mushrooms v tasty. Desserts ok.
author: dawn w.

description: this is definitely not a place to have a deep and serious conversation as the noise level is on the loud end.  but the food is pretty freaking good! i dont remember what i had but i remember it was amazing. this was my first date with my boyfriend so i was a little occupied and not paying attention much. i remember the cool containers the water comes in, the bread was delicious and so was everything else. i recommend this place even though i have no idea what i ate, ha.
author: Katie B.

description: I don't get the hype. This is your typical over priced at restaurant. Food was ok, service was polite, drinks ok. Nothing to write home about
author: Maria M.

description: Cozy & comforting foods pretty much sum up our experience at the Salt House last night. We relied on my sister's advice for where to eat since she lives in the Mission District in this wonderful city here. She was torn between the Salt house and town hall (same owner, interestingly enough). Cozy seating all close together in semi-wobbly chairs, but I guess it adds to the charm. I was enamored with the black/red chalk paintings of a pirate on the wall...too bad Jack Sparrow wasn't chugging back the wine with us! :) We started with a Darioush Pinot Noir and it was total Sade "Smooth Operator" like silk down your tongue and throat, yet still structured with tanins and lots of flavah flav! :) This wine is like La Perla lingerie...smooth & sexy. I guess I can't just stay fixated on the wine but it was soooo good & of course multiple bottles were enjoyed. The celery root puree soup with a hint of apple was deliciously comforting and was actually more enjoyable than my main course. My sister's winter salad with beets, persimmon, and hazelnut was also deliciously comforting. If i ate steak, I'd have probably rubbed my face all over her New York steak strip and the braised short ribs with a toasted crunchy mustard topping and brussel sprouts. My sole in a red wine reduction was light and healthy, but not the favorite thing I put in my mouth here. The seared ahi tuna with nicoise style olives and leeks was delicious as also was the lentil smoked salmon. Our favorite dessert was the cookie plate with oatmeal, chocolate chip, sugar shortbread, peanut butter, white chocolate macadamia nut, and a cookie version of a reese's peanut butter cup. Delish eating experience and the cute waiter with his rugged beard was icing on the cake for me! :)
author: Ashley F.

description: Good food, but quite pricey for lunch.  During a recent lunch visit, we waited over 45 minutes for food with no explanation or reassurances about the delay.  The server also forgot one of our apps.  Probably wouldn't go back... there are other places that are better.
author: Mama F.

description: best short ribs ever. so tender, fatty and beefy. i also loved the poutine, which is perfectly cooked french fries with cheddar cheese sauce and short rib gravy. if i only ordered these two things, then i'd give them five stars all the way. to put things in perspective, there are a few things which are decent, but not very special: the scallop appetizer, the pork appetizer and the banana dessert. can't win em all...
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: I'm just not having much luck with the new places in town. We headed to Salt House because we love Town Hall and thought it might have a similar understated excellence. We were flat out wrong. The service was atrocious with our waiter openly rude to us. We had pickled vegetables, the poutine fries, chestnut soup, special crab salad, and the lamb shank. Things started out pretty well with the fries and soup, both were rich and hearty reminding us of the experience at Town Hall. Then things crashed when we got our entrees. The shank while gigantic and tender as lamb shank should be was completely without flavor once you got past the mustard breadcrumb coating. The crab salad was a special and had fried artichokes, which didn't really seem to go with the crab flavor. It just ended up being too savory. Dessert was an apple tart with cider caramel and vanilla ice cream. Where the hell was the caramel. There were like three drops. The apples were a little dry, the ice cream seemed like it was store bought. Just really disappointing and not executed well at all. We'll be going back to Town Hall but can safely say Salt House is off the list.
author: Keith R.

description: hmmmm, it's called "salt house" because the food is SUPPOSED to be salty?  i figured it was called that for some other reason, but apparently not.  hell, well at least i was able to try poutine for the first time!  i guess that counts for something.  and at least i learned it wasn't pronounced "poontang", which also counts for something.  next time, i'll save my money and pour salt down my throat instead....okay, it wasn't that bad, but there are much better places to eat....
author: Miss P.

description: another soma establishment with mediocre service and above average food.  our server seemed very disappointed that we elected to order just an entree each.  my scallops were actually quite flavorful, and my friend's petrale sole was well-prepared but neither dish was exceptional.  our server was also not pleased by the fact that my friend didn't order a drink.  overall not a stand-out dining experience.
author: melita s.

description: I can't believe this place doesn't have 5 stars.  We had an excellent experience from beginning to end.  The service was attentive and friendly.  The food was amazing and unusual, and came in large portions.  The drinks were great.  The prices were totally reasonable for the quality/quantity (we paid $37/person for a salad, mains, drinks, coffe, and a dessert; everyone left stuffed and we have leftovers).  The ambiance/decor was a perfect cross between San Francisco and France.  I will send everyone I know here.  The beet/blue cheese salad was a perfect balance of salty, sweet, and sour.  The clam chowder isn't fishy at all, and has plenty of tasty bacon.  The croque madame was crispy and moist and flavorful. We gave in to trying the chocolate pot de creme, even though everyone was already stuffed, because the staff had been emoting about it to each other when we came in, and it was so good - so incredibly rich and flavorful - that we practically licked the bowl.  I will send everyone I know here.  Enjoy!
author: Kaz W.

description: The salad was so dry- like they had forgotten to dress it.  The oysters were very fishy.  I loved the gravy on the poutine, but the fries themselves tasted like frozen fries that had been baked.  My friend and I had two medium bottles of the house-made wine, poutine, oysters, one salad, and one soup.  The bill was $90.  Considering the paucity of the portions, the prices are way too high.  On the plus side:  good wait-staff and friendly hosts, nice decor.
author: abby d.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant based on the incredible customer service we received there.  It was a crowded lunch hour when our party of three arrived, each of us with a suitcase, and the hostess seated us immediately and found space for our luggage.  There was a snafu in our order (my friend ordered a salad without cilantro, and it came covered in the stuff), and the response was remarkable in this day of forgotten customer service.  The host came to our table to correct the situation, discussed the error with the chef, replaced my friend's meal with anything else she wanted on the menu, comped her lunch, and then at the end we got a free dessert to make up for the inconvenience.  We weren't even pushy about it... all of this was just because they clearly cared about the service they provided, and felt really badly that the order was messed up.  The food itself was pretty good, but the dessert we got (panna cotta) was fantastic.  The prices were reasonable too.  I would definitely go back the next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: cathy h.

description: I ate here last saturday.  The food was good but by no means spectacular.  I didn't think it had a good price:quality ratio.  I think you can definitely get better food for the same price elsewhere.   I started off with the foie gras - there were 3 types but only one was really tasty.  I also got the seared yellowfin tuna which was good but standard.
author: Amanda L.

description: the food was very mediocre, nothing stood out. for the price being charged you can find a much better quality meal someplace else. the flavor just was not there. the only thing they have going for them is the look and feel of the interior space. unfortunately i do not choose dinner locations based on ambiance alone, the food has to live up to the expectation, be a bit more than dull...
author: alisa o.

description: Good location but I think it is a bit over-priced. The scallops and poutine were good. The mixed green salad was too plain. They have a good drink selection though.
author: Annne N.

description:
This was the first of many restaurants I went to on my trip to SF.  And I would say the least favored amongst me and my friends.  Not to say it wasn't good, but definitely not as good as the many other places we went to.  Onto the review.

First off the hostess is rude and pretentious.  We had reservations for 9 but ended up getting there at 9:30.  Reason being our friends flight was delayed and she arrived late.  I notified the hotel concierge of this and he told me he would contact the restaurant of the delay.  We end up getting there and the hostess tells us we should hae been on time or let them know we were going to be late.  I told her the concierge at the hotel called in.  She refutes this by saying no hotel called.  Then comes a manager, a nice friendly lady in a suit jacket greets me by my last name, and apologizes for the rudeness of the hostess.  She told me she got the call from the concierge and was waiting for my arrival.  How awesome is that? 

We end up sitting up stairs which is great, you get a view of the restaurant.  It's a bit crowded down stairs so I highly recommend dining upstairs for a more intimate setting.  Our server comes and we ordered Poutine, which is AMAZING.  Hot fluffy french fries, covered in melted sharp white cheddar, and drenched in a nice warm beef gravy.  MMMMM.  And then I ask the server to recommend a white wine.  I tell her I don't like anything too dry, and like the lighter fruitier flavor.  She recommend a Pinot Gris when I was leaning towards a Reisling.  We get the wine and it was DRY.  So dry that everytime I took a sip I had to drink some water.  Horrible wine recommendation.  The food was good but to be honest with you, I can't remember anything special about it.  I got the steak with a porcini marrow crust,  which was good, but the crust made the steak dry imo.  The sauce accompanying it was amazing.  My friends ordered the Chicken and Sea Bass.  Both good but not worth mentioning.  

This place would have gotten a 3 star rating simply on the food alone.  But with the snooty hostess, and thehorrible wine recommendation they get a 2.  Bitchy hostesses can ruin your whole night.
