Update-  Thank you Gertie for messaging regarding my service.  I'm surprised you remembered let alone Yelped!  That's awesome.  But you still get 2 stars...sorry
author: William C.

description: fantastic! the food is amazing! took my bgf and her hubby for her birthday dinner, and we all loved it, we started switching our plates b/c everything was so good we were jealous of each other's plates. the service was impeccable too... love it! fabulous!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description: My husband and I had the most fabulous meal here Saturday night. We loved the ambiance and our food was seasoned perfectly. He said his foie gras was one of the best he has ever had. We also had a delicious steak and salmon. Both cooked perfectly. Staff was nice and very attentive. I am so happy to have a new place to go for date night. So worth the trip from Oakland.
author: Lori H.

description: I made a reservation for 8 people for a holiday dinner.  We got there on time for our dinner but we ended up waiting 1 hour to be seated!  We did get one free drink each but having to stand around in a cramped bar area was no fun, especially in heels.  The food was mediocre at best. It took 1 1/4 hours to get our food once we ordered.  There wasn't a single vegetarian offering and what the chef fixed up for our veggie friend was over salted.  I ordered the lamb chops and the veggies on this plate were inconsistent in their doneness.  Some were soft and some were hard.  I thought since the place is called Salt House that there would be more meats and even some cured meats, but it was a heavy seafood menu.  To top the night off some of us ordered the bake Alaska and the ice cream center was so incredibly hard that there was no way at all to eat it.  The only thing that gave me reason to give this place one star is that they bought us a bottle of wine for such a botched night.
author: suzanne c.

description: The waiter here was not good.  It was my wife's birthday and she ordered the Monk Fish.  It arrives and she can't even cut through it... we tell the waiter and his reaction is like it is our fault we don't like it "rare".  This was inedible!  After they actually cook the meal, they don't even comp anything (usually something like this they will comp dessert, wine or something!).  Otherwise, the food was OK but I like Town Hall better.
author: The M.

description: pretty much everything on the menu is great! gotta have the oysters to start and the gravy fries are up there too. looks funky, but tastes great. just do it.
author: Patrick D.

description:
i'll start with the bathroom.  
the restroom facilities in this establishment are of particular note, as they are shared with a discothque in the rear.  it's relatively easy to distinguish between clientele of either establishment.  the club kids are usually shellacked in a thick high gloss coat of  LA lacquer.  
       don't go hear if you want a quiet, intimate, romantic eating environ.  the atmosphere is loud and chaotic but also warm and seductive.  it's an oblong chunk of brick fragmented by intermittent thick heavy braces of wood and steel.  i think it would be fair to classify this establishment as  gastropub.  
       i actually prefer the bar and the community table.  it it just feels right to rub shoulders a little at salthouse.  my favorite bartender is kevin costner's little brother.  (no one else believes me, but i looked in to this,  its true)  it takes very little or nonexistent persuasion to convince him to match his alcho-imbibement to your own.  logic has it that if he is engaging this practice with several other customers chances are he's drunker than you are.  (his performance never lags however)  the old cubano is excellent (sparkling wine /  rum / mint / lime / bitters / shaken and served up in a champagne flute)  but if you prefer something a little stiffer try the bitter widow (ketel one vodka / campari / sweet vermouth / stirred and served up)
       the food is super solid.  serious bang-for-your-buck coefficient on the fois gras. you get an ample portion of both sauteed and torchon for 19$.  the scallops are also excellent.  their poutine is out-fucking-standing.  i felt however that when i got to the last  four french fries i wanted one more tablespoon of gravy.  the starters are so good i have yet to make it past more cocktails than i planned on consuming and appetizers.
author: jacob m.

description: Why do I love this place?  Girl's night out for happy hour (at John Collins) and dinner at Salt House is a  MUST.  From the crispy shrimp to the yellowfin tuna to the foie gras as an appetizer you can not go wrong.  Pair it with the braised lamb shank with a glass (or two) of  pinat nior and it's like heaven.  Service is excellent.  Gotta love this joint.
author: Ezzie M.

description: Salt house always delivers for lunch and dinner.  Take what used to be an average American style dish anywhere else and add lots of great fresh ingredients and creativity and you have some of the best food in the city.  The staff compliments the food with a very nice and casual approach to customers.  For a light lunch try the crispy shrimp, or one of their signature sandwiches like the tuna melt or Rubin.  For dinner the pasta dishes and lamb are always good.  It is close to my office so I end up eating there a couple days a week and have never been disappointed.
author: J K.

description: I like Salt House even better than its sister restaurant, Town Hall.  The scallops appetizer and the sole were both excellent, and dessert was good, but not as good as the savory dishes.  We'll definitely be back again.
author: Lisa R.

description: Here's a reasonably good new San Fran place to dine: housed in an old printing press, this new Rosenthal brothers venture in SOMA produces good, relatively simple dishes, though to be precise, it's not quite a four but certainly better than a three. The room has the potential to be noisy, since there is little on the painted brick walls to dampen the sound. The tables are close but not on top of each other. There's a small full bar near the front. The bread (two pieces of an epi-baguette from Bay Bread) was presented ceremoniously wrapped in brown paper but wasn't warmed, a bit surprising for a restaurant at this price point. The beet salad was tossed with a not-too-overpowering horseradish-based dressing which complemented the earthy beets and the salmon well. The salt cod brandade, while tasty, was just warm, not piping hot and bit starchy. For entrees, we had the duck confit with huckleberries, a lovely combination of nicely done fruit concentrate and tender, moist duck. There was some kind of orangish paste under the duck that was too sweet and ill-defined. The steak was done nicely with cippollino onions and was of good (not great) quality. Overall, compared, say, to Delfina, a restaurant of similar goals, this one's not quite up there. But then again, the environment was more pleasant and there was no pomp or circumstance required to get a table a few days ahead of time. Service was competent and pleasant, and (nice touch) everyone said goodbye as we left.
author: Willis N.

description: I've now been to salt house a few times, for both dinner & lunch - I keep hoping it will get better.  No such luck.  I went for lunch with a friend yesterday and ordered the hamburger with onion rings - pretty standard, right?  I ordered it medium and it came out raw in the middle.  I would have asked them to cook it a little more, but since we'd already waited 1/2 an hour to get our food the first go around, I didn't think I'd have time to get my burger properly cooked and not make my boss wonder where the hell I'd been all that time.  Generally, I'd let it go, but I proceeded to get pretty sick all evening and into the night.  So, careful what you order in this place - I'd stick to Happy Hour!
author: Jocy W.

description: This is actually a response to the review posted by marin m.  I was also a diner at salt house on friday and her recollection of her behavior is misleading at best.  I didn't know salt house offered dinner and a show on friday night.  Every diner around her knows that wine splashed on her purse because she chose to stand up and scream at the table that did it.  This is pretty much a direct quote: "What the #@!*, it's a $500 purse from New York!"  After the owner, not the manager, came over and led her away to calm her down, she returned to her table and started yelling at the people again.  That is when the owner returned and asked her to leave.  Needless to say, management and staff made sure everyone else around was OK and had a good laugh with our table about the incident.  All around a great time, with professional staff and exceptional food. Thanks, Salt House.
author: sandra v.

description: Prior visits were very pleasant, however my latest visit was very mediocre.  I ordered the shrimp appetizer.  The shrimp were great, but should have been de-veined.  The green-bean salad was over dressed and salty.  I ordered the scallops for my entree. They weren't cleaned well, gritty and one was obviously burned with the most extremely burned part cut off.  One of the accompanying clams was also rancid and the whole dish was over salted.  For dessert, I tried the sticky bun which was wonderful and the mint - chocolate chip cake which was just okay.    I guess I "Salt" house is appropriate given my experience.
author: Christina F.

description: I hate to give this place only 2 stars because the food was good and the service even better BUT...  it was the noisiest restaurant I think even been to, save maybe for NOPA.  For that alone I would never go back...  Who likes to have to carry on a conversation in at near yelling levels?
author: Marty B.

description: I imagine many others write reviews long after the fact. After hating on yelpers for so long now, I have decided to join the melee. I went to Salt House for lunch a few Thursdays ago. We had reservations for 12:45, but showed up thirty minutes early. Quite unexpectedly we ran into the owner who knows my girlfriend and he made sure we were seated right away. I know that this cannot be expected by all, but it was a very pleasant surprise. Besides the "vip" treatment the food and service were on point. We shared the scallop ceviche and roasted beet salad. Scallops had no fishiness and were absolutely wonderful. For entrees my girlfriend had the duck confit, my mother the petrale sole, and I the burger with bleu cheese. The temperatures were perfect and nothing was in need of seasoning. Although we had no room for dessert we were celebrating a birthday and three were sent out. All were fantastic, but the one with chocolate mousse was my personal favorite. As far as ambiance is concerned I dig the pirate theme. The water pitchers and lighting are especially cool. Timing was on in all aspects. Highly recommend.
author: pax r.

description: Mediocre food, small menu with few choices, boring decor.  Definitely not my favorite.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Accompaniments can be amazing; in fact, better than the lead. We ordered 4 appetizers - crispy shrimp, dayboat scallops, asparagus with pork belly, and tagiatelle. Our drinks came out first and we were not impressed. Then the crispy shrimp and the tagiatelle. Way to turn things around. The salad that comes with the shrimp is fantastic. Better than the shrimp for sure. The tagiatelle was our favorite appetizer. The flavors were so rich and different from anything we had ever tasted, but had this been an entree, I would have given up after 5 bites and been upset for trying this place. Good in small amounts. The best part of the dayboat scallops were the sauces and sunchokes. Lastly, the asparagus, I could have gone without the pork. It was fatty and lacking flavor. Everything that was supposed to be showcased was not that great, but all the sides were fantastic. When you look at whole picture, it was a a good meal. Will definitely return.
author: Vanessa W.

description: in a nutshell - i really liked this place.  my dad and i went for dinner and had a great experience.  the interior of the restaurant is cool, with mismatched silverware and different chairs, and there's a little pirate feel as well, with the skulls on the water bottle and the don quixote painting on the back wall.  and the food was absolutely delicious.  i had the crispy shrimp starter, which came on a mountain of green beans with prosciutto and almonds and inspired intense envy from my dad across the table.  he really enjoyed his dungeness crab starter, but said he would go for the shrimp if he went back.  and for an entree i went with the halibut, which is served in a broth with shrimp, artichokes and turnips and was exactly what i wanted.  my dad had the duck confit and  could not stop raving about it - i tried a bite and agree with him, it's that good.  to cap off the meal we split the chocolate fudge bar - yum!  oh yeah, and i almost forgot about drinks!  great and great.  so to recap:  in a nutshell - i really liked this place :).
author: ali l.

description: i like free food.  i'm lucky i have a job that occasionally allows me to get taken out by folks to nice restaurants.  most nights i'd rather get home to my dog after a long day of slaving away for the man, but some nights the company and food make it a fair trade.  my salt house experience was definitely one of those nights.  the decor is awesome.  an old print house converted into a restaurant.  they even put out an old type set piece on top of your check.  lots of exposed metal, beams, brick etc. etc.  the service was excellent.  we got seated right away, our waiter made great recommendations and was very attentive (but not overly so).  saving the best for last....the food. yum yum.  for apps we had the pontine (who knew cheese fries could be so gourmet?), canadian oysters (nice to have these as an option rather than the same kumo's miyagi's etc. etc.).  my dinner was awesome.  i got the seafood stew which was delicate and lovely.  the flavors of the orange and aioli were excellent with the snap peas with the scallops, mussels and clams.  i think my dinner mates had the fishes and mumbled mmm noises while not stopping the fork to mouth action.  the wine list was great.  i highly recommend the sancerre.  dessert was okay, not the best i've had but definitely good.  it just wasn't on the same level as the rest of the meal.  maybe we just ordered the wrong things.  overall, salt house, you did me well.  now how to afford to come back when it's on my dime.
author: Ann F.

description: I had the crispy shrimp green bean salad and my friend had the burger. The crispy shrimp was exactly what I was hoping it would be, although there were a lot of green beans. I would order this again, but it would be the smaller plate with less green beans. May be they should mix in another type of veggie to mix it up a little bit. I liked the almonds and bacon pieces in it and loved the sauce. Almost perfect! My friend had the burger with onion rings. The rings are a little thin and the burger looked a little small. He ate them separately, but I would have totally put the rings on the burger. It would be good to add a little side salad or a few fries to the burger plate, but that's just my opinion. I would still be hungry after just the burger and fried onion shavings. Seriously, how low of a setting is their mandolin on? If you go, definitely get an appetizer or starter salad and you will be satisfied at the end of your meal.
author: Michelle M.

description: i went there tonight with jovanie,garcia, and adrienne to celebrate garcia's birthday that was in december yet we're celebrating it on the day of the chinese new years day parade in march. go figure. we went to the salt house,which i wasnt very excited about sinc ei had been to town hall and had NOT had a very good experience.id yelp about it but it happened before yelp and all i can remember is that my waiter was an old,odd homosexual (im gay so i can bag on others of my kind as long as i dont write a column for an asian daily newspaper that will incite others to hate old odd homosexuals)  and let me tell you,i was very pleasantly impressed with salt house. we got there about 20 minutes early and the place was slightly empty.it was quarter of 6. by the time we left ,the place was bangin'. in a good way. the bartender was very nice though apparently im one of the few to order a double 'waltzing matilda'. the bartender had to go to the basement to get a bigger glass for my drink though the hostess/bartender(i never caught her name,but im going to call her matilda because apparenly she created the drink and was thrilled that i was getting a double),Matilda,was very excited and told our bartender to make a triple so she could sample the concoction.im all about quality control so i completely understand and support it. its jack daniels,tia maria,a dn lemon and i had 2 double waltzing matildas. they were awesome,and that was just the beginning of our evening. i had to slow down since i was driving back over the bridge and i didnt want to be say gung hay fat choy in a hospital or the police station.i got the french fries with cheese and short rib gravy.i started clapping when the gravy was being poured over the fries at our table,startling the server.i am just appreciative. jovanie got the pork belly,which he just told me,half asleep next to me,was very good. adrienne had the crab and garcia got the yellowtail.im not a big fan of seafood but they told me it was really good,though adrienne told me shes going back next friday and just ordering 3 plates of fries and have at it.really,theyre that good. for a main course,i had the ribeye,which i had medium well,which was a big mistake becasue it was over cooked.i read kitchen confidential,and read that people who order their steak like that are just giving a free license to the chefs to cook the shit out of the meat,and thats exactly what happened to my rib eye.it had a good taste to it,so next time i'll order it medium rare. the fingerlng potatoes that came with it were delicious. adrienne got the chicken with chorizo potatoes.the potatoes were a little too spicy for me,but the chicken was moist and lemony. garcia got the cassoulet,which she said was very good and jovanie got some kind of thai fish dish,which he loved. we got the coconut pineapple ice cream cake and the walnut tart with the poasted banana ice cream.we got the tart on Matildas advice.she would stop by the table every 15 minutes or so and ask when i was going to have my 3rd drink. she really made us feel like we were being personally taken care of.matilda,i love you! she suggested the tart,which we all loved,and now im lying on my bed,full,sweating,sleepy,gay,yet still in love with a woman who create the waltzing matilda.
author: Jim M.

description: We had an extraordinary dining experience at Salt House.  The food, atmosphere, energy and crowd were all terrific but what really blew us away was their attitude towards service.  Apparently the restaurant had inadvertently overbooked a table of 4 which had been waiting for a while.  We were sitting at a table for two with an empty table for two next to us.  The Maitre d' offered us an "indecent proposal" and after explaining the situation he asked if we would be willing to switch to a different table after our appetizer so that he could accommodate the waiting customers and offered to comp our dinner, a very generous gesture.  Moving tables was no trouble and not only was our meal on the house but he graciously added an extra desert.   That level of generosity was unexpected and unnecessary but really made an impression about their attitude toward customer service and customer satisfaction.
author: Paul R.

description: went there last friday w/another couple.  845 reservations. got seated at 940. they comp'd a round i think.  the specialty drinks--nothing special. the grapefruit one was too bitter and they didn't even have it on the first round.   the foie gras torchon was good but the liver was average. i'm a big foie gras fan.  the tuna dish had nice flavors. service was great. except for being seated an hour late but that happens sometimes.  great design--really like the floating second story.
author: Yelper S.

description: As a huge fan of Mitch and Steven Rosenthal (Postrio and Town Hall are two of my favorite restaurants) I was really excited to try Salt House. I went last night with a good friend, both of us coming straight from the office. For a Wednesday night it was PACKED and the atmosphere is great- a really awesome space. We had a reservation for 8:30 and didn't get seated until almost 9:00, which was kind of annoying. Our server was rushed and spacey, but I didn't mind too much because she was attentive when she needed to be. We shared a bottle of the house white, which came in a very cool retro glass bottle, and loved the water carafe in the old milk bottle too. Based on yelp reviews, I started with the crispy shrimp and green bean salad, which was AMAZING. A truly perfect appetizer. I followed it with another appetizer, the yellowtail, which was sashimi-style over a cucumber broth. It was interesting and delicious. My friend had the chicken and loved it. However, we shared the cookie plate for dessert- which was not very good at all. A plate of so-so cookies for 8.5 dollars. I would NOT recommend it to anyone. Anyway, overall a really yummy dinner and I will definitely go back, even though I do have to say that I still like Town Hall more.
author: Emily B.

description: Everything seemed to be perfect until the last minute....there was a small piece of plastic inside of my chocolate cake and it's got stacked in my throat. I gently announced the news to my waitress and she apologized and said that she would inform to her manager. I expected the manager would come to our table for apology or I would get a new cake since I really wanted to eat the chocolate cake. Things happen, so I was not upset but I was so disappointed at their service. Nothing happened, just my cake wasn't charged. It's not about money at all, so I would rather see how well the restaurant treats their customers. That's only one thing. Second, I had fresh raw oysters and apparently the oyster weren't fresh enough that I've got rash on my upper chest and back. I grew up eating raw oysters and I've never had any problem in my life. It was my first time to react such and I felt horrible. My rash got better by now but my whole experience at Salt House was unforgettable. I would never dine in again.
author: Kayo A.

description: arrived a little early for our reservation and the hostess was exceptionally nice and offered to seat me, despite lacking my three guests.  i sat at the table and waited for the rest of the party.  when i asked about any suggestions from the wine list, divided into "old world" and "new world" suggestions, i got a very high brow snooty response.  instead of steering me toward one  of her favorites or one of the house recommendations, i got a "well that totally depends on what you like"... and with that she walked away.  after we were seated, things deteriorated.  she left us there for quite some time with no drinks, then took our drink order and we had to remind her 15 minutes later we were still waiting for a margarita.  then we ordered some starters and then some appetizers.  the appetizers came first and after we finished those, she realized she never brought the starters.  then we cancelled the starters and waited for our entrees.  the entrees arrived and the food was good.  but certainly nothing spectacular.  then she brought over a dish of the roasted nuts starters that she had forgotten and said "we decided that you really need to have these, as they are so good".... AND SHE PUT THEM ON OUR BILL!!!  we had a good laugh at her rudeness and left her just 15%.  for a $400 meal, her service was absolutely abysmal.  never again.  not even if i read another 100 great reviews of the place.
author: kara p.
